Slide 1: Introduction Patient X  a 60-year-old caucasian male with a past medical history of intravenous drug use  uncontrolled Type II diabetes  and periodontal disease  presents with symptoms consistent with native-valve infective endocarditis.  Slide 2: Demographics According to literature  infective endocarditis has a male predominance and is typically seen in patients aged 30 to 60. Our patient falls squarely within this range. Furthermore  Caucasians have been reported to be more susceptible  though incidence in other races remains significant.  Slide 3: Relevant Medical History - Intravenous Drug Use: Patient X reports a history of intravenous drug use  a well-known risk factor for infective endocarditis due to frequent injection that provides potential entry points for bacteria into the bloodstream.  - Type II Diabetes: Patient X's uncontrolled diabetes may be associated with an increased risk due to poor vascular health and longer healing times for wounds.  - Periodontal Disease: Poor oral health  such as the patient's periodontal disease  is a recognized source of bacteremia  increasing the risk for infective endocarditis. Regular flossing and dental check-ups are encouraged.  Slide 4: Current Presentation  Patient X presents today with symptoms of fever  chills  night sweats  weight loss  and a new heart murmur that were observed for the past two weeks. These signs and symptoms are clinically consistent with infective endocarditis albeit nonspecific.  Slide 5: Diagnosis and Next Steps Further assessment is needed for diagnosis confirmation of native valve endocarditis. This will include blood cultures and an echocardiogram. Additional treatment will be guided by the etiology and susceptibility profile of the organism and may necessitate prolonged antibiotic therapy. Recommendations will also extend to management of his diabetes and periodontal condition to reduce future risk.

Presentation Title: An Overview of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Introduction: Today  I'd like to present a case of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Patient Profile: Our patient is a 56-year-old Caucasian male  considering that the condition most notably affects those between the ages of 50 and 70 and is intended to be more common in men than women. The patient is unmarried  lives alone  and has a history of intravenous drug use  a well-documented risk factor for infective endocarditis.  Medical History: The patient has a significant medical history which includes type 2 diabetes and hypertension. The patient is known to have poor control over his blood sugar levels and blood pressure  despite prescribed medications. He comes from a low socio-economic background  with limited access to regular and comprehensive healthcare due to lack of insurance.   He has previously been admitted to hospital for pneumonia and has undergone treatment for hepatitis C  presumably from his intravenous drug use. His dental health is poor with signs of untreated dental caries which can act as a source of bacterial inoculum leading to infective endocarditis. The patient does not have any history of rheumatic heart disease but reports frequent episodes of unexplained fever during the past year.   Recent Clinical Presentation: In the recent admission  the patient presented to the Emergency Department with high-grade fever  weight loss  night sweats  and fatigue. He has been experiencing these symptoms for a few weeks but did not consider them serious. During the examination  Osborne's sign  and Janeway lesions were noticed  both indicative of infective endocarditis. A foster murmur was heard on auscultation which was not previously documented and there was evidence of mild splenomegaly.  Investigations have been initiated including blood cultures and an echocardiogram to confirm the diagnosis.   In Conclusion: This case features a typical presentation of native-valve infective endocarditis in a high-risk patient due to intravenous drug use  poor dental health  and the existence of underlying co-morbidities. This highlights the criticality of early recognition of symptoms and prompt  targeted treatment to optimize patient outcomes. The ongoing management will include long-term antimicrobial therapy and addressing the underlying risk factors.

Slide 1: Introduction  Title: Case Presentation: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Slide 2: Patient Demographics  Title: Patient Information  - Age: 58 years old  - Gender: Male  - Race: Caucasian (Referencing literature  infective endocarditis has a higher prevalence among Caucasians. However  its incidence may vary based on geographical region and access to healthcare services.)  - Occupation: Plumber  Slide 3: Medical History  Title: Past Medical History  - Diagnosed with Rheumatic Heart Disease in teenage years  - Moderate aortic valve insufficiency  - Hyperlipidemia  - Mild Hypertension  - Discontinued intravenous drug use 20 years ago  Slide 4: Current Presentation  Title: Symptom Profile   - New onset heart murmurs detected during recent check-up  - Persistent  low-grade fever for the past 3 weeks  - Decreased appetite  - Unintentional weight loss  - General fatigue  - Chills and night sweats  Slide 5: Initial Diagnosis and Investigation  Title: Suspected Disease & Tests  - Based on symptoms  medical history  and physical examination  suspected diagnosis: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  - Tests ordered: Blood cultures  Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE)  CBC  ESR  CRP  Slide 6: Literature Insights  Title: Endocarditis & Demographics According to literature  males are more likely to develop infective endocarditis with a ratio of 1.7:1 (male:female)  and the disease is commonly found among individuals aged 30-60 years. The association with past intravenous drug use  existence of aortic valve insufficiency  and the patient's age group align well with the typical demographic representation.  (Note: Please remember that this is a general presentation and the risk factors  presentation  and demographics can differ between populations and patients  and not all patients will present in the same way.)

Title: Native-valve Infective Endocarditis: A Case Presentation   Patient Presentation:  Mr. Douglas is a 60-year-old Caucasian male  with a history of tobacco use and diagnosed with bioprosthetic aortic valve replacement due to severe aortic stenosis 2 years ago. He presents today with a two-week history of intermittent fever  general malaise  shortness of breath  and unexplained weight loss. He denies any recent dental procedures or intravenous drug use.   Demographics:  Statistically  native valve infective endocarditis (NVIE) is predominantly seen between age 50 and 70 years  and is more common in men. According to the literature  Caucasian patients  like Mr. Douglas  have the highest incidence of NVIE among different races.   Past Medical History:  In addition to his aortic stenosis  Mr. Douglas has a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He underwent coronary artery stent placement 5 years ago  due to ischemic heart disease. He has had an array of pharmacological treatments related to his various conditions  including metformin  ramipril  and simvastatin. He has a 45-pack year history of smoking but has not cut down significantly after his coronary artery disease diagnosis.   Analysis:  Mr. Douglas's profile fits with those most likely affected by NVIE. His past medical history puts him at increased risk  given the long-standing heart disease  presence of the bioprosthetic aortic valve  and poor general health status due to diabetes  COPD  and tobacco use. All these comorbidities further elevate his risk of developing NVIE.   Given the prolonged febrile illness and his past medical history  a suspicion of NVIE is reasonable in this case. Further investigations  including echocardiograms and multiple blood cultures  are advisable to ascertain the diagnosis.  References:  1. Cahill TJ  Baddour LM  Habib G  et al. Challenges in Infective Endocarditis. Journal of the American College of Cardiology. 2017; 69(3): 325-344.  2. Slipczuk L  Codolosa JN  Davila CD  et al. Infective endocarditis epidemiology over five decades: a systematic review. PLoS One. 2013;8(12):e82665.     3. Tleyjeh IM  Abdel-Latif A  Rahbi H  et al. A systematic review of population-based studies of infective endocarditis. Chest. 2007;132(3):1025-1035.

Title: A Case Presentation: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  I. Patient Information Our patient  referred to as Mr. White for confidentiality  is a 63-year-old Caucasian male from an urban town in the Midwest. He's a retired construction worker  currently living with his wife  and has a history of occasional alcohol use. No known drug abuse or tobacco use was reported.  II. Medical History Mr. White has a significant medical history  including a diagnosis of Type-II Diabetes  which he has managed with Metformin and lifestyle modifications for the past ten years. Other significant diagnoses include hypertension and hyperlipidemia  managed with Lisinopril and Atorvastatin  respectively. He has no previous history of valvular disorders or previous valve replacement  nor does he have any known allergies to medications.  III. Present Illness Mr. White presented with a two-week history of intermittent fevers  night sweats  unexplained weight loss  and a new heart murmur detected during initial physical examination. The heart murmur is consistent with native-valve endocarditis. A peripheral blood culture tested positive for Staphylococcus aureus  making infective endocarditis more likely.  Concurrently  he complained of weakness in the left side of his body coupled with difficulty speaking and understanding  indicative of a neurological event possibly linked to embolic phenomena secondary to endocarditis.  IV. Diagnosis and Management Based on his clinical signs and symptoms  positive blood cultures  presence of a new heart murmur  and the evidence of neurological involvement  a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis was made.   Mr. White was started on appropriate antibiotic therapy based on his blood culture sensitivity results. A transesophageal echocardiogram was ordered to visualize the heart valves and chambers and confirm the diagnosis. This is essential as the patient is at high risk of complications including stroke  heart failure  and other systemic embolisms due to his condition. Further management will be determined by the results of these tests and consultations with cardiology  infectious diseases  and possibly neurology teams.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Introduction  Meet Mr. John Johnson  a 65-year-old Caucasian male presenting with several weeks of feeling unwell  characterized by fever  general weakness  abnormal weight loss  and night sweats. Mr. Johnson was a resident of San Francisco and worked as a marine engineer before his retirement. He's married  a non-smoker  and drinks alcohol only occasionally. As a veteran  he has medical insurance coverage.  Teeth and Oral Care  Mr. Johnson hasn't been to a dentist in five years due to fear and neglect. He has a history of poor oral hygiene and has several untreated cavities. It is highly likely that the native-valve infective endocarditis (NVIE) originated from his untreated oral infectious foci.  DM and Cardiac History  Mr. Johnson has been managing type II diabetes for the past fifteen years. He's been on metformin and currently has good glycemic control. He has a ten-year history of hypertension controlled by lisinopril and atenolol  and also a three-year history of asymptomatic ischemic heart disease.  The interplay of his comorbidities such as diabetes and ischemic heart disease with poor oral hygiene puts him at increased risk of developing NVIE.  Relevant Lifestyle Factors   He enjoys occasional fishing and boat rides with his friends  which might indirectly increase his exposure to certain microorganisms. Mr. Johnson has no history of IV drug use  and has no tattoos or piercings.  Current Symptoms   He came to the emergency department complaining primarily of fever of unknown origin  night sweats  and unintentional weight loss. On physical examination  there are signs of peripheral embolism  including splinter hemorrhages  Janeway lesions on palms and soles  and Osler's nodes. Heart examination reveals a new murmur  suggestive of valve involvement.  With the triad of fever  new heart murmur  and peripheral manifestations of endocarditis  he was immediately admitted to the hospital and blood cultures were drawn. He's now on empiric antibiotics while awaiting the definitive diagnosis.  Conclusion   Mr. Johnson's case indicates that the demographic shift in endocarditis incidence over recent years is real  with the disease increasingly affecting older males with long-standing comorbidities. It underlines the need for proactive preventative measures such as routine dental care and general health check-ups  particularly in those with established risk factors for endocarditis.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-aged Caucasian Male with Diabetes Mellitus  Demographics: The patient is a 56-year-old Caucasian male who works as a welder. He lives in rural Pennsylvania and is of a middle class socioeconomic status. He is a current smoker with a 30 pack-year history. He has a history of intravenous drug use  which he quit 20 years ago. The patient does not consume alcohol and has no known allergies. He lives with his wife and two adult children.  Past Medical History: The patient has a ten-year history of poorly controlled Type II diabetes mellitus and has been non-compliant with prescribed oral hypoglycemic medications. He also has a history of peripheral artery disease  dating back 5 years and managed conservatively up to date. There is no known family history of cardiovascular or infectious diseases. The patient had a severe skin infection 4 years ago that required intravenous antibiotics  likely associated with a MRSA infection in his lower left leg.   Presenting Symptoms: The patient presented with a 2-week history of low-grade fever  unexplained weight loss  and generalized malaise. He reported experiencing night sweats  an increasingly persistent dry cough  and occasional chest discomfort over that same period.   Based on these symptoms  our working diagnosis is native-valve infective endocarditis  likely originating from the poor glycemic control or the past history of skin infection. Further investigation  including an echocardiogram and blood cultures  are needed to confirm the diagnosis and identify the causative organism.  Representation in Literature: According to literature  the typical patient diagnosed with infective endocarditis (IE) is male (70%) of a median age of 58 years. Caucasians represent 78.2% of IE cases in the United States. Diabetes is a well-documented risk factor for IE  as is a history of smoking and previous valvular or other heart diseases. Native valve IE is typically seen in patients with risk factors like immunosuppression  insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus  or the elderly. Intravenous drug use is a significant historical risk factor associated with native valve IE.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Presentation: Mr. John Smith is a 62-year-old Caucasian male who presented with a two-week history of persistent fever  nocturnal sweats  and unintentional weight loss. Born and residing in upstate New York  Mr. Smith has a history of smoking  specifically a 20 pack-year smoking history  but quit 10 years ago. His alcohol consumption is moderate  at 1-2 drinks per week. He has a sedentary lifestyle due to his occupation as an administrative manager. He has a known hypertensive disease  diagnosed seven years ago  and high cholesterol  diagnosed three years ago  both of which are managed with antihypertensive and antilipemic drugs  respectively.   His past medical history includes a diagnosis of dental caries  for which he underwent dental extraction two months ago. He also has a history of gout treated with colchicine. He does not have a known history of intravenous drug use  heart valve disease  or rheumatic heart disease. Genetic history indicates his father died at 67 of a myocardial infarction  and his mother is still alive at 88 with Alzheimer's disease.   His current ailments started with fatigue following the recent dental extraction but then progressed into persistent fever and night sweats. A recent development was the appearance of small  painful nodules on the pads of his fingers and toes. He also reports mild occasional chest discomfort without any specific pattern or activity associated with it. He denies shortness of breath  orthopnea  or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea.    Due to these signs and symptoms and given his recent dental procedure  a suspicion of native valve infective endocarditis might be considered. Based on the IDC-10 diagnostic procedure  Mr. Smith's case appears to accord with the I33.0 code  signifying Acute and subacute infective endocarditis. Further investigations and echocardiographic studies will be carried out to finalize the diagnosis. Appropriate antimicrobial therapy will be initiated if the diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis is confirmed.   The aim of presenting this case is to highlight the importance of considering infective endocarditis among older adults presenting with non-specific symptoms such as persistent fever and weight loss  specifically following invasive procedures  like dental extractions.

Slide 1: Introduction  Title: A Case Presentation of Native Valve Infective Endocarditis   Slide 2: Patient Demographics  Our patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male. Professionally  he is retired and has a history of intravenous drug use  specifically he reported using intravenous heroin approximately 20 years ago. He lives with his elderly mother and has a supportive community around him. His sexual history reported to be heterosexual  nonsmoker  and he denies regular alcohol consumption.  Slide 3: Past Medical History   The patient has a known past medical history of uncontrolled Type-2 diabetes mellitus  moderate to severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  and congestive heart failure. He has had a dental abscess 2 months ago which was treated with oral antibiotics. The patient has a known allergy to penicillin. He underwent a rheumatic heart disease surgery in his 30s.  Slide 4: Clinical Presentation  The patient complains of intermittent fever  night sweats  fatigue  mild shortness of breath  and weight loss occurring over the past three weeks. Upon examination  he is febrile with temperature of 38.5 C  heart rate of 102 beats/minute  and blood pressure of 120/80 mmHg. A heart murmur was noted on cardiovascular system examination.  Slide 5: Conclusion  Given the patient’s symptoms and signs  a diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis is suspected. The presence of predisposing factors such as his past intravenous drug use  dental infection  and rheumatic heart disease surgery makes this increasingly likely. Further investigations including blood cultures and echocardiogram are now necessary to confirm the diagnosis and guide appropriate management.   Note: It is recognized that these demographic characteristics do not represent every patient with native valve infective endocarditis. The choice was made based on the most commonly affected population in literature. Other populations can equally be affected  making it crucial to maintain vigilance in assessing symptoms and risk factors.  Reference: Fowler  Vance G.  et al. ""Staphylococcus aureus endocarditis: a consequence of medical progress."" JAMA 293.24 (2005): 3012-3021.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis: A Case Presentation  Patient Profile: Patient is a 67 year-old Caucasian male presenting with complaints of fever  fatigue  shortness of breath  and night sweats persisting for the past month. He has medical history of poor dental health  specifically untreated dental caries  and chronic hypertension  for which he takes medication. The patient has a history of smoking  about a half pack per day for the past 40 years  but has no history of IV drug use or alcoholism.   Medical History: Past medical history includes chronic hypertension managed with Lisinopril  and hypercholesterolemia managed with Atorvastatin. The patient has not had any surgical procedures in the past. He did have a dental procedure about two months ago and has been complaining of toothache since then but has not sought further dental treatment.   Literature Review: According to the research  this patient profile regards a typical demographic for native valve infective endocarditis. A study in the New England Journal of Medicine found that the average age for presentation of infective endocarditis was around 61 years. Despite the common belief that this condition is restricted to intravenous drug users  many research findings  including a study in PLOS ONE  have suggested poor dental health as a significant risk factor in non-IV drug users  as in the present case. Further  the European Heart Journal concludes from their study that males are more likely to acquire infective endocarditis than females.   This case's demographics indicate a need for early identification of infective endocarditis  given the presence of reliable risk factors: advanced age  male sex  poor oral health  and chronic heart disease. Prompt evaluation and management may help reduce the risk of severe complications such as heart failure or stroke.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 61-year-old Caucasian female  presenting to the clinic with ongoing fatigue  intermittent fevers  night sweat  and unintentional weight loss. She also reports a recent change in the nature of a pre-existing heart murmur that was diagnosed incidentally two years ago.  Past Medical History:  In terms of her past medical history  she has been previously diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension which are being managed with Metformin and Lisinopril respectively. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She has no history of IV drug abuse. Her family history includes Hypertensive Heart Disease on her father's side.   Recent Hospital Admission:  Patient had a dental procedure performed six weeks ago during which she received prophylactic antibiotic treatment. But soon after the procedure  she started to experience these vague symptoms of fatigue  low-grade fevers and dramatic weight loss.  Considering her age  ethnicity  gender  pre-existing heart murmur  and recent dental procedure leading to bacteremia  she is at a moderate risk for Native Valve Infective Endocarditis (IE).   Statistics:  Since the incidence of Native Valve IE is increasing in people older than 60  and the disease distribution typically skewed towards Caucasians and males  this case is slightly less conventional but still maintains clinical relevance. Although males are more commonly affected  women comprise about one-third of patients with IE  which is significantly higher than previous decades and particularly notable in older age groups.   Her past medical history of Diabetes might contribute to her slightly elevated risk  especially if her glycemic control has been suboptimal. Likewise  Hypertension can contribute to endothelial damage  making her susceptible to bacterial invasion.  Thus  the patient's symptoms  medical history  and recent dental procedure  compounded by the change in her heart murmur  suggest a high suspicion for Native Valve IE  which necessitates immediate investigation and management to prevent severe complications like heart failure or systemic embolization.   In conclusion  her case epitomizes the growing incidence and changing epidemiology of Native Valve IE  highlighting the importance of considering this diagnosis in similar clinical scenarios.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Information: Patient X is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the hospital complaining of persistent fever  malaise  night sweats  weight loss  and occasional breathlessness for the past few weeks.  Past Medical History: The patient has a documented past medical history of Stage II Heart Failure that was diagnosed four years ago. He has been prescribed medication and has been regularly following up with his cardiologist. Other comorbidities include type II diabetes and hypertension  both of which have been managed with oral hypoglycemic and anti-hypertensive medication respectively. He is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago  and is a moderate consumer of alcohol.  Clinical Examination: On physical examination  the patient was found to have a new systolic murmur  along with shortness of breath on exertion. His temperature was 38.6° C. Examination of his extremities revealed the presence of Janeway lesions and Osler's nodes  both classic signs of endocarditis. During his eye examination  Roth's spots were also noticed.  Diagnosis: Based on the presenting symptoms  namely persistent fever  new murmurs on auscultation  and various septic phenomena  along with the patient's previous history of heart failure  the suspicion of Native Valve Infective Endocarditis (NVIE) was raised. Further laboratory tests and Echocardiographic findings will be required to confirm the diagnosis.  Demographics: NVIE has been observed regularly in older patients  often over 60 years old  and is more common among males in comparison to females  according to the literature. It has also been shown to be more dominant among the Caucasian population.  Associated Risks: Patient X's heart failure exacerbates his risk for NVIE. Furthermore  his history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension may negatively influence the prognosis and potentially increase the complication rate due to endocarditis.  In Conclusion: The patient's demographics  medical history  and current symptoms align with those often seen in cases of NVIE. However  further diagnostic tests must be performed to confirm the diagnosis and to guide subsequent therapeutic decisions.

Title: A Case Presentation on Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 48-year-old Caucasian male  who is a known intravenous drug user  presenting to the hospital with complaints of persistent high-grade fever  malaise  chills  night sweats  and unintentional weight loss over the past two weeks. Associated symptoms include a new heart murmur and skin lesions that resemble petechiae and Janeway lesions on his palms and soles.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a known significant history of injecting heroin for the past 15-20 years. He has been diagnosed with previous episodes of cellulitis and a history of Hepatitis C  likely attributed to his intravenous drug use. He denies any history of HIV or other immunocompromising conditions. He has no known allergies and is not currently on any medications.  The prevalence of infective endocarditis is higher in individuals with a history of intravenous drug use  like Mr. Smith. Furthermore  in recent literature  infective endocarditis affecting native valves have been associated more often with men and Caucasians have been overrepresented among patients. Moreover  the age group of 30-60 years has been shown to have the highest incidence.  In conclusion  Mr. Smith's demographic and past medical history put him at a high risk for native-valve infective endocarditis. His symptoms and signs further increase our suspicion of this potentially life-threatening condition. Immediate diagnostics to confirm the diagnosis and timely treatment initiation is crucial to prevent further cardiac damage and systemic complications.

Title: A Case presentation on Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male  as this demographics appears to be the most commonly affected by infective endocarditis according to the literature. His occupation is a farmer  a profession that places him at risk for exposure to potential infection-causing agents.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a significant medical history of intravenous drug use  dating back to his late 20s. Substance abuse is known to significantly increase the risk of developing infective endocarditis. Additionally  he was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease in his early 50s. His diabetes is reasonably managed with Metformin  and he uses a corticosteroid inhaler for his COPD. Furthermore  there is a three-year history of untreated dental caries  a common predisposing factor for oral flora-related endocarditis.   Family History:  His father died of a heart attack at the age of 75  and his mother suffocates from chronic pulmonary diseases at the age of 68.   Social History:  The patient is a chronic heavy smoker  with a history of consuming one pack of cigarettes per day for the last 35 years. He admits to current alcohol and intravenous drug abuse. He lives alone in a rural area and has minimal social interaction.  Clinical Presentation:  The patient presents with a two-week history of persistent  high-grade fever  rigors  night sweats  unintended weight loss  and generalized fatigue. Four days ago  he notices multiple small  painless red spots on his palms and soles (Janeway lesions). On closer examination  there are hemorrhagic lesions in the retina  known as Roth's spots.   Clinical diagnosis was confirmed to be Native Valve Infective Endocarditis using the Duke Criteria due to the presence of major criteria: positive blood cultures and evidence of endocardial involvement as indicated by the manifestation of Roth's spots and Janeway lesions.   In conclusion  this case stands as a reminder of the potential severity of infective endocarditis  particularly within high-risk populations such as intravenous drug users. It highlights the necessity for early diagnosis and appropriate management to prevent mortality and morbidity.

Patient Presentation  Mr. Smith is a 62-year-old Caucasian male who presents with a three-week history of fever  weight loss  and malaise. He also describes experiencing night sweats and mild chest pain  particularly on deep inspiration. His wife notes that he has become increasingly short of breath even with minimal activity.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which have been managed by oral medication for over a decade. Mr. Smith is a retired schoolteacher and denies any tobacco  alcohol  or illicit drug use. He admits to infrequent dental check-ups despite poor oral hygiene.  Upon physical examination  Mr. Smith appears chronically ill. His vital signs indicate a low-grade fever of 37.8°C and a heart rate of 95 beats per minute. Cardiac auscultation reveals a new-onset heart murmur. Further examination of his skin exposes petechial lesions on his palms and soles.  Blood cultures have been taken and empiric antibiotic therapy considered in light of the suspicion for native-valve infective endocarditis. This correlates with Mr. Smith's demographic  which is found in literature as infective endocarditis patients commonly involve older adults  particularly male persons  with preexisting heart conditions. The presence of poor oral hygiene is also a known risk factor. The ongoing investigation includes an echocardiogram to identify any vegetations and to also assess the severity of the newly discovered heart murmurs.  Conclusion: The patient's clinical manifestation and demographic representation align with the typical patient profile for native-valve infective endocarditis. This case underlines the importance of regular dental check-ups  especially for individuals with co-morbidities  to prevent possible systemic infection that may result in serious complications  such as infective endocarditis.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Profile: Mr. Moore  a 62-year-old Caucasian male  hails from an urban  middle-income demographic and is self-employed.  Chief Complaint: Mr. Moore presents with the chief complaint of ongoing intermittent fever for the past two weeks. He has also recently noted weight loss  fatigue  and night sweats.  Present Illness: Over the course of the aforementioned period  Mr. Moore states that he has been experiencing increased shortness of breath with mild day time activities. He also experiences mild chest discomfort  lightheadedness  and reports bouts of confusion recently. His fever has been low-grade but persistent  responding initially to over-the-counter antipyretics but returning within a few hours.  Past Medical History: Past medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension for the last 10 years  both well controlled with metformin  lisinopril  and amlodipine. He is a former smoker with a 20-pack year history and quit smoking around 5 years ago.  Surgical History: Mr. Moore underwent appendectomy at age 22  and there were no post-operative complications noted.  Family History: His father had coronary artery disease and his mother had hypertension. His sister  age 58 has recently been diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus.  Social History: Mr. Moore lives with his wife and has no children. He reports occasional alcohol consumption on social occasions only. He has not travelled recently and denies any known drug allergies or use of illicit drugs.  Physical Examination: On physical examination  Mr. Moore appears fatigued and is in moderate distress due to dyspnea. His vital signs demonstrate a fever of 100.9°F  blood pressure of 145/95 mmHg  pulse rate at 100 BPM  and respiratory rate of 22 BPM. Cardiovascular examination reveals a diastolic murmur heard best at the apex.  This presentation is consistent with Native-valve infective endocarditis. However  confirmatory tests such as blood cultures  echocardiograms  or other forms of imaging may be necessary for a definitive diagnosis.     References:   Baddour L  Wilson W  Bayer A  et al. Infective Endocarditis in Adults: Diagnosis  Antimicrobial Therapy  and Management of Complications: A Scientific Statement for Healthcare Professionals From the American Heart Association. Circulation. 2015;132(15):1435–1486.

Title: Presentation of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in Elderly Male Patient  Patient's Profile: The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  who presents with a two-week history of fever  fatigue  and shortness of breath. He hails from a semi-urban community in Florida  USA  and lives with his wife.   Past Medical History: The patient has a documented history of rheumatic heart disease from his early twenties  for which he regularly takes prescribed medications. He was overweight  with a body mass index (BMI) of 27 (height: 6 feet; weight: 200 lbs)  but otherwise had been in good health until this time. He has been treated for hypertension for the last ten years and has been a non-smoker for more than thirty years.  Clinical Presentation: Upon examination  the patient appeared sick and fatigued. His vitals recorded at presentation showed a fever of 38.5°C  blood pressure of 135/90 mmHg  a heart rate of 110 beats per minute  and a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. Cardiac exam revealed a new murmur suggestive of valvular abnormality.   Initial investigations showed signs of inflammation with an elevated white cell count of 14 000/mm³ (reference range: 4 000-11 000/mm³) and an unusually high erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 80 mm/hr (reference range: 0-22 mm/hr)  indicative of an ongoing infectious process. Initial blood cultures are pending.  The patient's symptoms  signs on examination  and initial investigations suggest a diagnosis of infective endocarditis  affecting his native heart valves  most likely secondary to his history of rheumatic heart disease. Further diagnostic procedures  like an echocardiogram  along with consultation with an infectious disease specialist  have been ordered to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment.   Maintaining an awareness of the higher risk of infective endocarditis in patients with pre-existing heart conditions  especially in older adults  is essential for early detection and prompt treatment.

Title: A Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Profile: Patient is a 50-year-old Caucasian male named John Doe. Mr. Doe is a retail manager residing in Dayton  Ohio. He lives with his wife and two teenage children. He drinks socially and denies tobacco or drug use. Mr. Doe has a history of moderate physical activity and is slightly overweight with a BMI of 27. He reports having a balanced diet but has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  both controlled with medication.  Past Medical History:  John Doe maintains regular follow-ups with his primary care physician and endocrinologist to manage his type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and hypertension. He has been on Metformin 500mg BD and Lisinopril 20mg daily. His last HbA1c was 7.1% and Blood pressure was 134/89 mmHg. He has no known allergies. Mr. Doe had a dental procedure approximately three weeks ago. He also maintains regular dental check-ups.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient presented to the emergency department with a week-long history of low-grade fever  chills  malaise  and unexplained weight loss. On further questioning  he mentions experiencing night sweats and mild shortness of breath for the past few days. There is a faint rash on his lower limbs that he hadn’t noticed before. He denies any chest pain or cough.   Conclusion: Considering his recent dental procedure  persistent fever  possible septicemia symptoms  and new symptoms of heart failure like shortness of breath  an infective endocarditis of the native valve raises suspicion. Further investigations including blood culture  an echocardiogram  and potentially cardiac CT are warranted to confirm this suspicion and to plan out the best management strategies.

Title: Presentation of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-aged Male Patient   Patient Demographic Information: Our patient is a 55-year-old Caucasian male  who works as a construction worker. The patient is a smoker with a 30-pack year history and consumes alcohol socially. He does not report any illicit drug use. He has no known environmental allergens and no noted allergies to medications.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus type II and hypertension. He is on Metformin and Lisinopril for the same. The patient has no past surgical history and no family history of cardiac diseases.  Presenting symptoms: The patient was brought to the emergency department with complaints of high fever with chills  fatigue  weight loss  night sweats  and a new-onset heart murmur. The fever has been ongoing for around 3 weeks. He also noted an unintentional loss of weight and has been feeling excessively tired.   Examination: On physical examination  the patient has petechiae on his conjunctiva and a previously undocumented systolic murmur. His fingers exhibited signs of clubbing and Janeway lesions were noticed on the palms and soles.  Assessment: Considering the patient’s ongoing fever  new murmur  visible vascular phenomena  and risk factors such as diabetes  the initial suspicion is native-valve infective endocarditis. The patient’s occupational exposure to dust and particles as a construction worker may also contribute to the risk. More confirmatory tests including blood cultures and echocardiogram are recommended.   Disclaimer: This presentation has fictional elements for the demonstration of a typical case of native-valve infective endocarditis. In clinical practice  each patient will exhibit unique symptoms and risk factors.   References: 1. Murdoch DR  Corey GR  Hoen B  et al. Clinical presentation  etiology  and outcome of infective endocarditis in the 21st century: the International Collaboration on Endocarditis-Prospective Cohort Study. Arch Intern Med. 2009;169(5):463-473. 2. Holland TL  Baddour LM  Bayer AS  et al. Infective Endocarditis. Nat Rev Dis Primers. 2016;2:16059. 3. Kourany WM  Miro JM  Moreno A  et al. Influence of diabetes mellitus on the clinical manifestations and prognosis of infective endocarditis: a report from the International Collaboration on Endocarditis-Merged Database. Scand J Infect Dis. 2006;38(8):613-619.

Patient Presentation:   The patient is a 45-year-old Caucasian male  presenting to the hospital with complaints of persistent fatigue  persistent fever  chills  and a new cardiac murmur diagnosed by his general practitioner. He also expresses some discomfort in the chest area towards the heart. Patient reports unintentional weight loss over the past month but denied recent travel or IV drug use during his history collection.  Past Medical History:   The patient has a past medical history of congenital heart disease but no documented prior history of using injected drugs  HIV  or immunosuppressive disorders. He had a dental procedure performed several weeks ago but did not receive any antibiotic prophylaxis. He has no known allergies and takes no regular medication.  Relevant Demographic Information:   Native-valve infective endocarditis (NVIE) can affect individuals of all age groups but it commonly affects those aged around 30 to 60 years and is more prevalent in males. Literature suggests that Caucasians have a slightly increased risk of NVIE compared to other racial or ethnic groups. Individuals with pre-existing cardiac conditions like our patient  particularly chronic rheumatic heart disease  which is highly prevalent in this age group  can also increase the risk of NVIE. Dental procedures without appropriate antibiotic prophylaxis are known to provide a portal of entry for bacterial infection which often precedes the development of NVIE.  Making a clear and early diagnosis of NVIE in this patient is crucial  as this will inform appropriate treatment modalities and improve prognosis. Further diagnostic workup  including blood cultures  echocardiography  and complete CBC count  would be warranted.

Patient Presentation  Patient Details: The patient is Mr. Johnson  a 60-year-old African American male with a Sedentary lifestyle.  Presenting Issue: He has reported to the hospital complaining of persistent and recurrent fever over the past 3 weeks. He reports symptoms of generalized malaise and night sweats too. A physical examination revealed a heart murmur and the patient also had non-tender small erythematous lesions on the pads of his fingers and toes (Osler's nodes).  Medical History: Mr. Johnson is a smoker and has a past history of chronic hypertension  which has been managed by medication over the past ten years. His health history also includes Type II diabetes  diagnosed about 5 years ago. He has a family history of heart disease  with both parents having suffered from cardiovascular diseases. He has not had any surgeries in the past.   Social History: The patient lives alone and has recently retired from working as a plumber has infrequent visits from his two grown children. He consumes alcohol rarely and is observing a low salt diet for his hypertension.  On initial screening  he is found to be febrile  with a temperature of 38.6°C. Standard laboratory tests have been ordered and empirical therapy has been initiated. A blood culture has also been ordered.   Provisional Diagnosis: Based on the patient's symptoms  the presence of a heart murmur  Osler's nodes  and his risk factors of hypertension and diabetes  there is a high suspicion for Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis. It may be due to the damage caused by the blood rushing past a valve in his heart  where germs have attached. Given that Mr. Johnson's career as a plumber might have exposed him to several bacteria  this assumption is plausible.  Further investigations: The diagnosis of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis will be confirmed through laboratory examination of blood cultures. An echocardiogram may be ordered to provide an image of his heart to assess the suspected damage.  It is very crucial to note that immediate optimized treatment plan would be needed  should the diagnosis be confirmed to mitigate rapid disease progression and to stem resultant complications such as heart failure and systemic embolism.  Infective Endocarditis is a serious infection and can also lead to life-threatening complications. It is important for patients like Mr. Johnson  given his age and other underlying health conditions  to remain communicative about all the symptoms he experiences and be compliant with the treatment plan recommended by the healthcare team.

Title of Presentation: Presentation of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Caucasian Male   Introduction:  I would like to present a case of native-valve infective endocarditis (IE). According to literature  the disease is more common in males and individuals over 50 years of age and this demographic information has been taken into account for this presentation.  Patient's Profile:  Our patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian male from an urban area. He is married with one child and works in construction  a profession that is known to expose individuals to various environmental pathogens.  Past Medical History:  He was previously diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes approximately seven years ago and is currently managed with oral anti-diabetic medication. He has a history of cigarette smoking - a pack a day for 20 years  but quit 3 years ago. No known drug allergies are documented for this patient. There is no prior history of illicit drug use. Family history includes cardiovascular disease in his father who had a myocardial infarction at 65 years and sister with a congenital heart disease.  Presenting Condition:  The patient presented with a three-week history of unremitting fever  night sweats  weight loss  and increasing levels of fatigue. He reports having been generally healthy until this illness  although he has noticed occasional swelling in his feet and ankles over the past month.   As per the findings of Pettersson and Hussain (2016)  IE primarily affects individuals with existing heart conditions or those who use intravenous drugs  however  our patient was at risk due to his age  gender  and pre-existing condition of diabetes. This presentation is line with the documented findings in current literature. More diagnostic procedures are in progress to further ascertain the treatment protocol for the patient.   Conclusion:  Early identification of symptoms and diagnosis remains critical in managing IE  as it is a serious condition with potential for severe complications if left untreated. As healthcare providers  understanding the correlation between patient’s demographic details and risk factors  with potential medical conditions  is crucial to ensure accurate diagnosis.  References: Pettersson  G. B.  & Hussain  S. T. (2016). Current AATS guidelines on surgical treatment of infective endocarditis. Annals of cardiothoracic surgery  5(4)  295.

Title: Case Presentation: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Presentation:  Patient Profile: Our patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male with a history of alcohol abuse  cigarette smoking  and periodontal disease. He was lately diagnosed with diabetes mellitus  which is inadequately controlled  and admitted three months ago for an acute myocardial infarction. His daily medications include aspirin  metoprolol  and metformin.  Chief Complaints: The patient complains of persistent high-grade fever  malaise  chills  and night sweats persisting for the past three weeks. He has recently developed exertional dyspnea  mild chest discomfort  and fatigue. He also reported an unintentional weight loss of 5 kg over the last 2 months.  Physical Examination: Upon examination  patient was febrile and appeared ill and tired. Auscultation of the heart revealed a diastolic murmur and signs of heart failure were present. Examination of the oral cavity revealed poor dental hygiene with evidence of periodontal disease. Ophthalmoscopic exam showed Roth spots.  Investigation & Diagnosis: A series of blood cultures were positive for Streptococcus viridians. Transthoracic echocardiography was performed showing vegetations on the mitral valve consistent with a diagnosis of Infective endocarditis (IE). Based on presentation  clinical findings  and investigations  patients has been diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis associated with diabetes mellitus  which probably predisposed him to this condition.  Discussion:  Infective endocarditis typically affects males more often than females with a peak prevalence at age 60 or older. Co-existing conditions  notably including diabetes  increase the risk of infective endocarditis. The diagnosis usually involves identifying causative agents and conducting imaging studies to identify heart valve damage.  This patient's history of alcohol abuse  smoking  poor oral hygiene and poorly controlled diabetes  together with his recent diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction  has synergistically predisposed him to develop infective endocarditis. His demographics  clinical history  and presentation are consistent with epidemiological trends observed in native-valve IE patients. It is exceedingly important to identify such high-risk patients for early diagnosis and targeted management.

Title: Presentation of a Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis Patient  Introduction:  Meet Mr. Jenkins  a 60-year-old Caucasian male presenting with fever  fatigue  and a new cardiac murmur. Mr. Jenkins has been in generally good health until a month ago when he started to experience persistent fever along with weight loss  loss of appetite  night sweats  and general malaise. His GP initially treated him for a suspected upper respiratory tract infection but his condition didn't improve.  Demographics:  Mr. Jenkins  from a middle-class socioeconomic background  lives with his wife in a suburban setting. He retired from his work in construction a few years ago but remains physically active. He is a former tobacco user but has not smoked in the past 5 years. He has a moderate alcohol intake– predominantly wine – and does not use any illicit drugs.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Jenkins has a history of mitral valve prolapse diagnosed in his early 40s  for which he has remained asymptomatic throughout his life. Other relevant medical history includes hypertension  which has been well-controlled through medication  and mild hypercholesterolemia.  Presentation:  Upon physical examination  Mr. Jenkins is found to be febrile with a temperature of 38.2 degrees celsius. Cardiac auscultation reveals a new murmur  suggestive of possible valvular insufficiency. His blood pressure and resting heart rate readings are generally within normal limits  though they occasionally display mild fluctuation correlating with his fever peaks. Blood tests reveal increased inflammatory markers.   Conclusion:  Given his persisting fever  new murmur  and past medical history of valvular heart disease  a suspicion of infective endocarditis is raised. Further investigations  such as blood cultures and echocardiography  are needed to confirm this diagnosis. In the mean time  empirical antibiotic treatment is initiated until the definitive causative agent can be identified.   This presentation aligns with the demographic representation found in literature  stating that infective endocarditis primarily affects older adults with pre-existing valvular heart disease  and is more common in males. It also illustrates the atypical presentation of this disease  where symptoms develop gradually over a period of weeks.

Patient Presentation:   John Doe  a 60-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department reporting general fatigue  loss of appetite  and unexplained weight loss for the past three weeks. He also mentions recurrent fever spiking up to 38.7°C and night sweats for the same duration. He denies any current chest pain  cough or shortness of breath  but states that he has been feeling increasingly weak and lightheaded lately.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a history of moderately controlled Diabetes Mellitus Type II for which he takes Metformin and occasional insulin. He also reports a history of Rheumatic fever in his childhood which left him with a mild aortic stenosis – a condition he has been monitoring regularly with his primary care physician. He quit smoking 5 years ago  following a mild myocardial infarction which was managed percutaneously with angioplasty and stenting to his coronaries. He has been on maintenance aspirin for this. He drinks a glass of wine occasionally but denies any illicit drug usage. He underwent a dental procedure one month back and was prescribed a single dose of prophylactic amoxicillin due to his known valvular heart disease. No allergies are reported.  Based on his signs and symptoms  past medical history and the recent invasive dental procedure  a suspected diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis is considered. Research has shown that middle-aged and older adults  particularly men with a history of valvular heart disease  are at a higher risk for endocarditis.    Further diagnostic tests  including blood cultures for identifying causative organism and transthoracic or potential transesophageal echocardiography for visualization of valvular vegetation or abscesses would be necessary to confirm this provisional diagnosis.   Endocarditis is a serious disease  and without prompt diagnosis and treatment  the condition can lead to life-threatening complications. Therefore  the suspected diagnosis needs to be confirmed or ruled out swiftly for appropriate management.

Title: Presentation of a Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis Patient  Slide 1: Introduction - Subject: Native-valve infective endocarditis - Importance: Increasing in incidence due to an aging population  rising intravenous drug use  and healthcare-associated procedures.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics - Name: Mr. A - Age: 59 years old - Gender: Male - Occupation: Plumber - Lives in urban area - Literature: Men are more prone to infective endocarditis. Prevalence increases with age  peaking in the 5th-6th decade of life.  Slide 3: Social History - Occasional smoker  - Moderate alcohol consumption  - No history of recreational drug usage  Slide 4: Medical History - Diagnosed with diabetes mellitus three years ago - History of mitral valve prolapse - Literature: Diabetes mellitus is a recognized risk factor. Heart valve abnormalities (such as moderal valve prolapse) predispose to infective endocarditis.  Slide 5: Presenting Symptoms - Fever and chills over the past 2 weeks - Night sweats - Shortness of breath - Weakness and fatigue - Literature: Symptoms are typically nonspecific and can vary based on the severity of the cases.  Slide 6: Physical Examination - Heart murmur detected - Janeway Lesions  - Clubbing noted - Literature: Murmurs are typically present  especially in cases involving diseased valves. Janeway lesions and clubbing are signs of infective endocarditis.   Slide 7: Investigations - Blood culture tests – positive for Staphylococcus aureus - Echocardiography: Vegetations on the mitral valve - Literature: Staphylococcus aureus is a common causal organism. Echocardiography is crucial to detect vegetations on heart valves.  Slide 8: Conclusion  - Considering the medical history  clinical symptoms  physical examination findings  and investigations  a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis is made. - A consult with a cardiology specialist would be needed for treatment planning. - Prompt management is crucial to prevent serious complications  such as heart failure and spread of infection.

Title: Presentation of Native Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Profile:  Mr. George Cooper is a 56-year-old Caucasian male presenting with concerns related to frequent fevers  night sweats  fatigue  and a newly detected heart murmur as characterized in native-valve infective endocarditis. Born and raised in rural Georgia  Mr. Cooper previously worked in agriculture until his recent retirement. He is a non-smoker but admits to consuming alcohol socially.  Past medical history:  Mr. Cooper's medical history includes well-controlled hypertension and dyslipidemia  both of which have been managed through lifestyle modifications and medication for the past ten years. The patient has a documented allergy to penicillin  leading to a rash. There is no history of illicit drug use  and he has had no previous surgeries. He has not had any heart surgeries  previous endocarditis  or other cardiac conditions.  Recent history:  Mr. Cooper started experiencing unexplained fevers and significant fatigue about three weeks ago. He initially assumed it was a viral infection until the symptoms persisted. He also reports a weight loss of about ten pounds during this period. Over the last week  he has noticed increasing shortness of breath  especially on exertion. There are no gastrointestinal  urinary  or neurological symptoms.  Family history:  The patient's father had a myocardial infarction in his late sixties  and his mother has well-controlled type-2 diabetes mellitus. His older brother underwent a brain stent placement for an aneurysm a few years ago.  Clinical presentation:  On examination  Mr. Cooper appears fatigued. He has a low-grade fever and an irregular pulse. There are no visible skin lesions or petechiae. Cardiac auscultation reveals a new-onset systolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. Lungs are clear on auscultation  and abdominal examination is unremarkable.  Conclusion:  After a thorough review of Mr. Cooper’s profile  clinical presentation  and past medical history  there is a strong possibility of native valve infective endocarditis. Further diagnostic testing including blood cultures and an echocardiogram are warranted to confirm this diagnosis and guide the treatment accordingly.

Patient Information: Mr. Edward  a 60-year-old African-American mailman with a BMI of 28  living in an urban neighborhood  presents with general malaise  fatigue  and a persistent fever of 100.8°F.  Chief Complaint: ""I have been feeling run-down and feverish for about two weeks.""  History of Present Illness: Patient reports symptoms started gradually about two weeks ago  with increasing fatigue and intermittent fevers which are not responsive to over-the-counter remedies. He has also mentioned a weight loss of 8 pounds in the last month without any significant changes in his diet or activity routines.  Relevant PMH: Mr. Edward has a history of uncontrolled diabetes type II  which he manages with oral medications and dietary modifications  and hypertension controlled on medications. He also previously had a dental abscess treated three weeks ago.  Social History: He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially  approximately two times per week.  Review of systems: Patient also reports occasional night sweats  loss of appetite  and a new heart murmur noticed by primary care provider.  On examination  the patient appears in moderate distress. He displays pallor and has a couple of petechiae under his fingernails. His oral hygiene is poor. Cardiovascular exam elicits a new grade III systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. No other significant findings were noted.  Based on his history  age  racial background  presence of a new heart murmur  and recent dental procedures  Mr. Edward is suspected of having Native-valve Infective Endocarditis. Necessary lab tests and imaging studies have been ordered to confirm this diagnosis.

A 65-year-old African-American male named John Smith presents the emergency department with a 10-day history of intermittent fevers  chills  and malaise. Mr. Smith has a history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus  hypertension  and rheumatic heart disease. He has been in stable control of his DM and hypertension with a home regimen of Metformin and Losartan  respectively  and follows up regularly with his primary care physician.   A week ago  Mr. Smith visited an outpatient clinic with complaints of fatigue  myalgia with low grade fever  which was thought to be a viral syndrome. However  his condition deteriorated with persisting high-grade fevers  night sweats  and weight loss of around 5 kg in one month.   On examination  Mr. Smith had oral temperature of 38.4°C  blood pressure of 135/80 mmHg  heart rate of 100 beats/minute  and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. On cardiovascular examination  a diastolic murmur was heard on the left sternal border. Splinter hemorrhages were noted under his fingernails  and Janeway’s lesions were found on his palms and soles.   Considering his history of rheumatic heart disease and the positive findings from the physical examinations  a suspicion of infective endocarditis was made. The patient was admitted to the hospital for further investigation and management.

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. Martinez  a 60-year-old Hispanic woman  presents to the emergency department with a 10-day history of intermittent chills  fatigue  and shortness of breath. Over the past three days  she also reports experiencing night sweats and reduced appetite. She has a past medical history significant for poorly controlled type II diabetes mellitus  mitral valve prolapse  and intravenous drug use in her youth.  She denies any recent dental procedures  surgeries or indwelling catheters. On examination  she appears chronically ill and fatigued. Cardiovascular examination reveals a new regurgitant murmur over the mitral region. She also has non-blanching  erythematous nodules on the palms and soles  suggestive of Osler's nodes.  Diagnostics demonstrate elevated leukocyte count and a positive blood culture for Staphylococcus aureus  indicating bacteremia. Echocardiography reveals mitral valve vegetations  which further supports a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. Her glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) level of 9.5% indicates poor diabetic control as a potential risk factor for her current condition.

A 50-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of fever  general malaise  alternating sweats and chills  and unexplained weight loss. He also reports a new onset of shortness of breath and nocturnal cough.   The patient has a past medical history of intravenous drug use  for which he completed rehabilitation 10 years ago. He also has a history of untreated dental caries. The patient does not have any known cardiac history. His family history is noncontributory.   On physical examination  he appears fatigued and has a temperature of 101°F (38.3°C). Blood pressure and heart rate are stable. Auscultation of the heart reveals a new pansystolic murmur in the mitral valve area. On skin examination  he has two Janeway lesions on the palms of his hands and Osler nodes on his fingers. Oral exam shows multiple untreated dental cavities and poor oral hygiene.   Laboratory studies show elevated inflammatory markers  and blood cultures grew Staphylococcus aureus. Echocardiogram showed vegetation on his mitral valve. He was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis secondary to IV drug-use and poor dental hygiene. He was admitted and started IV antibiotic treatment for endocarditis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Juan Martínez  a 65-year-old Hispanic male  comes to the hospital expressing concern about high fever  weight loss  and profuse night sweats which has been worsening over the past one month. He reports experiencing episodes of shortness of breath and intermittent chest discomfort  associated with a racing heartbeat. The patient’s past medical history is significant for Type 2 diabetes mellitus and intravenous drug use in the past. He had a dental procedure performed about 6 weeks ago which he mentions was followed by a brief period of fever and discomfort but did not seek medical attention at that time.  He has a consistent history of poor dental hygiene as well  and upon oral examination a number of decayed teeth and bleeding  inflamed gums are evident  pointing towards chronic periodontitis. The patient is a current smoker and reports consumption of alcohol on a social basis. His family history is not significant for any cardiovascular disease.  On physical examination  Mr. Martínez is febrile with a temperature of 101.5F  a heart rate of 105 beats per minute  and blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg. Cardiac examination reveals a diastolic murmur at the apex and splinter hemorrhages under the nails are noticed. A blood culture is recommended by the attending physician and empirical antibiotic treatment is initiated in suspicion of possible native-valve endocarditis.   Comment: The patient’s age and ethnicity are consistent with epidemiological studies showing an increased frequency of infective endocarditis in males over the age of 60. Furthermore  his history of poor dental hygiene and a dental procedure make him susceptible to blood-borne bacterial infections that are well-known causes of endocarditis. His past of intravenous drug use and poorly managed diabetes are significant risk factors too.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. J is a 62-year-old Caucasian male  resident of a rural area  who presents to an outpatient facility with a one-month history of fever and chills followed by a recent onset of shortness of breath. He notes intermittent fever  as high as 39C  associated with profuse sweating  particularly at night. He has also reported a weight loss of 8 pounds in the past month  which he attributes to loss of appetite. He denies recent travel  alcohol  tobacco  or illicit drug use.  He has a history of moderate rheumatic heart disease  diagnosed in his early thirties after a bout of rheumatic fever  and managed per guidelines since then. He also has a known history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus  which is generally well controlled with metformin  and hypertension managed by taking lisinopril.  Mr. J works as a livestock farmer and had an incident of a deep cut on his arm around 2 months back  which was treated at a local clinic. He also has a dental cleaning procedure a few weeks before the onset of the fever but denies any dental pain or discomfort since then.  On examination  he appears fatigued. He is febrile  with a body temperature of 38.4C. Examination of his cardiovascular system reveals a previously undocumented murmur which is described as a mid-systolic ejection murmur heard at the left sternal border.   This case presentation is of note  as infective endocarditis is common in males  particularly those over 60 years old with pre-existing heart conditions. Furthermore  the association between rural residence and livestock farming with infective endocarditis has been noted in the literature.

Patient Presentation:  A 60-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of generalized fatigue  fevers  and night sweats. His past medical history is significant for aortic stenosis which has been managed conservatively till now. He also has a history of diabetes mellitus type 2  and he had a dental procedure performed approximately 3 weeks ago.   Upon examination  his vital signs are: temperature of 38.5°C  blood pressure of 125/85 mmHg  heart rate of 95 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. Physical examination reveals a new pansystolic murmur at the right second intercostal space  clubbing of his fingers and toes  and small painless erythematous lesions on his palms and soles (Janeway lesions).  Initial blood investigations show elevated inflammatory markers with leukocytosis and raised ESR and CRP. Blood cultures have been obtained and sent to the laboratory. EKG shows no acute pathological changes. A transthoracic echocardiogram is ordered and shows vegetations on the aortic valve  suggestive of infective endocarditis. The patient has been started on empiric antibiotics awaiting definitive culture results.  Patient's history of aortic stenosis  recent dental procedure  and clinical presentation with a new heart murmur  Janeway lesions  and positive blood cultures are suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis. The presentation is typical for the demographics  as native valve endocarditis more commonly affects male patients and those with prior heart conditions.

Patient Presentation: A 65-year-old Caucasian male  named Mr. Williams  presents to the office with complaints of continuous lower-grade fever for the past three weeks. His fever is accompanied by fatigue  mild weight loss  and occasional night sweats. He further mentions he has been feeling an unusual weakness while doing any physical activity. He denies any history of recent travel or sick contacts.   He is a retired construction worker  a non-smoker  and drinks alcohol socially. His BMI is within the normal range for his age and height.   Mr. Williams has a past medical history of type II diabetes  for which he takes metformin  and rheumatic fever in his early twenties. He used to have a dental procedure around two months ago.   On examination  he has a temperature elevation and a diastolic murmur on cardiac auscultation is noticed. Splinter hemorrhages are also seen under his fingernails. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable.   Given his symptoms and physical examination findings  a suspicion of infective endocarditis is raised  particularly in light of a dental procedure that could have served as a source of bacteremia. Further investigations are planned to establish the diagnosis.   This patient presentation involves the common demographic (older Caucasian male)  risk factors (history of rheumatic fever  dental procedures  and diabetes mellitus)  and symptoms (fever  fatigue  weight loss  night sweats  weakness  a diastolic murmur and splinter hemorrhages) associated with native-valve infective endocarditis as reported in literature.

Patient Presentation   Mrs. Lois Jennings is a 65-year-old African American woman from rural Georgia  who comes to the clinic complaining of experiencing fatigue  low-grade fevers  night sweats  and unexplained weight loss over the past two months. She mentions these symptoms began with the onset of a mild flu-like syndrome that did not resolve. Recently  she also started to notice changes to her skin  including small  painless red or purple spots under the skin on her fingers or toes.   Mrs. Jennings has a history of rheumatic heart disease due to an untreated strep throat infection during childhood. She also has a long history of poorly controlled Type 2 diabetes and was recently hospitalized for a dental abscess which had to be surgically drained.   She is a retired school teacher who lives with her husband. Mrs. Jennings mentions that she does not drink alcohol  smoke or use recreational drugs. She follows a diabetes-friendly diet but struggles with consistency due to personal preference and financial constraints. She has been inconsistent with her dental hygiene practices due to cost concerns around dental care. She is up-to-date on her recommended immunizations but is overdue for her regular dental check-up due to a fear of dental procedures.   The initial physical examination reveals a low-grade fever and a systolic murmur best heard over the apex. Skin examination reveals splinter hemorrhages under her nails and petechiae on her palms and soles. The exam also identifies Osler nodes (painful bumps on the fingers) and Janeway lesions (red spots on the palms and soles). Mrs. Jennings appears fatigued and reports feeling unusually weak.  Considering her clinical presentation and history  the working diagnosis is native-valve infective endocarditis  most likely from streptococci or staphylococci introduced during her recent dental abscess drainage. The next step would be to confirm the diagnosis with blood cultures and an echocardiogram.

Patient Presentation: Mr. Carter  a 66-year-old African American male  retired construction worker  presents to the hospital with a four-week history of increasing fatigue  night sweats  and unexplained weight loss. He also reports a low-grade fever that has persisted despite self-management  and difficulty breathing during minor physical activities which was not present before.  Past Medical History: Mr. Carter is a smoker with a 30 pack year history. He has been managing hypertension and type 2 diabetes for 10 years  which are under control with medications. He has no known allergies to drugs. There is no prior history of intravenous drug abuse  surgeries  or dental procedures.  On physical examination  Mr. Carter appears chronically ill. His body mass index is 30. His blood pressure is 145/80 mmHg  heart rate 108 beats per minute and irregular  respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute  and body temperature 38.1°C. Cardiac examination reveals a new cardiac murmur over the mitral area. Skin examination shows microhemorrhages on the palms and soles with small  pustule-like lesions.  Relevant diagnostic testing reveals anemia in complete blood count  elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate  CRP and poor glycemic control in HbA1C levels. Chest X-ray shows a small pleural effusion while electrocardiogram presents atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. Exceptionally  two sets of positive blood cultures grow Streptococcus viridans  leading to a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  The patient's age  pre-existing mitral valve disease due to hypertension  and poorly controlled diabetes are all identified as high risk factors that contributed to his development of endocarditis. This case is consistent with literature stating that infective endocarditis predominantly affects males over 60 with a history of diabetes or heart disease. His occupation did not add a significant risk  but his smoking history may have contributed to his overall poor health.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Gonzalez  a 62-year-old Hispanic female  presents to her primary care physician complaining of 3 weeks of fatigue  intermittent fever  night sweats  and unintentional weight loss of 10 pounds over the last month. She denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or cough. She reports a dental procedure 5 months ago but denies recent travel  IV drug use  or recent illnesses.   Her past medical history is significant for rheumatoid arthritis for which she takes weekly methotrexate and prednisolone daily; diabetes mellitus type 2 controlled with metformin; and hypertension managed with lisinopril. She is a retired elementary school teacher  doesn't smoke or drink alcohol  and lives alone. Her family history is significant for heart disease in her father; both parents are now deceased.  Examination reveals a temperature of 100.2°F  blood pressure of 140/80  heart rate of 98 bpm and respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute. She appears malnourished. Cardiac examination shows regular rhythm and a new grade III/VI systolic  rough  blowing murmur best heard at the cardiac apex. Skin examination shows tender  small erythematous nodules on her fingers (Osler's nodes) and non-tender  small  flat  reddish-pink spots on the palms and soles (Janeway's lesions). She also has some peripheral edema.  Given Mrs. Gonzalez's symptoms  physical examination  and history  she is suspected of having native-valve infective endocarditis  likely due to poor oral hygiene and a recent dental procedure. This suspicion is heightened because of her weekly use of methotrexate and daily prednisolone  both of which can suppress immune response  and advanced age  which is a known risk factor for the disease. She will require blood cultures and an echocardiogram to confirm the diagnosis and start on appropriate antibiotic therapy as soon as possible.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. David  a 60-year-old African-American male  presents to the emergency room with a 2-week history of intermittent fevers  chills  malaise  and an unintentional weight loss of 10 pounds. He also reports a new-onset of shortness of breath and occasional night sweats.  David has a significant past medical history of moderate-to-severe mitral valve regurgitation  for which surgery was deemed unnecessary at the time of diagnosis. He is a long-term smoker with a pack-year history of 20 years and has a reported history of intravenous drug use until about 15 years ago. He also has an established diagnosis of Type II Diabetes Mellitus but is relatively non-compliant with his medications.  On physical exam  he appears generally ill. There are splinter hemorrhages in his nails  and Osler's nodes were found on the pads of his fingers. A cardiac murmur  consistent with mitral regurgitation  is noted and seems to have increased in intensity since his last examination 6 months ago. Furthermore  Janeway lesions were observed on his palms and the soles of his feet.  Considering his background of underlying heart valve disease  and presentation including fever  weight loss  and classic clinical signs  a suspicion of native valve infective endocarditis is raised. Immediate blood cultures and an echocardiogram are ordered to confirm and for further management.  These symptoms  physical findings  and his past history coincide with his high risk for native-valve infective endocarditis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Hernandez  a 48-year-old Hispanic male accountant from San Antonio  presents at the outpatient department with complaints of persistent fever  fatigue  night sweats  and loss of appetite for the past 3 weeks.  He follows a vegetarian diet  doesn't consume alcohol or drugs  and denies any recent travels or unpasteurized dairy intake. He used to smoke a pack of cigarettes per day for 20 years but stopped smoking 5 years ago. His family history is notable for type 2 diabetes in his mother and hypertension in his father.  His past medical history is significant  with a diagnosis of Type 2 diabetes mellitus for the last 10 years which is controlled effectively with Metformin. 2 years ago  he was also diagnosed with moderate chronic kidney disease primarily managed by diet control and blood pressure control (Lisinopril). He also underwent a root canal procedure 4 weeks ago.  On physical examination  he appeared ill with a moderate size spleen palpable on deep inspiration. A new-onset pan systolic murmur was heard on auscultation  especially over the mitral region. Multiple tiny hemorrhagic spots were noticed under his fingernails (Splinter hemorrhages) and on the conjunctiva of his eyes.  Given his presentation and past medical history  there seems to be a strong clinical suspicion for native valve infective endocarditis. Further imaging (Echocardiography) and blood cultures have been ordered to confirm the diagnosis. The patient has been admitted to the hospital for intensive monitoring and treatment  given his underlying risk factors and poor health condition.

Patient Presentation:   A 60-year-old African-American male presents to the Emergency Department complaining of a feeling of general malaise  fevers  and shortness of breath for the past two weeks. He admits that he's been experiencing night sweats and unintentional weight loss over the same period. He denies any recent travel  exotic foods  risky sexual behavior  but admits to a history of regular intravenous drug use in his younger years.  Patient’s vitals on arrival are as follows: BP 120/80 mm Hg  HR 102 bpm  temperature of 101.4°F  RR 22 breaths per minute  and SpO2 of 92% on room air. On examination  he appears ill and diaphoretic.
