Cardiovascular exam reveals a new pansystolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. His conjunctivae appear pale and the presence of Janeway lesions is noted on the soles of feet and palms.   The patient has a history of advanced chronic kidney disease (stage IV)  which is managed with medications including angiotensin II receptor blockers and phosphate binders. He quit smoking 5 years ago  but had a 30-pack-year smoking history prior to quitting. Additionally  multiple medical notations confirm the patient has not been adherent to his medication or treatment regimen  as well as frequent missed clinical appointments. There is also a history of homelessness documented in his medical record; his current living situation is unstable.   This presentation  coupled with his medical history and lack of adherence to medical treatment  makes the patient a high risk for native-valve infective endocarditis. Identifying signs and symptoms such as a new-onset murmur  fever  and signs of vascular phenomena or immunologic reactions further affirm clinical suspicion.

Subject: 64-year-old Caucasian Male  Presenting Conditions:   The patient presents at the emergency department reporting persistent fever of 38.6 degrees Celsius (101.4 F) for two weeks  fatigue  weight loss of 5 kilograms over the past month  and new-onset shortness of breath. He also complains of night sweats and muscle pains. Physical examination reveals a heart murmur (not previously noted).  Demographics:   The patient is a 64-year-old Caucasian male  a retired coal miner  living in rural Pennsylvania. He is a nonsmoker and occasionally drinks alcohol. He adheres to a diet with animal protein and processed food  with a sedentary lifestyle. His body mass index (BMI) is 31 kg/m2  weighing 92kg for his height of 175cm  thus classified as obese.   Past Medical History:  He has a history of poorly controlled diabetes mellitus type II  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  and recently experienced a myocardial infarction 6 months ago and subsequently underwent angioplasty with stent placement later. He has a known history of untreated dental caries and poor oral health. His medication history includes atorvastatin  metformin  insulin  and ramipril. He has no known drug allergies. He has never had invasive procedures  such as surgery  within the past year. His last dental check-up was performed five years ago  and no invasive dental procedures were reported.  Family History:   His mother died of myocardial infarction at the age of 70  and his father died of lung cancer at the age of 72. He has two brothers in their 60s without any significant medical conditions.  Additional Findings:  Preliminary blood tests show increased inflammatory markers (C-reactive protein and ESR) and leukocytosis. Blood cultures are yet to return. An echocardiogram reveals vegetations on the mitral valve suggestive of infective endocarditis.  Considering the above presentation  current clinical condition  and health history  the patient’s ongoing symptoms of persistent fever  fatigue  weight loss  and new-onset shortness of breath may suggest a potential case of native-valve infective endocarditis  which is common in his demographics and medical history. Further blood culture testing and a consultation with a cardiologist is recommended.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. Smith  visits the emergency department accompanied by his wife. He is a retired schoolteacher and claims to adhere to a healthy diet and exercise regimen. Their home is in a rural hospice in Indiana where he enjoys gardening and woodworking. He presents with a 2-week history of progressive malaise  vague body aches  primarily in the joints  intermittent fevers  and night sweats. He also notes a recent loss of appetite and unanticipated weight loss which he estimates to be about 10 pounds over 2 weeks. He denies any recent travels  tick bites  or exposure to ill contacts.   His past medical history is significant for rheumatoid arthritis for which he takes non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs  mitral valve prolapse diagnosed 15 years ago  and mild hypertension managed with lifestyle modifications. He experienced a dental procedure about three weeks ago. He has no history of IV drug abuse  blood transfusions  or sexually transmitted diseases.   On physical examination  he appears sick and diaphoretic with a heart rate of 100 beats per minute  blood pressure of 135/85 mmHg  and a temperature of 38.5°C. Oral examination reveals poor dentition. Cardiac auscultation demonstrates a mid-systolic click and a late systolic murmur best heard at the apex. The rest of the physical examination  including neurologic examination  is normal.  Lab test notes leukocytosis and a positive blood culture for viridans group streptococci. An echocardiogram shows vegetation on the mitral valve  confirming the suspected diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Hernandez  a 60-year-old obese Hispanic male  presents in the emergency department with a history of intermittent fever for two weeks which was earlier low grade  accompanied by chills  a significant weight loss around 10 pounds and excessive fatigue for the same duration. Mr. Hernandez also complained of a recently developed slight shortness of breath while moving within his house and unexplained discomfort in the chest.  He has a complicated past medical history that includes Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  controlled with Metformin  and Hypertension  controlled with Lisinopril  both of which were diagnosed 13 years ago. Patient also mentioned a history of untreated dental caries  recent dental extraction around a month ago and an intravenous drug use 30 years ago during his early adult life  which he successfully left 25 years ago. He denies any recent travel  surgeries or exposure to contagious diseases  and he has no known allergies.  Family history reveals his father died of heart failure and his mother is diabetic. He is a retired taxi driver  a non-smoker though he consumed alcohol socially in the past. His BMI is 31.  The patient also complains about a new onset of back pain and a three-day history of worsening weakness in his lower limbs. Upon physical examination  we noticed a mid-diastolic murmur best heard at the apex with the patient in left lateral position  some mild crackles in both lower lung fields. Neurologic exam was significant for some decrease in light-touch sensation in both lower legs and feet  and decrease in muscle strength in his legs. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.  This clinical scenario and his past history suggest a potential case of Native-valve Infective Endocarditis complicated by potential heart failure and possible early septic emboli to the spine  although more diagnostic tests are necessary to confirm.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Anderson  a 68-year-old African American male construction worker from rural southern parts of New York  presents to the emergency department accompanied by his wife  complaining of a fever of 101.3°F  up-and-down body temperature for the last two weeks  fatigue  general discomfort  unexplained weight loss of about 6 lbs over the past month  and profuse night sweats. He mentions an increasing lack of energy and stamina  complaining of a decreasing exercise tolerance. He observes increased shortness of breath particularly while lying down and has to use two pillows for sleeping.  The patient has a past medical history of permanent atrial fibrillation (for which he takes warfarin)  hypertension  stage 2 chronic kidney disease  and a history of intravenous drug use (heroin) until his early 40s.  On physical examination  he exhibits conjunctival pallor  dental decay  and Janeway lesions can be seen on the palms and soles. Cardiac auscultation reveals a new-onset murmur best heard at the apex. His family history is significant for an ischemic heart disease in his father who died at 65. Mr. Anderson is a current smoker and used to consume alcohol heavily during his 40s.  There is a high suspicion of infective endocarditis in this patient based on his fever  new-onset murmur  other constitutional symptoms like fatigue  weight loss  Janeway lesions and his significant past medical history of atrial fibrillation  intravenous drug use  dental decay  and exposure to occupational dust.  Mr. Anderson works in construction and has possible exposure to dust  and with his history of drug abuse and menial oral hygiene  he was at high risk for developing native valve infective endocarditis.

Patient Information: Mr. Parker  59-year-old Caucasian male  Chief Complaint: High-grade persistent fever  shortness of breath  and generalized fatigue for the past two weeks. Lost 10 pounds during this period due to reduced appetite and generalized weakness.  Presenting Illness: He has a daily fever that goes as high as 101 degrees (F)  accompanied by night sweats and chills. He noticed his heart beating rapidly  even when at rest  and has experienced occasional shortness of breath upon exertion. His appetite has decreased substantially  and he feels increasingly fatigued and weak. He reports occasional mild joint pains and noticed tiny red spots on the skin of his legs and feet. There is no chest pain  cough  or other symptoms.  Past Medical History: He has a documented history of intravenous drug use more than 5 years ago. He underwent treatment and has stayed clean since then. He has been previously diagnosed with Rheumatic Heart Disease and has been on prophylactic antibiotic therapy. He has had no previous surgeries. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. There is no family history of valvular heart disease  autoimmune diseases  malignancies or any other major illnesses.  Physical Examination: Upon physical examination  Mr. Parker exhibited pallor and looks malnourished. He has an increased heart rate (tachycardia) and had a diastolic heart murmur. Evidence of petechiae on the skin and conjunctiva  as well as Osler nodes on his fingers and toes  was noticed.  Suspicion: Given his history of rheumatic heart disease and intravenous drug use  as well as his current signs and symptoms  there is a high suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis. He will need further diagnostic tests  including blood culture and an echocardiogram  to confirm this diagnosis  and appropriate therapy should be started without any delay.  Relevant Literature: In literature  mortality rates are high in patients with native-valve endocarditis  particularly those who are older  with comorbid heart conditions  and prior intravenous drug use. Immediate medical attention and targeted therapy are critical in improving patient outcomes.

Patient Presentation:  A 57-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for intravenous drug use (last reported use approximately three months ago) and hypertension  comes to the emergency department complaining of a three-week history of malaise  intermittent fevers  night sweats  and a recent onset of pain and redness in his left foot. He also reports a 10-pound unintentional weight loss over the last month. He does not have a known history of any heart disease and denies any history of HIV or Hepatitis C infection to his knowledge. He does not have any known allergies.  On physical examination  he appears generally unwell and underweight. He is febrile with a temperature of 38.5°C  blood pressure is 100/76 mmHg  heart rate 100 bpm  and oxygen saturation 96% on room air. Cardiac examination reveals a new grade 3/6 diastolic murmur over the left lower sternal border. Pulmonary examination reveals clear breath sounds bilaterally. Examination of his left foot shows signs suggestive of Janeway lesions.  Blood tests show a significative elevated white blood cell count (15 500 cells/micro-liter) with a predominance of neutrophils (85%). His hemoglobin level is low (10.8 g/dL). Blood cultures are ordered and later returned positive for Staphylococcus aureus. An echocardiogram subsequently reveals vegetations on the tricuspid valve  consistent with the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.

Patient Presentation:  A 63-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. J  presented to the hospital with a two-week history of intermittent fever  night sweats  and unexplained weight loss. He also reports experiencing increasing fatigue and an episode of syncope two days ago. He has a history of intravenous drug use in his early life  though he has been in recovery for the past 20 years. He also has a documented past medical history of rheumatic heart disease and was treated for strep throat numerous times in his youth. He has no known allergies but has been a smoker for over 30 years.   Over the past year  Mr. J has been treated for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Despite his previous history of IV drug use  he is currently negative for HIV and Hepatitis C. Family history reveals his mother suffered from endocarditis at an older age and his father had early coronary heart disease. His current medications include an ACE inhibitor and a statin.  On examination  he appeared ill and diaphoretic. He had a blood pressure of 100/60 mmHg  a pulse of 98 bpm  a respiratory rate of 18  and a fever of 38.5 Degrees Celsius. Cardiac examination was notable for a new murmur at the apex  and two Osler’s nodes were noted on examination of his hands. An echocardiogram and blood cultures were ordered subsequently. He is currently admitted and started on empiric antibiotic treatment pending culture results.

Patient Presentation:  A 64-year-old Caucasian male was admitted to the hospital with a 2-week history of fever  fatigue  and weight loss. Past medical history is notable for a diagnosis of moderate rheumatic heart disease from a bout of rheumatic fever in childhood  but he has never required surgery and has not undergone any recent dental procedures. He has a 30-year pack history of smoking  drinks alcohol socially  and denies illicit drug use.  On physical examination  there were indications of undernutrition with a BMI calculated 18.8 kg/m². Vital signs showed mild fever at 38.2 degrees Celsius  heart rate of 85 beats/min  blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg  respiration rate of 15 breaths/min  and oxygen saturation of 97% on ambient air. Cardiac auscultation revealed a grade 3/6 pansystolic murmur best heard at the apex  no further abnormalities were noted on chest examination. The skin showed no signs of petechiae  Osler's nodes  or Janeway lesions. Ophthalmologic examination revealed no Roth's spots.  Investigations showed elevated inflammatory markers with a white blood cell count of 13 500 cells/microlitre and a C-reactive protein level of 45mg/L. A set of blood cultures were taken and an echocardiogram ordered.  The patient’s presentation and past medical history of rheumatic heart disease is suggestive of a possibility of native valve infective endocarditis  although the definitive diagnosis will be based on blood culture results and echocardiographic findings.

Patient Presentation:  John A.  a 55-year-old Caucasian male  presents complaining about persistent fever  fatigue  and loss of appetite over the past two weeks. He states that he’s also experiencing night sweats and recent weight loss and notes that he feels his heart “beating out of his chest” on occasion.   Patient's medical history reveals a well-controlled type 2 diabetes and a 35-year history of intravenous drug use  although he has been clean for the past five years. There's no history of any previous cardiac disease or surgery  but he did have a bout of Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia approximately 1 year ago thought to be secondary to a cutaneous abscess at an injection site.   Physical examination reveals a fever of 38.5°C  heart rate of 95 beats per minute  and a new-onset grade III/VI systolic murmur best heard at the apex. Some petechiae are also noted on the skin  but there's no evidence of Osler's nodes or Janeway lesions. Neurological examination is unremarkable.   These clinical findings along with his persistent fevers  new murmur  and previous history of S. aureus bacteremia suggest possible native-valve infective endocarditis. Further evaluation with echocardiogram and blood cultures is indicated.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Charles is a 58-year-old African-American male who comes in with complaints of persistent fever (low grade) for the past 2-3 weeks  which has worsened over the past few days  malaise  loss of appetite  and a weight loss of 10 pounds. On detailed inquiry  he also mentions experiencing occasional shortness of breath  night sweats  and mild  intermittent chest discomfort. He states he lost consciousness briefly a week ago  but quickly regained consciousness.  Mr. Charles has a 30-year history of intravenous drug use but has been clean for the past three years. He has not been following well with his healthcare providers  as he was last seen 2 years ago. His previous medical history showed that he was diagnosed with Hepatitis C secondary to intravenous drug usage. There is no known history of HIV  tuberculosis  sexually transmitted diseases  or other infections. He does not report any heart murmurs  but there is also no previous echo report in the medical records reviewed.  On physical examination  he appears thin and pale. He has a blood pressure of 110/60 mmHg  pulse of 96 beats/minute  respirations 18 breaths/minute  and fever of 100.8°F. Cardiovascular examination reveals a new onset grade 3/6 diastolic murmur. Skin reveals multiple petechiae in the lower extremities and oral mucosa shows dental caries without obvious abscess formation.  The series of events points towards a likelihood of subacute native-valve infective endocarditis  considering the long-standing history of intravenous drug use  new heart murmur  consistent fever  and vascular phenomena like petechiae and syncope episode. The confirmative diagnosis would require blood cultures and an echocardiogram looking for evidence of infected vegetations on the heart valves.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Rodriguez is a 57-year-old Hispanic male who presents to the emergency department with a two-week history of low-grade fever  fatigue  weight loss  and mild temporary right-side weakness. The fever is intermittent  accompanied by night sweats. He also reports having mild joint pain and recently noticed small red spots on the palm of his hands.  Mr. Rodriguez is known to have a past medical history of type II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and a smoking history of 20 pack years and a mild to moderate alcohol drinker.  He works as a janitor and reports no recent recreational drug use or travel outside of the country. He did not undergo any invasive dental procedure in the recent past but admits to poor oral hygiene.  On physical examination  Mr. Rodriguez appears ill and is diaphoretic. His blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg  pulse 96 beats per minute  respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation 96% on room air  and temperature 100.4°F. There are few janeway lesions on his palms and soles  osler nodes on his fingers  and splinter hemorrhages under his fingernails.  Given the symptoms  presentation  and past medical history  a working diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis is suspected. The health team recommends a series of diagnostic tests  including blood cultures  echocardiography  and other relevant laboratory tests. In the meantime  Mr. Rodriguez is started on broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy for empiric treatment.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Gallegos is a 67-year-old Hispanic male presenting to the emergency department with a complaint of intermittent fevers  ranging from 99.5 to 101.4 degrees Fahrenheit for the past two weeks  associated with increasing fatigue  unintended weight loss of around 5 lbs and occasional night sweats. In-between these fevers  the patient feels relatively well. He also reports a new onset of intermittent chest discomfort over the past week  occurring at rest and not related to physical exertion.  Past medical history includes poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and a previous dental infection about a month ago for which he was prescribed antibiotics. He denies any drug use. The patient is a retired farmer and lives with his wife.   This presentation raises concern for possible infective endocarditis given his background of dental infections and new-onset cardiovascular symptoms. Further testing and consultation with cardiology and infectious disease specialists would be appropriate.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents with a 3-week history of persistent fevers  night sweats  and unintentional 10-pound weight loss. He mentions he has experienced increasing fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. Remarkably  recurrent arthritis has been a problem especially in his left knee. He reports occasional heart ""fluttering "" but denies chest pain or syncope.  The patient is a retired construction worker and a smoker of 20 years. He has a past medical history of degenerative arthritis and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease for which he uses tiotropium inhalation. He denies any use of recreational drugs.  On physical examination  the patient appears ill-appeased  his BMI is 28  blood pressure of 140/90 mm Hg  pulse of 98 bpm  temperature of 38.7 °C. Cardiac examination revealed a grade III/VI systolic ejection murmur best heard at the left sternal border and a previously undiscovered cardiac murmur. Other significant findings include splinter hemorrhages in fingernails  conjunctival petechiae  and a swollen  tender left knee. The rest of the systemic examination was unremarkable.  His EKG shows atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. Lab tests show increased inflammatory markers with a white blood count of 13 000/µl and C-reactive protein of 10mg/dl. Blood cultures have been drawn and he has been admitted for further evaluation under the impression of infective endocarditis. High-resolution transthoracic echo will be performed to verify the condition of the heart valves.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Jose Santiago  a 60-year-old Hispanic male  presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of persistent fever  severe night sweats  new-onset shortness of breath  and unintended weight loss over the past month. He also mentions the appearance of red spots on his hands and feet recently.  He has a documented history of longstanding uncontrolled diabetes mellitus type-2  diagnosed 15 years ago  but has been noncompliant with his medications. Additionally  he had aortic valve replacement surgery due to severe aortic stenosis approximately 3 years ago. The patient denied any other history of cardiovascular disease.  Mr. Santiago has a known history of intravenous drug use over the last 20 years but has been sober for the past 2 years. He is currently unemployed and lives alone. He does not have any known drug allergies. He is a life-long smoker with a 30 pack-year history. His father died in his early 60s with a heart attack  and his mother had type-2 diabetes mellitus.   On physical examination  he appears chronically ill. Cardiac examination reveals a murmur best heard at the left sternal border and the lung examination has rales at the bases. Splinter hemorrhages are observed under his fingernails and petechiae on his lower extremities. Systolic blood pressure measures 110 mm Hg and diastolic 70 mm Hg  and his heart rate is 95 beats per minute.  The presenting symptoms align with the potential diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis but would need confirmatory diagnostic tests  including blood cultures and heart imaging. Patient's history of intravenous drug use and uncontrolled diabetes mellitus provide potential predisposing factors. An interdisciplinary team's immediate action is necessary to manage this high-risk patient.

Patient Presentation == A 60-year-old Caucasian male  longtime smoker  presents to the emergency department complaining of intermittent fevers and night sweats for the past 6 weeks. He also mentions marked loss of appetite  weight loss  and occasional shortness of breath recently. On questioning  he admits to a history of intravenous drug use in his 20s and 30s  although he has now been in recovery for over 15 years. He has a known history of mild aortic stenosis  moderate pulmonary hypertension  and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  and is currently on appropriate medication for these conditions.  On clinical examination  he is febrile with a temperature of 101.5°F  blood pressure is 115/70 mmHg  pulse 105 bpm  and respiratory rate 24 breaths/min. Cardiovascular examination reveals a diastolic murmur that is best heard in the right second intercostal space. Also noted are Osler's nodes in his hands and feet and Janeway's lesions on the palms and soles.   Given his history of malaise  anorexia  and fever along with new murmurs and typical vascular and immunological phenomena  there is immediate concern for infective endocarditis  warranting further urgent investigation and care.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. X is a 67-year-old African American female who presents to our clinic for evaluation of a 3-week history of intermittent fever  nausea  and fatigue. A retired caterer  she has a past medical history significant for Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  well-controlled with Metformin  and aortic stenosis diagnosed two years prior during a routine visit with no subsequent intervention.  Recently  she noted unintentional weight loss of 12 pounds over the past two months. She denies any travel history  recent surgery  use of recreational drugs including IV drugs  or any recent procedures. Ms. X is a widower  lives alone  and is consistent with her medications with no known drug allergies. She has a family history of cardiovascular disease  her father died of a myocardial infarction at age 69.  On physical examination  she has low-grade fever  mild pallor  purple colored lesions on feet (Janeway lesions)  tender  nodular swellings on pads of her fingers (Osler's nodes)  and a new cardiac murmur suggestive of aortic regurgitation. Other systems were essentially within normal limits. Lab results showed mildly elevated ESR  CRP  and neutrophilic leukocytosis.  Based on her clinical presentation  risk factors  and physical exam findings  a high suspicion of possible native-valve infective endocarditis was made. Approval was obtained for further workup including blood cultures and an echocardiogram.  In this patient’s scenario  the demographics are accurately represented  in accordance with the literature. According to medical literature  older adults are more susceptible to infective endocarditis and African-Americans have been shown to have a relatively higher risk. Also  individuals with a past medical history of valvular heart disease  in this case  aortic stenosis  have an increased risk. Her symptoms including intermittent fever  fatigue  weight loss  and the observed Janeway lesions and Osler's nodes on physical examination correlate well with classic signs of infective endocarditis.

Patient Presentation:  A 64-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with complaints of fever  fatigue  loss of appetite  and weight loss over the last three weeks. Additionally  he reports night sweats and shortness of breath on exertion  which have progressively worsened over this period. He has a past medical history significant for intravenous drug abuse which was a problem about 20 years ago and has been clean ever since. He also has mild hypertension that is controlled with diet and occasional use of medication.  On examination  the patient appears ill and fatigued. His blood pressure is 138/90 mmHg  heart rate 105 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 20 per minute  and temperature of 38.5 degrees Celsius. A cardiac examination reveals mild tachycardia and a grade 3/6 diastolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border. He also exhibits petechiae on his palms and soles  and a Roth spot on fundoscopy. His lung fields are clear to auscultation and he has no evidence of splenomegaly or hepatomegaly on abdominal examination.  The patient and his wife confirm a lack of recent dental procedures or other invasive procedures and deny any known heart diseases or conditions. He does not have any allergies and is not currently on any medications. His family history is notable for coronary artery disease in his father  who passed away at the age of 75.  Given the findings on examination coupled with the patient's past medical history  there is a strong clinical suspicion for native valve infective endocarditis. The patient is admitted for further diagnostic tests including blood cultures  complete blood count  EKG  and echocardiography. Pending the results  empirical antibiotic therapy for suspected infective endocarditis is begun.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Jones is a 58-year-old Caucasian male who presents with a 2-week history of intermittent fever  profuse night sweats  and unintentional weight loss of approximately 10 pounds. His body temperatures have been fluctuating with documented spikes up to 103.0°F. He also reports general fatigue  and dyspnea on exertion that has been progressively worsening over the past week.  He has a known 20-year history of intravenous drug use  with the last known use about 2 weeks ago. His past medical history is significant for Hepatitis C infection  chronic back pain secondary to degenerative disc disease  and occasional episodes of cellulitis. He does not have any known cardiac history and has been relatively healthy until this episode.  He lives alone and denies any recent travel or exposure to animals. He has been unemployed for the past five years and currently survives on disability benefits. He has had multiple visits to the local soup kitchen due to financial constraints. He has a 30-pack-year history of cigarette smoking but denies any alcohol or other substance use.   On examination  he appears cachectic and generally ill. He exhibits poor dentition and multiple skin scars indicative of intravenous drug use. Cardiac exam is notable for a new diastolic murmur best heard over the left lower sternal border. The remainder of the physical exam is only remarkable for low-grade fever and tachycardia.  Given his history and presentation  there's concern for native valve infective endocarditis  likely secondary to his intravenous drug use. Further diagnostic workup  including blood cultures and echocardiography is planned.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Lopez is a 60-year-old Hispanic male farmer  who presents today with a 2-week history of intermittent high-grade fever  chilling  night sweats  and unintentional weight loss of approximately 5kg. The patient also reports experiencing fatigue  weakness  and a loss of appetite. His fever has been associated with a general malaise  poor concentration  and mild shortness of breath. Upon further enquiry  he reveals a history of intermittent dysuria over the past two months and recurrent dental abscesses which he has treated with over-the-counter medications.  His medical history is significant for rheumatic fever in his youth  which resulted in moderate damage to the mitral valve and thus has lived with mitral valve regurgitation for years. His last dental treatment was about 3 months ago. He has also been diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus which is controlled with metformin and lifestyle modification. He is non-smoker and denies any alcohol or illicit drug use. His family history is significant as his father had a heart disease.  On physical examination  he appears fatigued and in mild-to-moderate distress. Temperature is 38.4 degree Celsius  Blood pressure is 125/85mmHg  Heart rate of 110/min  and respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute. His oral examination reveals poor dentition with a significant amount of dental tartar  caries  and inflammation. Cardiac auscultation reveals a mid-systolic click and late systolic murmur at the cardiac apex. His lung fields are clear to auscultation. Palms show Janeway lesions and there are splinter hemorrhages under a few of his fingernails. His neurological examination  however  is normal.  The above symptoms and findings are suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis  especially with his history of previous cardiac valve damage and poor dentition  and his clinical presentation of extended fever and signs of systemic infection. Further diagnostic workup  such as blood cultures and an echocardiogram  are necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Brenda Knight is a 62-year-old African American female who presents to your clinic complaining of a two-week period of intermittent fever  malaise  and an unintentional weight loss of about 4 kg. She reports a low-grade fever that sometimes reaches 100.5°F accompanied by chills  poor appetite  fatigue  and aching muscles.   Past Medical History:  Ms. Knight has a documented history of diabetes mellitus type II and hypertension  which are under management with Metformin 500mg twice daily and Lisinopril 10mg daily respectively. She quit smoking 15 years ago but has a 30-pack year history. She doesn't drink alcohol.   Social History:  She is retired after working for many years as a high school teacher. She lives alone and has a dedicated caregiver who assists with shopping and cleaning. Ms. Knight's daughter visits her weekly  while her grandchildren visit once a month. She doesn't have any recent travels or exposure to farm animal or pets.  Examination:  On physical examination  she appears generally unwell  with pale conjunctiva and slight jaundice. Cardiovascular examination reveals a new-onset murmur best heard at the mitral area  suggestive of mitral incompetency. There is no peripheral stigmata of endocarditis. Her blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg  pulse rate is 88 beats/min  and she has a mild to moderate fever of 100.4°F.   Given her symptoms and physical examination findings  she was admitted and blood cultures were taken. The suspicions of infective endocarditis arose due to the presentation of fever and the new murmur in a patient with risk factors for this condition  ie. hypertension and diabetes. Empirical antimicrobial therapy was started pending the blood culture results.

Patient Presentation:  A 60-year-old Caucasian male  known smoker with a 30 pack-year history  presented to the emergency department reporting of persistent fatigue  intermittent fevers  night sweats  significant weight loss (approximately 10% of body weight) over the 6 weeks  and a new heart murmur noted by his primary care provider.  The patient was previously diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus  dyslipidemia  hypertension  and has a history of IV drug use. He is on regular medications including metformin and statins. He has a family history of aortic valve disease  with his father having had a valve replacement.  Physical examination revealed low-grade fever (37.8°C)  HR 95 bpm  BP 135/85  RR 18. Cardiac examination is notable for a new pansystolic murmur louder at the left sternal border. Cutaneous examination showed several painless  erythematous lesions on his palms and soles  consistent with Janeway lesions  and bleeding into the skin (Petechiae) was noted on his lower extremities. Ophthalmologic exam revealed presence of Roth spots.  Labs showed increased ESR and CRP indicating active inflammation. His blood glucose level was slightly elevated  and his lipid profile was within regular range owing to his compliance with medications. Blood cultures were drawn and patient was started on empiric antibiotics for suspected infective endocarditis. Confirmation of diagnosis awaits echocardiography and subsequent blood culture results.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Jacob Diaz  a 56-year-old Hispanic male  presents to the emergency department with complaints of fever  intermittent chills  fatigue  and malaise that have been ongoing for the last 3 weeks. Mr. Diaz also expresses concern about an unexplained weight loss of 15 lbs over the same period  despite no deliberate changes in diet or exercise.   He reports a history of intravenous drug use during his early adulthood but has been sober for the past 15 years. His wife also reports that he has a ""new"" heart murmur  although this has not been evaluated by a physician yet. Mr. Diaz has a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus  managed with metformin  and hepatitis C. He is allergic to penicillin.  Mr. Diaz is originally from Puerto Rico and works as a mechanic. He lives with his wife and has two adult children. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years but denies any current alcohol or recreational drug use.  On examination  he is febrile with a temperature of 100.9 F degrees  blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg  pulse 90/min and respiration rate 20/min. Cardiac auscultation revealed a new pansystolic murmur. Moreover  funduscopic examination revealed Roth spots.                                                                                                                           Given his risk factors including history of intravenous drug use  presence of fever with a new murmur  recent weight loss  and presence of Roth spots  there is a high index of suspicion for infective endocarditis.   Lab tests including blood cultures and an echocardiogram have been ordered to further assess the underlying etiology of his symptoms. Mr. Diaz has been admitted to the hospital for further work-up and pending culture results  he has been started on empiric antibiotic therapy for suspected infective endocarditis.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Maria Alvarez is a 65-year-old Hispanic female with a significant history of intravenous (IV) drug use  presenting to the emergency department with complaints of fever  chills  fatigue  and weight loss over the past month. She states that she has also been experiencing night sweats and a new onset of lower back pain. She admits to ongoing illicit drug use  specifically IV heroin  but denies any recent needle sharing practices. She has no known allergies and has been mostly out of medical care for the past decade.  Ms. Alvarez reports experiencing what she described as ""heart flutters"" for the past few days. She also reports a persistent cough but denies any other respiratory symptoms  such as chest pain or difficulty breathing. No gastrointestinal symptoms have been reported.  Her past medical history is significant for hepatitis C and recurrent cellulitis secondary to IV drug use. She lacks any medical records of recent health surveillance  immunizations or screenings. She also reports being homeless and a lack of regular access to hygienic facilities.  On physical examination  she was noted to have poor dentition with evidence of dental caries and poor oral hygiene. Upon cardiac examination  a new systolic murmur was identified.  With her background of IV drug use and new systolic murmur accompanied with systemic symptoms  there is a high suspicion for native-valve infective endocarditis. Further diagnostic investigation  including blood cultures and echocardiography  is warranted.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Hawkins is a 58-year-old Caucasian female who presents with complaints of persistent high grade fever of two weeks duration  chills  night sweats  decreased appetite and significant fatigue. She has also noticed that she has become increasingly short of breath over the past week even while performing her daily routine activities.  Past medical history is significant for intravenous drug use  which she quit 5 years ago. She was diagnosed with Hepatitis C related to her IV drug use 6 years ago. She has a known history of uncontrolled type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension  which she manages with oral medications. She has not had any surgical interventions in the past. Ms. Hawkins is a smoker  with a 25 pack-year history. She also consumes alcohol moderately.  Family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases as her father passed away due to a heart attack at the age of 62. Her mother is alive  with a history of hypertension and type II diabetes.  Her vital signs are stable but she does have a slight fever at 100.9 degrees Fahrenheit. Physical examination revealed a new heart murmur. The patient was pale  with some weight loss noticed. Fundoscopic examination showed Roth spots and further examination showed Osler's nodes on her palms and soles  as well as Janeway lesions.  Given her history of IV drug use  the new murmur  and physical exam findings  Ms. Hawkins' presenting symptoms are concerning for native-valve infective endocarditis.

Patient Presentation  A 45-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of intravenous drug use and hepatitis C presents to the clinic with persistent fever  chills  unintentional weight loss  and malaise over last one month. The patient also noted the presence of small painful nodules on his fingertips and occasional chest pain. He has not sought medical attention for these until now. He is homeless and reports drug relapse last month after six years of sobriety. He denies any known drug allergies.  On physical examination  the patient is febrile with a temperature of 38.7 C  heart rate is 96 beats per minute  respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute  blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg  and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Cardiovascular examination shows a new harsh mid-systolic murmur at left sternal border. Skin examination reveals some reddish-purple painless spots on his palms.   Lab tests reveal leukocytosis and elevated ESR and CRP levels. Blood cultures have been drawn and sent to the lab.  Given his presentation and his risk factors – history of intravenous drug use  homelessness  and hepatitis C  a suspicion of infective endocarditis is warranted. The next step would be to get a transthoracic echocardiogram to support diagnostic evidence of the condition.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Edwards is a 67-year-old African-American woman presenting to the office with a 4-week history of progressive  low-grade fevers  malaise  and a weight loss of about 7 lbs.   Social History:  She has a past history of intravenous drug use but has reportedly been sober for more than 20 years. She lives alone and is a retired school teacher. She has never smoked or consumed alcohol excessively. There is no history of recent travel  dental procedures  or contact with sick individuals.  Medical History:  Notably  she has a past medical history of rheumatic fever as a teenager and was diagnosed with mitral valve stenosis in her late forties. She has been on no medications and her vaccinations are up to date. Additionally  she has mild hypertension and well-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus. She does not have any known drug allergies.  Physical Exam:  On physical examination  she appears fatigued. Vital signs reveal a temperature of 99.9°F  blood pressure of 138/85 mmHg  heart rate of 88 beats per minute  and respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute. A new mid-systolic murmur is appreciated on auscultation. She has several very small  painless red and purple spots on her palms and soles  consistent with Janeway lesions.   Plan:  Given her history and clinical findings  undiagnosed native-valve infective endocarditis is suspected. Her doctors plan to perform further diagnostic tests  including blood cultures and an echocardiogram  to confirm the diagnosis.   Discussion:  Ms. Edwards' demographic details  including age  race  and past medical history of rheumatic fever and mitral stenosis put her at a higher risk for infective endocarditis. The combination of prolonged  unexplained fever  new onset of murmur  and evidence of vascular phenomena (Janeway lesions) in this clinical context strongly suggest infective endocarditis. The plan is to confirm the diagnosis and identify the causative organism to guide further management.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. A is a 55-year-old Hispanic male who presents to the emergency department with recent onset of unexplained fatigue  intermittent fever  and night sweats. He has been previously healthy  with no known past medical history. He has a history of dental problems  had a tooth extraction approximately six weeks ago. He is a smoker with a 20-pack-year history and denies any drug use. On physical examination  he is slightly underweight  febrile  and appears ill. He has a new systolic murmur noted on cardiovascular exam. Skin examination reveals scattered petechiae. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. His blood cultures are positive for Streptococcus viridans. He's been diagnosed with infective endocarditis  likely secondary to poor dental hygiene and dental procedure leading to bacteremia. The smoking history suggests a general lack of attention to health promoting behaviors  aligning with the more common finding of infective endocarditis to be found in individuals who have poor dentition or those who do not receive regular dental care.   This demographic aligns as the proportions of IE patients vary considerably by race and ethnicity  with the largest group from white ethnicity  followed by Hispanics. Men made up the greater part of the population across all age groups and in all regions. Middle-aged patients  particularly those aged 45–64 years  had the highest disease rate of IE.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Richardson is a 64-year-old African American female  who presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of an ongoing fever of one to two weeks duration  associated with chills and fatigue. She reports experiencing a worsening shortness of breath over the past few days  particularly upon exertion.  Her medical history is significant for rheumatic heart disease diagnosed in her 30s and uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has no history of drug abuse. She has been recently diagnosed with severe mitral valve regurgitation and has been advised to undergo surgery. However  she has been non-compliant with her medication regimen and medical appointments due to caring for her ailing husband at home.  On physical examination  she is lethargic  febrile with a temperature of 38.4°C  and mildly tachycardic with a pulse of 101 beats per minute. Cardiovascular examination reveals an early diastolic murmur. Both the spleen and liver are palpable and tender. Unusual skin findings include an erythematous linear streaks on her palms (Janeway lesions) and painful erythematous nodules on her fingertips (Osler's nodes).  Her overall presentation combined with her past medical history of rheumatic heart disease  diabetes  and recent mitral valve pathology  make native-valve infective endocarditis a highly possible diagnosis.

Patient Presentation: Mr. John Baker is a 62-year-old African-American male  a smoker with a history of injection drug use and congestive heart failure  presenting with fatigue  fever  and heart murmur. He reports episodes of persistent  low-grade fever over the last two weeks  unexplained weight loss  night sweats  and increasing fatigue. Additionally  he reports episodes of dyspnea on exertion and increased swelling in his lower extremities. He admits to sporadic adherence to his heart failure medications due to financial constraints. He denies recent antibiotic use.  Recent past medical history includes staged leg amputations secondary to peripheral arterial disease. His vital signs on admission revealed a temperature of 100.5°F  blood pressure of 115/70 mmHg  heart rate of 92 bpm  respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. He is currently unemployed and lives alone. He has a history of substance abuse  with multiple episodes of discontinuing rehabilitation efforts. He is not on regular follow-up with a primary care provider.  On examination  the patient appears cachexic. Cardiac auscultation reveals a grade III/VI systolic ejection murmur and a gallop rhythm. There are splinter hemorrhages present in the nails of his upper and lower extremities  and initial echocardiography reveals vegetations on his native mitral valve.

Subject is a 45-year-old Caucasian male presenting with fever  fatigue  and an irregular heart rhythm. He also reports recent weight loss and night sweats. The patient has a history of intravenous drug use  particularly heroin  and was diagnosed with hepatitis C several months ago.  During physical examination  tenderness was noted in his spleen and Osler's nodes were present on his fingers and toes. A heart murmur was also audible upon cardiac auscultation. As per patient history  he had experienced a few intermittent episodes of fever over the past month but dismissed them as unimportant.  Further inquiry indicated that he had been using drugs via the same needle without swapping or sterilizing between uses. His experience with fever  coupled with his prolonged IV drug misuse  prompts suspicion for native-valve infective endocarditis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Anthony  a 60-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department with complaints of persistent fever of two weeks duration  fatigue  night sweats  and unintended weight loss of about 10 pounds over the last month. He denies any cough  chest pain  shortness of breath  or gastrointestinal symptoms.  He was released from prison 15 days ago after serving time for multiple drug charges. His history is significant for heroin use for which he had been receiving methadone maintenance therapy prior to imprisonment but had relapsed for a short period before his recent release. He also has a known history of rheumatic heart disease and had been non-compliant with penicillin prophylaxis.  On physical examination  he displayed signs of poor dentition. Cardiac examination was significant for a new systolic murmur heard best at the apex which radiated to the axilla. Janeway lesions were noted on the palms and soles  and painless  erythematous Osler’s nodes were seen on his fingers. No peripheral edema  jugular venous distention or hepatosplenomegaly was noted.   Initial investigations including full blood count  inflammatory markers  kidney function tests  liver function tests  and chest X-ray were requested. Blood cultures were also obtained  given the clinical suspicion for infective endocarditis. Echocardiogram was ordered to confirm the diagnosis.    In view of his symptoms  history  and clinical presentation  the provisional diagnosis of infective endocarditis  likely as a result of Staphylococcus aureus infection secondary to intravenous drug use  was made. The patient was admitted for close monitoring and empiric treatment was started with intravenous antibiotics pending blood culture results.   Healthcare teams including cardiology  infectious diseases  and addiction medicine were consulted to manage the patient's endocarditis  underlying heart disease  and substance abuse disorder.   The patient was also educated about the importance of consistent penicillin prophylaxis for his rheumatic heart disease to prevent recurrent endocarditis events and the potential for fatal complications if non-compliance persisted. Methadone was restarted to manage his opioid dependence.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 62-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for intravenous drug use (IVDU)  hypertension  and type II diabetes mellitus. He was brought to the emergency department by his son  complaining of worsening malaise  low-grade fever  and generalized body aches and sweats for the past three weeks. The patient also reported unintentional weight loss  shortness of breath on exertion  and loss of appetite.   On examination  he was found to be febrile with a temperature of 101.2 F  had a new murmur upon cardiac examination  and exhibited multiple needle puncture scars visible on his arms. His other vital signs were stable. Blood cultures were drawn and are currently pending.  He denied any recent visits to the dentist  surgery  or any urinary or gastrointestinal symptoms. He admitted sporadic drug use in the past but denied any recent usage. He is compliant with his antihypertensive and antidiabetic medications. His family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases including his father who had a myocardial infarction at age 55.   The patient's clinical condition along with his notable IVDU history raises a strong suspicion for native-valve infective endocarditis. He has been admitted for further necessary imaging and management.

A 63-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department with a three-week history of intermittent fever  night sweats  weight loss  and progressive weakness. He has a past medical history of diabetes mellitus type 2  hypertension  and a 30-pack year smoking history.  His history further reveals that he had a dental extraction done about 4 weeks ago. His social history reveals a sporadic use of illegal IV drugs in his 20s  but ceased approximately 35 years ago. He does not have any history of intravenous drug use recently. He reports no travel or any sick contacts. On physical examination  he is febrile with a temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°F). Cardiac examination reveals a new murmur noted over the mitral area.  The patient's medical history  physical examination findings  and predisposing factors suggest a possible diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis  likely due to a dental procedure he had recently  since these usually predispose to streptococcal species infections.  This case is an example of the demographics which most commonly present with infectious endocarditis  as according to literature  the disease is most prevalent amongst males  middle-aged and elderly populations  and those with pre-existing heart conditions  diabetes  or a history of drug use  making this a typical patient presentation.

Patient is a 62-year-old African American male presenting to the emergency department complaining of a persistent fever for the past 7 days  associated with exertional shortness of breath and generalized fatigue. He also reports intermittent mild  sharp chest pains not related with exertion along with pale color in fingers and toes when exposed to cold  swollen feet  and unintentional weight loss. He does not complain of nausea  vomiting  abdominal pain  change in bowel or bladder habits  rash  or joint pain. Denies any recent travel  insect bites  animal contact  unusual food or drink  and sick contacts. No recent dental procedures or surgeries.  Past medical history is significant for intravenous drug use  with the most recent use reported 3 weeks prior. He has been in a methadone program for the last 10 years but admits to occasional relapses  the most recent being several weeks ago. He also has a history of uncontrolled Type II Diabetes Mellitus and high blood pressure. Patient reports non-compliance with medications due to financial difficulties. Further  he reports a known history of mitral valve prolapse.  Family history is significant for coronary artery disease in his father. He does not smoke cigarettes and consumes alcohol socially. He is divorced and lives alone. He is unemployed but is actively looking for work. His only known drug allergy is to penicillin  causing a rash.    Based on the symptoms and his history of mitral valve prolapse and intravenous drug use  a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis is suspected.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male  who presented with a 2-week history of gradually worsening fever  night sweats and fatigue. He has noted a loss of appetite with an accompanied weight loss of about 10 pounds during the same period. He does not report any respiratory symptoms  urinary symptoms  rash or joint pains.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of Intravenous Drug Use (IVDU) but he has been in recovery for the last 10 years. He has a past medical history of Hepatitis C infection which was successfully treated. He also has a known history of a bicuspid aortic valve. He has been living with this condition and has been on a regular follow-up with his cardiologist without any significant events or hospitalizations until now. He has never had surgery.  Social History: He is a retired construction worker  currently living alone. He does not drink often but used to smoke a pack of cigarettes a day for about 30 years and quit 5 years ago.   Family History: His both parents suffered from coronary artery disease. His father had a percutaneous coronary intervention at the age of 55 and his mother had cardiac bypass surgery at the age of 58.  On the examination  patient appeared ill and tired. He was febrile with a temperature of 101.5 F  heart rate 96 beats per minute  normal blood pressure  and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. Cardiovascular exam revealed a diastolic murmur best heard at the right second intercostal space. There were no visible skin lesions  Janeway lesions  Osler nodes  Roth spots  or splinter hemorrhages under his nail beds.  This clinical presentation prompts an evaluation for native valve infective endocarditis  given his known cardiac structural abnormality (bicuspid aortic valve)  his constitutional symptoms (fever  malaise  anorexia  weight loss)  his past history of IVDU  and the new cardiac murmur heard upon auscultation.

Patient Presentation:  A 67-year-old Caucasian male presents with a 2-week history of fatigue  night sweats  and unexplained weight loss. He has an intermittent fever not associated with chills or rigors. His maximum recorded temperature at home was 102 F. He also reports an intermittent  non-productive cough and occasional shortness of breath while performing his daily activities.  He has a history of intravenous drug use in his early adulthood and he quit 35 years ago. He is a retired construction worker with no significant history of exposure to carcinogens  dust or any similar agents. He has not undergone any dental procedures recently. He was previously fit and well  with no history of cardiac disease  hypertension  diabetes  or any chronic illness. He quit smoking 20 years ago and consumes alcohol socially. The patient lives with his wife in a suburban house and denies international travel or any recent changes in his lifestyle or diet.  Examination reveals frailty  weight loss  pallor  mild pitting edema of the lower extremities  and digital clubbing. Cardiovascular examination demonstrates a new  soft diastolic murmur heard better at the aortic area. The remainder of the examination is mitigative. Given his past history particularly IVDU  the new murmur  and his constellation of symptoms  a suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis was raised.    Relevant Past Medical History:   The patient has history of intravenous drug use in his earlier life but has been clean for the past 35 years with no other significant past medical history. He is a non-smoker and does not have history of diabetes or hypertension. He denies having any known cardiac issues in the past.

Patient Profile:  Mr. Sanchez  a 58-year-old Hispanic male  presents to the emergency department with complaints of high-grade fever  chills  malaise  and shortness of breath  particularly on exertion  which has been progressively getting worse over the past two weeks. He also reports weight loss and decreased appetite. There is no history of recent travel  but reports a sporadic cough with occasional sputum production.  Occupation: Janitor at Public School  Lifestyle: Smoker (15 cigarettes/day for the last 30 years)  low level of physical activity  alcohol use moderate.   Past Medical History: Mr. Sanchez has a known mitral valve prolapse  which is managed with monitoring and lifestyle modifications. He also has type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with metformin and lifestyle modifications  chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) managed with inhaled steroids  and hypertension controlled with lisinopril.   Family History:  There is a family history of cardiovascular disease  with his father having had a myocardial infarction in his early 60s.  Medication: Metformin  Inhaled steroids  Lisinopril.  Immunization history: Routine vaccinations are all up to date except for pneumococcal vaccine.  Physical Examination: He is febrile (Temperature  101.3°F)  tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 22/min  Blood Pressure 130/85 mmHg  and pulse is 92 beats/min.  There is a mid-systolic click and late systolic murmur on cardiac auscultation. The chest is clear to auscultation  but there are some crackles in the lower zones bilaterally. There appears to be a petechial rash on his extremities  but no osler nodes or janeway lesions.  This case would warrant further investigation  including blood cultures and echocardiography  to confirm the diagnosis of possible infective endocarditis in this patient with native valve disease.  He will likely need intravenous antibiotics  and possibly surgical intervention  based on the findings of these investigations.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 65-year-old African American male with a history of intravenous drug use (IVDU)  chronic Hepatitis C  and untreated dental disease  presenting with a 3-week history of fatigue  low-grade fever  and unexplained weight loss. He reports experiencing night sweats and on-and-off small joint pains during this period. He denies any recent dental procedures  IV drug use  or needle sharing in the past 6 months.  The patient lives in an urban setting and has been abstinent from IVDU for the past 6 months. His Hepatitis C was diagnosed 10 years ago and he has been intermittently compliant with antiviral therapy. He has no known allergies. Previous blood tests revealed mild anemia and elevated liver function tests  consistent with his chronic hepatitis C. He is currently unemployed and lives with his girlfriend. He has limited health-literacy skills and intermittent access to medical care.  He admits to being a chronic heavy alcohol drinker up until 6 months ago when he also quit alcohol consumption along with drugs. He is a non-smoker and denies any travel history. His current medications include sofosbuvir for Hepatitis C.  On examination  his vital signs reveal a low-grade fever of 38.2°C  heart rate 90 beats/min  blood pressure 120/70 mmHg  respiratory rate 18 breaths/min  and oxygen saturation 97% on room air. He appears fatigued. Oral examination reveals poor dentition. Cardiovascular examination identifies a new grade 3/6 diastolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. Lungs are clear to auscultation and he has good peripheral perfusion. Examination of his joints reveal mild tenderness over his hands and knees but no visible or palpable lesions.  Given his history  physical examination and the characteristic symptoms  there is a suspicion for native-valve infective endocarditis. An EKG is ordered and blood cultures are drawn prior to initiating empiric antibiotic therapy.

Patient Presentation:  Francis  a 60-year-old Caucasian male presents to the Emergency Department complaining of fatigue  shortness of breath  night sweats  low-grade fever  and unintentional weight loss over the past six weeks.   Francis reports an extensive history of drug abuse  especially intravenous (IV) drug use  but claims to have been clean for the past five years. He is a tobacco user and consumes alcohol casually. In terms of relevant medical history  he was diagnosed with Hepatitis C  likely from his history of IV drug use. His history also reveals previous hospital admissions for episodes of pneumonia and sepsis.   Francis has not been compliant with regular healthcare follow-ups and his immunizations are not updated. He does not have known heart conditions and his family history is not significant for cardiac diseases.  This prolonged and non-specific presentation  along with his medical history  raises the suspicion of infective endocarditis  likely native-valve given his lack of prior cardiac surgery or prosthetic valve.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of intravenous drug use and untreated dental decay. The most common causative organism of native valve endocarditis are Streptococcus viridans and Staphylococcus aureus  both of which often arise from oral or skin sources  respectively. The patient was previously diagnosed with chronic hepatitis C due to intravenous drug use  however  he claims to have been clean for the past year. Despite this  he cannot remember the last time he visited a dentist.  He arrived at the clinic reporting symptoms of malaise  weight loss  and night sweats. He stated these symptoms have been in progress for several weeks. The patient has also experienced low-grade fever and a new onset of heart murmur. He describes having intermittent shortness of breath and generalized fatigue. He noted that the symptoms were gradually increasing  causing him to seek medical attention.  The patient does not produce any ongoing symptoms of drug withdrawal. He appears oriented and cooperative  but he looks chronically ill and unusually weary. Physical examination reveals petechiae in the conjunctiva and nail beds  Osler's nodes on his fingers and toes  and Roth spots in his eyes. A cardiac examination revealed a new systolic murmur at the apex radiating to the axilla  suggesting mitral regurgitation.  With the patient's age  history of intravenous drug use  oral neglect  and presenting symptoms  the suspicion for native-valve infective endocarditis rises. His medical history of Hepatitis C and intravenous drug use put him at a higher risk of endocarditis due to possible skin or blood contaminations. Further investigations including blood cultures and an echocardiogram will be necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Joseph Alvarado is a 60-year-old Hispanic male presenting to the clinic with concerns about persistent  low-grade fevers over the past four weeks. In addition to the fevers  Mr. Alvarado has noticed increasing fatigue  night sweats  and reports an unintentional weight loss of approximately 10 pounds in the same period. He also complains of a new-onset  diffuse myalgia.   Mr. Alvarado has a significant medical history  including longstanding poorly-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus  which he manages with metformin  and a 20 pack-year history of smoking. He also reports a history of intravenous drug use in his 20s and 30s  but states that he has been sober for over 20 years.  On physical examination  Mr. Alvarado is noted to be febrile with a temperature of 38.5 degrees Celsius. He exhibits pallor  and there are splinter hemorrhages noted in his nails. On auscultation  a new murmur is heard over the left upper sternal border. An echocardiogram is ordered  which shows vegetations on the mitral valve consistent with native-valve infective endocarditis.  His blood cultures are positive for Staphylococcus aureus  a likely result of his prior intravenous drug use. His Hemoglobin A1c is found to be 9.0%  suggesting poor glycemic control over the past few months.    Note: The demographic details provided align with population-based studies indicating that infective endocarditis is more common in males  in individuals with a history of intravenous drug use and those with diabetes. Endocarditis also has a bimodal distribution  with one peak in young adults who use intravenous drugs and a second peak in older adults  particularly those with a history of heart disease or diabetes.

Subject is a 50-year-old Caucasian male  named Mr. A. He works as a construction worker and has a history of intravenous drug use (IVDU)  which he quit 5 years back. He presents with a two-week history of persistent fever  night sweats  and weight loss. Mr. A has a previous medical history of Hepatitis C  presumably related to his past IVDU.  In the past few weeks  he noted increasing fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion.  He also experienced a loss of appetite leading to substantial weight loss. Mr. A observed a new-onset rash on his extremities that he described as tiny reddish-purple spots.  He has had no recent dental procedures done or any known prior history of heart disease. However  he used to have spontaneous bleeding gums for which he failed to seek medical attention.   The family history is non-contributory  with no known genetic conditions or any heart diseases. He is a former smoker  having quit at the same time as his drug use. He occasionally consumes alcohol but has no known food or drug allergies.  Physical examination revealed the presence of a new cardiac murmur  Janeway lesions  and splinter hemorrhages under the nails. These are all suggestive of infective endocarditis. Further investigations  including blood cultures and echocardiogram  are warranted to confirm the diagnosis. It is suspected that Mr. A's history of IVDU and poor oral health may be significant contributing factors to his current condition.

Patient Profile:  Mr. Johnson  a 45-year-old African-American male  reports to the emergency department with complaints of fever  chills  malaise  and a new onset of heart murmur which has persisted for the last three weeks. He also reports experiencing unintended weight loss and occasional night sweats.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a long history of illicit drug use and has previously been hospitalized for drug overdose. He admits to using intravenous drugs  primarily heroin  and has been through several detox and rehab programs over the years without success. His other significant past medical history includes Hepatitis C infection  which was diagnosed five years ago and is currently being managed. He also has a history of recurrent skin abscesses  thought to be related to his intravenous drug use. He does not have any known allergies.  Vital signs:  His vital signs on arrival are: Temperature: 38.4°C  Blood pressure: 105/70 mmHg  Pulse rate: 112 bpm  Respiratory rate: 18 breaths/minute  and Oxygen saturation: 94% on room air.  Physical Examination:  Physical examination reveals pale and slightly jaundiced skin  with multiple needle track marks seen on both arms. Cardiac auscultation reveals a diastolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. There are no visible signs of any extracardiac manifestations of infective endocarditis such as Osler nodes  Janeway lesions  or Roth spots. The rest of the physical examination is essentially unremarkable.  Given Mr. Johnson's history of intravenous drug use and other features consistent with infective endocarditis  he was immediately admitted for further evaluation and treatment. A complete blood count showed leukocytosis and anemia. Blood cultures have been sent to the lab and transesophageal echocardiography is planned to check for vegetations and other signs of endocarditis. Antibiotics have been initiated according to the guidelines.

A 63-year-old African American male presents with symptoms of fever  chills  night sweats  fatigue  and unintentional weight loss over the duration of 3 weeks. He also complains of shortness of breath  chest discomfort  swelling in his feet and loss of appetite. He describes a dull ache in his right side  below the ribs. The patient has a history of intravenous drug use in his past but reports being clean for the last 15 years.   His medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus  and chronic hepatitis C infection  which is stable and managed with medication. He also has a known history of mitral valve regurgitation diagnosed 10 years ago for which he is on watchful waiting  and a 40-pack-year smoking history. He has known hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both managed with medications  and his current medications include metformin  lisinopril and atorvastatin.  On physical examination  the patient appears in mild distress and diaphoretic. There's a noticeable heart murmur on cardiac auscultation. There are a cluster of painless  erythematous lesions on his palms and soles (Janeway lesions) and a few small painful nodes (Osler's nodes) on his fingers  suggesting peripheral emboli and microabscesses.  Initial lab findings show elevated ESR and CRP levels suggestive of an inflammatory response  and three separate blood cultures taken 1 hour apart have tested positive for Staphylococcus aureus.   This patient's demographic details  history of mitral regurgitation and presentation are coherent with those of a typical patient presenting with native-valve infective endocarditis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Franco Joseph  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the Emergency Department with a 2-week history of intermittent fever  unexplained weight loss  and generalized malaise. He reports a low-grade fever primarily in the late afternoon and evening  sweats  fatigue  and a loss of approximately 4kg over the last month. He denies recent travel or exposure to sick contacts.  Mr. Joseph has a past medical history significant for bi-leaflet mechanical aortic valve replacement 10 years ago secondary to aortic stenosis  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hypertension. He is a retired construction worker and a current smoker with a 40 pack-year history.  On examination  his vital signs are within normal limits with the exception of a temperature of 38.3 degrees Celsius. Physical examination reveals a holosystolic murmur heard loudest at the aortic area along with several small erythematous lesions on his palms and soles  consistent with Janeway lesions. His dental examinations showed several large cavities with notable dental decay.  Given the presentation and history  there is a high clinical suspicion for infective endocarditis. Blood cultures have been sent  and the patient has been started empirically on antibiotic therapy while awaiting culture results. He is currently awaiting transthoracic echocardiogram to confirm vegetation on his aortic valve.

Patient Presentation:  A 60-year-old Hispanic male presents with a 10-day history of progressive malaise  intermittent fever up to 101.5°F  night sweats  and a recent onset of shortness of breath. The fever is associated with chills and decreased appetite but no cough or changes in bowel or bladder habits. The patient also reports a 15-pound unintentional weight loss over the past two months.   Patient Demographic and History:  The patient is a former construction worker; currently unemployed  living together with his wife and children. He is a current smoker with a 30-pack year history and occasionally drinks alcohol on weekends. He denies illicit drug use.  His past medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He has no history of intravenous (IV) drug abuse  dental work  or recent bodily injuries. He never had a rheumatic fever or any allergies. There is no family history of heart diseases.   Patient's medications include metformin  losartan  and atorvastatin. His vital signs today show a temperature of 101.3°F  heart rate of 100 beats per minute  blood pressure of 134/85 mmHg  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. On examination  a systolic murmur grade II/VI was detected  and three small  painless  erythematous lesions were noted on his palms. His lungs are clear to auscultation.  Based on the clinical presentation  the working diagnosis is native-valve infective endocarditis  likely associated with his long history of smoking and potential progression of subclinical atherosclerosis. Blood cultures and transthoracic echocardiogram have been ordered to confirm the diagnosis. He was also advised to quit smoking and limit alcohol intake. Despite the lack of IV drug abuse or recent invasive procedures  his clinical presentation and risk factors (diabetes  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  cigarette smoking) raise a high suspicion for infective endocarditis. He was immediately started on empiric IV antibiotic therapy.

Patient Presentation:  A 62-year-old Caucasian male patient presented at the emergency department with a two-week history of generalized fatigue  increased malaise  poor appetite  and a new unset of shortness of breath during daily activities. The patient reported an intermittent low-grade fever up to 100.5°F and unexplained 5kg weight loss within the last month. He also mentioned experiencing night sweats  but did not notice any skin changes or visual disturbances.  Yearly screenings  including echo-cardiography  have been unremarkable until now. The patient's pertinent past medical history includes a 10-year history of type II Diabetes Mellitus- adequately controlled with Metformin  essential hypertension- well managed with Lisinopril  and tobacco use disorder for the past 30 years though he quit smoking 5 years ago. The patient has no known drug allergies or prior surgeries.  The patient's family history is significant for cardiovascular disease in his father  who had a myocardial infarction at 65 years of age.   He recently had a dental procedure done 1 month ago- root canal treatment  after which he did not take any antibiotic prophylaxis.  Considering the reported ongoing symptoms of likely systemic infection and the recent invasive dental procedure  the provider is suspicious of the patient possibly having native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 60-year-old Caucasian male comes to the clinic with complaints of fever (38.5 °C)  chills  and fatigue over the past two weeks. Patient also mentions experiencing a notable weight loss—about 6lbs over the past month—without any intentional diet or exercise changes. He has a history of intravenous drug use up until his early 40s and currently smokes cigarettes (half a pack daily for the last 35 years). Past medical history includes Hepatitis C  effectively treated about 15 years ago  hypertension  and a mild heart murmur detected in his 50s  but no history of valve disease. He takes Lisinopril daily for hypertension control. The patient also admits to maintaining poor dental hygiene.  Upon examination  he appears weak and has notable paleness. Vital signs report a heart rate of 98 beats per minute  blood pressure at 145/92 mmHg  and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. Heart examination reveals a grade III/VI mid-diastolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border. Upon further inspection  there are also minor petechiae on his anterior chest and shoulders. Laboratory blood tests have been ordered for the patient to explore a potential diagnosis  including blood cultures  given his symptoms and history  the possibility of infective endocarditis is considered. This falls in line with published data suggesting that the majority of patients with infective endocarditis are men  of white race  and often have a history of intravenous drug use.

Patient Presentation:  A 62-year-old African American male patient  Mr. J  walks into the clinic with complaints of recurring fevers  unexplained weight loss of around 10 pounds over the last two months  fatigue  muscle joint pains  and night sweats. The fever is intermittent and high grade  recorded up to 101°F in the last two weeks. Mr. J is a smoker with a 20 pack-year history and is a retired long-distant lorry driver. He has a documented history of mild hypertension  for which he has been on and off anti-hypertensives. He mentions an untreated dental infection approximately 6 months ago.  Upon physical examination  there are Osler’s nodes on his fingers and toes  Janeway lesions on the palms and soles  and splinter hemorrhages under the nails.
