There's no history of invasive medical procedures or IV drug use. On basic lab studies  markers of inflammation (CRP  ESR) are elevated  and microcytic anemia is noted. Blood tests reveal positive blood cultures for Streptococcus viridans. Further Echocardiography shows vegetation on the mitral valve with mild regurgitation.   Taking account of the clinical presentation  examination findings  and investigation results  Mr. J has a diagnosis consistent with Native Valve Infective Endocarditis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Rodriguez is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of rheumatic heart disease  hypertension  and type 2 diabetes  presented to the hospital with a one-month history of low-grade fever  fatigue and weight loss of around 15 pounds. Upon further questioning  he also reported experiencing night sweats  loss of appetite  and occasional dyspnea.   Mr. Rodriguez is a retired construction worker who lives with his wife. He has a 40-pack year smoking history and drinks alcohol socially  but denies any use of illicit drugs. He has a family history of heart disease and diabetes. Mr. Rodriguez is compliant with his antihypertensive and antidiabetic medications. He reports he was diagnosed with rheumatic fever in his adolescence  but hasn't had any valve-related symptoms since.  On physical examination  he is febrile (temperature 100.7°F)  with a blood pressure of 125/80 mmHg  pulse rate of 88 bpm  and respiratory rate of 18 breaths/minute. Cardiac inspection reveals a regurgitant flow murmur. He is noted to have small erythematous lesions on his fingertips suggestive of Osler's nodes  and the examination of the retina shows Roth spots.   Based on these clinical findings  a diagnosis of possible native-valve infective endocarditis is considered. The patient is recommended to undergo further diagnostic evaluation  including blood cultures and transthoracic echocardiogram. He is hospitalized and started on empiric antibiotic therapy.

Patient Presentation  Mr. James is a 58-year-old African-American male  presented to the emergency department  complaining of sudden onset of fatigue  mild chest discomfort  irregular heartbeat  shortness of breath  and nightly sweats for the past two weeks. He is a known smoker and has been consuming alcohol heavily for the last 10 years. Probability of drug use could not be ruled out. He also reported unintentional weight loss of 8 pounds over the last month. On physical examination  his vital signs revealed a low-grade fever (100.4°F)  tachycardia (heart rate 110 bpm)  and mild hypertension (BP 145/90 mmHg). Small red or purple spots on the skin called petechiae were also observed.   His past medical history is notable for uncontrolled diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and chronic kidney disease for which he is under regular medication. He has a history of dental procedures without prophylactic antibiotics. His family history revealed that his father had rheumatic heart disease and his mother was diagnosed with cancer. He worked as a construction worker and has a history of occupational exposure to asbestos. He does not have any known contacting history of other communicable diseases.   Based on the clinical findings and the underlying comorbid patients' condition  the initial clinical impression is of native valve infective endocarditis. Further diagnostic tests including blood cultures  echocardiogram were ordered to confirm the clinical diagnosis and to assess the seriousness or complications of the disease. He was also referred for chest X-rays and kidney function tests due to his underlying diabetes and CKD. Other differential diagnoses to be ruled out are myocarditis  rheumatic heart disease  and aortic stenosis.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 63-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and intravenous drug use (IVDU) in his youth. He presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with progressive generalized weakness and malaise  periodic fever with chills occurring over the last 2 weeks. He further reports intermittent night sweats and unexplained weight loss during this period. He denies any recent travel  animal exposures  or known tick bites. Patient reported an episode of blood-in-urine a week ago  though the symptom has not recurred.  On physical examination  the patient appears fatigued and mildly tachycardic. He has notable pallor  but no signs of jaundice or lymphadenopathy. Cardiac exam reveals a new grade III/VI systolic murmur that is most prominent at the apex. Small erythematous  tender nodules were found on his fingers and toes (Osler's nodes) and splinter hemorrhages were observed under the nails. There was no evidence of peripheral edema or ascites.  Overall  the patient's presentation  combined with his personal medical history of IVDU and chronic diseases  is suggestive of a possible diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. The patient was admitted to the hospital and further investigations including blood cultures and echocardiogram were ordered to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Martinez  a 58-year-old Hispanic male  presents to the emergency department complaining of intermittent fevers  fatigue  and unintended weight loss over the past few weeks. The patient also reports a recent onset of exertional dyspnea and occasional night sweats.   Mr. Martinez has an extensive medical history which includes Rheumatic heart disease from his childhood  and he was diagnosed with Type-2 diabetes 10 years ago managed on oral hypoglycemic agents. He tells us that he missed his last cardiology follow-up appointment due to COVID-19 fears. He is compliant with his medications  does not smoke  drinks a glass of wine occasionally  and denies recreational drug use.   On physical examination  he appeared ill  with a low-grade fever (38°C) and tachycardia. Auscultation revealed a new harsh grade 3/6 systolic murmur best heard over the mitral region. Subconjunctival hemorrhages were noticed on ocular examination  and nailbed splinter hemorrhages were seen  suggestive of systemic emboli.    Considering his clinical presentation as well as his significant medical history  infective endocarditis is on top of my differential list. He will need some more diagnostic workup which includes blood culture and an echocardiogram. Mr. Martinez might need to be admitted  and possibly started on empirical antibiotic therapy while waiting for blood culture results.

A 67-year-old African American male  Mr. B  presents with a one-week history of persistent unexplained fevers  fatigue  and a new heart murmur. A retired engineer living in an urban area  the patient has a past medical history significant for chronic rheumatoid arthritis  for which he has taken methotrexate for the last 15 years. He also recently underwent dental extraction due to a dental caries about 2 months ago. He has a past long-term tobacco use has quit smoking ten years ago. He denies any recreational drug use.  On physical examination  he is febrile with a temperature of 38.7°C  blood pressure is stable at 118/78mmHg  heart rate is elevated at 102 bpm  and respiratory rate is normal at 18 breaths/min. Cardiac examination reveals a new diastolic murmur.   He was up-to-date on all immunizations. He lives with his wife  and their building has no reported cases of any infections. Mr. B denies traveling outside the country since retirement. His family history includes hypertension in both parents. His dietary habits are weighed towards high-protein  low-carb mostly.  No history of hospitalizations or major surgeries apart from dental procedures. He is overall  an active person who enjoys exercising regularly and has been feeling weak due to his current symptoms  an unusual occurrence. His medications include methotrexate and occasional over-the-counter NSAIDs for arthritic pain. He is compliant to his medications. He denies any known drug allergies.  Given his presentation  and coupled with his recent dental procedure  a differential diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis was considered. Blood cultures were drawn  and empiric antibiotic therapy was initiated. An echocardiography is scheduled to confirm the diagnosis and evaluate the extent of disease.

Patient Presentation:  A 60-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department with a 3-week history of intermittent fever spikes of unknown origin  accompanied by fatigue  night sweats  weight loss  joint aches  and a new-onset persistent cough. He was brought to the hospital by his daughter  about a week after his symptoms worsened  including apparent confusion and some difficulty speaking at times.   The patient is a retired construction worker  living in a rustic environment. He has a medical history of mild hypertension managed with diet and lifestyle modifications. He smokes a pack of cigarettes per day for many years and consumes alcohol on social occasions. He also admits to having poor dental health with recurrent dental infections over the past few years; however  he has not sought dental treatment due to limited resources.  Physical examination reveals low-grade fever of 37.8°C  a heart rate of 100 bpm  and blood pressure of 140/85 mm Hg. He looks fatigued and mildly disoriented during the consultation. Oral examination shows poor dentition and multiple tooth caries. Auscultation of the heart reveals a new diastolic murmur. Neurological examination demonstrates slight dysarthria  but no other focal neurological deficits.   These findings prompted further investigations  which include blood cultures and cardiac imaging  to evaluate the possibility of infective endocarditis  taking into consideration his risk factors including poor dental hygiene and recurrent dental infections  as well as symptomatology and examination findings suggestive of the condition.

A 60-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with complaints of intermittent fevers  weakness  night sweats  weight loss over the past four weeks  and newly onset dyspnea on exertion. The patient has a history of intravenous drug abuse  but he has been abstinent for over ten years. Past medical history is significant for hypertension  managed with Lisinopril  and a dental procedure 6 weeks ago requiring antibiotics due to a history of mitral valve prolapse. Family history is unremarkable. He denies any recent travel or exposure to sick contacts.   On physical examination  the patient appears ill and in moderate respiratory distress. Vital signs reveal tachycardia and a fever of 100.8°F. Cardiovascular exam reveals a new murmur heard best at the apex  suggestive of mitral regurgitation. Skin exam was significant for few petechiae noted on the lower extremities.   Initial laboratory results show elevated inflammatory markers  including C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Blood cultures were drawn and sent for testing. Considering the high suspicion for infective endocarditis  the patient was admitted for inpatient management and further diagnostic workup  including a transthoracic echocardiogram.   The patient was started empirically on vancomycin and ceftriaxone pending final blood culture results. His dyspnea improved significantly with initial management  and he remained hemodynamically stable. The case was discussed with the Cardiology team regarding further management strategy  depending on the echocardiography findings and culture results.

The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired long-haul truck driver  who presents with a 4-week history of intermittent fever up to 101.6°F (38.7°C)  unintended weight loss of 15 pounds  malaise  and night sweats. The symptoms have gradually increased in severity over the past month. He also noticed blood in his urine two days before his visit to the clinic.   His history is significant for moderate dental decay  and he had a root canal performed about 5 weeks ago at a local dentist's office. He has also a long-standing history of rheumatoid arthritis for which he takes methotrexate. He has no known allergies and is a former smoker who quit 20 years ago  and he does not consume alcohol or illicit drugs. His family history is relevant for coronary artery disease in his father and brother  both of whom had heart attacks in their mid-60s.  On physical examination  he appears slightly pale and fatigued but is oriented and answers questions directed at him. He has a mild systolic murmur  pale conjunctivae  multiple splinter hemorrhages in his nails  and small spots on his hands and feet  which were indicative of Janeway lesions and Osler nodes. His vital signs show a temperature of 101.1°F (38.4°C)  heart rate of 95 beats per minute  blood pressure of 132/78 mmHg  respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 96% on room air.   Based on the available information  a working diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis has raised and further confirmatory investigations are opted for.

Patient Presentation:  I am seeing Mr. José Méndez  a 58-year-old Hispanic male  who presents to the clinic today accompanied by his wife  complaining of a two-week history of intermittent fever  unexplained weight loss of about 5 pounds in the next month  periodic night sweats  and noticeably increasing fatigue.   Past medical history revealed that he had a dental procedure approximately three weeks ago  from which he developed a tooth abscess. His medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type 2  which is poorly controlled  and chronic periodontitis. Mr. Méndez is a former smoker quit 10 years ago and does not drink alcohol. He does not have any allergies and is currently on Metformin for his diabetes management. He has no significant family history of any cardiac or autoimmune diseases.  He has had no prior history of intravenous drug use or any incidence of STDs. He has a small-income job and is insured under his wife's work insurance. His dental procedure was performed at the local county clinic since he does not have dental insurance. While Mr. Méndez did receive prophylactic antibiotics  the persistent tooth abscess and his poor oral hygiene could have served as a source for bacterial infection that might have potentially seeded his heart valves  given the temporal association of his symptoms.   On physical examination  he appears chronically ill. Temperature is 38.2 degrees Celsius. There were also Osler's nodes on his fingers' pads and Janeway lesions over his palms  indicative of end organ damage secondary to septicemia. Cardiac auscultation revealed a new-onset murmur over the mitral area. There was no peripheral edema observed. The rest of the examination was normal.  Based on his presentation  history  and physical examination findings  native valve infective endocarditis is a consideration  more common in males and those with poor dentition or invasive dental procedures. Further investigation is needed to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient: Mr. Raymond  a 56-year-old African American male  presents to the Emergency Department (ED) with complaints of high-grade fever  malaise  and myalgia  persisting for over a week. He reports recently experiencing night sweats and a noticeable weight loss. He notes that his symptoms have gradually worsened  prompting his visit to the ED. The patient appears ill  is notably diaphoretic  and looks chronically unwell.  His past medical history is significant for intravenous (IV) drug use  being clean for the past eight years. He also discloses a 30-year history of heavy tobacco use but claims to have quit five years prior. Raymond reveals a known history of chronic Hepatitis C infection  but HIV test was negative two years ago. He denies any known history of heart disease.   Raymond directly states that he has not recently traveled outside his local area  has not been hospitalized  undergone surgery  or received any type of invasive procedure in the past year. He denies any known dental problems in the recent past.   This history  combined with his ongoing febrile state and previous IV drug use  elevates the concern for the possibility of native valve infective endocarditis  despite his prolonged abstinence from drugs.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the clinic complaining of fatigue  low-grade fevers  and night sweats persisting for the past six weeks. The patient claims he has also been experiencing an unintentional weight loss of about 6 pounds in this time. More recently  over the last week  he describes intermittent shortness of breath and a new-onset decline in exercise tolerance.   Past Medical History:  He has a known medical history of degenerative mitral valve disease diagnosed 5 years ago  for which he has been on watchful waiting per his cardiologist. He also suffers from type 2 diabetes mellitus  managed with metformin  and has a 20-pack-year smoking history  although he reportedly quit smoking fifteen years ago. There is no history of intravenous drug use.  Family History:  There is a family history of cardiac diseases  with his father who passed away at the age of 62 due to myocardial infarction. He has a brother diagnosed with coronary artery disease at 55.  Social Demographics:  The patient is retired and previously worked as a warehouse manager. He lives with his wife and reports occasional alcohol consumption. He has no travel history in the last year  and there were no recent changes in his medications  diet habits  or exercise routine.  Concern:  Given his previous mitral valve disease and diabetic status  the patient’s presentation raises concerns for possible native-valve infective endocarditis. Further diagnostic evaluation  including blood cultures and echocardiography  is necessary. The patient should be educated about the signs and symptoms of infective endocarditis and the importance of maintaining good oral hygiene to prevent possible valvular infections.

Patient Presentation  The patient is a 66-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the clinic complaining of a three-week history of fever  nighttime sweats  generalized fatigue  a recent occurrence of a rash on the palms and soles  and sudden weight loss of 5 kilograms over the last month without any intention of losing weight.  His past medical history includes type II diabetes mellitus  high blood pressure  and a recorded mitral valve prolapse with mild mitral regurgitation diagnosed 2 years ago. He does not have a history of IV drug use  and has no history of valve replacement surgery.   There are no known allergies. He has been on metformin and ramipril for the past ten years. He has a 40 pack-year history of smoking and quit 2 years ago. He drinks alcohol socially and denies any illicit drug use. He is a retired teacher  lives with his wife  and is up to date on all immunizations.   On his last visit one year ago  the physical exam was normal except for audible mitral valve ""click"" on auscultation of the heart. A repeat echocardiogram was suggested but the patient did not follow up.  On today's physical examination  blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg  heart rate is 98 bpm  temperature is 38.5C. Cardiac auscultation reveals a new grade III/VI systolic murmur best heard at the apex with radiation to the axilla  and scattered petechiae on his palms and soles. His oral health is poor with several missing and decaying teeth.    This patient's demographics  extended history of heart disease  and combination of symptoms might suggest a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. Blood cultures  ECG and a transthoracic echocardiogram have been ordered to establish diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department with a two-week history of intermittent fever and chills  malaise  and progressive shortness of breath. Mr. Doe is a retiree and lives with his wife. They have a pet dog at home.  Mr. Doe is a former smoker  has a history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus  and was diagnosed with aortic stenosis 10 years ago. His father also had heart disease. He has no known drug allergies. Medications include metformin and occasional over-the-counter ibuprofen for arthritis pain.  Mr. Doe reports a dental procedure performed about a month ago. He denies using intravenous drugs or having recent tattoos. He hasn't traveled recently and has never received a blood transfusion.  On physical examination  Mr. Doe appears fatigued and mildly in distress. His vitals on admission include a temperature of 38.6°C (101.5°F)  heart rate 110 bpm  blood pressure 130/80 mm Hg  respiratory rate 20 bpm  and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Cardiac exam reveals a new murmur consistent with aortic regurgitation and there are petechiae on his palms and soles.   This raises clinical suspicion for native valve infective endocarditis in the context of his recent dental procedure and chronic heart disease. An urgent transthoracic echocardiogram is recommended.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 60-year-old African American male  presenting to the emergency department with a week-long history of persistent fever  chills  night sweats  and unintentional weight loss. Recently  he also began experiencing shortness of breath and a mild  dull chest discomfort.  John has a past medical history of rheumatic heart disease following a streptococcal infection in his childhood. He also has a 20-year history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus  and he underwent a dental procedure 2 weeks ago.  On physical examination  Mr. Smith looks generally unwell and has a high-grade fever of 39.3°C. Auscultation of the heart reveals a new holosystolic murmur in the mitral area. Additionally  a few petechial rashes are seen disseminated on his lower extremities. His oral hygiene is noticeably poor.  Following suspicion of infective endocarditis  further workup reveals positive blood cultures growing Streptococcus viridans. An echocardiogram confirms large vegetation on his mitral valve  strengthening the diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis. He’s admitted for intravenous antibiotic treatment and further evaluation for possible valve replacement surgery.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 50-year-old African American male who arrived at the clinic stating that he's been experiencing a fever of 101.5°F  chills and night sweats for the past two weeks. Besides the fever  he has also been experiencing shortness of breath and unexplained weight loss. He rates his fatigue as a 6 out of 10 over the past few days. On physical examination  he presented with a heart murmur. He appeared fatigued  but the rest of his physical examination was unremarkable.  His past medical history is significant for a bicuspid aortic valve discovered about 5 years prior. Besides this  he was generally a healthy social worker who stated he had no recent travel history  no illicit drug use  no history of sexually transmitted diseases  or hepatitis. He does not smoke or drink alcohol and his family history was non-contributory.  This patient's high persistent fever  night sweats  heart murmur  and the fact that he has a bicuspid aortic valve places him at high risk for native valve infective endocarditis. Other symptoms like fatigue  weight loss and shortness of breath can also be manifestations of this condition. This clinical scenario is suggestive of an infective endocarditis case.   Literature shows that the mortality rate for endocarditis is higher in African Americans  therefore early detection and intervention for Mr. Smith's case could greatly improve his prognosis. Considering his risk factors and presentation  further investigations would be required to confirm the diagnosis and plan treatment for infective endocarditis.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Anita  a 60-year-old Caucasian female  presents to the hospital emergency department. She has been feeling progressively tired for the last week and reports a constant  low-grade fever for about 5 days. Anita was previously diagnosed with rheumatic heart disease in her youth and has had a history of intravenous drug use in her 40's (no current substance misuse). She also has a known mitral valve prolapse.  Over the last 6 months  she’s lost a considerable amount of weight and has reduced her alcohol consumption due 'just not enjoying it anymore'. She dismissed the fatigue and weight loss as part of ageing  but the persistent fever has concerned her. She insists she hasn't been overseas nor has she been in touch with anyone ill recently.  Initial examination showed BP 144/90 with a resting heart rate of 105 bpm. Physical examination reveals pallor  splinter hemorrhages in her nails  and a new murmur on auscultation. Blood tests show elevated inflammatory markers.  Given her history and presenting symptoms  a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis is suspected in Anita. An echocardiogram is ordered to confirm.

Patient Presentation  Ms. Jones is a 63 year-old African American female patient presenting to the ER with complaints of a new onset fever  chills  malaise and progressive fatigue over the last two weeks. History indicates a change in heart murmur  anorexia and weight loss. Past medical history is significant for long-standing untreated rheumatic heart disease  with known mitral valve regurgitation. She does not smoke or consume alcohol. She is originally from a low-income neighborhood  and leads a sedentary lifestyle.  With regards to her family history  her father died of complications from heart disease. On clinical examination  she has pale pallor  petechiae over extremities and conjunctival hemorrhage. Cardiac examination reveals a previously known systolic murmur and there is a new found diastolic murmur consistent with aortic regurgitation. Fundoscopy examination reveals Roth spots. She is hemodynamically stable but looks chronically ill.   Given the overall clinical presentation  differential diagnosis includes native valve bacterial infective endocarditis. Urgent complete blood work including blood cultures  ESR  CRP and echocardiography to identify vegetation over valve is suggested. Ms. Jones has been admitted to the hospital for close monitoring  supportive care and the initiation of empiric antimicrobial therapy.

Patient Information: A 62-year-old Asian male  living in a urban area  with a history of intravenous drug use  Chief Complaint: Persistent fever for the last two weeks  loss of appetite  weight loss  and fatigue  History of Present Illness:  The patient reports having fever persisting for a couple of weeks despite taking over-the-counter medications. The fever is of moderate intensity  reaching to a maximum of 38.5°C  and is associated with night sweats. Additionally  he is experiencing loss of appetite  weight loss of ~5 kg over a month  and increased fatigue. He also complains of occasional night cough and has noticed some red spots on his skin recently.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of intravenous drug use  and positive for hepatitis C. No history of diabetes  hypertension or congenital heart conditions. No allergies known to any medications.  Family History: Father had coronary artery disease and passed away in his early 70s. Mother is alive and well.  Social History:  Patient potentially lives alone as a divorcee  works as a software engineer  has a history of intravenous drug use though he states he is trying to quit. Smokes half a pack a day for about 20 years.  Review of Systems: On further inquiry  the patient also admitted to experiencing occasional chest pains and palpitations.  Physical Exam: Patient displays mild pallor. Observable petechiae on his lower and upper extremities. Bilateral basal rales observed on chest auscultation. Cardiac auscultation reveals a diastolic murmur. Remainder of the examination is within normal limits.  Clinical Impression: The presence of persistent fever  new murmur  and history of intravenous drug use raise a suspicious for native-valve infective endocarditis. Immediate blood cultures followed by transthoracic echocardiogram to confirm the diagnosis and start appropriate antimicrobial therapy are suggested. The rash on his extremities may be Janeway lesions  signs of septic emboli  which is consistent with infective endocarditis. The weight loss and fatigue speak to the chronic nature of disease  possibly due to long-term effects of septicemia and recurring fevers.  Plan:  The patient will be admitted to the hospital for further diagnostic tests and more immediate control of symptoms. A seriousness of the condition was explained to the patient and he has given consent for hospital admission. The infectious disease team will be consulted for further management. A transthoracic echocardiogram and blood cultures will be obtained immediately.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. B is a 60-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the cardiology clinic with a complaint of 2 weeks of persistent  unexplained low-grade fever  fatigue  weight loss  and night sweats. He also reports occasional shortness of breath and a newly developed intermittent heart murmur which was reported during his recent visit to a general practitioner. He denies any recent dental procedures or other invasive procedures.  Mr. B has a past medical history significant for intravenous drug use in his twenties  but states he has been clean for several years. His other medical history includes controlled hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. He has a 40 pack-year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. Family history was unremarkable for any heart disease.  On physical examination  he appeared unwell. His temperature was 100.4°F  with a regular pulse of 110 beats per minute  a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  and a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. Cardiac exam revealed a new systolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. Rounding out the physical examination were findings of minute  painless  red spots underneath the skin of his fingers (Osler's nodes) and on the palms of his hands (Janeway lesions) - both suggestive of endocarditis.  The patient's clinical picture  symptoms  and physical examination findings suggest a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis  which is a life-threatening disease. Blood cultures have been taken and started on empirical antibiotic treatment awaiting culture results. He was admitted to the hospital for further management including imaging studies to assess any other potential sites of infection or complications.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. J is a 53-year-old African American male who presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of high-grade fever  malaise  and shortness of breath for the past two weeks. He admits to having a history of intravenous drug use but has been clean for the past two years. He has a past medical history significant for hypertension  type II diabetes  and chronic hepatitis C infection  which are all well-managed with medication. On examination  he is found to have Osler's nodes on his fingers and Janeway lesions on his palms and soles. On auscultation  a new-onset murmur is noted.   His social history reveals that he is currently unemployed  lives alone  and smokes about half a pack of cigarettes a day. He denies any recent travel  close contacts with infectious diseases  or recent surgeries or procedures. There is no history of any known heart problems or rheumatic fever. His family history is non-contributory.   Given his symptoms  and past medical and social history  there is a high suspicion for native-valve infective endocarditis. Further investigations including blood cultures and an echocardiogram are planned to confirm the diagnosis.  Note: The typical demographic representation of patients with infective endocarditis tends to be male  middle-aged  often having a history of intravenous drug use  and frequently associated underlying conditions such as diabetes or hepatitis C infection. African Americans are over-represented among people who inject drugs in the United States  thus higher risk for native valve endocarditis has been reported.

Patient Presentation:  Patient is a 56-year-old Caucasian male  presenting to the hospital with complaints of persistent fevers  fatigue  chills  and an unintentional weight loss of 10 pounds in the last 5 weeks.   The physical examination reveals Janeway lesions (painless erythematous lesions) on the palms. Osborne's sign (visible undulating line in the artery of the nail bed) is noticed  along with Roth's spots (retinal hemorrhages) on funduscopic examination. Fever of 101.3 F is noted. A new pan-systolic murmur of grade 3/6 is heard at the left sternal border.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of intravenous drug use (primarily heroin)  which puts him at an elevated risk of bacterial endocarditis. He also has type II diabetes  but the patient confirms not taking any medication for it. He is a smoker with a 20 pack-year history and consumes alcohol socially. He has no known allergies.  Conclusion:  The patient's history of substance use  combined with the clinical signs  and symptoms suggest a likely case of native valve infective endocarditis. Further investigation including blood cultures and echocardiography is needed to confirm the diagnosis and evaluate for any potential complications.  Note: The median age of people with infective endocarditis in developed countries is about 60 years old and two thirds of patients are men. Predisposing cardiac conditions are present in more than 50% cases with mitral valve prolapse  aortic valve disease  degenerative valve disease  and congenital heart disease being the most common. Other significant risk factors are intravenous drugs and poor dental health.

Patient Presentation:  A 60-year-old non-Hispanic white male presents to the clinic with symptoms of generalized fatigue  intermittent fever  and unintentional weight loss over the past three weeks. He also complains of night sweats and anorexia.  Additional Details:   The patient works as a plumber. Social history shows he is a nonsmoker  consumes alcohol at social events only  and denies any illicit drug use. Family history is non-contributory.  Past Medical History:  He has a medical history of rheumatic fever which he suffered during his teenage years and was treated accordingly. He developed moderate aortic stenosis two years back. He also has Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed five years ago  which is being managed by oral hypoglycemic agents.  Current Medications:  His medication list includes Metformin 500mg twice daily for diabetes and occasional intake of over-the-counter NSAIDs for arthralgia.  On physical exam  he is febrile  with the blood pressure of 120/80 mmHg  and heart rate of 96 beats per minute (regular). Cardiac auscultation reveals a harsh systolic ejection murmur over the right second intercostal space  which radiates to the neck and is suggestive of aortic stenosis. Controlled oral candidiasis is also observed on intraoral examination.  Given the patient's symptoms and his rheumatic heart disease history  the presentation is suggestive of probable infective endocarditis on native valves  and further diagnostic workup like blood cultures and transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) are ordered.

A 60-year-old African American male patient  Mr. J  presents to the emergency department with a two-week history of malaise  fevers  night sweats  and unintentional weight loss of approximately 10 pounds. He denies any cough  chest pain  shortness of breath  or changes in bowel or urinary habits. He has been recently discharged from a hospital two months ago after undergoing dental extraction.  This patient has a significant past medical history of intravenous drug use but has been in recovery for the past five years. He also has a history of chronic hepatitis C  untreated stage II hypertension  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He currently smokes a pack of cigarettes daily and drinks alcohol occasionally. His medications consist of metformin for diabetes and amlodipine for hypertension. He is inconsistent with his medication regimen and often misses doses. He does not have any known drug allergies.  On physical examination  his blood pressure is 150/95 mm HG  pulse is 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute  and temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). Cardiac examination reveals a new murmur on the mitral area. He also exhibits Osler's Nodes on his fingers and toes and Janeway Lesions on the palms and soles.  Given his history and physical findings  there is strong suspicion for native-valve infective endocarditis  potentially secondary to poor dental hygiene or non-compliance with the prescribed antibiotic prophylaxis recommended during his recent dental extraction. Further tests and management are needed to confirm the diagnosis and begin appropriate treatment.

Patient Presentation: The patient is a 45-year-old Caucasian Male  presenting with a 2-week history of intermittent high-grade fever accompanied by persistent fatigue and marked weight loss. For the last few days  he has been having intense night sweats and a loss of appetite. He also mentions an increased discomfort and cloudiness in his vision.  Patient's past medical history reveals that he was a long-term intravenous drug user but has been sober for the last 3 years. He has a known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and was diagnosed with Hepatitis C and has undergone a mitral valve repair surgery 5 years ago.  Social history revealed that he works as a construction worker with exposure to dust and airborne particles. He is a chronic smoker with a 30-pack year history. On examination  pallor is present with the patient appearing acutely ill. Cardiac examination reveals a new-onset murmur heard best at the apex of the heart.   There is evidence of splinter hemorrhages under the fingernails and Janeway lesions are visualized on the palms and soles. The funduscopic exam reveals Roth spots. His vital signs are: blood pressure 130/80 mmHg  heart rate of 120 beats per minute  respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute  oral temperature of 39°C  and oxygen saturation around 94% on room air.  Recent blood results show increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) with normal white blood cells (WBC) count  suggestive of an ongoing systemic inflammatory response due to possible infection. Given his symptoms and clinical findings  a probable diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis is considered. This needs significant investigation like echocardiography and blood culture for confirmation.

Patient Presentation  Patient Information: Mr. Amaechi Nnabueze  a 62-year-old African male  visits the hospital complaining of fatigue  chills  night sweats  shortness of breath  and unexplained weight loss for the past 2-3 weeks.   Relevant Medical History: Mr. Nnabueze  previously diagnosed with diabetes mellitus type 2  for which he monitors his blood sugar level regularly and takes metformin. He has a 25-year history of IV drug abuse but has been in a recovery program and sober for one year.  Examination: On physical examination  there were signs of nail bed hemorrhages and Osler nodes on his fingers and toes  suggesting embolic events and immune-mediated phenomena. A grade II/VI systolic heart murmur audible at the left lower sternal border was also noticed.  Laboratory finding: Blood cultures taken showed Streptococcus viridans. Given his clinical condition  echocardiogram findings  and blood culture results  the diagnosis of infective endocarditis of native valves was made.   Note: According to literature  the male to female ratio for infective endocarditis is 2:1  with African individuals being disproportionately affected. The high prevalence among Africans is believed to be in part related to higher rates of rheumatic heart disease. Moreover  diabetes is also a risk factor for developing infective endocarditis. In the U.S.  there's a higher rate of infective endocarditis among individuals with a history of IV drug use.

Patient Presentation  Patient is a 61-year-old Caucasian male  with a history of intravenous drug use  presenting with a 2-week history of intermittent fever  night sweats  and unplanned weight loss. Denies any recent travel or contact with sick individuals. His past medical history is significant for intra-venous drug use  Hepatitis C  and HIV  for which he is following treatment.  Last used intravenous drugs about a month ago  but denies any needle sharing. He has been in recovery for past few years  but experienced multiple relapses. He is unemployed  lives alone  and has unstable housing conditions. No known allergies.   On physical examination  temperature is 100.4 F  pulse 90/min  blood pressure 92/60 mmHg  respiratory rate 20/min  and oxygen saturation 97% on room air. There are small erythematous lesions on his palms and soles  consistent with Janeway lesions. Auscultation of heart reveals a new murmur on the left lower sternal border  suggestive of tricuspid regurgitation. No osler nodes are noted.   This history and clinical presentation lead to a preliminary diagnosis of infective endocarditis  likely due to his high-risk behavior of intravenous drug use. Further investigation including blood cultures and transthoracic echocardiogram were planned for confirmation.

Patient Presentation:  A 61-year-old African American male with a past medical history of intravenous drug use and untreated diabetes mellitus presents with a one-month history of fever  malaise  and unintentional weight loss. He also reports a new onset persistent cough over the past 2 weeks.   On physical examination  he appears ill  tired  and is notably underweight for his height. Vital signs show a persistent low-grade fever at 100.4℉  blood pressure at 135/85 mmHg  heart rate at 100 beats per minute  and respiratory rate at 18 breaths per minute. His dentition is poor  and he admits to not visiting a dentist for several years. Cardiovascular examination reveals a diastolic murmur heard best at left lower sternal border. Neurological examination reveals an unsteady gait but no focal deficits. Small  dark  linear hemorrhages are present beneath the nails of his fingers and toes.  Labs are significant for anemia  elevated inflammatory markers (ESR: 70mm/hr  CRP: 80 mg/L)  and blood cultures reveal growth of Streptococcus viridans. His HbA1c is 9.5%  indicating poor glycemic control.   Echocardiography reveals vegetations on the mitral valve  pointing towards a diagnosis of native-valve bacterial endocarditis  likely resulting from his chronic IV drug use and poor oral hygiene.

Patient Presentation:  Gender: Male Age: 68 years old Ethnicity: Caucasian  Presenting Complaints:   Mr. J  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  visits the clinic complaining of recurrent low-grade fever (up to 100.4 degrees Fahrenheit) with accompanying intermittent chills and night sweats for the past three weeks. He also reports a lack of appetite  fatigue  and weight loss of approximately ten pounds during the same period due to reduced appetite and general malaise. He further notes experiencing moderate exertional dyspnea and a persistent mild-to-moderate headache.  Past Medical History:   Mr. J has a known history of stage 3 chronic kidney disease due to diabetes mellitus type 2 for the past 10 years. He has hypertension which is controlled with medication. Furthermore  he underwent a balloon mitral valvuloplasty ten years ago for symptomatically significant mitral stenosis. He is under regular medical follow-ups and is compliant with his medications  including metformin  lisinopril  and amlodipine.   Social History:  Mr. J recently retired. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history but quit 15 years ago. He occasionally drinks alcohol. He is living with his wife and has not traveled recently. His vaccinations  including the pneumococcal and seasonal influenza vaccines  are updated.  Family History:  There's a family history of cardiovascular diseases - father had coronary artery disease and mother had hypertension. There's no family history of autoimmune or hematological diseases.  This patient's age  gender  caucasian ethnicity  and past medical history of cardiac and renal disease are inline with typical demographic characteristics found in literature associated with patients with native-valve infective endocarditis.  Given his symptoms and past medical history  he is being evaluated further with suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis. β-hemolytic streptococcal blood cultures  Staphylococcal cultures  CBC  ESR  CRP  EKG and transthoracic echocardiography are ordered.

Patient Information:  Age: 55-year-old  Sex: Male Occupation: Construction Worker Lifestyle: History of intravenous drug use (last 10 years  currently in recovery). Race: White (according to literature  Infective Endocarditis is most common in white individuals.)  Presenting Complaint: The patient presents with a three-week history of intermittent  low-grade fever (up to 100.4° F)  night sweats  weight loss  and fatigue.  Medical History: The patient has a past medical history positive for Intravenous Drug Use (IVUD)  Hepatitis C (currently under treatment)  and is a known case of valvular heart disease  which was diagnosed 5 years ago. The patient is currently under the management of a cardiologist and has been advised surgery for his valve replacement but has been deferring it. He doesn't have any known allergies. He denies any alcohol consumption but admits to smoking about a pack of cigarettes per day for the past 25 years.  Physical Examination: Vital signs within normal limits except for mild tachycardia. Examination reveals venipuncture marks consistent with a history of intravenous drug use. Janeway lesions (non-tender hemorrhagic lesions on palms and soles) and Osler nodes (painful nodules on the pads of the fingers) are seen. Auscultation reveals a regurgitant murmur indicative of valvular regurgitation.  Investigations: Blood tests indicate leukocytosis and elevated CRP. Blood cultures are positive for Staphylococcus aureus. An echocardiogram reveals the presence of vegetative growth on the tricuspid valve.  Impression: Based on the clinical presentation  past medical history  and laboratory findings  a diagnosis of Native Valve Infective Endocarditis is made.

Patient Presentation:  The patient  Ms. M.  is a 70-year-old Caucasian woman who came to the hospital complaining of low-grade fever  intermittent  unusual sweating  and malaise for the last three months. She also reported experiencing unintentional weight loss and an unexplainable feeling of fatigue in the same period. She recently noticed red  painful sores on her fingers and toes and distinct dark red/brownish spots on her palms and soles.  Details of her past medical history revealed that she has a history of rheumatic heart disease after being diagnosed at the age of 12. Additionally  she was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation 5 years ago and has been taking anticoagulant medication ever since. The patient doesn't have any history of IV drug use or any immunosuppressive conditions. However  she recently underwent a dental procedure without any antibiotic prophylaxis.   Overall  her longstanding history of heart disease  presence of atrial fibrillation  and recent dental procedure  combined with the new onset of generalized symptoms like fatigue  low-grade fever  sweating  and skin lesions collectively raise suspicion for infective endocarditis. Given her medical history and current symptoms  blood cultures and an echocardiogram are recommended for further evaluation.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. A.R. is a male  48 years old  Hispanic  truck driver by occupation  originally from Mexico  now living in the Texas. He is a former smoker and admits to recreational drug use in the past  particularly intravenous drug use. He has a history of untreated dental caries and recent dental extractions two months ago. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus well-controlled with metformin.  He presents to the emergency department complaining of feeling unwell with intermittent  high-grade fever for the past four weeks  loss of appetite  having lost 5 kg within a month  night sweats  and a new cardiac murmur that was detected on a recent visit to his primary care provider. On examination  he has a systolic heart murmur  tender spleen enlargement  and signs of peripheral emboli including Janeway lesions (painless erythematous lesions on the palm and soles) and Osler nodes (painful nodules on the fingers and toes).  Blood culture results and ECG findings from the primary care provider indicated bacterial endocarditis with positive for Staphylococcus aureus. Patient’s diabetes was previously controlled but blood glucose levels taken in ED were slightly elevated which might be due to infection and stress. He is feverish  with low blood pressure but not in severe distress.  The patient’s history and clinical findings suggest a possible diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis  possibly from subpar dental hygiene and procedure  combined with his past intravenous drug use. He may have been at a higher risk due to his diabetes as well.

Patient Presentation  A 43-year-old African American male presents to the clinic accompanied by his wife  complaining of persistent fever  fatigue  night sweats  weight loss  and intermittent chills for the past three weeks. Past medical history revealed that he has a history of illicit drug use  particularly intravenous heroin  which he quit 5 years ago. He has been diagnosed with Hepatitis C secondary to his past drug use.  His wife noticed that he had a poor oral hygiene and saw a few small red spots on his skin  particularly on his lower extremities. She also reported that he had lost his appetite and unintentionally lost approximately 10 pounds in the last month.  His surgical history is insignificant. He is currently taking pegylated interferon and ribavirin for his Hepatitis C  but does not have any known allergies to medication.     The patient has a family history of cardiovascular disease. His father had a heart attack at the age of 65 and his older brother has high blood pressure.  On physical examination  a new grade 3/6 holosystolic cardiac murmur was heard over the left sternal border. Other positive findings were petechiae in the conjunctiva and under fingernails  and Osler nodes (painful erythematous nodules) on the fingers and toes.  The clinical presentation  with a history of intravenous drug use  alongside new cardiac murmur and other relevant symptoms  raises a high suspicion for a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 65-year-old African American male presenting to the hospital with worsening malaise  fever  chills  night sweats  weight loss  anorexia  and a new onset heart murmur. His current heart rate is 96 beats per minute  blood pressure of 108/65 mmHg  and his temperature is 38.5℃. Patient mentions intermittent chest pain for the past week  but denies any cough  shortness of breath  hemoptysis  or syncope.  His past medical history is significant for intravenous drug use (Heroin) until about 15 years ago. He has no known history of valvular heart disease  rheumatic heart disease  or prosthetic valves. He was diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus 10 years ago  for which he is under medication control. He does not consume alcohol frequently or use tobacco products.  On examination  he is found to have petechiae on his palms and soles  with Osler nodes noted at his fingertips. There are needle track marks in the antecubital fossas  though they look old and well-healed.  With suspected infective endocarditis due to the new murmur  fever  and classic signs of Osler nodes and petechiae  empirical antibiotic therapy was started and the patient was admitted for further tests. Blood cultures were ordered  as well as a transesophageal echocardiogram to confirm vegetations on the heart valves  which would support the diagnosis of infective endocarditis. His HBA1c levels were also measured to monitor the control of his diabetes.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. S is a 65-year-old Hispanic male  with a past medical history significant for intravenous drug abuse with heroin approximately five years ago  type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and peripheral vascular disease. He reports that over the past month  he has been experiencing consistent fevers with temperatures up to 102 F  night sweats  weight loss  and generalized malaise.   He mentioned having flare-ups of dental pain during this time period but could not afford dental care. He notes that his appetite has been poor  contributing to a weight loss of about 10 pounds over the past month. Recently  Mr. S has also noticed increasing shortness of breath  especially on exertion  and swelling in his lower extremities.  On physical examination  he is febrile with temperature 101 F  BP 135/85 mmHg  heart rate 95 bpm  respiratory rate 20 bpm and oxygen saturation 95% on room air. Examination of the oropharynx reveals several carious teeth. Cardiac examination reveals a new systolic murmur appreciated at the apex. There are a few petechial lesions on his palms and soles  and his fingers exhibit slight clubbing. His lungs are clear but his lower extremities show mild bilateral pitting edema.  Following initial clinical examination and considering his past medical history  native-valve infective endocarditis is suspected. He would need to be further evaluated with blood cultures and an echocardiogram to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Information: John  a 65-year-old African-American male  retired factory worker  coming from a suburban neighborhood. Weighs around 85 kg and measures 170 cm tall.  Chief Complaint: The patient presents with extreme fatigue  a high-grade fever of 39.1°C (102.3°F) that has persisted for the past 10 days  and intermittent chills.  History: The patient discloses a history of aortic stenosis diagnosed 5 years ago for which he did not undergo surgery due to personal reasons. He also has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus with intermittent compliance to medication. His surgical history includes a hernia repair 20 years ago. He does not have any known allergies.  Social History: The patient is married  lives with his wife  is a former smoker who quit 10 years ago  does not consume alcohol regularly  and has never used any illicit substances.  Family History: His mother passed away due to a stroke and his father had a history of heart disease.   Review of Systems: Positive for sweating at night for approximately 2 weeks  loss of appetite  slight weight loss  and shortness of breath on exertion. He also mentions experiencing occasional mild headaches  but denies any vision changes  chest pain  cough  or altered bowel habits.   Based on the symptoms  clinical findings  and past history  a potential diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis is being considered.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Trent is a 64-year-old Caucasian male  employed as an electrical engineer  who presents to the clinic with complaints of persistent fever  generatl fatigue and a recent onset of palpitations for the past two weeks which have progressively worsened. Symptoms are accompanied by moderate night sweats and unexplained weight loss of 5kg over the last month  which have caused him considerable worry. He reports no chest pain  dizziness or syncopal episodes.  Past Medical History: Mr. Trent has a history of rheumatoid arthritis for which he has been taking prednisone 5mg daily for 6 years. His other relevant medical history includes hyperlipidemia  controlled with statins  and treated stage II hypertension. He is a former smoker  quitting the habit 10 years ago  and a lover of a social drink on weekends. No history of illicit drug use. Has a dental history of multiple extractions and poor oral hygiene until his 30s.   Mr. Trent's family history reveals his mother suffered from congestive heart failure and his father passed away due to end-stage renal disease.   Recent Medical History: Two months prior  Mr. Trent had undergone a dental extraction without prophylactic antibiotics  which was complicated by a postoperative infection.   Current medications include Prednisone 5 mg daily  Atorvastatin 10 mg at bedtime  and Lisinopril 10 mg daily. He has no known drug allergies.  Given his age  ethnicity  presentation with nonspecific symptoms  and significant medical history including dental procedures  rheumatoid arthritis  use of glucocorticoids which potentially present an immunocompromise; a suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis should be considered.

Patient Presentation:  A 60-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with a two-week history of persistent  low-grade fever  fatigue  loss of appetite  and unexplained weight loss. He also mentions that he noticed bloody urine earlier today.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of intravenous drug use in his late 20s. He quit drug use 25 years back. He was diagnosed with Hepatitis C 15 years ago  which has been stable with antiviral therapy. The patient also has a past medical history of hypertension and rheumatic heart disease diagnosed five years back for which he is on beta-blockers and received benzathine penicillin G prophylaxis in his younger years.  HOME Medications: He takes Lisinopril 10mg daily for hypertension and Ledipasvir-sofosbuvir combination for Hepatitis C.  Social History: He admits to occasional alcohol consumption. He quit smoking 10 years back.  On physical examination  he appears fatigued  heart sounds reveal a systolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border. Petechial rash noted on his palms and soles. A Janeway lesion observed on his right palm.  These findings illustrate a representation of a patient with potential native-valve infective endocarditis  a condition more common amongst males with a median age of diagnosis around 60 years and is often associated with a history of intravenous drug use  rheumatic heart disease  and notable infective agents like Hepatitis C. Appropriate diagnostic tests should be initiated to confirm the diagnosis.

Title: A Case Study of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Slide 1: Introduction The term ""native-valve endocarditis"" is used to describe an infection of native  non-prosthetic heart valves. This disease may cause life-threatening complications when left untreated. The most common pathogens are streptococci  staphylococci  and enterococci diagnostically assessed via blood cultures.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics And Past Medical History Patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male  who emulates the most ordinary demographic afflicted by native valve infective endocarditis according to literature. He is a retired mechanic  married with two children. The patient has a past medical history of moderate aortic valve disease and was previously diagnosed with type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  but neither has required surgical intervention nor insulin respectively.  Slide 3: Presenting Symptoms The patient was admitted presenting with four weeks of low-grade fever  dyspnea on exertion  and malaise  indicative of subacute endocarditis. Physical examination revealed unstable vital signs with a femoral systolic bruit.  Slide 4: Diagnostic Evaluation  Osler's nodes and Janeway lesions were noted upon further examination  classic physical findings in infective endocarditis. His routine blood investigations demonstrated elevated markers of inflammation including CRP and ESR. Blood cultures were requisitioned which eventually grew Streptococcus viridans.  Slide 5: Echocardiography Findings  Trans-thoracic and trans-esophageal echocardiogram were performed. Echocardiographic findings included large oscillating mass on the aortic valve with moderate to severe aortic regurgitation  concluding to vegetations on aortic valve – classic for infective endocarditis.  Slide 6: Treatment and Management  Patient is planned for a course of intravenous antibiotics to clear the bacteremia. Cardiology input will be sought for surgical intervention considering the severity of aortic insufficiency and the large size of vegetation  as an attempt to prevent systemic emboli.  Slide 7: Conclusion This case underscores the importance of early diagnosis and prompt treatment of native-valve infective endocarditis to prevent morbidity and mortality  along with effective management of any underlying disease. Furthermore  it is essential to consider this condition in the differential diagnosis in patients with a history of valve disease presenting with unspecific signs such as fever  fatigue and weight loss  for appropriate management.

Title: Case Presentation of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Slide 1: Introduction - Brief explanation of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis (NVIE): A microbial infection of the native valves of the heart often caused by bacteria entering the bloodstream and settling in the heart lining  a heart valve  or a blood vessel.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics - Gender: Male (Males are more affected  with a ratio of approximately 2:1 according to literature) - Age: 60 years (Infective Endocarditis is most common in patients over 60) - Race/Ethnicity: White (There's no specific prevalence toward any race or ethnicity  however  demographic information should point toward the majority of the student’s patient population)  Slide 3: Background & Lifestyle  - Occupation: Manual laborer  - Lifestyle: Smoker  Moderate alcohol consumer  - Dental hygiene: Poor dental hygiene  Slide 4: Past Medical History - History of illicit drug use in the distant past - Dental procedures in the last six months - Prior episodes of Staphylococcus aureus skin infections - No documented heart conditions or valve abnormalities - No recent hospitalizations or invasive procedures  Slide 5: Current Medical Condition  - Patient presented with three-week history of fatigue  low grade fevers  and weight loss. - Mild anemia reported  - Night Sweats   Slide 6: Physical Examination - Temperature: 100.4 F (38 C) - Blood Pressure: 140/90 mmHg  - Heart Rate: 95/min - Respiratory Rate: 18 breaths per minute - Cardiac auscultation: Diastolic murmur best heard at the apex - Splinter hemorrhages seen on the nails and Janeway lesions on palms and soles  Slide 7: Diagnostic Procedures and Results  - Blood cultures: Positive for Staphylococcus aureus - Echocardiogram: Displays vegetation on aortic valve  Slide 8: Conclusion - Diagnosis: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  - Discussion and explanation of the diagnosis according to the medical history  current symptoms  and test results  Slide 9: References - Listing of all sources used in the presentation.

Title: Case Presentation: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  **Slide 1: Demographics** Our patient  Mr. X  is a 60-year-old Caucasian male  representing the typical demographic group for this medical condition as per epidemiologic studies. However  it's important to note that this disease can affect people of any age group  race or gender.  **Slide 2: Past Medical History** Mr. X has a history of moderate alcohol use and smokes one pack of cigarettes per day. He has been previously diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and hypertension for which he takes oral medication.   **Slide 3: Relevant History** Mr. X has an extensive dental history with multiple bouts of neglected dental infections which feasibly represents a source of bacterial seeding. There is no known history of any heart disease  IV drug use or rheumatic fever.   **Slide 4: Presenting Condition - Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis (NVIE)** The patient presented with symptoms consistent with NVIE  such as: fever  fatigue  night sweats  weight loss  and a new-onset heart murmur.   **Slide 5: Epidemiology** According to literature  NVIE cases have shown substantial demographic changes over the past few decades. Currently  the prevalence is higher in males aged 50-70 years old  with underlying conditions like diabetes  hypertension  or history of invasive procedures or dental infections increasing susceptibility.  **Slide 6: Diagnosis** Diagnosis of NVIE was confirmed in Mr. X through physical examination (finding a heart murmur) and laboratory tests  including blood cultures which identified a causative organism  echocardiography revealing vegetations on the heart valves  and additional lab findings such as anemia and elevated ESR.   **Slide 7: Treatment and Management**  Given his diagnosis of NVIE  Mr. X was immediately started on empirical antibiotic therapy awaiting culture results  tailored according to guidelines. Tailored therapy includes penicillin or cephalosporin plus aminoglycoside. Depending on the causative organism  the specific regimen may vary. Surgically  valve replacement may be discussed for patients with valvular dysfunction or uncontrolled infection.  **Slide 8: Patient Education & Prognosis** Mr. X was educated about the importance of regular dental hygiene  optimal management of his diabetes  smoking cessation  and minimizing his alcohol consumption. Though the prognosis of NVIE can vary  addressing the source of infection and initiating immediate treatment increases the chance of successful recovery.   References: 1. __________ 2. __________ (Include necessary references)   This case reiterates the importance of considering NVIE in diagnosing a patient with persistent fever and new-onset heart murmur  especially in those with relevant predisposing factors.

Title: Infective Endocarditis - A Case Study   Slide 1: Introduction Today we'll be discussing a case of native-valve infective endocarditis. Infective endocarditis is an infection of the heart valves caused typically by bacteria. Native valve endocarditis refers to infection of a patient's own  unaltered heart valves.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics  Our patient  Mr. R  is a 52-year-old Caucasian male  which fits within the demographic mainly affected by native valve infective endocarditis based on current literature. The condition commonly afflicts middle-aged to older adults  with a higher prevalence in males.  Slide 3: Past Medical History  Mr. R has a history of type 2 diabetes managed with medication and lifestyle modifications. He also has a history of intravenous drug abuse – a significant risk factor for infective endocarditis. He's been in methadone maintenance treatment for the past five years.  Slide 4: Presenting Symptoms  He presented to the hospital with a two-week history of malaise  low-grade fever  and a new heart murmur. He also exhibited signs of Osler’s nodes on his hands and feet  petechiae on his legs  Janeway lesions  and splinter hemorrhages under the nails – classical systemic presentations of infective endocarditis.  Slide 5: Diagnosis  His blood cultures tested positive for Staphylococcus aureus  pointing towards MRSA-associated infective endocarditis due to his history of intravenous drug use. Transthoracic echocardiography confirmed the presence of vegetations on his mitral valve  corroborating the diagnosis.  Slide 6: Treatment  Mr. R was administered IV antibiotics - vancomycin and ceftriaxone for a 6-week course. Due to the large vegetations affecting his heart function  he underwent successful surgical removal of the infected valve and valve replacement surgery.  Slide 7: Follow-up  His post-operative recovery has been steady with regular follow-ups being scheduled for monitoring his cardiac status and the control of his diabetes.  Slide 8: Conclusion  This case illustrates the potential severity of infective endocarditis  especially in patients with a past medical history of intravenous drug use. Early detection and prompt treatment are critical to minimize complications  enforce the vital role of heart function assessments  and underscore the necessity for life-long disease management in individuals with increased risk profiles.

Title: A Case Study on Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Slide 1: Introduction - Brief mention of the condition: Native-valve infective endocarditis (NVIE) - a serious infection often caused by bacteria  affecting the lining and valves of the heart. - Overview of presentation structure: introduction  patient demographics  case description  diagnosis  treatment options  and conclusion.    Slide 2: Patient Demographics  - Age: 62-year-old male - Residential Status: Urban residence - Occupation: Retired construction worker - Lifestyle: Ex-smoker  occasional alcohol consumption - Reason for Presentation: Recent onset of intermittent fevers  marked fatigue  weight loss and increasing shortness of breath.  Slide 3: Past Medical History  - Relevant History: History of untreated dental caries and a recent dental procedure. - Comorbidities: Hypertension managed by medication  previous smoker with no recorded chronic lung disease.  Slide 4: Symptoms and Physical Examination - Presentation: Presents with a new heart murmur  low-grade fevers  night sweats  and mild weight loss. - Physical Examination: Notable findings include Osler's nodes on fingers  Janeway lesions on palms  and splinter hemorrhages under the fingernails.   Slide 5: Diagnosis  - Initial Diagnostic Tests: Blood cultures reveal substantial growth of Streptococcus viridans. - Imaging findings: Transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) demonstrates a vegetation on the mitral valve leaflet.   Slide 6: Treatment  - Antibiotic treatment: Intravenous administration of Penicillin G and Gentamicin after sensitivity testing of the isolate. - Surgery: Valve replacement may be necessary depending on the response to antibiotic treatments and ongoing assessments of the patient's clinical condition.   Slide 7: Conclusion and Discussion  - Clarify that this case emphasizes the importance of taking thorough patient histories  especially regarding dental procedures as native-valve infective endocarditis typically follows dental or other medical procedures. - Prompt diagnosis and treatment are crucial in managing NVIE due to the high risk of complications  so high clinical suspicion is critical when patients present with suggestive signs and symptoms.    Slide 8: References  - Inclusion of all pertinent literature and guidelines that informed the case presentation.   Note: Keep in mind  the content and flow of the presentation will depend on who the audience is. Simple language must be used when the discussion is to be held with patients or non-medical folks  whilst it could be more technical and detailed for a medical audience.   This is merely fiction and not descriptions of actual patients or events. This presentation does not give health advice.

Title: A Case Study on Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Slide 1: Patient Demographics We present the case of a 62-year-old African American male patient  Mr. A. Based on literature  infective endocarditis (IE) is more common among males in their 60's and African Americans tend to be disproportionately affected due to a variety of systemic factors - socioeconomic  healthcare access  etc.  Slide 2: Past Medical History Mr. A has a history of intravenous drug use (IVDU) during his youth  though he has been clean for about 20 years. He is hypertensive and has stage 3 chronic kidney disease (CKD). He also has a history of rheumatic heart disease with moderate valvular disease. These comorbidities increase his risk for developing IE  particularly given the valvular heart damage from rheumatic heart disease.  Slide 3: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis (IE) A week prior to admission  Mr. A experienced upfront symptoms of fever and fatigue  later developing into more alarming signs like petechiae  Osler's nodes  and Janeway lesions. After a serological study  he was found to have Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia  and an echocardiogram revealed vegetations on the native mitral valve.  Slide 4: Further Investigations Blood cultures revealed methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA). Absence of illicit drug use  normal immunity status  and echocardiographic findings provoked us to consider Mr. A's history of rheumatic heart disease as possible gateway leading to native-valve IE. Further investigations were directed towards leukocytosis and elevated inflammatory markers indicative of a systemic inflammatory response.  Slide 5: Management and Prognosis IE  especially with a highly virulent organism like S. aureus  in patients with pre-existing cardiac disease is a grave condition. After confirming the diagnosis of native-valve IE  Mr. A was initiated on empiric antibiotic therapy and closely monitored for any signs of heart failure or embolic events. The need for surgery will depend on the patient's sequential clinical and echocardiographic evaluations.  Slide 6: Conclusion This case highlights the significance of comprehensive past medical history and underlines the importance of early detection and management for improving patient survival in infective endocarditis. Further  it emphasizes the ongoing need for focused strategies to reduce the rate of IE among African Americans and other vulnerable patient groups.
