Introduction: Today we'll be discussing a clinical case of native-valve infective endocarditis (IE) in a middle-aged patient.  Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 50-year-old Male  Demographics: Mr. Smith is a 50-year-old Caucasian male  an accountant by profession living in a suburban neighborhood. According to the literature  infective endocarditis has a higher incidence in males aged 30 to 60 years and in the Caucasian population.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a significant medical history of diabetes mellitus type II  hypertension  and had suffered a minor stroke three years ago. These are significant as diabetes and hypertension may have resulted in micro-damage to the vascular endothelium  making it more susceptible to bacterial invasion. Furthermore  strokes can occur as a serious complication of infective endocarditis due to septic emboli.  He has a 20-year history of cigarette smoking  averaging one pack a day - a habit that has increased his risk for multiple cardiovascular diseases. He has shown no signs of intravenous drug use or any relevant dental history  both of which are common causes of native-valve infective endocarditis.   Clinical History: Over the last few weeks  Mr. Smith reported experiencing fluctuating fevers  chills  weakness  and unexplained weight loss. He noticed the appearance of small red or purple spots (Petechiae) on his skin and inside his mouth. A heart murmur was also observed during the medical examination  which was previously undocumented.  Based on these presentations  suspicion was high for possible infective endocarditis. Mr. Smith was immediately referred for further investigations. He went through a set of blood cultures and an echocardiogram – both standard procedures for diagnosing endocarditis.   This case represents a common presentation of native-valve infective endocarditis with predisposing factors such as diabetes and hypertension. It reinforces the need for prompt recognition and management of this serious condition  with its potential for severe complications such as stroke. It’s crucial for healthcare providers to maintain a high index of suspicion for IE in patients with a similar clinical presentation and risk factors.

Title: A Case Study of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Slide 1: Introduction  Native-valve infective endocarditis (NVIE) is a serious infection of the endocardium (inner heart lining) that primarily affects the heart valves. This case study presents a profile of an individual most likely affected based on demographic data from the literature.  Slide 2: Demographics   Patient Profile: A 60-year-old Caucasian male.  - Gender & Age: NVIE has a higher prevalence in males (about 2:1 male to female ratio) and is more common in the 60-65 age group. - Ethnicity: Literature implies a slightly elevated risk for Caucasians. However  all ethnicities can be affected.   Slide 3: Past Medical History   - Previous Cardiac Conditions: The patient has a history of mitral valve prolapse  a common risk factor for NVIE. - Intravenous Drug Use (IVDU): No history of IVDU is present. Although a significant risk factor  IVDU-associated NVIE is more common among younger age brackets.  - Dental Procedures: The patient underwent invasive dental procedures without prophylaxis  which contributively risked NVIE.   Slide 4: Recent History   In the past few weeks  the patient has presented symptoms including fever  chills  night sweats  and unexplained weight loss  all suggestive of NVIE. He also experienced shortness of breath  hinting at possible heart failure  a complication of NVIE.  Slide 5: Conclusion   This case illustrates the demographics and medical history frequently associated with NVIE. Early recognition  diagnosis  and management are crucial to improving patient outcomes.  End of Presentation. This presentation outlines a typical or common patient profile but may not apply universally.

Title: A Case Presentation on Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis: Analysis and Management  Slide 1: Introduction   Native-valve infective endocarditis is a severe infection of the endocardial surface of the heart that primarily affects individuals with a history of illicit intravenous drug use or pre-existing cardiac diseases.  Slide 2: Patient Demographic Information     Patient Info:  - 52-year old Caucasian male   - Occupation: Hardware Store Manager  - Residence: Urban metropolitan area  Slide 3: Past Medical History  Past medical record: - Diagnosed with rheumatic heart disease at age 25 - No history of intravenous drug use - Non-smoker - High Blood Pressure - Complex partial seizures  - Controlled type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  Slide 4: Reason for the current visit   He reported a 2-week history of unexplained weight loss  malaise  night sweats  and intermittent fever.   Slide 5: Clinical Examination  Upon examination: - Fever (38.5 °C  or 101.3°F) - New systolic murmur  - Petechiae on the soles of his feet  Slide 6: Diagnostic Evaluation  Upon laboratory examination: - Blood cultures are positive for Staphylococcus aureus. - Echocardiogram results indicate vegetations on the aortic valve.  Slide 7: Diagnosis  Based on the clinical features  lab findings  and echocardiogram results  the patient was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis.  Slide 8: Management  The patient was administered a standard regimen for the treatment of methicillin-sensitive S. aureus infective endocarditis  including intravenous nafcillin and gentamicin.   Slide 9: Discussion  This presentation highlights the diagnostic challenges of Infective Endocarditis. Despite being relatively infrequent  early detection is crucial for effective management and to prevent deadly complications such as heart failure or systemic embolization.   Slide 10: Conclusion  Our patients  particularly those with a history of cardiac diseases  should be educated about the signs and symptoms of infective endocarditis to promote earlier presentation and evaluation.   Slide 11: References  - List of reference.    **Please note that Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis often seen in older adult populations  and is more common amongst males than females. It is more prevalent among the white population compared to other races. It is also often associated with pre-existing heart conditions like rheumatic heart disease.

Title: A Case Study: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Slide 1: Introduction Infective endocarditis is a critical infection of the endothelial surface of the heart  primarily impacting the heart valves. Today  we present an archetypal case that mirrors the common demographic representation of this disease.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics Meet Charlie  a 59-year-old Asian male with a past medical history of intravenous drug use. Asian males around the age of 60 are underrepresented in many arenas but are overrepresented in the instance of infective endocarditis  particularly where there's a history of illicit drug use.  Slide 3: Background Charlie previously worked as a construction worker but has been unemployed for the last few years. He's a smoker with a 15-pack year history  and has been a chronic intravenous drug user for the past 25 years.  Slide 4: Previous Medical History Five years ago  Charlie was diagnosed with Hepatitis C due to his drug use. He also has a history of right-sided heart failure  adding to his increased risk for infection.  Slide 5: Presentation  Presenting Symptoms: Charlie came to the emergency department with complaints of persistent fever  night sweats  fatigue  and a new murmur noticed in a routine check-up.  Slide 6: Diagnosis Based on these findings  suspicion for infective endocarditis was high. Confirmation was made via blood cultures  identification of typical microorganisms (S. aureus)  and echocardiographical findings.   Slide 7: Disease Prevalence  and Impact Native-valve infective endocarditis  though rare  has severe complications and a high mortality rate  especially in older males with illicit drug use history. Charlie's case is representative of the epidemiological data.  Slide 8: Treatment and Prognosis Charlie was started on targeted antibiotic therapy following culture result  aiming for a total duration of 6 weeks. He presents a high-risk case  with potential for complications due to his age  co-existing medical conditions  and the late diagnosis.  Slide 9: Conclusion Charlie's case offers a potent reminder of the diagnostic and therapeutic challenges posed by infective endocarditis. Proper education and healthcare interventions can help prevent and manage such complicated situations for highest risk groups.   Slide 10: Questions and Discussion Time for any questions and further discussion regarding the diagnosis  management  complications  and preventive strategies of infective endocarditis.

Title: A Case Study on Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Slide 1: Introduction Patient's Demographics:  - Gender: Male - Age: 55 years old - Race: Caucasian   Past medical history: The patient has a history of intravenous drug use and was identified as having Hepatitis C infection.  Slide 2: Past Medical Findings - The patient had multiple hospital admissions related to his IV drug use. - He has a known history of mild heart murmur  which  in prior evaluations  was deemed physiologic and no significant heart disease was noted.    Slide 3: Presenting Complaint The patient presented to the emergency department with persistent fever  fatigue  headache  and a new murmur on physical examination.  Slide 4: Clinical Investigations & Findings - The physical exam revealed signs associated with Endocarditis i.e.  Osler's nodes  Janeway lesions. - Lab tests: Positive blood cultures with Staphylococcus aureus  Elevated ESR and C-Reactive Protein  - Electrocardiogram: High-degree atrioventricular block - Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE): evidenced vegetations on the native valves.  Slide 5: Final Diagnosis Based on the Durack Criteria (Duke’s Criteria)  with 2 major (positive blood cultures with microorganism consistent with IE and evidence of endocardial involvement on TTE) and three minor criteria (fever >38°C  risk factor- IV drug use  and vascular phenomena) the patient was diagnosed with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis (IE).  Slide 6: Treatment The patient was treated in accordance with AHA guidelines which include an intravenous course of antibiotics like Ceftriaxone and Vancomycin for around 6 weeks. The new atrioventricular block necessitated the placement of a permanent pacemaker. The patient's cardiac function was closely monitored.  Slide 7: Patient Outcome Patient's condition improved gradually over a span of 6-8 weeks. He finished his antibiotic course and was enrolled in a drug rehabilitation program to avoid relapse of infection.  Slide 8: Conclusion  This case highlights the need for early diagnosis and treatment of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  especially in patients with a history of IV drug usage  as it significantly contributes to the disease's morbidity and mortality.  Slide 9: References All the citations and references used for assembling this presentation are indicated here.    Note: Although Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis can affect various populations  it is more prevalent in male patients  especially those with a history of intravenous drug use  poor dental health  and conditions like rheumatic heart disease and congenital heart abnormalities. This case study intends to represent an appropriate demographic based on existing medical literature.

Slide 1: Introduction  Infective endocarditis (IE) is an infection of the endocardial surface of the heart  which can include one or more heart valves  the mural endocardium  or a septal defect. It predominantly affects older adults with certain risk factors  including rheumatic heart disease and intravenous drug use.  Slide 2: Case Presentation  Patient's Profile: A 65-year-old African American male   Past Medical History: A consistent history of poor dental health and a recent dental extraction. He also has a past medical history significant for rheumatic heart disease from childhood with resultant mitral valve regurgitation.  Slide 3: Presenting Symptoms  The patient presented with a 2-week history of a fever of unknown origin  chills  night sweats  and a recent weight loss. He also complained of feeling generally unwell and extremely fatigued.   Slide 4: Physical Examination   Physical exam was notable for a temperature of 100.8°F  a new-onset heart murmur  conjunctival petechiae  and palpable spleen.  Slide 5: Diagnostic Procedures   Blood cultures drawn showed growth of Streptococcus viridans  a common pathogen in IE related to dental processes. The diagnosis of IE was confirmed further by trans-esophageal echocardiography showing vegetations on the mitral valve indicative of IE.  Slide 6: Demographics and IE  Infective endocarditis is most common in males in their late 50s and 60s. African Americans are overrepresented in cases of infective endocarditis  accounting for a significant burden of the disease compared to the white population.  Slide 7: Risk factors and IE   Poor dental health triggers bacteremia  increasing the risk for endocarditis. Furthermore  previous history of rheumatic heart disease with resultant valvular disease is a well-established risk factor for the development of IE.  Slide 8: Conclusion   This case emphasizes the importance of strong suspicion for IE in patients with previous valvular disease and poor dental health presenting with prolonged fever and new-onset heart murmur.

Slide 1: Introduction  Title: Case Presentation: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Slide 2: Patient's Demographic Data  Our patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male. The prevalence of infective endocarditis is higher among males and the risk increases with age  especially after 60.  Slide 3: Past Medical History  He has a past medical history significant for intravenous drug use in his 20s and 30s  although he's been sober for the past 15 years. He also suffers from chronic rheumatoid arthritis  for which he takes immunosuppressant medications. He does not have any known heart defects or previous heart surgeries.  Slide 4: History of Present Illness  He was admitted to the hospital with complaints of fever  muscle ache  fatigue  and shortness of breath for two weeks. These symptoms are consistent with infective endocarditis  an infection caused by bacteria that enter the bloodstream and settle in the heart lining  a heart valve  or a blood vessel.   Slide 5: Relevant Clinical Findings  On examination  he was febrile with temperature of 38.5 degrees Celsius  heart rate 90 beats per minute  and blood pressure 130/80 mmHg. Also detected were a new murmur on auscultation  Janeway lesions on palms and soles  and Osler nodes noted on his fingers and toes.  Slide 6: Relevant Investigation and Diagnostic Procedures  Blood cultures were taken  which grew Staphylococcus aureus. An echocardiogram showed vegetations on the native mitral valve  confirming the diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis.  Slide 7: Discussion  Our patient's demographic data and past medical history put him at a higher risk for developing infective endocarditis. Moreover  his clinical presentation and diagnostic tests further support this diagnosis. His intravenous drug use in the past  even though he's been sober for years  still places him at a higher risk for infective endocarditis.   Slide 8: Conclusion  This case emphasizes the importance of considering infective endocarditis in patients that present with nonspecific symptoms such as fever and fatigue  particularly if they have a past of intravenous drug use and a new heart murmur. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial in reducing mortality rates associated with this condition.

Title: ""Case Presentation: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis""  Slide 1: Introduction Fact: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis predominantly affects adult males above 50 years with preexisting heart conditions  intravenous drug users  individuals with poor dental hygiene  and those with prolonged intravascular access.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics -The patient is Mr. Edward  a 60-year-old Caucasian male  from urban Dallas  Texas  living on his own. -He is retired and primarily engages in home-based activities. -He is a non-smoker but has a history of excessive alcohol use and intravenous drug abuse.  Slide 3: Past Medical History -Mr. Edward reports hypertension for which he takes antihypertensive medication. -He has a history of rheumatic fever in his early adult years  which resulted in mild mitral valve stenosis. -Admitted thrice in past decade for alcohol-related liver problems. -No history or presence of cardiac device implants. -Regular dental check-ups have been skipped  dental hygiene is not optimal.  Slide 4: Presenting Complaints -Patient presents with intermittent fever of two weeks duration  associated with chills. -There is a loss of appetite  weight loss and fatigue. -He reports increased difficulty in breath  occasional night sweats and a persistent cough.  Slide 5: Conclusion -The task now remains to consolidate these findings  perform needed diagnostic procedures (such as blood cultures and echocardiogram)  and define a targeted treatment plan for Mr. Edward. Understanding his medical history and lifestyle habits are key drivers in managing the case and helping mitigate infective endocarditis complications.  Slide 6: Objectives for Future Care -Identify triggers and associated risk factors to mitigate chances of recurrence. -Incorporate a tailored behavioral change strategy for improved lifestyle habits  including substance abuse and dental hygiene. -Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the prescribed medication regimen. -Evaluate the need for valve surgery  given the patient's mild mitral valve stenosis.  Slide 7: References [Appropriate citations from recent studies and guidelines on infective endocarditis]

Title: A Case On Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Slide 1: Introduction - Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis (NVIE) is a serious cardiovascular disease  often associated with high morbidity and mortality rates. Despite advances in diagnostic methods  antimicrobial therapy  and management of complications  NVIE remains a severe health problem.  Slide 2: Demographics  - Based on literature  NVIE typically presents in patients aged 30-60 years and affects both males and females. It has a higher prevalence among people with poor dental health  intravenous drug users  those with prosthetic valves or structural heart diseases and  more recently  in healthcare-associated situations.  Slide 3: Case Profile - Patient Information: 56-year-old male - Occupation: Carpenter - Lifestyle: Non-smoker  ocassional alcohol consumer  no history of recreational drug use.  Slide 4: Past Medical History - The patient has a known history of mitral valve prolapse detected during a routine physical examination five years ago.   - He also has a history of poor dental health but has no history of any other cardiovascular disease or rheumatic fever. - No prior surgeries were reported.  Slide 5: Presenting Complaints - The patient arrived at the clinic complaining of a two-week history of intermittent fever  fatigue  loss of appetite  and weight loss. Recently  he has developed difficulty in breathing.  Slide 6: Clinical Findings  - Upon physical examination  the patient appeared ill and cachectic. - The diagnostic procedures revealed the presence of Janeway's lesions and Osler's nodes on the palms and soles.  - A heart murmur was detected through a stethoscope.  Slide 7: Investigations  - Lab results showed elevated ESR levels  normocytic anemia  and positive blood cultures for Staphylococcus aureus.  - An Echocardiogram confirmed the presence of vegetation on the mitral valve.  Slide 8: Diagnosis  - With these findings  a diagnosis of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis was made.  Slide 9: Management and Prognosis - The patient was immediately started on appropriate antibiotics as per the guidelines. - Surgical consultation was also made considering the patient's severe symptoms and the presence of complications. - Despite advances in management  the prognosis of NVIE remains poor with high mortality rates. Prompt diagnosis and early initiation of treatment are critical to improving outcomes.   Slide 10: Conclusion - NVIE is a severe infectious disease requiring prompt diagnosis and treatment. This case highlights the importance of assessing past medical history  maintaining a high index of suspicion and conducting thorough physical examination in patients presenting with non-specific symptoms.

""A 62-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of intravenous drug use and untreated rheumatic heart disease  now diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis.""

A 60-year-old Hispanic male with a history of IV drug use  untreated dental caries  and rheumatic fever in childhood  now presenting with fever  fatigue  and a heart murmur suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 60-year-old African American male with a history of intravenous drug use and chronic hepatitis C  now presenting with a week-long persistent fever and murmur suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis.

""55-year-old Hispanic male with a history of IV drug use  presenting with native-valve infective endocarditis characterized by high-grade fever  anemia  and worsening cardiac murmur with associated sepsis.""
A 60-year-old male smoker with a past medical history of IV drug use and recurrent pneumonias presents with fever  night sweats  and fatigue  diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 68-year-old male with a history of intravenous drug use and chronic renal failure now presenting with a two-week history of intermittent fever and weight loss  diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of intravenous drug use and recurrent skin infections  now presents with suspected native valve infective endocarditis  characterized by high fever and a new heart murmur.

""72-year-old Caucasian male  with a history of Type 2 diabetes and smoking  presenting with fever  malaise  and weight loss  diagnosed with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  likely secondary to poor glycemic control and invasive dental procedures.""

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use  alcohol dependency  and transient homelessness  presents with fatigue  fever  and a new heart murmur indicative of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 55-year-old Caucasian male smoker with a past medical history of type II diabetes and intravenous drug abuse presenting with fever  fatigue  and a new heart murmur  diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 50-year-old male smoker with previous history of IV drug use and untreated dental caries  presents with persistent fever for the past two weeks  accompanied by malaise  dyspnea on exertion  and unexplained weight loss. Physical examination reveals a new-onset heart murmur  Osler nodes (painful nodules on the fingers)  and Janeway lesions (painless erythematous macules on palms and soles). He denies any recent dental procedures  but does admit to continuing IV drug use despite multiple drug rehabilitation attempts. This presentation is suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis  likely secondary to IV drug use and poor oral hygiene. Confirmatory diagnosis will require blood cultures and echocardiography.

A 62-year-old Caucasian male  with a known history of intravenous drug use and Hepatitis C  presents with symptoms of persistent fever  progressive fatigue  and unintentional weight loss over the last 2 weeks. The patient also reports experiencing night sweats and a new-onset murmur. On examination  he exhibits Osler's nodes on his fingers and toes and Janeway lesions on palms and soles. His medical history includes multiple previous hospitalizations for drug-related infections. He is unemployed and lives in substandard housing. He does not have a regular primary care physician and has minimal continuity of care. He has a 30 pack-year smoking history and admits to ongoing intravenous drug use. These symptoms and findings are suggestive of native valve infective endocarditis.

A 63-year-old  Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use (IDU)  congestive heart failure (CHF)  and a prior mitral valve replacement presents with a 3-week history of intermittent fever  fatigue  weight loss  and new onset of shortness of breath. Physical examination reveals a murmur and splinter hemorrhages under the nails. Labs show a marked elevation in ESR  CRP  and leukocytosis. Two sets of blood cultures are drawn that are positive for Staphylococcus aureus. Echocardiogram reveals vegetations on the native aortic valve consistent with native-valve infective endocarditis. Patient's symptoms  history of IDU and CHF  positive blood cultures  and echocardiographic findings align with a possible diagnosis of native-valve endocarditis.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus and intravenous drug use presents with a 2-week history of subjective fever  night sweats  weight loss  malaise  and new onset shortness of breath. He also describes experiencing intermittent  migratory joint pains  predominantly in his elbows and hips. On physical examination  he exhibits signs of right-sided heart failure. Repeated blood cultures grew Staphylococcus aureus  suggesting a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. He denies recent dental procedures  but admits to frequent needle sharing in the context of drug use.

A 63-year-old Caucasian male with a history of smoking and late stage chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents complaining of three weeks of fatigue  intermittent fevers  drenching night sweats  and a new murmur noticeably audible during recent physical examination. Key features of his case include a heart murmur  consistent with possible valve damage  and vague systemic symptoms in line with an infection like fever  fatigue  and night sweats. Clinically  given the combination of these symptoms  suggestive patient history  presentation  and physical findings on examination  a working diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis is highly suspected.

A 45-year-old Caucasian male  a recovered intravenous drug user with a recent dental procedure  presents with a two week history of intermittent fever  fatigue  joint and muscle pain  and unintentional weight loss. He also complains of a new-onset heart murmur  night sweats  and difficulty breathing. Accompanying symptoms include small red or purple spots on the skin due to tiny hemorrhages (petechiae) and splenomegaly. No history of cardiovascular diseases or use of prosthetic heart devices. The patient exhibits risk factors for native-valve infective endocarditis  including recent dental procedure and history of IV drug use  which could have potentially introduced bacteria into his bloodstream.

A 60-year-old Caucasian male with a history of chronic untreated dental infections presents with malaise  fevers lasting for 3 weeks  and a new-onset heart murmur. His past medical history includes limited access to medical resources due to living in a rural setting. He has lost 10 pounds since the onset of his symptoms and reports occasional night sweats. He denies any intravenous drug use and has no known drug allergies. On physical examination  he is febrile and tachycardic. There is no evidence of peripheral stigmata of endocarditis. Auscultation of the heart reveals a new systolic murmur best heard at the apex. The patient reports no known family history of heart disease. These findings are suggestive of a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 63-year-old male with a history of intravenous drug use presents with a two-week history of malaise  fever  and new-onset heart murmur. The patient also reports experiencing night sweats and unintentional weight loss. He denies any recent dental procedures. He admits to using intravenous heroin without clean needles. On examination  he appears ill  and vital signs reveal tachycardia and fever. A heart exam reveals a new systolic murmur best heard at the left upper sternal border. Labs show an elevated white blood cell count and blood cultures are pending. He is homeless and does not adhere to regular health check-ups. This patient’s clinical presentation and history are suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis. His intravenous drug use  lack of hygiene  and poor healthcare access are significant contributors to his risk of acquiring this condition.

Patient is a 45-year-old Caucasian male  a dishwasher by profession  who presents with a two-week history of fever  night sweats  weight loss and lethargy. It has been discovered that he is an intravenous drug user  having used heroin for the past five years. There is no history of previous heart disease  but he does have a history of Hep C. He reports experiencing a new onset of murmur  and joint aches and pains. On physical examination  he had a body temperature of 38.8 °C  heart rate of 110 beats/minute  and a regurgitant murmur heard at the mitral area. A few tiny red spots (petechiae) were noticed on the conjunctiva and spots on the palms (Janeway lesions) were also noticed. Examination of the peripheral pulses showed a difference in volume between the two arms. His weight was noted to be 10 lbs less than his last doctor visit six months ago. Cardiac ultrasound showed evidence of vegetations on native mitral valve suggestive of endocarditis. Blood cultures have been drawn. Further work-up underway to confirm diagnosis and decide on treatment plan.

A 67-year-old Hispanic male with a past medical history of diabetes and kidney disease presents with a 2-week history of fever  dyspnea  fatigue  and unexplained weight loss. He also reports experiencing night sweats and has identified multiple painful red nodules on his fingers and toes. He denies any recreational drug use. Patient has poor dental hygiene with visible dental caries. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. His family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases. On examination  he is found to be febrile with a heart rate of 110/min and his blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg. Cardiac examination reveals a new regurgitant murmur at the mitral area. The initial assessment indicates possible native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug abuse and chronic homelessness presents with symptoms of fever  weight loss  and fatigue. On auscultation  a new-onset regurgitant murmur is discerned. He also exhibits small hemorrhages on his palms and soles (Janeway lesions) and tender nodules in his fingers (Osler's nodes). The patient's medical history includes Hepatitis C  which is common in intravenous drug users. He has not been adherent to standard medical care and doesn't have any known allergies. There is laboratory evidence of increased inflammation markers including ESR and CRP  along with a positive blood culture indicating bacteria in the bloodstream which suggests native valve infective endocarditis.

A 61-year-old Caucasian male  with a medical history significant for intravenous drug use (IVDU) and hepatitis C  presents with a three-week history of intermittent fever  chills  fatigue  and unintentional weight loss. Upon further questioning  he discloses experiencing discomfort in the right upper quadrant of his abdomen and occasional night sweats. He denies any recent dental procedures and has not been hospitalised recently. His physical examination reveals a new-onset regurgitant murmur noted upon cardiac auscultation and palpable purpura on his lower extremities  suggestive of immune complex deposition. These findings combined with the patient's history of IVDU and hepatitis C raise the suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 60-year-old  Caucasian male with a history of IV drug use and Hepatitis C  presents with a one-month history of moderate fever  chills  night sweats  fatigue  and unexplained 5 kg weight loss. He also complains of a new murmur  noticed by him and confirmed by physical examination. The patient also has petechiae in his conjunctiva and over his legs  and Osler's nodes present on the tips of his fingers. His condition is consistent with symptoms of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 62-year-old male patient with a history of intravenous drug use presents with symptoms of weight loss  night sweats  and generalized weakness lasting over the past month. Past medical history reveals years of chronic hepatitis C infection and untreated dental caries but no other significant infectious or cardiac episodes. He reports decreased appetite  subjective fevers  and a new-onset  mild-to-moderate intensity  constant chest discomfort  which doesn't worsen on effort. On examination  he appears cachectic  has poor dentition  and moderate splenomegaly  with oral temperature registering at 38.5°C (101.3°F). Murmurs are noted on auscultation of the heart  and multiple needle track marks are seen on the forearms. Preliminary blood tests show anemia and elevated ESR. Blood cultures have been drawn and the patient is being evaluated for likely native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 56-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use presents with a two-week duration of fever  malaise  and weight loss. He reports increasing fatigue  poor appetite  and unintentional weight loss of 15 pounds over two weeks. He also complains of a new-onset regurgitant murmur on physical examination  accompanied by petechiae on the conjunctiva and splinter hemorrhages on the nails. Patient has a known history of Hepatitis C  which is common among intravenous drug users.

A 44-year-old male with a history of intravenous drug use presents with a 1-month history of intermittent fever  night sweats  chills  weight loss of approximately 5 kilograms  and fatigue. He describes experiencing short-lived episodes of chest discomfort but denies any pronounced chest pain. Further  he reports noticing several small  painless red-purple skin spots on his extremities. He does not have a history of rheumatic heart disease  dental procedure  or congenital heart disease. He is not on regular medication  denies smoking  and does not consume alcohol. His family history is non-contributory. Physical examination reveals low-grade fever and a diastolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. Examination also reveals petechial rash on his lower extremities and Osler’s nodes on his fingers.   This presentation is consistent with native-valve infective endocarditis  with possible involvement of the tricuspid valve due to the patient's history of intravenous drug use. The absence of joint pain and previously established heart disease alongside the acute onset of symptoms suggest a native valve  rather than a prosthetic valve infection. His generalized symptoms of fatigue  weight loss  fever  and night sweats further contribute to the suspicion of infective endocarditis  while the presence of Osler’s node and petechiae supports this diagnosis.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use  uncontrolled Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  and moderate alcohol consumption presents to the emergency department with general malaise  weight loss  and fever. He also reports a new murmur  and has experienced episodes of night sweats over the past two weeks. He has no prior surgical history or allergies. On physical examination  there is evidence of splinter hemorrhages under his fingernails  as well as Osler's nodes on his fingers and toes. His temperature is 38.5°C  BP is 100/70 mmHg  and his heart rate is regular but rapid. Relevant laboratory results include elevated WBC  C-reactive protein  and ESR  indicating systemic inflammation. Blood cultures are taken and pending. A complete infectious disease workup is underway to monitor and treat right-sided native-valve infective endocarditis  likely secondary to his history of intravenous drug use. This patient requires immediate hospital admission for management  as delay could lead to severe valvular damage  heart failure  or systemic emboli.

A 60-year-old Caucasian male patient  former intravenous drug user  with a history of mitral valve prolapse and poorly controlled type II diabetes presents with a four-week history of intermittent fever  fatigue  unintentional weight loss  and a new murmur noted on examination. The patient also mentions occasional night sweats over the past two weeks. He has no known allergies and his current medications include metformin and lisinopril. Upon physical examination  his heart rate is 100 beats per minute  and his blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. His last HbA1c was 9.5% indicative of poorly controlled diabetes. He is not currently under the care of a cardiologist. He exhibits Osler's nodes on his fingers  a murmur consistent with mitral regurgitation  and splenomegaly. The patient has a two-pack a day smoking history for the past 30 years and currently abstains from drug use. His family history is significant for coronary artery disease in his father. Initial laboratory findings include leukocytosis  elevated ESR  and presence of gram-positive cocci in blood cultures.

A 55-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use presents with persistent high-grade fever  fatigue  and unintentional weight loss over the last month. He reports having recently experienced shortness of breath upon exertion and a new onset of night sweats. He also mentions a visibly painful  red bump on his right forearm  which he attributes to recent drug use. On auscultation  a new heart murmur is detected. No previous history of murmurs  heart valve diseases  or congenital heart defects. His immunizations are up-to-date  and he has no known allergies. There is no family history of heart diseases or early sudden death. This patient's symptoms suggest a high suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis  likely related to his history of IV drug use. Furthermore  evaluation of the bloodstream infection associated with the forearm skin infection may identify the causative organism.

A 60-year-old Caucasian man  with a past medical history significant for type II diabetes and intravenous drug use  presents with a three-week history of persistent fever  fatigue  and weight loss. He also reports experiencing episodic night sweats. He has not been adherent to his diabetes medication and lacks regular medical follow-ups. He reports no recent travel or close contact with sick people. On physical examination  he is febrile with a temperature of 38.5-degree Celsius  and a new systolic murmur is heard on cardiovascular examination. He also has several small  painless erythematous lesions on the palms of his hands  and soles of his feet. A neurological examination reveals minor cognitive impairments. Given the symptoms and history  there is a strong suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 50-year-old male with a history of intravenous drug use and Hepatitis C presents with a four-week history of fever  night sweats  and weight loss. He additionally notes decreased appetite  fatigue  and diffuse body aches. On physical examination  he has several splinter hemorrhages on his fingernails and a palpable  painful lesion on his right heel. He has a new  harsh murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. Bloodwork reveals elevated inflammatory markers and a positive blood culture for Staphylococcus aureus. This presentation is consistent with native-valve infective endocarditis secondary to IV drug use with characteristic systemic symptoms of infection  cardiac murmur  and physical signs of embolic events.

A 50-year-old Caucasian male with a history of long-term IV drug use presents with symptoms indicative of native-valve infective endocarditis. He reports experiencing chills  night sweats  weight loss  fatigability  and a new onset of a heart murmur in the past three weeks. He also describes having intermittent fevers  which are often high-grade (peaking at 102 F). On physical exam  he has scattered petechiae across his trunk and extremities  and the presence of Osler nodes (tender nodules) on his fingers and toes. He has a known history of hepatitis C but denies any history of HIV infection or other immune-compromising diseases. He is currently homeless and lacks access to regular medical care  which likely contributes to the delayed presentation of severe symptoms.

A 60-year-old caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use  and no known heart disease  presents with fever  malaise  and rapid weight loss over the past four weeks. He also endorses experiencing night sweats  a new heart murmur  and multiple painful red nodes on his skin. He denies chest pain  dyspnea but complains about experiencing some dysphagia and loss of appetite. He has a long history of opioid abuse and smokes. His family history shows paternal side heart disease. He has no record of regular health checks despite having a poorly controlled lifestyle. His BP is 130/80 mm Hg  pulse rate 90 bpm  and temperature 38.5°C (101.3°F). Physical examination exhibits a diastolic murmur best heard along the lower sternal border  splinter hemorrhages  Osler's nodes  and Janeway lesions. Upon these findings  he is highly suspected for native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 60-year-old African American man with a past medical history of intravenous drug use  prior staphylococcal skin infection  smoking  and hypertension presents to the clinic with a 2-week history of weakness  fatigue  weight loss  night sweats  intermittent fever and a new heart murmur. He mentions he has been increasingly fatigued and has lost approximately 10 pounds since the onset of his symptoms  even though his diet hasn't changed. Physical examination reveals an afebrile patient with the presence of Osler nodes on his fingers and toes  Janeway lesions on the palms and soles  conjunctival hemorrhages  and a III/VI systolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. These findings are suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis.   Reference: The underrepresented population in this problem is African American men  who are more common among those with infective endocarditis related to intravenous drug use. Patients aged between 30-50 years old make up the majority of these cases  however  older patients have also been represented  which is why a 60-year-old man was chosen for this case.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for intravenous drug use  and untreated dental caries presents with a 2-week history of progressively worsening fatigue  fever  chills  night sweats  and a new-onset  acute lower back pain. His vitals at presentation are abnormal with a fever of 38.5 C  HR 110. On physical examination  he has a diastolic decrescendo murmur best heard at the left sternal border  multiple petechiae on his lower extremities and painful erythematous nodules (Osler nodes) on his fingers. He also has mild splenomegaly. His blood cultures grow Streptococcus viridans.

A 65-year-old Caucasian man  with a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and a recent dental extraction  presents to the clinic with a 3-week history of persistent  low-grade fever and tiredness. He also reports experiences with intermittent night sweats  a drastic weight loss of about 20 pounds over the past month  and a new onset of malaise. Upon physical examination  it is observed that he has painful erythematous nodules on his fingertips and toes (Osler nodes)  petechiae on the conjunctival  oral  and skin surfaces  as well as painless  small erythematous lesions on the palms or soles (Janeway lesions). Additionally  the patient exhibits a regurgitant murmur upon auscultation. Blood cultures are taken  and the patient is admitted for suspected native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 64-year-old African American male with a history of IV drug use and uncontrolled diabetes presents with symptoms of persistent fever  night sweats  weight loss  and a new murmur on auscultation. The patient has had recurrent hospital admissions due to skin abscesses related to drug use. Recently he has noticed a rapid weight loss without any changes in diet or exercise. He also complains of joint pain and fatigue. Physical examination reveals petechiae on the lower extremities and Roth spots in the eyes. Labs show increased ESR and CRP  and multiple blood cultures are positive for Staph aureus. The ECG shows some nonspecific ST-T wave changes  but no primary QT changes or arrhythmia. Echo reveals vegetative growth on the mitral valve  and severe mitral regurgitation is observed. These findings are indicative of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 62-year-old African American male  with a history of untreated dental caries and previous methamphetamine use  presents with a four-week history of unexplained weight loss  fever  night sweats  and fatigue. Despite recent use of over-the-counter medication  his fevers persist; they are undulating and typically occur in the late afternoon or evening. He also reports a newly developing shortness of breath on exertion. On physical examination  he has a diastolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border along with cutaneous manifestations such as Janeway lesions and petechiae in the conjunctiva and palate. There are no clinical symptoms of heart failure visible. He currently has no significant family history. Preliminary laboratory investigation shows mild anemia and elevated inflammatory markers.

A 58-year-old male  with a known history of intravenous drug use  presents to the emergency department complaining of persistent fever  malaise  night sweats  and weight loss over the past three weeks. He also reports exertional dyspnea  intermittent joint pain  and recently noticed a red rash on the palms and soles. Physical examination reveals peripheral stigmata of endocarditis such as Janeway lesions  Osler's nodes  and splinter hemorrhages under the nails. As per the literature  patients with a history of intravenous drug use are often more susceptible to developing native valve infective endocarditis  and this individual's constellation of symptoms align with this diagnosis.

A 55-year-old White male construction worker  with a history of intravenous drug use about a decade ago and no recent hospitalizations presents with a six-week history of intermittent fever  fatigue  and unexplained weight loss. He also reports experiencing night sweats and has been increasingly short of breath over the past week. There is no known history of cardiac disease or rheumatic fever  but patient mentions a recent dental procedure one month ago  for which he did not take any antibiotics. The patient is a smoker  but denies any alcohol or illicit drug use in the recent years. Physical examination reveals a grade 3/6 systolic murmur at the mitral area  pale due to anemia  and splinter hemorrhages on the nail beds. He has no signs of heart failure on presentation.

A 58-year-old Caucasian male with a history of type 2 diabetes and intravenous drug use presents with a three-week history of intermittent fever  fatigue  and night sweats. He reports a new-onset  intermittent heart murmur and has recently experienced unintentional weight loss of 15 pounds. Over this period  he has had several episodes of blood-streaked sputum and mild shortness of breath. He exhibits Osler's nodes on his fingers and toes  and Janeway lesions are visible on his palms and soles. Findings from the physical examination also include slight swelling and tenderness of his left knee. He is currently unemployed  lives alone  and admits to unsafe needle practices. He does not have any past hospitalizations or surgeries. His at-home medications include metformin for his diabetes. He has no known allergies. His social history is significant for tobacco use and crystal methamphetamine use  and he doesn't engage in regular physical activity. His family history is non-contributory.

A 62-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history of intravenous drug use and unregulated diabetes presents to the emergency department with a 3-week history of malaise  night sweats  intermittent fevers  and recent onset of dyspnea. He denies any chest pain but reports some weight loss and appetite decrease. Physical exam results show a new murmur and petechiae on his extremities. Findings are suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis.

Patient Information: A 65-year-old Caucasian male  Medical History: Recent (less than 3 months ago) dental procedure; history of heart murmur secondary to mild aortic regurgitation  smoking (40 pack-years)  alcohol use (moderate)  Presenting Complaints: The patient is currently presenting with a 2-week history of fever (spiking  with temperatures up to 102°F)  chills  night sweats  weight loss  malaise  and body aches. He also reports a 4-day history of new back pain and a 3-day history of a petechial rash on his lower extremities.  Physical Examination: Upon examination  the patient has a systolic ejection murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border. He also has petechiae on his lower legs and feet. Dental examination revealed poor oral hygiene but no active dental caries.   This patient presents with cardinal signs of native valve infective endocarditis (IE)  which include fever and cardiac murmur  as well as several of the minor Duke criteria  including vascular phenomena (petechiae) and immunologic phenomena. His recent dental procedure  mild aortic regurgitation  smoking  and alcohol use contribute to his risk of IE.

A 65-year-old male African American patient presents to the emergency department complaining of fatigue  fever  night sweats  and weight loss over the last several months. He also mentions experiencing heart palpitations for the past few weeks. The patient has a significant medical history of diabetes and uncontrolled hypertension. He reports that he doesn't have regular check-ups and hasn't been taking his prescribed medications. He is also a pack-a-day smoker for forty years and has a history of intravenous drug use in his youth but has been clean for the past 20 years. On physical exam  the patient appears ill and pale. A cardiac murmur is identified  and small  tender spots are observed under the skin of his fingers (Osler's nodes)  with splinter hemorrhages present in his nail beds. Based on these presentations  the existing risk factors and medical history  the problem of native-valve infective endocarditis is considered.

A 65-year-old African-American man with a past medical history of intravenous drug use and poorly-controlled diabetes presents with a four-week history of fever  generalized body pain  and rapid weight loss. He also complains of fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. Denied any recent dental procedures. On examination  he has conjunctival pallor and splinter hemorrhages on his fingernails. Auscultation of the heart reveals a pansystolic murmur in the left lower sternal edge. Neurological examination indicates no focal deficits. Given the symptoms and the findings  there is a high suspicion for native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 45-year-old intravenous drug-using Hispanic man presents with a 2-week history of fatigue  fever  night sweats  and weight loss. Past medical history is notable for Hepatitis C and recurrent skin abscesses. On examination  he appears fatigued with a temperature of 38.5 C. Cardiovascular examination reveals a new cardiac murmur and he has multiple petechiae on his lower extremities. His blood cultures show growth of Staphylococcus aureus  suggesting a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 60-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use  congestive heart failure  and type II diabetes mellitus presents with 2 weeks of persistent low-grade fever  extreme fatigue  night sweats  and shortness of breath. On examination  multiple Janeway lesions were noted on the palms and soles  and Osler's nodes on the fingers and toes. Other findings include a new murmur suggesting valvular heart disease. Blood culture is positive for Staphylococcus aureus  pointing to a likely diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. The patient's cardiac health history  drug use  and diabetes may have contributed to his vulnerability to this condition.

A 55-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of intravenous drug abuse presents with a one-month history of fatigue  night sweats  weight loss  a persistently high fever  as well as intermittent chest pain. Physical examination reveals a new murmur over the mitral valve  Osler's nodes on fingers and toes  and Janeway lesions on the palms and soles. The patient confirms no recent dental procedures or surgeries  but admits to sharing needles for drug use. The patient's vitals are stable but he appears weak and ill. His social history reveals he lives alone and has been unemployed for the last 2 years  however  he denies homelessness. He has no known family history of heart disease.

A 62-year-old Hispanic male with a past medical history of chronic periodontal disease and moderate alcohol use presents to the clinic complaining of gradual onset fatigue  weakness  low-grade fever  loss of appetite  and a weight loss of 10 pounds in the last 2 months. He also reports a painful purplish rash on his hands and feet  which had started to appear a couple of weeks ago. Physical examination reveals a new systolic murmur along with painless  red linear lesions in the nail beds  and tender lesions on his fingertips and toes. Given his subacute symptoms and other findings  and considering his chronic periodontal disease  it’s highly suspected that he is suffering from native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 54-year-old Caucasian male with a known long-term history of intravenous drug use presents with complaints of persistent and high-grade fever for the past 15 days. Associated symptoms include chills  sweating  fatigue  weight loss  and a new-onset heart murmur. The patient also describes experiencing muscle pain and small  painful  red or purple pea-sized bumps under the skin on his fingers and toes. He denies any respiratory distress  chest pain  syncope  or a history of rheumatic heart disease. He has never had dental procedures recently  has not had surgeries in the last six months  and has no known allergies. On physical examination  he is febrile and looks generally unwell. Notably  there are multiple puncture marks consistent with intravenous drug use. Vital signs show borderline tachycardia. Cardiac examination reveals a systolic murmur best heard at the mitral area. Due to the classic presentation along with his risk factors  a working diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis is made.

A 65-year-old male with a history of intravenous drug use presents with a four-week history of fevers  chills  fatigue  and unintended weight loss. He also reports experiencing night sweats and intermittent joint pain. On physical examination  he has a new heart murmur and Janeway lesions noted on his palms and soles. He reports no recent dental procedures or surgeries. Given his symptoms  history of IV drug use  the new murmur  and cutaneous signs  the clinical suspicion is high for native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 64-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use without any known comorbidities  presents with a 10-day history of fevers  generalized malaise  weakness  and unexpected weight loss. He also reports a new onset of low back pain  night sweats  and intermittent chills. On examination  he has a fever of 38.5°C  a new heart murmur  several small non-painful erythematous skin lesions on palms and soles  along with multiple needle track marks on his forearms. He is hemodynamically stable. Limited histories of recent dental procedures or exposure to unclean equipment are noted.

A 62-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use and recent dental procedure presents with a 10-day history of fatigue  low-grade fevers  and night sweats. Patient also reports a progressive weight loss and malaise. There is no known history of heart disease in the patient's family  but he is a smoker and reports occasional alcohol use. On physical examination  he presents with tachycardia  a new heart murmur  and Janeway lesions on his palms and soles. Blood investigations reveal elevated inflammatory markers and positive blood cultures  suggesting native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 60-year-old African American male with past medical history significant for IV drug use  hepatitis C  and multiple dental procedures presents with fatigue  weight loss  intermittent fever  and a new heart murmur noticed over the past two months. On examination  he has petechiae on his palms and soles and tender  red nodules (Osler's nodes) on his fingers. His teeth appear poorly maintained  and his oral hygiene is suboptimal. His blood cultures grow Staphylococcus aureus and an echocardiogram reveals vegetations on his mitral valve. The patient's symptoms  examination findings  and diagnostic results along with his risk factors point toward a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 64-year-old African American male with a past medical history of intravenous drug use and type 2 diabetes presents with a week-long history of fever  fatigue  and a new murmur. He notes he is constantly feeling weak and has experienced unintentional weight loss with decreased appetite. He also describes experiencing migraines and seeing spots. Physical examination reveals a diastolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border and tender  erythematous lesions on his palms and soles. Laboratory studies reveal leukocytosis and blood cultures grow Staphylococcus aureus. These findings are consistent with a case of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 60-year-old Caucasian male construction worker with a history of intravenous drug use is reported to present complaining of fever  night sweats  chills  generalized fatigue  and weight loss for about three weeks. He has also recently been complaining of dyspnea and shows signs of congestive cardiac failure along with a new cardiac murmur. There is no other significant past medical history apart from IVDU. On physical examination  the patient looks ill  with pallor  low-grade fever  subconjunctival hemorrhages  and Osler's nodes seen on his hands and fingers. On cardiovascular examination  a new murmur is heard  indicative of possible valve abnormalities  possibly aortic regurgitation. His vitals reveal moderate tachycardia and slightly elevated blood pressure. Given his history of intravenous drug use and current symptoms  a presumptive diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis is made. Further tests including blood culture and transesophageal echocardiography could be used to confirm diagnosis and plan treatment.

A 52-year-old Caucasian man with a past medical history of intravenous drug use and Hepatitis C presents with a 3-week history of worsening fever  night sweats  and general malaise. The fever was initially low-grade but recently spiked to 39.5 degrees Celsius. The patient also reports a new onset of a heart murmur  weight loss  and increased fatigue. He denies any history of rheumatic fever or congenital heart disease. He has not received any dental treatments recently and does not report any respiratory or urinary symptoms. The patient's persistent fever and new murmur raise concerns for native-valve infective endocarditis  which may be associated with his history of intravenous drug use.

A 63-year-old Caucasian male  with a medical history of intravenous drug use  obesity  and type II diabetes mellitus  presents with a 2-week history of intermittent high fever  night sweats  fatigue  and weight loss. The patient also reports a new-onset heart murmur and a painful  swollen red bump on his elbow. History of noncompliance to diabetes medications and missed regular check-ups in the past year. Despite never having been diagnosed with heart issues before  the presence of a new heart murmur  along with systemic signs of infection and septic emboli evidenced by the clinical symptoms in the elbow  raise the suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 60-year-old Caucasian man with a history of intravenous drug use presents with a one-month history of intermittent high-grade fevers  night sweats  weight loss  and a new-onset heart murmur. He has not had any surgical interventions in the past. His vitals upon presenting showed a heart rate of 95 bpm and a fever of 38.5C. Physical examination revealed the presence of Osler's nodes on his fingers  Janeway lesions on his palms and soles  and splinter hemorrhages in his nails. He also showed signs of conjunctival pallor suggestive of anemia. Blood cultures were drawn and showed growth for Staphylococcus aureus. Echocardiography revealed vegetations on the tricuspid valve suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis. The patient is HIV negative and has no history of congenital heart defects. He admits to not adhering to harm reduction services in his community  often sharing needles during drug use.

A 59-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of Intravenous drug use  Hepatitis C and heart murmur presents with a four-week history of persistent fever  weight loss and malaise. He has also been experiencing occasional night sweats and intermittent chest discomfort. The patient reports a recent dental procedure a month back. Examination reveals osler’s nodes on the fingertips and a new murmur on auscultation. He denies any recent travel  animal exposure or unpasteurized dairy consumption.

A 62-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use presents to the ER with a 3-week history of chills  night sweats  fatigue  unintentional weight loss  and new onset of shortness of breath. He also reports experiencing a low-grade fever intermittently for the same duration. His social history is significant for homelessness. Physical examination reveals needle track marks on his arms  pallor  and a new systolic murmur heard best at the lower left sternal border. He also has multiple Janeway lesions on the palms and soles  and Osler nodes on his fingers. The patient appears cachectic and has poor dental hygiene with evidence of untreated dental caries. Blood cultures have been sent and empirical antibiotic therapy started. His presentation combined with his high risk behavior of intravenous drug use and poor dental hygiene indicates a working diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 40-year-old intravenous drug user Caucasian male presents with a 2-week history of fever  malaise  and progressive dyspnea. He also reports a weight loss of approximately 10 pounds during this period  but denies any issues related to appetite. Physical examination reveals a grade III/VI systolic ejection murmur on the left lower sternal border  Janeway lesions on his palms and soles  and Osler's nodes on his fingers. He is febrile  has mild tachycardia  and appears diaphoretic. He also has a history of Hepatitis C infection  for which he is currently not under treatment. Given these findings  the patient is suspected to have native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 62-year-old Caucasian male from a rural farming area with a history of untreated dental caries and a 30-pack-year smoking history presents with a 3-week history of intermittent fever  night sweats  weight loss  and fatigue. New onset of unexplained heart murmur noted  along with vascular phenomena such as petechiae and Janeway lesions. Patient denies IV drug use but admits to poor oral hygiene and no recent dental visits. Diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis is being considered.

A 58-year-old male  scanner operator with a history of type 2 diabetes and periodontal disease  presents with a 2-week history of persistent fever  lethargy  appetite loss  and nocturnal sweats. There is no known drug or alcohol habit involved. Over the past 3 days  he has noticed that the whites of his eyes have turned yellow and developed dark urine without abdominal pain. He further reports a new onset of difficulty in breathing  mainly during exertion. On examination  he has a high-grade fever  tachycardia  jaundice  and splinter hemorrhages under the nails. Lung sounds are decreased on the left side with a faint mid diastolic murmur noted at the left sternal border.

A 61-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of intravenous drug use and previous episodes of skin and soft tissue infections presents with fever  malaise  and new-onset heart palpitations for the past week. He has also noted weight loss in the past few weeks. On examination  he is febrile with a pansystolic murmur in the left lower sternal border that is new compared to the previous examination record six months ago. Ophthalmologic examination demonstrates Roth spots  and skin examination shows multiple splinter hemorrhages under the nails. The patient has no history of heart surgery or valve replacement. His blood cultures are positive for Staphylococcus aureus.

A 60-year-old Caucasian male  with past medical history significant for intravenous drug use  presents with a 3-week history of intermittent fever  chills  and night sweats. Additionally  he reports a recent loss of appetite and associated weight loss  as well as increasing fatigue. On physical examination  there are small tender erythematous nodules on his fingers and toes (Osler's nodes) and non-tender  flat  erythematous macules on the palms and soles (Janeway lesions). His cardiovascular exam reveals a diastolic murmur best heard over the left sternal border. Blood cultures are drawn and the patient is admitted for further management for presumed infective endocarditis.

A 58-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug abuse presents to the emergency department complaining of persistent fever  night sweats  fatigue  and unintended weight loss over the past couple of weeks. He also describes a new onset of lower back pain. He denies any cough  chest pain  or shortness of breath. But  he admits to using heroin recently. On examination  he has a temperature of 101°F  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  and blood pressure 110/70 mmHg. Cardiac examination reveals a previously unidentified systolic murmur. No Osler nodes  Janeway lesions or petechiae noted. Labs reveal elevated ESR and CRP with anemia. Blood cultures are drawn and pending. Given his past medical history and new onset symptoms  there is a high clinical suspicion for infective endocarditis.

A 55-year-old Caucasian male with a history of illicit intravenous drug use (IVDU) and hepatitis C infection  presents with a 2-week history of fever  fatigue  unintended weight loss  and malaise. He also reports recently experiencing night sweats and shortness of breath on exertion. Physical examination reveals a new-onset murmur on cardiac auscultation  tender red spots on the palms and soles (Osler’s nodes)  small  red lines under the fingernails (splinter hemorrhages)  and multiple petechiae on the skin. His complete blood count shows high levels of leukocytes  and blood culture results show the presence of Staphylococcus aureus. The patient undergoes transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) which demonstrates vegetations on the tricuspid valve  indicative of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male patient with a past medical history of moderate-to-severe aortic stenosis and type 2 diabetes presents with a two-week history of low-grade fevers  fatigue  and unintentional weight loss of around 10lbs. He also complains of dyspnea on exertion  which has gradually worsened over the past week. There is no history of intravenous drug use. On examination  he is febrile with a temperature of 100.8 F  has a new-onset  grade 3/6 diastolic murmur heard best at the aortic area  and exhibits Janeway lesions on the palms and soles. White Blood Cell count was elevated at 15 000 cells/μl on lab testing. An echocardiogram was ordered to evaluate for possible infective endocarditis.

A 40-year-old homeless Caucasian male with a past medical history of intravenous drug use presents to the emergency room with complaints of fever  chills and fatigue for the past two weeks. He also reports dyspnea  orthopnea  and intermittent chest pain. On physical examination  he's febrile with a temperature of 39°C. He has palpable spleen and exhibits conjunctival pallor  clubbing of fingers  and traces of petechiae on his lower limb. Cardiac examination reveals heart murmurs. The patient has no known documented medical care or active medications. Blood cultures and transthoracic echocardiogram have been sent to confirm the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis secondary to intravenous drug abuse.

A 60-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of intravenous drug use  and recent  untreated dental infection presents with a three-week history of high-grade fever  malaise  and weight loss. The patient also describes new onset of severe shortness of breath  orthopnea and palpitations. Physical examination reveals evidence of heart failure  including peripheral edema  elevated jugular venous pressure and a new pansystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. There are also notable findings of Osler nodes on the fingertips and splinter hemorrhages in the nails suggestive of embolic phenomena. Blood cultures are pending.

A 45-year-old male intravenous drug user presents with a 2-week history of intermittent fever  night sweats  and weight loss. On physical examination  he has a low-grade fever (38.2 degrees Celsius) and appears generally unwell. Cardiac auscultation reveals a new grade 3/6 systolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. Petechiae are noted over the upper extremities and conjunctiva. His past medical history is significant for hepatitis C and he has a known history of heroin addiction. His family history is unremarkable and he reports no known drug allergies. He is currently homeless and does not take any prescribed medications regularly. Lab findings reveal leukocytosis  elevated sedimentation rate  and positive blood cultures for Staphylococcus aureus. His echocardiogram shows a large vegetation on the tricuspid valve. These findings are consistent with a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 60-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use presents with fatigue  weight loss  and low-grade fever for the last two weeks. He also complains of a new onset  persistent headache and night sweats. He denies any respiratory or gastrointestinal symptoms. He is vague about his drug history  but admits to recent needle use. There is no recent history of dental procedures or assessment. He was incarcerated 10 years ago for drug-related offences but has since held stable employment and lives with his wife. His immunizations are up to date and he denies any known allergies or other past medical history. On physical examination  he has conjunctival pallor and appears weak and malnourished. Cardiac auscultation reveals a holosystolic murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border. The patient also has multiple attrition scars on both the upper limbs suggestive of repeated needle use. Relevant investigations are planned to rule out native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 62-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of intravenous drug use  chronic hepatitis C  and intermittent homelessness presents with a 2-week history of malaise  night sweats  and a new murmur. He has a low-grade fever  increased fatigue  weight loss  and reports loss of appetite. On examination  he exhibits signs of peripheral embolization  such as petechiae in the conjunctiva  Janeway lesions on his palms and soles  and Osler's nodes on his fingers and toes.

A 55-year-old African-American male with a history of intravenous drug use  and recurrent untreated dental infections presents with three weeks of intermittent fevers  night sweats  weight loss  and new-onset weakness. He also reports experiencing a changing nature of pain from an existing chronic backache. On physical examination  he has a new heart murmur suggestive of tricuspid regurgitation. He also has scattered petechiae on his lower extremities  Janeway lesions on his palms  and Osler nodes on his fingers. His oral exam reveals poor dentition and active dental caries. There are also needle track marks seen on both his upper extremities signifying active intravenous drug use. No neurologic deficits are noted. Blood cultures are taken and he is immediately started on empirical antibiotics for suspected native-valve infective endocarditis secondary to his high-risk behavior of intravenous drug use and poor dental hygiene.

A 62-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use  hepatitis C  and previous MRSA infection  presents with one week of subjective fevers  night sweats  and malaise  along with multiple tender nodules on his fingers and toes. He also complains of unintentional weight loss of 10lbs over the past month. He notices dark urine but denies any abdominal pain  jaundice  cough  chest pain  or shortness of breath. He currently homeless and reveals a recent relapse into IV drug use but denies any other high-risk sexual or social behaviors. His temperature on admission is 101.2°F (38.4°C). On physical examination  multiple Osler nodes are observed on his fingers and toes  and a systolic murmur is heard most intensely at the left mid sternal border. The clinical presentation  combined with his history of MRSA infection and intravenous drug use  suggests the possibility of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 63-year-old male  with a past medical history of Stage 2 hypertension  diabetes mellitus  and previous smoking habits  presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of persistent fever  fatigue  and unexplained weight loss. He reports experiencing night sweats and new onset of exertional dyspnea over the same timeframe. He also mentions an intermittent  nonspecific abdominal discomfort  previously attributed to dietary intolerance. Physical examination reveals a mid-diastolic rumbling murmur at the cardiac apex  along with Janeway lesions on the palms and soles  and Osler's nodes on the fingers. Blood tests show anemia  elevated inflammatory markers  and three sets of blood cultures grown on aerobic and anaerobic media reveal Streptococcus viridans. An ECHO is ordered due to high suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis  specifically affecting the mitral valve.

A 58-year-old Caucasian male presents with a two-month history of unexplained weight loss  fatigue  intermittent fever  malaise  and a single episode of night sweat. He also complains of dull  constant discomfort in the left side of his chest. Past medical history is significant for intravenous drug use  though he self-reports being clean for the past eight years. He’s currently working as a waste management technician. His family history is unremarkable. On physical examination  he has a low-grade fever  an audible heart murmur  and petechiae on his arms and palms. Blood cultures have been taken and he is awaiting results.

A 57-year-old Caucasian male smoker with a past medical history of intravenous drug abuse presents with worsening shortness of breath  weakness  and intermittent fever with night sweats over the past four weeks. He also reports weight loss and loss of appetite. Patient's family notes that he appears confused lately and has a decreased urine output. On physical examination  he is febrile with a new diastolic murmur noted on cardiovascular examination. He also has multiple subungual hemorrhages and an erythematous  swollen right ankle joint suggestive of septic arthritis. Blood cultures are pending. The patient's presentation of fever  new murmur  septic arthritis and multiple systemic symptoms may suggest a diagnosis of infective endocarditis  further investigation with echocardiography is planned.

A 50-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for intravenous drug use and untreated dental caries presents with a two-week history of fever  fatigue  and a new-onset  continuous heart murmur. He also reports unintentional weight loss  poor appetite  and night sweats over the same period. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or changes in vision. His symptoms have progressively worsened  with the fever not improving despite over-the-counter medications  prompting his visit. He is socially isolated  unemployed  and admits to ongoing drug misuse. No known allergies or family history of heart diseases. On physical examination  he was febrile  and cardiac auscultation revealed a new grade 3/6 systolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal edge. Dentition was poor with visible decay. No Osler's nodes  Janeway lesions  or Roth spots were noted. Initial suspicion is of native valve infective endocarditis  most likely secondary to his intravenous drug use and poor dentition.

A 61-year-old White male with history of IV drug use and Hepatitis C presents with a 3-week history of intermittent fever  night sweats and weight loss. Symptoms also include generalized fatigue and a new-onset cardiac murmur on the left side. Physical examination reveals several subcutaneous abscesses in the crook of the arm  petechiae in the conjunctiva and nail bed and Osler's nodes on his fingers and toes. Dental exam reveals poor oral hygiene. Echocardiogram reveals vegetations on the tricuspid valve confirming probable native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use and type 2 diabetes presents with a 2-week history of fevers  chills  and progressive fatigue. He reports recent unexplained weight loss and dyspnea on exertion. He also mentions having experienced a few episodes of nocturnal sweating. On examination  he is febrile with a temperature of 38.4ºC (101.1ºF)  with a heartrate of 104 beats per minute. Cardiac auscultation reveals a new grade II/VI systolic murmur best heard at the apex. Blood cultures have been drawn and are pending. Given his symptoms and clinical presentation  there is high clinical suspicion for native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 63-year-old Caucasian male  with a known history of intravenous drug use and prior episodes of pneumonia  presents with two weeks of persistent low-grade fever  generalized weakness  and unintended weight loss. He's also been experiencing occasional episodes of night sweats and shortness of breath. Patient has poor oral hygiene and also admits to neglect of routine healthcare. Physical examination reveals pallor  osler nodes on the pads of several fingers  petechial rash on extremities  and splenomegaly. Heart auscultation identifies a new mitral regurgitation murmur heard best over the apex. No history of prosthetic valve placement or recent surgical procedures. Given the clinical presentation and past medical history  differential diagnosis includes a high suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 56-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use presents with a 2-week history of fatigue  intermittent fever  and night sweats.
