He also reports new onset lower back pain radiating to both legs. On examination  he has a grade III pan-systolic murmur heard over the precordium and small erythematous macules on palms and soles (Janeway's lesions). His temperature is 38.5°C  and blood tests show elevated inflammatory markers. The suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis arises in the context of his risk factors of drug use and presence of cardiac murmur  with systemic signs of infection and characteristic skin lesions.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use presents with 3 weeks of fever  fatigue  and unexplained weight loss. He also reports experiencing malaise  anorexia  and night sweats. On examination  he has a new murmur on cardiac auscultation  Janeway lesions on his hands and feet  and Osler nodes on his fingers. Lab findings show an elevated ESR and CRP  with positive blood cultures for Staphylococcus aureus. The patient's history of intravenous drug use and current presentation is suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis. He denies any previous history of heart disease or rheumatic fever.

A 45-year-old male  obese (BMI 30.5) with a past medical history of IV drug use and untreated dental caries  presents with a 4-week history of generalized discomfort  fatigue  weight loss  and a new-onset  mid-systolic murmur over the tricuspid area. He also complains of low-grade intermittent fevers  night sweats  and a recent bout of hematuria. The patient denies any history of rheumatic heart disease or past valve surgery  but admits to not seeking regular medical or dental care. Physical examination reveals splinter hemorrhages in the nail beds  Osler's nodes on the fingers and toes  and Janeway lesions on the palms and soles. His vital signs are stable  but he appears chronically ill.

A 56-year-old homeless African American male  with a history of intravenous (IV) drug use  comes to the emergency department. He reports a 1-week history of persistent fevers  fatigue  and a new onset of unusual dark spots on his palms and soles. He also mentions experiencing shortness of breath  especially on exertion  witnessing unexplained weight loss and night sweats. He admits to regular IV drug use and has never been treated for any prior infection or disease. He also shares that he hasn't been able to access regular meals and healthcare services due to his living situation. His condition raises suspicion for native-valve infective endocarditis  predominantly associated with his IV drug use. His shortness of breath suggests potential development of cardiac or pulmonary complications due to the infection.

A 60-year-old Caucasian male  with a known history of intravenous drug use  presents with a three-week history of persistent high-grade fever  chills  and night sweats. He also reports increasing fatigue and poor appetite  along with unexplained weight loss. In addition  he notes an episode of transient visual loss in his right eye a week ago. He has no known history of heart disease. He has not been adherent to previous substance abuse treatment programs and was recently homeless. On examination  there are conjunctival hemorrhages and tender  erythematous nodules on his hands (Osler's nodes). Cardiac auscultation reveals a new murmur suggestive of aortic regurgitation.

A 60-year-old African American male with a history of intravenous drug use and hepatitis C presents with a 4-week history of fever  chills  fatigue and weight loss. The patient also reports recent onset of new heart murmurs and lower back pain. Further history reveals night sweats and intermittent fevers for around a month  but denies any cough or changes in bowel or urinary habits. On physical exam  the patient appears cachectic and has a temperature of 101.8°F. He demonstrates several stigmata of infective endocarditis including Osler's nodes (tender nodules on the pads of the fingers and toes)  Janeway lesions (non-tender  flat  macular  red lesions on the palms and soles)  and Roth spots (retinal hemorrhages). The patient also has multiple track marks on his arms indicative of IV drug use. The remainder of his physical examination  including respiratory and abdominal exam  is normal. Client’s blood cultures grow Staphylococcus aureus. Based on the clinical and laboratory findings  he is diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 52-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use presents with a one-month history of intermittent fever  malaise and weight loss. He also reports a new-onset  harsh  systolic murmur on the left sternal border  mild tachycardia  pallor and splinter hemorrhages in the nail beds on clinical examination. He denies any recent dental procedures but admits to recurrent use of non-sterilized needles for drug administrations. There are no other significant findings on the physical examination. His past medical history is significant for Hepatitis C infection. He is not on any chronic medications and does not have any known allergies. The patient is single  unemployed and homeless. The immediate concern is the possibility of native-valve infective endocarditis secondary to recurrent use of unsterile needles and chronic Hepatitis C infection.

A 65-year-old homeless male with a history of untreated Type 2 diabetes and IV drug abuse presents with complaints of fever  chills  weakness  and an unexplained weight loss over the past few weeks. He has also noticed dark spots (resembling splinter hemorrhages) on his nails and the whites of his eyes have taken on a yellowish hue. The patient admits to poor hygiene practices and reports having a ""heart murmur"" noticed years ago but has never sought medical attention for it. His social history is significant for frequent unprotected sex and a 35-pack-year smoking history. He denies any past surgical history. Physical examination reveals fever  an IV track on his arm indicating illicit IV drug use  jaundiced eyes  splinter hemorrhages on the nails  a systolic murmur best heard over the mitral area  and small  tender  erythematous nodules palpable at the finger pulps and toes (Osler's Nodes). His condition and symptoms are suggestive of possible native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 58-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of intravenous drug use presents to the emergency department complaining of fever  fatigue  and unintended weight loss over the past month. The patient additionally reports experiencing night sweats and noticing a new-onset  non-pruritic  red rash on his palms and soles in the past week. Physical examination reveals the presence of Osler's nodes on his fingers and Janeway lesions on his palms and soles. Initial lab work shows an elevated white blood cell count  erythrocyte sedimentation rate  and C-reactive protein. A subsequent transthoracic echocardiogram reveals vegetation on the mitral valve  suggesting a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. The patient’s exam findings and history of intravenous drug use  a known risk factor  highly supports the suspicion of infective endocarditis.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and mild congestive heart failure presents with a 2-week history of intermittent fever  night sweats  fatigue  and unexplained weight loss. He also reports experiencing occasional shortness of breath and palpitations. The patient admits to recent dental work 1 month priorly without antibiotic prophylaxis. On exam  his temperature is 38.5 °C  BP is 140/90 mm Hg  HR is 110 beats/min  and RR is 20 breaths/min with O2 Sat 94% on room air. He has janeway lesions on the palm of his hand and Osler nodes on toe pads. Cardiac auscultation reveals a new murmur consistent with mitral regurgitation. These symptoms suggest the possibility of native valve infective endocarditis  likely secondary to Streptococcus viridans following dental work.

A 42-year-old African American male  a tattoo artist with a history of recreational intravenous drug use and untreated hepatitis C  presents to the emergency department with a 3-week history of persistent high-grade fever  malaise  loss of appetite  weight loss of about 8 lbs  and increasing fatigue. The patient also complains of low back pain  dyspnea on moderate exertion and a new onset skin rash on his legs. He reports no regular medical checkups  no known allergies  and no previous surgeries. Patient is a tobacco smoker  has no known family history of cardiovascular diseases.   On examination  multiple petechiae (non-blanching skin rash) are noticed on his lower limbs  and spinter hemorrhage under his nails. Cardiac auscultation reveals a new onset regurgitant murmur best heard at the apex. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. His blood pressure is within normal range  but he is tachycardic and slightly tachypneic.   The symptoms of prolonged fever and malaise coupled with findings of a new audible heart murmur  petechiae  and splinter hemorrhages suggest the possibility of native-valve infective endocarditis. His recreational intravenous drug use further increases the risk of infective endocarditis. This warrants further diagnostic testing including blood cultures and echocardiography.

A 60-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use presents with a one-week history of fever  malaise  and unexplained weight loss. Patient also reports experiencing nocturnal sweats  slight shortness of breath  and a new heart murmur was noticed on auscultation. This patient's medical profile and presenting symptoms raise great concern for the possibility of native-valve infective endocarditis. His long history of intravenous drug use creates an inherent risk for this type of infection.

A 60-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use presents with a three-week history of fever  malaise  weight loss  night sweats  and a new onset of heart murmur. The patient also observed small reddish spots on the skin (Petechiae)  and an examination revealed Osler's nodes (painful nodules) on his fingers and toes  and Janeway's lesions (non-tender hemorrhagic lesions) on the palms and soles. His past medical records reveal no previous cardiac abnormalities or any implanted cardiac devices. The patient lives alone  has low-income status  and is a smoker but has no known allergies to drugs. The patient admits to not being currently engaged in substance abuse treatment. His family history is non-contributory to cardiovascular diseases. His symptoms suggest a severe systemic infection with involvement of the heart valves  hinting at a possible diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 50-year-old Caucasian male  with a history of intravenous (IV) drug use  presents with a 3-week history of fever  night sweats  and unexplained weight loss. He also reports a new onset of lower back pain. The patient is homeless and admits to recent noncompliance with his weekly methadone program. Physical exam reveals fever  a new heart murmur suggestive of mitral regurgitation  and scattered petechiae. Suspicion is high for native-valve infective endocarditis secondary to persistent IV drug use. Further investigation  including blood cultures  echocardiography  and possibly spinal imaging  is required to confirm diagnosis and assess the extent of the disease.

A 50-year-old African American male with a history of intravenous drug use and undiagnosed heart murmur presents with a 3-week history of intermittent fever up to 38.5°C  night sweats  fatigue  reduced appetite  and unplanned 10 pound weight loss. He also reports a new progressive shortness of breath  and a persisting relatively new-onset back pain over the same period. These symptoms are associated with generalized weakness and malaise. Examination reveals subconjunctival hemorrhages  embolic skin lesions on his hands and feet  and a grade III/VI systolic ejection murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. His blood cultures drawn at the clinic are positive for Staphylococcus aureus. These findings are suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis  a condition common amongst intravenous drug users due to recurrent bacteremia. The patient's race as African American is important as research has shown a higher incidence of infective endocarditis among African Americans. His right-sided heart murmurs are indicative of tricuspid valve involvement  common in intravenous drug users with endocarditis.

A 65-year-old male with a history of intravenous drug use (IVDU) presents with a three-week duration of fever  night sweats  and fatigue. He also reports a recent unintended weight loss  malaise and intermittent chest pain. Physical examination reveals Janeway lesions on his palms and soles  and Osler nodes on his fingers  evidence of blood culture positive infective endocarditis. Auscultation of the heart reveals a new murmur consistent with valvular insufficiency. He has no prior history of heart disease  surgical procedures  or prior use of prosthetic valves. The patient's social history is significant for regular intravenous drug use  currently injecting heroin. He has limited access to healthcare and doesn't engage in regular medical care.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male  with a history of moderate to heavy sustained alcohol abuse  presents with a three-week history of high-grade fevers  increasing fatigue  and rapid weight loss. The patient also reports experiencing consistent night sweats  general malaise  and shortness of breath on exertion. He has no known drug allergies  is not on any medications  and denies illicit drug use.  In physical examination  he is found to be febrile with a temperature of 38.5 degrees Celsius and tachycardic with a heart rate of 105 beats per minute. Cardiac auscultation reveals a new-onset diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. Splinter hemorrhages are noticed under the nails of both hands. Good oral hygiene is noted  eliminating oral sources of the bacteremia.  Given the clinical findings suggesting possible cardiac abnormalities  the patient's history of long-term alcohol abuse which potentially predisposes him to the risk of bacterial endocarditis  especially Streptococcus and Staphylococcus species  there is a high index of suspicion for native-valve infective endocarditis. This is further supported by the symptoms of fever  fatigue  weight loss  and night sweats  which might indicate a chronic systemic infection. The new diastolic murmur may imply structural damage to the heart valve  a common complication of infective endocarditis. The presence of splinter hemorrhages under the nail beds  which are common in endocarditis  also increases the suspicion for this condition.

A 64-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use  chronic hepatitis C  and untreated dental infections presents to the emergency department with 2 weeks of intermittent fever  night sweats  malaise  weight loss  and new-onset lower back pain. He states he has also noticed a few red spots on his legs and feet  which have worsened in the past several days. He denies any recent use of intravenous drugs but admits to poor dental hygiene. On physical examination  he exhibits multiple Janeway lesions on his lower extremities  Osler nodes on the fingers  and a new murmur on the cardiac exam suggestive of possible native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 59-year-old White male without any known cardiovascular disease and a long history of IV drug abuse presents to the clinic with a 4-week history of fever coupled with new onset cardiac murmur and weight loss. The patient shares that the fevers are often higher than 38°C and are associated with night sweats. Additionally  there is a 3kg weight loss in the last month. On exam  there are signs of peripheral emboli  which include petechiae on the extremities and Osler nodes on his fingers. He denies any family history of congenital heart disease or prior cardiac surgeries. His drug abuse history has been punctuated by a lack of consistent healthcare follow-up  with his last known healthcare encounter being a hospital admission for sepsis a year ago. The patient admits he has not been receiving regular checkups for any HIV-related problems. He states he has never been told he has Hepatitis C  but it has been many years since he was last screened. Current medication use includes methadone as a part of a drug rehabilitation program. No known drug allergies. For this patient  the concern is for native valve endocarditis secondary to long-term intravenous drug use.

A 56-year-old African American male  with a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and IV drug abuse  presents to the emergency department complaining of one-month duration of fever  weight loss  and night sweats. He also reports having a worsening shortness of breath  particularly noticed during walks. Physical examination discloses an unsteady gait  pallor  and splinter hemorrhages in the nail beds. Closer inspection reveals a new-onset murmur at the apex suggestive of mitral regurgitation.

A 58-year-old Caucasian male with a history of IV drug use and Hepatitis C  presents with a three-week history of intermittent fever  periodic night sweats  appetite loss  fatigue  and unintentional 7 kg weight loss. The patient also reports experiencing a new heart murmur and multiple septic emboli along with some Osler's nodes on his fingers and toes. The patient admits to recent drug relapse with needle sharing. His recent convictions around homelessness may increase his risk. The patient's vitals are stable  though a fever of 101.5 F is noted. Blood work indicates slightly elevated WBC count. In this case  given the history of IV drug use  native valve infective endocarditis is highly suspected.

A 63-year-old man with past medical history of intravenous drug usage and Hepatitis C  presents with a three-week history of fatigue  malaise  weight loss  and intermittent fever. The patient reports a recent dental procedure without prophylactic antibiotics. His vitals show mild tachycardia  but are otherwise stable. Physical examination reveals petechiae across his chest and extremities  a new musical murmur on cardiac auscultation and multiple painful red nodules on the pads of his fingers and toes. Based on history and clinical features  the patient is suspected to have native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use and chronic hepatitis C presents with a three week history of intermittent fevers  night sweats  and unintentional weight loss. He also reports exertional dyspnea and chest discomfort that improves with rest. He notes a new-onset skin rash and painful red nodules on his fingers and toes. He complains of lower back pain and has identified blood in his urine. Physical examination reveals a new murmur  suggestive of valve disease  lower back tenderness  petechiae  and Janeway lesions on the palms and soles. Blood cultures and an echocardiogram are pending. His last dental procedure was a year ago and he does not have regular dental care.

A 60-year-old African American man  with a history of intravenous drug use and previously diagnosed with congestive heart failure  presents with a 3-week history of fatigue  shortness of breath  unexplained weight loss  night sweats  and fever. He also notes a new heart murmur  petechiae  and subconjunctival hemorrhages. On initial assessment  he is found to have blood cultures positive for Staphylococcus aureus and echocardiogram shows vegetation on the mitral valve  consistent with native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 58-year-old Caucasian male  smoker  with a history of IV drug use and uncontrolled diabetes presents with a one-week history of fatigue  night sweats  weight loss  and intermittent fevers. He has not seen a healthcare professional in a significant amount of time. Physical examination revealed poor dental hygiene  a low-grade fever  and a new systolic murmur. His extremities showed multiple needle track marks  without signs of acute infection. No Osler's nodes or Janeway lesions were noted.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of poorly-controlled diabetes mellitus and history of intravenous drug use presents with a two week history of low-grade fevers  night sweats  malaise  and a new heart murmur. The patient is a widower and works as a janitor. He reports a 10-pound unintentional weight loss over the past month. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  cough  or any changes in his bowel habits. He uses alcohol and tobacco frequently. He admits to the infrequent use of intravenous heroin until about a year ago  but he denies any recent substance use. His physical examination reveals a diastolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border  weight loss  and pale conjunctiva. Mother passed away from heart disease. Previous dental procedures but no recent dental work. His echocardiogram reveals vegetations in the aortic valve. Blood cultures isolate Staphylococcus aureus.

A 56-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use and poor dental hygiene presents to the emergency department with a two-week history of intermittent fevers  night sweats  fatigue and a new  heart murmur. His temperature is 38.6 C and he appears acutely ill. He mentions experiencing a weight loss of 10 pounds within the last month but states this was unintentional. He denies any recent dental procedures. On physical examination  there's evidence of cutaneous manifestations relevant to endocarditis  such as Janeway lesions on his palms and soles  and Osler's nodes on his fingertips. On cardiovascular examination  a new pansystolic murmur is noted at the mitral area along with signs of congestive heart failure including bilateral basal lung crackles and lower limb edema. Blood cultures have been drawn.

Problem Representation:  Patient Information: - Male patient - Age: 65 years old - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired - Living situation: Lives alone - Social habits: Non-smoker  occasional alcohol use - Geographic location: Urban area  Past Medical History:  - History of mitral valve prolapse - Recent dental surgery two months ago - History of periodontal disease - No known drug allergies - Previous hospitalization for pneumonia five years ago - Familial history of heart disease - High blood pressure controlled with medication - Underwent angioplasty three years ago  Presenting Symptoms: - Persistent fever for the past 10 days - Shortness of breath - Night sweats - Fatigue - Weight loss - Small  painful red spots on palms and soles - New onset of heart murmur   Provisional Diagnosis:  Based on the presenting symptoms  past medical history  and demographic characteristics  the most likely diagnosis is native-valve infective endocarditis.  Justification: Elderly patients with a history of valvular heart disease and recent invasive dental procedures  symptoms of persistent fever  new onset of murmur and signs of systemic embolization are at a higher risk of developing infective endocarditis. This diagnosis aligns with the recommendations in the literature and the demographics described in the epidemiological studies on infective endocarditis  which show a higher prevalence amongst elderly males with a history of heart disease.    Risk Factors: - Presence of mitral valve prolapse - Recent dental surgery - Age  - Male gender - History of invasive heart procedures - High blood pressure  Plan:  This patient needs immediate hospital admission for further diagnostic investigations such as blood cultures and echocardiogram. If confirmed  urgent empirical antibiotic treatment should be started until the causative organism is identified. Cardiothoracic surgery consultation should be arranged for potential valve replacement if required. Additional supportive care measures and modification of risk factors are equally essential in his management.

Patient Profile:   Name: XYZ Age: 65 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Accountant Location: Urban Area  Medical History:  1. History of intravenous drug use (IDU) 15 years ago 2. Previously diagnosed and treated for Hepatitis C  3. Untreated dental caries for the last 2 years 4. Mild to moderate hearing loss 5. Tobacco use disorder: Currently smokes one pack a day for the last 30 years  6. Moderate Alcohol consumption: drinks socially once a week   Problem Description:   Patient XYZ  a 65-year-old male presents with a 6-week history of intermittent fever with night sweats and has lost about 10 pounds over the past 6 weeks despite no changes in his diet and physical activities. He also has new onset heart murmur and generalized weakness. He has a known history of intravenous drug use (IDU)  Hepatitis C  untreated dental caries  and tobacco use disorder. Given his history of IDU  untreated dental caries  and recent weight loss couple with the presence of fever and heart murmur  there is a high index of suspicion for native-valve infective endocarditis.  Initiate appropriate blood work for cultures  specifically with a focus on any potential causative organisms for infective endocarditis. It is crucial to initiate early antibiotic therapy and provide symptomatic treatment for the patient. Comprehensive cardiac assessment is also needed to evaluate any cardiac damage due to possible ongoing infective endocarditis. Assessment of the degree of hearing loss and providing assistance for the same would also be required given the patient's ongoing complaints. A multidisciplinary approach involving internal medicine  infectious diseases  and cardiology teams is warranted for optimal patient outcomes.

Diabetes mellitus: The patient has been living with type 2 diabetes for the last 10 years. He requires oral hypoglycemic agents to manage his blood sugar levels. 2. Alcohol: Minimal alcohol consumption  roughly one glass of red wine a week. 7. Exercise: Engages in light physical activity  walks for about 30 minutes every day. 8. This patient's presentation is consistent with infective endocarditis  potentially caused by an infection that could have been introduced during his last dental procedure. Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 60-year-old Caucasian male with no known history of intravenous drug use. The patient has a history of moderate aortic stenosis diagnosed five years ago which has been managed conservatively. His past medical history also includes diabetes mellitus and hypertension  which are well controlled with medication. He is a retired construction worker  currently lives alone  and is a non-smoker with moderate alcohol consumption.  Chief Complaint: The patient is presented with a three-week history of intermittent fever  malaise  night sweats  and a recent onset of unexplained weight loss. The fever has been moderate to high and is not associated with any chill or rigors. He reports a decrease in appetite and likes to lay down most of the time. Lately  he has also noted a new onset of shortness of breath when doing some light physical activity.  Context: Endocarditis generally affects individuals between the ages of 30-60 years. The patient's age is consistent with the typical demographic of patients diagnosed with infective endocarditis. As reported in literature  men have a two-fold increased risk compared to women. The patient's previous medical history of aortic stenosis  diabetes  hypertension  and his moderate alcohol consumption habit are additional risk factors that might have predisposed him to acquiring infective endocarditis. The patient's profession – construction worker – does not have a direct role in the etiology of the disease but contributes to a potential physical stress load.  Past Medical History: This is crucial for identifying potential predisposing cardiac conditions. Our patient has a history of moderate aortic stenosis which is a known predisposing cardiac condition for native-valve infective endocarditis. Furthermore  poorly controlled diabetes mellitus is linked with an increased risk of several infections  including endocarditis. Well controlled hypertension does not increase the risk directly  but it is often associated with other cardiovascular risk factors.    Problem Representation: 60-year-old Caucasian male with a history of aortic stenosis  diabetes  and hypertension presents with a 3-week history of fever  malaise  night sweats  weight loss  and shortness of breath. Given his previous cardiac condition  these symptoms are suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis.

Problem Representation:  Demographic Representation:  Patient Profile: A 60-year-old Caucasian male patient presents himself to the emergency department.  Ethnographic Information: The patient is native English speaking  heterosexual  affiliated to Christian religion. He has a Bachelor's degree and works as a mid-level manager in a corporate firm. He lives in a suburban neighborhood with his wife and has two adult children who live separately. He is a non-smoker and reports moderate alcohol consumption.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a past medical history of IV drug use during his early years  which has ceased for the last 25 years. He has been diagnosed and treated for hypertension over the past 10 years. He also reports occasional toothaches in the past few months  for which he has not sought any professional treatment. His family history includes a father with a history of early onset coronary artery disease and a mother who died in her seventies due to a stroke. He is currently taking antihypertensive medication and has no known allergies.  Current Presentation:  The patient presents to the clinic with complaints of persistent fever  chills  unexplained weight loss  and malaise over the past two weeks. He also mentions experiencing night sweats  fatigue  and aching muscles and joints. Recently  he has identified noticeable rashes or spots on his palms or soles. The primary concern that led to his visit is a new onset of heart murmur that he correlated with his pulse.  Relevant Findings:  On evaluation  the physician identifies irregularities in heart rhythm and the presence of a heart murmur. Preliminary lab reports indicate elevated ESR and C-reactive protein levels while the chest X-ray shows signs of pulmonary infiltration with possible signs of mild congestion. Physical examination also reveals splinter hemorrhages under the fingernails  Osler's nodes (painful nodules on fingers or toes)  and Janeway lesions (small  painless  red or purple spots on the palms or soles).   The clinical and lab findings suggest a probable diagnosis of Native Valve Infective Endocarditis possibly due to the patient's previous vulnerability with IV drug usage and neglect of consistent dental health. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) and perhaps a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) will be considered for confirmation  along with blood cultures to identify the offending microorganism. A multidisciplinary team consisting of a cardiologist  infectious disease expert  and a dentist will likely be involved in determining the best plan for treatment and management.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Doe Age: 61 years old Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired teacher Marital Status: Married Place of Residence: Urban area Insurance: Medicare   History:  Chief Complaint:  Mr. John Doe presents with a 2-week history of persistent fever  fatigue and unintended weight loss. He also complains of on and off discomfort in the left side of his chest and shortness of breath. He expressed experiencing night sweats and a decrease in appetite.  Medical History: 1. Diagnosis of Rheumatic Fever at age 12  which was well treated but affected his heart valves. 2. Consistently treated for Hypertension for the past 8 years. 3. History of smoking and moderate alcohol use  with the last cigarette smoked 6 years ago. 4. No known allergies.  Medication: Beside his hypertension medication (Lisinopril 20mg daily)  he does not take any other regular medication. Occasionally  he takes over the counter pain medication for arthritis.  Family History: His mother had Heart Disease and his father had Type 2 Diabetes. His father passed away from complications related to Diabetes at 65 years.  Social History: He lives with his wife. He is a retired teacher. He is a former smoker. He drinks alcohol socially  roughly 4 drinks per week. He has no known drug use.  Review of Systems: Positive for fever and chills  fatigue  unintended weight loss  decreased food consumption  chest discomfort  and shortness of breath. Negative for rash  cough  hemoptysis  nausea and vomiting  abdominal pain  changes in bowel habit.  Physical Examination: Vitals: T 38.5°C  BP 135/80 mmHg  HR 98 bpm  regular. RR 16 bpm  SpO2 98% room air. Cardiovascular: Irregular heart beat with a systolic murmur noted. Respiratory: Normal sounds heard bilaterally. Rest of the exam is within normal limits.  Problem Representation: A 61-year-old male  with significant past medical history including Rheumatic Fever and hypertension  presents with 2 weeks of persistent fever  fatigue  weight loss  chest discomfort  and difficulty in breathing. These symptoms  in combination with heart murmur and a previous history that includes Rheumatic Fever  are strongly suggestive of possible infective endocarditis. Further diagnostic investigations are required for confirmation.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 48-year-old white male. He lives in an urban/town setting and works as a blue-collar worker.  Presenting Problem: The patient presents with a two-week history of a high-grade fever associated with chills  fatigue  and easy tiredness. He also reports body aches  night sweats  and a loss of appetite leading to weight loss.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of Intravenous Drug Use (IVDU) for 15 years  last episode 3 days ago. He admits to sharing injecting equipment. There is also a background history of moderate Alcohol Use Disorder  Smoking (10 pack-years)  and Hepatitis C (currently in treatment).  Family History: His mother and father both have hypertension and his father had a Myocardial Infarction at the age of 63.  Social History: He lives alone  has been divorced for 5 years  and has two children who live with their mother. He works as a mechanic full time  but has taken a sick leave due to his current illness. He does not exercise regularly and his diet is mainly fast food.  Relevant Findings on Examination: On physical examination  the patient appears chronically ill and underweight. Fever of 101°F  mild tachycardia (110 bpm)  and blood pressure is normal. Cardiac examination reveals a diastolic murmur at the left sternal edge. There is also evidence of needle track marks in antecubital fossa.  Preliminary Diagnosis: Based on the patient's history  physical exam findings and risk factors present  a preliminary diagnosis of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis secondary to IVDU is suspected.  Further Evaluation: Blood cultures should be done before initiating antibiotics. Transthoracic echocardiogram (or if necessary  a transesophageal echocardiogram) should be performed to identify endocardial involvement. Other diagnostic procedures include a complete blood count  ESR  CRP  and tests for kidney and liver function. Considering the patient's IVDU history and accompanying Hepatitis C diagnosis  liver function tests  Hep C viral load  and monitoring for other bloodborne infections would be necessary. For his cardiac risks  cholesterol and lipid profile would be worthwhile. Review his Hep C management progress and his alcohol and IVDU to address possible rehabilitation or interventions.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:  A 58-year-old male patient  identified as Caucasian based on representative demographics  enters the clinic reporting symptoms relating to fevers  fatigue  night sweats  and unexplained weight loss for the past several weeks. He has a history of intravenous drug use  currently ceased but was an active user for over 10 years. He also has a reported history of smoking and excessive alcohol use but has been sober for the last 6 years. Patient's family history includes hypertension in both parents. He also reports a diagnosis of Hepatitis C as a result of prolonged intravenous drug use  for which he received treatment about 3 years ago.   Medical History:  1. Intravenous Drug Use: He was an active user for about 10 years but has been clean for the past 6 years.     2. Hepatitis C: Diagnosed and treated 3 years ago  since then liver function tests have been within normal limits.  3. Smoking: A history of heavy smoking but has quit 6 years ago.  4. Alcohol Abuse: History of alcohol abuse but maintained sobriety for the past 6 years.  5. Hypertension: Genetic predisposition due to both parents suffering from the disease.  Relevant Examination Findings:  1. Clinical signs consistent with congestive heart failure including dyspnea  orthopnea and nocturnal dyspnea.  2. Positive blood cultures indicating an infection.  3. Presence of irregular heart rhythm on cardiac auscultation.  4. Presence of anemia and elevated white blood cell count as shown in laboratory test results.  5. Echocardiographic evidence of valvular vegetation.  Final Problem Representation:  The patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use  Hepatitis C  smoking  and alcohol abuse  presenting with symptoms indicative of native-valve infective endocarditis such as fevers  fatigue  night sweats  weight loss  and signs of congestive heart failure. As evidenced by positive blood cultures  irregular heart rhythm  and valvular vegetation on echocardiographic findings  infective endocarditis can be primarily suspected. The associated risks for this condition include his past intravenous drug use and existing liver condition.

Patient Profile: - Sex: Male - Age: 70 years old - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired teacher  Presenting Symptoms: - Prolonged fever with night sweats - Shortness of breath - Fatigue - Recent weight loss - Dark urine  - Persistent cough  Past Medical History: - Diagnosed with Rheumatoid arthritis 10 years ago - History of dental procedures without prophylactic antibiotic treatment - No history of intravenous drug use - No history of valvular heart disease or heart surgery - Diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus five years ago - Family history of heart disease  Social History: - Lives alone - Doesn’t smoke  occasional alcohol use  - No history of recreational drug use - Has a pet dog  Narrative Description:  Mr. B  a 70-year-old Caucasian retired teacher presents with prolonged fever  night sweats  shortness of breath  fatigue  recent weight loss  dark urine  and persistent cough. His past medical history reveals a diagnosis of Rheumatoid arthritis 10 years ago. He has had dental procedures performed without prophylactic antibiotics. Mr. B is a non-smoker but drinks alcohol occasionally. He has a pet dog which he lives with. He has been diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus five years ago and has a family history of heart disease. His lifestyle includes no history of recreational drug use or intravenous drug use. Mr. B has never had heart surgery or been diagnosed with valvular heart disease.   This type of profile captures a patient demographic and likely medical history observed in typical cases of native-valve infective endocarditis  an infection of the endocardial surface of the heart  affecting individuals typically with pre-existing cardiac conditions  high-risk behaviors  or immunocompromised states. Rheumatoid arthritis  diabetes  and a history of non-prophylactic dental procedures are all risk factors predisposing Mr. B to this condition.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: Mr. Smith is a 45-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use and current smoker. He is unemployed  has low socio-economic status  and is living in poor sanitary conditions.  Presenting Complaint: He has been feeling unwell for about three weeks  experiencing symptoms such as fatigue  malaise  weakness  fever  chills  and excessive sweating  especially during nights. In the last few days  he has noticed some weight loss  loss of appetite  and occasional chest pain.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith's medical history includes several episodes of IV drug-induced septicemia  Hepatitis C  and a recent hospital admission for pneumonia. He has no known allergies. His family history reveals that his father had heart disease and his mother had type 2 diabetes. His alcohol and drug use history confirms ongoing intravenous drug use.   Conclusion: Given the patient's social  behavioral  and medical history  including substance abuse and recent infection  there may be a higher suspicion for infective endocarditis.   Background Literature Research: Infective endocarditis (IE) often affects individuals between the age of 30 and 60 and is more common in males. It shows a higher association with people living in poor conditions  having lower socio-economic status  and those with a history of substance abuse  especially intravenous drug use. A history of valvular heart disease or congenital heart diseases  presents a higher risk of getting IE  but our patient only has a family history of heart disease  so this doesn't necessarily increase the likelihood in this case. Connections have been found between IE and bacterial infections like septicemia and pneumonia  and viral infection such as Hepatitis C  all of which our patient has had in the past.  This profile accurately represents demographics seen in literature and clinical practice. Ongoing monitoring and further investigations would be warranted to confirm diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis and to manage the patient's overall health condition effectively.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 60 years old Gender: Sex- Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Office Executive Marital Status: Married Geographic Location: Urban area  United States  Medical Presentation: Chief Complaints: The patient complains of fatigue  shortness of breath  night sweats  chills  and unexplained weight loss over the past few weeks. He was diagnosed with moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) five years ago and has been under treatment. He also has a history of bicuspid aortic valve diagnosed during a routine check-up two years ago and was kept under surveillance.  Family History: His mother died of a myocardial infarction at 75  and his father had a stroke at 70 but is still alive.  Social History: He reports a 2-pack-a-day smoking history for 40 years and admits to drinking alcohol socially. Retired for five years  he lives with his wife and has two adult children.  Physical Examination: On examination  he appears fatigued  has slight pallor  and his temp is 38.2 C. His pulse is irregular  blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg  and respiratory rate is 20 bpm. Cardiac auscultation reveals a diastolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border.  Problem Representation: A 60-year-old heavy smoking and alcohol using Caucasian male with a history of type 2 diabetes  moderate COPD  and a known bicuspid aortic valve presents with symptoms suggestive of potential infective endocarditis  including unexplained weight loss  fatigue  chills  night sweats  and an intermittent fever.

Problem Representation:  Demographic Information: Patient is a 45-year-old white male with no known drug allergies living in an urban setting in the United States.  Medical History: Patient has a history of intravenous drug use (IVDU) which ended approximately 10 years prior and a subsequent diagnosis of Hepatitis C  which was treated and has been undetectable for several years. The patient drank regularly until about 8 years ago and has been sober since. He has had no previous surgeries and no known family history of cardiovascular disease. The patient is a smoker  averaging about 1.5 packs per day for the past 20 years.  Presenting Complaint: The patient comes in complaining of 4 weeks of progressive fatigue  night sweats  weight loss  shortness of breath  and a low-grade fever.  Physical Examination: Upon physical examination  the patient is found to have splinter hemorrhages in the nails  Osler's nodes (painful nodules on pad of fingers)  Janeway lesions (painless lesions on palm or sole)  and Roth spots in the retina. A heart murmur is heard upon auscultation.  Relevant Tests: Lab tests reveal a significant rise in erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP). A blood culture also shows evidence of bacteria common to infective endocarditis such as Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus viridans. An echocardiogram is conducted and vegetations are found on the heart valves  consistent with native-valve infective endocarditis.  Risk factors identified for this problem: The patient has several risk factors for developing native-valve infective endocarditis. These include a history of IVDU  active smoking  a previous stint with Hepatitis C  and the fact that the patient is male and middled aged. The presence of an untreated dental infection could be a possible source of bacteria causing bacteremia leading to endocarditis. Other potential sources could include the gastrointestinal or genitourinary tract. Therefore a detailed examination and/or testing to rule out these potential sources might be required.

Problem Representation:  Demographics:  Patient is a 65-year-old white male. He is retired  married  living with his wife in an urban environment. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially.   Past Medical History:  1. Medical history reveals a congenital heart defect  which was surgically corrected at an early age.  2. Patient has been diagnosed with early-stage heart failure for the past 2 years  currently managed with beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors.  3. He had a febrile episode about three months ago  which was diagnosed as pneumonia  for which he was treated with antibiotics. 4. Currently  he is not using an intravenous catheter  nor has a history of long-term catheterization. 5. Dental history indicates poor oral hygiene with recent dental extraction four weeks ago. 6. No history of illicit drug use or risky sexual behavior.  7. Patient also has a history of type 2 diabetes which is being managed through diet  regular exercise  and hypoglycemic agents. 8. There is no family history of endocarditis. 9. There are no signs of recent trauma or other indication of an entry point for bacterial infection.  Presenting Symptoms:  Patient presents with a four-week history of fever  night sweats  and weight loss. He complains of experiencing fatigue and malaise  and occasional shortness of breath. He does not present with typical skin manifestations (Janeway lesions  Osler nodes  etc.) or with signs of stroke or other neurological symptoms.   Based on the above information  there is a possibility that this patient may be suffering from native-valve infective endocarditis. Further testing is required for confirmation including a physical exam  echocardiogram  and blood cultures.
