Chief Complaint:   The patient presents with a two-week history of intermittent fever  night sweats  fatigue  and unintentional weight loss. The patient also reported a new-onset  mild heart murmur.  History of Present Illness:  The patient experienced the aforementioned symptoms two weeks ago  which have grown progressively worse. Apparently  the patient has been having intermittent fever with temperature reaching to 38.5°C (101.3°F)  especially in the evening. He’s experienced fatigue even with minimal activities and has also noticed significant weight loss even without deliberately trying to lose weight.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a 25-year history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus  a 10-year history of hypertension  and he was diagnosed with mild aortic stenosis three years ago. He has been taking insulin  Metformin  and Lisinopril.   Family History:  No family history of infective endocarditis. His father had coronary artery disease and his mother had type 2 diabetes.  Social History:  Lives alone since being widowed 5 years ago. He quit smoking ten years ago  rarely drinks alcohol  has no history of intravenous drug use  no recent tattoos or body piercings  and no recent unregulated procedures that could have introduced bacteria into his bloodstream.  The represented patient is a combination of characteristics generally common in people with native valve infective endocarditis; such as middle to older age  male gender  uncontrolled diabetes mellitus and previous history of valve disease. It's important to mention  this is a general probable representation and real scenarios can show different combinations of characteristics and presentation.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:  A 50-year-old Caucasian male  Demographics:  Lives in a suburban area in the US  married  finishes high school education  employed full time  non-smoker  has private health insurance.  Presenting Problem:  He has been feeling unwell for the past 2 weeks with symptoms including fatigue  chills  mild fever  and a new heart murmur arising from cardiac auscultation. He reports unintentional weight loss and submitted to an emergency department because of increasing shortness of breath on exertion over the last quartet of 1 week.  Past Medical History:  He has a known history of type 2 diabetes over the last 5 years  controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents  and does not require insulin. He was also treated for periodontal disease (severe gum infection) 3 months ago  but does not have a history or clinical evidence of drug abuse  immune-compromising conditions  or invasive medical interventions. His family history includes father with heart disease and mother with type 2 diabetes.  Habits: The patient drinks alcohol socially  2-3 drinks per week  does not smoke or use illicit drugs. Regular light exercise includes walking and golf.  Examination:  Physical examination reveals a new cardiac murmur on the left second intercostal space  along with mild splenomegaly. Slight pallor is present  but there are no osler nodes  Janeway lesions  or splinter hemorrhages seen in the nails. His vital signs include blood pressure 125/80 mmHg  pulse 90 bpm  respiratory rate 18 per minute  temperature 37.6 degrees Celsius (99.6 degrees Fahrenheit)  and oxygen saturation 97% on room air.  Suspected Problem: Based on the observed symptomology  there is a suspicion of Native Valve Infective Endocarditis. Subsequent investigations including blood culture and echocardiography are designed to confirm the diagnosis and specify the causal microorganism.

Patient Profile: - Name: John Doe - Age: 53 - Sex: Male - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Construction worker  Problem: John presents with several symptoms indicative of native-valve infective endocarditis which include fever  chills  fatigue  aching joints and muscles  night sweats  shortness of breath  palpitations  weight loss  and small spots on his skin and under his fingernails. A new or changed heart murmur is also noted during his physical examination. The intensity and duration of his symptoms have been gradually increasing  leading him to seek medical attention.  Relevant Past Medical History: John had a history of intravenous drug use in his early adulthood. He also has a medical history of untreated dental cavities and has always been in poor oral health. Further  he has a history of rheumatic fever in his teens which predisposes him to bacterial endocarditis. Moreover  he was diagnosed with chronic heart valve disease a few years ago. John also has diabetes which could make his infection even more complex due to potential complications.  Smoking and Alcohol: John is a heavy smoker and regularly consumes alcohol in substantial amounts.  Family History: Positive family history of heart diseases  with his father having died from a heart attack.  Medications: John is on insulin therapy for his diabetes. He also takes aspirin regularly to manage his chronic heart disease.  Allergies: No known allergies.  Review of Systems: John has a history of fatigue  weight loss  and loss of appetite. He also mentions episodes of coughing and decreasing exercise tolerance. On cardiac review  a murmur was noted. He also complained of increasing dyspnea.  Demographic breakdown: According to literature  infective endocarditis is more commonly seen amongst males. It is also seen more among individuals with a history of intravenous drug use and/or poor dental hygiene. The median age at diagnosis is around 50 to 60 years old. It is also associated with certain occupations  such as construction work  that have a heightened risk of injury and thereby providing a portal of entry for bacteria.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 66-year-old white Caucasian male presents with native-valve infective endocarditis. Studies show that the incidence of infective endocarditis is higher in males and in people over 60 years old  which is consistent with our patient profile.  Presenting symptoms: The patient reports a history of fatigue  low-grade fever  loss of appetite  unintentional weight loss  and night sweats for the past several weeks. He also describes a new heart murmur that wasn't there during the last medical check.   Past medical history: He has a significant past history of intravenous drug use in his youth but has been clean for over twenty years. He also indicates the existence of some dental procedures in the last six months with no antibiotic prophylaxis. His baseline health status includes a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension for the past decade. His medications include metformin and a daily aspirin. Stopped smoking ten years ago but has a 30-pack year smoking history.  Epidemiological history:  Since retirement  he has limited his social activities and had no recent travel history or exposure to animals that could potentially carry zoonoses.  Family history:  Non-contributory  no known genetic disorders or immediate family members with similar symptoms.  Relevant laboratory and imaging findings: Moderate anemia and elevated inflammatory markers were noted during initial laboratory investigations. Blood cultures are pending  and an initial transthoracic echocardiogram shows vegetation in the mitral valve suggestive of endocarditis.   Based on preliminary evaluations  further investigations are warranted to confirm the diagnosis and determine the appropriate therapeutic strategy. The patient's previous intravenous drug use and recent dental procedures represent potential sources of infection leading to his current presentation. His chronic conditions  including type 2 diabetes and hypertension  may also influence his treatment plan and potential outcomes.

Problem Representation:  Patient Description: A 60-year-old Caucasian male patient presents with symptoms consistent with infective endocarditis.  Presenting Complaints: The patient has been experiencing persistent fever for the past two weeks  with intermittent chills and night sweats. He also reports fatigue  unexplained weight loss  and poor appetite.   Medical History: The patient was previously diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  which are both being currently managed with oral medication. He is a non-smoker with a history of occasional alcohol consumption. No history of recent dental procedures or use of intravenous drugs but underwent knee replacement surgery 6 months ago.   Examination: On physical examination  the patient has a new heart murmur. He has several small  painless  erythematous lesions on his palms and soles (Janeway lesions).   Investigations: Lab tests reveal leukocytosis and increased inflammatory markers (C-reactive protein  ESR). Blood cultures are currently being processed. An echocardiogram showed vegetations on the aortic valve suggesting infective endocarditis.  Hypothesis: The patient's clinical presentation combined with preliminary investigations suggest a likely diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis. The bacterial infection may be the result of a bloodstream infection post knee-replacement surgery.  Management: Antibiotic therapy will be initiated empirically until definitive blood culture results can guide more specific treatment. Cardiology consultation for close monitoring of cardiac function and possible surgical intervention for the infected valve  if it becomes necessary  should be considered. Patient education for infection prevention strategies will also be part of the management plan.  Risk Factors: The patient's history of heart disease and diabetes may have increased his risk of developing infective endocarditis. Age and the recent surgery are also significant risk factors.   Social History: The patient lives with his wife. He is a retired banker and engages in regular physical activity like walking and swimming.   Family History:  The patient's family history includes coronary artery disease in his father and hypertension in his mother. No known family history of valvular heart diseases or infective endocarditis.

Patient Profile:   Name: John Doe Age: 61 years old Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian  Chief Complaint:   Fatigue  fever  weight loss  and night sweats for the past 4 weeks. Also complaints of shortness of breath.  Medical History:  1. Past history of intravenous drug use more than 15 years ago. 2. Prior diagnosis of mitral valve prolapse. 3. History of frequent dental procedures without prophylactic antibiotics.  Social History:  1. Smoker  1 pack a day for 30 years. 2. Alcohol use – previously used heavily  now occasional 3. Works as an independent builder and lives with his wife.  Family History:  1. Father died at the age of 80 due to ischemic heart disease. 2. Mother died from breast cancer at the age of 76. 3. One brother  alive  with no significant cardiovascular or other diseases.  Physical Examination:   On examination  presents with pallor  mild peripheral edema  and Petechial rashes noted on the lower limbs. He has a regurgitant murmur best heard in the mitral area on auscultation. His blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg  pulse rate is 100/min  and respiratory rate is 22/min.  Relevant Investigations:  1. Blood cultures are positive. 2. Echocardiogram shows vegetation in the mitral valve. 3. Full blood count shows raised inflammatory markers  anemia. 4. Chest X-ray shows no signs of congestive heart failure.  Problem representation:  A 61-year-old male smoker with a past of mitral valve prolapse and intravenous drug use presents with a four-week history of fever  night sweats  fatigue  shortness of breath  and weight loss  suggestive of systemic infection or inflammation. Physical examination and investigation findings including the presence of a mitral regurgitant murmur  positive blood cultures  raised inflammatory markers  vegetation in the mitral valve suggest a probable diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis. Early intervention is crucial given the worsening symptoms and the potentially fatal nature of the illness. His past history of intravenous drug use places him at risk  and repeated exposure to dental procedures without antibiotic prophylaxis could have been a precipitating factor.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:  54-year-old caucasian male born and living in a suburban area in the United States  employed as a construction worker. He is a smoker and is fond of moderate alcohol consumption.   Presenting Complaint: The patient presents with a high-grade fever of 103 degrees Fahrenheit which he has had for the past two weeks. He has been experiencing dyspnea  night sweats and unintentional weight loss. He also complains of anorexia  malaise  and a new onset of a heart murmur.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of bi-leaflet Mitral Valve Prolapse(MVP) diagnosed 5 years ago. He has been regularly under follow-up and was doing well until recently. The patient also has a history of Intravenous Drug Use (IVDU) but ceased usage around 2 years ago. His other medical history includes moderate Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) due to long-term smoking and partially treated Dental Caries. The patient is not diabetic  does not have a history of rheumatic fever or hypertension and isn't undergoing any form of immunosuppressant treatment. He does not have a family history of cardiac diseases.   Completed Investigations: On clinical examination  his vitals were stable except for tachycardia. Janeway lesions were observed on the soles of his feet  and splinter hemorrhages were found under his nails. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) showed vegetation on the mitral valve leaflets.   Hypothesis: Based on his symptoms  past medical history  and investigations  this patient is likely presenting with Native Valve Infective Endocarditis (NVIE). The fact that he has been experiencing these symptoms for over two weeks and having known MVP along with the evidence from the TTE highly indicative of this condition. His past IVDU could have exposed him to Staphylococcus Aureus  Pseudomonas Aeruginosa  or Candida  which are known causes for NVIE. His untreated dental caries could represent another potential source of bacterial pathogens that can lead to NVIE  possibly due to Streptococcus mutans.   Assessment:  This 54-year-old male patient presents with clinical signs and symptoms consistent with NVIE. His history of untreated dental caries  known MVP  and prior IV Drug Use could have been potential sources of bacteremia leading to NVIE. The TTE results also support the diagnosis.   Plan: To confirm the diagnosis  blood cultures should be obtained before initiating antibiotic therapy. After that  a tailored treatment plan will include a regimen of antibiotics and possible surgery  depending on the patient's response to antibiotics. The plan will also include educating the patient on maintaining good oral hygiene and regular follow-ups regarding his MVP. Possible future interventions could include the mitral valve repair or replacement if the disease progresses.

Patient Profile: 1. Age: 60 years old 2. Gender: Male  3. Race: Caucasian 4. Occupation: Retired teacher 5. Lifestyle: Non-smoker  occasional drinker  maintains good hygiene  no history of IV drug use.   Health Status: 1. Past Medical History: The patient has a history of rheumatic heart disease from childhood that was never adequately treated. He had a mild heart attack five years ago and has been on medication for hypertension for the past decade. He also had a dental procedure performed two weeks ago.  Presenting Symptoms: 1. The patient has been noticing fever  chills  fatigue  aching muscles and joints  night sweats  edema in his feet  legs  and abdomen. He also reports a new heart murmur  rapid weight loss  and loss of appetite.   Reason for Presentation: The patient was brought by his spouse who was particularly concerned about his persistent high fever and new heart murmur.  Possible Problem: Given the presenting symptoms and considering his past medical history  the patient appears to be suffering from native-valve infective endocarditis  an infection of the heart's inner lining (endocardium) or the heart valves caused by bacteria entering the bloodstream and settling in the heart.  Related Factors: The patient's history of rheumatic heart disease and recent dental procedures significantly increases his vulnerability to the infection. Additionally  his age and previous heart conditions also make him more susceptible to this condition.   Appropriate Physical Examination and Investigations: On suspicion of infective endocarditis  the clinician should undertake a comprehensive physical examination with particular attention to findings that may indicate infection such as a new heart murmur. Further diagnostic procedures such as blood cultures  an electrocardiogram (ECG)  and an echocardiogram should be initiated to validate the clinical suspicion.  Treatment: If confirmatory investigations reveal infective endocarditis  appropriate antibacterial therapy should be initiated and the patient may require hospitalization. In severe cases  surgery may be necessary to repair or replace the damaged heart valves.  Patient Education: Patient and his family should be educated about the disease  its treatment  follow-up care  and the importance of maintaining good dental hygiene.

Patient Profile:  Name: Alan G. Age: 50 years old Sex: Male Occupation: Construction worker  Ethnicity/Race: Caucasian Living situation: Lives with spouse in urban metropolis Socioeconomic status: Middle-class   Problem Representation:  Mr. Alan G.  a 50-year-old Caucasian male  presents with complaints consistent with infective endocarditis. His major clinical manifestations include marked fatigue  night sweats  persistent low-grade fever  and unintentional weight loss over the past 2 months. He also reports experiencing intermittent discomfort in his chest and joints  newly noticed small red spots on his palms and soles  and shortness of breath  yet denied of having a cough or hemoptysis. He has observed changes in his nails with pain and swelling in his fingertips.   Relevant Past Medical History:  Mr. Alan G. has a history of IV drug usage through his early adulthood  but reports he has abstained for the past 15 years. He also has a known history of dental procedures done without appropriate antibiotic prophylaxis. His medical history includes benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)  hypertension attended with pharmacological therapy. There is no history of any hereditary or chronic illnesses. He also reports he is a current smoker (20 cigarettes/day for the past 30 years). He is not known to have any allergies.   This case presents a typical patient with a clear connection to endocarditis risk factors. Epidemiological studies show that infective endocarditis predominantly affects men (~60-75% of cases). The mean age observed is ~50 years old. Caucasian individuals seem to be at a somewhat higher risk  particularly for native valve infective endocarditis. IV drug users especially have high-risk of native-valve infective endocarditis due to an increased proclivity to Staphylococcus aureus. Dental procedures without appropriate antibiotic prophylaxis also increase the risk of dissemination of microbes into the bloodstream leading to endocarditis. Other predisposing factors for endocarditis include age  male gender  and history of heart valve disease.   Thus  with vague systemic signs such as fatigue  low-grade fever  night sweats paralleled with some typical signs of infective endocarditis such as splinter hemorrhages  shortness of breath and chest discomfort  Mr. Alan G. fit well with the profile of a patient with native-valve infective endocarditis. Therefore  more investigations needed for the firm diagnosis and treatment.

Problem Representation:  Demographic Information: • Age: 60 years old • Gender: Male • Race/Ethnicity: White • Socioeconomic Status: Middle class • Occupation: Retired electrician  Presenting Complaint: • Persistent fever of a couple weeks duration which has not reduced despite taking over-the-counter medicines • General fatigue  weakness  and malaise • Severe night sweats causing sleep disturbances • Loss of appetite and unintentional weight loss • Shortness of breath  especially with exertion • Heart murmur  Relevant Past Medical History: • History of rheumatic fever in childhood • Mitral valve prolapse diagnosed ten years ago • Mild hypertension controlled with medication • Dental procedures performed recently  specifically tooth extraction  with no prophylactic antibiotics. • Former smoker with a 20-pack year history  quit smoking 15 years ago • Regular alcohol consumption • No history of IV drug usage  Relevant Family History: • Father had a history of coronary artery disease and mother had hypertension.  Given the symptoms and background history  the clinical scenario suggests native-valve infective endocarditis  which needs to be evaluated further with appropriate investigations. Commonly  white males of 30 to 60 years of age are affected. Existence of a valve disease (like mitral valve prolapse here) or a prior rheumatic heart disease  invasive procedures without prophylactic antibiotics administration  and being a former smoker with regular alcohol consumption can predispose to infective endocarditis. Fever  fatigue and weight loss  night sweats  shortness of breath  and a new or changed heart murmur can be signs and symptoms of infective endocarditis.

Problem Representation:  Mr. Smith is a 62-year-old white male from a middle-income socioeconomic background who presents to the hospital with symptoms suggestive of infective endocarditis. He has a history of occasional social drinking and is a non-smoker. Mr. Smith has a relevant medical history of uncontrolled type II diabetes mellitus and a recent dental procedure about two months ago. He has no other significant past medical or surgical history  and he does not have any known allergies.  The clinical features Mr. Smith is presently showing include a low-grade fever  loss of appetite  general fatigue  and a new onset of heart murmur. He also described experiencing intermittent bouts of night sweats and unexplainable weight loss over the past few weeks. In addition  he has been having difficulty sleeping due to discomfort in the left side of his chest.   Mr. Smith's current medication regimen to manage his diabetes includes Metformin and Glipizide. However  he admits he has not been adherent with his medication regimen lately due to financial constraints.  He denies any recent travel or exposure to communicable diseases. His sexual history is unremarkable and he claims he has maintained a monogamous relationship with his wife of 40 years. He does not use intravenous drugs and has no known history of sexually transmitted diseases.  The patient's family history is notable for heart disease; his father had an episode of myocardial infarction at the age of 50  and his older brother had a stroke at the age of 60.  In his social history  he worked as an accountant until his retirement five years ago. He lives with his wife and their Toy Poodle in a well-maintained suburban home.  Mr Smith's symptoms  past medical history  and recent dental procedure point towards the possibility of native-valve infective endocarditis  a diagnosis that would require urgent assessment and potentially lifesaving treatment.

Patient Problem Representation:   Patient Profile:  Age: 64 years old  Gender: Male  Race: Caucasian  Living Situation: Lives alone  Social Situation: Retired engineer  smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years and drinks alcohol occasionally.  Family History: Father had a heart attack at age 70; mother had hypertension and diabetes.  GP regular review: last seen 8 weeks ago.   Presenting Complaint:  Patient presents with the complaint of fatigue  sweating  low-grade fever ranging between 99.5°F to 100.5°F  shortness of breath  particularly with activity for the past two weeks  weight loss of about 5 kilograms over the last month. Patient also mentioned occasional chest discomfort and recently noticed dark red spots on their palms and soles.   Past Medical History:  Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) (diagnosed in the early stage about 2 years ago)  hypertension (controlled by medication for the past 10 years).    Physical Examination:  Upon physical examination  the patient is found to have pale conjunctiva  a new systolic murmur  small painless red spots on skin (Janeway lesions)  small painful nodes in the pads of the fingers (Osler's nodes)  and nontender small red or purple spots under the fingernails (splinter hemorrhages).   Investigations:  Discovered vegetation on the mitral valve with the help of an echocardiogram. Series of blood cultures found growth of Streptococcus mutans  an organism often found in native-valve infective endocarditis patients.   Clinical Impression:  64-year-old male with a past medical history significant for COPD and hypertension presents with fatigue  low-grade fever  weight loss  a new systolic murmur  and characteristic skin manifestations  consistent with native-valve infective endocarditis. Patient's smoking history  advanced age  and male gender may have contributed to his risk. Confirmatory diagnosis was made through echocardiogram findings and positive blood cultures for Streptococcus mutans.

Patient Profile: Mr. Smith is a 65-year-old Caucasian male from an urban area  with a history of intravenous drug use (IDU) approximately 30 years ago. He is an ex-smoker with a 20 pack-year smoking history and has been alcohol-free for the last 15 years. He is retired and lives alone.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a known history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) due to his past smoking history and is on regular medication for the same. He had undergone aortic valve replacement surgery 10 years ago due to aortic stenosis.  Presenting Complaints: For the past 2 weeks  Mr. Smith has been experiencing intermittent fever with temperatures of up to 101 F  fatigue  and shortness of breath  particularly on exertion. He has also had occasional night sweats and lack of appetite for the same duration.  Family History: His father had ischemic heart disease  his mother had type 2 diabetes  and his elder brother passed away at the age of 70 due to lung cancer.  Social History: Mr. Smith lives alone but interacts with a group of older adults in his community regularly. He does not have any pets. He admits that his diet has not been nutritious due to lack of appetite  but he tries to maintain hydration.  Representation of the Problem: The clinical scenario raises the possibility of native-valve infective endocarditis in Mr. Smith  considering his past history of aortic valve replacement and intravenous drug use. Symptoms of fever  fatigue  night sweats  loss of appetite  and shortness of breath on exertion supports this hypothesis. A comprehensive diagnostic work-up would be needed to confirm this.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: 1. Demographics: 60-year-old Caucasian male  2. Social History: Non-smoker  Non-alcoholic 3. Family History: No significant hereditary diseases   Presenting Complaints: The patient presents with a four weeks history of persistent unexplained fever  chills  night sweats  fatigue  and unintentional weight loss. There has been an inspection of a new heart murmur that was not previously documented.  Past Medical History: 1. Dental procedure one month back: The patient had a dental extraction  a well-known risk factor for infective endocarditis. 2. Congenital heart disease: The patient was born with bicuspid aortic valve  a condition that alters the normal flow of blood and increases the risk of infective endocarditis. 3. Diabetes Mellitus: The patient was diagnosed with type-II Diabetes Mellitus five years ago  which has been controlled with oral medications.  Physical Examination: 1. Cardiovascular examination revealed a new diastolic murmur over the aortic area of the heart. 2. Examination of the extremities revealed Osler nodes (red  painful nodules on the fingers and toes). 3. Ophthalmic examination reinforced suspicions by revealing sight-threatening complications like Roth spots (retinal hemorrhages with white centers).  Investigations: 1. Blood culture: Multiple blood culture tests performed with at least a 12-hour interval between tests. 2. Echocardiogram: Transesophageal and Transthoracic echocardiograms to visualize heart structures. 3. Complete blood count  ESR  and CRP.  This representation is consistent with demographic data from literature  indicating endocarditis predominantly affects males  and is more common in the older adult population. The patient's congenital heart disease and dental procedure are notable risk factors. Diabetes is also an independent risk factor for infective endocarditis due to altered immunological defenses.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: John  a 53-year-old Caucasian male  has come to the emergency department with complaints of unexplained weight loss  fatigue  night sweats  and intermittent fever over the past few weeks. He has a history of Intravenous drug use (up to 5 years back). He works as a construction worker and is a resident of an urban area. He has been a moderate smoker for over 30 years and a heavy drinker. His BMI is 29 and regularly consumes fast food  but his diet lacks fruits and vegetables. He has a past medical history of a mild heart attack around 2 years ago. He had been on antiplatelet therapy post the event. His family history suggests his father died of a stroke  and his mother is a living diabetic.   Problem Detail:  John is presenting with the following symptoms:  - Unexplained weight loss - Fatigue - Night sweats - Intermittent fever  Relevant Past Medical History:  - Intravenous drug use (up to 5 years back) - Past mild heart attack (2 years ago) treated with antiplatelet therapy - Moderate smoker and heavy drinker - Unhealthy diet  overweight with BMI 29 - Family history of Cardiovascular disease and diabetes  Possible Diagnosis:  Considering his symptoms and medical history  John might have native-valve infective endocarditis. Intravenous drug use history  unhealthy lifestyle  and a history of cardiovascular disease increase his risk substantially. However  comprehensive diagnostic evaluation  including blood cultures and an echocardiogram  is essential to confirm the diagnosis.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: - Gender: Male - Age: 60 years old - Ethnicity: Caucasian  Social History: - Employment: Retired factory laborer  - Habits: Non-smoker  occasionally drinks alcohol  Presenting Complaints: The patient presents with persistent fever  chills  night sweats  fatigue  and weight loss for several weeks. Recently  the patient has experienced shortness of breath and has noted swelling in his ankles.  Past Medical History: - History of having poor oral health  especially recurrent tooth infections and treatment - History of intravenous drug use during his youth  which ceased 30 years ago - History of previous hospitalization for colon surgery two years ago  Physical Examination: - Appearance: Pale and fatigued - Temperature: 38.5°C (101.3°F) - Heart Examination: Irregular heartbeat detected  a murmur heard on auscultation - Examination of extremities showed peripheral oedema  Based on current symptoms and past medical history  coupled with the physical examination findings  a comprehensive and systematic investigation should be launched  including blood cultures and echocardiography  for the possible diagnosis and management of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Recent Research and Demographics for Reference: Literature suggests that infective endocarditis predominantly affects men  with a male to female ratio of approximately 2:1 (Baddour et al.  2005). In the Western world  the age of patients with endocarditis is increasing  with a mean age in the 50s decade of life (Baddour et al.  2005). Intravenous drug use is a significant risk factor for infective endocarditis  particularly in native valves. Other risk factors include poor oral health and prior hospitalizations wherein sterile procedures may have been done (Mylonakis & Calderwood  2001). The patient's presentation and past medical history match these demographic characteristics.   References: 1. Baddour  L.M.  Wilson  W.R.  Bayer  A.S.  Fowler  V.G.  Tleyjeh  I.M.  Rybak  M.J.  Barsic  B.  Lockhart  P.B.  Gewitz  M.H.  Levison  M.E.  Bolger  A.F.  Steckelberg  J.M.  Baltimore  R.S.  Fink  A.M.  O'Gara  P.  Taubert  K.A.; American Heart Association Committee on Rheumatic Fever  Endocarditis  and Kawasaki Disease of the Council on Cardiovascular Disease in the Young  Council on Clinical Cardiology  Council on Cardiovascular Surgery  and Anesthesia  and Stroke Council  Infective endocarditis in adults: diagnosis  antimicrobial therapy  and management of complications  Circulation. 2015;132(15):1435-86. 2. Mylonakis  E.  Calderwood  S.B.  Infective endocarditis in adults  N Engl J Med. 2001;345(18):1318-30.

Problem Representation:  Patient Demographic Information:  - Age: 60 years old - Gender: Male - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired military officer - Residing Country: United States  Presenting Complaint:  The patient is presenting with a 2-week history of fevers  night sweats  fatigue  a new heart murmur  and unintentional weight loss.   Past Medical History:  - Moderate aortic stenosis diagnosed 5 years ago. - Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus managed with Metformin. - Past smoker  quit 10 years ago.  Recent History:  - Oral dental procedures 1 month ago.  Family History:  - Father passed away from a heart attack at age 70. - Mother has hypertension and is still alive.  Social History:  - Lives alone in a suburban neighborhood. - Son visits on weekends. - Used to enjoy golf but has had to stop because of recent lack of energy.  Physical Examination Findings:  - Tachycardia and a new systolic murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border. - Fever of 38.5°C. - Pale conjunctiva and oral petechiae. - Splenomegaly and small painless erythematous lesions on the pads of fingers and toes.  From the data available in the literature  several characteristics of this patient align with typical demographics of native-valve infective endocarditis. His age  gender  and history of aortic stenosis are risk factors for native-valve endocarditis. Further investigations  like blood cultures and echocardiogram  are needed to confirm the diagnosis. Moreover  his diabetes and past smoking habit may increase the risk for complications. His recent dental procedures may have allowed bacteria to enter the bloodstream  leading to endocarditis. The patient's fever  heart murmur  and skin findings could be indicative of endocarditis but can also be found in other conditions. Hence a differential diagnosis is necessary to rule out other possibilities.   References:  - Writing  A. M. (2019). Problem representation. Csu. https://csu-cvmbs.colostate.edu/Documents/communications-w-journal-article-problem-representation.pdf. - Thuny  F.  Grisoli  D.  Collart  F.  Habib  G.  & Raoult  D. (2012). Management of infective endocarditis: challenges and perspectives. The Lancet  379(9819)  965-975.

Problem Representation:  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male  as in the U.S. Caucasians have shown to have the highest rate of infective endocarditis. He is an intravenous drug user  as this group is at an increased risk. He lives in a low socioeconomic area  as epidemiologic studies have suggested that socioeconomically disadvantaged groups are at a higher risk. He has a past history of alcohol abuse disorder  adding to his risk probabilities.  Past Medical History: The patient has a complex past medical history. He has a history of diabetes  which is a risk factor for infective endocarditis. He has a history of IV drug abuse  which increases his risk of bloodborne infections  including infective endocarditis. Further  his past surgical history includes a mitral valve repair surgery 10 years ago  which increases his risk for native-valve infective endocarditis.   Considering non-cardiac surgeries  he underwent a gastric bypass procedure 15 years ago for morbid obesity. Given his high BMI and potential complications post-surgery  this could contribute to his predisposition for infections.  The patient is also documented to have chronic kidney disease secondary to longstanding  poorly controlled hypertension. This  along with his diabetes  might have brought about abnormal changes in his immune response  making him more susceptible to infections.   In addition  the patient had an episode of Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia 5 years ago  which was adequately treated at that time but could predispose him for a future infective endocarditis. He is not currently on any antibiotic prophylaxis.  Social History: The patient is a current smoker of 45 years and drinks alcohol occasionally. He is separated and lives alone  making it difficult to aim for a robust social support system in the disease management strategy. The patient's social history contributes to his overall risk profile and provides context for his health behaviors.   Representation of Current Problem: The patient is presenting with a 1-week history of fever  chills  night sweats  decreased appetite  and discomfort in his left flank. On examination  he has a new systolic murmur and petechiae on the palmar surfaces of his hands and conjunctiva. His blood cultures are positive for Streptococcus viridans  confirming a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. Considering his deteriorating renal function and systemic signs of infection  he is at high risk for complications.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male from an urban setting  presenting with symptoms of fever  malaise  and weight loss. He is a smoker and leads a sedentary lifestyle  working as a financial adviser. He also has a history of high blood pressure and high cholesterol.  Past Medical History The patient has a significant past medical history of intravenous drug use in his early twenties  which has since resulted in a previous episode of infective endocarditis approximately 20 years ago. Since then  the patient has undergone treatment for drug addiction and has remained sober for 15 years. The patient also has a history of rheumatic fever in childhood  mild obesity  and type 2 diabetes managed with medication.  Family History The patient's father passed away at 70 due to a myocardial infarction. His mother  age 85  is living with controlled hypertension. There is no history of endocarditis or any other heart diseases in the family.  Presenting Complaint The patient has been experiencing moderate to severe intermittent fever for the past 10 days  accompanied by chills  night sweats  and loss of appetite. He has also lost around 10 pounds over the past three months without any dietary changes or increased physical activity. He complains of mild shortness of breath  fatigue  and lethargy. There is no cough  chest pain  or edema.   Examination On examination  he is pale with a temperature of 38.5°C  pulse 100 per minute  blood pressure 140/90 mmHg  and respiratory rate 18 per minute. Cardiac examination reveals a new murmur.  Objective The goal of this case is the diagnosis and management of a potential case of native-valve infective endocarditis  as suggested by the combination of a history of intravenous drug use  symptoms such as fever and weight loss  and the presence of a new cardiac murmur on examination.    Possible Complications Consideration should also be given to potential complications  such as heart failure and embolic events  which could impact management and prognosis.   Other considerations The patient's past medical history (including previous infective endocarditis  drug use  and current lifestyle) and demographic factors (including age and race) have been considered in constructing this problem representation.                                                                                                 References This patient presentation is in line with data from the literature which suggests that infective endocarditis is more common in males  tends to occur in middle to older age  and is frequently associated with a history of intravenous drug use and/or pre-existing heart disease such as rheumatic heart disease.

Patient Presentation  Demographics:  John Doe  a 55-year-old Caucasian male  is a resident of an urban area. He is unemployed and has a history of homelessness. He does not smoke or drink alcohol  but has a history of intravenous drug use.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a significant past medical history which includes repetitive intravenous drug abuse over the last 15 years. There is a documented history of Hepatitis C infection from his past intravenous drug use. He has no known allergies. He previously experienced an episode of Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia 3 years ago but completed the prescribed course of antibiotics.  Present Illness:  Over the past week  he has noticed progressive fatigue  malaise  and intermittent fever with night sweats. He also describes an appetite loss with unintentional weight loss. On examination  he appears fatigued and exhibits some finger clubbing. There is a systolic murmur best heard at the apex  which was not documented in previous medical records. Other significant findings include petechiae noted on his sclera  conjunctiva  and distal extremities. Further investigation also identified Osler’s nodes in his fingers and toes  and Janeway lesions in palms and soles.   Problem Representation: Given the background of a 55-year-old man  who is a long-term intravenous drug user  presenting with symptoms of low-grade fever  malaise  weight loss  a new systolic murmur  and classic skin and mucosal lesions  there is a high clinical suspicion for infective endocarditis related to his drug abuse history and native valve status.   Literature references indicate that infective endocarditis is more commonly found in males [PubMed:26857892]. As per a study published in JAMA  the prevalence of infective endocarditis is increasing among those with drug use disorders  particularly in urban areas [PubMed:28350929]. Disease predisposition in the homeless or unemployed population is frequently associated with limited access to health care  added to substance abuse making them more prone to infectious diseases [PubMed: 28379749]. As such  these factors cumulatively portray a picture of high risk for developing infective endocarditis in this patient.   Concerning presentation  symptoms of low-grade fever  malaise  weight loss  a new systolic murmur  and classic skin and mucosal lesions; they are considered characteristic for infective endocarditis  and align with literature references [PubMed:28118680  PubMed:26868136  and PubMed:27777222]. Further evaluation and management protocols should  therefore  be expedited to confirm diagnosis and commence appropriate treatment.

Patient Characterization:  Patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male  presenting with fever  fatigue  night sweats  and weight loss. He has a history of intravenous drug use  which is a common risk factor for infective endocarditis. Furthermore  he also has a history of cardiac conditions including a previous myocardial infarction and heart failure. He is unemployed and lives in an urban setting in lower socioeconomic conditions. He is not currently on any regular medications nor does he have any known allergies. His family history is notable for cardiovascular diseases  with both parents having succumbed to heart-related complications.  Risk Factors:  1. Intravenous drug use (IVDU): Former history of intravenous drug use poses a significant risk since this route of drug delivery can introduce bacteria or fungi into the bloodstream  adhering to the cardiac valves and leading to infective endocarditis.  2. Age: Advanced age can result in a higher predisposition to infective endocarditis.  3. Gender: Infective endocarditis tends to be more prevalent among males.  4. Cardiac history: The patient's history of myocardial infarction and heart failure increases the risk of infective endocarditis. In particular  prior damage to the heart valves predisposes them to bacterial adherence and subsequent infection.  5. Socioeconomic factors: Lower socioeconomic background and unemployment foster living conditions conducive to health risk behaviors  disease and poor access to healthcare  increasing the chances of acquiring and poorly managing infections  including endocarditis.   Signs and Symptoms:  Presenting symptoms are consistent with infections endocarditis  including intermittent fever  fatigue  night sweats  and weight loss. Other signs to look out for would be Osler nodes (painful red nodules on the fingers) and Janeway lesions (painless red lesions on the palms or soles).   Medical History:   Previous cardiovascular events like myocardial infarction and heart failure result in heart tissue damage  creating niches for bacterial or fungal colonization. His history of IVDU is indicative of lifestyle factors that could heighten the risk of exposure to infection.

Patient Profile:   Mr. Thomas is a 60-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use. He lives in an urban area on the East Coast of the United States and is retired from his former job as construction worker. Thomas is currently unemployed and without health insurance. He is separated from his wife and lives alone. He has two adult children whom he sees occasionally. He is a current smoker and has a history of alcohol abuse  although he has abstained from alcohol for the past 3 years.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Thomas has a notable previous medical history that consists of intravenous drug abuse  Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)  and Hepatitis C infections. His COPD is mostly managed with inhaled corticosteroids and bronchodilators. His Hepatitis C infection was diagnosed five years ago and he completed antiviral treatment regimens successfully  but hasn't undergone further evaluation for hepatic fibrosis or cirrhosis. He's not under any current medication regime for his history of drug abuse. He is not known to have any allergies.  Present History:   Mr. Thomas has been feeling fatigued and short of breath for the last two weeks  accompanied by low-grade fever and night sweats. He reports a loss of appetite and unintentional weight loss of about 7 kilos over the last two months.   On examination  he is found to have a new murmur suggestive of aortic regurgitation. His pulse rate is irregular  and he exhibits localized weakness on the left side of his body hinting at possible embolic events. His temperature is 38.4 degrees Celsius.   By correlating his symptoms  history of IV drug use  and physical exam findings  Mr. Thomas likely has native valve endocarditis. Based on his specific risk factors  likely pathogens could be Staphylococcus aureus or Pseudomonas aeruginosa  and less likely  Streptococcus viridans.   Blood cultures and echocardiogram would be needed to confirm the diagnosis and identify the causative pathogen for appropriate targeted antibiotic treatment. Multidisciplinary team input would also be necessary for the management of his drug abuse and his neurological symptoms. Further investigation for potential systemic complications  such as metastatic infections and glomerulonephritis  is also necessary  considering the duration and systemic manifestations of his illness.

He has also noticed night sweats and shortness of breath during his usual activities. Medication History:  Longstanding prescription for metformin 500mg BID for diabetes and aspirin 81mg daily for coronary artery disease. Social History: The patient is a retired engineer  married with two grown children. He quit smoking approximately 20 years ago and drinks alcohol socially. He doesn't use any recreational drugs and reports no known drug allergies. Patient reports that he has been quite active  taking part in regular moderate-intensity exercises including walking.  Review of Systems: General: Fever  fatigue  weight loss. Cardiovascular: Shortness of breath on exertion  no chest pain  no palpitations. Lungs: No cough  no wheezing. Patient Profile:  Mr. John Doe  a 57-year-old Caucasian male  a resident of a high-income country with access to quality healthcare  comes in presenting symptoms akin to native-valve infective endocarditis. Given the statistical majority presented in literature  he is not a low-risk individual  but rather one who already suffers from some form of heart condition. Current Medications:  - Daily aspirin (low-dose) - An angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor for hypertension - A beta-blocker for heart disease management  No known drug allergies.  The problem representation is hence: A 57-year-old male with a history of hypertensive heart disease  mitral valve surgery  dental prosthesis  and periodontal disease presents with a two-week history of persistent low-grade fevers  malaise  night sweats  mild weight loss  shortness of breath  and easy fatigue; raising the possibility of native-valve infective endocarditis.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Doe Age: 54 years old  Sex: Male  Race: Caucasian Occupation: Unskilled worker Residential Status: Urban resident Socioeconomic Status: Low  Presenting Issue: John Doe presents with potential symptoms indicative of native-valve infective endocarditis  including fevers  shortness of breath  fatigue  aching muscles  night sweats  chills  unexplained weight loss  and small spots of blood under the nails.  Past Medical History: John has a history of intravenous drug use  last documented 5 years ago. He has previously been diagnosed with a mild form of heart disease and has irregular dental check-ups.  Epidemiological Background: The patient is representative of the typical demographic most affected by native-valve infective endocarditis  being a middle-aged Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use. Research shows that this condition is most common in this demographic group  with males twice as likely to develop the condition than females  and the age group 40-80 being most affected. Substance abuse  particularly intravenous drug use  is also a well-documented risk factor. Other contributing factors include heart disease and poor dental hygiene due to increased risk of bacteria entering the bloodstream.  Symptoms: The typical symptoms of native-valve infective endocarditis that the patient is presenting with include fevers  fatigue  aching muscles  night sweats  unexplained weight loss  and signs of minor hemorrhaging. The condition is characterized by bacterial infection of the heart's inner lining or valves  resulting in general sickness and potentially serious heart complications if left untreated.  Risk Factors: Given his past medical history  this patient's risk is increased due to pre-existing heart disease  a history of intravenous drug use  and poor dental hygiene. Non-modifiable risk factors include his demographic profile (middle-aged Caucasian male)  socioeconomic status  and residence in an urban setting.  Problem Representation: The patient's symptoms along with his past medical history and demographic factors strongly suggest a possible diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. Early detection and appropriate treatment are crucial for patient prognosis. Considering the patient's past behavior and socio-economic status  a comprehensive and multidimensional approach would be necessary for efficient management of his condition.

Patient Representation:  Name: Mr. Smith Age: 67 years old Sex: Male  Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired corporate banker  Country of Birth: United States  Current Residence: New York City  NY  Medical History:   Mr. Smith was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus type 2 and hypertension in his mid-50s  for which he is taking metformin and lisinopril  respectively. He exercises regularly  following a moderate-intensity exercise program including 30-minute daily walks and light weight training thrice a week. Patient Profile:   Mr. John Doe  a 60-year-old Caucasian male  presents with complaints of persistent high-grade fever of around 101-102 degrees Fahrenheit  excessive fatigue  night sweats  muscle aches  and unexplained weight loss over the past three weeks. His older sister is alive and has a history of ovarian cancer; she is in remission.  Risk Factors:  1) Age - Increased age is a risk factor for native valve infective endocarditis. 2) Gender - The condition is more common in males. 3) Valvular Heart Disease  4) Dental procedure - Linked with transient bacteremia  a risk factor for infective endocarditis. 5) Diabetes Mellitus - Poor control of diabetes may affect the immune system  increasing the risk of infection. 6) Hypertension - Chronic high blood pressure can damage the blood vessels making them more susceptible to infection.  Clinical Presentation:  The symptoms he is showing like fever  fatigue  night sweats  weight loss  and muscle aches  are consistent with infective endocarditis.   Considering the above history  the representation of the problem can be constructed. The persistent high fever with generalized discomfort in a patient with a history of valvular heart disease  recent dental cleaning procedure and presence of other comorbidities like Hypertension and Diabetes may represent a probable case of native-valve infective endocarditis. Diagnostic aspects should focus on blood cultures and echocardiographic studies according to published guidelines.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: The patient is a 56-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use (IVDU).  Presenting Complaint: The patient presents with a two-week history of fatigue  night sweats  weight loss  and a new heart murmur.  Demographics: Native-valve infective endocarditis (IE) is more common in males  with a median age for presentation around 57.8 years according to literature. Caucasians are more likely to develop native-valve IE  compared to other races. Past history of IVDU has been associated with an increased risk of native valve infective endocarditis.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  for which they take Lisinopril. The patient also has chronic Hepatitis C  a common finding in people with a history of IVDU. A history of such illicit drug use significantly increases the chance of IE.  Social History: The patient admits to ongoing IVDU  focused on opioids. He lives alone and does not have any regular employment. He is not on any regular medications apart from his anti-hypertensives.  Occupational History: The patient is unemployed at the moment but used to work as a construction worker.  Family History: There is a family history of heart disease (father had a heart attack at age 59).  Summary Problem List: 1. Presenting complaints: New onset heart murmur  fatigue  night sweats and weight loss. 2. Past medical history: Hypertension  chronic Hepatitis C. 3. Social Risk factors: IVDU (specifically opioids)  living alone  unemployment. 4. Family history: Heart disease.  Relevance: All these factors contribute to the patient's increased risk of developing native valve infective endocarditis. Therefore  immediate and appropriate management should target both the suspected infective endocarditis and the associated complications  as well as the underlying risk factors (IVDU  Hypertension  Hepatitis C). Providing a multidisciplinary team that includes addiction specialists might be beneficial for this patient management.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 56-year-old Hispanic male  who was a former intravenous drug user and quit five years ago  presents to the Emergency Department (ED). Patient also complains of unintended weight loss.  Social History: He had been working as a construction worker until recently when he lost his job. He lives alone in a one-bedroom flat and had a turbulent relationship with his family due to his past substance abuse. He quit smoking ten years ago but still indulges in alcoholic beverages on weekends.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of Hepatitis C  for which he received treatment five years ago. He also has hyperlipidemia controlled by statins. He has been compliant with his medications and regularly visits his primary care physician. There is no past history of cardiac diseases or surgeries.  Relevant Investigations: On examination  he has a cardiac murmur on auscultation. Peripheral petechiae are present. Three sets of blood cultures are drawn due to suspicion of infective endocarditis based on clinical and examination findings.  The purpose of this problem statement is to provide a comprehensive representation of a patient present to the ED with suspected native-valve Infective Endocarditis. This is based on the aggregation of common demographic characteristics and clinical attributes of patients with this condition  as well as additional personal details to foster a contextually-rounded perspective.

Demographics:  The patient is a 62-year-old African American male. He resides in an urban setting in the Midwestern United States and identifies as working-class. His educational level is high-school graduate and he worked for 45 years as a professional auto mechanic  which involved moderate to high levels of physical activity. He lives with his spouse in a house that they own. The patient is a former smoker  with one pack per day for 20 years  but quit smoking at the age of 50. He admits to frequent alcohol consumption  typically 2-3 times per week. He has not reported any recent travel or occupational exposure to potentially infectious environments or substances.  Past Medical History:  He has a documented history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes  which are managed with medication but have shown signs of poor control in recent months due to irregular medical follow-up and medication nonadherence. The last HbA1c was 8.5% (Normal range under 7%) and BP readings have consistently been above 135/95 mmHg. He also has a history of degenerative joint disease of the knee. No record of previous surgeries or invasive medical procedures could be found. No reported allergies to medications.  Recent Symptoms and Infection:  The patient presents persistent  unexplained fever for two weeks (~101-103°F)  noted weight loss (~10 pounds in 1 month)  generalized weakness  and occasional night sweats. He also mentions an intermittent headache and a new heart murmur was detected on his latest physical examination. He had apparent skin manifestations including Osler's nodes (painful nodules on fingers and toes) and Janeway lesions (painless red lesions on the palms and soles).  Problem Representation:  62-year-old African American male  with poorly controlled hypertension and Diabetes mellitus type 2  presenting with fever  malaise  weight loss  new heart murmur  and typical skin manifestations suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis.

Based on his demographic characteristics and past medical history  and given his new onset of symptoms (especially unexplained fever)  infective endocarditis should be a serious consideration. Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: Mr. Smith is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  born and raised in the United States. He used to drink in moderation but quit alcohol 10 years ago. He has no history of intravenous drug use. He has two children with whom he has regular contact. He has regular weekly meetings with his friends at a local seniors' recreation center. He has no significant travel or exposure history.  Past Medical History: Significant medical history includes hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and suffered a mild stroke 5 years ago. He compliantly follows his prescribed medications: low-dose aspirin  Lisinopril  and Simvastatin.  Examination Findings: On examination  Mr. Smith has a new-onset heart murmur best heard in the mitral area  petechiae over his lower limbs  and minor splinter hemorrhages in his nails. Blood pressure records at 145/95 mmHg  heart rate at 80 bpm normal rhythm  respiratory rate 18/min  and oxygen saturation 96% on room air. He appears lethargic but fully oriented to person  place  and time.  These clinical presentations along with the new onset heart murmur and positive blood cultures point toward the possibility of native-valve infective endocarditis in this patient.  Studies to Confirm Diagnosis: To confirm the diagnosis  Mr. Smith will have to undergo an echocardiogram to visualize vegetations consistent with infective endocarditis along with continued collection of blood cultures to identify the causative pathogen. Additional tests to evaluate the degree and impact of his condition like full blood count  renal function tests  and an ECG will also need to be considered.  Risk factors: Advanced age  male sex  cardiovascular problems (hypertension  heart murmurs)  and unfavorable lifestyle habits (smoking) are the clinical risk factors that have likely contributed to the development of infective endocarditis in Mr. Smith. With his prior history of stroke  it also places him at risk of embolic complications if he does have infective endocarditis. His social activities also might have exposed him to microbial agents causing infective endocarditis.

Patient Profile: - Age: 60 years - Sex: Male - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired teacher  Health Background: - Past Medical History: Type II diabetes mellitus well-controlled with Metformin  Hypertensive under control with Losartan. - Allergies: No known medication allergies.  - Family History: Mother had Lupus  Father had Colon Cancer. - Social History: Non-drinker  non-smoker. Lives alone. Active  enjoys gardening and volunteering at the local library.   Presenting Problem: The patient is presenting with a three-week history of evolutionary symptoms including weakness  intermittent fever  night sweats  diminished appetite and weight loss. He also mentions experiencing discomfort in his joints and muscles. More recently  he noticed some spots on his legs that he identified as petechiae.   Relevant Findings: - Physical exam: The patient is afebrile  heart rate is somewhat rapid  blood pressure slightly low; a heart murmur is present upon examination; Osler’s nodes are identified on his fingers and toes  and Roth spots are found during the eye exam. Petechiae are present on the lower extremities.  - Labs: Elevated WBC  ESR  and CRP. Blood cultures positive after 24 hours. Hemoglobin slightly low  could suggest anemia possibly related to chronic disease. - Imaging: Transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) reveals a vegetation on the mitral valve  confirming a diagnosis of infective endocarditis.   Diagnosis: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  This patient fits within the typical demographic for native-valve infective endocarditis. Current literature suggests that men are more likely to be affected than women  specifically in a ratio of about 2:1. The disease is also more common amongst older adults. The conditions leading to this concern can be tied back to his underlying cardiovascular disease (hypertension) and his advanced age. His diabetes mellitus does not help as it affects the immune system’s ability to fight infections. His clinical profile and investigative findings corroborate quite well with a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.
