Therapeutic intervention: The patient was admitted and intravenous antibiotic therapy was initiated  including penicillin and gentamicin  in accordance with guidelines for Streptococcus bovis IE. Despite therapeutic intervention  signs of heart failure began to manifest  and surgical intervention was considered. Subsequently  the patient underwent successful mitral valve replacement without any complications.  Follow-up and outcomes: The patient responded well to the surgical intervention and subsequent oral antibiotic regimen over a period of six weeks. Her post-discharge recovery was also satisfactory  with no further signs of IE. Heart failure symptoms have resolved and her ejection fraction improved. She is currently on regular follow-ups and has adhered to her diabetic and hypertensive medications.  Patient’s perspective: The patient reports feeling better with a drastic decrease in her symptoms. She acknowledges the importance of maintaining control over her type 2 diabetes and hypertension to avoid further complications.  Informed consent: The patient gave informed consent for her data to be published in a case report.  Teaching points: Native-valve infective endocarditis remains a severe disease with potential lethal complications  particularly heart failure. Early detection and appropriate management are crucial in improving patient outcomes. Regular follow-ups for high-risk individuals  like the patient with comorbidities in this case (hypertension and diabetes)  are critical to prevent and identify diseases in early stages. The student should learn to evaluate patients with persistent fever and consider IE in differential diagnosis  especially when a new murmur is detected.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Caucasian Male  Introduction: This case report presents a middle-aged Caucasian male with complex presentation of native-valve infective endocarditis.   Case Presentation: Mr. AH  a 52 year-old Caucasian male insurance agent  residing in Chicago  Illinois  presented to the emergency department with recurrent fever  extreme fatigue  weight loss  and progressively worsening shortness of breath for the past two months. He denied any history of drug abuse  travel  pets at home  dental procedure  or recent surgery.  Past Medical History: The patient's medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia managed with Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively. He does not smoke tobacco or drink alcohol. There is no family history of heart disease or similar symptoms.   Clinical Examination: On admission  Mr. AH was febrile with a temperature of 38.5°C  blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg  heart rate of 98 beats/min  and respiratory rate of 24 breaths/min. Cardiac examination revealed a grade III/VI mid-systolic murmur best heard at the apex. Lung auscultation was normal  and there were no peripheral stigmata of infective endocarditis observed.  Investigations: His blood examination showed elevated leukocyte count and C-reactive protein. His renal function and liver functions were within normal limits. Blood cultures were drawn and sent for analysis. Transthoracic echocardiography demonstrated a mobile echodensity on the anterior mitral leaflet  suggestive of vegetation with moderate mitral regurgitation. Chest radiograph was unremarkable.  Management and Outcome: He was started empirically on broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics  which included Vancomycin and Gentamicin. Once blood culture results confirmed methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) as the causative organism  Vancomycin was discontinued  and the patient was continued on high-dose intravenous penicillin G and Gentamicin.  The patient's clinical condition gradually improved over the next few days and he was afebrile by the fifth day of hospitalization. His fatigue and shortness of breath also improved significantly.    After a course of intravenous antibiotics for 6 weeks  a follow-up Transthoracic Echocardiography showed a significant reduction in vegetation size  and his clinical symptoms were completely resolved.   Conclusion: This case illustrates the complexity of diagnosing native-valve infective endocarditis. The prompt recognition of the key symptoms  the systematic approach to investigation  and the early initiation of empiric antibiotic therapy were vital in providing effective treatment for Mr. AH.

Title: A Case Study on Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Male Patient   Case Presentation:  Mr. A  a 63-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department with complaints of chills  high-grade intermittent fever  and extreme fatigue persisting for the past two weeks. He also reported unintended weight loss of approximately 10 pounds over the same period. The patient denied any history of recent travel  any contact with sick individuals  illicit drug use  and did not have a history of any recent dental procedures.  Past Medical History:  His past medical history included stable coronary artery disease  hypertension  and type 2 diabetes  all under control with a combination of medications including as aspirin  metoprolol  and metformin. His family history highlighted coronary artery disease and cancer. He had quit smoking about 10 years ago  previously having a 30 pack-year smoking history  and consumed alcohol socially.  Clinical Examination:  On physical examination  Mr. A was found to be febrile with a body temperature of 38.5℃  heart rate of 98 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  and blood pressure of 135/88 mmHg. There was no skin rash  lymph node enlargement  or joint inflammation. An examination of the oral cavity revealed no obvious source of infection  and lung auscultation was normal.  Cardiovascular examination revealed a distinct heart murmur and the presence of the Janeway lesions on his palms and soles  suggestive of infective endocarditis.  Investigations:  Lab findings showed a high white blood cell count  erythrocyte sedimentation rate  and C-reactive protein level indicating systemic inflammation. Blood cultures were drawn  which showed growth of Streptococcus mutans  a definitive diagnosis for infective endocarditis. An echocardiogram was performed which demonstrated vegetations on the mitral valve  confirming the diagnosis.  Treatment and Outcome:  The patient was started on empirical antibiotics immediately after blood cultures were collected. According to culture and sensitivity results  treatment was then shifted to penicillin G and gentamicin for four weeks  which led to a resolution of his fever and improvements in his microbial and inflammatory markers. Follow-up echocardiogram demonstrated substantial regression of the vegetations.  Conclusion:  Early detection and timely intervention can result in a favorable prognosis in individuals with native-valve infective endocarditis. This case underscores the importance for clinicians to maintain a high index of suspicion for endocarditis in high risk individuals who present with persistent fever  heart murmurs  and systemic signs of infection.

Title: Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-aged Male with History of Valvular Heart Disease: A Case Report  Abstract:  This case report represents a 55-year-old Caucasian male with a history of Degenerative Heart Valve Disease  who was diagnosed and managed for Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis (IE).  Case Presentation:  A 55-year-old Caucasian male  accountant by profession  non-smoker and occasional alcohol consumer  presented to the hospital with a two-week history of low-grade fever  chills  general fatigue  weight loss  and a recent onset of intermittent chest discomfort. He had a noted past medical history of Degenerative Heart Valve Disease diagnosed five years prior. However  he never underwent any surgical intervention required for his existing heart condition  citing his fear of surgery and the perceived desire to manage the disease conservatively.   Clinical Findings and Diagnosis:  On examination  he was found to have a temperature of 38.5 degrees Celsius. Cardiac examination revealed a systolic murmur. Blood tests illustrated an elevated white blood cell (WBC) count and C-reactive protein (CRP). Three sets of blood cultures were obtained which  after 48 hours  identified Staphylococcus aureus as the infecting organism. A Transthoracic Echocardiogram (TTE) demonstrated a 1.1 cm mobile vegetation on the ventricular side of the aortic valve  confirming the diagnosis of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis as per the Modified Duke's Criteria.  Management and Outcome:  The patient was started on empirical antibiotic therapy with Cefazolin and Gentamicin per American Heart Association (AHA) guidelines  which was continued for 6 weeks followed by a two-week course of Cloxacillin as per the sensitivities of the blood culture findings. The patient’s clinical conditions  including fever and symptoms  started to improve after a week of antibiotic treatment. The patient declined surgical treatment. After completion of antibiotic therapy  a follow-up TTE exhibited significant decrease in the size of the vegetation. The patient was subsequently discharged with instructions for rigorous dental hygiene to prevent future recurrence and was scheduled for routine follow-ups.  Conclusion:  This case underscores the importance of appropriate timely diagnosis and management of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  particularly in patients with pre-existing valvular heart disease. Additionally  it emphasizes the patient's role in therapeutic decisions and the necessity of regular follow-up evaluations to monitor disease progression and treatment efficacy.   Confidentiality: The patient's name and other identifiable data have been omitted to respect privacy and confidentiality as per HIPAA guidelines. Consent has been obtained from the patient for this case report.

Title: A Case Report on Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Male Patient  Introduction  This report represents a case of a 72-year-old Caucasian male patient diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis (IE). This case study emphasizes the importance of early and accurate diagnosis  followed by appropriate management  in improving the prognosis of IE.  Case Description  Mr. X  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presented with complaints of recurrent low-grade fever  generalized fatigue  and shortness of breath for approximately four weeks. The patient has a known history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension  both well-controlled on medications. Smoking history was noted with the patient reported being a former smoker  quitting smoking approximately 20 years back. He lives alone and he is mostly independent with his activities of daily living  but had recently found these tasks increasingly challenging due to his ongoing symptoms.  Clinical Findings  Upon physical examination  the patient appeared to be malnourished and mildly dehydrated. Notable findings included pallor  low-grade fever (100.4F)  and a new onset  grade II pansystolic murmur best heard at the cardiac apex. No other immediate clinical abnormalities were detected.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment  The pansystolic murmur identified upon examination alarmed physicians to a potential heart condition  and subsequent investigations were targeted at diagnosis and assessment of potential cardiac involvements. The patient's lab results showed elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP)  signifying an ongoing systemic inflammatory response. His blood cultures were dispatched which later confirmed the growth of Staphylococcus aureus  highly suggestive of a bacterial endocarditis.  A transthoracic echocardiogram revealed a thickened mitral valve with a mobile echodensity suggestive of vegetation attached to the leaflet  dramatically affirming the suspicion of native valve infective endocarditis.  Treatment  The patient was immediately started on intravenous antibiotics as per the Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) guidelines for Staphylococcus aureus endocarditis. Given the identification of sizable vegetation  alongside the patient's deteriorating clinical condition  a multidisciplinary team concluded that surgical intervention for his infected valve would offer the best chance of recovery. The patient underwent successful mitral valve replacement surgery two weeks following initial diagnosis  with a smooth postoperative period.  Conclusion  This case illustrates the importance of clinical suspicion for IE in patients presenting with non-specific clinical pictures  especially in those with predisposing health conditions  like diabetes mellitus. Prompt initiation of investigations  correct diagnosis  and appropriate management are pivotal in treating IE effectively  thereby improving patient prognosis and quality of life. The role of interdisciplinary management is also underlined in ensuring comprehensive care for patients with IE.

Title: A Rare Presentation of Streptococcus viridans Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 56-year-old African American Male  Patient Information: A 56-year-old African American Male  married  currently working as an office clerk  came to the medical outpatient department complaining primarily of the following conditions: fluctuating fever for 1 month  weakness  weight loss  night sweats  a new murmur (heard during auscultation)  and shortness of breath on exertion. The patient's family history revealed that his father died due to coronary artery disease while his mother had diabetes and hypertension. He reported smoking half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 35 years but denied any alcohol intake or illicit drug use.  Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  the patient was tachycardic but stable. Further symptoms included splinter hemorrhages under the nails  Janeway lesions  and Osler’s nodes on his palms. A systolic murmur was noticed at the cardiac apex. Blood pressure was recorded at 130/90 mmHg  heart rate at 85 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  and temperature at 100.5F. The rest of the physical examination didn't reveal any other significant finding.  Diagnostic Assessment: Two sets of blood cultures were drawn from different sites  both of which grew alpha-hemolytic Streptococcus viridans. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) showed vegetations on mitral valve with moderate regurgitation but no abscess or perforation. These findings aligned with the Modified Duke Criteria and led to the diagnosis of Definite Infective Endocarditis.  The patient's CBC showed mild anemia and leukocytosis. Kidney function tests  liver function tests  and electrolytes were within normal limits. An EKG showed normal sinus rhythm with no ischemic changes.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient had been started on Empiric IV antibiotic therapy (Vancomycin and Gentamicin) while waiting for the blood culture result. Given the culture sensitivity report  the antibiotics were deescalated to IV Penicillin G and Gentamicin.   The patient's condition improved over the next few days  as indicated by a decrease in fever and reduced severity of breathlessness. A follow-up TTE after two weeks of therapy showed a size reduction in vegetation.  Follow-up and Outcomes: The patient completed a 4-week course of antibiotics. His symptoms improved significantly  and repeat blood cultures remained negative. He was advised to quit smoking and was given appropriate counseling. A regular follow-up monthly plan was arranged to monitor the patient's clinical and echocardiographic progress.  Patient Perspective: The patient expressed his gratitude and satisfaction with the outcome of his treatment after his discharge. He also affirmed his intention to heed his physician’s advice concerning smoking cessation and maintaining regular follow-up visits.  Informed Consent: Informed written consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report and accompanying images.

Title: A Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 55-Year-Old African-American Male  Introduction: We present the case of a 55-year-old African-American male diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis. Studies show a slightly higher incidence of infective endocarditis among African-American populations  with males manifesting more severe symptoms.  Case Description:  A 55-year-old African-American male  working as a construction worker  presented with a two-week history of fatigue  fever  night sweats  and atypical chest pain. The patient had a history of intravenous (IV) drug use in his 20s but had remained sober for over 25 years. He had a known history of hypertension  for which he was taking hydrochlorothiazide  and a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus managed through oral hypoglycemic agents.  On examination  the patient appeared ill and had a low-grade fever. He presented with rashes consistent with Osler's nodes on his fingers and toes  as well as Janeway lesions in his palms and soles. Cardiac examination revealed a murmur consistent with mitral regurgitation.   Investigations:  Laboratory investigations revealed anemia with hemoglobin of 9.9 g/dl and elevated inflammatory markers with a C-reactive protein of 93 mg/L. Prolonged blood cultures (3 sets) were positive for Staphylococcus aureus.  Transthoracic echocardiogram showed large vegetations on the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve with severe mitral regurgitation. The remaining valves appeared normal. These findings were consistent with the diagnosis of left-sided  native-valve infective endocarditis.  Management:  The patient was started on intravenous antibiotics (vancomycin and ceftriaxone) according to infective endocarditis treatment guidelines. Despite medical treatment  the patient remained symptomatic with persistently positive blood cultures after one week. It was decided to proceed with surgical intervention considering the large vegetations  severe valve damage  and persistent bacteremia.   The patient underwent successful mitral valve replacement surgery and continued on postoperative antibiotics for six weeks.   Discussion:  This case underscores the complexity of diagnosing and managing infective endocarditis  that may occur even in patients without recent IV drug use. It additionally highlights the role of surgical intervention when medical therapy alone fails.   Conclusion:  Despite being a relatively rare condition  early recognition of infective endocarditis symptoms  especially in at-risk populations  is essential in managing this potential life-threatening condition. Clinicians should maintain a high index of suspicion when faced with suggestive clinical features and should promptly initiate appropriate antibiotics and necessary intervention as required.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis: A Case Report  Patient Profile: A 50-year-old Hispanic male  resident of New York City  working as a school bus driver with no known travel history outside the United States.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented in the Emergency Department reporting a 2-week history of intermittent fever  night sweats  malaise  and a weight loss of 10 pounds. He also complained of persistent fatigue and mild shortness of breath.  Past Medical History: The patient had a known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  well-controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents and diet. He had been diagnosed with hypertension five years ago and was taking antihypertensive medication. There were no previous hospitalizations  surgery or allergies reported. The patient quit smoking twelve years ago  and denied illicit drug use  but admitted to drinking alcohol socially.  Clinical Examination: On examination  the patient looked moderately ill  with a low-grade fever of 100.5°F. A systolic murmur was detected over the left lower sternal border. The rest of the physical examination  including a detailed neurological examination  was unremarkable.  Lab Tests and Imaging: Several blood cultures were positive for Streptococcus viridans. Complete blood count showed anemia and a slightly elevated white blood cell count. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein were significantly elevated. A transesophageal echocardiogram demonstrated a vegetation on the mitral valve  with moderate mitral regurgitation. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis was ordered and it did not reveal any abscesses.  Infective endocarditis was diagnosed based on the Duke Criteria with 2 major criteria (positive blood cultures and echocardiographic findings of vegetation) satisfied.  Case Management and Outcome: The patient was promptly initiated on empiric antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone and gentamicin  tailored down to penicillin monotherapy based on antibiotic susceptibility results. After 4 weeks of antibiotic treatment  he showed significant clinical improvement with resolution of fever  normalization of inflammatory markers  and weight stabilization. Repeat blood cultures were negative  and the patient was subsequently discharged home on strict follow-up with infectious diseases and cardiology clinics.  Conclusion: The early diagnosis and prompt  appropriate management of this case underscores the importance of maintaining a high index of suspicion for infective endocarditis in patients with clinical features of prolonged unexplained fever  cardiac murmur  and markers of systemic inflammation  even in the absence of any history of intravenous drug use or structural heart disease. This report adds to the literature highlighting native-valve infective endocarditis in middle-aged individuals with underlying non-cardiac comorbidities.

Title: Native Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 65-Year-Old Male: A Case Report   Introduction:  This case report describes a 65-year-old Caucasian male patient who presented with native valve infective endocarditis.  Patient Information:  The patient is a 65-year-old retiree living in Birmingham  Alabama with his wife. He is a former construction worker with a 45-pack-year smoking history and had quit smoking ten years prior. His past medical history included hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).  Clinical Findings:  The patient first came to the medical attention complaining of generalized malaise  fever  and unintentional weight loss of around 5 kg over a period of one month. He reported subjective fevers and noted increasing shortness of breath over this period.  Diagnostic Assessment:  His vital signs revealed a blood pressure of 140/80 mmHg  heart rate of 100 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute with increased use of accessory muscles  and an elevated temperature of 38.7°C. Physical examination revealed a grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur heard best at the apex of the heart and punctate  erythematous skin lesions over the palms and soles.  The blood work showed an increased white blood cell count with neutrophil predominance  mild anemia  and elevated inflammatory markers. His chest radiograph showed a normal cardiothoracic ratio  clear lung fields  and normal hilar shadows . Echocardiography showed vegetations on the mitral valve along with severe mitral regurgitation  confirming the diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis.  The patient was started on empiric therapy with intravenous Vancomycin and Gentamicin  and blood cultures subsequently grew Streptococcus viridans  underlying the need for continuation of the same antibiotics.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient continued antibiotic therapy for six weeks. The physicians suggested a surgical consultation considering severe mitral regurgitation and persistent heart failure symptoms  despite medical therapy. However  the patient decided against surgery.  Follow-ups and Outcomes:  During the follow-up period  the patient's symptoms improved modestly  suggesting partial resolution of the infection. Unfortunately  he continues to suffer from exertional dyspnea due to severe mitral regurgitation  requiring periodic hospital readmissions for heart failure exacerbation.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the significant morbidity associated with native valve infective endocarditis  especially in patients with pre-existing cardiac conditions. It underlines the critical need for early detection  appropriate antibiotic therapy  and vigilant follow-up care in the management of this life-threatened condition.   Confidentiality statement:  Patient confidentiality was maintained  with personal identifiers removed from this report.

Title: Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 61-year-old Male with Previous Myocardial Infarction  Patient Information:  A 61-year-old Caucasian male with a significant history of smoking  hypertension  dyslipidemia and a past myocardial infarction was admitted for a high spiking fever  chills  fatigue  anorexia and weight loss over the past two weeks. He works as a construction worker and lives alone. He reported poor dental health  with missing teeth and periodontal disease.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed a temperature of 38.6°C  blood pressure 145/85 mmHg  heart rate 98 beats/min  and respiratory rate 20 breaths/min. A cardiac examination revealed a grade II/VI systolic ejection murmur heard best at the left middle sternal edge. A dental examination showed poor oral hygiene and several carious teeth.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Blood and urine cultures were obtained. High-sensitivity C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation rate were elevated at 91mg/l and 65mm/h respectively. Transthoracic echocardiography demonstrated a mobile echodense mass at the junction of the left ventricular outflow tract and the anterior mitral leaflet consistent with vegetation. Blood cultures eventually grew Streptococcus viridans  reinforcing the diagnosis of infective endocarditis.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was started on intravenous penicillin G and gentamicin  in combination following the American Heart Association's guidelines for the management of infective endocarditis. He completed 4 weeks of therapy with a close therapeutic drug monitoring.  Follow-up and Outcomes: Post-treatment  his symptoms improved significantly  and repeat blood cultures were negative. Repeat echocardiography at six-week follow-up revealed a significant reduction in vegetation size. He was referred for assessment and treatment of his poor dental health to reduce the risk of recurrent infective endocarditis.  Patient Perspective: The patient expressed relief at the resolution of his condition and committed to improving oral hygiene and attending regular dental check-ups  as well as managing his overall cardiovascular health.  Conclusion: This case report highlights the association between poor dental health and the development of native-valve infective endocarditis  especially in individuals with previous heart conditions. It underscores the need for improved education around oral hygiene as a part of comprehensive care for at-risk patient populations.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Male Patient: A Case Report  Introduction  Infective endocarditis is a life-threatening disease associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Native-valve infective endocarditis  which affects the heart's natural valves  is particularly significant in older adults with underlying heart diseases. This case report presents a 73-year-old Caucasian male diagnosed with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis (NVIE).  Patient Information  Mr. A is a 73-year-old Caucasian male  a retired teacher residing in Minnesota  USA. The patient was generally healthy aside from a known medical history of Hypertensive Cardiovascular Disease (HCVD)  and Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus (DM-2). His family history had a significant pattern of cardiovascular disease (CVD)  with his father having died from myocardial infarction. He is a non-smoker  occasional consumes alcohol  and had no known drug allergies.  Clinical Findings  The patient presented at the emergency department with a week-long history of low-grade fever  malaise  weight loss  and night sweats. Newly onset of cardiac murmur was detected during a physical examination. He also complained of arthralgias  more prominent over the right knee and ankle. Routine blood tests showed elevated white blood cell count  C-reactive protein  and erythrocyte sedimentation rate.   Diagnostic Focus and Assessment   After initial suspicion  diagnosis of NVIE was confirmed by Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) showing vegetations on the mitral valve and moderate mitral regurgitation. Blood cultures grew Streptococcus mutans  a common causative organism of NVIE. Diagnosis was satisfying the Duke criteria and further supported by the combination of persistent bacteremia  echocardiographic findings  and clinical symptoms.  Therapeutic Intervention  The patient was started on empirical intravenous antibiotics (vancomycin and gentamicin) which was later de-escalated to ceftriaxone and gentamicin after getting the blood culture results  in accordance with the American Heart Association guidelines for NVIE. Glycemic control was optimized with insulin to minimize the effects of DM-2.  Follow-up and Outcomes  The patient responded well to the antibiotic regimen. After a four-week course  his inflammatory markers normalized  and symptoms subsided. A follow-up echocardiography showed a decrease in the size of the vegetations and reduced mitral regurgitation. Although he remains at risk for potential complications such as heart failure  stroke  or systemic embolization  Mr. A was deemed stable for discharge with recommendations for close follow-up.  Patient Perspective  Mr. A reported significant improvement in his health status after the treatment. He voiced a strong commitment to maintaining his treatment regimen  regular follow-up visits  and monitoring his health condition to minimize the risk of recurrence or complications.  Conclusion  This case underscores the importance of early detection and aggressive medical management of NVIE  especially in elderly patients with underlying cardiac disease. Comprehensive care including diligent antibiotic administration  strict glycemic control  and patient education were key to the successful outcomes in this case.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Patient Information:  Mr. L is a 62-year-old Caucasian male from a rural community who presented with a four-week history of fatigue  weight loss  intermittent fever and chills. Prior to this  he enjoyed an active lifestyle and worked full time in agriculture.  Past Medical History:  Mr. L is a known diabetic  with his blood glucose levels well-controlled on oral hypoglycemic agents. He has been monitored for mild hypertension and hyperlipidaemia  but has had no previous hospital admissions. He does not smoke  reports moderate alcohol consumption and has no known allergies.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  Mr. L appeared chronically unwell and was febrile (38.7°C.). He displayed symptoms of heart failure including increased jugular venous pressure  a pansystolic murmur best heard at the lower left sternal edge  bilateral basal crackles on chest auscultation  and pitting lower limb edema. Spleen size was normal on abdominal examination. There were no peripheral stigmata of endocarditis. Blood pressure was 150/85 mmHg  heart rate 90 bpm  and oxygen saturation 96% on room air.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment:  Blood investigations showed a raised white cell count of 12 x 109/L (normal 4-11 x 109/L)  an elevated C-reactive protein of 100 mg/L (< 5 mg/L) and slightly elevated creatinine levels. A chest radiograph showed signs of pulmonary congestion. An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed left ventricular hypertrophy and sinus tachycardia. A transthoracic echocardiogram  followed by a confirmatory transesophageal echocardiogram  illustrated severe mitral regurgitation with a large vegetation on the posterior leaflet of the mitral valve. A positive blood culture identified Streptococcus bovis as the infectious agent.  Therapeutic Focus and Assessment:  Mr. L was admitted to the hospital and treated with intravenous antibiotics (Penicillin G and Gentamicin) following the antibiotic susceptibility testing. His condition showed improvement with antibiotics. However due to the size of the vegetation and severe mitral regurgitation  surgical intervention became necessary. He underwent successful mitral valve replacement and was discharged on long-term oral antibiotics  anticoagulation  and advised on strict blood sugar and pressure control.  Follow up:  At follow up one month later  Mr. L reported improved symptomatically and his blood cultures showed no growth. However  due to the association of Streptococcus bovis bacteremia with colorectal neoplasia  an additional colonoscopy was scheduled. A small adenoma was identified at sigmoid colon and successfully removed.  Discussion:  This case emphasizes the importance of a high index of suspicion for infective endocarditis  especially with persistent nonspecific symptoms. The case also shows the importance of following the complete treatment paradigm of native-valve endocarditis - including diagnosis  appropriate use of antibiotic therapy  consideration of surgical intervention  and investigation of possible associated conditions.    This case conforms with the typical demographic of infective endocarditis patients who are often middle-aged to older men with pre-existing heart conditions or those with comorbid conditions such as diabetes. Future case reports could analyze whether there is a growing trend toward increased disease incidence in individuals from rural areas.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in Elderly Patient with Diabetes Mellitus Type II: A Case Study  INTRODUCTION: Infective endocarditis (IE) is a severe  life-threatening condition  particularly in the elderly  caused by the infection of the heart valves by microorganisms. Native valve infective endocarditis occurs in individuals without a history of prosthetic heart valve replacement. This will present a case of an elderly male with a history of diabetes mellitus type II  who developed native-valve infective endocarditis.  CASE PRESENTATION:  Patient Information: Mr. JH is a 75-year-old Caucasian male who presented with a one-week history of progressively increasing fatigue  intermittent fever  and shortness of breath. He also reported an unintentional weight loss of approximately 10 pounds in the last month.   Medical history: Mr. JH has a long-standing history of diabetes mellitus (DM) type II for over 25 years which has been complicated by peripheral neuropathy but well-controlled with Metformin. He also has hypertension controlled with Lisinopril. He had a history of arteriovenous fistula repair two years ago and a cholecystectomy 10 years ago. He is a former smoker  with 20-pack-year history and quit smoking five years ago.   Clinical Findings: On physical examination  he had a fever of 38.5°C (101.3°F)  blood pressure of 150/85mmHg  pulse rate of 90 beats per minute  and oxygen saturation of 93% on room air. Cardiac auscultation revealed the presence of a new murmur  specifically a systolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. Slight splenomegaly was palpable on abdominal exam  and pitting edema was present in both lower extremities  more prominent on the right.  Diagnostic Assessment: The laboratory studies showed a white blood cell count of 12.6 x 10^3/uL  hemoglobin level of 10.2 g/dL  and platelet count of 490 x 10^3/uL. ESR was 65 mm/hr  and C-reactive protein levels were elevated. Blood glucose was slightly elevated at 155mg/dL. Blood cultures grew Staphylococcus aureus. Mr. JH underwent a TTE  followed by a TOE which demonstrated vegetation on the mitral valve and severe mitral valve regurgitation confirming the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Therapeutic Intervention: Mr. JH was started on empiric antibiotic therapy with vancomycin and ceftriaxone  which was later adjusted based on the results of blood culture sensitivities. His clinical status started improving over the next few days with a decrease in fever and resolution of his symptoms. His shortness of breath was managed with diuretics.  Follow-up and Outcomes: Despite initial improvement  after two weeks of therapy  his symptoms started to worsen. Repeat TTE suggested progressive valve destruction. Consequently  a decision was made for surgical intervention and a mitral valve replacement was performed successfully. Post-operation  the patient underwent an extended course of intravenous antibiotics and cardiac rehabilitation. He showed resolution of symptoms and an improved quality of life in the subsequent follow-ups.  CONCLUSION: This case underscores the need for high clinical suspicion in diagnosing infective endocarditis in the elderly population  particularly with predisposing conditions such as diabetes mellitus type II. Early diagnosis and prompt management are critical to preventing life-threatening complications  highlighting the significance of a comprehensive clinical and investigational approach.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Caucasian Male: A Case Report  Patient Information:  This report discusses the case of an 80-year-old Caucasian male admitted to the cardiology department of our medical center. The patient lives in a suburban setting and lives alone  with most of his support provided by his children. He is retired and has a past part-time history of breeding cattle.  Presenting Complaint: The patient complained of progressive fatigue  intermittent fever  weight loss  and night sweats occurring over the last 6 weeks. He also reported experiencing mild chest discomfort with increasing frequency.   Previous Medical History: The patient is known to have a 20-year history of well-controlled hypertension and was diagnosed with Type II diabetes five years ago. He had an uncomplicated myocardial infarction 15 years ago and was placed on a medication regimen of low-dose aspirin  a beta-blocker  and a statin that he has continued since. No history of intravenous drug use  dental procedures  or recent surgical interventions was reported. The patient had a bout of pneumonia 2 years ago that required hospitalization but recovered well without complications.  Investigational Findings and Diagnosis: Physical examination revealed mild pallor and a new-onset systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. Blood tests showed a high erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein level  mild normocytic anemia  and leukocytosis. His blood glucose levels and other vital signs were within typically managed ranges. Serial blood culture sets grew Streptococcus bovis  indicative of bacteremia.   Echocardiography showed thickening and vegetation of the aortic valve  with moderate aortic regurgitation. No ventricular wall motion abnormalities were detected. These findings led to a diagnosis of definite infective endocarditis  based on the modified Duke criteria.   Treatment and Progress:  The patient was started on high-dose penicillin  initially administered intravenously  following the American Heart Association (AHA) guidelines. After showing good clinical response  he was switched to oral medication. The patient's clinical condition gradually improved over the next 2 weeks.  The presence of S. Bovis led to further investigation  including total colonoscopy  which revealed an early stage of colon carcinoma. The Mass General Brigham Department for Primary Care took over and set up a predilection for routine checks and continuous monitoring.  Conclusion: This case underscores the importance of prompt diagnosis and appropriate management of native-valve infective endocarditis  and the need to investigate for a possible gastrointestinal malignancy in patients with S. Bovis bacteremia. Active involvement of the primary healthcare team in follow-up and medication compliance is paramount in managing such cases.

Title: A Case Report of a 65-year-old Male Patient with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Information: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male belonging to the low socio-economic group and hailing from an urban area in the Midwest of the United States of America. He has no prior history of illicit drug use or alcohol addiction. He is a retired construction worker and lives with his wife; they have four adult children.   Past medical history: The patient has a significant medical history  including type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 15 years that is controlled with Metformin and insulin therapy  and hypertension for around ten years under management with Losartan. He had an ischemic stroke five years ago with satisfactory recovery and maintains a regimen of aspirin and statins. Routine blood work in the past has remained within normal limits. Recent review of systems was positive for dyspnea on exertion and weight loss  which was attributed to an aging process by his primary care physician. Though the patient reported occasional swollen and tender joints on his hands and feet  no diagnosed inflammatory or rheumatic diseases were found in his medical records.   Presenting complaints: The patient came to the emergency room with complaints of shortness of breath and increasing fatigue over the past two weeks. The symptoms were worsening progressively  and he started noticing swelling in both lower limbs  high-grade intermittent fever  and unintentional weight loss. There were no complaints of cough  chest pain  orthopnea  or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea.  Diagnostic assessment: His clinical and lab reports suggested congestive heart failure and were suspected for infective endocarditis. His peripheral white blood cell count was significantly high  demonstrating left shift. Blood cultures were positive for Streptococcus species. Transthoracic echocardiography showed an echogenic mass on the aortic valve  indicating vegetations  with valve regurgitation and mild left ventricular dysfunction. Findings were consistent with native-valve infective endocarditis.  Treatment: The patient was hospitalized immediately  and an appropriate antibiotics regimen was started based on the sensitivity tests of the blood cultures. The patient was treated with Ceftriaxone and Gentamycin. The patient's heart condition showed improvement and plans for valve replacement were deferred.  Outcome: Post-hospital stay  the patient responded well to the given antibiotics. His inflammatory markers improved  and heart failure symptoms resolved significantly after a two-month protocol as an outpatient.  In conclusion  this case enlightens the importance of considering infective endocarditis in older adults presenting with symptoms of heart failure  especially in those with pre-existing heart conditions. Regular follow-ups and meticulous care are necessitated in such patients to prevent the recurrence and complications of the condition.

Title: The Role of Early Diagnosis in Improving Future Prognosis of Native-valve Infective Endocarditis: A Case Report  Introduction: Infective endocarditis (IE) is a serious infective disease of the endocardium. If left untreated  it can lead to severe complications and may even be fatal. The severity of IE requires healthcare providers to be extremely vigilant and familiar with its possible symptoms.  Demographic Information: The patient is a 64-year-old Caucasian female  called J.P.  a retired secretary  living in the Midwest of the United States with her husband  referred to our hospital on Mar 2  2020. She has been habitual of smoking since she was a teenager but quit about five years ago. She has no history of alcohol or substance abuse.   Past Medical History: The patient has a previous diagnosis of hypertension (since the age of 48) and type 2 diabetes mellitus (since the age of 57). These conditions are being managed with the use of metoprolol and metformin  respectively  from the past seven years. She has an intact familial history with no specific hereditary diseases reported. J.P. also underwent menopause at the age of 50. She has no allergy towards antibiotics or other medications.  Presenting Complaint and Diagnosis: The patient reported a three-week history of progressive fatigue  mild fever  and a recent loss of appetite. Physical exam revealed a heart murmur and splinter haemorrhages under the nails. Blood cultures were taken  which ruled out sepsis but grew Streptococcus viridans. Echocardiography showed vegetations on the mitral valve  highly suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis.   Hospital Course: The patient was admitted to the hospital and immediately initiated on intravenous ceftriaxone and gentamicin therapy for the aggressive management of IE. J.P. responded optimistically to the treatment by displaying signs of improvement such as reduced fatigue and the gradual return of a healthy appetite seven days after the initial administration.  Discussion: Native-valve endocarditis mostly inflicts elderly people with pre-existing cardiac conditions. This case illustrates the necessity of suspicion  prompt diagnosis  and appropriate treatment of IE  especially in patients with existing cardiovascular diseases.  Moreover  this case implicates the need for patient education on the importance of routine health check-ups to ensure early detection of any potential health issues and create a better prognosis for complications of chronic conditions.  Conclusion: This case report serves as a reminder of an increasingly recognized causative organism of native-valve endocarditis – Streptococcus viridans. It emphasizes the need for active health assessment in the elderly population  particularly those with cardiovascular disease comorbidity  to allow the early diagnosis and treatment and prevent severe complications of IE.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Caucasian Male with a History of Intravenous Drug Use  Introduction:  Infective endocarditis (IE) is a significant pathological infection of the endocardial surface of the heart. Among those at risk are individuals with pre-existing heart disease  or those who engage in high-risk behaviors such as intravenous drug use. This case report explores an episode of native-valve IE in a middle-aged  Caucasian male with a documented history of opioid addiction.  Case Presentation:  A 54-year-old Caucasian male was admitted to the emergency department presenting with fever  malaise  night sweats  and a newly developed murmur. Over a period of two weeks prior to admission  he had noticed increasing fatigue  weight loss  and intermittent fever. He had a history of heroin addiction and reported recent intravenous drug use. His past medical history was otherwise non-contributory  with no prior episodes of IE  other cardiac anomalies  diabetes  nor immunodeficiency. His family history revealed no instances of cardiac disease or conditions predisposing to IE.  On examination  the patient was febrile (38.7 degrees Celsius) with a heart rate of 86 beats per minute. A new-onset grade 3/6 diastolic murmur was noted on auscultation. Osler's nodes and Janeway lesions were absent. The initial blood analysis revealed elevated inflammation markers; C-reactive protein levels were at 90 mg/L and the erythrocyte sedimentation rate was elevated at 48 mm/hour. Other significant findings included a white blood cell count of 12 000 cells/mm3 (neutrophil predominance) and mildly elevated liver enzymes.  Three sets of blood cultures were drawn over a 24-hour period  all of which grew methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA). Transthoracic echocardiography showed vegetations on the tricuspid valve  suggestive of infective endocarditis. Subsequent transesophageal echocardiography confirmed the diagnosis  showing large (15mm) mobile vegetations on his tricuspid valve  with moderate regurgitation but no abscess or signs of perforation.  The patient was diagnosed with native-valve IE due to MSSA  likely secondary to his intravenous drug use. He was started on intravenous nafcillin and gentamicin according to Infectious Diseases Society of America guidelines for MSSA endocarditis. Due to the size of his tricuspid valve vegetations and moderate regurgitation  the case was discussed with cardiovascular surgery for possible valve repair or replacement.  Discussion:  This case describes a classic presentation of native-valve infective endocarditis in a patient with a major risk factor– intravenous drug use. Success in treating such cases involves early identification through careful clinical assessment  including a thorough history and physical exam  followed by confirmatory blood cultures and echocardiogram. Prompt initiation of appropriate antibiotic therapy is critical  and surgical intervention is required in certain cases. This case serves as an important reminder for clinicians to consider IE in patients with a history of injection drug use who present with consistent symptoms.

Title: Native Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Hispanic Male  Introduction  Infective endocarditis is a potentially fatal heart infection affecting the endocardial surface of the heart that can have serious systemic implications if not treated timely. This report outlines the case study of a middle-aged Hispanic patient with native-valve and no history of heart disease  infective endocarditis.  Patient Information and Clinical Findings  The patient was a 58-year-old Hispanic male  a resident of San Antonio  Texas. He was brought to the emergency department with a 3-week history of fever  fatigue  weight loss  night sweats  and shortness of breath. Professionally  he worked as a construction worker. He denied any history of intravenous drug use  alcoholism  or connections to people with severe illnesses. His medical history revealed that he was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus about 5 years ago but has been uncontrolled due to non-adherence to medication and irregular follow-ups. He was also found to be smoker with a history of twenty pack-years.  On physical examination  his vital signs were found to be unstable with a blood pressure of 100/60 mmHg  a heart rate of 110 beats per minute  and a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute. He also had a fever of 38.6°C. The oral cavity examination showed poor dental hygiene with several overt carious lesions. Auscultation of his chest revealed a diastolic murmur in the aortic region.  Diagnostic Assessment  Blood cultures taken from the patient turned out positive for Streptococcus viridans. Transthoracic echocardiogram confirmed vegetation on the patient’s native aortic valve  supporting a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Therapeutic Intervention  The patient was initiated on empirical antibiotic therapy with IV vancomycin and ceftriaxone as well as necessary supportive treatment. The fever subsided after the first two days of the antibiotic therapy and the patient reported an improvement in his fatigue and shortness of breath.  Follow-Up and Outcomes  After a 6-week course of tailored antibiotic therapy  follow-up blood tests showed no evidence of bacteremia  and a repeat echocardiogram showed a marked reduction in the size of the aortic valve vegetation. The patient was discharged with instructions to complete a two week course of oral amoxicillin-clavulanate. As part of the regular follow-up  his diabetic status was also reassessed and is being managed for better outcomes.  Patient Perspective  The patient confessed he had neglected his own health due to work pressures  and the diagnosis was a wake-up call to prioritize his wellbeing. He pledged commitment to regular medical check-ups and an improved lifestyle.  Learning Points  This case highlights the importance of comprehensive medical history and examination in diagnosis  particularly with respect to conditions like infective endocarditis that may not initially present with typical symptoms. It also underscores the need for regular health checks in patients with conditions like diabetes  which can make them more susceptible to infections. It serves to remind us that comprehensive dental care is an integral part of overall health and well-being.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Male: A Case Report  Introduction:  Infective Endocarditis (IE) is a severe infection of the heart valves or endocardium that develops due to bacteria or fungi's colonization. While IE is most common in individuals with pre-existing heart conditions  it can also occur in individuals with native  or unmodified  valves. This case report describes an elderly male with native-valve IE.  Case Description:  Patient Information: The patient is a 76-year-old Caucasian male who presented to a tertiary hospital in Washington D.C. with complaints of persistent high-grade fever for ten days accompanied by fatigue and unintentional weight loss of around 5 kg over the last month. The patient's history revealed he is retired  living with his wife  and had a previous smoking habit.  Medical History: Medical history revealed the patient is a known case of hypertension  controlled with medication for eight years. He had angina two years ago  managed conservatively. He had no previously documented valve abnormalities. He has no history of intravenous drug use  recent hospitalization  or invasive procedures. His surgical history includes appendectomy during his early twenties.  Clinical Findings: On presentation  the patient was febrile (101.3 degrees Fahrenheit)  tachycardic with a heart rate of 120 beats per minute  and blood pressure was controlled (130/85 mmHg). Cardiac examination revealed a new murmur on the mitral area. Splinter hemorrhages were found on fingernail examination  and Janeway lesions were noticed on his palms. His Chest X-ray was unremarkable. ECG showed signs of sinus tachycardia.  Laboratory Examination: A complete blood count showed mild anemia with a hemoglobin level of 11.2 g/dL with an elevated ESR (Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate) and CRP (C Reactive Protein). Repeated blood cultures grew Streptococcus viridians.   Diagnostic Tests: Transthoracic echocardiogram revealed vegetation on the mitral valve with moderate regurgitation. Transesophageal echocardiogram confirmed the findings.  Treatment: The patient was started on empiric antibiotics which was tailored based on the blood culture sensitivity. After discussing risks and benefits  the cardiology team decided to manage the patient medically with close monitoring.  Outcome: The patient responded well to the treatment; his fever subsided  the cardiac murmur diminished  and repeat blood cultures were sterile.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the classic features of native-valve IE in an elderly patient without a history of intravenous drug use or invasive procedures. Early recognition  diagnosis  and prompt aggressiveness of therapy are vital to prevent complications in the future. Although surgical intervention remains the mainstay treatment for valve dysfunction in IE  a conservative approach can also be successful  as demonstrated in this case.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 62-year old Male Patient  Patient Information: The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian man named Mr. Doe who is a non-smoker and non-alcoholic. He is a retiree living in a suburban neighborhood of New York City. He is married with two adult children and lives with his wife. His records show that he has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. There is no history of drug abuse or contact with animals. He denies recent travel  dental procedures or surgeries.  Clinical Findings: Mr. Doe presented to the emergency department with complaints of productive cough  fever  chills  night sweats  and unintended weight loss over the last 8 weeks. He also reported increasing fatigue and exertional dyspnea. There were no gastrointestinal or genitourinary symptoms  no changes in mental status such as confusion or loss of consciousness. Upon examination  Mr. Doe was found to have a low-grade fever (38.1°C) with an irregular heartbeat.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment: His complete blood count revealed mild anemia (Hb: 11.5 g/dl) and an elevated total leukocyte count of 13000 cells/cumm with a predominance of neutrophils. The ESR and CRP were raised confirming the presence of inflammation. Additionally  renal and liver function tests were within normal ranges. Blood culture tests grew Streptococcus viridans  suggesting bacteremia. Urine analysis was normal  with no signs of urinary tract infection.  A cardiac echocardiogram showed an oscillating intracardiac mass on the mitral valve  confirming suspicions of infective endocarditis. Choestrol crystals were absent  thus ruling out Libman-Sacks endocarditis. Mr. Doe’s prior history of cardiac health was unremarkable  making this a case of primary or native-valve infective endocarditis.  Therapeutic Intervention: Mr. Doe was immediately started on intravenous antibiotic therapy with a combination of Penicillin G and Gentamicin for a period of four weeks  as per the American Heart Association's guideline for the management of native valve infective endocarditis. He was continually monitored for improvements in clinical symptoms and laboratory findings with regular follow-ups.  Follow Up and Outcomes: The initial response to treatment was good; after two weeks of therapy  Mr. Doe reported a decrease in fever and fatigue  and his cough started to abate. A repeat echocardiogram at the end of the therapy course showed a significant reduction in the size of the vegetation on his mitral valve  and the patient was discharged from the hospital with instructions for at-home oral antibiotic therapy and regular follow-ups.  Patient Perspective: Mr. Doe was initially anxious but cooperated well with the treatment procedure. After initial signs of recovery  he felt relieved and was compliant with the post-discharge guidelines.   Informed Consent: The patient gave his informed consent for the case report to be published.  This case highlights the importance of considering the diagnosis of native valve endocarditis in elderly patients presenting with unexplained constitutional symptoms  even in the absence of known valvular heart disease or recent invasive procedures.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Male: A Case Report  Demographic Data: The patient is a 54-year-old Caucasian male of medium build with weight within the normal range for his height. The individual is a non-smoker  drinks alcohol occasionally and does not use illicit substances. He resides in an urban area in the North-Eastern region of the United States and is gainfully employed in the construction industry. The patient is well educated  completing up until high school and understands the English language proficiently. He lives with his wife  who is his main caregiver during illness.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of diabetes mellitus type 2  which was diagnosed six years ago. He also has hypertension and a pre-existence of mild mitral valve prolapse diagnosed during the investigation of palpitations. The diseases are well managed with Metformin  Lisinopril  and lifestyle modifications. The individual also has a history of two separate incidents of pneumonia three and five years ago  respectively  both adequately resolved with antibiotics. He does not have any known allergies. His family history is significant for coronary artery disease and type 2 diabetes.  Case Presentation: The patient presented with a two-week history of fatigue  loss of appetite  and intermittent fever. He also reported recent unexplained weight loss and night sweats. Physical examination revealed a paler-than-normal complexion and the presence of murmur upon cardiac auscultation.  Over the course of hospital stay  the patient developed new cardiac murmurs and showed signs of heart failure  including shortness of breath  edema  and fatigue. Additional diagnostic tests revealed anemia and elevated inflammatory markers in blood  further pointing toward an infectious process.  Blood cultures were positive for Streptococcus viridans. An echocardiogram displayed a vegetation on the patient's mitral valve  confirming the diagnosis of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis (NVIE).  Management and Outcome: The patient received intravenous antibiotics as per Infective Endocarditis guidelines for a total of six weeks. He also underwent an overall cardiovascular function evaluation to assess the damage to the heart by the condition. His condition improved markedly during the treatment course.  The patient was also advised and educated upon discharge about the need for future dental prophylaxis and the mitigation of further episodes of infective endocarditis.  Conclusion: NVIE is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate evaluation and treatment. Despite a history of mild mitral valve prolapse  the patient's active lifestyle and good adherence to his medical regime allowed him to recover satisfactorily from NVIE. This case highlights the need for awareness and medical vigilance in managing unexpected presentations in high-risk patients.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-aged Woman  I. Patient Information   The patient is a 56-year-old Caucasian female  a non-smoker  and moderate drinker from a suburban setting in the United States. She works as an accountant and lives with her husband and three pets; two cats and a dog.  II. Chief Complaint  Patient presented to the Emergency Department with symptoms of high-grade fever  chills  fatigue  and joint pain persisting for the past 3 weeks. She also reported loss of appetite and unintended weight loss.  III. Past Medical History   The patient has a history of Rheumatoid Arthritis  for which she has been on Methotrexate and Sulphasalazine for the past two years. She also mentions having livedo reticularis since her early twenties but has not sought any specific treatment for it. Apart from these  her past medical history was unremarkable.   IV. History of Present Illness  The patient first noticed low-grade fever 3 weeks prior which gradually progressed to high-grade along with fatigue and chills. She also began experiencing joint pain  primarily in her knees  around the same time. It was initially an episodic occurrence which later became persistent. In addition  she has also noticed a loss of appetite and marked unintended weight loss. Her symptoms did not improve with general symptomatic treatments at home.  V. Physical Examination  On physical examination  she appeared acutely ill  in moderate distress. Vitals were stable except for a fever of 100.9°F. Skin examination revealed livedo reticularis primarily located on the lower limbs. Cardiovascular examination revealed a diastolic murmur upon auscultation  and signs of peripheral embolizations were present including Janeway lesions on her palms and soles and splinter hemorrhages under several nails.  VI. Diagnostic Assessment  Based on the clinical presentation  the infectious disease workup was initiated considering the differential diagnoses. Two sets of blood cultures which were collected 12 hours apart grew Gram-positive cocci that were identified as Streptococcus oralis & mitis group. Echocardiogram demonstrated a single  large  oscillating mass attached to the anterior mitral leaflet with moderate mitral regurgitation  suggestive of infective endocarditis.    VII. Therapeutic Intervention   IV Penicillin G and Gentamicin were initiated immediately for antibiotic treatment as per the sensitivity results and Infective Endocarditis guidelines. The patient responded positively to the treatment with resolution of fever and improvement of general health status withdrawn 14 days after.  VIII. Follow Up and Outcome  On discharge  the patient was advised to follow a course of oral antibiotics and return for regular follow-up evaluations. She was strictly advised to maintain oral hygiene and to immediately report any symptoms suggestive of infective endocarditis.  IX. Conclusion  This patient's case is an example of native-valve infective endocarditis  emphasizing the importance of timely identification of the condition and the need for urgent antibiotic therapy to prevent severe complications. A vigilance for infective endocarditis should be maintained  particularly in patients with nonspecific symptoms and identified causative organisms that are part of normal flora.

Title: A Serious Case of Native Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Male  Introduction: Infective endocarditis (IE) is a rare but severe infection of the endocardium that can induce high morbidity and mortality if not promptly treated. Although literature and demographics may vary  IE is more prevalent in males  with the incidence increasing with age. This case report discusses the clinical presentation  diagnosis  and treatment of an adult male patient with native valve endocarditis.  Case Description: The patient is a 52-year-old Caucasian male  John Doe  from an urban setting in Atlanta  Georgia  USA. John Doe is a known smoker  but has no known illicit drug use. He is overweight with BMI 28. He has a past medical and surgical history significant for hypertension and gastric bypass surgery over eight years ago. He has been on antihypertensive medication for the past five years.   Clinical Findings: The patient presented to the emergency department (ED) with a complaint of intermittent high-grade fever for the past two weeks  associated with chills  night sweats  and unintentional weight loss. Physical examination revealed oral temperature 102.3°F  pulse 102 beats per minute  blood pressure 136/88 mmHg. Cardiac examination showed a diastolic murmur heard loudest in the left mid-sternal border. No other significant positive findings were observed.  Diagnostic Assessment: Blood samples were taken for complete blood count  coagulation profile  renal and liver function tests  and blood cultures. Laboratory results show anemia  elevated C-reactive protein  and erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Blood cultures grew Streptococcus oralis. Transthoracic echocardiogram demonstrated a 1.5 cm diameter mobile vegetation on the mitral valve with severe regurgitation.  Therapeutic Intervention: Following the diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis  the patient was started on appropriate antibiotics according to sensitivity (IV Penicillin G and Gentamicin). However due to the advanced valve damage  patient was referred to cardiothoracic surgery for valve replacement. The post-operative course was uneventful and the patient's general condition improved significantly.  Follow-up: Peripheral intravenous line was placed for continuation of IV antibiotics for six weeks. The patient is scheduled for close follow-up and outpatient physical rehabilitation to optimize recovery.   Conclusion:  This case report signifies the critical importance of early diagnosis and timely surgical intervention in native valve infective endocarditis to prevent severe complications.

Title: Diagnosis and Management of Native Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 65-year-old Hispanic Male  Patient Information: A 65-year-old Hispanic male  a former machine operator with a history of smoking and uncontrolled diabetes mellitus II  was brought to the hospital's Emergency Department (ED). His family reported a 2-week history of low-grade fever  fatigue  shortness of breath  weakness  and weight loss of approximately 10 lbs. The patient denied any alcohol or drug misuse.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  the patient was febrile (38.7°C)  blood pressure was 120/80 mm Hg  pulse rate was 95/min  respiration rate was 22/min  and oxygen saturation was 94% on room air. He was noted to have splinter hemorrhages in the nail beds  Osler's nodes in his hands  conjunctival pallor  and mild pedal edema. Heart sounds were normal with a noticeable systolic murmur.  Diagnostic Assessment: Further laboratory investigations revealed hemoglobin 11.5g/dL  white blood cell count 12 300/cu mm  platelets 220 000/cu mm  fasting blood sugar 180 mg/dL  HbA1c 8.7%. Blood cultures were taken and patient underwent Transthoracic Echocardiogram (TTE)  which showed a vegetation on the mitral valve  suggestive of Infective Endocarditis (IE).   Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was started on empiric antibiotic therapy with vancomycin and ceftriaxone  while awaiting blood culture results  which subsequently demonstrated Streptococcus oralis. In view of the heavy burden of vegetation  cardiothoracic surgery advice was sourced and the decision was made to monitor the patient conservatively under double antibiotic therapy.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: The patient made good progress for the initial 5 days; however  on the 6th day of being in the hospital  he developed an acute stroke with right-sided weakness. An urgent CT brain showed left middle cerebral artery territory infarction. The patient was managed conservatively as per stroke protocol since the window for thrombolysis had passed. After stabilization of his neurological condition  the treatment plan was reviewed  and in view of further embolic risk  it was decided to proceed for mitral valve surgery.  Patient Perspective: The patient agreed to undergo surgery and post-surgery significantly improved. His neuromotor functions improved and he was transferred to rehabilitation following discharge from hospital. The patient and his family were relieved and optimistic after the intervention.  Conclusion: This case highlights that early detection and management of Native Valve Infective Endocarditis (IE) is crucial. While antibiotic therapy forms the cornerstone of therapy  certain clinical situations may mandate surgical intervention as seen in this case. This case further underlines the significance of comprehensive care and close monitoring in patients with IE to prevent and appropriately manage potential complications such as systemic embolization.

Title: A Case Report on Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an 60 Year Old Male Patient  I. Introduction  Native-valve infective endocarditis (NVIE) is a critical cardiovascular disease characterized by infection and inflammation of the inner membrane that lines the heart chambers and the heart valves. Despite advancements in diagnostic imaging  surgical interventions  and antibiotic treatment  NVIE remains a significant health concern with high morbidity and mortality rates.  II. Patient Information   The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male  residing in a rural area of Alabama  USA. He works as a craftsman. He is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol. The patient has no known drug allergies.  III. Chief Complaint  The patient presented with symptoms of fever  malaise  and undocumented weight loss over a period of two months.  IV. Past Medical History   The patient had a medical history of type 2 diabetes for five years  controlled with metformin. There were no previous cardiovascular diseases  surgeries  or hospitalizations. He has a known history of occasional recreational drug use (opioids) during his early life (30 years before)  but had not done so recently  as per his report. Immunizations were up to date  and there was no history of recent dental procedures.  V. Clinical Findings   On physical examination  the patient appeared acutely ill with a fever of 38.5°C. He had pale conjunctiva and a few scattered petechiae on the lower extremities. Cardiac examination revealed a diastolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border.  VI. Diagnostic Assessment   Blood culture samples revealed the growth of Streptococcus viridans  a common bacterium responsible for NVIE. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) was conducted which revealed the presence of valvular vegetations  confirming the diagnosis.   VII. Therapeutic Intervention   The patient was immediately initiated on intravenous antibiotics therapy  specifically a 6-week course of Penicillin G and Gentamicin. Due to valvular defects identified on the TTE  the patient was referred for valve repair surgery.  VIII. Follow-up and Outcomes   The patient responded well to the antibiotics therapy as evidenced by defervescence of fever within a week and clearance of bacteremia within two weeks. Post-surgical recovery was also uneventful.  IX. Takeaway lessons   This case highlights the importance of having a high index of suspicion for NVIE in older patients with unexplained fevers especially with a history of mild recreational drug use. The diagnosis can be challenging due to nonspecific clinical presentations and requires prompt initiation of antibiotic therapy to decrease morbidity and mortality.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Male Patient with a Past History of Intravenous Drug Use  Introduction:  This case report outlines the diagnosis  management  and treatment of a 44-year-old Caucasian male suffering from native-valve infective endocarditis. The patient presented high fever  general illness feeling  and a history of illicit intravenous drug use.  Patient Information:  The patient is a 44-year-old Caucasian male who presented at the emergency department with a general feeling of being unwell  pervasive weakness  and high fever of 1-week duration. He reported chest discomfort radiating to his shoulder. The patient's past medical history includes chronic Hepatitis C infection which he contracted through intravenous drug use  a habit he claimed to have stopped approximately three years ago. The patient is unemployed and homeless  with sporadic medical follow-ups. He has a history of tobacco smoking and moderate alcohol consumption.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination revealed pale skin  low-grade fever (38.2°C)  with heart rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and blood pressure of 92/68 mmHg. Cardiac examination detected a new grade III/VI diastolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. The patient had splinter hemorrhages under the nails  and Osler's nodes were present on his fingertips  suggesting possible endocarditis. No signs of heart failure were noted. His lungs were clear to auscultation  and there was no evidence of any hepatic or splenic enlargement.  Diagnostic Assessment:  The differentials included infectious endocarditis  acute coronary syndrome  and pneumonia. Lab tests revealed leucocytosis and raised C-reactive protein (CRP). Three separate sets of blood cultures were taken  all of which came back positive for Staphylococcus aureus. The diagnosis of Staphylococcus native-valve infective endocarditis was confirmed through Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) showing large vegetation on the tricuspid valve. The patient tested negative for HIV.  Therapy:  The patient was started on empiric therapy with intravenous vancomycin and gentamicin. Following susceptibility testing  the patient was switched to flucloxacillin. He remained afebrile with improvement in his murmur and general health. Cardiac surgery was not performed due to the significant reduction of the vegetation size and the patient's clinical recovery with medical therapy.  Outcome:  After six weeks of treatment  the patient was discharged in stable condition with outpatient cardiology and infectious disease follow-ups planned.  Conclusion:  This case underscores the importance of recognizing infective endocarditis in patients with a history of intravenous drug use. Early diagnosis and aggressive antibiotic therapy are crucial for favorable outcomes. These individuals require thorough assessment considering their potential risk factors and need for extensive social support to ensure continuity of care.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in A Middle-aged Caucasian Male  I. Patient Information The patient is a 56-year-old Caucasian male from a rural Midwestern community in the USA.  II. Clinical Findings Upon presentation  the patient complained of intermittent fever  fatigue  weight loss  and night sweats  occurring for the past three weeks. The patient also noted a new-onset shortness of breath that had been worsening over the past five days.  III. Medical History The patient has a history of moderate alcohol use and tobacco smoking  both of which have persisted for around 30 years but has not been diagnosed with any chronic illnesses before this presentation. He has no known allergies to medications and does not have a family history of cardiac disease. He lives alone and is employed as a farmer. His regular medications include occasional ibuprofen for joint pain. He denied illicit drug use and has no history of dental procedures or surgeries in the past year.  IV. Physical Examination Initial assessment revealed a malnourished man appearing his stated age. Vital signs showed fever with a temperature of 38.5 degrees Celsius  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  respiration rate of 20 breaths per minute  and blood pressure of 129/76 mm Hg. Cardiac auscultation detected a new murmur in the mitral region which was not previously documented.  V. Diagnostic assessment Initial routine laboratory testing revealed mild anemia (Hb 11 g/dL)  elevated inflammatory markers (C-Reactive Protein 54 mg/L  Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate 68 mm/hr) as well as findings indicative of impaired renal function (elevated Blood Urea Nitrogen and Creatinine). Chest X-ray showed unilateral basal lung infiltration. Subsequent blood culture samples grew Streptococcus viridans. Transthoracic echocardiography confirmed the presence of large oscillating vegetation on the mitral valve with moderate mitral regurgitation  indicative of infective endocarditis.  VI. Therapeutic intervention The patient was started on intravenous Ceftriaxone and Gentamicin  consistent with American Heart Association guidelines for Streptococcus viridans endocarditis. Despite aggressive antibiotic therapy  the patient’s condition continued to deteriorate with persistent fever  and acute renal failure. After discussing the risks and benefits with the patient and his family  the decision was made to proceed with urgent mitral valve replacement surgery.  VII. Follow-up and outcome Postoperatively  the patient's fever resolved and his renal function gradually returned to normal levels. He completed a six week course of antibiotic therapy. At the six month follow up visit  the patient expressed good health with no residual symptoms.   VIII. Patient Perspective The patient expressed gratitude for the treatment he received and mentioned now having a renewed perspective on life with a determination to improve his lifestyle habits.  IX. Informed Consent Informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.   This case illustrates the potential severity of native-valve endocarditis  its presenting symptoms and highlights the importance of early detection and the appropriate course of treatment.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis: A Case Report in an Elderly Male Patient   Patient Information: A 75-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department with an 8-day history of on-and-off fever  loss of appetite  and progressive fatigue.  Presenting Complaints: The patient complained of a sudden onset of high-grade fever that intermittently relapsed and remitted  accompanied by loss of appetite  significant weight loss over the week  and progressive fatigue making him bed-bound.
