Medical History: The patient had a significant past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus which he managed with Lisinopril and Metformin  respectively. Additionally  he was also being treated for benign prostate hyperplasia with Dutasteride. He had quit smoking 10 years ago and reported moderate alcohol consumption. There was no previous history of heart disease  intravenous drug use  dental procedures  or any significant travel history.  Clinical Findings: On initial physical examination  the patient appeared in acute distress  pale  and sweaty. Vital signs indicated tachycardia (105 beats per minute) and fever (38.9 degrees Celsius). Cardiac auscultation revealed a new regurgitant murmur. Routine blood examination demonstrated an elevated white blood cell count (16 x 109 per liter) and C-reactive protein (160mg/L). No physical signs of peripheral embolization or Janeway lesions were noticed on a skin examination.  Diagnosis: The clinical features and the new cardiac murmur directed towards a possible diagnosis of infective endocarditis. Further  blood cultures were performed which returned positive for Streptococcus viridans. Transthoracic echocardiography showed a vegetation on the aortic valve  supporting the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Treatment: The patient was immediately started with intravenous Penicillin G and Gentamicin  as per the standard therapeutic regimen for Streptococcus viridans causing endocarditis. His fever subsided over the next week  and there was a remarkable clinical improvement.  Follow-up  and Outcomes: The patient was continued on the treatment for six weeks  monitored closely for any adverse developments. Repeated blood cultures were drawn at regular intervals which returned negative after two weeks of treatment. A follow-up echocardiogram after six weeks showed a significant reduction in vegetation size. The patient subsequently improved clinically  demonstrating weight gain and a return to daily activities.  Disclaimer: This case was achieved in compliance with the hospital’s ethics and privacy policies  and the patient gave written informed consent to publish his health information.  KEYWORDS: Native-valve endocarditis  Elderly  Streptococcus viridans  Case report.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Female Patient: A Case Report  Introduction:  Infective endocarditis (IE) is an infection of the inner surface of the heart  most frequently the heart valves  caused by bacteria or fungi. Native-valve infective endocarditis occurs in normal  natural heart valves  with Staphylococcus and Streptococcus species being the most common pathogens. This report describes a case of native-valve infective endocarditis in an elderly female patient  which highlights the need for early diagnosis and management.  Case Presentation:  Patient Information:   A 73-year-old Caucasian woman presented to the hospital with a 3-week history of intermittent fever  fatigue  and loss of appetite. She also reported a recent history of unintentional weight loss. She lives independently and has a 50-year history of tobacco use  though she quit smoking ten years ago.  Medical History:   The patient has a known medical history of hypertension and atrial fibrillation  which she has managed with oral anticoagulation (Warfarin) and an Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme inhibitor (Lisinopril). Additionally  she was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia five years prior  and she has been managing it with a statin (Atorvastatin). She has no known allergies.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination revealed a low-grade fever (100.4°F)  and regular heart rate and rhythm with a grade II/VI systolic murmur heard best at the apex. No peripheral stigmata of endocarditis like Osler's nodes  Janeway's lesions  Roth's spots or splinter hemorrhages in the nail beds were observed. The lungs were clear to auscultation bilaterally.  Diagnostic Assessment:  The patient’s blood cultures grew Streptococcus viridans. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) showed a mobile 10mm x 5mm mass on the atrial surface of mitral valve  consistent with a vegetation. The chest X-ray did not show any signs of pulmonary infection or congestive heart failure.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was started on intravenous Penicillin G for 4 weeks combined with Gentamicin for the first two weeks. Anticoagulation was temporarily held due to the risk of intracerebral hemorrhage given the large vegetation.  Follow-Up:  At the one month follow-up  she reported feeling significantly better with resolution of fever and no further weight loss. A repeat TTE showed a significant reduction in vegetation size to 3mm x 2mm without evidence of valvular insufficiency. She was instructed to continue follow-ups every 3 months to monitor her condition.  Discussion:  This case underscores the importance of maintaining a high index of suspicion for infective endocarditis in elderly patients presenting with non-specific symptoms like fever and weight loss  especially with the presence of predisposing factors like atrial fibrillation and a history of heart valve disease.  Conclusion:  Early diagnosis and appropriate management of native-valve infective endocarditis is crucial in preventing complications like stroke  heart failure  or systemic embolisms  especially in elderly patients who are often more susceptible to such complications.

Title: Native Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Caucasian Male with a History of Intravenous Drug Use: A Case Report  Background: Native valve infective endocarditis (IE) is a severe infection of the endocardial surface of the heart  typically affecting individuals with pre-existing heart disorders or those with a history of intravenous drug use. Despite both surgical and medical improvements  IE continues to have high morbidity and mortality rates.  Case Presentation: A 68-year-old Caucasian male was admitted to the hospital with a two-week history of unexplained fever  malaise  and weight loss. He had a past medical history significant for chronic hepatitis C infection secondary to intravenous drug use  which he quit over 30 years ago. At that time  he had a workup done which suggested mildly regurgitant mitral and tricuspid valves but no definitive diagnosis was made.  On physical examination  the patient appeared lethargic and feverish with a temperature of 38.5°C. Auscultation revealed a new grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex. Upon careful inspection  Janeway lesions on the palmar surfaces of the hands were noted  along with Osler’s nodes on the finger pads. Given his symptoms  signs  and history  there was a high suspicion for infective endocarditis.  Initial lab work revealed leukocytosis and elevated C-reactive protein level. Three blood cultures  taken 12 hours apart  grew Streptococcus viridans. Transesophageal echocardiogram showed a large vegetation on the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve  consistent with the diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis.  The patient was started on IV antibiotics as per local guidelines  including ampicillin and gentamicin. Despite initial mild improvement in his symptoms  he eventually developed acute heart failure secondary to worsening mitral regurgitation. Cardiac surgery consultants agreed upon mitral valve repair as the most suitable intervention.  The patient underwent successful mitral valve repair and continued on intravenous antibiotics for a total of 6 weeks. He was discharged on lifelong prophylactic oral antibiotics due to his risk factors. At the 3-month and 6-month follow-up  the patient was asymptomatic with a well-functioning mitral valve on echocardiogram. He was counseled extensively on the risks of recurrent IE and was enrolled in a substance misuse programme as a precaution.  Conclusion: This case highlights the intricacies of diagnosing and managing infective endocarditis in patients with a history of intravenous drug misuse. The association between IE and intravenous drug use is well-documented  though it must be noted that this patient's history of misuse was over 30 years in the past. Medical providers must maintain a high index of suspicion for endocarditis in patients with 'distant' drug misuse history especially when presenting with nondescript symptoms such as fever  malaise  and weight loss. Prompt diagnosis and swift initiation of antibiotics can improve morbidity and mortality significantly. It also underscores the importance of continued preventive measures in such a high-risk population.

Case Report Title: Treatment and Management of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Patient  Patient Information:  Mr. A  an 80-year-old Caucasian male  currently living in an urban community in Philadelphia  Pennsylvania. He was diagnosed with hypertension in his early forties and has been on regular medication. His social history reveals he is a retired bank employee and lives with his wife. He stopped smoking two decades ago and is a non-alcoholic. His family medical history includes death of his father from a stroke at an age of 75 and his 83-year-old mother is living with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.  Chief Complaint: Mr. A presented to the emergency department with a 3-week history of fatigue  intermittent fevers  chills  and unintentional weight loss. His medical charts indicate he also reported experiencing a loss of appetite and night sweats.  Clinical Findings: On examination  Mr. A appeared fatigued. He had a temperature of 38.5°C  a heart rate of 105 bpm  a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  and blood pressure of 140/85 mmHg. Cardiac examination revealed a diastolic murmur. No other significant abnormalities were found during the rest of the physical examination.  Diagnostic Assessment: Blood cultures were taken and revealed growth of Streptococcus viridans  which confirmed the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. An echocardiogram was also performed demonstrating vegetations on the mitral valve. There was no evidence of valve destruction or severe regurgitation that would necessitate surgical intervention.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was started on a 4-week course of penicillin. Given his age and current clinical status  the healthcare team decided to treat him aggressively with antibacterials and closely monitor his clinical and laboratory responses  in order to avoid possible progress to heart failure or other complications.  Follow-up and Outcomes: Following 2 weeks of treatment  the patient showed considerable improvement in symptoms and repeated blood cultures remained negative. By the end of his 4-week course  he was asymptomatic and returned to his baseline functional status. Further follow-up is still necessary for Mr. A to ensure a successful resolution of the infective endocarditis and to monitor for any possible future complications.  Conclusion: This case affirms the importance of early detection and intervention in the management of native-valve infective endocarditis  particularly in elderly patients. The patient's timely presentation  diagnosis  and management potentially prevented serious complications such as congestive heart failure  valve destruction  or other systemic or neurological manifestations.

Title: A Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Male Patient   Case Report:  Patient Information: The patient was a 75-year-old Caucasian male  to represent the demographic group this disease is often seen in literature. He is a retired engineer  non-smoker  and a moderate alcohol consumer. Residing in suburban New England  he lives with his wife and owns pets  including cats and dogs.  Chief complaint: The patient presented in the emergency department complaining of ongoing fatigue  intermittent fevers  chills  weight loss  and a recent onset of difficulty breathing.  Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes which had brought him to the clinic for regular checkups. He has good compliance with his antihypertensive (Lisinopril) and anti-diabetic (Metformin) medications. He had no known allergies. His family history revealed that his father had coronary artery disease. He had an appendectomy at the age of 30  but no other surgical history. Recent dental procedures and pet scratches were reported. No drug abuse was identified.  Clinical findings: His vitals demonstrated a fever of 100.8°F  mildly elevated blood pressure and rapid heart rate. Physical examination revealed pallor  a heart murmur and splinter hemorrhages under his fingernails. There were no osler nodes or Janeway lesions seen. His weight was recorded as 72 kg  demonstrating a weight loss of 10 kg over the past two months.   Diagnostic assessment: Labs revealed an elevated white blood cell count  ESR  and CRP. Blood cultures were drawn which grew Streptococcus viridans. An ECG showed no evidence of heart block. Echocardiography confirmed vegetation on the aortic valve with evidence of moderate aortic regurgitation  establishing the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.   Therapeutic intervention: After consultation with a cardiologist and infectious disease specialist  the patient was started on intravenous Penicillin G and Gentamicin. He was admitted to the hospital where he was closely monitored.   Follow-up and outcomes: Over the course of his 6 week hospitalization  the patient responded well to the intervention. Repeat blood cultures were negative  indicating successful treatment. However  due to the persistent aortic regurgitation  cardiothoracic surgery was consulted and the patient underwent a successful surgical valve replacement. Upon follow up after 3 months  the patient had returned to his baseline weight  was back to his daily routine and the heart murmur was no longer audible.  Patient perspectives: The patient expressed relief for his improved energy level and overall health. He voiced thankfulness for health professionals and satisfaction with his healthcare experiences.   Informed consent: The patient gave informed consent for his case to be published in a medical journal.   This case report has emphasized the importance of maintaining high clinical suspicion for infective endocarditis in patients presenting with non-specific symptoms like fatigue  weight loss  and fever especially in the presence of a murmur  and having a recent dental procedure or minor pet-inflicted injuries.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Caucasian Female  Introduction: Endocarditis is a rare but potentially life-threatening condition characterized by inflammation of the heart's inner lining or endocardium  often the result of a bacterial  viral  or fungal infection. This report presents the case of a 50-year-old Caucasian female with a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis (NVE).  Patient Information: The patient was a nonsmoking female of 50-years-old  who had a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. She is currently unemployed and lives in a suburban setting in Wisconsin  USA.  Clinical Presentation: The patient was admitted to the emergency department with complaints of intermittent fevers and chills for the past four weeks  associated with night sweats  fatigue  and an unintentional weight loss of approximately 5kg over one month. The patient also reported a history of transient ischemic attack (TIA) about two weeks prior  despite not having any known cerebrovascular disease.  Physical Examination and Diagnostic Assessment: On physical examination  the patient appeared chronically ill and cachectic. She was febrile with a temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°F) and her blood pressure was slightly elevated. Multiple Osler's nodes were observed on the pads of her fingers and toes  and Janeway lesions were present on the palms and soles. A grade III/VI systolic murmur was noted at the left lower sternal border.  Laboratory results revealed a high white blood cell count and elevated C-reactive protein (CRP). Three sets of blood cultures grew Streptococcus mutans. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) demonstrated a 2.5 cm vegetation on the mitral valve with moderate mitral regurgitation. The patient was diagnosed with NVE of the mitral valve secondary to Streptococcus mutans infection.  Therapeutic Interventions and Follow-up: The patient was started on intravenous (IV) Penicillin G and Gentamicin according to guidelines for Streptococci infective endocarditis therapy. She experienced a gradual improvement of her symptoms over the course of two weeks of antibiotic therapy. After six weeks of IV antibiotics  a repeated TTE revealed significant reduction in the size of the vegetation. The patient was advised for regular follow-up visits and was educated about the signs and symptoms of recurrent infective endocarditis.   Conclusion: This case illustrates the importance of early recognition and timely intervention in NVE. The timely diagnosis and prompt treatment ensured successful management of this patient's condition  preventing severe complications such as heart failure and recurrent stroke.   Ethics Approval and Consent to Participate: The patient provided informed consent for her case to be published. This case study adheres to the standards set by the Declaration of Helsinki.

Title: Infective Endocarditis in a Native Valve of an Elderly Male with Chronic Kidney Disease: A Case Report  Introduction:  Infective endocarditis (IE) is a serious infectious disease that affects the endocardium of the heart and can lead to severe complications if not treated promptly. Herein  we report a case of an elderly male with a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD) who was diagnosed with infective endocarditis of a native valve.  Case Presentation:  Demographics: Mr. A  a 75-year-old Caucasian male from an urban community  was admitted to our hospital with complaints of persistent high fever  fatigue  and weight loss which had worsened over the last three weeks.  Past Medical History: The patient had a 10-year history of stage 3 CKD  supposed to have resulted from hypertensive nephrosclerosis. He was on angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and statin therapy. There was no history of illicit drug use  major surgeries  dental procedures  or relevant family illness.  Results/Investigations: Physical examination revealed a temperature of 101 °F. A new murmur was audible in the mitral area. Laboratory tests showed significant leukocytosis  decreased hemoglobin levels  elevated C-reactive protein  and elevated creatinine levels  aligning with his CKD status.  Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) was performed due to the new murmur  persistent fever  and other signs of infection  which showed multiple vegetations on the mitral valve  leading to a preliminary diagnosis of endocarditis. The diagnosis was confirmed by blood cultures which grew Staphylococcus aureus.  Management and Follow-up: After the diagnosis  the patient was immediately started on targeted intravenous antibiotic therapy. Due to the presence of multiple vegetations and the patient's deteriorating condition despite antibiotic therapy  the care team decided that the patient should undergo surgery. He had a successful mitral valve replacement and was continued on antibiotics postoperatively for a total of six weeks.  Discussion:  The present case highlights the importance of considering infective endocarditis in elderly patients having immuno-compromise due to a chronic illness  such as CKD  presenting with unexplained fever and cardiac murmurs. The case also brings attention to the good prognosis following early diagnosis  appropriate antibiotics  and surgical intervention in patients with native-valve infective endocarditis.  Conclusion:  This report underscores the need for high clinical suspicion  early diagnosis  and aggressive management  which can affect the morbidity and mortality associated with infective endocarditis. The clinicians should keep a keen eye for the tell-tale signs of the condition in susceptible patients  such as elderly CKD patients.

Title: A Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 57-Year-Old Caucasian Male  Introduction:  This case report presents a patient diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis (NVIE). We are highlighting this case in light of the risk factors that tend to precipitate the condition  its clinical course  and outcome after treatment. This is to increase awareness about the criticality of early diagnosis and management of NVIE to improve patient outcomes.  Case Presentation:  A 57-year-old Caucasian male patient presented to the emergency department complaining of fatigue  night sweats  and unintentional weight loss over the past four weeks. He also reported a new onset low-grade fever. Further interrogation revealed intermittent migratory arthralgia and a loss of appetite.  The patient has a past medical history significant for type II diabetes mellitus well-controlled on metformin  hypertension managed with amlodipine  and tobacco abuse (30 pack-year history). He has no known allergies.  Physical examination revealed a dentition problem. Cardiac auscultation demonstrated a diastolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border. Additionally  arterial blood pressure was 130/70mmHg  he had a heart rate of 90 bpm  and a slight fever of 37.6 degrees Celsius. He had no physical signs of peripheral stigmata of endocarditis.  Initial laboratory findings indicated a mild elevation in inflammatory markers with a white blood cell count of 11.0 x 10^9/L. Other blood tests were normal  including kidney and liver function tests.  Due to suspicion of infective endocarditis  blood cultures were taken and transthoracic echocardiography was performed. The echocardiogram revealed vegetation on the mitral valve  confirming the diagnosis of NVIE.  Discussions:  Culture reports showed the growth of Streptococcus sanguinis  a viridans group streptococci after 72 hours of incubation. This supported the diagnosis of NVIE due to its strong association with poor dental hygiene in literature. As per the American Heart Association guidelines  the patient was put on a regimen of intravenous crystalline penicillin and gentamicin.  NVIE largely affects males in their late middle age. Having diabetes and hypertension and being a chronic smoker  this patient belonged to a high-risk category. Besides  poor dental hygiene was a significant risk factor that led to the Streptococci sanguinis bacteremia and subsequent NVIE.  Outcome and Follow Up:  With the initiation of antibiotic therapy  the patient's symptoms gradually improved over the subsequent days. He was discharged after four weeks of treatment with close follow-up arranged with Infectious Diseases and Cardiology departments. In subsequent outpatient visits  he demonstrated good recovery and abstinence from smoking. There were stress on the importance of good dental hygiene and regular dental health check-ups to prevent any potential recurrence.   Conclusion:  This case underscores the importance of considering NVIE in patients with new onset non-specific symptoms and identified risk factors. Early detection and prompt treatment of NVIE are critical to minimize the associated high morbidity and mortality.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Male Patient: A Case Report  Patient Demographic Information: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a weight of 76 kg and a height of 5'8"". He is a retired automotive engineer residing in suburban Detroit  Michigan  with his wife. He has a history of smoking 10 cigarettes a year but quit 15 years ago. He moderately consumes alcohol and enjoys a fairly active lifestyle.  Past Medical History: The patient has a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which are well controlled by Atenolol 50mg and Atorvastatin 40mg  respectively. Moreover  he underwent coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery approximately 10 years ago due to ischemic heart disease. He has no known allergies or genetic disorders. He also has no previous history of drug abuse.  Chief Complaint / Symptoms: The patient was admitted to the ER with a two-week history of malaise  intermittent fever  night sweats  and weight loss. He also complained of fatigue  a decrease in exercise tolerance  and occasional shortness of breath  but no associated chest pain.  Laboratory Results and Diagnosis: On examination  fever (38.5°C)  heart rate of 92 bpm  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  and blood pressure of 140/85mm Hg were recorded. Cardiac auscultation revealed a new grade 3/6 systolic murmur. Routine blood tests showed elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP). Blood cultures were drawn and revealed Streptococcus sanguinis  a common bacterial agent of native-valve endocarditis. The patient underwent a Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) which confirmed the presence of a vegetative growth on the mitral valve consistent with infective endocarditis.  Treatment and Outcome: The patient was started on empirical intravenous antibiotic therapy with Ceftriaxone 2g every 24 h and Gentamicin 1mg/kg every 8 h. Following the sensitivity report  Gentamicin was stopped after two weeks while Ceftriaxone was continued for a total of four weeks. He showed marked clinical improvement with resolution of fever and other symptoms. Post-treatment echocardiography showed reduction in size of the vegetation. The patient was discharged with instructions to complete a follow-up in the outpatient department.  Conclusion: This case offers an insight into the complex presentation and management of infective endocarditis in an elderly patient. It also underscores the importance of a detailed medical history  thorough clinical examination  and the need for early diagnosis and initiation of appropriate antimicrobial therapy.

Title: Native-valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged African American Male with a History of Intravenous Drug Use  Case Report:  Patient Information: A 50-year old African American male patient presented to the hospital with a one-week history of intermittent high-grade fever  malaise  anorexia  and night sweats. He had no allergies and was unemployed. He acknowledged a long history of intravenous drug use  with recent use within the past week. The patient had no history of childhood heart disease and no prior episodes of infective endocarditis. His immunization status was up-to-date and he had no recent history of any dental procedures or invasive medical procedures.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  the patient appeared ill and in slight distress. Vital signs included a temperature of 38.9 degrees Celsius  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg  respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 98% in room air. Heart examination revealed a new systolic murmur best appreciated at the left sternal border. Skin examination showed non-tender  erythematous lesions on the palms and soles indicative of Janeway lesions  and small painful nodules on the fingers suggestive of Osler's nodes.  Diagnostic Assessment:  A series of laboratory tests were ordered including complete blood count  liver function tests  renal function tests  and blood cultures. The patient had marked leukocytosis and elevated C-reactive protein  suggestive of acute systemic inflammation. Liver function tests and renal function were within normal limits. Blood cultures were positive for Staphylococcus aureus  confirmatory for infective endocarditis. An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed normal sinus rhythm. Transthoracic echocardiography revealed vegetation on the tricuspid valve  indicative of native valve infective endocarditis.  Therapeutic Interventions: Intravenous antibiotic treatment was initiated based on positive blood culture sensitivity for Staphylococcus aureus; treatment included intravenous vancomycin and ceftriaxone. The patient was also educated about the potential risks and complications of continued intravenous drug use.   Follow-up and Outcomes: Treatment led to initial improvement of the patient's symptoms; however  two weeks into therapy  the patient's condition deteriorated due to developing congestive heart failure and sepsis  eventually leading to his death.   Patient Perspective: The patient demonstrated regret for his continued intravenous drug use and expressed initial willingness to make life changes  but was unable to commit to any addiction rehabilitation programs before his condition deteriorated.  Informed Consent: Informed consent was obtained from the patient for medical investigations and treatment.   Conclusion: This case underscores the severe consequences of infective endocarditis  primarily in populations at risk such as intravenous drug users. Halting drug abuse and early detection of common predisposing factors can be potential lifesavers.

Title: A Case Report of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-aged Hispanic Male  Introduction:  This report describes a case of a 52-year-old Hispanic male diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis (IE). It delineates his demographic  medical history  clinical features  diagnostic procedures  treatment regimen  and prognosis.   Case Description:  The patient  a 52-year-old Hispanic male  who works as a construction worker  reported to the emergency department complaining primarily of fever  night sweats  weight loss  and fatigue that had persisted over the last four weeks. He was a non-smoker and moderate alcohol drinker.   Past Medical History:  The patient has been medically managed for hypertension for the past ten years and has no history of diabetes or other chronic illnesses. There was no personal or family history of cardiac disease. He had no known allergies. His last visit to the hospital was five years ago due to a minor work-related injury. The patient denied any illicit drug use.  Clinical Evaluation and Investigations:  Physical examination revealed a temperature of 38.7°C related to fever and fatigue. There were no visible skin lesions  but a systolic murmur was audible upon chest auscultation. No other abnormalities were found during the examination.   Blood cultures were obtained  which subsequently grew Staphylococcus aureus. Laboratory analysis showed elevated inflammatory markers  C-reactive protein  and erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Complete blood count revealed mild anemia and leukocytosis.   An echocardiogram was performed revealing vegetations on the mitral valve  consistent with a diagnosis of native-valve IE.  Treatment:  Empirical antibiotic therapy was initially started with Vancomycin and Gentamicin  according to international guidelines for Staphylococcus aureus IE. Once susceptibility results came back  antibiotic therapy was de-escalated to Oxacillin. The patient showed significant improvement after two weeks of treatment.  Even though surgical intervention was considered  it was deferred due to patient's stability and the absence of heart failure signs or septic emboli.  Follow-Up and Outcome:  The patient completed a six-week course of antibiotic therapy with regular monitoring of therapeutic drug levels and renal function. The repeated echocardiogram post-treatment showed the disappearance of the vegetations and no valvular dysfunction. His symptoms of fever  night sweats  and fatigue resolved  and he reported improved energy and resumption of his regular activities.   Discussion:  This case is illustrative of native-valve infective endocarditis commonly found in patients with no prior history of structural heart disease. The patient's long period of vague symptoms before diagnosis highlights the sometimes-insidious nature of IE. Early detection and appropriate antibiotic therapy were essential components in the successful treatment of this patient's condition. This patient will benefit from regular follow-ups to ensure cardiac function and prompt assessment if symptoms re-appear.   Conclusion:  Native-valve infective endocarditis can be fatal if left untreated. This case report emphasizes the importance of timely diagnosis and appropriate treatment. Regular follow-up and lifestyle modification  including hypertension management  are essential for preventing any recurrence of the infection.

Title: A Case Report Of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis In A 72-Year-Old Male Patient  Introduction:  Infective endocarditis (IE) is a serious infection of the inner surface of the heart that usually affects the heart valves. It typically occurs when bacteria or other germs enter the bloodstream and settle in the heart.  Case presentation:  The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a previous medical history of type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and a long-standing history of alcoholism. He was a retired construction worker with a 45 pack-year smoking history.  He was admitted to the hospital with a three-week history of progressive malaise  night sweats  intermittent fever  and unintentional weight loss. Despite seeking treatment with oral antibiotics at a local healthcare clinic for presumed pneumonia  the patient's symptoms failed to resolve.  Clinical findings:  Upon presentation  the patient was ill-appearing with temperatures up to 38.7C  blood pressure of 132/89 mmHg  a heart rate of 85 beats per minute  and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. Physical examination revealed a diastolic murmur on cardiac auscultation and non-tender erythematous nodules on the pads of his fingers and toes (Osler's nodes). There were no other significant findings.  Investigations:  Complete blood count revealed anemia (Hb 10.3 g/dL) and leukocytosis (WBC 14.5 x 109/L). Blood cultures (5/5) grew Staphylococcus aureus. Chest x-ray was unremarkable. An echocardiogram demonstrated vegetation on the aortic valve with severe aortic regurgitation.  Diagnoses:  With physical findings  positive blood cultures  and echocardiographic evidence of valvular vegetation  a diagnosis of Native-valve Infective Endocarditis (NVE) was made.  Treatment:  The patient was started on intravenous antibiotics in accordance with the IDSA guideline for the treatment of methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) infective endocarditis. Furthermore  due to severe heart valve damage  he was referred to cardiothoracic surgery for an aortic valve replacement procedure.  Outcomes:  The patient responded well to antibiotic treatment and aortic valve replacement procedure. After a prolonged hospital stay  marked by periods of delirium likely secondary to his longstanding alcohol use  the patient was discharged in stable condition with outpatient follow-up.  Conclusions:  This case underscores the importance of early and accurate diagnosis of NVE  especially in patients with risk factors such as age  the presence of comorbidities  and lifestyle factors. Furthermore  it highlights the role of appropriate and prompt treatment in preventing complications from NVE.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis: A Case of the Unusual Presentation in a Middle-Aged Asian Female   Background: Native-valve infective endocarditis (NVIE)  an infection of the heart's inner lining  is a severe  potentially fatal disease typically occurring in individuals with damaged heart valves. Timely diagnosis is crucial in initiating effective treatment plans.   Case Description:   Patient Information: The patient is a 50-year-old Asian female  a sales representative with no history of intravenous drug use. She lives in a suburban area  is married and has two grown-up children. She does not smoke  consume alcohol  or any illicit substances.  Past Medical History: She had previously been diagnosed with type-2 diabetes mellitus  well-controlled with oral antidiabetic drugs. She reports no known heart disease or dental conditions. She has not undergone any recent invasive procedures or surgeries. Her family history reveals no significant incidences of heart disease.  Present Issue: The patient presented to the hospital with a three-week history of intermittent high-grade fever and significant weight loss. She also reported a one-week history of new onset shortness of breath with no significant cough  chest pain  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  or lower extremity edema.   Clinical Findings: On examination  she had a regular heart rate (84 beats per minute) and blood pressure (122/78 mmHg)  but her temperature was elevated (38.7°C). Cardiac examination revealed a diastolic murmur along the left lower sternal border. Physical examination also demonstrated Osler's nodes on the fingers and toes and conjunctival hemorrhage  both consistent with infective endocarditis.  Diagnostic Assessment: A full blood count showed an elevated white blood cell count indicative of an ongoing infection. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate was significantly raised. Blood cultures isolated Streptococcus viridans. Electrocardiography (ECG) showed normal sinus rhythm with no significant changes. Transthoracic echocardiographic (TTE) findings revealed vegetations on the mitral valve  confirming NVIE.   Therapeutic Interventions: She was started on empirical intravenous antibiotics (penicillin G and gentamicin) after the blood cultures were taken. After the confirmation from the blood culture  the treatment was extended for six weeks  along with diabetic medicinal therapy.  Outcome and Follow-Up: She responded well to the treatment  with a decline in the fever within a week. The shortness of breath improved  and she gained weight during subsequent follow-ups. The patient is scheduled for regular follow-ups with a cardiologist and an endocrinologist for both the endocarditis and diabetes.  Teaching Points: This case emphasizes the importance of considering NVIE in diabetic patients presenting with unexplained fever and new cardiac murmurs. It also encourages considering NVIE even when patients lack traditional risk factors such as intravenous drug use  prosthetic valves  or previous cardiac surgery.    Consent: Informed consent was obtained from the patient to publish the data concerning her case.  Confidentiality: The confidentiality of the patient’s information was maintained throughout  as per ethical guidelines.

Title: Native-valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Male with Diabetes Mellitus: A Case Report  Demographics:  The patient is a 50-year-old Caucasian male  residing in an urban area in the United States. He is a smoker  with a two-pack-per-day habit maintained over the past 20 years. He is suffering from type II diabetes and uncontrolled hypertension.  Presenting Complaint: He presented to the emergency unit with high-grade fever  marked malaise  and lower back pain of three weeks' duration. The patient also reported a recent weight loss of about 5 kilograms over a month.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination upon admission revealed pallor and moderate splenomegaly. He had a grade II/VI systolic murmur in the mitral area. The patient also had positive Osler’s and Janeway’s signs  indicative of infective endocarditis (IE).  Laboratory investigations revealed anemia (hemoglobin: 10.5 g/dl)  raised erythrocyte sedimentation rate  and C-reactive protein levels. Peripheral smear showed features of anemia of chronic disease. Blood culture grew Staphylococcus aureus. His random blood glucose levels were elevated  with poor glycemic control. Chest radiography and ultrasound of the abdomen were unremarkable.  Echo-Cardiographic Findings: Transthoracic echocardiography revealed moderate mitral regurgitation due to mitral valve thickening  suggestive of native-valve endocarditis (NVE). The presence of vegetation on the mitral valve measuring approximately 1.5 cm × 0.7 cm was also noticed.  Treatment: The patient was initiated on intravenous antibiotics as per the AHA/ACC guidelines for management of NVE  based on the sensitivity pattern in his blood culture. Insulin therapy was started for glycemic control  and he was also prescribed medications to control his blood pressure.  Follow-up and Outcomes: The patient showed clinical and microbiological response to the antibiotics  with defervescence of fever after two weeks of treatment. Repeat echocardiography after 6 weeks revealed a regression in the size of vegetations. His blood pressure and glucose levels were well-controlled on medication. Over a period of three months of follow-up  the patient showed significant improvement in his overall condition with resolution of his symptoms.  Patient Perspective: The patient reported feeling better and healthier than before the hospital stay  emphasizing the importance of proactive monitoring and control of his diabetes and hypertension.  Conclusions: This case underscores the increased risk for native valve endocarditis in diabetic patients  emphasizing the importance of early recognition and prompt treatment of this potentially life-threatening condition. Health care professionals need to be aware of this association  especially in patients with uncontrolled diabetes presenting with non-specific symptoms.    Informed Consent: Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report and any accompanying images.

Title: A Case Report on a 65-Year-Old Male with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Abstract: We report the case of a 65-year-old Caucasian male diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis (NVE) and managed with a combination of medical therapy and surgical intervention. This case demonstrates the necessary vigilance required for early detection of NVE and the immediate application of appropriate interventions.  Case report:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male  a smoker with a past medical history of hypertension  dyslipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus presented to the emergency department with a four-week history of progressive dyspnea  low-grade fever  and weight loss. The patient was not drug addicted and did not have any underlying heart conditions or known immunodeficiencies.  Physical examination revealed him to be hemodynamically stable but febrile at 38.3°C with pale conjunctiva  peri-oral cyanosis  and peripheral edema. His cardiovascular exam was notable for a new murmur best heard over the left lower sternal border. No Janeway lesions  Osler nodes  or Roth spots were seen.  Laboratory tests showed a raised ESR and CRP  indicating inflammation. A complete blood count showed leukocytosis and anemia. An elevated BUN and slightly reduced GFR suggested kidney involvement. EKG displayed non-specific T-wave changes. Blood cultures yielded Streptococcus viridans  and a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) showed a 1.5 cm x 1 cm mobile vegetation on the mitral valve's anterior leaflet.  Given the clinical presentation  laboratory findings  positive blood culture  and TEE evidence  he was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis. He was promptly initiated on intravenous antibiotics based on sensitivity testing.   Despite the initial medical management  the patient developed congestive heart failure symptoms due to significant mitral valve regurgitation secondary to leaflet destruction by the infective process. Surgery was considered necessary due to worsening heart failure  despite appropriate antibiotic therapy. The patient underwent a successful mitral valve replacement.  Post-surgery follow-up showed his symptoms had markedly improved  and repeat blood cultures were found to be negative. The patient was set on a prolonged course of targeted antibiotics and was advised for regular follow-ups.  Conclusion: The case highlights the critical importance of high clinical suspicion and prompt comprehensive evaluation in patients presenting with non-specific symptoms. Despite advances in microbiology and imaging  NVE continues to be a severe disease associated with high mortality and morbidity. This case reinforces the role of early diagnosis  appropriate antibiotic therapy  and timely surgical intervention in managing native-valve endocarditis effectively.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Information:   The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who is a retired engineer. He resides in a suburban community with his wife. His main activities include reading  gardening  and volunteering in local community service.  Past Medical History:   The patient has a history of cardiovascular disease and past episodes of rheumatic fever in his childhood. He also suffers from Type 2 diabetes  high cholesterol  and hypertension. The patient takes medications including metformin for diabetes  a statin for high cholesterol  and Lisinopril for hypertension. The patient does not smoke  but drinks alcohol occasionally. There is a family history of heart disease.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Smith presented with a two-week history of intermittent fevers  malaise  and a recent onset of exertional dyspnea. He also complained of weight loss and night sweats. He had no known allergies.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  he was febrile with a temperature of 101°F  heart rate of 92 beats per minute  and blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg. He was pallor with a noticeable weight loss. Cardiac auscultation revealed a previously undocumented grade III/VI systolic murmur consistent with mitral regurgitation. There were no peripheral stigmata of endocarditis.  Diagnostic Assessment:  The lab data showed elevated WBC count of 15 000/µl with a left shift  and high levels of C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation rate  indicating inflammation. Blood cultures were obtained prior to initiating antibiotics  which revealed Methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA). Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) showed a 1.2 cm mobile echodensity on the anterior mitral leaflet confirming the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Mr. Smith was initiated on intravenous Nafcillin  honoring the sensitivity report from his MSSA blood cultures. A multidisciplinary team consisting of a cardiologist  infectious disease specialist  and cardiothoracic surgeon was involved in his care. Given his stable condition  the decision was made to complete a 6-week course of antibiotics with reassessment for surgery.  Follow-Up and Outcomes:  After completion of antibiotic therapy  repeat blood cultures were negative  and his constitutional symptoms had resolved. A repeat TTE demonstrated resolution of the vegetation  but a residual mild-mitral regurgitation. The patient was discharged in stable condition with follow-up appointments scheduled in respective specialty clinics.  Patient Perspective:   The patient felt that he received appropriate care and was grateful that surgery was not required at this point. He understood that further interventions might be necessary in the future and was compliant to continuous follow-up. He was educated about maintaining good oral hygiene and regular checkups to prevent recurrence of this severe infection.  This case emphasizes that high clinical suspicion plays a key role in the early diagnosis and effective management of native-valve infective endocarditis  thus reducing the overall morbidity and mortality associated with this condition.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged African American Female: A Case Report  Introduction: Infective endocarditis (IE) is a relatively rare condition that is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. A challenge in the field remains the accurate diagnosis  especially in at-risk populations. Here  we present the case of native-valve IE in an otherwise healthy African American female patient.  Case Presentation:  Patient Information: The patient is a 53-year-old African American female  with an unremarkable past medical history  residing in Fort Worth  Texas. She is a non-smoker  with occasional alcohol consumption and no significant family history of heart disease. The patient earns a living as a primary school teacher.   Clinical findings: The patient presented to the emergency department with a 10-day history of generalized malaise  intermittent fever  and shortness of breath. She also complained of a new and progressively worsening arthralgia. No known recent dental procedures or infections were reported. Physical examination showed a diastolic murmur best heard at the apex  slight splenomegaly  and non-tender petechiae on her legs.   Diagnostic Assessment: Preliminary lab investigations showed an elevated white cell count (17000 /mcL) and C-reactive protein level (42 mg/L). Her ESR was also raised (65 mm/hr). Blood cultures were positive for Streptococcus viridans. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) revealed large mobile vegetations on her mitral valve leaflets without significant regurgitation or stenosis. The rest of the valvular apparatus and the heart chambers were normal. These findings were confirmatory of native-valve Infective Endocarditis (IE).  Therapeutic Interventions: The patient was started on empirical antibiotic therapy with intravenous (IV) ceftriaxone and gentamicin as per local guidelines. After the sensitivity results  the patient was successfully treated with 4 weeks of IV Ceftriaxone alone.  Follow-up and Outcomes: The patient responded well to the treatment with marked improvement in her clinical condition. A follow-up TTE at six weeks did not show any vegetations. The patient was educated about the necessity of prophylactic antibiotics before any future dental procedures or surgeries.  Conclusion: This case report highlights the importance of a high index of suspicion in diagnosing IE and underscores that IE can occur even in individuals without a significant past medical history. This is especially critical in minority populations that have been traditionally underrepresented and potentially understudied  as noted in this case with an African American female. Timely diagnosis and management significantly reduce morbidity and mortality in IE.   Informed consent: Informed consent was obtained from the patient for the publication of this case report.   Author Contributions: All authors contributed to data analysis  drafting  and revising the paper  gave final approval of the version to be published  and agree to be accountable for all aspects of the work.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Moroccan Male: A Case Report  Introduction  This case report documents the clinical presentation  diagnosis  management  and outcome of native-valve infective endocarditis in a 54-year-old Moroccan male  taking into account relevant demographic and clinical factors.  Case Presentation  A 54-year-old Moroccan male  with a previous medical history of poorly controlled type II diabetes and concealed tobacco usage  was admitted to our facility with severe malaise  intermittent fever  and weight loss over the past three months. The patient reported a recent dental abscess  for which he took broad-spectrum antibiotics without medical supervision. He had no previous history of cardiac disease  and denied any family history of cardiac illnesses. He has been living in low socio-economic conditions with substandard sanitation.  On admission  his vital signs were within normal range with a slightly elevated temperature (37.8C). Physical examination revealed Janeway lesions on the palms and soles  along with weight loss and pallor. The patient was fairly cooperative and alert but appeared fatigued. Cardiovascular examination revealed a diastolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border.   Two sets of blood cultures were obtained from different sites  which subsequently grew Streptococcus viridans  a common pathogen implicated in native-valve infective endocarditis. Transthoracic echocardiogram revealed an oscillating intracardiac mass on an aortic valve consistent with vegetation.  The diagnosis was consistent with Native Valve Infective Endocarditis (NVIE). The patient was subsequently started on empirical parenteral antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone and gentamicin based on local susceptibility patterns.  Despite appropriate antibiotic therapy  the patient developed acute heart failure after one week of treatment  likely secondary to aortic valve destruction and subsequent severe aortic regurgitation. He was urgently referred for surgical intervention where he successfully underwent aortic valve replacement with a bioprosthesis.  The patient was further managed for his underlying diabetes with oral hypoglycemic agents  diet modification  and lifestyle changes. Upon a six-month follow-up visit  the patient reported significant improvement in his overall health and no recurrence of endocarditis symptoms. Long-term intravenous antibiotic therapy was continued under careful supervision to ensure complete eradication of the infection.  Conclusions:  This case emphasizes the link between poor dental hygiene  misuse of antibiotics  underlying non-cardiac comorbidities  and the development of native-valve infective endocarditis. It serves as a reminder for appropriate and superintended use of antibiotics  regular dental check-ups  and importance of good glycemic control in patients with diabetes to prevent serious secondary infections like NVIE.

Title: Case Report of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 65-Year-Old African-American Male With Underlying Diabetes Mellitus   Patient Information:   The patient is a 65-year-old African-American male  native to New York City  with past medical history significant for diabetes mellitus type II and hypertension for which he has been on oral hypoglycemic agents and antihypertensive medication respectively.  Chief Complaint:   The patient presented to the emergency department with complaints of fever  fatigued feeling  and unintentional weight loss over a span of two months.  Clinical Findings:   On examination  the patient had a temperature of 38.6 celsius  blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  heart rate of 98 beats per minute  and a respiration rate of 18 breaths per minute. He had Janeway lesions on his palms and soles  and Osler's nodes were noted on his fingers.  Diagnostic Assessment:   Given the suspicion of infective endocarditis based on his clinical presentation  laboratory tests and echocardiography were conducted. Laboratory results revealed an elevated white blood cell count of 15 000 cells/µL (normal range: 4 500-11 000 cells/µL) and increased C-reactive protein of 50 mg/L (normal range: up to 10 mg/L). Blood cultures were taken and were positive for Staphylococcus aureus. Transthoracic Echocardiogram showed vegetation on his native mitral valve  suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis.   Therapeutic Intervention:   The patient was initiated on intravenous antibiotics  including nafcillin and gentamicin  per the Infectious Disease specialist’s recommendations. His blood sugar levels were monitored regularly  and his oral hypoglycemic agents were adjusted as needed. His antihypertensive medication was also continued. The patient’s response to the treatment was monitored using daily temperatures  clinical signs  and repeat blood cultures.  Outcome and Follow-Up:   After four weeks of continuous antibiotic therapy  the patient showed significant improvement in his clinical symptoms. Repeat blood cultures were negative  and a follow-up echocardiogram showed a decrease in the size of vegetation. Prior to discharge  the patient was scheduled for close outpatient follow-up to monitor his recovery and potential complications from his endocarditis.  Discussion:  Infective endocarditis remains a significant cause of morbidity and mortality  especially among individuals with underlying conditions like diabetes mellitus  as presented in this case report. The necessity for proper and prompt diagnosis  as well as effective therapeutic intervention  cannot be overemphasized  as delay in treatment can lead to severe  often life-threatening complications.

Title: A Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 55-Year-Old Male with Past Medical History of Illicit IV Drug Use and Alcohol Abuse   Introduction: Native-valve infective endocarditis (NVE) is a severe infection of the endocardial surface of the heart  primarily affecting the valves. This case report presents a patient with NVE  illustrating the complexity of diagnosis and management.   Patient Information: A 55-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department (ED) with a two-week history of intermittent high-grade fever  fatigue  weight loss  cough  and night sweats. A comprehensive review of his past medical history revealed long-term intravenous (IV) drug use  alcohol abuse  and Hepatitis C virus (HCV). He had no family history of cardiac diseases.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination showed conjunctival pallor  numerous needle track marks  Osler’s nodes on fingers  splinter hemorrhages on the nailbeds  and a diastolic murmur heard best at the fifth left intercostal space. The patient's blood pressure was 110/70 mmHg  pulse rate was 98/min  and body temperature was 38.5 °C.  Diagnostic Assessment: Laboratory investigations showed leukocytosis (WBC: 15.0 x 10^9/L)  elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR: 45mm/hr)  and C-reactive protein (CRP: 45mg/L). Blood cultures grew Staphylococcus aureus  suggestive of bacteremia. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) revealed vegetation on the tricuspid valve  supporting the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was promptly initiated on empiric antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone and gentamicin as per local Staphylococcus aureus susceptibility patterns. Following the confirmation of culture results  the patient also underwent Tricuspid valve replacement surgery. The post-operative period was uneventful and he was discharged with instructions for a full 6 weeks of IV antibiotics.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: The patient attended monthly follow-up appointments. The 6-month follow-up showed the patient remaining abstinent from drug use. Echocardiography showed normal prosthetic valve function. The patient reported adherence to antibiotic therapy and was symptom-free. A close monitoring plan for his alcohol and drug addiction was also implemented.  Discussion: This case enhances our understanding of how NVE manifests in patients with chronic IV drug usage. It underlines the significance of comprehensive history taking  early recognition  and prompt intervention in mitigating the morbidity and mortality associated with NVE.  Conclusion: The presentation of this case aims to increase clinician awareness of the potential for NVE in patients with histories of substance abuse. Interdisciplinary care  involving cardiology  infectious diseases  and addiction specialists  is key in ensuring favourable patient outcomes.

Title: A Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 52-Year-Old Male with Previous Intravenous Drug Use  Introduction: Infective endocarditis is a severe and potentially life-threatening infection of the endocardial surface of the heart. While it may affect individuals regardless of their background  certain populations such as those with a history of intravenous (IV) drug use or valvular heart disease are at greater risk.  Patient Information: Mr. X is a 52-year-old Caucasian male with a self-reported history of IV drug use. He is unemployed  and his habitual residence is shared with several other individuals with a similar history of substance misuse. His last known IV drug use was reportedly three weeks prior to initial consultation.  Clinical Findings: The patient came to the emergency department complaining of persistent chills  night sweats  unintended weight loss and generalized body malaise that had commenced two weeks prior. He also disclosed a recent history of intermittent fevers. He was not experiencing any chest pain  cough  or shortness of breath. On physical examination  the patient appeared generally unwell  with pale skin and evidence of peripheral stigmata of endocarditis  including Janeway lesions and Osler's nodes. His blood pressure was 130/80mmHg  heart rate was 90bpm  temperature was 38°C  and oxygen saturation level was at 95%.   Past Medical History: The patient's medical record revealed a history of hepatitis C related to his former use of IV drugs. He had no history of known heart disease or hospitalization for any cardiac-related conditions. No prior history of infective endocarditis was noted. His vaccination status was unclear  and he had no known allergies.  Diagnostic Assessment: Two sets of blood cultures were subsequently obtained and an echocardiogram was commended - which revealed large  mobile vegetations on the patient's tricuspid valve  satisfying the major Duke criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was started on empiric antibiotic therapy with vancomycin and gentamycin. This was later adjusted to nafcillin and rifampin after the blood culture results showed methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus.  Follow-up and Outcomes: The patient's clinical condition improved steadily with ongoing antibiotic therapy. After six weeks  cultures were negative and the patient was deemed clinically well enough to be discharged  but he is to continue outpatient antibiotic therapy for another six weeks. Further counseling on drug rehabilitation was advised.  Conclusion: This case serves to highlight the risk of infective endocarditis among intravenous drug users. Timely diagnosis and appropriate antibiotic therapy are critical to improve patient outcomes. Alongside medical treatment  it is crucial to address underlying problems such as substance misuse in order to prevent a recidivist course.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Caucasian Female Patient with a Past Medical History of Mitral Valve Prolapse: A Case Report   Introduction: This case report presents the occurrence and management of native-valve infective endocarditis in an elderly Caucasian female patient with a history of mitral valve prolapse in Maine  USA  showing a complex aspect of clinical management among vulnerable populations.   Case Presentation: The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian female of non-Hispanic descent currently living in an assisted care facility. She has a well-documented medical history of mitral valve prolapse  diagnosed 15 years prior. Other parts of her past medical history include uncontrolled hypertension  managed by diuretic medication  chronic renal disease due to long-term hypertension  and osteoarthritis which often causes her moderate to severe pain. The patient is also a former smoker  quit 20 years ago  with an estimated 15 pack-years history.  She was brought to our healthcare facility presenting with non-specific symptoms that have persisted and gradually worsened over three weeks  including fever with chills and fatigue  reduced appetite  weight loss  and night sweats  with no recent history of travel or known source of infection detected.  An initial set of blood cultures were taken upon admission  and she was started empirically on intravenous (IV) ceftriaxone and gentamicin due to the high suspicion of infective endocarditis given her history of mitral valve prolapse. Electrocardiogram and echocardiography were also performed  resulting in visual confirmation of possible vegetation on the mitral valve.  Final blood culture results confirmed Streptococcus viridans bacteremia  and the antibiotic regimen was then transitioned to tailored treatment. The patient's course in the hospital was complicated by renal function deterioration and the development of heart failure symptoms  which prompted adjusting her antibiotic therapy and starting her on heart failure medications.  The patient was managed by a multidisciplinary team including cardiologists  infectious disease specialists  and nephrologists  given her complex comorbidities. Surgical intervention was deemed too high risk due to her impaired renal function and overall frail condition. Instead  she was given conservative medical management and was closely monitored for her cardiac  renal functions  and systemic signs of sepsis.  Conclusion: This case demonstrates the severity and complexity of managing infective endocarditis especially in elderly patients with several co-morbidities. It emphasizes the importance of early detection  adequate treatment  and diligent monitoring to prevent further complications. It also highlights that a team-based approach involving multiple specialities is crucial for managing such complex cases.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Hispanic Female: A Case Report  Patient Presentation:  A 45-year-old Hispanic female presented to the emergency department with the chief complaints of fever  malaise  fatigue  and a new-onset heart murmur that had evolved over the past three weeks. The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled with metformin  intermittent intravenous drug use  and no known allergies. She lives in an urban setting and works as a cleaner. She denied any recent dental work or invasive medical procedures.  Vitals & Examination:  On examination  the patient had a temperature of 38.4°C (101.1°F)  HR - 102/min  BP - 98/60 mm Hg  RR - 20/min  and oxygen saturation - 95% on room air. The patient appeared pale and fatigued  with splinter hemorrhages in her nails and Janeway lesions on both palms and soles. On systemic examination  a new grade III/VI systolic murmur was audible over the aortic area.   Investigations & Diagnosis:  A diagnosis of infective endocarditis was suspected based on the clinical findings. Laboratory tests showed an increased white blood cell count at 16 000 cells/µl  elevated Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR) at 56 mm/hr  and C-reactive protein at 65 mg/L  indicating an active infection. Three sets of blood cultures revealed the presence of Staphylococcus aureus.  An echocardiogram showed an oscillating intracardiac mass on an aortic valve consistent with vegetation  along with moderate aortic regurgitation  corroborating the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Treatment & Progress:  The patient was promptly started on empiric antibiotic therapy with intravenous ceftriaxone and gentamicin. After susceptibility testing  the regimen was narrowed to IV nafcillin  which was continued for six weeks. The patient's conditions improved over the first 10 days  with decreasing fever and leukocyte count. Regular echocardiograms showed decreasing vegetation size. However  severe aortic regurgitation remained.   She was referred to cardiothoracic surgery for valve replacement but declined surgery due to personal beliefs. Therefore  the patient was managed conservatively with continuation of antibiotics and cardiac medications. She will be closely followed up in the outpatient clinic and educated regarding the importance of good glycemic control and cessation of intravenous drug use.  Morbidity & Prognosis:  Studies suggest that nearly 25% of patients with native valve endocarditis may require surgical intervention due to heart failure  persistent infection  or to prevent systemic embolism. The patient has higher risks of complications due to her choice of refusing surgery  existing diabetes  and intravenous drug use  making her case critical with a guarded prognosis.   Conclusion:  This case illustrates the importance of maintaining high clinical suspicion for infective endocarditis in patients with new-onset murmurs and non-specific symptoms such as fever and malaise  especially in high-risk populations like intravenous drug abusers. Healthcare providers must advocate for proper management  including surgery if necessary  to prevent irreversible damage and potential mortality.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Female with a History of Rheumatic Heart Disease: A Case Report   Patient Information: The patient  a 75-year-old Caucasian female  presented to the emergency department with a two-week history of intermittent fevers  chills  night sweats  loss of appetite  and gradual weight loss. She lives with her husband and is a retired school teacher. She has a 30-year history of rheumatic heart disease without any prior surgery and is on regular medications including aspirin and statins.   Clinical Findings: Vital signs were notable for a fever of 38.6°C  pulse rate of 110 bpm  and blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg. Physical examination revealed a diastolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border.   Diagnostic Assessment: Blood investigations revealed elevated ESR (Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate) and CRP (C-Reactive Protein). Blood cultures grew Streptococcus viridans. Transthoracic echocardiography showed vegetation on the patient's mitral valve consistent with infective endocarditis. These findings  along with the patient’s symptoms and clinical picture  met the modified Duke criteria for definite infective endocarditis.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was initially started on empirical antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone and gentamicin until the blood culture results were obtained. According to the culture sensitivity report  the patient was then treated with Penicillin G and gentamicin for six weeks.  Outcome: During the treatment period  the patient's condition improved significantly with resolution of fever  chills  and weight gain. Follow-up echocardiogram showed reduced size of the vegetation on the mitral valve  although mild mitral regurgitation persisted. However  the patient did not develop heart failure symptoms. She was discharged after six weeks of inpatient intravenous antibiotics.   Conclusion:  Consideration of infective endocarditis in an elderly patient with rheumatic heart disease presenting with unexplained fever led to early diagnosis and successful treatment in this case. Adherence to the modified Duke Criteria was key in establishing the diagnosis and guiding the therapeutic decision-making process. The case emphasizes the importance of microbiological diagnostic procedures and tailored antibiotic therapy for the best possible patient outcome.   Teaching Points: 1. Persistent fever in patients with a history of rheumatic heart disease should raise suspicion for infective endocarditis. 2. Empirical antibiotics should be started promptly  with therapy adjusted according to blood culture results. 3. Adherence to the modified Duke Criteria aids in diagnosis. 4. Patient follow-up is essential to monitor for complications and assess treatment effectiveness.

Title: Infective Endocarditis in a 60-year-old Female with Native Valves: A Case Report  Abstract: This report discusses the clinical presentation  diagnosis and management of a 60-year-old female who was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis. Despite the decreased incidence of native-valve infective endocarditis among elderly populations  this case signifies the importance of early recognition and therapeutic intervention.  Introduction: Infective endocarditis (IE) is a rare  life-threatening disease associated with substantial morbidity and mortality. Native-valve endocarditis remains a significant health concern  especially among the elderly individuals.  Case Presentation: The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian female with a medical history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. She presented to the emergency department with a two-week history of persistent fever  chills  and fatigue  with recently developed dyspnoea. She was previously healthy until three weeks ago when these symptoms began to gradually manifest. No known drug allergies were reported. She had no history of intravenous drug use  no recent dental procedures  and no family history of heart diseases.   Clinical Findings: On initial examination  she had a fever of 39.2°C  heart rate of 110 beats/minute  respiratory rate of 22 breaths/minute  blood pressure of 135/90 mmHg and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. Cardiac auscultation revealed a diastolic murmur at the left sternal border. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Diagnostic Assessment: Laboratory investigations showed elevated white blood cell count and raised C-reactive protein. Blood cultures grew Streptococcus viridans. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) showed an oscillating intracardiac mass on the mitral valve along with moderate mitral regurgitation highly suggestive of infective endocarditis. A transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) was then performed which confirmed the diagnosis by demonstrating a large vegetation on the mitral valve with moderate to severe mitral regurgitation.  Therapeutic Intervention: Intravenous ceftriaxone and gentamicin were initiated as per the American Heart Association guidelines for Streptococcus viridans endocarditis. Despite 2 weeks of appropriate antibiotics  the patient's clinical condition deteriorated due to ongoing sepsis and heart failure secondary to severe mitral regurgitation. Cardiac surgery was consulted and she successfully underwent mitral valve replacement surgery.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: The patient showed significant improvement of her symptoms post-operatively. She was then discharged on a prolonged course of oral antibiotics for six weeks. Follow-up echocardiography four weeks later showed the prosthetic mitral valve was functioning well and there were no signs of residual infection.  Conclusions: In the elderly population  early recognition and treatment of infective endocarditis can be life-saving. This case underscores the crucial role of a high index of suspicion  rapid initiation of appropriate antibiotic therapy and timely surgical intervention when necessary.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Diabetes-Concomitant Male Patient: A Clinical Case  Introduction: Infective endocarditis is typically an infection of the endocardial surface of the heart and valves. Native-valve infective endocarditis relates to such infection occurring in individuals with no history of valve surgery. This report concerns a patient with no history of intravenous drug use or valve defects but presented with native-valve infective endocarditis with concomitant diabetes mellitus.  Case Presentation:  The patient is a 55-year-old Hispanic male who presented to the emergency department with complaints of general malaise  fever  and recent-onset exertional dyspnea. His past medical history was remarkable for well-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and obesity with a body mass index (BMI) of 31.2kg/m^2. He’s a non-smoker and consumes moderate quantities of alcohol.  On examination  he was febrile  with a temperature of 38.2 degrees Celsius. His blood pressure was 115/75 mmHg  pulse rate was 100 beats per minute. Cardiac auscultation revealed a grade II/IV diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. There was no evidence of any peripheral stigmata of infective endocarditis.  Investigations and Management:  The patient was admitted under suspect of infective endocarditis. Initial blood tests revealed elevated white cell counts and C-reactive protein. Blood cultures were drawn and the patient was commenced on empirical intravenous antibiotics. Trans-thoracic echocardiography confirmed the presence of a mobile echodense structure attached to the ventricular side of the mitral valve leaflet  suggestive of vegetation.  The blood culture results  available after 48 hours  revealed Gram-positive cocci identified as Streptococcus bovis. The antibiotic regime was then narrowed down to penicillin G and gentamicin according to the sensitivity pattern.  Conclusion:  The unique aspect of this case is the development of native-valve infective endocarditis in a patient with no other identifiable risk factor other than poorly controlled diabetes  hypertension  and obesity. It’s noteworthy that these factors  while contributing to an increased risk of infection  have not typically been implicated in the development of native-valve infective endocarditis. Further research is required to clarify this potential association.   The patient responded well to the focused antibiotic therapy and showed clinical recovery. There was a significant reduction in vegetation size upon repeating the echocardiography after six weeks of treatment. The patient was advised to maintain control of his blood sugar level rigorously and to seek early medical attention should he experience similar symptoms in the future.

Title: A Case Report of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Male with Pre-existing Rheumatic Heart Disease  Patient Demographic and Medical History:  Mr. A is a 54-year-old Caucasian male working as a truck driver  who presented to the emergency department with an approximately three-week history of malaise  weakness  and low-grade fever.? He resides in a suburban neighborhood of San Francisco  California and is not aware of any familial diseases or prominent genetic disposition to cardiovascular diseases.   He has a past medical history (PMH) significant for rheumatic heart disease (RHD)  a diagnosis established ten years earlier due to recurrent rheumatic fever during his childhood. His compliance with prophylactic antibiotic treatment was inconsistent due to his mobile work demand. He is also a heavy smoker (30 pack-years) and reports occasional alcohol intake but denies any illegal drug use. He is married for 27 years and has two adult children.   Clinical Findings:  On arrival  Mr. A was found to be febrile (38C)  and laboratory results revealed an elevated WBC count (15 x 10^3/uL) with significant neutrophilia  indicating an ongoing systemic infection. Blood cultures were taken  and wide-spectrum antibiotic therapy was initiated.   On further cardiac evaluation with echocardiography  consequent to a new murmur noted on physical examination  a large mobile vegetation was identified on the mitral valve with severe mitral regurgitation  satisfying the major criteria for infective endocarditis (IE).  Microbiological Assessment: Microbiological analysis of the blood cultures showed growth of Streptococcus viridans  a native oral flora typically associated with native valve infective endocarditis if aspir or underlying valvular heart disease is present.   Management and Outcome: Mr. A was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis secondary to Streptococcus viridans. He was started on IV Penicillin and Gentamicin as per the standard treatment guidelines. Post six weeks of IV antibiotics  there was a significant improvement in his symptoms; however  the size of vegetation and the severity of mitral regurgitation remained almost unchanged. Hence  patient was referred to cardiothoracic surgery and underwent successful mitral valve replacement with bioprosthetic material.  Follow-Up:  On follow-up one month post-operatively  the patient reported significant improvement of dyspnea and fatigue. He was highly encouraged to quit smoking and taking antibiotic prophylaxis before future dental procedures to prevent recurrent infective endocarditis. The importance of adherence to the prescribed antibiotics and follow-up cardiac check-ups was emphasized.   Conclusions:  This case demonstrates the development of native valve endocarditis in the setting of pre-existing rheumatic heart disease. High suspicion for IE is warranted in patients presenting with prolonged febrile illness  history of RHD  and new cardiac murmur. Early detection and appropriate management  including timely surgical intervention  are crucial to a positive prognosis.
