Encouraging smoking cessation  adherence to prophylactic antibiotic regimens  and follow-up are vital for prevention of recurrent IE in such high-risk individuals.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Caucasian Female with a History of Intravenous Drug Use  Case Presentation:  A 45-year-old Caucasian female presented herself to the emergency room with a two-week history of fever  chills  fatigue  and notable weight loss. Gait instability and occasional moments of confusion were also reported. The patient resides in a suburban area and declares herself as an active intravenous drug user  a habit which she has been struggling to overcome for the last 7 years.  Medical History:  Upon further probing  it was discovered that she has a past medical history of recurrent skin abscesses  chronic hepatitis C infection  and depression. She also reports having a heart murmur in her childhood but was never treated or monitored and denies any familial history of heart disease. She has not been seeking professional medical care on a regular basis due to financial constraints and fear of stigmatization. She is a current tobacco smoker and declares occasional alcohol consumption.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  the patient was febrile with a temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°F). The heart exam revealed a loud pansystolic murmur best heard at the apex and a diastolic rumble at the lower left sternal border. Skin inspection showed multiple track marks indicating intravenous drug use  along with few petechiae. Neurological examination revealed mild cognitive impairment assessed by the Montreal Cognitive Assessment tool. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Her initial blood work showed leukocytosis with prominent left shift  anemia  elevated inflammatory markers (C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation rate)  and slightly impaired renal function. Three sets of blood cultures were positive for Streptococcus againness - a highly suggestive evidence of infective endocarditis. Electrocardiogram showed no abnormalities.   Further diagnostic work-up included a transesophageal echocardiogram  that confirmed the presence of a large mobile vegetation on the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve  observed in conjunction with a significant mitral regurgitation. These were strongly supportive of a diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis.  Patient's course and therapy:  Following multidisciplinary discussion  the patient was started on a course of appropriate antibiotics  as per the guidelines suggested by the American Heart Association  for Streptococcal infective endocarditis. The psycho-social service team and addiction specialty teams were consulted to manage her addiction issues and cognitive decline. Due to the large size of the vegetation and evidence of systemic complications  urgent surgical intervention for valve replacement was also considered.  Conclusion:  This case emphasizes the importance of thorough clinical and social history taking  particularly focusing on drug misuse in the setting of potential infective endocarditis. The management of infective endocarditis in intravenous drug users can be complex  requiring a multi-disciplinary approach  stretching beyond just the microbial treatment  and addressing underlying social and psychological issues.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged  Caucasian Male  Patient Information:  Mr. Johnson is a 54-year-old  Caucasian male of average build  who works as a carpenter. He presented to our hospital with a one-week history of persistent fever associated with night sweats  malaise  and weight loss. He had a past medical history of moderate rheumatoid arthritis but had been in good health otherwise. He never smoked and drank alcohol only socially. There was no recent history of intravenous drug use.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination revealed an ill-looking patient. He was febrile (38.2°C)  with a blood pressure of 135/85 mmHg and a pulse rate of 80 beats per minute. A new early diastolic murmur was heard at the left upper parasternal area  suggestive of aortic regurgitation. Multiple Janeway lesions were apparent on the palms and soles on further examination.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Initial blood tests showed an elevated white cell count and C-reactive protein  suggesting an infectious process. Blood cultures taken on three different occasions turned out positive for Staphylococcus aureus.  A transesophageal echocardiogram showed a large (1.5 cm X 2 cm)  mobile vegetation on the aortic valve with associated significant aortic regurgitation and dilatation of the aortic root. The findings were consistent with a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Treatment and Outcome:  The patient was started on intravenous antibiotics (nafcillin and gentamicin)  following Infectious Disease Society of America's guidelines. Rheumatology was consulted for the management of his autoimmune disease in the setting of the infection. After two weeks of treatment  the patient’s symptoms diminished  and inflammatory markers started to decline.  The patient was recommended for surgical intervention due to the large size of the vegetation  signs of uncontrolled infection  and presence of significant aortic regurgitation. He underwent successful aortic valve replacement and was discharged after being stabilized and asymptomatic. Antibiotics were continued post-surgery for six weeks. On three-month follow-up  the patient was doing well with no signs of recurrent infection.  Conclusion:   This case highlights the importance of early diagnosis and appropriate management of native-valve infective endocarditis  a potentially life-threatening condition. Clinicians should have a high index of suspicion for this disease in patients presenting with persistent fever and new cardiac murmurs  even in the absence of traditional risk factors such as intravenous drug use.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Adult Male: A Case Report  Patient Information:   A 76-year-old Caucasian male was admitted to our medical facility with persistent fever  malaise  and weight loss. The patient resides in a suburban community  is retired  and lives with his spouse. His family history was non-contributory.  Medical History:  The patient has a medical history of type II diabetes managed with metformin  hypertension controlled with lisinopril  occasional atrial fibrillation treated with amiodarone  and no known allergies. He had undergone a prostatectomy 10 years ago due to benign prostatic hyperplasia but currently had no urological complaints. He had never smoked and reported moderate alcohol consumption.   Symptoms:  Over the past month  the patient experienced a consistent fever of 38.5°C  along with fatigue  muscle aches  and a weight loss of 5kgs  prompting his visit to the hospital.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  a heart murmur was heard in the aortic region and Janeway lesions were observed on the palms and soles. The patient appeared pale and mildly breathless. Lab tests revealed elevated white blood cell count (WBC 13000/uL) with a left shift  increased ESR (80mm/hr)  and C-reactive protein (CRP; 56 mg/L). His kidney function tests showed impaired renal function; serum creatinine was 1.6 mg/dL. Blood sugar and other laboratory parameters were within the normal range.  Diagnosis:  Based on the clinical findings and investigations  the diagnosis was native-valve infective endocarditis (NVIE). Blood cultures identified Staphylococcus aureus as the causative agent. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) visualized a vegetation on the aortic valve  confirming the diagnosis.  Treatment:  The patient was treated with a six-week course of intravenous ceftriaxone and gentamicin  as per the current treatment regimen for methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) endocarditis. His condition improved gradually over the treatment course with resolution of fever and decline in inflammatory markers.  Outcome:  At a three-month follow-up  the patient has remained fever-free and without symptoms. Echocardiography showed a reduction in the size of the vegetation on the aortic valve. He was recommended regular monitoring of cardiac status and liver and renal function tests.   This case highlights the importance of establishing a prompt diagnosis of infective endocarditis in elderly patients presenting with persistent fever  especially in those with predisposing conditions like diabetes  hypertension  and atrial fibrillation. Early diagnosis and treatment are key to improving patient outcomes for this serious and potentially fatal disease.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Caucasian Male  Introduction: Non-rheumatic native-valve infective endocarditis (IE) is a serious cardiovascular condition  often associated with increased morbidity and mortality. Here  we discuss a case of a 53-year-old Caucasian male patient presenting with IE  highlighting clinical  diagnostic  treatment  and follow-up aspects of the condition.  Case Presentation: A 53-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of intravenous drug use  Hepatitis C  and alcohol abuse was admitted to the emergency department. The patient had been experiencing persistent fever  malaise  shortness of breath  and intermittent chest pain for the past three weeks. Chronic cough and unintentional weight loss of around 4 kg over the last month were also noted. He was unemployed and reported no recent hospitalizations or dental procedures. No family history of any cardiac or infectious diseases was noted.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed poor dental hygiene  pallor  a diastolic murmur in the aortic area  bilateral crackles on lung auscultation  and peripheral stigmata of IE  like Osler nodes and Janeway lesions. Hepatomegaly and splenomegaly were also palpated on abdominal examination.  Diagnostic Assessment: Routine blood tests showed leukocytosis  anemia  and increased inflammatory markers (ESR  CRP). Liver enzymes were raised  correlating with the patient's hepatic condition. Blood cultures were positive for Staphylococcus aureus  confirming suspicion of bacterial endocarditis as per the Duke Criteria. Transthoracic and transesophageal echocardiograms revealed vegetations on the native aortic valve  moderate aortic regurgitation  and an aortic root abscess.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately initiated on empirical antibiotic therapy  which was later tailored according to the culture and sensitivity report. Urgent surgical intervention was planned due to the presence of complications (aortic abscess and severe aortic regurgitation)  and an aortic valve replacement was performed.  Follow Up: The postoperative period was uneventful  and the patient showed significant symptomatic improvement. He was discharged on a long-term antibiotic regimen and regular follow-ups were scheduled. Improved dental hygiene was strongly advised. The patient was also referred to addiction counselling services for substance abuse management.  Conclusion: This case report underscores the importance of early recognition and management of IE in high-risk populations  with a focus on a comprehensive diagnostic approach and the implementation of appropriate drug and surgical treatment strategies. Long-term follow-ups are essential to monitor the patient's clinical condition  cardiac function  and to ensure successful substance abuse management.

Case Report: Native-valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-aged African American Male  Patient Profile:  Demographics: African-American Male  Aged 57  Occupation: Unemployed  Marital Status: Divorced  Location: Urban Area; Patient currently residing in Chicago  Illinois  Living Situation: Lives alone in a rented apartment.  Social History: The patient smokes half a pack of cigarettes per day and reports moderate alcohol consumption.  Medical History:  The patient has well-controlled hypertension and Type II diabetes mellitus for the past 12 years and a history of intravenous drug use although he has been clean for the last two years. He is currently on medication for both conditions  receiving Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension. He has a family history of heart disease.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient was admitted with a week's history of fever  chills  night sweats  and increased fatigue. The patient also reported weight loss and loss of appetite.  Clinical Examination:  Upon examination  he was found to have a low-grade fever of 38.2 °C and a heart rate of 110 bpm. Cardiac examination showed a new murmur and a few painless lesions on his fingers and palms  compatible with Janeway lesions.  Investigations:  Three different sets of blood cultures were positive for Staphylococcus aureus. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) demonstrated a 2.1 cm vegetation on the ventricular side of the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve. Laboratory test reports showed elevated white cell count and C-reactive protein level. The patient was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis.  Management and Course:  The patient was initiated on empiric intravenous antibiotic therapy with vancomycin and gentamicin. He showed clinical improvement after 2 weeks of treatment  with resolution of fever and decrease in fatigue. However  due to the size of the vegetation and the continued presence of the mitral regurgitation despite antibiotic therapy  it was decided to refer the patient for valve replacement surgery. The patient successfully underwent mitral valve replacement and post-operatively continued on intravenous antibiotics for a total of 6 weeks.   Follow up:  After discharge  he was on regular follow-up with cardiology and infectious disease clinics. After six months  he remains clinically stable with regular adherence to his medication regimen.  This case illustrates the importance of early recognition and treatment of native-valve infective endocarditis and the potential need for surgical interventions even if there is clinical improvement on antibiotic therapy. It also highlights the relationship between a history like that of our patient's - including smoking  controlled diabetes and hypertension  and prior intravenous drug use - and the risk for developing this serious condition.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Diabetic Male: A Case Report  Introduction:  Infective endocarditis is a life-threatening bacterial or fungal infection of the heart valves  which is relatively uncommon but potentially fatal if not quickly diagnosed and treated. This report deals with a case of native-valve infective endocarditis in a middle-aged male patient.  Patient Information:  The patient is a 50-year-old African American male with a history of poorly controlled type II diabetes mellitus  recurrent staphylococcal skin infections  and a 20 pack-year smoking history. The patient resides in an urban middle-class neighborhood in New York City and works as an auto mechanic. He is married  with 2 children. His family history revealed that his mother had type II diabetes and died from a stroke in her late sixties  and his father had hypertension and died from heart failure.  Chief Complaint:  The patient presented to the hospital primarily complaining of 2 weeks of worsening fever  fatigue  a new heart murmur  and unexplained weight loss. He also reported having shortness of breath  night sweats  and occasional confusion.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination showed the patient was febrile with temperature of 38.7 °C  blood pressure 130/80 mmHg  pulse 110 bpm  and respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. Cardiac examination revealed a diastolic murmur. Ophthalmic examination demonstrated Roth spots  and Janeway lesions were observed on the palms and soles. Auscultation of the lung fields was normal.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Blood cultures revealed the presence of Staphylococcus aureus. A transthoracic echocardiogram showed vegetation on the patient’s native mitral valve  indicative of infective endocarditis. The patient's poorly controlled diabetes  combined with his history of recurrent staphylococcal skin infections and smoking  were factors that potentially contributed to his developing infective endocarditis.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was initiated on tailored intravenous antibiotic treatment regimen based on the blood culture sensitivity result. The glycaemic status was addressed and blood sugar was controlled with insulin therapy. Through consultation with a cardiothoracic surgeon  decision for surgical intervention was postponed  and focus remained on antimicrobial therapy.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  After six weeks of tailored antibiotic treatment  the patient's fever subsided and his symptoms gradually improved. A repeat echocardiogram showed a reduction in the vegetation size. He was discharged with oral antibiotic regimen and a strict follow-up for his diabetes management.  Conclusion:  The case highlighted the importance of prompt recognition and early aggressive treatment of native valve infective endocarditis. Also  it emphasized on the need of control of comorbidities  like diabetes  in preventing severe complications or the progress of the disease.

Title: A Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Female  Introduction: Infective endocarditis (IE) is an infection of the inner lining of the heart valves that can lead to severe complications if not recognized and treated promptly. Native-valve infective endocarditis (NVIE) refers to the disease occurring in patients without prior valve replacement.   Patient Information:   The patient is an 80-year-old post-menopausal female  residing in an assisted living facility in New York. She is a retired bank manager  a lifelong non-smoker  and occasional alcohol-user  with no family history of IE.  Past Medical History:  The patient has been living with a history of hypertension for the last 20 years  managed with Lisinopril and Metoprolol. She was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes about 10 years ago and has been under a dietician for dietary management and continuous use of Metformin. Five years earlier  she was diagnosed with mild mitral regurgitation and has been under observation with routine outpatient follow-ups. The patient received regular dental care  with her last dental cleaning procedure done 3 months ago.   Case Presentation:  The patient was admitted to the department of cardiology with complaints of fever  night sweats  malaise  and intermittent palpitations over the last 3 weeks. On examination  she displayed a murmur on auscultation  with occasional irregular heart sounds  but no other significant findings were observed. A set of blood cultures were obtained  which grew Staphylococcus aureus. Transthoracic echocardiography revealed a vegetation on the mitral valve.   These findings  coupled with clinical symptoms and blood culture results  led to the diagnosis of NVIE. Given the patient's advanced age and history of diabetes and hypertension  she was considered high-risk. Consequently  the patient was initiated on appropriate intravenous antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone and gentamycin  following which symptoms gradually decreased.   Conclusion:  The case illustrates NVIE in an elderly female patient with pre-existing cardiac and metabolic conditions. Further investigation is required regarding the potential correlation between such conditions and the risk or progression of NVIE. The importance of early diagnosis and treatment is emphasized  given the potential for severe complications  especially in high-risk individuals. Finally  the role of routine dental care in preventing IE deserves further investigation  particularly in elderly individuals with previous valve pathology.  References:  (the references related to the case and research should be here)

Title: Native-valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Caucasian Female: A Case Report  Introduction:  This case report describes the presentation  diagnosis  and management of infective endocarditis in a 78-year-old Caucasian female. Despite the overall rarity of this disease  the incidence of infective endocarditis is higher in men  and in those aged 60 or above. This case report aims to contribute to the literature on infective endocarditis  highlighting its presentation in an elderly female patient.  Case Presentation:  A 78-year-old Caucasian woman  living in rural Pennsylvania  was admitted to the hospital with a week-long history of progressive shortness of breath  low-grade fever  and generalized malaise. Her past medical history included hypertension  atrial fibrillation  and osteoarthritis. She was on multiple medications  including warfarin  metoprolol  and lisinopril. The patient has been a life-long non-smoker and consumed minimal alcohol. There is no family history of cardiac diseases or infections.  On physical examination  she appeared chronically ill  and her vitals were stable  albeit her blood pressure was on the low side (90/50 mmHg). Cardiovascular examination revealed an early diastolic murmur and a mid-systolic click. Other physical findings included splinter hemorrhages in the nail bed and Osler nodes noted on her fingers.   Investigations:  Given her presentation  a blood culture was determined and echocardiography was scheduled. The blood culture demonstrated the presence of Staphylococcus aureus. The transesophageal echocardiography confirmed the presence of two vegetations (10mm and 8mm) on her native mitral valve  suggestive of infective endocarditis.  Management and Follow-Up:  The patient was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis and started on intravenous vancomycin. Cardiology was involved for possible valve replacement consideration. The patient responded well to the antibiotic therapy and showed significant clinical improvement. Surgery was deferred due to the patient's frailty and improving clinical condition. Her condition was stabilized  and she was discharged with a home healthcare plan  including continued antibiotic therapy. The patient was asked to visit the outpatient clinic for a follow-up  where periodic echocardiograms were scheduled.  Conclusion:  This case illustrates that a high clinical suspicion is often necessary for diagnosing infective endocarditis  especially in elderly patients with nonspecific symptoms. Elderly patients' care should be multidisciplinary  involving cardiology  infectious disease specialists  and primary physicians  to guarantee optimal management and follow-up.  Patient Consent:   Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.

Title: Infective Endocarditis Complicates a Patient with Native Valve  Case Report:  Introduction:  The patient is a Caucasian male  65-year-old retiree with a medical history significant for Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM)  hypertension  and moderate tobacco use who presented with a 2-week history of fatigue  recurrent fever  and weight loss. He was admitted to the hospital after a physical examination revealed a diastolic murmur along with splinter hemorrhages in the fingernails.   Medical History:  The patient was diagnosed with T2DM ten years ago and hypertension five years ago. Both conditions are managed with Metformin and Lisinopril  respectively  with a stable diet and exercise regime. The patient reported smoking half a pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years. He had no previous heart-related issues nor a history of injection drug use. He also had an allergic reaction to Penicillin two years ago during a dental procedure.  Clinical Findings:  Upon admission  the patient was febrile with a temperature of 38.5°C. Lab tests revealed leukocytosis (14 000 µL)  with elevated ESR (60mm/h) and C-reactive protein (45mg/L). Blood cultures were positive for Streptococcus viridans. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) showed a vegetation in the aortic valve suggestive of infective endocarditis. Chest radiographs and CT scan were normal.  Diagnosis:  The patient met the modified Duke criteria for infective endocarditis - two major (positive blood cultures and endocardial involvement) and three minor (fever  vascular phenomena  and immunological phenomena). Combining these clinical findings with his lab results  the patient was diagnosed with native valve infective endocarditis.  Treatment:  The patient was started on empiric therapy with a combination of Vancomycin and Gentamicin due to his penicillin allergy. Anticoagulants were not prescribed due to risk of cerebral hemorrhage.  Outcome:  The patient responded favorably to treatment. His fever subsided  and he reported a significant improvement in his general well-being. A repeat TTE showed a decrease in vegetation size. The patient was discharged on a six weeks course of antibiotics.  Discussion:  This case underscores the importance of timely diagnosis and management of infective endocarditis in patients presenting with nonspecific signs and symptoms  especially in those with risk factors such as T2DM  hypertension  and tobacco use. While the patient had a relatively benign course  infective endocarditis can lead to serious consequences such as heart failure or systemic embolization if not promptly recognized and treated.   Informed Consent:  The informed content to discuss the patient's clinical situation anonymously in this case report has been obtained in written form. There is no identifiable content for the patient. It also follows the Declaration of Helsinki written in 1975 and updated in 2008 that must be taken into account to protect patient's rights.   References:  Information about the disease  diagnosis  treatment and follow up were taken from standard medical textbooks  peer-reviewed articles related to the disease studied and clinical practice guidelines.

Title: A Case Report on Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Female with Previous Mitral Valve Prolapse   Abstract:   We report the case of a 52-year-old Caucasian female who presented to the health care facility with fever  malaise  and progressive shortness of breath. The patient had been previously diagnosed with a mitral valve prolapse but was not on any specific treatment. After an evaluation  the patient was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis (IE).   Case Presentation:  The patient  a 52-year-old Caucasian female  presented to the emergency department with complaints of persistent high-grade fever  malaise  fatigue and progressive shortness of breath over a week. The patient is a non-smoker  non-alcoholic  and denied any illicit drug use. Her medical history revealed a mitral valve prolapse which was diagnosed 2 years ago  but she was not undergoing any specific treatment.  On examination  the patient appeared ill  with a temperature of 38.9°C. Cardiac examination revealed a diastolic murmur best heard at the cardiac apex. The patient had no skin lesions  no signs of peripheral emboli  or any evident neurological deficit.   Investigations:  Suspecting IE  blood cultures were drawn that grew Streptococcus sanguinis. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) and subsequently performed Transesophageal Echocardiography (TEE)  revealed a vegetation on her mitral valve  confirming a diagnosis of native-valve IE.  Treatment:  On diagnosis  the patient was immediately started on intravenous penicillin and gentamicin therapy with a planned course of 6 weeks. The patient responded well to treatment  and her symptoms gradually dissipated over a couple of weeks.   Conclusion:  Native-valve IE remains a critical condition requiring an early diagnosis and prompt antibiotic therapy. This case emphasizes the importance of educating patients with known valvular diseases about the potential risk of endocarditis. Regular follow-ups are paramount  particularly in patients with valvular heart diseases  as they are at increased risk of developing infective endocarditis.  Keywords: Streptococcus sanguinis; Mitral valve prolapse; Native valve endocarditis; Case report.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Female: A Case Report   Introduction: Infective Endocarditis (IE) is a severe infection of the heart valves and endocardial surface. Native valve endocarditis  an infection of the heart's native valves  is more common than prosthetic valve infection  and its incidence increases with age  especially in those over 60 years of age. We report a case of an 82-year-old female patient with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis (NVE).  Case Presentation: An 82-year-old African-American female presented to the emergency department with a seven-day history of progressive shortness of breath  fatigue  and general malaise. She reported her symptoms to be more pronounced during her routine activities.   Her past medical history was significant for hypertension  controlled with Lisinopril and mild osteoarthritis. She has no known allergies and had no previously reported heart conditions. She denies any tobacco  alcohol  or drug use. She has no family history of heart diseases.  On examination  the patient appeared slightly fatigued. Her blood pressure was 145/85 mmHg  heart rate 98 bpm  SpO2 94% on room air  and temperature 37.5-degree Celsius. Cardiac auscultation revealed a 3/6 systolic murmur over the left lower sternal border.  Investigations: Laboratory tests were done  which revealed positive blood cultures significant for Staphylococcus aureus. Her CBC showed a high white blood cell count of 13.5 x 10^3/uL. ESR and CRP levels were significantly elevated. ECG detected no signs of ischemia or arrhythmia.   A transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) was performed  revealing vegetations on the aortic valve  with moderate aortic valve regurgitation. These findings were consistent with the Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis (NVE).   Management and Outcome: She was immediately commenced on empiric antibiotic therapy with vancomycin and ceftriaxone. After the blood culture results  considering the sensitivity and resistance profile  the antibiotics were switched to oxacillin. The patient responded well to the antibiotics and showed signs of clinical improvement over the next few days. Gradually  her symptoms improved and blood cultures sterilized after 2 weeks of therapy.  Due to her age and comorbidities  surgical intervention was deferred  and she was managed medically. The patient completed six weeks of antibiotic therapy. Follow-up TEE after eight weeks showed reduced vegetation size with mild residual aortic regurgitation.  Conclusion: This case illustrates the significance of high clinical suspicion for infective endocarditis in elderly patients presenting with non-specific symptoms. Swift diagnosis and appropriate management are crucial in native-valve infective endocarditis to prevent complications and to ensure improved patient outcomes.

Title: Native-valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-aged Caucasian Male with a History of Intravenous Drug Use  Introduction:  Infective endocarditis (IE) is an inflammation of the endocardial surface of the heart  mainly affecting the valves  due to infection by microorganisms. It is more common among those with a history of heart disease  those who have undergone invasive procedures  and those with a history of intravenous drug use. We present the case of a patient with native-valve infective endocarditis with unique clinical features.   Case Report: The patient was a 45-year-old Caucasian male  unemployed  with a known history of chronic intravenous drug use (primarily heroin) for over 20 years. He presented to the emergency department with a 3-week history of progressive malaise  night sweats  weight loss  and a new-onset transient ischemic attack (TIA). There was no history of IV access  dental procedures  or infected skin sores in the recent past. His other medical history included hepatitis C infection  diagnosed 10 years prior  and recurrent bouts of cellulitis due to his drug use. The patient had a long history of non-compliance with medical advice and had disengaged from drug rehabilitation programs in the past. He had no known allergies.  On examination  he was febrile (38.5 degree Celsius) with a heart rate of 100 bpm. Physical examination revealed pallor  poor dentition  and multiple track marks indicative of long-standing intravenous drug use. Cardiac examination showed a new grade III/VI systolic murmur best heard at the apex.  Blood cultures were drawn  and the results revealed methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) bacteremia. Transthoracic echocardiography showed a large  mobile 15mm vegetation on the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve  with moderate mitral regurgitation.  The diagnosis of Native valve infective endocarditis (IE) was made and the patient was started on empirical intravenous antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone  according to guidelines. His hepatitis C infection was also managed in coordination with a hepatologist. He was referred to cardiothoracic surgery  but he refused surgical intervention.  As a result  he was committed to a long-term plan involving continued intravenous antibiotics  regular follow-ups  and a referral to addiction services for primary management of his underlying illicit drug use. His clinical condition improved over his hospital stay and he was discharged with outpatient antibiotic therapy and close follow up.  Conclusion: This case report underscores the vulnerability of intravenous drug users to native-valve infective endocarditis. It also highlights the importance of multidisciplinary care involving addiction services in managing such complex patients. A high index of suspicion  early diagnosis  and aggressive treatment helps in reducing the morbidity and mortality associated with this condition. However  the patient's lack of willingness to undergo surgical interventions constitutes a major barrier to a full recovery.

Title: A Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged African-American Male  Introduction: Native-valve infective endocarditis (IE) is a rare but serious infection  often resulting in illness and death. This case report provides an illustrative example of IE in a middle-aged African-American male.  Case Presentation:  The patient  a 52-year-old African American male  presented at the emergency department with a week-long history encompassing high fevers  chills  sweats  loss of appetite  and episodes of confusion. He had also been experiencing moderate chest pain that intensified upon lying flat but eased on sitting up. The patient had an unremarkable family health history but had notable past medical history  including untreated hypertension  a fifteen year history of intravenous drug use (IVDU)  and recent rehabilitation for abuse of cocaine and opioids. He had been tobacco-free for three years but had a 15 pack-year smoking history.   Physical examination revealed clammy and mildly jaundiced skin  low blood pressure (90/60mmHg)  elevated heart rate of 110 beats per minute  and a temperature of 38.8°C suggestively febrile. Cardiac auscultation discovered an early diastolic murmur consistent with aortic regurgitation. Auscultation of the lungs uncovered crackles in the lower lung fields. Ophthalmic inspection confirmed Roth’s spots  visual evidence of IE.   Blood cultures positively identified Staphylococcus aureus consistent with native-valve infective endocarditis. A subsequent transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) further validated an aortic valve vegetation measuring approximately 1.5cm by 1.0cm. No valvular insufficiency or damage to surrounding structures was detected  although moderate aortic regurgitation was present.   Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) and a subsequent transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) indicated no evidence of intracardiac abscess formation or any other form of intracardiac complication. The patient's diagnosis was native-valve infective endocarditis  secondary to methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA).   The patient was managed with a six-week regimen of intravenous nafcillin to treat MSSA-induced IE. Additionally  blood pressure control was maintained with medications. The patient was also provided with counseling and resources to address his history of substance abuse.   Conclusion:  This case emphasizes the importance of quick diagnosis and treatment of IE  particularly in vulnerable populations like intravenous drug users. It also stresses the necessity of monitoring and providing comprehensive care for patients with a history of heart disease and concurrent drug use to prevent serious infections like native-valve infective endocarditis.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in A Middle-aged Asian Female: A Case Study  Introduction:  Native-valve infective endocarditis (IE) involves the infection of a person's original heart valves  a rare condition that can lead to severe cardio-vascular complications if not timely diagnosed and treated. This case report describes the case of a 45-year-old Asian female presenting with symptoms suggestive of infective endocarditis.  Case Presentation:  Demographic Information: The patient is a 45-year-old Asian female  born and raised in rural India. She is a married housewife and the primary caretaker of her three children. She has no history of drug or alcohol use and is a non-smoker.  Past Medical History: The patient has had a medical history of rheumatic heart disease at an earlier age and has not undergone any surgeries or procedures. There's no family history of cardio-vascular disease. She was on medication for her rheumatic heart condition  however  she discontinued the medication two years ago due to financial constraints.   Presenting Complaints: The patient reported persistent high-grade fever for two weeks  accompanied by chills  night sweats  loss of appetite and weight. She has been experiencing generalized body weakness  mild abdominal discomfort  breathlessness on exertion and palpitations.  Investigations and Diagnosis: Initial investigations revealed marked leukocytosis and anemia. Blood cultures were isolated positive for Staphylococcus aureus. Transthoracic echocardiogram demonstrated vegetation on the native mitral valve. On further examination  Janeway lesions were also observed on the soles of her feet and palms of her hands. She was also diagnosed with acute kidney injury. Based on these findings  a diagnosis of Native-valve Infective Endocarditis was made.  Treatment and Outcome: The patient was started on empirical antibiotic therapy  as per the American Heart Association's guidelines  with intravenous vancomycin and gentamicin. Renal function was closely monitored due to concurrent acute kidney injury. After four weeks  her symptoms subsided  lab results normalized and repeat echocardiography showed a significant reduction in vegetation size. The patient was advised long-term prophylaxis and provided assistance to access and adhere to medication in the future.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of early diagnosis and aggressive treatment of native-valve infective endocarditis  especially in patients with a medical history of valvular disease like rheumatic heart disease. The case provides an insight into financial barriers contributing to the discontinuation of treatment in rural areas  emphasizing the need for improved access to care. Furthermore  it showcases the need for long-term infection prophylaxis to prevent the recurrence of IE in such individuals.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in An Elderly Female: A Case Report  Patient Demographic Information:  The patient is a 72-year-old African American female  retired  known case of type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. She has no known allergies and doesn't consume alcohol or use illicit drugs. She has no family history of cardiac illness but most of her family members are diabetic and hypertensive.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient initially presented with new onset dyspnea  loss of appetite  unintended weight loss and low-grade fever persisting for a month.  Investigations:  Physical examination revealed pallor and a diastolic murmur best heard at left mid-sternal border. Laboratory studies revealed a WBC count of 15000 cells/µL  erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 50 mm/hour and C-reactive protein (CRP) of 30 mg/dL. Blood cultures were taken and sent for testing. The echocardiogram showed a mobile vegetation of 1.5cm on the aortic valve consistent with infective endocarditis.  Disease Course:  Her condition was complicated by an episode of stroke within 12 hours of her hospital admission. An evaluation for underlying embolic cause was carried out  and a transthoracic echocardiogram was done promptly. It showed the presence of an echogenic non-calcified mass attached to the aortic valve cusps strongly suggestive of vegetation. Cerebral computed tomography ruled out cerebral abscess but confirmed ischemic stroke.  Patient Management:  She was initiated on empiric broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy for the management of endocarditis. It was then de-escalated to targeted therapy based on her blood culture and sensitivity results which revealed methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA).  Her condition improved significantly with antibiotics and supportive care. However  given the occurrence of stroke and the relatively large size of vegetations  she was evaluated for urgent surgical intervention. Balancing her age  co-morbidities  and potential complications  it was decided to continue medical management with close monitoring. She was discharged after 4 weeks of intravenous antibiotics with a plan for close follow-up.  Conclusions:  The present case illustrates the presentation of native-valve infective endocarditis in an elderly female patient. Importantly  this patient's experience highlights the relevance of taking into account the aging population and their increased vulnerability to this condition  especially those with other comorbidities like diabetes and hypertension.  This case also underlines the importance of an early diagnosis  aggressive antibiotic therapy  and proactive decision-making regarding surgical intervention aided by a multidisciplinary team. The presence of neurological complications should prompt the clinician to evaluate the need for early surgery albeit in the context of the patient’s overall health status and risk-benefit balance.

Title: Native Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Male with a History of Rheumatic Heart Disease and Diabetes Mellitus: A Case Report  Introduction: Infective endocarditis (IE) is a severe infection with significant morbidity and mortality. IE is most common in older individuals  typically aged 60 years and above. Native valve endocarditis occurs more commonly than prosthetic valve or device-related endocarditis. Herein  we report a case of an elderly patient with a history of rheumatic heart disease and diabetes mellitus  who presented with native valve endocarditis.  Case Presentation: A 74-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department with complaints of intermittent  high-grade fever and unexplained weight loss for a period of 1 month. The patient reported increasing fatigue and shortness of breath over the past week. In the past  he had been diagnosed with rheumatic heart disease and type 2 diabetes mellitus which was under control with oral hypoglycemic agents.  On physical examination  the patient appeared lethargic and pale. He was febrile with a temperature of 38.5°C. Cardiac auscultation revealed a pansystolic murmur best heard at the apex. The patient’s blood pressure and heart rate were within normal limits. There was no evidence of peripheral stigmata of infective endocarditis.  Investigations:  The patient's blood tests showed increased inflammatory markers with a raise in ESR and CRP values. His blood cultures subsequently grew Streptococcus viridans  suggestive of a bacterial infection. Transthoracic echocardiography revealed large vegetations on the mitral valve leaflets  consistent with infective endocarditis.  Treatment:  The patient was initiated on high-dose intravenous penicillin therapy  based on the antibiotic susceptibility of the infecting organism. The patient also received subcutaneous insulin for diabetes. Despite the initiation of antibiotic therapy  the patient remained febrile and symptomatic. After multidisciplinary consultation  decision was taken for surgical intervention. He underwent mitral valve replacement surgery with a bioprosthetic valve.  Outcome and Follow-up: The patient's post-operative course was uneventful with resolution of fever  improvement in clinical symptoms  and overall stable condition. He was subsequently started on oral antibiotics and discharged home after 2 weeks. The patient has been regularly followed up in the outpatients department over the past 6 months  displaying a good recovery trajectory.   Conclusion: This case emphasizes the importance of considering infective endocarditis in elderly patients with a history of rheumatic heart disease presenting with symptoms of unexplained fever  fatigue  and weight loss. Such patients warrant early and aggressive diagnosis and treatment strategies  including surgical intervention when required.

Title: A Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Caucasian Male  Patient Information:  The patient is a 57-year-old Caucasian male with a BMI of 28. His occupation is in manual labor  working as a carpenter for almost 30 years. He has been a smoker for the last 35 years  averaging about one pack of cigarettes per day. He also reports regular alcohol consumption  averaging about 3-4 beers every night after work. He denies any history of illicit drug use.   Past Medical History:  The patient has been diagnosed with hypertension for the last 10 years  which has been managed with Lisinopril 10mg once daily  and Metoprolol Tartrate 50mg twice daily. He has a well-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 8 years ago  which is managed with Metformin 1000mg twice daily. There is no known history of heart diseases in the family  though his father died of lung cancer at the age of 64.  Presenting Complaint and Clinical Findings:  The patient presented to the emergency department complaining of high-grade fever  fatigue  night sweats  and unintended weight loss over the past 3 weeks. Upon physical examination  the patient was found to have splinter hemorrhages on his nails  petechial rashes throughout his body  and Janeway lesions and Osler nodes in his extremities. These findings are consistent with the classical clinical manifestations of infective endocarditis.  Investigations:  Following the clinical examination  blood samples were taken for culture. A transthoracic echo-cardiogram was performed revealing vegetation on the native aortic valve with moderate regurgitation without any signs of valve perforation or abscess.  Hospital Course:  The patient was admitted to the cardiology unit for treatment and monitoring. His blood culture confirmed the presence of Streptococcus viridans  which is commonly seen in cases of native-valve infective endocarditis. The patient was started on a treatment regimen of intravenous penicillin G and gentamicin as per standard guidelines.   The patient's fever resolved within 72 hours following initiation of antibiotic therapy  although he remained hospitalized for an overall duration of four weeks to complete the recommended course of antimicrobial therapy.   In addition to his infection  the patient was also counseled on lifestyle modification  cutting down on smoking  and alcohol consumption  along with dietary control for his hypertension and diabetes.   Conclusion:  Infective endocarditis is a serious disease with high morbidity and mortality even after early recognition and aggressive treatment. A high level of clinical suspicion and early antibiotic therapy can greatly improve patient outcome. This case highlights the common clinical presentation and follow-up of a patient with native-valve infective endocarditis.

Title: Case Study: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 53-Year-Old Male  Introduction  This case report focuses on a 53-year-old Hispanic male diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis (NVE) in a clinical setting. Previous literature states that native valve infective endocarditis is more common in men  with higher incidence reported for patients between 30 to 60 years old. Ethnicity does not potentiate susceptibility  but certain comorbidities  lifestyle habits  and socioeconomic status can add to the risk of developing this disease. This case illustrates the clinical presentation  diagnostics  treatment  and long-term management of NVE.  Case Presentation  The patient  a 53-year-old Hispanic male  presented to the emergency department with intermittent fever  chills  and fatigue for the past three weeks. He reported a weight loss of about five pounds within the last month. He also complained of mild  diffuse joint pains and noted dark-colored urine for the past week.  History and Physical Examination  Patient’s past medical history revealed a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes mellitus  well-controlled through oral hypoglycemic agents. He had also been treated for hypertension for the past ten years and was on regular medication for the same. The patient was a non-smoker with mild alcohol consumption. He denied any substance abuse or risky sexual behavior. There was no familial history of cardiac conditions.  On physical examination  the patient was febrile (38.5 °C)  had mild pallor with a notable murmur on cardiac auscultation. There were no Osler's nodes or Janeway lesions. Other systems did not reveal any significant abnormalities.  Diagnostic Findings   Given the patient's clinical presentation  the initial working diagnosis was endocarditis. Blood cultures were obtained. Laboratory investigations showed raised inflammatory markers and anemia. The patients' creatinine levels were slightly elevated  indicating possible renal involvement.  Confirmatory diagnosis was made with a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE)  which showed vegetation on the mitral valve  without significant valvular insufficiency or stenosis.  Management and Outcome  The patient was admitted to the inpatient cardiac unit for antibiotic therapy based on suspected NVE  guided by blood culture results. Upon culture growth  the intravenous antibiotic regimen was adjusted to tailored therapy involving a 6-week course of intravenous ceftriaxone and gentamicin.  The patient’s clinical condition improved with treatment. Follow-up TTE revealed a reduction in vegetation size along with an improvement in the patient’s condition. Education and counseling on risk factor modification  adherence to medications and periodic follow-up visits were emphasized.  Conclusion  This case report illustrates a typical presentation of native-valve infective endocarditis. Prompt diagnosis and early initiation of treatment mitigated the potential averse effects and complications of the disease. This case underscores the importance of a high index of suspicion for endocarditis in patients presenting with fever and cardiac murmurs  particularly in those with comorbidities.  Future research should focus on strategies to timely recognize  intervene  and manage such cases to improve patient outcomes  reduce healthcare costs  and prevent disease-associated morbidity and mortality.

Title: Severe Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Male: A Case Report  Introduction: Infective endocarditis (IE) is a rare but severe condition indicating infection of the endocardial surface of the heart. Despite advancements in diagnostic modalities and treatment  IE continues to have a significant morbidity and mortality rate. This report describes a case of native-valve infective endocarditis in a 56-year-old Caucasian male patient.  Case Presentation:  The patient is a 56-year-old Caucasian male  working as an electrician  with a history of smoking and moderate daily alcohol consumption but no significant past medical history. He had no family history of heart disease. The patient lived in a suburban region in the Midwest United States and had no history of recent travel out of the state.  The patient initially presented to the primary care clinic with complaints of intermittent fever  myalgia  and weight loss for the last six weeks. On physical examination  he had small erythematous lesions on the palms and soles (Janeway lesions) and tiny hemorrhagic spots under his nails (splinter hemorrhages). A systolic murmur was noted on cardiac auscultation.   Investigations:  Given the clinical presentation  IE was suspected and further investigations were ordered  including blood cultures and an echocardiogram. Blood cultures were positive for Streptococcus viridans  confirming the diagnosis of infective endocarditis.  The patient was referred immediately to a cardiologist and a transesophageal echocardiogram was performed  which showed vegetations on the mitral valve with moderate regurgitation  confirming a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Management and Outcome:  The patient was admitted to the hospital and treated with appropriate intravenous antibiotic therapy as per the guidelines. Due to the presence of moderate mitral regurgitation and the poor response to the antibiotic therapy  the patient eventually required mitral valve replacement surgery. The post-operative period was uneventful. The patient was discharged on long-term oral antibiotics and was asked to follow up with cardiology regularly. On subsequent follow-up visits  the patient remained symptom-free with a well-functioning prosthetic mitral valve.  Conclusion:  This case report demonstrates the successful diagnosis and management of a relatively late-stage native-valve infective endocarditis in a middle-aged Caucasian male with no significant past medical history. Despite the delayed diagnosis and the development of mitral regurgitation  timely intervention and appropriate treatment resulted in a favorable outcome. This case also highlights the importance of early suspicion and diagnosis in patients presenting with non-specific symptoms like fever and weight loss in the context of suggestive physical findings.

Patient Case Report: 63-Year-Old Caucasian Male with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Demographics: Mr. A  a 63-year-old Caucasian male  presented himself to the emergency department with a two-week history of progressive fatigue  intermittent fever  night sweats  weight loss and dyspnea on exertion. He's an ex-smoker who quit smoking 20 years back. He states he's socially consuming alcohol. He works as a lawyer and leads a sedentary lifestyle. There was no personal or family history of heart diseases.  Past Medical History: He had been previously diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus and mild hypertension  both of which are well-controlled with medication (Metformin 1000 mg twice a day and Lisinopril 20 mg once a day). His cholesterol levels have also been in the high-normal range  managed through diet and lifestyle changes. Retired from his job 5 years ago but returned to work due to financial circumstances. An employee health check-up two years ago indicated no remarkable findings.  Physical Examination and Diagnosis: On admission  he was found to be febrile  tachycardic with a regular heart rhythm  blood pressure of 135/85 mmHg  and mild pallor. Cardiovascular examination revealed a diastolic murmur. There was no evidence of peripheral stigmata of endocarditis.   Investigations included blood cultures that showed the growth of Streptococcus viridans and an Echocardiogram which demonstrated a vegetative growth on the native mitral valve indicating infective endocarditis. His HbA1c was 6.5  suggesting good control of diabetes.  Medical Progress: Mr. A was started on intravenous penicillin and gentamicin for streptococcus viridans. After two weeks of therapy  his symptoms significantly improved and he was switched to oral antibiotics. He completed a six-week course under close clinical and echocardiographic follow-up. Two months post-treatment  he remained symptom-free  confirming the successful treatment of native valve infective endocarditis.  Discussion: Infective endocarditis (IE) is a microbial infection of the endothelial surface of the heart. The occurrence of IE in the general population is estimated to be between 1.7 and 6.2 cases per 100 000 person-years  with a higher incidence in males and older adults. This case underscores the importance of considering a diagnosis of IE in patients with persistent fever and constitutional symptoms. It also highlights the importance of early blood cultures and echocardiograms in the management of a febrile patient with a cardiac murmur.  Despite his sedentary lifestyle and age  Mr. A's direct engagement in his care  including compliant medication use  and his good control of diabetes and hypertension likely contributed to his effective recovery. This case demonstrates that with early detection and appropriate treatment  the morbidity associated with infective endocarditis can be significantly reduced.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Caucasian Female with a History of Intravenous Drug Use  Patient Presentation:   A 52-year-old Caucasian female was admitted to the emergency department with a 2-week history of fever  fatigue  malaise and a new onset of a petechial rash on her lower extremities. She had also noticed swelling in her feet and painful  red nodules (Osler's nodes) on her fingers and toes.  Demographics:  The patient is a single woman  unemployed  who lives alone in a metropolitan area. She admitted to being a habitual intravenous drug user  primarily heroin  for the past 5 years. The patient has had no previous hospitalizations or surgeries. She has no known allergies. Her family history indicates no genetic diseases. She mentions tobacco use but denies alcohol use.  Medical History:  Her past medical history includes hepatitis C  for which she had received treatment 3 years ago. Other than her addiction and hepatitis  she has no known significant medical history  and she has not regularly visited a physician for annual examinations  nor does she have a primary care provider. She is not on any medications and she denied being sexually active in the recent past.  Physical Examination:  The patient appeared ill and had a body temperature of 39.3°C. Her blood pressure was 95/60mmHg  heart rate was 105 beats/min  and respiratory rate was 18/min with a normal oxygen. Cardiac examination revealed a new 2/6 systolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border. There was no hepatosplenomegaly on abdominal examination. Skin examination showed multiple petechiae over the lower extremities and tender  raised erythematous nodules on the tips of her fingers and toes. No Janeway lesions were observed.  Investigations:  Laboratory examination showed an elevated white blood cell count of 13 000 cells/µL (normal range: 4 000−11 000 cells/µL) and elevated levels of C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Blood cultures were taken which confirmed the presence of Staphylococcus aureus. Echocardiography showed vegetation on the mitral valve  confirming the suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis. The patient also tested positive for HIV.  Diagnosis:  The diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis with secondary embolization was made based on the following Duke Criteria: sustained fever  positive blood cultures  presence of a heart murmur  characteristic vascular and immunological findings  and confirmed by echocardiography.  Treatment and Outcome:  The patient was immediately started on intravenous antibiotic therapy (vancomycin and gentamicin)  which led to improvement of symptoms over a period of several weeks. She was also initiated on highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) for HIV. Social services and a drug rehabilitation program were engaged for her long-term treatment and care. Regular monitoring for possible complications (renal failure  heart failure  septicemia) was established. Early intervention and aggressive treatment resulted in a disease-free survival at 6 months.  Learning points:  This case highlights the high risk of infective endocarditis in IV drug users and the importance of a comprehensive approach to diagnosis  treatment  and long-term care in this large and vulnerable patient population.

Title: A Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 52-Year-Old Male with a History of Valvular Heart Disease  Patient Information The patient is a 52-year-old Caucasian male residing in the urban area of Miami  Florida. He is a nonsmoker and a casual drinker.  Presenting Complaints The patient presented with a two-week history of fever  night sweats and unintentional weight loss. He also complained of generalized body weakness and fatigue.  Medical History The patient has a known history of valvular heart disease for seven years but has been managing it with lifestyle changes and regular medical appointments. He takes no other medications except a daily aspirin for heart health. He has no history of intravenous drug use or recent dental procedures. His father had early-onset heart disease while his mother is a breast cancer survivor.  Clinical Findings The examination was significant for a temperature of 38.6 degrees Celsius  heart rate of 98 beats per minute  and blood pressure of 120/80 mmHg. Heart auscultation revealed a diastolic murmur. He was pale  alert but not oriented to time. No Janeway lesions  Osler nodes  or petechial rashes were observed. The rest of the physical exam was unremarkable.  Diagnostic Assessment Two sets of blood cultures were obtained  returned positive for Streptococcus viridans  a typical organism associated with infective endocarditis. Echocardiography revealed vegetations on the mitral valve  confirming the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.   Therapeutic Intervention The patient received intravenous antibiotics as per the appropriate guideline for native-valve infective endocarditis. In his case  a four-week regimen of ceftriaxone and gentamicin was administered. His fever subsided after five days on antibiotics  and his symptoms improved steadily.  Follow-Up and Outcomes By the second week of treatment  body weakness and fatigue markedly improved. After completion of the antibiotic course  the patient was discharged. A follow-up outpatient transesophageal echocardiogram showed complete resolution of the vegetation. His renal function  liver function  and hematological parameters remained normal during the antibiotic therapy and at follow-up.  Patient Perspective The patient expressed gratitude for the successful treatment outcome  understanding the nature of his illness  and the severity should it was left untreated. He commits to adhering to control measures stipulated for valvular heart disease to prevent recurrence in the future.  Informed Consent The patient provided written informed consent for publication of this case report  and the case has been anonymized accordingly.  This report highlights the importance of early recognition and management of native-valve infective endocarditis  especially in patients with a history of valvular heart disease. Timely diagnosis and intervention can bring positive  even lifesaving results.

Title: Streptococcus viridans Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Male: A Case Report  Introduction: Infective endocarditis (IE) is a rare but serious disease worldwide  accounting for about 0.05% of all hospital admissions. Here  we report a case of native-valve infective endocarditis (NVIE) caused by Streptococcus viridans in a 56-year-old Caucasian male.  Case Presentation: A 56-year-old male  a non-smoker with a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes  presented to our hospital with a two-week history of intermittent high-grade fever  dyspnea  fatigue  and loss of appetite. The patient worked as an engineer with no other significant exposure history.   There was no family history of cardiac disorder or autoimmune diseases  and patient reported adherence with medications for previously diagnosed conditions. He denied alcohol or illicit drug use. He was not on any long-term immunosuppressive therapy and had no known allergies.  Clinical Examination and Diagnostic Assessment: Physical examination revealed a temperature of 39.2°C  heart rate of 105 beats/min  blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  and respiratory rate of 18 breaths/min. Cardiac auscultation revealed a diastolic murmur; no Osler's nodes or Janeway lesions were observed.  Laboratory test results showed leucocytosis with elevated C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Blood cultures were obtained that came back positive for Streptococcus viridans. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) showed a 1.2 cm x 1.5 cm mobile vegetative mass on the anterior cusp of mitral valve  with moderate mitral regurgitation.  Diagnosis and Treatment: The patient was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis caused by Streptococcus viridans based on the Duke criteria. He was started on empiric therapy with intravenous vancomycin and gentamicin  which was continued for 4 weeks.  Afterwards  the patient was evaluated for valve surgery considering the large vegetation size and ongoing infection  the decision was made to perform a surgical intervention. The patient underwent successful mitral valve replacement with a bioprosthetic valve and made an uneventful recovery.  Discussion: The current case emphasizes the importance of early identification of infective endocarditis  which despite being a rare event  can lead to life-threatening situations if not promptly identified and managed. Streptococcus viridans is a common causative organism  and given its resistance to many antibiotics  the choice of empirical antibiotics should be guided by local resistance patterns.  Conclusion: Timely diagnosis and therapy initiation are pivotal in NVIE  as it is associated with high mortality and morbidity rates. Both medical and surgical interventions should be considered and balanced  based on the individual's specific clinical context and overall health status.   Meticulous periodic follow-ups post-discharge with a focus on dental hygiene  lifestyle modifications  and medication adherence in these patients may reduce the risk of NVIE recurrence. Further research is mandated to optimize the standard of care for patients with NVIE.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged African American Female  Case Report:  Introduction: We report a case of a 54-year-old African American female with a known history of untreated dental caries who presented with native-valve infective endocarditis.  Clinical Presentation: The patient came to the hospital complaining of fever  malaise  weight loss  night sweats  and generalized body pains persisting for around four weeks. She was previously healthy and did not have a history of intravenous drug use  rheumatic heart disease  congenital heart disease  or previous valve surgery. She had no known allergies or family history of cardiac diseases.   Examination: The patient was found to be febrile with a temperature of 38.6°C and tachycardic with a heart rate of 112 bpm. Physical examination revealed dental caries and poor oral hygiene. Cardiac examination noted a new systolic murmur along the left sternal edge. Nail bed splinter hemorrhages and Janeway lesions were also observed.   Investigations: Blood tests showed increased inflammatory markers  and blood cultures were positive for Streptococcus mutans - a common microorganism linked to dental caries and endocarditis. Chest x-ray did not reveal any abnormalities. An Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed sinus tachycardia  but no other changes.   Echocardiography showed a significant vegetative growth on the mitral valve  confirming the diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis. It had led to a moderate mitral regurgitation. The remaining heart structures appeared normally.  Management: The patient was introduced to intravenous antibiotics (penicillin and gentamycin) per the American Heart Association's guidelines for endocarditis caused by S. mutans. After four weeks of intensive antimicrobial therapy  her symptoms improved considerably  she became afebrile  and repeat blood cultures were negative.  Surgery could not be performed due to her medical condition at the time and a collective decision with her and family members. She received heart failure management  including diuretics  and was referred for a dental abscess treatment to prevent recurrence of endocarditis.   Conclusion: This case emphasizes the importance of maintaining good oral health since untreated dental caries can lead to serious complications like infective endocarditis. Consideration should be given to S. Mutans in patients with poor dental health presenting with fevers of unknown origin  especially if new murmurs are noted on examination. Moreover  this case is a good reminder that infective endocarditis can affect patients without the traditional risk factors of intravenous drug use or pre-existing heart disease.  Discussion: Surveillance studies across the globe have shown relatively low rates of infective endocarditis among African Americans. This case offers critical insights into the manifestations  diagnosis  and management of native valve endocarditis in this demographic group  underscoring the need to improve dental health practices and provision of adequate healthcare facilities.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 60-year-old Asian Male with a History of Rheumatic Heart Disease: A Case Report  Introduction: Infective endocarditis  a serious infection of the endocardial surface of the heart  predominantly affects the heart valves. Native-valve infective endocarditis (NVIE) refers to the infection of native  or non-artificial  valves. Although NVIE is rare  it carries significant morbidity and mortality.   Case Presentation: A 60-year-old Asian male patient presenting to the hospital with a history of rheumatic heart disease  currently prescribed Warfarin due to chronic atrial fibrillation  was admitted with complaints of high-grade intermittent fever  chills  and fatigue for the past two weeks. He has been living with type 2 diabetes mellitus for the last 8 years managed by Metformin. He is a nonsmoker and does not consume alcohol.  On physical examination  he had a heart rate of 105 beats per minute  blood pressure of 130/90 mmHg  and body temperature of 38.7°C or 102°F. Cardiac examination revealed a soft systolic murmur. Skin examination exhibited Osler’s nodes on his fingers and toes and Janeway lesions on his hands and feet.   A complete blood count showed a high white blood cell count indicative of infection. Blood culture was positive for Staphylococcus aureus. Transesophageal echocardiogram showed an echodense mass on his mitral valve  confirming a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Management and Outcome: The patient received empirical antibiotic therapy (penicillin and gentamicin) as per the local guidance for native valve infective endocarditis until the susceptibility results were available. After six weeks of intravenous antibiotics under hospital care  the patient’s symptoms improved significantly. Regular follow-ups have been kept to monitor his condition.   Discussion: The patient’s rheumatic heart disease and diabetes mellitus perhaps contributed as risk factors for developing infective endocarditis.  Conclusion: This report underscores the importance of high clinical suspicion for NVIE in patients presenting with fever and heart murmur  especially in individuals with a history of rheumatic heart disease. Early diagnosis and appropriate management are crucial to reduce the risks of significant morbidity and mortality associated with the condition. Compliance with long-term treatment is essential to prevent recurrence and manage any potential complications.   Note: All treatments and diagnostic tests within this case report are in compliance with current medical guidelines and literature concerning NVIE diagnosis and treatment.

Title: Infective Endocarditis in a Native Valve of an Elderly Male - A Case Report  Introduction: Infective endocarditis (IE) is a severe condition often involving the endothelial surface of the heart and its structures  most commonly the valves. Here  we present the case of an elderly male with native-valve infective endocarditis.  Case Report: A 73-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus presented to the emergency department with high-grade fever  fatigue  and progressive shortness of breath for one week. The patient reported a decrease in appetite  unintentional weight loss  and night sweats. He had been previously managed with metformin  lisinopril  and aspirin. There was no history of intravenous drug use  recent dental procedures  or immunosuppressive therapy.  On physical examination  the patient appeared acutely ill with a temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°F). The cardiovascular examination revealed a diastolic murmur best heard at the left sternal edge. A few petechial rashes were noted on his lower extremities and under his fingernails (splinter hemorrhages). There was no clubbing or osler nodes noted.  Investigations revealed leukocytosis  increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)  and C-reactive protein (CRP). Multiple blood cultures grew Staphylococcus aureus  confirming the diagnosis of bacteremia. Transthoracic echocardiography showed a large echogenic vegetation on the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve with moderate mitral regurgitation  consistent with infective endocarditis.  The patient was started on intravenous antibiotics in accordance with the sensitivity pattern  including vancomycin and gentamicin. However  due to persistent symptoms  worsening regurgitation  and the high risk of systemic embolization  a decision for surgical intervention was made. He underwent successful mitral valve replacement surgery and was continued on antibiotics thereafter.   The postoperative period was uneventful  and he was discharged on lifelong anticoagulant therapy with warfarin. At a six-month follow-up  the patient was asymptomatic with a functioning prosthetic mitral valve.  Discussion: This case illustrates the management of native-valve infective endocarditis in an elderly patient with cardiovascular risk factors. It underlines the importance of early recognition and aggressive management of IE  including appropriate antibiotic therapy and the potential need for surgical intervention in cases with high embolic risk.  Conclusion: This case report emphasizes the challenges encountered in managing patients with native valve infective endocarditis  particularly in patients with a history of chronic conditions such as hypertension and diabetes. Prompt recognition and optimal management including possibility of surgery are critical to improve patient outcomes.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis Presenting with Neurological Deficits in a 63-year-old Male  Patient Profile:   A 63-year-old Hispanic male presented to the emergency department (ED) with one-week history of generalized malaise  intermittent fever  and sudden onset left-sided weakness. He had no significant past medical history. The patient lives alone  is a retired engineer and a non-smoker. He occasionally consumes alcohol in moderation.  Clinical Presentation:   On presentation  vital signs were stable except for a fever of 38.9°C. Neurological examination revealed left upper and lower extremity weakness with a power of 3/5. He also had a noticeable facial droop on the left side suggestive of a stroke. Initial physical exam findings included a diastolic murmur  noted over the aortic area. No other significant findings were noted.   Investigations:  Blood culture showed growth of Streptococcus viridans. Trans-esophageal echocardiogram (TEE) revealed vegetations on the aortic valve  confirming the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis (NVIE). A MRI brain confirmed acute ischemic stroke on the right side.  Treatment and Response:  The patient was started on intravenous antibiotics per the Infective Endocarditis (IE) treatment protocol. Consultations were made to the Infectious Disease and Cardiology services for further management of NVIE. Neurology was consulted for the stroke. The patient was also given aspirin for secondary prevention of stroke. His hospital course was complicated by heart failure  for which he was managed with diuretics and vasodilators.  Outcome:   The patient completed a 6-week course of antibiotics. Follow-up TEE at the end of treatment showed resolution of the vegetations  and cultures turned negative.  The patient’s motor deficits improved significantly but did not fully resolve  warranting ongoing physical therapy.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the diversity in presentation of NVIE as it presented with neurologic deficits  consistent with septic embolization. This emphasizes the need for a high index of suspicion especially in older patients presenting with stroke and associated cardiac signs and symptoms.   Broad demographic representation within case reports is necessary to understand the entire disease spectrum as this case illustrates infective endocarditis in an elderly Hispanic male  an often-underrepresented group in medical literature. Further research in this domain can drive better awareness and diagnostic strategies to appreciate the subtle nuances in presentation across diverse populations.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 57-Year-Old Male Patient with a Prior History of Congenital Heart Defect: A Case Report   Introduction:  Infective endocarditis (IE) is a rare but serious condition that involves the infection of the endothelial surface or lining of the heart chambers and valves  usually by bacteria. The diagnosis and management of IE in patients with prior history of congenital heart defects (CHD) are particularly challenging due to increased risk factors. We present a case of a 57-year-old male patient with a history of CHD who developed native-valve infective endocarditis (NVIE).  Case Presentation:  A 57-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department with a two-week history of intermittent fever  fatigue  and weight loss. His medical history included a ventricular septal defect  which was corrected surgically during his childhood  hypertension  well-controlled diabetes mellitus type II  and a two-pack-a-day smoking habit for 35 years.  On physical examination  the patient was febrile  the heart sounds revealed signs of a new-onset mitral regurgitation murmur  and tiny red or purple spots on the patient’s skin  a symptom known as petechiae  were observed on the extremities.  Laboratory findings showed marked leukocytosis  increased inflammatory markers - elevated C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Blood cultures were positive for Staphylococcus aureus. The EKG showed sinus tachycardia  but no distinct ST or T wave changes. A transthoracic echocardiogram demonstrated a mobile echogenic mass attached to the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve suggestive of a vegetation  and moderate mitral regurgitation.
