The diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis was made based on the patient’s symptoms  physical findings  positive blood culture  and the presence of a vegetation on echocardiogram  according to the modified Duke criteria.  The patient was initially treated with intravenous Antibiotic therapy with a combination of Nafcillin and Gentamicin. Despite  the treatment  the patient continued to have persistent fever and positive blood cultures. Given the poor response to medical treatment and the risk of systemic embolization  surgical intervention was determined. The patient underwent mitral valve replacement surgery with a bioprosthetic valve.  Postoperatively  the patient’s fever resolved  and follow-up blood cultures were negative. The patient was discharged on a course of intravenous antibiotics and arranged for regular follow up at the outpatient clinic.   Conclusion:  This case demonstrates the challenges of diagnosing and managing native-valve infective endocarditis in a patient with a prior history of CHD  and the potentially integral role of surgical intervention in patients with poor response to medical management. Multimodality imaging and an interdisciplinary team approach are crucial for improving the outcome of such patients.

Title: Native-valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Female: A Case Report  Introduction:  This report chronicles the case of a 54-year-old Caucasian female patient who presented with native-valve infective endocarditis. The incidence of native valve infective endocarditis is higher in men and increases with age  however  it is not uncommon among middle-aged women.   Case Presentation:  Demographics: The patient is a 54-year-old Caucasian female  nonsmoker  industrial worker by profession living in an urban district. She has a body mass index (BMI) of 28  indicating overweight status.  Past Medical History: The patient's past medical records indicated a history of rheumatic fever in childhood  treated hypertension for the past five years  and no previous heart surgeries. The patient was not diagnosed with any pathologies such as diabetes  kidney diseases  or immunodeficiencies and was not using immunosuppressive therapy. She was noncompliant on her antihypertensive medication  citing occasional forgetfulness due to a hectic work schedule. There is no history of intravenous drug use.  Presenting Complaints: The patient approached the healthcare facility complaining of persistent  high-grade fever associated with chills and night sweat for about a week. She also reported fatigue and unexplained weight loss over a month. On specific inquiry  she also expressed experiencing intermittent chest discomfort and breathlessness on exertion.  Clinical Assessment: Physical examination revealed pallor  elevated heart rate (tachycardia)  and a diastolic murmur on auscultation over the cardiac apex. No peripheral stigmata of infective endocarditis were present.   Investigations and Diagnosis: Blood cultures were positive for Streptococcus viridans. Echocardiography showed vegetations on the mitral valve  confirming a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis (NVIE). Further tests indicated no significant kidney  liver function abnormalities  or electrolyte imbalances.   Management: The patient was admitted immediately and treated using a tailored antibiotic therapy based on culture sensitivity  including high-dose penicillin G and gentamicin for synergistic therapy. Despite treatment  the patient's condition did not improve  and she developed heart failure symptoms over the next week. Surgical consultation was sought  and the decision for a valve replacement was made considering the patient's deteriorating condition and lack of response to medical therapy.  Conclusion: This case highlights the presentation and management of NVIE in middle-aged women without a history of intravenous drug use or congenital heart defects  pointing out the importance of appropriate diagnosis and timely intervention. A multidisciplinary approach between the Cardiology and Cardiothoracic Surgery teams was key to ensuring the patient's recovery.   Keywords: native-valve infective endocarditis; Case report; Middle-aged female; Valve replacement surgery; streptococcus viridans; Antibiotic therapy.   References: Available upon request.

Title: Native-valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Male  Introduction:  Infective endocarditis (IE) is a critical  deadly condition primarily involving the heart valves. Although it has declined over the past decades  native valve endocarditis still signifies a significant portion of IE cases. This report presents a case of a 67-year-old Caucasian male with native-valve infective endocarditis.   Case Presentation:  The patient  a 67-year-old Caucasian retired accountant with a history of heavy tobacco use and hypertension  presented to the emergency department (ED) with a two-week history of fever  night sweats  breathlessness  and generalized malaise. Despite no prior history of heart diseases  the patient complained of new-onset mild chest discomfort. There was no history of illicit drug use  dental procedures or recent invasive procedure.  Upon physical examination  the patient appeared weak and dyspneic. There were no visible cutaneous or conjunctival lesions. Cardiac examination revealed a diastolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border. No Janeway lesions  Osler’s nodes  or Roth’s spots were observed. Other examination findings were unremarkable.  Investigations:  Blood tests showed an elevated white blood cell count (15 200/µL) and C-reactive protein level (180 mg/L). The patient was also anemic with a hemoglobin of 9.8 g/dL  and a mildly impaired renal function was shown by a creatinine level of 1.4 mg/dL. Three sets of blood cultures were obtained  which all grew Streptococcus viridans.  A trans-thoracic echocardiogram followed by a trans-esophageal echocardiogram confirmed vegetations on the tricuspid valve with subsequent severe regurgitation  leading to the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.   Management and outcome:  Given the sensitivity profile of the isolated bacteria  the patient was initiated on a 6-week course of intravenous penicillin and gentamicin. In the following weeks  the patient had few instances of rigors and ongoing fevers  indicating a slow response to treatment. Due to the severe tricuspid regurgitation and heart failure symptoms  the patient was referred for valve replacement surgery.  After a month post-surgery  the patient showed significant improvement with normalization of inflammatory markers  and improvement of anemia and kidney function. He was eventually discharged under cardiology review.  Conclusion:  The patient's age  gender  and presentation are consistent with demographic trends reported in literature for native-valve infective endocarditis; older males with underlying cardiovascular issues are at a higher risk. Despite the availability of advanced antimicrobial therapy  surgical intervention remains a cornerstone in managing this condition. Prompt recognition and management of these patients is essential due to the high morbidity and mortality associated with delayed or inappropriate treatment.

Title: An Unusual Presentation of Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Adult with No Known Heart Disease  Description:  I. Patient Demographics  The patient is a 42-year-old Caucasian male construction worker from New York City. He is not a smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. He has no significant travel history and denies illicit drug use.  II. Past Medical History  The patient has an unremarkable past medical history with no known incidences of congenital heart disease  rheumatic heart disease  immunodeficiency  or diabetes. He has not had any invasive medical or dental procedures carried out recently. He has no known allergies.  III. Presenting Symptoms  The patient presented to the emergency department with a two-week history of persistent low-grade fever  malaise  and weight loss. For the past week  he had also been experiencing intermittent left-sided chest pains that radiated to the shoulders and forearms.  IV. Physical Examination and Diagnostic Tests  On examination  the patient was slightly tachycardiac  with reported heart rate varying between 100-120 bpm. The rest of his vitals were unremarkable. A heart exam revealed a grade II/VI diastolic murmur at the aortic area with no associated rubs or gallops. No other significant cardiovascular  pulmonary  abdominal  or neurological abnormalities were noted.  The patient’s blood test showed leukocytosis with a predominance of neutrophils. A significant elevation of erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) suggested an ongoing inflammatory response. Several sets of blood cultures were drawn  all of which grew Staphylococcus aureus.   A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) revealed an oscillating intracardiac mass on the aortic valve suggestive of vegetation  confirming a diagnosis of infective endocarditis. A subsequent transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) highlighted no perivalvular abnormalities.  V. Management and Outcome  The patient was started on intravenous antibiotics (vancomycin and rifampin) as per sensitivity results from the blood culture. His condition began to improve after the initiation of treatment. He received intravenous antibiotics for six weeks. Repeat blood cultures at the end of six weeks showed no bacterial growth and inflammatory markers returned to normal. A repeat TEE demonstrated a resolution of the vegetation albeit mild aortic regurgitation  most likely due to valve damage caused by the infection.  VI. Conclusion  This case underscores the concept that infective endocarditis can occur even in individuals without traditional risk factors  including congenital heart disease  rheumatic heart disease  or recent invasive procedures. This highlights the importance of considering infective endocarditis in the differential diagnosis of patients with unexplained persistent fever  malaise  and elevated inflammatory markers.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged  African American Male: A Case Report  Patient Profile: Mr. J  a 52-year-old African American male  presented with a two-week history of intermittent fever  shortness of breath  and fatigue. He had no known drug allergies and had no significant family history. He was a former smoker  with a consumption history of 20 cigarettes per day lasting up to 25 years  but was able to quit five years ago. He reported mild alcohol consumption  but denied any illicit drug use.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension (HTN) and type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM)  both of which were diagnosed ten years ago and have been managed by medication. There is no history of heart disease in his family  and he had no previous cardiac problems. At his last medical check-up three months ago  his blood pressure was 130/85 mmHg and his HbA1c level was 7.2%.  Presenting Complaints: His primary complaints were of constant low-grade fever  shortness of breath  fatigue  and unintentional weight loss. He also reported occasional night sweats and recent onset malaise over the past two weeks. He did not have any cough  chest pain  palpitations or edema.  Physical Examination: Mr. J's blood pressure was 138/90 mmHg  pulse rate was 102 bpm  respiratory rate was 20 breaths per minute  and his temperature was 38.2°C. Upon cardiovascular examination  a systolic murmur was noted. Rest of the physical examination was within normal limits.  Investigations and Diagnosis: Blood tests showed an elevated white blood cell count and C-reactive protein level. Chest X-ray was normal. Electrocardiogram revealed sinus tachycardia. A subsequent transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) showed a vegetation on the mitral valve  confirming the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Management and Follow-up: Mr. J was admitted and started on empirical antibiotics (vancomycin and gentamicin). The blood cultures confirmed Staphylococcus aureus as the causative organism. His antibiotic regimen was switched according to the sensitivity pattern. The patient was closely monitored for complications like heart failure and septic emboli. His condition improved considerably after two weeks of treatment. He was discharged with instructions to complete a six-week antibiotic course and regular follow-up appointments.   Outcomes: The patient had a good recovery and was stable during follow-up. His repeat echocardiogram showed a slight reduction in vegetation size. It was deemed that surgical intervention was not required at this point  and he was continued on suitable antibiotic therapy. The patient was referred to cardiac rehabilitation and was educated on lifestyle modification and how to control his diabetes and hypertension. Follow-up echocardiography and routine visits were advised for the patient.  Conclusion: This case illustrates the importance of early recognition and treatment of native-valve infective endocarditis  particularly in patients with risk factors such as hypertension and diabetes. Suitable management can lead to a significant improvement and reduce the need for surgical intervention.

Patient Initials: JS  Age: 55 Years Sex: Female Race: Caucasian  Presenting Problem: The patient came in complaining about a high-grade fever  fatigue  new heart murmur  and unexpected weight loss.   Medical History: The patient has a past medical history of chronic rheumatic heart disease caused by recurrent episodes of rheumatic fever and a recent dental procedure. She has no history of intravenous drug use. She doesn't have any allergies. Her immunization is up to date. Her family history includes ischemic heart disease in her father and type II diabetes mellitus in her mother.   Physical Examination: Upon examination  the patient had a temperature of 38.5 degrees Celsius. The cardiovascular examination revealed the presence of a systolic murmur heard best at the cardiac apex. Splinter hemorrhages were present on the nail beds  and her fingers also displayed signs of clubbing. The other systemic examination was within normal limits.  Laboratory Results: The patient's white blood cell (WBC) count was elevated  with a neutrophilic predominance. Blood cultures showed growth of streptococcus viridans. ELISA for HIV was performed and came out negative.   Imaging and Further Steps: Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) showed thickening and vegetation on the mitral valve. This was confirmed with a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE)  further strengthening the diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis as it correlates with the patient's symptoms and clinical findings.  Infective endocarditis (IE) susceptibility being the highest in the presence of valvular heart disease and history of dental surgery. Due to her chronic rheumatic heart disease  she has a higher risk of contracting native valve endocarditis. Streptococcus viridans bacteria  which typically reside in the mouth  are known to cause IE after dental procedures.  Diagnosis: Native Valve Infective Endocarditis  Plan: The patient was admitted to the hospital for further treatment. Antibiotic therapy was started as per the guidelines for streptococcus viridans  which included intravenous ceftriaxone and gentamycin. The patient also required valve replacement surgery due to severe damage caused. The surgery was complicated by heart failure but was eventually controlled with medications.   The patient was in the hospital for six weeks and was discharged on lifelong anticoagulation and regular follow ups for valve monitoring and blood works.   This case underscores the typical presentation of infective endocarditis and illustrates its associated complications. Early detection and appropriate therapeutic strategies are key components in managing this life-threatening condition. Regular dental hygiene will be crucial for this patient to prevent recurrent episodes.   Consent: Obtained

Title: A case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in Middle-Aged Male  Introduction  Native-valve infective endocarditis (IE) is a severe  and often critical  infection of the endocardial surface of the heart  including the heart valves. Characteristically causing valvular insufficiency  congestive heart failure  embolic phenomena  and other multi-organ complications  it demands early diagnosis and adequate treatment to prevent mortality and complexities.  Case report  We present here the case of a 54-year-old Caucasian male  with a history of smoking and recreational drug use  who presented to the emergency department with a two week history of generalized malaise  intermittent fever and night sweat. He reported no known allergies. His past medical history revealed an underlying case of hypertension  which was being managed with regular medications.  Physical examination revealed him to be pyrexial with a blood pressure of 145/85 mmHg  pulse rate of 110 beats/minute  and respiratory rate of 18 breaths/minute. An audible diastolic murmur was detected during a cardiovascular examination. On admission  blood cultures were drawn  and laboratory results showed elevated inflammatory markers along with microcytic anemia.  After initial stabilization  further diagnostic procedure incorporated transthoracic echocardiography (TTE)  which highlighted an echogenic mass adherent to the anterior mitral leaflet  supportive of valvular vegetation. Simultaneously  the isolation of Streptococcus viridans from serial blood cultures confirmed the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Management of the patient’s condition encompassed a four-week course of antibiotic therapy  specifically intravenous Penicillin G and Gentamicin. The patient showed a favorable response to the treatment and subsequent repeat blood cultures turned out negative. Moreover  a follow-up TTE delineated the resolution of the vegetation although the patient had developed a moderate mitral regurgitation.  Given the patient’s recreational drug use  a referral was also made for substance use counselling and rehabilitation. The patient was discharged with instructions for treatment adherence and regular follow-ups in outpatient clinic and cardiology unit.  Discussion   This case inspires a discussion about the significance of a prompt diagnosis and adequate treatment procedure in managing cases of infective endocarditis  especially among vulnerable populations such as those with a history of substance abuse. It also underlines the importance of addressing underlying issues  such as drug use  in order to prevent future episodes.  In conclusion  native-valve infective endocarditis  although severe in clinical course  can be managed effectively with vigilant approach in diagnosing the condition  coupled with robust therapeutic procedures and follow-up care.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an 67-Year-Old Male Patient: A Case Report   I. Introduction: Native-valve infective endocarditis (NVIE) is an infection of the endocardial surface of the heart and typically implies infection of a heart valve or the endocardium itself  without a prosthetic device or repair present. It is predominantly caused by gram-positive bacteria  with Streptococcus viridans and Staphylococcus aureus being the most common pathogens.  II. Case Presentation:  Patient Information: A 67-year-old Caucasian male presented to the hospital with a one-month history of intermittent fever  fatigue  night sweats  and unexplained weight loss. He had a past medical history significant for type II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and prior tobacco use but discontinued it a decade ago. He had no history of illicit drug use or intravenous drug use.  Clinical Findings: On examination  the patient appeared diaphoretic and short of breath. He had a temperature of 38.5°C  blood pressure 130/85 mmHg  heart rate 110 beats per minute  and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. Cardiac examination revealed a diastolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. The patient displayed Osler's nodes on his fingers and toes and Janeway lesions on the soles of both feet- signs suggestive of infective endocarditis.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment: Blood cultures were collected and the patient was started empirically on intravenous vancomycin and ceftriaxone. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) demonstrated a large mobile mass on the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve consistent with vegetation. The patient's blood cultures eventually grew Streptococcus viridans. The Duke criteria for infective endocarditis was met with 2 major criteria (positive blood cultures with typical IE organism  and evidence of endocardial involvement by TTE) and 1 minor criterion (vascular phenomena).  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was treated with intravenous penicillin G and gentamicin for a total of 6 weeks. After completion of antibiotic therapy  repeated echocardiography showed a resolution of vegetation.  Follow-up and Outcome: The patient's symptoms resolved  and he was discharged home in stable condition. He was advised to attend regular follow-ups for monitoring his cardiac function. In a follow-up visit 3 months later  he was asymptomatic with no complications.  III. Discussion: This case exemplifies the importance of early recognition and treatment of NVIE  particularly in patients with risk factors such as underlying heart disease or immunocompromised states. It highlights the significance of clinical signs such as Osler’s nodes and Janeway lesions  despite their rarity  in suspecting infective endocarditis.   Patient Consent: Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for the publication of this case report.   Conflict of Interest: The authors declare that they have no conflict of interest.  Sources of Funding: None.  Ethical Approval: Not required.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Sexagenarian Diabetic Female Patient  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 61-year-old Caucasian female residing in a suburban area in the United States. She is retired and living with her husband of 40 years. She has no history of smoking or alcohol abuse. The patient is independent and enjoys gardening as a hobby.  Past Medical History: The patient has a 25-year history of well-controlled Type 2 diabetes mellitus  for which she is taking daily doses of Metformin. She also has a history of hypertension which she manages with Lisinopril. There's no history of previous heart conditions in the patient's medical history. There is no history of illicit drug use or recent dental surgeries. Her last annual check-up was six months prior to admission and no significant issues were found at that time.  Presenting Complaints and Symptoms: The patient presented to the emergency department with a two-week history of a low-grade fever  extreme fatigue  loss of appetite  unintentional weight loss  and night sweats. Upon further probing  she also admitted to a recent onset of joint pains  which she attributed initially to her gardening activities.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  she appeared pale and fatigued. She had a temperature of 100.8°F  a heart rate of 90 beats per minute  a respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute  and a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg. There were no visible skin changes. Auscultation of the heart revealed a new onset  grade II/VI systolic atypical heart murmur and no other significant findings.  Investigations: Blood tests showed mild anemia and raised inflammatory markers. Blood cultures were taken and she was started empirically on intravenous antibiotics. The cultures later identified Streptococcus viridans as the infectious organism  suggesting a likely diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. An echocardiogram confirmed the presence of a vegetative lesion on the mitral valve  hence confirming the diagnosis.  Treatment & Follow-Up: She was treated with tailored intravenous antibiotics  based on the blood culture and sensitivity reports for six weeks  maintaining rigorous blood sugar control to aid with the recovery process. Following treatment  her symptoms gradually improved.  Outcome: Despite her age and diabetic condition  she weathered through the infection well. A follow-up six months later with an echocardiogram showed a significant reduction in the size of the vegetation.  This case highlights the importance of considering native-valve infective endocarditis in the differential diagnosis in older adults presenting with persistent low-grade fever  fatigue  and unintentional weight loss  especially in patients with a history of chronic diseases.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Caucasian Male: A Case Study Report  Patient Information  The patient is an 84-year-old male resident of Jacksonville  Florida. He is a retired naval officer and lives independently in his own home with his wife  who is his primary caregiver. The couple has two adult children living nearby who actively participate in their father's care. The patient is a lifetime non-smoker and reported social alcohol consumption. He identifies as Caucasian.  Presenting Complaints  The patient presented to the emergency department (ED) with a 10-day history of fatigue  subjective fevers  and progressive shortness of breath.  Past Medical History  The patient has a known history of hypertension  mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) (distant past smoker)  and previously well-managed type II diabetes mellitus. There is no known history of heart disease  infectious diseases  or cancers. His medications include metformin  ramipril  and a short-acting beta-agonist inhaler.  Clinical Findings  On arrival to the ED  he had a low-grade fever (38.2°C)  elevated heart rate (110 bpm  regular rhythm)  and blood pressure within normal limits (132/84 mmHg). The patient displayed slight confusion indicative of delirium. Physical examination revealed a new grade 3/6 pansystolic murmur at the left lower sternal edge  fine end-inspiratory crackles at both lung bases  and peripheral edema. No peripheral stigmata of infective endocarditis were detected.  Diagnostic Assessment  Blood tests revealed elevated white blood cells  C-reactive protein  and an increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate suggestive of an inflammatory state. An electrocardiogram showed no ischemic changes. Chest x-ray demonstrated mild congestion.   Three sets of blood cultures were drawn and subsequently grown Streptococcus bovis. Transthoracic echocardiogram  followed by transesophageal echocardiogram confirmed the presence of vegetations on the tricuspid valve  confirming the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.   Therapeutic Intervention  The patient was commenced on intravenous ceftriaxone and gentamycin following Infectious Diseases Society of America Guidelines. His course was complicated by septic pulmonary emboli  requiring extended antibiotic therapy.  Follow Up and Outcomes  The patient made a slow but steady recovery over ten weeks with resolution of the infection. Repeat echocardiography showed no residual valve damage  indicating a successful treatment response. He continues to be monitored for potential relapse.  Patient Perspective  The diagnosis and extended hospital stay was a stressful experience for the patient and his family. Psychosocial therapy was employed to help them cope.  Informed Consent  Informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report. His identity has been protected.   Conclusion  This case highlights the importance of clinical suspicion of infective endocarditis in elderly patients presenting with systemic inflammatory signs and new cardiac murmurs. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate management can result in successful patient outcomes  even in the setting of severe infection.

Title: ""Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Hispanic Female: A Case Report""  Introduction:  Infective endocarditis (IE)  a risky and potentially life-threatening infection of the endocardium  primarily affects the heart valves. Those with native-valve IE have not had valve replacement surgery. This case study pertains to an elderly Hispanic female with native-valve infective endocarditis and the complexities of her diagnosis and treatment.  Case Description:  Patient Demographics: The patient is an 83-year-old  Hispanic Female  retired school teacher  devoted Catholic and resident of Brownsville  Texas.  Medical History: The patient's past medical history is significant for hypertension  non-insulin dependent type II diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia  and previous breast cancer  for which she had undergone a mastectomy 20 years earlier.   Presenting Complaints: The patient arrived at the ER with complaints of fatigue  intermittent fever  loss of appetite  progressive shortness of breath on exertion and disturbing weight loss over the past two months. She also exhibited symptoms like mild confusion and night sweats.  Clinical Findings: Clinicians found her vitals at presentation to be slightly unstable: BP was 140/90 mmHg  pulse 105 bpm  respiratory rate 20 breaths per min  and temperature 100.4°F. On physical examination  the patient exhibited pallor. A cardiac exam revealed a new 3/6 systolic murmur. While skin examination showed no signs of Osler's nodes  Janeway lesions  or splinter hemorrhages  funduscopic examination revealed Roth's spots.  Diagnostic Assessment: Blood cultures were drawn and she underwent an echocardiogram which showed vegetations on the mitral valve with moderate regurgitation confirming the clinical suspicion of infective endocarditis. Blood cultures later isolated Streptococcus viridans. This  along with the new murmur and fever confirmed the diagnosis of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis (NVIE).   Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately started on intravenous Penicillin G and Gentamicin  following the AHA/ACC guidelines for subacute bacterial endocarditis caused by Streptococcus viridans. The patient was monitored for complications including heart failure  valve rupture  and embolization.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: Over the next two weeks  the patient's condition stabilized. She showed an overall improvement  and her weights indicated that she was regaining lost weight. Six-weeks post-initiation of treatment  the patient was deemed stable enough for discharge with oral antibiotics and a follow-up echocardiogram scheduled for three months.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the necessity of a high index of suspicion when older patients present with nonspecific symptoms including fatigue  fever  and unexplained weight loss  especially in those with preexisting heart conditions. The patient’s age and underlying hypertension may have contributed to her relatively poor condition on presentation  leading to a more complex diagnostic and treatment procedure for NVIE.

Title: Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 54-year-old Caucasian Male   Introduction: Infective endocarditis (IE)  particularly native-valve infective endocarditis is a severe type of heart valve infection associated with high morbidity and mortality. This case report describes a patient with this condition  emphasizing the importance of early diagnosis and aggressive management.  Case presentation: The patient was a 54-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of hypertensive cardiovascular disease and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He was a former smoker (stopped ten years ago) and denied any illicit drug use. He presented to the emergency department with a five-day history of intermittent  high-grade fever accompanied by chills  malaise  night sweats  and a 3 kg weight loss over the past month. There was no reported history of chest pain  cough  shortness of breath  or orthopnea. The patient's previous echocardiography for hypertension monitoring  conducted six months ago  detected no signs of valvular disease.  On examination  the patient was febrile with a temperature of 38.5 °C  a pulse rate of 100 beats per minute  and blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg. Except for a faint heart murmur  physical inspection and systemic examinations were largely unremarkable. However  infectious disease signs such as Osler's nodes  Roth spots  or Janeway lesions were absent.  Labs drawn indicated moderate leukocytosis with left shift  elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate  and C-reactive protein. Blood cultures grew viridans group streptococci  which was susceptible to penicillin. The chest X-ray was within normal limits  whereas the transesophageal echocardiogram revealed large  oscillating vegetation on the aortic valve consistent with native-valve infective endocarditis.  Treatment Strategy: The patient was admitted to the hospital and initiated on intravenous ceftriaxone and gentamicin as per the American Heart Association guidelines for native-valve infective endocarditis due to streptococci. In spite of aggressive antibiotic therapy  the patient showed no clinical improvement after seven days  and the vegetation size remained unchanged on follow-up echocardiography. Therefore  the decision for early surgical intervention was taken. The patient subsequently underwent a successful aortic valve replacement with a prosthetic valve  followed by a six-week course of intravenous ceftriaxone.  Outcome: Postoperative course was uneventful. The patient showed marked clinical improvement  was afebrile  and had stabilized cardiac function. At the two-month follow-up visit  the patient remained asymptomatic  with the prosthetic valve functioning optimally on echocardiography.  Discussion: This case highlights the salient features and complexities associated with the management of native-valve infective endocarditis. Despite being a less common form of infective endocarditis  early recognition paired with aggressive medical and  if necessary  surgical intervention is essential to reduce morbidity and mortality.  Keywords: Infective endocarditis  Native-valve  Case report  Cardiovascular disease.

Title: A Case Report of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Hispanic Female With History of Intravenous Drug Use   Patient Information  A 55-year-old Hispanic female presented to the emergency room with a week-long history of fatigue  chills  intermittent fevers  and loss of appetite. She has a past medical history of chronic hepatitis C  frequent intravenous drug use  and is a nonsmoker. She reported no allergies and is not on any routine medications.   Clinical findings   The patient was noted to be febrile (38.5°C) and had tachycardia (110 bpm) upon physical examination. She appeared generally unwell with mild jaundice. Physical examination also revealed subtle Janeway lesions on the palms of her hands. Cardiac examination demonstrated an early diastolic murmur best heard in the left third intercostal space. Chest auscultation revealed clear and equal air entry  and examination of her abdomen was unremarkable. She had poor dental hygiene but no obvious dental abscesses.   Diagnostic Assessment  Blood tests showed elevated white cell counts (15 000/mm^3)  C-reactive protein (CRP) of 180 mg/L  and mildly elevated liver enzymes. She tested positive for HCV. Chest radiography was clear with no evident signs of pneumonia or pulmonary emboli.   Two sets of blood cultures were taken from different sites at 12 hours apart before starting antibiotics. Both turned positive for Staphylococcus aureus. The patient was subsequently diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis based on the combination of her clinical findings and positive blood cultures.   A transthoracic echocardiogram confirmed the presence of a large vegetation on the anterior leaflet of mitral valve with moderate mitral regurgitation.  Therapeutic Intervention  The patient was started on IV vancomycin and gentamicin in the emergency department after collecting blood cultures. After diagnosis confirmation  she was continued on the antibiotics regimen for six weeks as per guidelines for S. aureus endocarditis. She was also counseled extensively on the harmful effects of intravenous drug use  and she was referred to a drug rehab program.  Follow-Up and Outcomes  The patient showed improvement after two weeks of antibiotics with normalized temperature and no signs of heart failure. Repeat blood cultures at week 2 and at the end of therapy were negative. Post-treatment transthoracic echocardiogram showed smaller vegetation size and less severe mitral regurgitation. Following the successful completion of antibiotic therapy  she was recommended for interval dental care and regular medical follow-up for hepatitis C management.  Teaching Point  This case highlights the importance of considering infective endocarditis in patients with intravenous drug use presenting with prolonged fever. Early diagnosis and prompt antibiotic therapy are crucial to reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with this condition. It also underscores the importance of multidisciplinary approach involving addiction medicine.

Title: Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis Presenting as a Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Profile: Mr. JH  a 48-year-old African-American male with a past medical history notable for well-controlled hypertension  presented to the hospital with a two-week history of progressively worsening lethargy  lower limb edema  and weight gain.  Presenting Complaint: His primary complaints were episodes of dyspnea that emerged two days prior to admission and became worse over time and fatigue with a recent onset of lower limb swelling.  Medical  Surgical  and Family History: His past medical history reveals a 10-year history of well-regulated hypertension via the use of amlodipine. Previously  he had no surgeries or known allergy issues. His family history was germane for father and brother suffering from end-stage renal disease correlated with unidentified glomerulopathies.  Examination/Investigations: JH was afebrile and had a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg. Cardiac examination revealed a diastolic murmur heard best at the left fifth intercostal space. Respiratory examination found bilateral basal crackles. Lower limb pitting edema was noticed as well. Despite these findings  the patient appeared to be in no distress.   Lab findings upon admission included creatinine - 3.2 mg/dl  hemoglobin - 10.1 g/dL  and a urine analysis demonstrated proteinuria (3+) and hematuria. His electrocardiogram and Chest X-ray were normal. An echocardiogram revealed an oscillating intracardiac mass on the ventricular side of the anterior mitral leaflet  consistent with a vegetation (0.8 x 0.5 cm).  Treatment: JH was admitted under the preliminary diagnosis of nephritic syndrome associated with infective endocarditis. The clinical team initiated empiric antibiotic therapy with intravenous vancomycin and ceftriaxone  whilst blood cultures were sent.  Cultures and histopathology: Blood cultures grew Streptococcus oralis  a viridans group streptococcus. Renal biopsy revealed ‘lumpy-bumpy’ sub-epithelial deposits indicative of immune complex-associated pathology - focal endocapillary proliferative glomerulonephritis.   Outcome: JH was treated with a six-week course of intravenous ceftriaxone to target the isolated streptococcus species. Over the next weeks  his fluid overload and hypertension were managed with diuretics and ramipril. At the completion of his treatment  his renal function had improved  but still impaired (creatinine - 1.9 mg/dl). Long-term follow-up arrangements were made with both the Cardiovascular and Renal outpatient services  along with plans for repeat echocardiography.  Discussion: This case report highlights membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis presenting as a case of native-valve infective endocarditis - an interesting intersection of nephrology and cardiology in clinical practice.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Male Patient: A Case Report  Introduction:  Infective endocarditis (IE) is an infection of the endocardial surface of the heart  commonly occurring in the heart's valves. Native-valve infective endocarditis (NVIE) involves infection of normal  previously undamaged heart valves. Despite advances in diagnosis and treatment  IE remains a significant cause of morbidity and mortality.  Case Presentation:  Patient Information: The patient is an 78-year-old Caucasian male who is a retired school teacher  hailing from a suburban area. He lives with his wife and maintains an active lifestyle.  Chief complaints: The patient presented at our healthcare facility with complaints of persistent low-grade fever  chills  malaise  and unexplained weight loss over the last three weeks.  Past Medical History: The patient has a medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both well-controlled with medication. He had no history of intravenous drug use  prior valve disease  or congenital heart abnormalities. There was no known history of dentistry-associated IE. His family history was non-contributory.  Clinical Findings: On physical exam  the patient appeared lethargic and moderately ill. His vital signs included a low-grade fever  heart rate of 96 beats per minute  blood pressure of 140/80 mmHg  and respiratory rate at 16 breaths per minute. Cardiac examination revealed a diastolic murmur along left sternal border. There were no signs of peripheral stigmata of endocarditis.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment: Blood cultures were drawn  which eventually grew Streptococcus viridans  a common causative agent of NVIE. A transthoracic echocardiogram was performed  which showed a vegetation on the mitral valve  consistent with NVIE.    Therapeutic Focus and Assessment: The patient was admitted and promptly started on empiric antibiotic therapy with intravenous penicillin and gentamicin. After the positive blood culture results  treatment was de-escalated to targeted therapy with intravenous penicillin for six weeks considered effective for Streptococcus viridans.   Follow-up: The patient showed steady improvement with the treatment regime. His fever subsided  and general well-being improved. Repeat blood cultures drawn after a week of therapy were negative. After six weeks  a follow-up echocardiogram showed resolved vegetation.   Discussion: NVIE is a severe condition that requires prompt recognition and aggressive management. This case underscores the importance of taking a thorough history and maintaining a high index of suspicion for NVIE  especially in older patients with nonspecific symptoms.  Patient Perspective: The patient was relieved with the diagnosis  progress  and outcome of his condition. He was thankful for the comprehensive care received at the health facility.   Informed Consent: Informed consent was obtained from the patient for publishing this case report.   Conclusion: This case emphasizes that NVIE  although less common in the modern antibiotic era  should always be included in the differential diagnosis when an older patient presents with nonspecific symptoms such as unexplained fever  fatigue  and weight loss along with clinical signs of valvular disease. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate treatment can significantly improve the patient's prognosis.

Chief Complaint:  ""Shortness of breath and intermittent fevers""  Patient Description: The patient  Mr. X  is a 63-year-old African American male from the urban North-East USA. He was brought to the emergency department with complaints of breathlessness and intermittent high-grade fever for the past two weeks. The patient also endorsed experiencing a decreased appetite  unintentional weight loss  and nights sweats.   Past Medical History: Mr. X has known hypertension  diagnosed 10 years ago  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  diagnosed 7 years ago. Both conditions have not been well-controlled  primarily due to medication non-adherence. Additionally  there is a history of I.V. drug abuse in his past  but he has been clean for the past 15 years. The patient does not have any known drug allergies.  Family History: His mother died at 68 due to a stroke  and his father passed away at 66 due to complications of lung cancer. The patient has two brothers; one has hypertension while the other is healthy.  Social History: He is currently unemployed  living on his own with no family support. He smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily and has mild  occasional alcohol consumption.   Examination Details: The clinical examination revealed poor dentition  fever (38.9°C)  tachypnea  a heart murmur  and splinter hemorrhages under the fingernails. His BP was 150/90 mm Hg  pulse rate 110/min  respiratory rate 22/min  and oxygen saturation 90% on room air. Otherwise  his systemic examination was unremarkable.  Clinical Course and Diagnoses: Considering fever  heart murmur  weight loss  the patient's poor dentition and history of I.V. drug abuse in past  suspecting subacute bacterial endocarditis. Blood cultures were sent and he was started empirically on intravenous antibiotics. His echocardiogram showed vegetation on the mitral valve suggestive of infective endocarditis.   Diagnosis: Based on clinical findings  blood culture results  and echocardiography  the patient was confirmed to have native-valve infective endocarditis.  Management and Follow-up: The patient was admitted to the hospital and a treatment plan for infective endocarditis was instituted per the IDSA guidelines. His chronic hypertension and diabetes were also managed in the hospital. The patient was enrolled in a smoking cessation program and a consultation with a social worker was arranged for housing and social support. Outpatient follow-up after discharge was scheduled for the assessment of response to treatment  and to continue managing his chronic conditions.

Patient Profile: Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 60 years Sex: Male Ethnicity: African American Birthplace: USA Residence: Urban area  medium socio-economic status Occupation: Retired engineer Family History: Both parents diagnosed with heart disease. Elder brother died from a stroke. Younger sister has type 2 diabetes.  Case Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 60-year old African American male was admitted to the hospital complaining of experiencing fever  fatigue  and a persistent cough over the past 3 weeks. His symptoms were accompanied by a loss of appetite leading to unintentional weight loss. He mentioned intermittent dull chest pain but denied any shortness of breath. On physical examination  there were signs of mild pallor and evidence of splenomegaly.  From his medical history  it was found that Mr. Doe was diagnosed with a mitral valve prolapse 20 years ago but remained asymptomatic. He is also hypertensive and has been on medication for past 15 years. Mr. Doe disclosed that he had dental extraction 2 months ago. He quit smoking a decade ago and maintains a history of moderate alcohol use.  His blood results revealed anemia of chronic disease  a raised erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) suggesting an ongoing inflammatory response. In addition  persistent bacteremia was revealed in blood cultures indicating an infection. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) was performed due to his history of mitral valve prolapse and symptoms suggestive of infectious endocarditis. The TTE confirmed vegetation on his mitral valve  leading to a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Discussion:  Native-Valve infective endocarditis is a serious condition. In Mr. Doe's case  his previous history of mitral valve prolapse  age  regular alcohol consumption and invasive dental procedure possibly contributed to the increased risk of developing this disease. Given his symptoms  inflammatory indicators and TTE results  a prompt treatment plan is required to avoid further complications such as heart failure  systemic embolism  damage to the infected valve  or septicemia. Antibiotic therapy will likely be initiated  tailored to the organism found in blood culture results.  The scenario illustrates the importance of comprehensive history taking and appropriate diagnostic tests for patients presenting with vague symptoms. Especially  patients with pre-existing conditions like valvular heart diseases should be closely monitored  educated about the risks  and should be advised prophylactic measures during invasive procedures  including dental work. A collaboration between primary care physicians  cardiologists  infectious disease specialists and microbiologists remains pivotal in managing such cases.   The case also reinforces the role of sociodemographic factors in disease prevalence  emphasizing the value of continued research into the influence of race  age  and socio-economic status to ensure equitable care for all patients.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male  a retired engineer  with a past medical history of symptomatic pleural effusions secondary to heart failure  diabetes mellitus type II  and hypertension. He is a non-smoker  non-alcoholic and has a family history of cardiovascular disorders  particularly on the maternal side. His mother passed away at the age of 67 due to a myocardial infarction  and an elder sibling is currently managed with medication for hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Current Clinical Presentation:  The patient presented in the ER describing a two-week history of recurrent fevers  fatigue  and a notable weight loss of approximately 5 kg within the last month. He also complained of experiencing night sweats and shortness of breath  particularly with exertion. Upon admission  he was febrile  with a temperature of 101.5 F. Physical examination indicated a new systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border and visible Janeway lesions on the palms and soles.  Investigations:  Initial blood work revealed an elevated white blood cell count of 15.0 x 10^9/L and C-reactive protein of 180 mg/L  indicating an ongoing inflammatory response. Blood cultures were drawn and sent to the lab. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) revealed vegetations on the mitral valve indicating endocarditis. Blood cultures subsequently grew Staphylococcus aureus  sensitive to flucloxacillin  confirming the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Management:  The patient was immediately started on intravenous flucloxacillin in line with the culture sensitivity results. He was also referred to the cardiovascular surgical team for consideration for valvular surgery  due to the considerable size of the vegetations discovered on echocardiogram.  Summary:  The patient's comorbidities such as heart failure  diabetes mellitus II  and hypertension potentially contributed to the development of native-valve infective endocarditis as they are proven risk factors. The presence of symptoms such as fever  fatigue  weight loss  night sweats  and shortness of breath  combined with physical findings and laboratory results  helped establish the diagnosis. The positive growth of Staphylococcus aureus from blood culture samples confirmed the diagnosis and determined the appropriate antibiotic therapy. The patient's case is cooperative to the findings in the literature  as Caucasian males above the age 60  particularly with a history of heart disease  constitute a significant proportion of reported infective endocarditis cases.

Patient Introduction: The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. Robert Smith  residing in the urban area of Philadelphia  PA. He is financially comfortable and has lived a fairly sedentary lifestyle due to his work as a software engineer. He is an active smoker with a 30-pack year history and a routine moderate alcohol consumer. He has an extensive family history of heart diseases  with both his father and grandfather dying of myocardial infarctions in their late 60s.  Presenting Complaint: Robert was admitted to the hospital presenting with a two-week history of low-grade fever  night sweats  weight loss  and increasing fatigue. Recently  he has also experienced shortness of breath on exertion and a visible decrease in appetite.   Medical History: Robert has a known history of Type II diabetes and hypercholesterolemia  both of which are well-managed with medication (metformin and atorvastatin  respectively). However  he has struggled with consistent management of these conditions due to his sedentary lifestyle and poor diet. His only surgical history is a hernia repair 10 years ago.   Clinical Findings and Relevant Test Results: In the emergency department  Robert was febrile with temperature of 100.8°F and exhibited signs of mild heart failure (bilateral ankle edema  elevated jugular venous pressure). An initial cardiac examination revealed a new-onset murmur detected on the left sternal border. Blood tests showed elevated CRP and ESR  indicating systemic inflammation.   Three sets of blood cultures were taken  all which eventually grew Staphylococcus aureus  implicating bacterial endocarditis. An ECG was ordered to investigate further  revealing some ST-segment changes consistent with ischemia.   Following these results  a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) was performed which showed a vegetation on the mitral valve  confirming the diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis.   Management and Discussion: Given the blood culture results  the patient was started on empiric antibiotic treatment with intravenous flucloxacillin and gentamicin. An infectious disease consult was requested for the best antibiotic treatment regimen going forward. Cardiology consult was called for discussion of need for possible surgical intervention  considering the extent of valve damage on the echocardiogram  along with the patient's future quality of life.  Although Robert's daily lifestyle and comorbidities related to diabetes and hypercholesterolemia are considered risk factors for heart disease  they are not traditional risk factors for infective endocarditis. It is more frequently found among individuals with a history of IV drug use  the presence of a prosthetic heart valve or congenital heart disease. As it stands  Robert's case represents a somewhat atypical presentation of native valve endocarditis in a patient without classic risk factors.

Patient Case  Patient Profile: The patient is a 65-year-old African American male named Mr. J  who lives within a long-term healthcare facility due to his physical inability to live independently. The patient has not been a smoker  drug or alcohol user. He is retired and used to work as a construction worker  up until about 5 years ago when he was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis  which now confines him to a wheelchair.   Past Medical History: The patient has a past history of rheumatoid arthritis  for which he takes methotrexate and a TNF inhibitor. He also has a history of hypertension controlled with lisinopril and atherosclerosis. His BMI is 30  being overweight  and is previously diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes  controlled with Metformin. He also had a past kidney infection treated with antibiotics and has chronic lower urinary tract symptoms associated with benign prostatic hyperplasia and is managed with Tamsulosin.  Family History: His mother died at age 75 due to myocardial infarction  and his father died at 74 due to a stroke. He also has one brother who is 67  diagnosed with Diabetes Mellitus Type 2 and hypertension.  Chief Complaint: Mr. J presented symptoms that included continuous high fever  chills  night sweats  fatigue  unexplained weight loss  and swollen feet.   Diagnosis:  After extensive evaluation with blood tests  complete body check-up  transthoracic echocardiography (TTE)  and trans-esophageal echocardiography (TEE)  the Rheumatoid arthritis presence in his body and typical clinical features such as fever  positive blood cultures  and echocardiographic evidence suggested that Mr. J had native-valve infective endocarditis.  Treatment: The patient was treated with appropriate antibiotics to combat the endocarditis. Efforts have also been made to improve his nutritional health and increase his immunity in order to avoid future complications. Furthermore  physical and occupational therapy were initiated to improve his mobility  and the medical team have considered the possible need for surgical intervention  given his persistent infection.  This case underscores the importance of a holistic patient assessment for successfully diagnosing and managing complex diseases like native-valve infective endocarditis  particularly considering factors like chronic rheumatoid arthritis  which might predispose an individual to this condition.

Patient Overview:  Patient Initials: J.K Age: 57 Sex: Female Race: African American  Past Medical History: J.K is a 57-year-old African-American woman diagnosed about 20 years ago with Type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. She's managed her conditions with oral hypoglycemic agents  angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors  diet control  and exercise. She has a 10-pack a year history of smoking but quit over 15 years ago. She had an episode of acute pyelonephritis five years ago that required hospitalization and IV antibiotics.  Presenting Problem: J.K presents at the emergency department (ED) with chief complaints of intermittent high-grade fever  night sweats  fatigue  unintentional weight loss (about 6 kg in 3 months)  and a recent onset of shortness of breath.  Investigations: On examination  the physician detects a grade II/VI systolic ejection murmur in the mitral area  suggestive of possible mitral regurgitation. Temperature of 38.3°C  pulse 92/min  blood pressure 130/76 mmHg  respiratory rate 18/min. Routine blood examination reveals leukocytosis (WBC count: 18 000/mm3 - neutrophils 82%). There is also elevated CRP and ESR showing signs of inflammation.   Echocardiography reveals a vegetation of size 1.5 cm X 0.5 cm on the posterior leaflet of her mitral valve and mild mitral regurgitation. Blood cultures drawn at the ED later reveal the growth of Streptococcus viridans  confirming the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.   Social History: She is a retired elementary school teacher who lives with her husband of 32 years. She has two adult children who live out of state. She denies any drug or alcohol abuse.  Family History: Her mother died of a stroke at age 75  and her father died of congestive heart failure at 80. She has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and cardiovascular disease in the family.   Discussion: J.K's diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis is less common among African American adults than whites (Fowler et al.  2005). Risk factors relating to J.K's case include her age (most patients are over 50 years old)  existing valvular disease  and being female as she falls under the lower risk group (Bor et al.  2013).   Her history of dental work may have led to transient bacteremia  with S. viridans as the causative organism  a common feature seen in native-valve endocarditis. Her diabetes could also have contributed to her susceptibility to infection. She will require prolonged antibiotic therapy together with a close follow-up to monitor her response to treatment and cardiac function.  Citations: Bor  D. H.  Woolhandler  S.  Nardin  R.  Brusch  J.  Himmelstein  D. U. (2013). Infective Endocarditis in the U.S.  1998–2009: A Nationwide Study. PLoS ONE  8(3)  1-7. DOI:10.1371/journal.pone.0060126  Fowler  V. G.  Miro  J. M.  Hoen  B.  Cabell  C. H.  Abrutyn  E.  Rubenstein  E.  Corey  G. R. et al. (2005). Staphylococcus aureus endocarditis: a consequence of medical progress. JAMA  293(24)  3012–3021. DOI:10.1001/jama.293.24.3012.

Patient Profile: Mr. James  a 60-year-old Caucasian male  was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis. He was born and raised in a suburban area and worked as an accountant for 35 years. He retired two years ago and has since been used to a sedentary lifestyle.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. James presented with symptoms of high fever above 101.3℉  fatigue  night sweats  chill  and weight loss over the last three weeks. He also complained of shortness of breath during normal daily activities.  Past Medical History: Mr. James has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes  being treated with oral hypoglycemic agents for the last ten years. He has a history of hypertension  controlled with medications. He is also a former smoker and quit 15 years ago.  Family History: Mr. James has a family history of coronary artery disease. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 56. There is no family history of valvular heart disease or rheumatic fever.  Clinical Findings and Diagnosis: Tests indicated anemia and a raised erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Echocardiography confirmed the presence of vegetations on the mitral valve and moderate mitral regurgitation consistent with a diagnosis of native valve endocarditis. Blood cultures were positive  confirming infective endocarditis.  Management: Mr. James was hospitalized immediately and empirical antibiotic therapy was started before obtaining the blood culture and sensitivity tests. His regimen consisted of intravenous vancomycin and gentamicin. A cardiologist recommended continuing conservative medical management. Routine monitoring of his blood sugar levels and blood pressure was ordered. Dietician advice for a diabetic and cardiac-friendly diet was also initiated.  Prognosis: Given Mr. James's pre-existing conditions  his prognosis was guarded. He was informed of the potential complications  including heart failure  stroke  and the potential need for valve replacement surgery if the heart function worsens.  In conclusion  Mr. James' case presents a common scenario of a patient with native-valve infective endocarditis  complicated by advanced age  diabetes  and high blood pressure  contributing factors towards a more aggressive clinical progression. His case necessitates assertive treatment and frequent follow-ups.

Patient Initials: RS                   Age: 66                          Sex: Male                            Ethnicity: Caucasian  Chief Complaint: High fever  fatigue  night sweats  and shortness of breath.  Present Illness: The patient presented with a two-week history of persistent high-grade fever  malaise  shortness of breath and night sweats. He also reported a recent dental procedure about a month ago.  Past Medical History: RS is a known case of rheumatic heart disease and has been on medication for the past 20 years. Additionally  he also suffers from hypertension which is well-controlled with medication. He does not have any history of diabetes or any other chronic illnesses including malignancies. He was hospitalized 2 years ago for a mild stroke from which he recovered fully.  Family History: Both his parents suffered from cardiovascular diseases. His father died from a heart attack and his mother from stroke. No history of genetic disorders.  Social History: He is a retired engineer  married with two children. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He is quite active despite his age and often engages in light physical activities like walking.  Physical Examination: The examination revealed a high grade fever (39.5°C)  blood pressure of 135/85mmHg  heartbeat irregular at 85 bpm. His heart auscultation informs a regurgitant murmur. His lungs were clear and all other system examinations were unremarkable  and he showed no obvious signs of heart failure. He was alert and oriented  with normal speech and no apparent neurological deficits.  Laboratory findings: Blood test results showed elevated WBC count and ESR  indicating ongoing inflammation. His haemoglobin and platelet levels were normal while the liver and kidney function tests were slightly deranged.  Echo-cardiogram and chest X-ray findings: Echocardiography demonstrated large mobile vegetations on the native aortic valve  confirming the diagnosis of infective endocarditis.  Intervention: Intravenous antibiotics were administered as per hospital guidelines considering bacterial endocarditis. Due to the valve damage  the patient was recommended for surgical aortic valve replacement due to the presence of large vegetations and regurgitating valve.  This case of RS highlights that even with a past medical history of rheumatic heart disease  one must be vigilant to recognize and diagnose a case of native valve infective endocarditis  especially after dental procedures which are known risk factors. Early antibiotic administration with necessary surgical intervention can significantly improve the prognosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. X is a 65-year-old African American male diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis. Mr. X who resides in a semi-urban region of New York  presented to the hospital with complaints of persistent fever  chills  fatigue  and a loss of appetite. He has been experiencing these symptoms intermittently for about six weeks.   Past Medical History:  Mr. X has a history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus and hypertensive disease  which are well controlled by Metformin 500 mg twice daily and Lisinopril 20 mg once a day respectively. He was also diagnosed with rheumatic heart disease in his early 30s and had been on Amoxicillin prophylaxis until 5 years ago  after which it was discontinued due to repeated allergic reactions. He has no known drug allergies except Amoxicillin. He quit smoking 10 years ago and has a moderate intake of wine. Mr. X is compliant with his medications but his compliance to lifestyle modifications is inconsistent.  Family History:  Mr. X's father had Coronary Artery Disease and Type II Diabetes Mellitus. His paternal grandfather expired due to a stroke at a relatively elder age while his mother and one sibling are living and well. There's no significant family history of valvular heart diseases  infectious diseases or autoimmune diseases.  Clinical Examination:  On the day of admission  Mr. X exhibited a heart murmur confirmed by auscultation  and his vitals showed a mild tachycardia. He had Janeway lesions on his palms and soles  Osler nodes on his fingers  and mild splenomegaly. Blood work showed mild anemia and an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate  and a patient's white blood cell count was normal.   Laboratory Investigations:  Blood culture revealed the presence of Streptococcus Viridans. Echocardiography showed abnormalities of the mitral valve consistent with infective endocarditis.   Summation:  Mr. X is a 65-year-old African American male with a complex medical history of rheumatic heart disease  hypertension  diabetes  coming from an at-risk community. He presented with persistent fever  fatigue  Janeway lesions  Osler nodes  and a positive blood culture resulting in a diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis most likely attributable to the untreated rheumatic heart disease. The patient's history of rheumatic heart disease and the cessation of prophylaxis against Streptococcal infections put him at a high risk of developing bacterial endocarditis.   This case underlines the importance of continuation of prophylaxis in patients at risk for endocarditis  the role of regular clinical follow-ups  and the necessity of detailed education about the importance of their medication regimen to such patients.

Patient Profile and Presentation: Mr. Smith is a 58-year-old Caucasian male who has been admitted to the hospital due to severe shortness of breath  weakness  and chest pain. He has a history of intravenous drug abuse but has been sober for about five years. Additionally  he has a past medical history of rheumatic heart disease and has undergone heart valve replacement surgery fifteen years ago.  Social History: Mr. Smith is a former construction worker  currently unemployed  living in a suburban setting averaging low socioeconomic status. He lives alone  is divorced  and has two daughters who live out of state. He has a 35-pack year smoking history but quit five years ago. His diet is low in fruit and vegetables and high in processed  fatty foods.  Family History: Both parents succumbed to cardiovascular diseases in their late sixties. His father had a history of ischemic heart disease  while his mother had a cerebral vascular accident. One paternal uncle had stomach cancer  while another had Parkinson's disease. There is no other significant family history.  Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  Mr. Smith appeared anxious and diaphoretic with a heart rate of 120 beats/min  blood pressure of 105/70 mmHg  and a respiratory rate of 22 breaths/min. His cardiovascular examination revealed a high-pitched  blowing  diastolic  and decrescendo murmur heard at the left third intercostal space along the sternum  suggesting aortic regurgitation. Laboratory reports showed elevated ESR  CRP  and white cell count. Blood cultures grew Streptococcus viridans  and the transthoracic echocardiogram confirmed vegetation on aortic valve  aligning with a diagnosis of infective endocarditis.  Treatment and Prognosis: Mr. Smith was immediately started on empiric antibiotic therapy  using a combination of intravenous Penicillin G and Gentamicin  following the AHA guidelines for native valve endocarditis due to Streptococcus viridans. The medical team is seeing a modest improvement in his condition. However  his prognosis remains uncertain due to his prior medical condition and his socioeconomic circumstances  including limited access to regular healthcare and poor dietary patterns.  Discussion: Infective endocarditis  although rare  is a severe condition and remains a substantial contributor to cardiovascular morbidity and mortality  particularly in patients with previous heart valve surgery or a history of intravenous drug abuse. Timely diagnosis and prompt antibiotic therapy remains the cornerstone for managing infective endocarditis. Further  the case emphasizes the importance of providing adequate outpatient resources for patients with poor socioeconomic backgrounds to prevent disease relapse or complications.   This presentation was created following standard demographic representation as found in related literature  and does not aim to stereotype or overgeneralize any population groups.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. Miller Age: 63 years old Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retiring electrician  Chief Complaint:  Mr. Miller presents at the clinic with persistent  high-grade fever for the past three weeks. He is also complaining of fatigue  night sweats  weight loss  and occasional breathlessness.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Miller has a history of Type 2 Diabetes and hypertension  both of which are well-controlled with medications. He is also a former smoker for 40 years but has quit for 10 years now.  Family History:  His father had a Mike's murmur which was treated successfully and his mother passed away due to complications related to heart failure. His only sibling  an older brother  has a history of rheumatoid arthritis.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  Mr. Miller appeared generally unwell and was diaphoretic. He was febrile with a temperature of 38.6°C. Cardiac examination revealed a new murmur on the left sternal edge  grade 2/6  during diastole. No signs of Janeway lesions  Osler nodes  or Roth spots were observed. His BMI indicated overweight status.  Laboratory Findings:  Blood test results confirmed a raised white cell count and high C-reactive protein  signaling an infection. Trans-thoracic echocardiogram revealed a mobile mass on the native aortic valve with mild aortic regurgitation  confirming infective endocarditis. Blood cultures were also positive for Streptococcus viridans  common in native-valve infective endocarditis which is usually found in the mouth.   Summary:  Mr. Miller  a 63-year-old Caucasian male  with a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes and hypertension  presents with a 3-week history of high-grade fever  fatigue  night sweats  weight loss  and occasional breathlessness. Physical examination and confirmatory lab investigations indicated a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.    Treatment Plan:  Mr. Miller was admitted to the hospital for close monitoring. His treatment regimen includes intravenous antibiotic therapy with Ceftriaxone and Gentamicin  to be used synergistically for at least 4-6 weeks. Surgery may be necessitated if conditions escalate. Regular follow-ups are scheduled for monitoring the patient's response to the treatment.   Prediction/Prognosis:  The prognosis in Mr. Miller's case is cautious  given his age and already compromised health condition. However  with intense antibiotic treatment and potential surgical intervention  the possibility of clinical improvement is feasible.  Educational Needs of Patient/Family:  Education about the importance of strict dental hygiene will be provided  given that Streptococcus viridans  causing IE  is generally found in the mouth. Further  the patient and family will be educated about the signs and symptoms of endocarditis exacerbation  teaching them when to seek immediate medical attention.

Title: A Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 62-year-old Caucasian male with a History of Intravenous Drug Use  I. Introduction: The patient  Mr. S.  is a 62-year-old Caucasian male from the urban Midwest with a past medical history of intravenous drug use  type II diabetes mellitus  and hypertension. He was admitted to the Emergency Department  presenting with symptoms of chronic fatigue  visual disturbance  and fever that have progressively worsened in the past week.  II. Family History and Social History: The patient's family history is significant for cardiovascular disease  with his father dying of myocardial infarction at the age of 55. His mother  88  is alive and suffers from osteoporosis and hypertension. Mr. S. is a retired construction worker and divorced. He has a sociocultural background indicative of low socioeconomic status and has a habit of cigarette smoking and former intravenous heroin abuse. He reported being clean for the past five years.  III. Presenting Concerns:  On admission  Mr. S.'s temperature was 38.6°C (101.5°F)  blood pressure was 136/85 mmHg  pulse rate was at 92 beats per minute  and oxygen saturation was 94% on room air. He was noted to have poor dental hygiene and findings consistent with peripheral manifestations of endocarditis  including Osler's nodes  splinter hemorrhages  and Janeway lesions.  IV. Diagnosis:  Examination and investigations  including three sets of blood cultures  chest X-ray  and transesophageal echocardiography (TEE)  were conducted. The blood cultures were positive for Staphylococcus aureus and TEE revealed the presence of vegetations on the mitral valve  confirming a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  V. Treatment and Prognosis:  Mr. S. was treated with appropriate antibiotic therapy targeted at the identified organism. Given his history of substance use and poor dental hygiene  his risks are significantly heightened for recurrence. Upon discharge  he was advised regular dental check-ups  strict control of his diabetes  and to maintain his sobriety  in light of his high-risk status for recurrent endocarditis. His prognosis  while guarded due to the previous damage done to the cardiac tissues and vessels through prolonged drug abuse  is fair with adherence to proper management.  VI. Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of considering native-valve infective endocarditis in older patients with a history of intravenous drug use who present with seemingly nonspecific symptoms. Recognizing the signs of this condition amidst various presentations can prompt timely diagnosis and treatment  better affecting patient outcomes.

Patient Presentation:  Patient X is a 65-year-old African American male  currently residing in Brooklyn  New York. He has been a smoker for the past 35 years and is still active. He often consumes alcohol but it is within reasonable limits. He is unmarried  retired  lives alone  and has two adult children who live separately.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension  managed by diet restriction  regular exercise and oral antihypertensives for the past 15 years. He was diagnosed with Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) stage III five years ago. As far as oral health is concerned  the patient has neglected his dental hygiene and has missing teeth and gum disease.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. X came to the emergency department (ED) complaining of recurrent fever  chills  malaise  and a new heart murmur which was discovered through clinical examination. He hasn't reported any recent travels or exposure to infectious diseases. His temperature at the time of admission was 39.4°C.  Investigations:  Routine labs revealed anemia (hemoglobin of 9.2 g/dl) and a raised white cell count of 18 000/microL with 80% neutrophils. His ESR was also high at 90 mm/hr. The patient X's renal function tests were impaired with a creatinine level of 2.5 mg/dL. Blood cultures were positive for Staphylococcus aureus. An echocardiogram revealed a vegetation on the mitral valve  confirming a diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis.  Treatment:  On diagnosis  he was started on appropriate intravenous antibiotic therapy: naficillin and gentamicin. Procedure for mitral valve replacement was discussed with him and his next of kin considering the severe mitral regurgitation and heart failure symptoms.  Family history:  His father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 70  and his mother suffered from hypertension and passed away due to stroke at the age of 72. His older brother  aged 68  has been managing coronary artery disease for ten years. His two children are reported to be healthy.  Given his history of poor oral health  smoking  diabetes  and CKD  he is at an increased risk for native valve infective endocarditis. This case underscores the importance of the consideration of endocarditis in patients presenting with fevers of unknown origin  especially in those with risk factors such as poor dental hygiene and underlying heart conditions. It is also essential to educate such patients about oral hygiene and regular dental checkups in an attempt to prevent endocarditis.  In conclusion  this case highlights the importance of considering a diagnosis of infective endocarditis in a patient with predisposing factors presenting with unexplained fever. Early diagnosis and management can significantly reduce morbidity and mortality associated with this condition.

Case Presentation:  Patient Profile: The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian Male from urban Missouri. He is a retired construction worker  lives with his wife  and has two adult children. He has recently been diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis.  Past Medical History: The patient has a medical history of type 2 diabetes and moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He also has a history of smoking one pack a day for the past 40 years  though he quit two years ago.  Family History: The patient has a family history of heart disease  with his father dying from a myocardial infarction in his late 60s and his mother diagnosed with heart valve disease. His older brother has hypertension.  Presenting Complaint and Symptoms: The patient presented with a persistent high-grade fever of 101.2 F  sweating  shortness of breath  persistent cough  weight loss  and fatigue.   Clinical Examination and Findings: On clinical examination  the patient had a regular heart rate but a noticeable heart murmur was heard on auscultation.
