Proposed Management: Antimicrobial therapy was initiated based on the blood culture and sensitivity results. Mr. Martinez was referred to a cardiologist for further evaluation and consideration of a possible mitral valve replacement procedure. He was also seen by a dietician due to his poor nutritional status secondary to the weight loss  diabetes and renal impairment.   This case presents an example of a common clinical picture for native-valve infective endocarditis in a patient with underlying valve disease secondary to an early rheumatic fever exposure.  Going forward  Mr. Martinez’s condition needs significant changes in his lifestyle to prevent further complication or recurrence of this severe infection. Along with these  rehabilitation  along with mental and social support is deemed necessary  given the socio-economic status and demanding nature of the patient's occupation.

Patient Presentation  Demographics  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  John  who lives in a suburban community.  Presenting Complaint  John presented to the emergency department complaining of malaise  low-grade fever  loss of appetite  and unintentional weight loss.  Past Medical History  His past medical history is significant for coronary artery disease (CAD) for which he had undergone angioplasty. Moreover  he has hypertension and hyperlipidemia  controlled with medication. His other past medical history includes recurrences of rheumatic fever in childhood. He is also a retired miner suggesting potential for occupational exposure to silica  with some periods of homelessness and habitual excessive alcohol consumption.  Family History  Both his parents died of cardiovascular diseases. His brother has diabetes and a sister with breast cancer. However  the patient has no family history of endocarditis.  Clinical Findings  On examination  he appeared pale  diaphoretic  and fatigued. He had a low-grade fever (38.1°C) and his blood pressure was low (90/60 mmHg). He exhibited signs of peripheral stigmata of endocarditis including Janeway lesions and Osler nodes. Cardiac auscultation revealed a new  low-intensity heart murmur suggestive of valvular insufficiency.  Investigations  A complete blood count showed leukocytosis and anemia. An elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein level pointed towards an ongoing inflammatory process. The blood culture results reported Streptococcus viridans. John had a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) which revealed vegetation on the mitral valve and moderate mitral regurgitation  indicating infective endocarditis (IE).  Diagnosis  John was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis.  Treatment   John was started on empiric intravenous antibiotic therapy with vancomycin and ceftriaxone per the IDSA guidelines until culture and sensitivities were available. After that  antibiotics were trimmed down to a penicillin-based therapy due to the organism's sensitivity. He was also monitored for any complications.  Discussion  Native valve endocarditis is a form of infective endocarditis affecting a non-prosthetic  native valve. The most common organism is Streptococcus viridans. In this case  John's history of CAD  episodes of rheumatic fever  and lifestyle all pose as risk factors. His clinical manifestations  positive culture  and TTE findings confirmed the diagnosis. Prompt treatment with antibiotics is crucial to minimize morbidity and mortality.   Conclusion   The diagnosis of IE should be considered in patients with new or worsening murmur  persistent or recurrent fevers  and peripheral signs of endocarditis as in John's case.

Patient Profile: Mr. Johnson  a 65-year-old African American male  presents to the hospital with complains of prolonged fever  chills  unexplained weight loss  and night sweats for the past three weeks. He lives alone in a low-income neighborhood of Chicago and has a history of occasional alcohol use and smoking for several decades.   Past Medical History: The patient's medical history reveals he was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis ten years prior. He has been consistently managing this condition with oral medications  including methotrexate and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). However  he admits to missing doses due to financial constraints. In addition  he has been treated thrice in the past for episodes of pneumonia and has been suffering from poor dental health with recent invasive dental procedure approximately a month ago. He has not undergone any cardiac surgeries in the past nor has a medical or familial history of heart diseases  valve injury or IV drug use.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Johnson primarily complains of high grade fever with chills  excessive sweating at night  episodes of cough and chest pain  loss of appetite  and rapid weight loss. He also mentions experiencing increased fatigue and difficulty in breathing when performing his daily activities  which he attributes to his old age.  Physical Examination: On physical examination  the patient appears fatigued. He has a low-grade fever (38.3 degrees Celsius) and his examination reveals the presence of a new systolic murmur heard best at the apex. There is evidence of poor dental hygiene. There are no abnormal findings related to the joints.  Laboratory and Imaging Study: His blood work shows increased ESR and CRP levels  suggestive of an ongoing inflammatory process. The complete blood count with differential shows a slight increase in the neutrophil count suggesting an ongoing infection. Three sets of blood culture tests were positive for Streptococcus viridans. Echocardiogram (ECHO) revealed vegetations on his native mitral valve  confirming our suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis.   Management and Follow-up: Mr. Johnson was immediately started on empiric antibiotic therapy according to the culture & sensitivity report  in accordance with the American Heart Association (AHA) guidelines for the management of endocarditis. This included intravenous administration of bactericidal antibiotics for a median duration of four weeks. In addition  his dental health was addressed and optimized to prevent recurrence of the infection.  The patient was educated about the importance of medication adherence and the possible complications  including heart failure and septic emboli  arising from untreated infective endocarditis. A follow up appointment has been scheduled in two weeks to assess his response to antibiotic treatment and overall cardiac functioning. He is also being referred to a social worker to help him apply for medication assistance programs.  Conclusion: Mr. Johnson’s case exemplifies the potential life-threatening complications of infective endocarditis  highlighting the importance of early detection and treatment. His case highlights the socio-economic factors that can interfere with adherence to therapy and the potential of such factors to influence disease course.

Patient Demographics:   The patient is a 45-year-old Caucasian male  currently unemployed and living alone in a single-family home. He is a smoker  with a 15-pack year history  but denies any alcohol or illicit drug use. He was previously employed as a construction worker.  Presentation:  He presented to the emergency department with a four-week history of malaise  fatigue  low-grade fever  and unexplained weight loss of approximately 8 pounds. He also reported shortness of breath upon exertion and occasional chest pains. He noted a new-onset rash on his palm and soles  along with painful swelling of one of his elbows.  Medical History:  His past medical history is significant for rheumatic fever as a child  and he disclosed a recent oral surgery about six weeks ago. Additionally  he has untreated hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He reports no known drug allergies.  Family History:  His father had a cardiovascular disease and hypertension. His mother is alive and well at 74  but has a history of rheumatic fever and osteoarthritis. He has a younger sister who is in good health. However  there is no known family history of endocarditis  autoimmune disorders  or malignancies.  Physical Examination:  Upon examination  his blood pressure was high 140/95 mmHg  heart rate was elevated 110 beats per minute  and he was slightly febrile at 100.4℉. Cardiovascular examination revealed a new 3/6 diastolic murmur noted at the apex. There were Janeway lesions (painless erythematous lesions) on the palms and soles  and Osler’s nodes (painful nodules) were present on the tips of fingers. Also  he had slight erythema and swelling over his right elbow.  Investigations:  His laboratory investigations showed elevated inflammatory markers (ESR and CRP)  leukocytosis  and positive blood cultures for Streptococcus mutans  an organism that is normally found in the mouth and is a common cause of endocarditis after oral procedures. The transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) showed vegetation on the mitral valve consistent with infective endocarditis.  Diagnosis and Plan:  He was diagnosed with native valve infective endocarditis (IE). The infection was likely secondary to the recent oral procedure he underwent  and his past medical history of rheumatic fever might have made him more susceptible. He was admitted for intravenous antibiotics according to the sensitivity of the cultured organism and would likely require long term treatment. Cardiothoracic surgery consultation is recommended due to the possibility of valve damage which might require surgical intervention.   Additional considerations include substance abuse counseling for his smoking history and management of his untreated hypertension and hyperlipidemia.

Case Presentation  Patient Profile: Mr. A  a 55-year-old Caucasian man  presented in the emergency room; he works as a welder and is married with two grown-up children.   History and Presentation: He has had a past medical history of rheumatic heart disease but has never undergone heart surgery. He has been suffering from general malaise  intermittent fevers  and night sweats for the past three weeks. He acknowledged that his symptoms have been escalating for the past five days alongside unexplained weight loss. Additionally  he complains of a new-onset  progressive shortness of breath  especially on exertion.  There is an absence of history of IV drug abuse  alcoholism  or any sexually transmitted infections. His family history reveals his father succumbed to a myocardial infarction in his early 60s  while the patient’s mother suffers from hypothyroidism. There were no known cases of endocarditis or chronic diseases in the rest of the family.  Examination Findings: On examination  he appeared fatigued. His temperature was 38.6°C. A new murmur was noted upon cardiac auscultation. He also presented with Janeway lesions on the palms  petechiae in his conjunctiva  and Osler’s nodes on his fingers.  Further Investigations: Chest x-ray results were within normal limits  while the EKG showed no signs of ischemia  just mild left atrial enlargement. A transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) revealed a mobile vegetation on the mitral valve with moderate regurgitation. Blood work showed increased inflammatory markers. Blood cultures were taken  which identified Streptococcus viridans  pointing to the diagnosis of infective endocarditis.   Treatment and Progress: He was started on empirical antibiotic therapy with penicillin and gentamicin as per the American Heart Association guidelines. After blood culture sensitivity results  his treatment was deescalated to Penicillin G  which was continued for a total of four weeks. Anticoagulation therapy was withheld considering the risks of intracranial hemorrhage.  Conclusion: The patient responded well to the therapy  with resolution of fever and improvement in his general condition over time. However  he was advised to have follow-up outpatient visits and to observe dental hygiene strictly to prevent recurrent infective endocarditis. The scenario highlights the necessity for early identification and prompt treatment of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Note that this is a fictional representation of a patient with native-valve infective endocarditis based on common presentations. Always refer to the current clinical guidelines when making treatment decisions.

Patient Presentation  John Doe  an unmarried 60-year-old white male construction worker  has resided in Oregon for the majority of his life. The patient is 5’11” tall and weighs around 190 lbs (BMI: 27)  categorizing him as 'Overweight'. His BMI indicates that he is at risk for both diabetes and cardiovascular conditions. He does not smoke or take illicit drugs  and displays moderate consumption of alcohol.  Past medical history reveals Type II diabetes for the past ten years  controlled with diet and Metformin. Recently  he had dental extraction two months ago. He has no known allergies. He never traveled outside the U.S.  got no pets  tattoos or body piercings.  The patient's family history reveals his father died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 55  and his younger brother  currently 57  has been diagnosed with congestive heart failure. His mother  aged 86  is alive with a history of hypertension  and his two sisters  aged 62 and 58  are both hypertension-free and cardiac disease-free.  A physical examination showed the patient's temperature to be intermittently febrile for the past week with a range of 99.5°F to 101.3°F. He has also been experiencing fatigue  chills  and a noticeable shortness of breath during daily activities over the past week. The presence of heart murmur was observed during auscultation. No needle tract marks were noted that would indicate intravenous drug use.  A blood culture showed the presence of Streptococcus viridans  an organism that can often cause infective endocarditis following a dental procedure. An echocardiogram confirmed the diagnosis as it depicted affected valves and vegetation.  Given his recent dental procedure  a history of Type II diabetes (putting him at a higher risk for infections)  and currently observed symptoms  Mr. Doe is diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis.  Management will comprise of long duration antibiotics  notably ampicillin/sulbactam or vancomycin  and supportive care. Furthermore  educating the patient about maintaining oral hygiene and regular dental check-ups will be pertinent to prevent any future recurrences. Regular follow-ups to evaluate response to treatment  renal function  and any antibiotic-related side effects will be of paramount importance. Finally  the scenario warrants a discussion about a healthier lifestyle and possibly pharmacotherapy to manage his weight to lower the risk of diabetes and cardiac disease complications.    This case serves as a valuable reminder for the importance of considering infective endocarditis in patients who present with fevers  particularly in those with a recent dental procedure and a history of certain comorbidities  like diabetes.

Patient Profile: The patient is a 65-year-old Mexican-American male  known as Mr. A. He lives with his wife in a rural part of Texas and works as a farmer. He has a 30-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes per day and drinking alcohol in moderation. Mr. A is bilingual and speaks both English and Spanish fluently. He is Roman Catholic and regularly attends church in his local community.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. A was presented to the hospital with a 2-week history of persistent fever (38.5-39.1°C)  chills  fatigue  and unintentional weight loss (a reduction in weight of about 8 pounds).  Past Medical History: Mr. A was diagnosed with type 2 Diabetes Mellitus at 45 years of age which is reasonably well controlled with Metformin. He has a history of untreated rheumatic fever in childhood and was diagnosed with a bicuspid aortic valve at age 40. He has a history of high blood pressure  for which he takes Lisinopril.  Family History:  There is a family history of heart disease with his father dying from a myocardial infarction at the age of 65. His mother had rheumatoid arthritis and both his older siblings have type 2 Diabetes.  Examination: Mr. A appeared unwell and was febrile at presentation. On cardiac auscultation  a new grade 4/6 ejection systolic murmur was heard at the left sternal edge. Blood pressure was 130/85 mmHg and pulse was 100 bpm.  Investigations: Blood tests showed elevated inflammatory markers (C-Reactive Protein  ESR)  evidence of normocytic anemia and raised renal function tests. His HbA1C level was 7.2% indicating suboptimal control of his diabetes. An echocardiogram revealed vegetation on the aortic valve confirming a diagnosis of aortic valve endocarditis. Blood cultures grew Staphylococcus aureus.  Plan: Mr. A was started on empirical intravenous anti-staphylococcal antibiotics (Flucloxacillin and Rifampicin)  pending sensitivity results. Involvement of cardiothoracic surgery as an outpatient regarding potential aortic valve replacement after completion of his course of intravenous antibiotics.  Future Advice: Major lifestyle modifications were recommended  including advice on smoking cessation and alcohol moderation. His antihypertensive and diabetic medications were also optimized. All advice was also suited to his cultural and religious beliefs.   End-note: This case illustrates the classic clinical presentation of native valve infective endocarditis. Delay in diagnosis can result in worsening prognosis and emphasizes the importance of early recognition. These changes will also have a significant impact on his overall cardiovascular risk in the long term.

Patient Presentation:  The case concerns a 67-year-old Hispanic male named Mr. S. He was a retired janitor  living with his wife in a suburban community. Mr. S was a non-smoker and reported occasional alcohol use on social events. His family history revealed that his father died following a stroke at the age of 75 and his mother had a history of diabetes and passed away from renal complications at the age of 83. No other significant family medical history was indicated.   Past Medical History:  Six years prior to his endocarditis diagnosis  Mr. S was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and hypertension. He had been managing his conditions with a combination of metformin  amlodipine  and lifestyle modifications. Additionally  he had a history of a dental abscess 5 months prior to his endocarditis diagnosis for which he received treatment but did not undergo any prophylactic antibiotic treatment.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. S presented with a three-week history of malaise  fever  night sweats  and unintended weight loss. He had no history of recreational drug use or any recent surgical intervention.  Clinical Findings:  Upon physical examination  he was found febrile with a temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°F)  a heart rate of 95 beats per minute  a blood pressure of 140/95 mm Hg  and a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute. Significant findings included a new heart murmur on auscultation  and Osler nodes on his fingers. The rest of his examination was unremarkable.  Investigations:  Laboratory blood analysis revealed high ESR  CRP and the presence of anemia. Cultures of blood revealed Streptococcus viridans  indicating a probable oral flora origin of bacteremia. An echocardiogram showed mobile vegetations on his mitral valve.  Diagnoses:  The clinical presentation  laboratory findings  positive blood cultures  and echocardiographic evidence supported a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Discussion:  In retrospect  the patient's dental abscess and lack of prophylactic antibiotic treatment may have predisposed him to developing infective endocarditis. The patient had several risk factors for the development of cardiovascular disease  including age  ethnicity  hypertension  and diabetes. These may have contributed to a heightened susceptibility to the effects of the infection on the heart valves.   In considering the demographic trends of infective endocarditis  this disease has been found to occur more commonly in males  individuals over the age of 60  and in those with a history of heart disease. It has also been associated with poor dental hygiene and invasive dental procedures. While race/ethnicity doesn't significantly impact the risk for endocarditis  comorbid conditions like diabetes and hypertension that are prevalent in Hispanic populations can compound the overall cardiovascular risk.  Treatment and prognosis will depend on the severity of the disease  the pathogen involved  and the patient's overall health. The treatment generally involves high-dose  long-term antibiotic therapy  and in some cases  surgery may be required to repair or replace damaged heart valves.

Patient Profile: Mr. A  a 65-year-old Hispanic male  works as a professional gardener  known for his meticulous attention to details whether pertaining to flora or his personal health. With a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis  his cardiac prowess throws itself into scrutiny  warranting intervention. He is a non-smoker and non-alcoholic  maintaining a balanced diet and undertaking light physical activities.   Medical History: He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes a decade ago  remaining well-controlled on Metformin. His father  late Mr. B  departed at 70 due to a myocardial infarction  hence a family history of cardiac illness is prevalent. His mother still flourishes with general age-related ailments at 87. There is no history of any major surgery or blood transfusion that Mr. A had to undergo.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. A presented to the practice with complaints of intermittent high grade fever  anorexia  weight loss and fatigue lasting for a month. On further probing  he affirmed the presence of night sweats and chills.  Examinations and Findings: Initial examination revealed a grade 2/6 systolic murmur. Neurological examination was unremarkable. Ophthalmologic examination found the presence of Roth spots  suggestive of infective endocarditis. Janeway lesions and Osler’s nodes were absent.  Investigations: Blood tests revealed an elevated ESR (60mm/hr) and CRP (80mg/L). Full blood count was within normal range except for slightly raised white cell count (12 x10^9/L). Blood cultures grew Staphylococcus aureus. Echocardiogram showed vegetations on the mitral valve.  Diagnosis: Considering the clinical presentation  examination findings and investigations  Mr. A was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis.  Management: Mr. A was promptly started on empirical antibiotic treatment with intravenous vancomycin  following Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) guidelines for Staphylococcus aureus infective endocarditis  considering the severity of his presentation. Monitoring of blood culture results and echocardiography findings will follow.  Conclusion:  While Mr. A’s age and diabetes put him at higher risk for complications  early diagnosis and continued management could result in a favorable outcome. He will benefit from a multidisciplinary care approach including infectious disease specialists  cardiologists  and potentially  cardiothoracic surgeons. Amidst this  comprehensive patient education shall be emphasized  enumerating the importance of maintaining good oral hygiene and recognizing early endocarditis symptoms to reduce chances of recurrence.

Patient Information: Case Presentation: Mr. J  a 65-year-old African American male who lives alone in an urban area  was admitted to the hospital with a high-grade fever of 39.8°C  extreme fatigue  shortness of breath  and appetite loss. He has a BMI of 28 and is identified as a hypertensive and diabetic patient. Patients from African American descent have been associated with a higher risk for endocarditis due  among other factors  to higher rates of hypertension and diabetes.   Past Medical History: Patients' medical records show a history of poorly controlled type II diabetes mellitus  with a recent HbA1c level at 8.5 percent. He also has hypertension  under control with lisinopril. He underwent dental cleaning about three weeks ago but failed to take his prescribed prophylactic antibiotic due to forgetting. He has no history of intravenous drug use or any other risky behavior  but he is a 10-pack-year smoker. He has a history of mitral valve prolapse  which makes him more susceptible to infective endocarditis.  Family History: Mr. J is a widower with no children. His parents are deceased. His father passed away in his late 80s because of complications related to Alzheimer's disease. His mother passed away in her 70s due to complications of heart disease. His older brother  aged 70  is living with prostate cancer  and his younger sister  aged 63  has type II diabetes and hypertension.  Clinical Findings: Upon examination  Mr. J's blood pressure was 140/90 mmHg  pulse 90 bpm  respirations 22/min  O2 saturation 92%  and weight 78 kg. Notable physical examination findings include pallor  mild pedal edema  and a pansystolic murmur heard best at the apex of the heart. There were no Osler nodes  Roth spots  Janeway lesions  or splinter hemorrhages found  which are commonly associated with endocarditis. Laboratory investigations revealed increased ESR (54 mm/hr)  a high CRP level of 93.9 mg/L and WBC count (14 000/µL). Blood cultures were positive for Viridans Streptococci  which are often associated with infective endocarditis following dental procedures.  Diagnosis and Management: Based on the patient's symptoms  clinical findings  and the Duke Criteria for infective endocarditis  a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis was made. He was started on empiric therapy with IV ceftriaxone and gentamicin  which was later adjusted based on his culture and sensitivity results. He was monitored with daily labs and EKGs to evaluate the effect of treatment and screen for potential complications. He declined cardiothoracic surgery consultation but chose to complete a six-week course of antibiotics.  Conclusion: This case is an example of the consequences of disregarding the recommended prophylactic measures in a patient with a clear predisposition for infective endocarditis. This reinforces the importance of preventative care  particularly in individuals with comorbidities that place them at higher risk for severe infections.   Reference:  Cahill TJ  Prendergast BD. Infective endocarditis. Lancet. 2016;387(10021):882-893.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Information: Patient ""X"" is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired from a physically demanding labor job. He is a nonsmoker and a non-drinker  currently living alone. He has a BMI of 28  classifying him as overweight. The patient reports enjoying a diet high in red meats and processed foods. There is no history of illegal or recreational drug use.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes  which he manages with oral hypoglycemic agents  and hypertension managed by diet and exercise. No history of any surgical intervention is reported.  Presenting Complaint: He presented at the hospital with complaints of persistent fever  chills  fatigue  and a slight shortness of breath for the past fifteen days. There was no report of any chest pain or any other significant symptoms.  Family History: There is a significant family history of cardiac problems  with coronary heart disease being reported in his father  mother  and younger brother  who all passed away in their early 70s.  Physical Examination: Upon examination  he appeared ill  with noticeable weight loss and perspiration. There was noted pallor with icy cold hands. His heart exam revealed a new cardiac murmur suggestive of valvular disease  and Osler’s nodes were present on his fingers.  Diagnosis: Considering the clinical presentation  past medical history  and the classical physical findings  the patient was suspected to have a case of native-valve infective endocarditis  confirmed later by blood cultures and echocardiogram results which revealed vegetations on the native valves.  This case study serves as a typical representative of how Caucasian males in an older age group  particularly with comorbidities like diabetes and hypertension  can become exposed to native-valve infective endocarditis  an infection of the endothelial surface of the heart. The history of consuming a diet high in red meats and processed foods  being overweight  and a strong family history of cardiac diseases further helped support this case.   The key to managing such conditions is early recognition to limit valve destruction and initiate proper treatment  which may involve antibiotics and possible surgical intervention. His strong family cardiac history and his personal history of comorbidities like diabetes and hypertension may make the patient's recovery more challenging.

Patient Presentation  Patient Demographics: S.M. is a 55-year-old Caucasian male  hailing from a middle-class background. He is a non-smoker but has a history of heavy alcohol consumption. He is married with two grown children. According to U.S. health statistics  males  especially the Caucasian population aged 50-59  are at a slightly higher risk of endocarditis due to a combination of lifestyle and physiological factors.  Presenting Complaint: S.M. presented to the emergency department with a fever of 38.4°C  fatigue  weight loss  night sweats  a new-onset cardiac murmur  and a red rash on his legs (Osler's nodes). These symptoms match the criteria for possible infective endocarditis.  Past Medical History: S.M. shares a history of type-2 diabetes and hypertension that has been managed effectively with metformin and hydrochlorothiazide  respectively  for the past 10 years. He also had a minor stroke five years ago  with no significant residue. S.M. also has mild renal impairment  which is monitored regularly.  Family History: Both of S.M's parents are deceased - mother due to breast cancer and father due to heart disease. S.M's sister has rheumatoid arthritis  and his brother has type-2 diabetes. His two children are both healthy adults.  Clinical Findings: Examination revealed pallor  Osler's nodes  Janeway lesions  night sweats  anemia  renal impairment  and inflammation of the heart on an electrocardiogram. Blood cultures tested positive for Staphylococcus aureus  confirming infective endocarditis. A subsequent transthoracic echocardiography supported the diagnosis revealing vegetations on the mitral valve.  Discussion: Given S.M.'s lifestyle choices  his hypertension  and diabetes  he had a predilection for developing native-valve endocarditis. His high blood pressure may damage the inner layer of his artery  making it easier for bacteria to attach and multiply there. Probably the bacteria entered his bloodstream during routine activities such as brushing or flossing since there was no record of a recent surgery or invasive medical procedure.   Management: S.M. is currently being treated with IV antibiotics in the hospital (vancomycin considering Staphylococcus aureus in culture and his renal impairment). He will also be closely monitored by the cardiology team for valve function and the neurology team for stroke risk. His diabetes will also be appropriately managed considering his current health status. He may eventually require mitral valve replacement if there's no improvement on antibiotics.  S.M's case demonstrates the necessity of careful monitoring and management of patients with multiple comorbidities  as complications from one condition can give rise to other severe health problems.

Patient Presentation:   We present the case of a 55-year-old Hispanic male  Mr. J Rodriguez  who was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis (NVE). The patient works as a school janitor and lives in an urban average-income neighborhood in California. He is married  a father of two  and lives with his wife and children.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Rodriguez had been previously managed for type 2 diabetes mellitus for about six years and has a history of substance abuse in his mid-20s that includes cocaine use. However  he has been clean for nearly 30 years. He successfully completed rehab and maintained complete abstinence from illicit substances. He was a smoker throughout his 20s and has quit  but was recently diagnosed with Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) by his primary care physician.   Family History:  Mr. Rodriguez's family history includes a father who suffered from coronary artery disease and passed away due to myocardial infarction at the age of 60. Rodriguez’s mother was recently diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease. His younger brother has been managing hyperlipidemia and hypertension.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient presented with a one-week history of high-grade fever  malaise  night sweats  anorexia  unintentional weight loss  and heart palpitations. The fever failed to recede despite a week of antibiotics administered by his primary care physician.  Investigation:  In line with his symptoms  a blood culture was ordered  which revealed Streptococcus oralis  confirming a diagnosis of infective endocarditis. An echocardiogram further showed the presence of large vegetations on the native mitral valve  supporting the initial diagnosis.  Treatment Plan:  The Infectious Diseases Society of America's (IDSA) guideline for NVE was followed for Mr. Rodriguez. Antibiotic therapy was initiated as recommended by IDSA guidelines along with supportive care for fever and related symptoms. Given the location and size of the vegetations  in consultation with the cardiothoracic surgery team  a decision was taken against early surgical intervention.  Discussion:  Infective endocarditis primarily affects the vegetation of heart valves  commonly affecting individuals with pre-existing heart diseases. Hispanic males above 50  particularly those with diabetes and histories of substance abuse  are at a higher risk  confirming the literature references. It's essential to consider patients' socio-demographic factors when diagnosing and managing NVE as earlier intervention significantly reduces morbidity and mortality.  This case underscores the importance of vigilant clinical assessment and aggressive therapeutic management in patients at high risk for NVE. A detailed and pertinent history is essential for leading clinicians toward the correct diagnosis  which in this case was influenced by the patient's demographic representation  past medical history  family history  and presenting complaints.   The patient's treatment was tailored to his medical history and current clinical status. Regular and detailed follow-up visits were planned  considering the chronicity of the disease process and the risk of potential complications. The patient  his spouse  and his wider family were also educated about the disease  its treatment  and prognosis to ensure compliance and follow-up.

Case Presentation  Patient Profile:  The patient is a 75-year-old African-American male  consistent with literature which suggests a higher prevalence of endocarditis amongst older adults and African Americans. He resides in an urban setting and lives with his wife of 45 years. He is a retired engineer and has a 30 pack-year history of smoking but quit ten years ago. He has no history of alcohol or illicit drug use. His BMI is 29  pointing to overweight issue  but not to the point of obesity.  Past Medical History:  His medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes and hypertension  managed primarily through Metformin and Lisinopril respectively. The patient's hypertension is likely contributory to the heart valve pathology sought to be a source of his endocarditis.   Evaluation:  The patient came with a one-month history of low-grade fever  fatigue  and unexplained weight loss. On physical examination  he had Janeway lesions on his palms and soles as well as Osler nodes on his fingers. The oral examination further revealed poor dental hygiene with multiple untreated caries- a common source of bacteria causing infective endocarditis. Pertinent laboratory findings include raised ESR and CRP levels  mild anemia  and evidence of microhematuria on urinalysis. Further blood cultures have grown Staphylococcus aureus  a common pathogen in native-valve infectious endocarditis.  Diagnostic Confirmation:  An echocardiogram revealed vegetations on the mitral valve consistent with infective endocarditis. There was also evidence of moderate mitral regurgitation.  Management:  The patient is currently under treatment with intravenous antibiotics as per Infective Endocarditis in Adults: Diagnosis and Treatment Guidelines from the American Heart Association.  Family History:  There is a strong family history of cardiovascular diseases. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 70 and his mother had a stroke at 68. His elder sister is being treated for congestive heart failure.  This case underscores the importance of prompt recognition and management of infective endocarditis in the face of known risks such as poor oral hygiene and hypertension and the heightened risk factor considering the strong familial predisposition to cardiovascular diseases.  The patient’s ongoing management strategy will involve monitoring the effectiveness of antibiotic treatment  managing his underlying comorbidities (Diabetes  Hypertension) and considering a possible mitral valve replacement surgery given the signs of moderate mitral regurgitation caused by the vegetation. Further  addressing his poor oral hygiene is critical to prevent a potential future re-infection.  Author’s Note: This case presentation has been anonymized  ensuring there are no HIPAA violations or infringements on patient privacy.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Information: Mr. Thomas Reed  65-year-old Caucasian male.  Chief Complaint: General weakness  fever  sweating  and shortness of breath.  Past Medical History: Mr. Reed has a history of IV drug abuse in his early twenties but has been clean for several decades. He has been on management for hypertension for the last 10 years and is a 20-pack-year history of smoking but quit five years ago. He was diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus 15 years ago  with fairly good control. Additionally  he had a heart attack in his early sixties  for which he received percutaneous coronary intervention and stents placement. He has no known allergies.  Family History: Mr. Reed's father had a history of heart disease and died of a heart attack at an early age. His mother had hypertension and diabetes  and she died of a stroke. His sister  60  is diabetic and on chronic medication for hypertension.  Presenting Complaint: He initially developed generalized malaise two weeks ago which progressed to intermittent fever  sweating  and increasing weakness. He stated he has been feeling unusually tired and short of breath even on mild exertion. He has noticed that he has lost some weight recently  though he hasn’t been trying  and has noticed a decreased appetite. His wife noticed that his palms have become redder.  Physical Examination: Fever was noted (101.1 F). The patient looked acutely ill and was sweating. Auscultation revealed a new cardiac murmur. Additionally  a few petechiae were seen on the skin  and the extremities were cool to touch. Pulses were slightly irregular.  Investigations and Diagnosis: Blood tests revealed a high white cell count and raised inflammatory markers (CRP and ESR). Three sets of blood cultures were taken. Echocardiogram showed vegetations on the mitral valve indicating native-valve infective endocarditis  which corresponds with his presenting symptoms. Blood cultures further confirmed growth of Staphylococcus aureus  consistent with infective endocarditis. An abdominal ultrasound showed mild splenomegaly.  Patient Progress and Treatment: The patient was immediately commenced on IV antibiotics based on initial culture results (modified later as per culture sensitivity reports)  and cardiology was consulted for potential surgical treatment. The patient was educated on the importance of dental hygiene and to avoid any procedures that could lead to an infection henceforth due to his newfound risk for repeated endocarditis incidents.  Summary: This reinforces that patients with drug abuse history  despite prolonged abstinence  retain the vulnerability for infective endocarditis. It underlines the importance of routine dental care & avoidance of procedures that can lead to infections in these individuals due to this enhanced risk. Note: This case presentation is purely fictional and does not represent any particular individual living or deceased. The data provided is meant to provide an example of how a medical professional might approach an actual patient's case.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 63-year-old African American male who presented to the emergency department with a 4-week history of nighttime sweats  fatigue  weight loss  and an intermittent high-grade fever. He works as a janitor and reports having no recent travel history or significant exposures.  Past Medical History:   The patient has a history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He had been a smoker with a 40-pack year smoking history but quit 15 years prior. His medications include metformin  lisinopril  and a short-acting bronchodilator. He reports non-compliance to medications due to financial constraints. He has no history of intravenous drug use or known exposure to tuberculosis.   Family History:   His mother died at the age of 72 due to complications from stroke  and his father died at the age of 75 due to heart failure. He has two sisters who are living and healthy  one with type 2 diabetes. He has no known family history of endocarditis.   Physical Examination:   Upon examination  he is fatigued and febrile with a temperature of 39°C. Other vital signs include a blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg  a mildly tachycardic rate of 105 beats per minute  and a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute with oxygen saturation of 96% on room air.  Cardiovascular exam reveals a new  harsh  pansystolic murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border. There were no stigmata of endocarditis found on skin or eye exam. The rest of the physical examination  including lung auscultation  abdominal exam  and neurological examination  are within normal limits.   Investigations and Diagnosis:   Lab findings showed hemoglobin of 9.8 g/dl  white cell count of 15 000 microliter  and platelets of 400 000 microliter. Blood cultures grew Streptococcus viridians. Chest X-Ray was unremarkable. An ECG showed left ventricular hypertrophy but no arrhythmia or signs of ischemia. A transesophageal echocardiogram revealed a large  mobile echodensity on the mitral valve consistent with vegetation.  The patient’s clinical presentation  blood cultures  and the presence of new murmur  met the criteria for Duke's definitive diagnosis of infective endocarditis.   Course of Treatment:  The patient was admitted to the hospital and started on intravenous antibiotics based on sensitivity testing  after which he showed some improvement in his general condition. Surgical consult recommended mitral valve replacement once the infection was controlled. The patient's social circumstances and medication compliance issues were noted and addressed by the healthcare team and social services.  This case reflects the demographics found in existing literature  as infective endocarditis is more common in men than women  and African Americans have a higher prevalence of risk factors such as hypertension and diabetes. The case also accurately describes common symptoms  as well as diagnostic and treatment procedures for infective endocarditis.

Patient Presentation:  Subject Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 65 years old Occupation: Retired Race: Caucasian Sex: Male  Demographics: Mr. Doe hails from a suburban community in the Midwest  United States. As a retiree  he enjoys a quiet life with his wife of 40 years. He has three adult children  none of whom have medical conditions related to infective endocarditis. None of them has had any form of congenital heart disease  connective tissue disease  or intravenous (IV) drug use that is known to increase the risk of the condition.   Past Medical History: Upon detailed medical history taking  it was found that Mr. Doe had a medical background of Rheumatic Heart Disease during his late childhood years. He also had mild hypertension managed with low-dose thiazide diuretic which has remained under control. No history of diabetes or other autoimmune diseases. Prior to the current episode  his last hospital admission was over 20 years ago for appendectomy. He has no history of IV drug use  blood transfusions  recent dental procedures  or recent travel history.  Presenting Symptoms: Mr. Doe presented at the hospital with symptoms including fever of 38.6°C and severe fatigue persisting for two weeks. He also complained about weight loss  night sweats  and occasional shortness of breath on exertion. Further examination revealed a new heart murmur that had not been noted previously  along with petechiae in his conjunctiva and lower extremities.  Diagnostic Evaluation: With the given history and clinical findings  a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis was suspected. Blood cultures tested positive for Streptococcus viridans. An echocardiogram revealed aortic valve vegetations  confirming the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis per the modified Duke Criteria.  Treatment Plan: Mr. Doe was immediately started on culture-specific IV antibiotics. Close monitoring of his cardiac function and clinical status was done. An interprofessional team approach was taken for his case  involving a cardiologist  infectious disease specialist  and a dietician.  Discussion: While he lacks the most common risk factors for infective endocarditis – IV drug use  prosthetic heart valves or cardiac implants  immunosuppression – Mr. Doe does have a history of rheumatic heart disease which damages heart valves and can predispose to future infections. Thus  the case highlights the importance of systemic assessment  clinical vigilance  and long-term follow up of at-risk populations such as those with a history of rheumatic heart disease.  Differential Diagnoses:  Atypical pneumonia  Tuberculosis  Leukemia  Lymphoma  HIV  Prognosis: With timely IV antibiotics and supportive care  Mr. Doe is expected to have a favorable prognosis. However  potential complications like heart failure  septicemia and systemic emboli need to be monitored closely. Chronic monitoring of cardiac function and prophylactic measures are paramount given his history of rheumatic heart disease.   Patient education regarding the need for regular follow ups and timely reporting of symptoms  especially before any surgical or dental procedures is necessary. This case study emphasizes the consideration of infective endocarditis in the differential diagnosis for patients presenting with vague prolonged febrile illnesses  especially in the setting of prior heart disease.

Patient Presentation:  Patient's Initials: A.B. Age: 65 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired  Chief Complaint: A.B. presents with symptoms of fatigue  fever  decreased appetite  and weight loss for the past couple of weeks.   Past Medical History: A.B. has a history of intermittent heart murmurs  was diagnosed with mitral valve prolapse 3 years ago. However  he refused prophylaxis after being educated about the risk of endocarditis. He also has a 10-year history of Type II diabetes mellitus  managing it with lifestyle modifications and medication. A.B. has been smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for the last 30 years  consuming alcohol occasionally.  Family History: The patient's mother suffered from rheumatic heart disease and his father died of a myocardial infarction.   Social History: A.B. lives alone in a suburban area. He is a widower with two adult children who live out of state. His financial situation is stable.  Physical Examination: A.B.'s vital signs were stable except for a temperature of 38.1°C (100.6°F). Cardiac auscultation revealed a mid-systolic click and a late systolic murmur. He showed signs of conjunctival pallor and splinter hemorrhages were seen under the nails.  Diagnostic Tests: Lab tests revealed the presence of anemia and high ESR. A positive blood culture for Streptococcus viridans was obtained  indicating an ongoing bacterial infection. EKG showed irregular heart rhythm. Echocardiography confirmed the presence of vegetations on the mitral valve  consistent with infective endocarditis.  Diagnosis: Based on the clinical symptoms  lab findings  and imaging data  A.B. was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis.   Discussion: Infective endocarditis is more common in males and people over 60. A.B.'s pre-existing heart condition (mitral valve prolapse)  diabetes  and lifestyle behavior (smoking) put him at higher risk. The patient's refusal of prophylaxis after the initial diagnosis of mitral valve issue has also contributed to the current infection.  Plan: A.B's treatment plan includes hospitalization and administration of intravenous antibiotics for 4-6 weeks. Patient education regarding the importance of medication compliance will also be given due emphasis. Considering his smoking history  counseling for smoking cessation will also be initiated. A dietitian will be consulted for diet modification to manage both endocarditis and diabetes.  Educating A.B. about the criticality of his condition and the possible complications  including heart failure  stroke  and the necessity of heart valve surgery  is essential to ensure he understands the importance of following medical advice.  Follow-up: After completion of the antibiotic treatment  A.B. is to be closely followed up to assess for symptom relief and echocardiograph improvement. Regular check-ups are also crucial to control diabetes and monitor for potential cardiac complications.

Patient Presentation  Subject: An 60-year-old African-American male  Medical history: Hypertensive and smoker for the past 20 years. No prior known cardiac disease. Noncompliant with antihypertensive medications. Last known visit to a healthcare provider was three years ago.  Family history: His father died of myocardial infarction at age 65. Mother has hypertension and diabetes. Sibling has a history of stroke.  Presenting Complaint: He presented at the emergency department  reporting two weeks of persistent fever  fatigue  and unexplained weight loss. He also mentioned experiencing shortness of breath  especially on exertion  and nocturnal sweating.  Physical Examination Findings: Examination revealed the patient's blood pressure to be 155/95 mmHg  a heart rate of 90/min  and a temperature of 38.5°C. The patient demonstrated a cardiac murmur suggestive of valve disease  and small  flat  painless spots (Janeway Lesions) noted on the palms and soles.  Investigations: Blood cultures returned positive for Staphylococcus aureus. Transthoracic and Transesophageal Echocardiogram revealed vegetations on the mitral valve with severe mitral regurgitation  diagnostic of endocarditis.  Management: The patient was admitted for in-patient management - intravenous antibiotics with nafcillin and gentamicin were administered for six weeks. His blood pressure management was optimized with the introduction of an ACE inhibitor and a diuretic.  Discussion: The patient is a perfect representation of a demographic group that presents a high risk for developing native-valve infective endocarditis due to several factors  including his age  race  longstanding untreated hypertension  smoking habits  and noncompliance with medical treatment for blood pressure. His delayed presentation is typical and contributed to the established severe mitral valve damage and systemic manifestations seen on admission.  Native-valve Infective Endocarditis remains a significant health concern due to its high morbidity and mortality. Its diagnosis can be challenging due to its protean manifestations  but a strong index of suspicion in high-risk groups can lead to prompt diagnosis and management. Coupled with the need for patients to adhere to their medication regimens and a more regular follow-up to monitor their chronic conditions.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  who presents with complaints of fever  fatigue  unexplained weight loss  and night sweats for the past three weeks. He has a past medical history of Stage 2 hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He also reported a recent dental procedure completed a month ago without pre-medication. He is not currently on any immunosuppressant drugs. The patient lives with his wife  is retired  and they both enjoy gardening.  Past Medical History:  The patient was diagnosed with high blood pressure at the age of 52 years and later diagnosed with type 2 diabetes around the age of 60 years. He has been well managed on Metformin 1000mg twice daily and Lisinopril 20mg once daily. He has no history of previous surgeries or known allergies. He does not smoke  has an occasional alcohol intake  and denies use of illegal substances.  Family History:  His father had a history of heart disease and succumbed to a myocardial infarction at the age of 68 years. His mother is 85 years old and has type 2 diabetes and hypertension. His two siblings are alive and well  with the older brother having diabetes.  Presenting Issue:  Clinical investigations revealed the patient has a slightly elevated white blood cell count  blood cultures yielded Streptococcus viridans  and an echocardiogram revealed vegetations on the mitral valve suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis. He was started on appropriate antibiotics.  The lack of premedication prior to a tooth extraction may have led to the spread of bacteria to the heart causing endocarditis. His comorbidities (hypertension and diabetes) may have heightened his risk for infection.  Plan:  The patient is admitted for inpatient care to monitor and manage his condition. He will be given a course of intravenous antibiotics and undergo regular echocardiograms to monitor the status of the heart valves. Lifestyle modifications will be suggested and the importance of preventative oral care and pre-medication before dental procedures will be emphasized.  Discussion:  The demographic of the patient  Caucasian male  age above 60 years  co-morbidities like hypertension and diabetes  aligns with what is often reported in literature for patients with native-valve infective endocarditis. Factors such as dental procedures without prophylactic antibiotics and poor glycemic control can increase the risk for this infection. This case underscores the importance of proper dental care and use of prophylactic antibiotics in individuals with risk factors.

Patient Presentation  Our patient is a 67-year-old African American male named Mr. J  coming from the inner city of Chicago. This demographic group is likely to have higher rates of cardiovascular diseases. Mr. J was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis. He has a past history of IV drug abuse  which is a common risk factor for this condition. His drug usage was comparatively higher than most cases  significantly increasing his chances.   Mr. J was clinically obese (BMI 30.5) and has a history of rheumatic heart disease  hypertension  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  poorly managed over the years. The chronic disorders might have damaged the valves of his heart  making him susceptible to infective endocarditis.   Family History  Mr. J family history reveals that his father died of heart attack at age 56 and his mother was diagnosed with hypertension and diabetes  both of which could be associated with increased genetic predisposition to cardiovascular disease. An important aspect is that Mr. J’s younger brother also had a history of substance abuse  however his drugs of choice were alcohol and cigarettes  and due to multiple public intoxication offenses  he also presented with a legal history.   Health Behaviors  Mr. J is a smoker  smoking 2 packs of cigarettes a day for the last 35 years  exacerbating his condition. Unfortunately  Mr. J also has a poor nutritional habit; he often eats fast food  attributing his obesity and poor diabetic control.   Recent Problems  Three weeks ago  Mr. J had symptoms similar to a common flu  such as fever  fatigue  muscle ache  and night sweats but did not seek immediate medical attention. However  recently he has been experiencing severe chest pain accompanied by shortness of breath. His neighbor found him unconscious in his house  so he was immediately rushed to our emergency department.   On physical examination  he had a high fever  elevated blood pressure  and a new murmur was detected upon cardiac auscultation  raising the suspicion of infective endocarditis. The lab results  including a positive blood culture for Staphylococcus aureus and his echocardiogram showing vegetation on his mitral valve  confirmed our diagnosis.   Conclusion   Mr. J’s case is a textbook presentation of native-valve infective endocarditis resulting from IV drug abuse  chronic health conditions  and negative health behaviors like smoking and poor diet. His delayed treatment led to a complicated medical situation. His condition has improved after undergoing valve replacement surgery and multi-drug antibiotic therapy  highlighting the need for immediate attention and action when facing symptomatic complaints  and the crucial role of lifestyle choices in managing health conditions.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe is a 57-year-old Caucasian male from Charleston  South Carolina  presented with a 3-week history of intermittent fever  night sweats  and malaise  showing classical signs of an infection. He denies any history of intravenous drug use  recent dental procedures  or signs of septicemia. He resides in a suburban area with his wife and works as a carpenter. He has been a smoker for 35 years  averaging one pack per day. He occasionally drinks alcohol on weekends. His diet consists predominantly of fast foods  due to hectic work schedules.   Past Medical History:  He has a known history of mild hypertension  diagnosed five years ago  which is controlled on medication (Lisinopril 10 mg/day). He was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus three years ago and is on Metformin (500mg twice daily). He has a history of Rheumatic fever during his childhood  though he did not have any valve abnormalities prior to this admission.  Family History:  Regarding family medical history  his mother had Hypertension and died of a stroke at 72  and his father battled lung cancer and passed away at 66.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Doe came to the clinic with chief complaints of fever  night sweats  and malaise which did not improve with over-the-counter medications. He had felt a general weakness and decreased productivity at work. He noticed some unexplained weight loss but wrote it off due to his intense work. On physical examination  he had an irregular pulse rate  and a systolic murmur was evident on auscultation.  Investigations:  His lab reports showed increased ESR  CRP  and the presence of anemia. Blood cultures isolated Streptococcus viridans  suggesting infective endocarditis. An echocardiography revealed vegetations on the native valve confirming the diagnosis - native valve infective endocarditis.  Management Plan:  Following the guideline-based strategy  he was promptly initiated on antibiotic therapy with Penicillin G and Gentamicin to target the identified organisms. This treatment regime is planned for up to 6 weeks  according to the AHA’s guidelines for the management of infective endocarditis.  Summary:  Mr. Doe's occupation as a carpenter and his lifestyle habits  including long-term smoking and unhealthy diet  contribute to his overall medium-to-high risk profile. He already had pre-existing conditions - Hypertension and Diabetes. Patients with Diabetes tend to have a higher risk of infections and complications. His past history of Rheumatic fever brings out susceptibility towards cardiac issues and further complicated by his age. His family history also indicates a possible predisposition to cardiovascular diseases.   His clinical presentation  test findings  and the identification of Streptococcus viridans lead to a confirmed diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis  which appears to be a complication of his past rheumatic fever and acerbated by his diabetic condition. Presently  efforts are on to treat the infection aggressively to prevent complications like congestive heart failure and septicemia.

Patient Presentation: The patient is a 57-year-old African-American male with past medical history significant for Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  well-controlled with Metformin  and Mild Hypertension  managed by dietary changes. He has been admitted to the hospital with complaints of persistent fatigue  intermittent fever  and weight loss for the past few weeks.   Social History: The patient is a non-smoker and occasionally consumes alcohol. He is employed as a carpenter and lives with his wife and three adult children. No history of illicit drug use or recent travel.  Family History: His father had coronary artery disease and mother had stroke. No immediate family history of heart valve disorders  rheumatic heart disease  or other cardiac diseases.  Clinical Findings: On examination  he was noted to have a new systolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. Also  petechiae were observable on the conjunctiva  palate  and over the upper extremities. Further investigations were prompted in view of these findings and his symptoms.  Investigations: His CBC showed moderate anemia with a Hb of 8.7g/dl  WBC count of 12000/mm3  predominantly neutrophils  and an ESR of 75mm/hr. His blood sugars were well controlled  renal parameters were within the normal range  lipid profile showed borderline high LDL and normal HDL. 3 sets of blood cultures were sent and he was started on empirical antibiotic treatment and underwent Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE). The TEE demonstrated a vegetation on the atrial aspect of the mitral valve.  Hospital Course: Blood culture results showed growth of Streptococcus viridans  sensitive to Penicillin. Antibiotic therapy was deescalated to Intravenous Penicillin and the patient showed significant improvement with these interventions.  Diagnosis: Based on the positive blood culture finding confirming bacteremia  the TEE findings and his clinical presentation  a diagnosis of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis caused by Streptococcus viridans was made.  Prognosis: He has been counseled regarding the seriousness of his condition  the need for long-term antibiotic therapy  and the possible need for surgical intervention if medical management fails. Risk factors for morbidity include his co-existing conditions of diabetes and hypertension which can complicate management and recovery.  This case is representative of clinical presentations commonly encountered with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis. Due consideration has been given to his demographic  occupation  and past medical history as these factors could contribute to his disease development and progression.

Patient Information: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presenting from his home. He has been retired for two years and lived alone since the passing of his wife about three years ago. He is not an avid smoker nor does he drink alcohol. He used to work in a factory that exposed him to mercury and lead among other elements contrastingly high to average.  Past Medical History: The patient had been diagnosed with Rheumatic Heart Disease (RHD) in his early 40s. He has been on prophylactic antibiotics (Penicillin) since his diagnosis to prevent streptococcal infections. Furthermore  he has suffered from Diabetes Mellitus type II and hypertension for 15 years. He is under regular medication for his conditions including Metformin  ACE inhibitors  and beta-blockers. There is no history of recent dental procedures  or any other invasive interventions. He has not had any blood transfusions in the past.  Family History: Both his parents had died of heart disease; a myocardial infarction for his father and heart failure for his mother. The paternal side of his family also has a noted history of RHD. On the maternal side  his mother had type II Diabetes Melitus. He has two siblings  a sister who suffers from hypertension and a brother who is healthy.  Presenting Complaints: The patient visited the clinic with the principal complaint of high fever (38.5-degree Celsius)  persistent fatigue  unintended weight loss  night sweats and slight breathlessness on exertion  for a period of last 4 to 5 weeks. On further investigation  he also reported experiencing a periodic and sudden change in vision  accompanied by a headache.  Physical Examination: On auscultation  a murmur was detected suggestive of aortic valve damage. He had some petechial rashes on his chest and conjunctival hemorrhages. The peripheral pulses were unequal  and rapid. There was no noted clubbing  pallor  jaundice  or lymphadenopathy. Neurological examination remained non-significant.  Diagnostic Assessment: Blood culture has been carried out due to suspicion of Infective Endocarditis  which subsequently revealed the growth of Staphylococcus aureus. The echocardiogram revealed an oscillating intracardiac mass on aortic valve consistent with vegetation. His blood glucose level was high  suggesting the need for further management of diabetes. His ECG showed nonspecific ST-T wave changes but no acute ischemia.  Treatment: The patient was commenced on intravenous Vancomycin and Gentamycin to manage the infective endocarditis. His diabetes medicine was adjusted to cope with his current blood glucose levels. He was admitted to the hospital for careful monitoring and frequent evaluation of his vitals and overall health.  Conclusion: This clinical scenario is a classical presentation of a subacute native-valve infective endocarditis in an older male patient. The bacterial infection was likely secondary to his pre-existing heart condition - RHD. This case further emphasizes the importance of early diagnosis and aggressive treatment of infective endocarditis in patients with valvular heart disease  to prevent potential lethal complications. Sustained efforts should be focused on monitoring and managing his co-morbid conditions such as diabetes and hypertension that may further complicate his case. His family history and previous workplace exposure should not be ignored as potential risk factors. This patient requires error-prone antibiotic therapy  as well as a comprehensive plan for long-term care and lifestyle modification advice.

Subject: Case Presentation: 68-year-old Male Patient Diagnosed with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Patient Information: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male presented to a community hospital emergency department with fatigue  low-grade fever  and a new murmur on the cardiac exam. He denies any recent history of dental procedures  intravenous drug use  or any skin infections. He resides in a suburban area and lives with his wife.  Medical History: The patient has a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which are well-controlled with medication (Lisinopril 10 mg daily and Atorvastatin 20 mg daily  respectively). He underwent coronary artery bypass graft surgery 5 years prior with no postoperative complications. He does not have any known allergies. He does not smoke  occasionally consumes alcohol  and has no history of illicit drug usage.  Family History: His father had coronary artery disease and passed away in his 70s due to a myocardial infarction  and his mother died of a stroke at the age of 81. His elder sister is currently battling breast cancer. There are no known familial forms of congenital heart diseases in the family.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  the patient appeared fatigued but was otherwise in no acute distress. Vital signs revealed a temperature of 38.2°C  blood pressure of 135/85 mmHg  pulse rate 90/min  and respiratory rate of 18/min. Cardiac examination revealed a new grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur heard best at the apex  moving to the axilla. There were no visible skin lesions  such as Osler nodes or Janeway lesions  nor were there splinter hemorrhages on the nails. His abdomen was soft and non-tender.  Diagnostic Assessment: Blood cultures were obtained  and the patient was admitted for further evaluation. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) and transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) confirmed a vegetation on the mitral valve consistent with infective endocarditis. Cultures showed positivity for Streptococcus viridans.  Treatment and Outcome: The patient was started on empirical antibiotics upon admission based on clinical suspicion. After culture sensitivity results  the antibiotics were adjusted to high-dose penicillin G combined with gentamicin. The patient responded well to this antibiotic regimen. He showed considerable improvement with resolution of fever  and repeat blood cultures were negative. He was discharged after six weeks of treatment and is being regularly followed up in the cardiology outpatient department.  This case presentation is representative of the demographic and clinical profile of native-valve infective endocarditis. It highlights the importance of early suspicion and investigation in patients with a new murmur and nonspecific symptoms  particularly in those with a history of heart disease.  References: Patients with native-valve infective endocarditis have been widely studied  and this presentation is consistent with the epidemiology and symptomatology reported in literature. The case reflects the common bacterial pathogens involved and the treatment approach typically used.

Patient Presentation:  Our patient is a 65-year-old African-American male diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis. This individual has a past medical history significant for hypertension controlled with medication  a 20-year pack history of smoking  and moderate alcohol consumption. He denies IV drug use. His family history is remarkable for a mother who suffered a stroke at the age of 72 and a father who died from myocardial infarction in his 60s. His sister  who is in her fifties now  has type 2 diabetes. There is no family history of rheumatologic disease or other heart-related conditions.  The patient presented to the emergency department with persistent fever for one week  malaise  and a new-onset murmur heard at the left lower sternal border. Decreased breath sounds in the left lung were noted on the physical examination. Notoriously  he additionally reported unplanned weight loss for the last two months  night sweats  joint pain  and previously unexperienced episodes of shortness of breath.   A complete blood count showed leukocytosis—17 000/uL with 90% neutrophils—and an elevated C-reactive protein level was noted. Blood cultures were also drawn at the time of evaluation  which latter showed gram-positive cocci in clusters  consistent with Staphylococcus aureus.   An echocardiogram revealed moderate aortic valve regurgitation with large vegetations on the cusps of the aortic valve  suggesting the diagnosis of infective endocarditis. The lung examination and hypoxemia signs might pointed out to septic emboli.  During his course of hospitalization  our patient needed further diagnostic procedures and aggressive treatment with antibiotics. He was also assessed for surgical intervention for valve replacement due to his heart failure symptoms and large vegetation size.   Management of his condition was challenging given his past medical history and lifestyle risk factors. A multi-disciplinary approach was adopted  involving cardiology  cardiothoracic surgery  and infectious diseases.  This case remains central in considering the high-risk population susceptible to developing infective endocarditis  especially among elderly African-American males who smoke  consume alcohol  and have hypertension.   Conclusion: Elderly patients with a history of smoking  alcohol consumption  and hypertension may be at a higher risk for developing native valve infective endocarditis. Of note  these individuals may not always have classical features  such as IV drug use or a previous history of rheumatic heart disease. Continued vigilance is needed to diagnose and manage individuals like our patient successfully.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. J.D.  who presented to the emergency department with complaints of intermittent low-grade fever for a month  malaise  loss of appetite and a weight loss of about 8 pounds. He also reports dyspnea and occasional nocturnal dry cough. The patient lives with his wife in a small suburban home  and they do not have any pets. He is retired and previously worked as a plumber for 20 years.  Past Medical History:  Mr. J.D. has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) for which he uses Salbutamol inhalation occasionally. He has hypertension and dyslipidemia  both well-controlled with Amlodipine 5mg daily and Atorvastatin 20mg daily. He also has a history of occasional alcohol consumption  but he quit smoking ten years ago.  Family History:  In addition  there is a notable family history of heart disease; his father died from an acute myocardial infarction at the age of 67  and his older brother has been diagnosed with coronary artery disease. His mother is alive and well at 85 with a history of osteoarthritis and hypertension. He has a younger sister with type 2 diabetes mellitus.  Findings on Examination:  On physical exam  he appeared exhausted and in discomfort. His vital signs were as follows: temperature of 100.3°F  heart rate of 96 bpm  respiratory rate of 20 bpm  blood pressure of 145/85 mmHg  and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. His cardiac examination revealed a new-onset grade 2/6 systolic murmur best heard at the apex. Further systematic examination revealed occasional inspiratory crackles in the right lower bronchial region and mild peripheral edema.  Investigation Results:  Laboratory investigations showed elevated ESR and CRP levels. His blood cultures grew Streptococcus viridans  consistent with the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis (IE). An ECG showed normal sinus rhythm. Echocardiography revealed moderate aortic regurgitation with vegetation on the aortic valve.  Treatment Plan:  He has been admitted to the cardiology department for further management. Antimicrobial therapy was started as per the Infectious Diseases Society of America's (IDSA) guidelines for IE  including Ceftriaxone and Gentamycin. His condition is being carefully monitored due to the added risk factors of COPD and heart disease. A multidisciplinary team  including cardiology  infectious disease  and internal medicine specialists  is involved in his care.  Follow-up:  Mr. J.D. will continue to be monitored closely for response to the antimicrobial regimen  and changes will be made as necessary. Depending on the progression of his condition  surgical intervention may be needed. His COPD and hypertension management will be optimized to avoid further complications. He will also be referred to a dietary and fitness regimen to improve his overall health. His family members will be encouraged to get screened for heart disease  considering the significant family history.   This case illustrates the complexity of managing an older adult with multiple comorbidities presenting with infective endocarditis  necessitating a comprehensive and multidisciplinary approach.

Patient Presentation:  Background Information: The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male who is a retired schoolteacher. He has a known past medical history of mitral valve prolapse (MVP)  hypertension  and type II diabetes. The patient is a non-smoker  with a moderate alcohol intake. His mother reportedly died from stroke at 70  and a brother has been recently diagnosed with coronary artery disease. Apart from the MVP  there is no family history of congenital heart disease. The patient currently lives with his wife and has three adult children  all in good health.  Recent Health Status: Three weeks prior to presentation  the patient had a minor dental procedure conducted and experienced unremitting fever which ranged between 38 - 39°C accompanied by fatigue and significant weight loss. There was no history of illicit drug use or recent travel.  Physical examination: On presentation  the patient was febrile and had peripheral manifestations of endocarditis including Janeway lesions  splinter hemorrhages under the fingernails  and Osler's nodes. Heart auscultation revealed a new systolic murmur indicative of mitral regurgitation.  Investigations: Lab results include white blood cells of 15 000/uL  erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 75mm/hr  C-reactive protein (CRP) of 90mg/L. Blood culture yielded Streptococcus viridans. An echocardiogram displayed vegetations on the mitral valve and worsening of mitral regurgitation.  Diagnosis: The patient  thus  was diagnosed with infective endocarditis affecting the native mitral valve. Given his recent dental procedure and the culture results showing Streptococcus viridans  it can be deduced that the dental procedure might have triggered the bacteremia and subsequent colonization of the already susceptible mitral valve due to the MVP.  Plan: The patient was started on a 6-week course of intravenous penicillin  which is bactericidal to Streptococcus species. Gentamicin is also added for the initial two weeks to target a possible drug-resistant phenotype and for its synergistic effect alongside penicillin. Surgical evaluation for mitral valve repair or replacement would be necessitated if the patient shows signs of heart failure  persistent infection despite appropriate antibiotics or recurrent emboli. Education is also provided to the patient about the need for prophylactic antibiotics before future dental procedures.  Conclusion: This case underlines the importance of bacterial endocarditis prophylaxis in patients undergoing dental or other procedures that could lead to transient bacteremia  especially in those with a known risk factor for endocarditis like mitral valve prolapse. It is essential for clinicians to be vigilant and catch the first signs of this grave yet treatable disease.

Patient Presentation  Patient: Mr. Garcia  a 64-year-old Hispanic man.   Presenting complaint: Reported to the emergency department with a three-week history of fatigue  mild fever  weight loss  and occasional night sweats.  Past Medical History: Mr. Garcia has a history of type II diabetes  for which he takes Metformin. He had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) five years ago but has had controlled blood pressure since then. He occasionally uses over-the-counter non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for arthritis pain.  Social History: Mr. Garcia is a retired office worker  lives independently  and does not use tobacco or illicit drugs. He consumes alcohol in moderation and does not have a known history of intravenous drug use. His only travels were within the United States.   Family history: His mother had type II diabetes  his father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 70  and his only sibling has hypertension.
