Examination & Results: On physical examination  the patient seemed cachectic. His temperature was mildly elevated (99.8°F). Cardiac auscultation revealed a systolic murmur. Blood investigations showed mild anemia and a raised erythrocyte sedimentation rate. His kidney and liver function tests were normal. Blood cultures taken were positive for Staphylococcus aureus.   Further Findings: Upon suspicion of infective endocarditis  a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) was performed  which reported a vegetative growth on the native mitral valve  confirming the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.   Progress & Follow-up: The patient was immediately started on proper antibiotics and referred to a cardiologist for further consideration of surgery. Mr. Garcia's family was informed of his condition and the importance of immediate and regular follow-up.  Discussion: Infective endocarditis  although rare  is more common among older males and more prevalent among the Hispanic population. Key risk factors include heart valve diseases  intravenous drug abuse  and a history of invasive procedures. In this case  Mr. Garcia's poor diabetic control might have predisposed him to this infection in the absence of other common risk factors. The late presentation is typical  as the initial symptoms are non-specific  often leading to diagnostic delay.

Patient Presentation  The patient is a 55-year-old Hispanic male who presents with a 2-week history of intermittent fever  shortness of breath  and palpitations.   Medical History  He has a past medical history notable for intravenous drug use (IVDU) which ended fifteen years ago and poorly controlled type II diabetes mellitus. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. He does not exercise regularly and his diet predominantly consists of high carbohydrate foods.  Family History  The patient’s family history is significant for heart disease. His father passed away at the age of 62 due to a myocardial infarction. The patient’s mother is alive and well  aged 87.   Presenting Complaint  Now he reports a feeling of ""pounding in his chest"" along with extreme fatigue. He reports recurrent bouts of nocturnal sweat with a low-grade fever over the same period as well. He has developed dyspnea  initially on exertion  which has progressively worsened to being at rest. The patient also has been losing weight over the past few weeks despite no changes in diet or activity levels.  Clinical Findings  Physical examination reveals the patient to be in mild distress  with a temperature of 38.5 C  pulse of 104/min  blood pressure of 123/82 mm Hg  respiratory rate of 18/min  and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. Cardiac examination revealed an early diastolic decrescendo murmur heard best at the left sternal border and the presence of Janeway's lesions were noted in the patient's palms. Chest auscultation revealed bibasilar crackles.  Clinical Status and Diagnosis  Laboratory investigations showed leukocytosis and positive blood cultures for Staphylococcus aureus. An ECG showed tachycardia without signs of ischemia. An echocardiogram revealed the presence of a mobile echogenic mass attached to the posterior leaflet of the mitral valve with moderate mitral regurgitation  consistent with infective endocarditis (IE).  Treatment  The patient was started on intravenous (IV) ceftriaxone and vancomycin  in consultation with an infectious disease specialist. Plans have been made for potential cardiac surgery  in case of failure of antibiotic therapy or in the presence of life-threatening complications.  Conclusion  This case highlights a presentation of native-valve infective endocarditis  a serious complication associated with increased cardiac mortality. This patient’s history of IVDU coupled with poor diabetes control likely put him at greater risk for the development of IE. A multidisciplinary approach is required to manage such cases optimally.

Patient Overview:   Mr. J  a 73-year-old African American male  retired construction worker  presents to the emergency department with symptoms of high-grade fever  chills  weakness  unintentional weight loss  and night sweats for two weeks. No known drug allergies  a non-smoker  and social alcohol use only.  Past Medical History:  Patient has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with metformin and diet. Additionally  the patient had recently been treated for Staphylococcus aureus related skin infection six months ago. No history of surgeries or hav ing any intravascular devices. No previous hospitalizations.  Family History:  Mr. J's mother had died of stroke in her late 70s  and his father had a history of cardiac issues. There are no instances of endocarditis or similar heart disorders in his immediate or extended family.  Clinical Findings:  Physical exam revealed a blood pressure of 100/60 mmHg  a heart rate of 110 bpm  temperature of 38.5°C (febrile)  and respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute. Findings from a cardiac examination were notable for a new-onset murmur over the apex of the heart. Lab findings included leukocytosis  slightly decreased hemoglobin  positive blood cultures for Staphylococcus aureus and elevated inflammatory markers (ESR  CRP).  Diagnostic Assessment:  Considering the clinical and lab findings  the patient was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis likely secondary to Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia. This was confirmed on Transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) that demonstrated vegetations on the mitral valve.  Treatment:  The patient was immediately started on empirical treatment including intravenous (IV) vancomycin and gentamicin  according to the American Heart Association (AHA) guidelines for Staphylococcal infective endocarditis.  Prognosis:  Despite the serious nature of the condition  with prompt and appropriate antibiotic therapy  the prognosis can be favorable. However  in some cases  it may require valve replacement surgery. Due to his age and co-morbid conditions  there is potential for complications. The patient and his family were counseled about the condition  likely prognosis  and intended management approach.  Epidemiological data indicates that infective endocarditis is more prevalent in older adults  males  those with diabetes  IV drug users  and individuals with a previous history of a similar condition. Mr. J fits into the first two high-risk demographic categories; these factors along with the skin infection might have made a him prime candidate for such an infection.  This case demonstrates the importance of maintaining a high degree of suspicion for infective endocarditis in patients presenting with fever of unknown origin  especially in those with a relevant demographic and clinical history  as swift diagnosis and treatment can significantly improve patient outcomes.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 54-year-old African American male carpenter  living in urban United States. He presents to the emergency department with a two-week history of fever  malaise  and arthralgias  weight loss of about eight pounds  loss of appetite  and night sweats. He denies chest pain  dyspnea  cough  or other respiratory symptoms  changes in bowel habits  or recent travel.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  chronic untreated Hepatitis C acquired during his substance abuse era  and has been abstinent from intravenous drugs in recent years. His diabetic condition is currently controlled through diet and Metformin. He mentions that he has not received regular dental care  and his dental hygiene was poor until his recent health concerns.  Family History: No significant family history of cardiac  kidney  or liver diseases. His mother had hypertension. He has one sister who is alive and well. His father died of lung cancer related to smoking.  Physical Examination: Upon evaluation  the patient seems in slight distress due to the discomfort from recent onset back pain. He is febrile (38.5 Degrees Celsius)  blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg  heart rate of 85 bpm  Body Mass Index (BMI) is 27  and Oxygen saturation (SpO2) is 96% on room air. He appears to have poor dentition  including visible tooth decay.  Blood examination reveals slight leukocytosis and an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and CRP  indicative of an ongoing inflammatory process. His previous lab works show mild renal functioning affected which could be consulted if patient requires any invasive procedure in the future.  Diagnosis and Management: The combination of persistent fever  weight loss  malaise  night sweats and the cardiac murmur resulted in the suspicion of infective endocarditis. He is planned for blood culture and awaiting results. Directed empirical antibiotics are initiated.   An Echocardiogram is planned to confirm the diagnosis  assess valve function and look for any vegetations or abscesses. The dental health issues and history of IV drug use come into play as these could have served as local site for bacteremia.  If left untreated  infective endocarditis can result in serious complications  including heart failure  systemic emboli  and death. As such  the patient is counselled about the importance of continuous and effective treatment. Close Monitoring will be needed to evaluate infection response  cardiac function  and identify complication. +- The patient will also be referred to a dental hygienist to treat existing dental issues and promote future oral health  reducing the risk of future endocarditis episodes. Referral to a hepatologist would be considered for potential treatment of his Hepatitis C.  The patient's substance use disorder history is also noted. He will be referred to a clinical psychotherapist to manage his substance abuse history and social worker consultation would be beneficial for appropriate community resources.   This case is a classic presentation of native-valve infective endocarditis  which is most commonly caused by streptococcal or staphylococcal pathogens. Though African Americans exhibit lower rates of infective endocarditis compared to White Americans  in the case of our patient  his past history of IV drug use  poor dental hygiene and diabetes increases his risk  reinforcing that health disparities stem from a combination of genetic  environmental  and sociological factors.

Patient Profile:   Mr. X is a 52-year-old male construction worker from suburban New England  USA. He is of Caucasian ethnicity  non-smoker  but has a history of excessive alcohol consumption. He is married with two adult children and lives with his wife and a pet dog.   Past Medical History:  Mr. X has a history of controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes. In his early thirties  he had a diagnosis of rheumatic fever but had no known issues with his heart valves. He received treatment and regular follow-ups during this phase. There has been no record of IV drug use. He does not have any allergies  and his immunizations are up-to-date.  Family History:  There is no significant family history of cardiovascular diseases  but both his parents had type 2 diabetes. His older sister was diagnosed with hypertension in her late forties.   Clinical Presentation:  Mr. X was admitted to the emergency department with complaints of high-grade fever  fatigue and new-onset shortness of breath for a week  neglecting it initially as work-related stress. He also stated he had experienced unintentional weight loss over the month.   Investigations:   On systemic examination  he had splenomegaly  a murmur heard on cardiac auscultation in mitral region  petechiae  and Osler's nodes on hands and feet. Blood cultures were taken  and echo-cardiography was ordered  which revealed vegetations on the mitral valve suggestive of infective endocarditis  possibly native-valve endocarditis considering his past history of rheumatic fever.  Further investigations confirmed the diagnosis of native valve  infective endocarditis.  Management Overview:  Mr. X was started on empiric antibiotic therapy  as the final culture results are awaited. Consultation with a cardiology team was done. His general condition improved after the initiation of antibiotics. The decision about the necessity of surgical intervention awaits the comments from the cardiovascular surgery team considering the size of his vegetations and his overall clinical condition.  Preventative Counseling:  Upon discharge  Mr. X will need regular follow-ups and extensive counseling on maintaining good oral hygiene  minimal alcohol consumption  and proper management of his chronic conditions to prevent recurrent infective endocarditis. He should also be educated about the signs and symptoms of infectious endocarditis so he can seek immediate medical attention if they recur.  This case discussion is to make informed decisions about the potential clinical outcomes  the necessity for further intervention  and ways of prevention of recurrent episodes.  (Actual patient care decisions should be made based on individual patient and clinical circumstances.)   Note: Although the case demographic and disease profile are based on scientific literature  they do not represent every patient's experiences and outcomes with native valve infective endocarditis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 68-year-old African American male who is currently admitted to our hospital with chief complaints of recurrent fever  malaise  and weakness of 1-month duration. He also notes recent weight loss and night sweats. There is no known drug or alcohol abuse. His vitals (BP: 140/90mmHg  Pulse: 110 bpm  Temp: 101°F) imply a state of continuous mild pyrexia. His ethnicity was included due to the incidence and prevalence rates of endocarditis noted to be significantly higher among African American males.  Medical History:  He has a past medical history suggestive of type 2 diabetes mellitus (managed with metformin and diet) and hypertension (managed with losartan). Recently  his glycemic control has been suboptimal with HbA1c level above 8%. He underwent a dental procedure two months ago without antimicrobial prophylaxis. He has no history of IV drug use or any recent surgeries which makes him a case of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Family History:   He denied having any familial history of autoimmune diseases  cardiovascular diseases  or malignancies.  Examination & Investigation:  On physical examination  non-tender petechial lesions were found on his palms and soles  and slight murmur was noticed on auscultation. An ophthalmologic exam revealed Roth spots. Echocardiography revealed vegetations on the mitral valve with mild regurgitation. Blood culture reports were positive for Streptococcus viridans.  Management:  He was started on intravenous administration of Penicillin G  and Gentamycin to cover for the most likely organism as revealed by the blood culture result. The patient is being closely monitored for signs of congestive heart failure  and the cardiology team will be consulted to assess the need for future surgical intervention.  Summary:  This is a classic case of native valve infective endocarditis in an elderly African American male with a history of teeth cleaning procedure without prophylaxis  diabetes  and hypertension. His symptoms  together with the physical findings (petechiae  Roth spots) and positive blood culture for Streptococcus viridans  constitute a diagnosis of definite infective endocarditis as per the Modified Duke's Criteria. His diabetes  though not directly related to endocarditis  might hamper his immunity and worsen his prognosis. The relevance of including ethnicity is due to the well-documented disparity in cardiovascular disease seen in African Americans. Boosting his clinical management  we assert that his long-term outcomes may be improved.

Patient Information:   The patient  Mr. J.S.  is a 60-year-old African American male from an urban setting. He has a history of IV drug usage but has been clean for the past 5 years. There is no history of smoking  and he consumes moderate alcohol.   Presenting Complaint:  Mr. J.S. presented with a two-week history of fever  fatigue  and intermittent confusion  which has worsened in the past few days. He also reported occurrence of night sweats and weight loss of approximately 5 kg in the past two weeks.  Past Medical History:  His past medical history includes hypertension  managed with medication (Lisinopril 20 mg)  and past intravenous drug usage which he stopped 5 years ago  after a rehabilitation program and ongoing therapy. He has had Hepatitis C in 2005  treated successfully.  Family History:  His family history reveals that his father had coronary artery disease and passed away from a myocardial infarction at the age of 58. His mother is alive  aged 85  and has type 2 diabetes and hypertension. He has one sister  healthy  aged 55years.  Examination:   On examination  Mr. J.S was febrile with a temperature of 102 degrees Fahrenheit. Cardiovascular examination revealed a new systolic murmur in the mitral valve area. A fundoscopic examination of his eyes revealed a few Roth Spots and his fingers showed clubbing.  Diagnosis:  Based on the presentation  clinical findings  and history of IV drug use  a diagnosis of possible Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis was considered. Further investigations  including Blood Cultures to identify the causative organism  Transesophageal echocardiogram to identify any vegetation  and a complete blood count to confirm any inflammation/infection  were ordered.  Results:  Blood cultures grew Streptococcus Viridans  and his Echocardiogram showed vegetation on the mitral valve. His white blood cell count was elevated  indicating a systemic inflammatory response.   Treatment:  Management began with intravenous Penicillin and Gentamicin as per Infective Endocarditis Therapy regimen  together with heart failure management.   Patient education and counseling sessions for ongoing care and the importance of medication adherence were conducted. The possibility of valve replacement surgery in the future was discussed with Mr. J.S.   Conclusion:  This case presents a 60-year-old African American male with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  likely due to his previous intravenous drug use. In addition  complications were minimized through early diagnosis and multidisciplinary management  indicating the necessity of prompt diagnosis and management in such cases.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. J is a 66-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the emergency room with a 1-week history of intermittent fever  loss of appetite  night sweats  and a feeling of general malaise. Mr. J’s temperatures have been averaging 101˚F. He has no relevant travel history  but mentioned a dental procedure about three weeks before the onset of symptoms.  Past Medical History:  Mr. J has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes controlled with oral medications. He has been smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years and consumes alcohol socially. In addition  he has had a joint replacement surgery in the past. There is no known drug allergy.  Family History:  His father died from complications of a stroke at an age of 72 and his mother died at 76 from congestive heart failure. Both of his siblings are living and healthy.  Social History:  Mr. J is a retired mechanical engineer. He lives with his wife and has 2 grown-up children. He is moderately active and enjoys working on DIY projects and gardening.  Physical Examination:  On examination  he appeared lethargic and had a heart rate of 98 bpm. Auscultation revealed a new cardiac murmur. There were no Osler's nodes or Janeway lesions. His overall oral hygiene appeared poor with several carious teeth.   Investigations and Diagnosis:  Initial laboratory investigations showed a slightly elevated total leucocyte count  neutrophilia  and raised inflammatory markers. Blood cultures isolates Streptococcus viridans. An echocardiography showed vegetations on the mitral valve  confirming a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.   Thought Process:  The patient's history of recent dental procedure was a crucial clue pointing towards a possibility of native valve endocarditis. The dental procedure  combined with poor oral hygiene  likely allowed mouth bacteria to infiltrate the bloodstream and adhere to the heart valves.  Plan:  After consulting with cardiology and infectious disease specialist  Mr. J was started on IV penicillin and gentamicin for six weeks. He was also referred to a dentist for the management of oral health. The importance of good oral hygiene was stressed and follow-up appointments were scheduled to monitor his progress.  Implication:  Mr.J presents a classic case of infective endocarditis originating from a dental procedure in the setting of poor oral hygiene. His case also highlights the significance of social history  as his heavy smoking habit may have contributed to the vascular changes that allowed bacteria to adhere and grow in his heart.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 65-year-old African-American male with a diagnosis of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis (NVIE). He is married and a retired schoolteacher living in rural Georgia. The patient's primary language is English and he has a Higher School Certificate. His past medical history includes a diagnosis of Type II diabetes for which he takes metformin twice daily  hypertension managed with lisinopril daily  and moderate hyperlipidemia managed with rosuvastatin.   Clinical Details:  He first presented with intermittent fevers  fatigue  and unexplained weight loss over the past month. Several days ago  he began experiencing chest discomfort and shortness of breath  leading his primary care physician to refer him for cardiac assessment. An echocardiogram revealed an oscillating intracardiac mass on the mitral valve and a positive blood culture identified Staphylococcus aureus. Therefore  the diagnosis of NVIE was confirmed.  Family History:  The patient's father died of heart disease in his early seventies  and his mother died at 85 with Alzheimer's disease. He has one brother who is in his sixties and is living with heart disease. The patient's two children are healthy.  Social History:  The patient is a long-time smoker with a 30 pack-year history and admits to occasional alcohol use but denies any illicit drug use. He is not very physically active and has a diet high in sodium and saturated fat  contributing to his more significant cardiac risk factors.  Current Treatment:  Inpatient treatment was initiated promptly  including intravenous antibiotics per Infective Endocarditis protocol. Surgical consultation is in process concerning the appropriateness of valve replacement given the patient's risk factors and disease severity.   Discussion:  Infective endocarditis is a significant public health issue  particularly among older individuals and those with pre-existing cardiac conditions. Demographics like the African-American race and men are disproportionately affected  indicative of our patient. Risk factors such as diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  all of which are present in the patient  contribute to the overall risk of developing NVIE. Additionally  lifestyle factors like smoking and diet further contribute significantly.   Preventative measures  as well as early diagnosis and aggressive treatment  are crucial as NVIE is associated with a high mortality rate. The coordination of care between doctors  nurses  dietitians  and other healthcare professionals will be crucial in managing the patient’s condition and improving his overall health.  Successful management of our patient's condition will need his active involvement in maintaining a healthier lifestyle post-discharge  including smoking cessation  healthier diet choices  and increased physical activity.

Patient Name: John Doe Age: 53 Gender: Male Occupation: Plumber   Chief Complaint: Persistent fever and fatigue  Present Illness: Mr. Doe has been experiencing a persistent low-grade fever (approx 38.5-degree Celsius) and fatigue over the past two weeks. Additionally  he reported unintentional weight loss and occasional night sweats.   Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a history of IVDU (intravenous drug use) and was previously treated for Hepatitis C. He has been sober for nearly five years.   Family History: According to Mr. Doe  his mother died due to heart disease and his father had a stroke at the age of 65. There is no family history of congenital heart diseases or rheumatic fever.  Physical Examination: On general physical examination  Mr. Doe appeared pale and was in mild distress due to fatigue. His oral temperature was 38.3-degree Celsius. Heart auscultation revealed a diastolic murmur noted in the aortic valve area. An ocular examination revealed a few splinter hemorrhages in his nail beds.   Laboratory Findings: Blood tests showed mild anemia and increased level of ESR  CRP  and white blood cell count indicating an infection. Blood cultures isolated Streptococcus viridans  implicating a diagnosis of infective endocarditis.  Echo-Cardiographic Findings: A transthoracic echocardiogram was performed which showed a vegetation on one of the aortic valve leaflets. Left ventricular function was normal  with no sign of any cardiac dysfunction.   Diagnosis: Mr. Doe was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis possibly due to his past history of IVDU and recent streptococcal infection.   Management Plan: Given his diagnosis  Mr. Doe was started on IV antibiotic therapy with Penicillin and Gentamicin for a minimum of 4-6 weeks. His condition and response to treatment are to be continuously monitored. He has been strongly advised to maintain good dental hygiene and avoid any IV drug use. Surgical consultation will be considered if medical management fails or complications arise.  This case identifies the importance of a thorough clinical assessment in making a diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis  particularly in an individual with a past history of risk factors.

Patient Presentation:  Patient: A 65-year-old Caucasian male  Presenting Complaint: He reported fatigue  intermittent fever  occasional shortness of breath  and weight loss over the past month. The patient also mentioned experiencing night sweats and a loss of appetite.  Past Medical History: The patient has a medical history of rheumatic fever in his teenage years but was otherwise healthy until these recent symptoms appeared. Patient embarked on treatment for rheumatic fever and had no sequela of the disease since then.  Family History: Both of his parents passed away in their late 70s due to cardiovascular issues. His older sister (68 years old) has been diagnosed with diabetes mellitus Type II. No cases of endocarditis in the immediate family  based on the patient’s knowledge.  Lifestyle: The patient lives with his wife  who is his primary caregiver. He is a retired engineer and his alcohol use is occasional with rare usage of tobacco. He does not use illicit drugs and follows a moderate dietary plan.  Clinical Findings: Physical exam showed a mild fever  pale skin  and a new murmur was noted on the cardiac examination. Several Osler's nodes were detected on his fingers and toes  and Roth spots were visible in his eyes during fundoscopic examination.  Investigations: His complete blood count showed mild anemia with an elevated white blood cell count. Elevated ESR and CRP demonstrated an ongoing inflammation process. Blood cultures were positive for Streptococcus viridans  and the patient's EKG showed no signs of conduction abnormalities. An echocardiogram showed vegetations on the bicuspid aortic valve  confirming suspicions of endocarditis.  Diagnosis: Given his clinical picture  positive blood cultures  the presence of a new cardiac murmur  and echocardiographic findings  a diagnosis of Native Valve Infective Endocarditis (NVIE) was made.  Management and Prognosis: The patient was hospitalized and started on a regimen of IV antibiotics  initially on high-dose Penicillin G and Gentamicin  as per IDSA guidelines. He possibly would need surgery to repair or replace the valve if the infection progresses or if heart functions worsen. The prognosis for NVIE varies and depends on the patient’s clinical progression.  The clinical scenario is well within the average age of presentation for endocarditis  represented generally between the ages of 30-60 years with some studies showing a higher incidence rate in males. Possible risk factors in this case include age and a previous episode of rheumatic fever. Early detection and appropriate treatment might result in a good prognosis.

Patient Background: Gender: Male Age: 60 years Occupation: Farmer Race: Caucasian Residence: Rural area  Case Presentation: Mr. A  a 60-year-old Caucasian man  was admitted to the hospital following complaints of fever  malaise  and an unintentional weight loss of about ten pounds over a two month period. The fevers were intermittent and associated with night sweats. Mr. A is a farmer and lives in a rural setting.   Medical History: His past medical history is relevant for Type II Diabetes Mellitus and Rheumatoid Arthritis. He takes oral hypoglycemic agents and Methotrexate to manage these conditions. The patient reported minimal alcohol consumption and denied tobacco use or illicit drug use. He had not been on any antibiotic therapy recently. He had no history of dental procedures or any episode suggestive of a continuous bacteremia.  Family History: Both parents were deceased. His father died of myocardial infarction and his mother died of colon cancer. His older brother  a 65-year-old  was diagnosed with coronary artery disease and Type II Diabetes Mellitus.   Clinical Examination: On physical examination  his temperature was 38.7 degrees Celsius  heart rate 110 bpm  blood pressure 130/80 mm Hg. His cardiovascular exam revealed a systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. Ophthalmologic examination showed Roth's spots  retinal hemorrhages with a clear center.  Investigations: Blood cultures revealed the growth of Streptococcus bovis. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) demonstrated vegetation on the aortic valve  confirming the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. Further test like colonoscopy was performed due to the known association between S.bovis bacteremia and colonic pathology which revealed an adenomatous polyp.  Treatment: Treatment was oriented to the infective endocarditis with intravenous antibiotics based on culture sensitivity. An aortic valve replacement was done due to the severity of infection and regurgitation. The patient completed six weeks of antibiotics  and kept a regular follow up with Cardiology and Infectious Disease Departments.  Summary: This case highlights a presentation of infective endocarditis in a patient with risk factors including age and underlying rheumatoid arthritis. His occupation as a farmer may also have contributed to his increased susceptibility to infection. Prognosis is dependent on timely diagnosis and aggressive treatment. It also underscores the importance of a thorough evaluation for other potential primary sources of infection in the body as Mr. A had a colonic adenomatous polyp which may have been the primary source of the S.bovis bacteremia.

Case Presentation  Patient Profile: Presenting a case today of Mr. Ramirez  a 60-year-old Hispanic male resident of East Los Angeles. He is a retired school teacher  living with his wife and youngest son in a quiet suburb. Mr. Ramirez has no prior history of illicit drug use or any tattoos.  Past Medical History: Mr. Ramirez has a significant medical history  which includes being recently diagnosed with diabetes mellitus type II  and hypertension for the past ten years. He has suffered from rheumatic fever in his childhood having lasting effects on his cardiovascular health. He does not have a history of any surgeries. There is no known history of any genetic diseases in the family.  Current Presentation: He was admitted to the hospital after presenting with a persistent high-grade fever  accompanied by night sweats  fatigue  loss of appetite  and weight loss for the past four weeks. His wife also noted the presence of petechial skin lesions on his trunk. Four days before the emergency department visit  he started to have moderate chest discomfort on mild exertion. On physical examination  a soft mid-diastolic murmur was appreciated at the apex  followed with a later high-pitched click at the second intercostal space with inspiratory splitting of S2.  Investigations: On laboratory analysis  white blood cell count was elevated with a shift to the left. The blood cultures grew Streptococcus viridans after serial plating  likely suggesting a bacterial endocardial involvement. The EKG showed no signs of acute ischemic changes. An echocardiogram revealed vegetations on the mitral valve with moderate mitral regurgitation. The evaluation of the source of infection revealed poor oral hygiene and progressive periodontal disease. A significant amount of dental caries was observed.  Diagnosis: Considering the presentation  clinical and laboratory findings  Mr. Ramirez was diagnosed with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis due to Streptococcus viridans. The possible origin might be secondary to bacteremia from dental procedures  as studies reveal a higher rate of occurrence in patients with periodontal disease. Poor blood sugar control in Mr. Ramirez might have added to his susceptibility.  Treatment Plan: Antibiotic therapy was initiated  and blood sugar was controlled. Considering the consequences of possible embolization and the patient's progressively deteriorating mitral valve function  early surgical intervention was discussed with him. Mr. Ramirez provides informed consent and undergoes successful mitral valve replacement surgery. His postoperative course is uncomplicated. Dental treatment is arranged for Mr. Ramirez after recovery.  Reviewing literature  native-valve infective endocarditis is more prevalent among older men and individuals with pre-existing heart diseases. The presence of poor oral hygiene and diabetes only elevated the risk. Early diagnosis plays a significant role in reducing mortality and morbidity associated with infective endocarditis.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 65-year-old African-American male who has been previously healthy  presenting to the hospital with intermittent fevers  significant weight loss  and increasing fatigue over the past six weeks.  Medical History:  The past medical history reveals that the patient is hypertensive  controlled with Lisinopril for the past decade  and is a 20-pack-year smoker. He has no history of illicit drug use  dental abscess  or other infections. His family history is significant for congenital heart disease in both his brother and sister  but no family history of rheumatic fever.  Physical Examination:  On examination  the patient looked fatigued. Cardiac examination revealed a new murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. There were also several non-tender  erythematous lesions on the palms and soles  consistent with Janeway lesions and Osler's nodes. No other significant findings were found on a systemic examination.  Investigations:  His complete blood count showed a mild normocytic anemia and an elevated White blood cells count at 14 500. His erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) levels were also raised. Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed sinus rhythm with no ST or T wave changes.  Echocardiography revealed a mobile echo-density on the aortic valve suggestive of vegetation. Blood cultures grew Streptococcus viridans. Based on these findings  a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis was made.  Management and outcome:  The patient was started on intravenous antibiotics based on sensitivity reports. After four weeks of treatment  repeat blood cultures were negative and inflammatory markers had responded. Repeat echo at six weeks showed resolution of the vegetation. Given the known family history of congenital heart disease and the complicated presentation of native-valve infective endocarditis  the patient is scheduled for genetic testing and regular cardiac follow-ups in the future.  This case illustrates the importance of considering the diagnosis of infective endocarditis in older individuals presenting with unexplained fevers  particularly those with predisposing cardiac conditions or relevant family history. It also highlights the importance of a thorough physical exam  which may reveal characteristic signs of endocarditis such as Janeway lesions or Osler nodes.

Patient Profile:  The patient is a 56-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Smith  from a middle-class suburban community. He is a non-smoker and denies the use of any illicit drugs. He drinks in moderation. As to his occupational history  he is a long-term employee at a local factory.   Mr. Smith presented to the Emergency Department with a 2-week history of intermittent fevers  chills  night sweats  fatigue  and unexplained weight loss. He also noted a new heart murmur during a recent routine check-up with his primary care provider.  Medical History:  Mr. Smith’s past medical history reveals he had rheumatic fever as a child  which predisposes him to endocardic infection. Moreover  he was diagnosed with mitral valve prolapse 5 years ago  which remains an ongoing issue. His most significant surgical history includes a total knee replacement two years ago. He has a mild allergy to penicillin  resulting in a rash.   Mr. Smith’s family history shows a high prevalence of cardiovascular disorders. His father and paternal grandfather both died from myocardial infarctions. His mother suffers from hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Clinical Findings:  In Emergency Department  Mr. Smith was febrile with a temperature of 38.5°C. His heart rate was mildly elevated (90 bpm)  his blood pressure was 120/80 mmHg  and his oxygen saturation was slightly reduced at 92% in ambient air.   Cardiovascular examination revealed a new systolic heart murmur  grades II/VI at the apex of the heart  which was not present in his previous medical records. No peripheral stigmata of endocarditis such as Osler's nodes  Janeway's lesions or splinter hemorrhages were noted.  Laboratory findings showed an increased WBC count and elevated inflammatory markers  including ESR and CRP. Blood cultures drawn in the ED  before the initiation of antibiotics  subsequently grew Streptococcus Viridans.   Imaging:  A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) demonstrated a mobile echodensity on the posterior leaflet of the mitral valve  suggestive of vegetations  confirming the diagnosis of native valve endocarditis.  Treatment:  Mr. Smith was admitted to the hospital and IV Ceftriaxone was initiated. He demonstrated improvement both clinically and in his inflammatory markers over the subsequent days. It was decided by the Infection Diseases  Cardiology  and Cardiothoracic teams to manage Mr. Smith conservatively with antibiotics rather than immediate surgery. Long term follow-up and management were planned.  Conclusion:  In Mr. Smith’s case  in light of his previous history of rheumatic fever and mitral valve prolapse  the development of infective endocarditis was a serious but not unforeseen complication. It demonstrates the importance of routine checks and vigilant observation for new signs and symptoms  especially in the light of a new heart murmur in a patient with a known history of valvular disease.

Patient Information: A 62-year-old Hispanic female  Mrs. Maria Gomez  a resident of Texas  has been admitted to the healthcare facility with ongoing fever and generalized weakness for the past 3 weeks.  Past Medical History: Maria has a history of rheumatic fever during her adolescence with minimal long-term cardiac impact. Her other prevalent conditions include Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  which is being managed with Metformin  and Hypertension  under control with Lisinopril. She also had a cholecystectomy ten years ago. There is no known drug allergy. She is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol socially.  Family History: Her father had a history of cardiac issues  with a myocardial infarction at the age of 67  and her mother had Type 2 Diabetes. She has two siblings – a brother with obesity and a sister in good health.  Presenting Complaints: Maria has been experiencing a high-grade fever  weakness  fatigue  and unintentional weight loss. On further inquiry  she reported experiencing night sweats and occasional chest discomfort over the past weeks.   Examination and Investigation: Her physical examination revealed a systolic murmur on cardiac auscultation and petechial rash on her upper extremities. Lab findings showed an elevated ESR  C-reactive protein  and leukocytosis suggestive of systemic inflammation. More specific investigations like blood culture assays returned positive  reaffirming the presence of infectious agents. The echocardiogram showed vegetations on her mitral valve indicating infective endocarditis.  Discussion: The findings correspond with Native Valve Infective Endocarditis (NVIE). Maria's history of rheumatic fever is pertinent given its association with valvular damage  predisposing her to NVIE. Further  her demographic  age  and ethnicity align with literature suggesting that among Americans  older adults and Hispanics present higher rates of Native Valve Infective Endocarditis. Risk factors like her underlying comorbid conditions (DM and HTN) contribute significantly to the disease process.  Treatment: Maria is currently being treated empirically with intravenous antibacterials while awaiting full blood culture results to guide more specific antibiotic intervention. Further plans include monitoring for signs of cardiac failure  embolic phenomena  and medication side effects.  Conclusion: It is essential to provide Maria with a multidisciplinary care approach tailored to manage her NVIE  coordinate her extant comorbidities  and ensure full recovery. Her situation underscores the need to maintain a high index of suspicion for NVIE in patients with a similar demographic and clinical profile.

Patient Information: A 48-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of type 2 diabetes  intravenous drug abuse  and ethanol abuse. He did not have a history of congenital heart defects or rheumatic heart disease. He was living with his wife  and they have two children all in good health. The family medical history included myocardial infarction and hypertension in the father’s line.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented to the emergency department with a 2-week history of intermittent fever  fatigue  and weight loss. He also reported the recent onset of a new murmur.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  the patient was febrile (Temp. 101.4°F) and pale. His heart rate was increased (110 bpm)  and he had a new holosystolic murmur heard at the apex of the heart. He also had Janeway lesions in his palms and soles  and Osler nodes were present.  Diagnostic Assessment: The patient's blood cultures tested positive for Staphylococcus aureus. A chest X-ray was normal  and an electrocardiogram showed sinus tachycardia. An echocardiogram displayed vegetation on the mitral valve suggestive of infective endocarditis. The patient was also found to have elevated ESR and CRP levels indicating ongoing inflammation.   Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was started on an empiric antibiotic regimen of intravenous vancomycin and gentamicin. Insulin was administered to control blood glucose levels. Detoxification and recovery process from drug and alcohol abuse were initiated with the help of addiction specialists.   Outcome and Follow-up: Subsequent blood cultures cleared after two weeks of antibiotic therapy  showing an effective response to the treatment. Subsequent echocardiograms showed a reduction in the vegetations size. The patient was maintained on IV antibiotics for six weeks. The patient had several counselling sessions for drug and alcohol abuse and was enrolled in a rehabilitation program. His diabetes management continued with regular insulin administration and diet regulation.   In conclusion  this was a classic presentation of infective endocarditis in an individual with a complex social history that included intravenous drug use  coupled with comorbidities like diabetes and alcohol abuse.

Patient Profile:  Name: Jane Doe Sex: Female Age: 60 years Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired school teacher  Presenting Condition:  Jane has been admitted complaining of a persistent fever  loss of appetite  and heart palpitations for the past couple of weeks. She has a history of intravenous drug use in her distant past but has been sober for over 30 years.  Past Medical History:  She has a history of several comorbidities. Jane has a 10-year history of Type II diabetes and hypertension. She has been managing both diseases effectively with medications and diet. Additionally  she had a congenital heart defect which was surgically corrected when she was an infant. No other surgeries in her medical history have been reported.  Family History:  Jane's father died of a myocardial infarction at 75 years of age; her mother died from complications related to Alzheimer's at 90. She has one older sister who is living with osteoporosis  and a younger brother who has a history of substance abuse and HIV.  Review of Systems:  On examination  Jane presented with a low-grade fever  fatigue  and shortness of breath. Physical examination revealed a murmur suggestive of possible valvular disease. Jane also reported a recent unintentional weight loss. No other abnormal findings were noted during the physical examination.  Investigations:  Concerning her murmurs  heart palpitations  and persistent fevers  further investigations were done. EKG displayed some arrhythmia. Two separate blood cultures drawn 12 hours apart came back positive for Staphylococcus aureus  confirming her infection. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) subsequently identified vegetation on her mitral valve  leading to the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Management:  Antibiotic therapy was initiated immediately using intravenous vancomycin. A team including cardiology  infectious diseases  and cardiac surgery specialists was assembled to manage the case. given the patient's medical history  and the size and stability of the vegetations  it has been agreed that the patient would undergo valve replacement surgery following a course of antibiotics to control the infection.  Discussion:  Native valve infective endocarditis is a crucial diagnosis due to its serious implications and need for early treatment. This case aligns with literature showing that the condition can be more common in those with heart defects corrected early in life  and those who have a history of intravenous drug use - even if distant. The choice of antibiotics was tailored to the identified organism  which is the recommended treatment approach in clinical guidelines.  Considering the patient's age and comorbidities  a multidimensional approach involving professionals from different medical specialties will be essential to provide the best therapeutic strategies. Although the risk associated with surgery poses a significant concern  it may be necessary to prevent further potential complications related to endocarditis such as heart failure and systemic infections.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 56-year-old African American male with a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. Research indicates that infective endocarditis tends to be more common among males and individuals above 50 years. Moreover  African Americans tend to be at a higher risk for bacterial heart infection compared to other racial or ethnic groups in the United States.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a documented history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both conditions of which have been managed through medication and diet. He also has a long history of intravenous drug use which ceased ten years ago. This increases his likelihood of contracting endocarditis.  Presenting Complaint:  He presented to the hospital with a two-week history of persistent high-grade fever  general malaise  night sweats  and weight loss  all of which are common symptoms of endocarditis. A new murmur was noted during his physical examination.  Investigations:  Blood Cultures have been ordered  which confirmed Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia. An echocardiogram displayed vegetation on the tricuspid valve  which was indicative of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Family History:  His mother had rheumatic heart disease and his father was hypertensive and diabetic. No known family history of endocarditis.  Social History:  The patient is a divorced single father of two children  works as a construction worker and resides in an urban environment. He has a history of heavy smoking and a past history of intravenous drug use.  Management Plan:  Given the results of the investigations  empirical antibiotic therapy with vancomycin and gentamicin has been initiated. A consultation with a cardiothoracic team was also suggested to evaluate the need for surgical intervention  considering the severity of the valve damage detected in the echocardiogram.  This case highlights the importance of vigilance in quickly recognizing and treating native-valve endocarditis  particularly in patients with a history of intravenous drug use or in demographics more susceptible to the disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Jose Rodriguez  aged 61  is a Hispanic American male who lives in Los Angeles  California. He presents to the Cardiology Clinic with complaints of fever  fatigue  and a recent inexplicable weight loss. He does not smoke or drink and leads a rather sedentary lifestyle with little to no physical activity due to his previous occupation as an office worker.  Past Medical History:   Jose has a chronic history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes and had previously suffered a mild stroke at the age of 57 which left him with a slight right-sided weakness. He also has a history of mild hypertension  for which he was prescribed medication  although he admitted difficulty adhering to it due to his busy lifestyle. His most recent blood pressure was 140/90mmHg during his last clinic visit. He also has a history of gingivitis and had a tooth extraction performed about a month ago.   Family Health History:  Jose has a strong family history of heart diseases  with his father having suffered from multiple myocardial infarctions and his mother having died from complications arising from congestive heart failure. His elder brother  age 68  was recently diagnosed with atrial fibrillation.  Current Presentation:  Upon physical examination  the patient displayed signs of congestive heart failure with mild bilateral lower extremity edema. He was slightly short of breath  even at rest. Blood tests showed an increased ESR and C-reactive protein level  suggesting a possible systemic infection. A heart examination revealed a new cardiac murmur  leading the clinician to suspect infective endocarditis. The suspicion was later confirmed by a Transesophageal Echocardiogram (TEE)  which revealed vegetations on his mitral valve. Blood cultures grew Streptococcus viridans  a common causative organism for native valve endocarditis  often associated with dental procedures.  This presentation has elements that are common in cases of native valve endocarditis like the patient's previous dental intervention  the chronic disorders like diabetes and hypertension  and the family history of heart disease. The common symptoms of fatigue  weight loss  and fever  coupled with cardiac murmur and positive blood cultures  strongly point towards a diagnosis of infective endocarditis. It is important to note that native valve endocarditis is generally more common in male patients  similar to this case  as described in the literature.  Diagnosis:   Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis due to Streptococcus viridans.   Follow up:  Jose's treatment plan involves long-term intravenous antibiotic therapy aimed at the identified organism  dietary advice to manage his diabetes better  and a strict follow-up schedule to monitor the progression of his condition. He was also advised to report immediately in case of any neurological symptoms due to the potential risk for embolic stroke associated with this condition. Additionally  a consult with the dental team was made to educate him about the importance of maintaining oral health in preventing recurrent endocarditis. The plan for surgical repair of the valve would be considered depending on his response to the medical treatment and ejection fraction status.

Patient Presentation  The patient  a 55-year-old African American male  was presented to our care with severe fatigue  pallor  and unexpected weight loss. He complained of high-grade intermittent fever with chills dating back 3 weeks prior. An alarming symptom that proceeded was experiencing shortness of breath on exertion  profound enough to restrict his daily activities.  Past Medical History  The patient has a medical history significant for smoking  alcohol consumer  and illicit drug usage  specifically intravenous drug use  which he quit around 10 years back. He is hypertensive  controlled on medication  and was diagnosed with AIDS 5 years ago. Interestingly  he has no known cardiac history and his records consistent with regular medical visits and follow-ups.  Family History  The patient’s father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 62  mother is a known diabetic and hypertensive. His only sibling  a brother  is in good health with no known chronic disease.  Examination and Result  Physical examination displayed substernal systolic murmur of grade IV/VI heard best at the left lower sternal border with no radiation. The patient appeared pale  tired and was diaphoretic. Examination of the primary hypertension showed systolic murmur with no accompanying signs of endocarditis - no Janeway lesions  Osler nodes  Roth spots  or splenomegaly were detected.  Blood cultures were ordered and were positive for Staphylococcus aureus. His cardiac biomarkers turned out to be normal  while EKG showed no significant abnormalities. Echocardiography revealed a vegetation of about 1 cm on the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve.  Diagnosis  Combining these observations  clinical findings  and laboratory data  we made a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis  caused by Staphylococcus aureus. The patient's IV drug use history  though not recent  along with the lack of any prosthetic valve or rheumatic fever history likely pointed towards the native valve rather than a prosthetic valve being affected.  Treatment & Prognosis  The patient was administered a daily dose of intravenous antibiotic Ticarcillin-clavulanate  with his treatment course spanning over six weeks. His shortness of breath was managed with prescribed diuretics. HIV/AIDS management treatment was also optimized by a qualified infectious disease specialist. The patient showed a slow improvement in his vitals  symptoms  and overall health condition. He was advised regular follow-ups  strict compliance with medications  and a balanced diet accompanied by mild to moderate exercise.   The case was a succinct presentation of infective endocarditis in a patient with past medical history demonstrating high-risk behaviors  coupled with predisposing factors such as HIV/AIDS and substance misuse  showcasing the need to incorporate these prominent characteristics into one's diagnostic thinking when relevant symptoms are presented. It stands as a reminder of the potential severity of some fairly common symptoms when seen in a complex patient group.

Case Presentation  Demographics: Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male from a suburban area.  Presenting complaint: The patient came in with a 2-week history of intermittent fever  chills  fatigue  and loss of appetite.   Past medical history: The patient has a medical history of type II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and end-stage renal disease (ESRD)  which are common comorbidities associated with infective endocarditis (IE)  according to literature. He has been on hemodialysis for the last 2 years. Previously  he had a myocardial infarction five years ago  but he hasn't had any cardiac surgery.  Family history: There is no reported family history of heart disease or other relevant genetic predisposition.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed pallor and splinter hemorrhages in his fingernails suggesting subacute bacterial endocarditis. There was no evidence of peripheral stigmata of infective endocarditis such as Osler's nodes or Janeway lesions.   Investigations: Lab results showed elevated levels of C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Two sets of blood cultures obtained from different sites returned positive for MRSA  a common pathogen in native-valve infective endocarditis. Further evidence of IE was provided by a Transesophageal Echocardiogram (TEE)  which showed a large mobile vegetation on the mitral valve consistent with infective endocarditis.   Treatment: The multidisciplinary IE team decided to initiate treatment with intravenous vancomycin and rifampicin following current guidelines. Control blood cultures were ordered after 48 hours of antimicrobial therapy to evaluate the response. The possibility of surgical intervention was also discussed  considering the size of vegetation and the risk of embolization and hemodynamic instability.  In our patient  the likely predisposing factor for native valve IE was his chronic kidney disease and consequent hemodialysis  a well-documented risk factor for bacteremia and infectious complications. This case underscores the importance of considering infective endocarditis in the differential diagnosis for patients on hemodialysis presenting with prolonged fever  despite lack of cardinal clinical signs of IE.     Note: The specifics would have to be adjusted based on the region or population you're studying  as factors like common comorbidities  common bacterial strains  and treatment strategies can vary.

Patient Presentation: Mr. Rodriguez  a 55-year-old Hispanic male  presented to the emergency department with complaints of persistent high-grade fever  malaise  and fatigue for the past three weeks. Mr. Rodriguez is a resident of Texas  U.S.  where he operates a farm amidst a large Hispanic community. He has a history of tobacco smoking (20 pack years) and occasional alcohol consumption.  Past Medical History: The patient was diagnosed with Diabetes Mellitus Type II five years ago and has been compliant with Metformin 500mg twice daily. He was also diagnosed with Rheumatoid Arthritis two years ago  for which he has been receiving low dose Methotrexate therapy along with daily NSAIDs. He has no known drug allergies.  Complete Demographics: Born in McAllen  Texas  Rodriguez is a 5th generation Mexican American and communicates efficiently in both Spanish and English. He completed high school and pursued a brief certification course in agriculture  before joining the family business of farming. He lives with his wife and has two adult children. Mr. Rodriguez's annual income puts him in the lower-middle-class category. Due to his urban setting and income bracket  he has access to primary healthcare facilities.  Family History: There's a significant family history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  with his mother also being a diabetic patient. His father passed away due to myocardial infarction at the age of 60. Mr. Rodriguez has a younger brother diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis as well.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient started feeling unwell approximately three weeks ago. Initial symptoms included low-grade fever  malaise  which gradually worsened over a period of a week. He also experienced night sweats  fatigue  transient joint pain  and loss of appetite. In the past week  Mr. Rodriguez noticed increasing shortness of breath and unintentional weight loss.  Physical Examination: On general examination  Rodriguez was found to be febrile (100.6°F) with a slightly elevated blood pressure  (140/90 mmHg). A cardiac examination revealed mild tachycardia with a soft systolic murmur heard best at the apex. An inspection of fingers showed splinter hemorrhages under the nail beds.  Diagnostic Evaluation: Laboratory findings showed elevated leukocyte count and Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR). A blood culture has been sent and we're awaiting results. An echocardiogram showed significant vegetations on the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve  supporting our diagnosis of a native valve endocarditis.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was admitted to the cardiology ward and started on empirical antibiotic therapy with Vancomycin and Gentamicin. Further therapy will be decided based on the outcome of his blood culture and antibiogram results. His diabetes and rheumatoid arthritis medication routines have been continued with adjustment for his current disease status.  Further Plan: As well as monitoring response to antibiotics  surgery is being considered in case of therapy failure  signs of heart failure  or recurrence of emboli. Additionally  smoking cessation advice  diet adjustment  and exercise routine have been implemented as part of his comprehensive care plan.

Patient Presentation  Demographics: Mr. Johnson is a 64-year-old Caucasian male engineer  non-smoker  with a body mass index (BMI) of 26.  Past Medical History: His past medical history is significant for well-controlled hypertension  for which he has been taking Lisinopril 10 mg once daily. He underwent a mitral valve repair surgery due to mitral regurgitation 25 years ago and has been in normal sinus rhythm since then. His last dental procedure was a root canal treatment about six months ago.  Family History: His mother had rheumatic heart disease  necessitating mitral valve surgery in her later years. His father was hypertensive and died of a myocardial infarction at age 75. He has three siblings  all living  with no history of cardiac diseases.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Johnson presented with complaints of intermittent fever  night sweats  malaise and weakness for the past 3 weeks. He also reported an unintentional weight loss of approximately 5 kg over the last month.  Examination and Diagnosis: On examination  his temperature was found to be 101.5 F  BP was 140/85 mmHg  and Heart Rate was 95 bpm. Cardiac auscultation revealed a new systolic murmur at the apex. Blood investigations showed elevated inflammatory markers - ESR and CRP. There was moderate leucocytosis (WBC- 12 000 cells/cu mm) with increased neutrophils. His ECG showed no significant abnormalities.  Two sets of blood cultures were positive for Streptococcus viridans. Transesophageal echocardiography (TOE) confirmed ‘vegetations’ on the native mitral valve compatible with infective endocarditis.  Treatment: He was started on intravenous antibiotics: Penicillin G and Gentamicin as per local sensitivity profiles. Supportive measures were also started for his symptoms.  Summary: Mr. Johnson's prior mitral valve surgery  recent dental procedure  and the presence of Streptococcus viridans in the blood cultures all contribute to his diagnosis of native valve endocarditis. His treatment has been initiated accordingly. Regular monitoring and adjustments of antibiotic therapy will be needed based on his clinical response and any adverse effects experienced.  This case illustrates the need for prophylactic measures to prevent infective endocarditis  especially in patients with prior history of valvular heart disease undergoing dental and other procedures introducing bacteria into the bloodstream.

Patient Presentation The patient is a 45-year-old African American male diagnosed with native valve infective endocarditis (I.E.). He works as a handyman and has been living in the rural south for his whole life. The patient presents with signs of moderate to severe malaise  intermittent fever alongside chills  and gradual weight loss for the past three weeks.  Past Medical History Mr. S reports a past history of intravenous drug use  primarily cocaine  from his 20s to mid-30s. His addiction was treated about ten years ago  and he has remained clean. However  the patient has previously been diagnosed with Hepatitis C presumably contracted during his period of substance misuse. After consultation  the patient also revealed a history of Rheumatic fever from his childhood.  Demographics The patient belongs to a low-income group and has limited access to healthcare services because of remote residence and inconsistent employment. The patient is unmarried  does not smoke or consume alcohol  and does not have children. Unfortunately  he is also homeless and resides in shelters or stays with friends occasionally. Despite struggling with his socio-economic status  he has managed to remain sober for a significant period  fighting substance misuse.  Family History Mr. S's mother passed away from heart disease complications in her 60s  and his father from a stroke in his early 70s. His older brother has a history of cardiovascular disease  and his sister has been diagnosed with diabetes type 2. No family history of rheumatic heart disease or autoimmune disorders is reported.  Present Condition Upon examination  the patient exhibited an irregular heartbeat  lower extremity edema  and petechiae in the conjunctiva. Blood cultures were positive for Staphylococcus aureus infection. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) revealed vegetation on the patient's mitral valve indicative of infective endocarditis. Significant mitral regurgitation and moderate left ventricular hypertrophy were also observed.   In terms of mental health  the patient has mild depressive symptoms  likely associated with his living condition and a stressed lifestyle. He expressed feelings of sadness  low energy levels  trouble concentrating  and occasional suicidal ideation with no plans or intent.  Conclusion Given the history of intravenous drug use  existing Hepatitis C infection  and evidence of Staphylococcus aureus infection  the patient is diagnosed with native valve infective endocarditis. He is currently admitted to the hospital and started on treatment.  Note  Literature states racial/ethnic disparities in relation to Infective Endocarditis. African American males  such as the patient in this case  are disproportionally affected by this condition  often as a result of socioeconomic factors  including low income  access to healthcare services  history of drug use  and homelessness.  Please note that this case presentation includes assumptions based on norms from existing literature and data and may not reflect every individual's experiences.

Patient Case Presentation: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Patient Presentation  A 65-year-old African-American male patient  with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  Type 2 diabetes mellitus and gout  presented with a 10-day history of persistent  low-grade fever and progressive fatigue. He also reported experiencing intermittent chest discomfort and easy shortness of breath over the past week. He has no known drug allergies  smokes one pack of cigarettes daily  and does not drink alcohol. There is no history of intravenous drug abuse. Family history is notable for coronary artery disease with a father who died from a heart attack at the age of 70 and a mother who had a stroke at 75.  Clinical Findings  On examination  the patient was febrile with a temperature of 38.2 °C  had a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  pulse rate of 90 beats/min  and oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. Heart sounds were irregular and there was a grade 3/6 diastolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border.   Diagnostic Assessment  Blood tests showed a raised total white count of 12 000 per cubic millimeter (normal 4 000–11 000)  a high erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein. Electrocardiogram demonstrated atrial fibrillation. Transthoracic echocardiography revealed the presence of a 1.5 cm x 1 cm irregular  mobile mass attached to the ventricular side of the second anterior leaflet of the mitral valve  suggestive of a vegetation. Three sets of blood cultures grew Streptococcus viridans highly suggestive of infective endocarditis.   Treatment  The patient underwent definitive therapy with intravenous antibiotics for six weeks guided by an Infectious Disease specialist. He also received anticoagulation therapy for atrial fibrillation  and was referred to Cardiology for consideration of mitral valve surgery.  Discussion  This patient's presentation is consistent with native valve infective endocarditis  a serious condition associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Risk factors included age  male gender  and presence of chronic conditions (hypertension  diabetes). The diagnosis was based on positive blood cultures and the presence of vegetation on the mitral valve leaflet identified in the echocardiogram. Early recognition  appropriate antimicrobial therapy  and possible surgical intervention are vital for better prognosis.  This case report underscores the importance of considering infective endocarditis in patients with suspected cardiac abnormalities such as valve diseases presenting with persistent fever and other systemic symptoms. This is particularly true in populations more likely to be affected such as the older adults and African Americans  who according to the available literature tend to have higher risk of cardiovascular disease compared with other demographic groups. Importance is also stressed on the need for optimized control of chronic conditions that may exacerbate infective endocarditis  such as diabetes and hypertension.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 64-year-old African American male  presenting complaints of intermittent fever and chills that has been ongoing over the past 3 weeks. The patient also cited fatigue  shortness of breath  and night sweats disturbing his sleep routine. On admission  he had a blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg  pulse rate of 100 bpm  and fever at 100.8°F. No significant weight loss was reported.  Past Medical History:  He has a history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus managed with oral hypoglycemics  diagnosed approximately 10 years ago  and well-controlled hypertension observed since his late 40s. In his medical record it is also noted that he has recurrent profile of Staphylococcus aureus infections known for last 4 years. He underwent tooth extraction and minor sinus surgery a year ago. There is no record of illicit drug use or past surgeries other than the recent periodontal and sinus surgery.  Family History:  His mother died of stroke at the age of 79 and his father died of prostate cancer at the age of 70. His older brother  aged 70  is a known patient of coronary artery disease and his sister  aged 65  is a Type 2 Diabetic.  Social History:  He is a retired engineer  married with 3 children  residing in an urban community. He quit smoking 15 years ago but admits to drinking alcohol moderately and does not exercise regularly.  Findings and Diagnostic Assessment:  Clinical examination revealed a grade II/VI systolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border. No peripheral stigmata of endocarditis were found. Lab investigations indicated a higher than normal white blood cell count  ESR  and CRP  suggestive of a systemic infective process. A couple of sets of blood cultures grew methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus. Echocardiogram revealed vegetations on the native aortic valve consistent with infective endocarditis and moderate regurgitation.   Diagnosis:  Given the history  clinical presentation and diagnostic test results  the patient was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis.  Plan:  The patient is planned to receive appropriate IV antibiotic therapy as per infectious disease consultation. He will be monitored closely for treatment response and further surgical intervention has not been ruled out. Regular follow-ups post his hospital stay will be scheduled to monitor progression. Patient’s diabetic status along with lifestyle changes particularly regular exercises  moderate alcohol use and oral hygiene need to be emphasized during his stay and discharge planning.   Comments:  Native-valve infective endocarditis often occurs in patients having a history of heart valve disease or previous endocarditis  but can also be associated with poor oral hygiene  immunosuppression  history of Intravenous drug use or  invasive procedures (like dental procedure). Our patient has some of these risk factors which might have led to endocarditis.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male was admitted to our facility  showing signs of fever  chills  rigors  and fatigue. He reported experiencing a low-grade fever three weeks prior  which had been escalating over time. Alongside this  the patient also complained of unexplained weight loss of approximately 5 kg over the last month and generalized body aches.  Past Medical History: The patient had been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 10 years ago that was in good control with metformin. He also has a history of hypertension. There were no previous issues with regard to cardiovascular or renal diseases. No prior surgeries or transplants were reported. He reported regular check-ups at a local clinic  with the last being two months prior when his HbA1c and routine cardiovascular biomarkers were at normal levels.  Current Medications: He was on Metformin 500mg twice daily for his diabetes and took Captopril 50mg daily for his hypertension.  Family History: There was a reported family history of cardiac disease  with the patient's father succumbing to a myocardial infarction at the age of 70 years. His 67-year-old sister has been diagnosed with congestive heart failure. No family history of infective endocarditis was reported.  Habitual History: The patient is a retired high school teacher  a non-smoker  and social drinker. He has no known drug allergies. He reported poor dental hygiene practices and had not seen a dentist for over a year.  Clinical Findings: Upon examination  the patient appeared to be in distress. His body temperature was 38.5°C  blood pressure was 130/80 mmHg  and heart rate was 100 bpm. His oxygen saturation was 95%  while breathing ambient air. Cardiac auscultation revealed a new heart murmur.  Investigations: A range of investigations was undertaken  including a complete blood analysis  urine test  and cardiac imaging.  Patient’s blood cultures revealed a growth of Streptococcus viridans  sensitive to Penicillin G. Echocardiography was suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis with vegetations seen on the mitral valve.  Conclusion: The patient's clinical presentation  blood cultures and echocardiographic findings led to a diagnosis of definite native-valve infective endocarditis.  Management: The patient was admitted to the cardiology ward  given his diagnosis and the general medical condition in the event of possible complications. An infectious disease consultant was involved  Penicillin G was started as per sensitivity testing  and the patient’s clinical conditions were monitored closely. The patient’s poor dental hygiene was acknowledged as a potential non-cardiac source of the infection.  This case illustrates the importance of considering infective endocarditis in patients with a new heart murmur  fever  and unspecific signs of infection  particularly in those with poor dental hygiene practices as the oral cavity can often be a reservoir of pathogens responsible for native-valve infective endocarditis.

Patient Profile:  Mr. J is a 56-year-old African-American male  retired construction worker  with a history of intravenous drug use. He is divorced with no kids. He has a body mass index (BMI) of 32. According to CDC data  this demographics is at heightened risk for diseases like infective endocarditis.  Past Medical History:  Mr. J has a long-standing history of uncontrolled hypertension  diabetes mellitus type 2  and smoking. He has been inconsistently compliant with his antihypertensive and hypoglycemic medications and his last known Hba1c level was 8.7%.  Current Presentation:  Over the past 3 weeks  Mr. J reports experiencing recurrent fever  fatigue  loss of appetite  and weight loss. He also reports a new onset of shortness of breath  occasional cough with a small amount of blood  and night sweats. He has no complaints of chest pain  palpitations  or syncope.  Physical Examination:  Physical examination reveals a temperature of 38.5°C  heart rate of 95 bpm  and blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg. Chest examination showed dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds at the left base  suggestive of a pleural effusion. Cardiac examination revealed a new holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex.   Pertinent Lab Data:  Complete blood count showed leukocytosis and anemia. His blood cultures were positive for methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA).  Imaging:  Chest radiography revealed a left lower lobe infiltrate and small pleural effusion. Transthoracic echocardiogram showed a large  mobile vegetation on a normal-appearing mitral valve consistent with severe mitral regurgitation.  Diagnosis:  Based on the clinical findings  positive blood cultures  and imaging studies  Mr. J was diagnosed with left-sided native-valve infective endocarditis secondary to MSSA. The patient's condition suggests possible pulmonary septic emboli given the imaging findings and the occurrence of hemoptysis.  Treatment & Follow Up:  Appropriate IV antibiotic therapy was initiated immediately for MSSA. Considering the size of vegetation and the patient's clinical stability  he was offered surgical evaluation for possible early intervention. Patient education was carried out about the need for medication adherence to manage his diabetes and hypertension  cessation of tobacco use  and the risk linked with intravenous drug use.  This case emphasizes that infective endocarditis should be considered in patients with a history of intravenous drug use who present with fever and new murmur.  (Note: Please customize this data accordingly as this is just a demonstration of how a case of infective endocarditis can be presented. The data may not accurately represent risks or illness severity of infective endocarditis for all populations.)

Case Presentation:  Patient Profile: A 54-year-old male African-American named Mr. Johnson presented at the emergency department of a local hospital in southern Louisiana.  Medical History: Mr. Johnson’s past medical history includes hypertension  managed by Lisinopril for the last 10 years  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  managed with metformin for 5 years. He smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily  moderately consumes alcohol  and has a diet high in carbs and fats. There is no history of intravenous drug use.   Family History: Unfortunately  Mr. Johnson’s family history is significant. His father died at the age of 60 from a stroke and his mother was diagnosed with heart disease but lived until 78. He has one brother with type 2 diabetes and coronary artery disease.  Current Complaint: Mr. Johnson was brought to the hospital with complaints of high-grade fever  chills  malaise  and a new-onset systolic murmur that he has been experiencing for a couple of weeks.
