Additionally  he reported an unintentional loss of about 10 pounds over the past month.  Examination and Result: Upon physical examination  he has a fever of 38.5°C  a heart rate of 110 beats/min  blood pressure of 120/80 mmHg. A first-degree AV block was found on his electrocardiogram (ECG). There were audible rales in the lower segments of both lungs. Auscultation of the heart revealed a new-onset grade 3 diastolic murmur heard best at the heart base.  Investigations: The laboratory studies were significant for leukocytosis (WBC count 13 000/uL) and high erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP). Blood cultures were drawn  which suggested the presence of Gram-positive cocci. Upon performing a transthoracic echocardiography (TTE)  a 2x1.5cm vegetation was visualized on the aortic valve.  Diagnosis and Treatment: Based on clinical findings  blood culture results  and echo findings  Mr. Johnson was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis (IE) caused by Staphylococcus aureus. He was hospitalized and empiric antibiotic therapy with intravenous vancomycin was started promptly  pending further susceptibility results. Cardiothoracic surgery was also consulted concerning the large vegetation and new-onset heart block  which could potentially indicate a need for surgery.  Follow-Up and Evaluation: The patient responded well to intravenous antibiotic therapy. Serial blood cultures turned negative and he reported a significant improvement in symptoms. Upon re-evaluating his case with Cardiothoracic Surgeons  a decision was made against immediate surgical intervention considering his positive response to medical management. The patient was thus continued on an antimicrobial regimen. Further management involves educating Mr Johnson on the importance of preventing IE by maintaining good oral hygiene and getting regular dental checkups.  This case ultimately underscores the importance of early recognition of the signs and symptoms of IE as delay in diagnosis and treatment can cause severe complications and mortality.

Title: A Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. A  Gender: Male  Age: 58  Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Physical laborer  Past Medical History: Mr. A has a known history of intravenous drug use and was clean for about ten years. He had thankfully never contracted HIV or Hepatitis C. He also managed to overcome a year-long dependent on alcohol. He had previous episodes of non-specific skin infections. The patient reported to be a regular smoker for the past 40 years with a history of heart disease in his family.   Presenting Complaints: Mr. A presents to the emergency department  complaining of fever with chills  persistent fatigue  loss of appetite and steady weight loss over the past 2 months. Further probing revealed intermittent night sweats and unlocalized joint pain. On detailed inquiry  Mr. A reports that his ""heart feels like it's pounding out of his chest"" sometimes.   As per the literature  these symptoms are consistent with that of native valve infective endocarditis (IE). Intravenous drug use is a key risk factor. IE is found to be more common in Caucasian males than any other demographic  with middle-aged individuals (30-60 years old) most affected. Also  people with pre-existing heart disease or artificial heart valves are more susceptible to IE. These characteristics were taken into consideration while designing this case.   [The clinical condition will further be detailed with appropriate clinical investigations and findings necessary for a complete medical workup  but as it deviates from the current request  it was not documented.]

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male farmer  residing in the rural Midwestern United States with history of intravenous (IV) drug use.  Past Medical History:  Patient has a medical history of drug abuse  especially IV drug use from his forties leading to chronic Hepatitis C. He was treated for it during the previous year. He also reported prior episodes of binge drinking  though quit alcohol consumption five years back. He also has a history of untreated dental caries and periodontal disease.  Presenting Complaints:  The patient presented to the outpatient clinic with a four-week history of fever  fatigue  unintended weight loss  and an ebbing generalized body pain. He also reported a change in the colour of his urine to a dark yellow  and occasional night sweats. He mentioned experiencing a decreasing appetite over the previous month. He also reported an episode of transient visual loss in the right eye a week back  which resolved spontaneously.  This case design was created considering the demographic representation in literature. Infective endocarditis often occurs in individuals between 30 to 60 years  with a predominance in males. IV drug use is a major risk factor that predisposes individuals to this condition  which is corroborated by the patient's medical history. Other notable factors contributing to the risk include poor oral hygiene and chronic diseases such as Hepatitis C. The patient's rural residency correlates with the geographical epidemiology of endocarditis.  Notes for Educators: The case allows trainees to integrate knowledge across various medical areas  including infectious disease  cardiology  neurology  and immunology. The differential diagnosis should initially be broad  but through relevant history taking  physical examination and subsequent investigations  trainees should hone in on a diagnosis of Infective Endocarditis. Excellent talking points would include the importance of recognizing the presence of non-specific symptoms such as fever and fatigue  the role of dental hygiene in preventing systemic diseases  and the impact of social determinants on health.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  The patient is an African American male  aged 60 years old  hailing from an urban low-income setting. He is retired  has a high school-level education  and is a former tobacco user. No known drug or alcohol abuse.  Past Medical History:  He has a history of diabetes mellitus type II for the past 10 years  which has been fairly controlled. He also suffers from moderate hypertension. The patient underwent dental procedures twice over the past year. No known allergies were documented.  Presenting Complaints: Patient has been experiencing severe fevers  ongoing for the past 10-15 days. He presents with persistent fatigue  poor appetite  weight loss  and night sweats. Recently  he has been reporting muscular pains as well. He also complains of experiencing heart palpitations over the last week.   Rationale:  Various epidemiological studies indicate that infective endocarditis (IE) shows a greater disposition towards males  particularly those aged 60+ years. Studies also show that IE is common among African American populations and people from low socioeconomic classes. Risk factors considered include dental procedures and pre-existing conditions such as diabetes and hypertension  which align with the patient's medical history. The common symptoms of IE include persistent fever  fatigue  night sweats  poor appetite  weight loss  and occasionally heart palpitations - all of these have been reported by the patient in this case.

Patient Information: Mr. J  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  working as a farmer in rural Pennsylvania.  Chief Complaint: High fever  malaise  night sweats  fatigue  shortness of breath on exertion and a new onset of a heart murmur.   Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of:  1. Mild aortic regurgitation (native-valve) diagnosed 3 years ago via an echocardiogram. 2. Type 2 diabetes mellitus  well-controlled with metformin. 3. Combined Hyperlipidemia  controlled with statin therapy. 4. Prior tobacco use  having quit approximately 10 years ago. 5. No known drug allergies.  Family History: His father suffered from coronary artery disease and mother had a history of hypertension and osteoporosis. He has one older brother with type 2 diabetes and an older sister with no serious health conditions.  Review of Systems: Patient admits to experiencing unexplained weight loss and weakness for the past couple of weeks. Denies chest pain  palpitations  syncope  cough  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  edema  gastrointestinal symptoms.   Clinical presentation: On physical examination  the patient is febrile with a temperature of 38.7°C (101.7°F). His heart rate is 105 beats/min and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. Cardiovascular examination reveals a regurgitant murmur at the right upper sternal border that changed in character since his last medical checkup.   The case of Mr.J is designed to provide a clinically appropriate scenario for a patient with infective endocarditis to help medical students understand the disease's progression  clinical presentation  management  and complications. It takes into account most common risk factors of infective endocarditis: an existing heart valve disease and diabetes. In the U.S.  it's most frequently diagnosed in males  especially within the age group of our patient. Moreover  this case presents the commonly manifested systemic symptoms of the disease such as fever  malaise  night sweats  and weight loss without any apparent cause.

Case Report:  Patient Information: A 60-year-old African American woman presents to the emergency department (ED).  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of intravenous drug use (IVDU). She has been clean for approximately ten years. The patient also has a history of hypertension and occasional migraines.  Current Complaints: The patient complains of a high-grade fever that has persisted for over a week  malaise  and significant weight loss over the past two months. She also reports a recent episode of night sweats.  Case Scenario: The woman resides in a low-income urban area and works as a store clerk. She initially noticed a low-grade fever which progressed to a high-grade fever over the course of a week. She tried treating it with generic over-the-counter flu medicines without success  which prompted her eventual visit to the ED.  Over the course of the last month  she also started feeling constantly fatigued and lost nearly 10 pounds unintentionally. Furthermore  she reports difficulty in breathing during moderate physical activities such as climbing stairs or walking a short distance  which were formerly routine for her. She denies any chest pain or palpitations.   In triage  she is noted to be febrile with temperature of 101.8°F  heart rate of 110 bpm  respiratory rate of 21/min  and blood pressure of 132/85 mmHg. Upon physical examination  there is notable pallor  splinter hemorrhages under the nail beds  and osler nodes on her fingers and toes. A heart murmur is observable during the cardiac examination. She also has splenomegaly on abdominal examination.  Work up including blood tests  cultures  and an echocardiogram suspecting native-valve infective endocarditis is ordered due to her history  presentation symptoms  and physical examination. Initial blood tests show mild anemia  leukocytosis  and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein indicating a severe systemic infection. Meanwhile  blood culture results are being anticipated.  Take Away: The patient is representative of typical native-valve endocarditis patients who are often older persons and might have a past of significant IVDU. Furthermore  she represents the population that might have limited access to healthcare due to their socioeconomic status. Despite well-documented physical findings suggestive of endocarditis  it stays a diagnosis that is often missed due to vague symptoms overlapping with many other illnesses. This case emphasizes the importance of a thorough history taking and physical examination in such individuals.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:   The patient is a 52-year-old Caucasian male. He works in construction and lives in a suburban neighborhood in Denver  Colorado. He is married and has two grown children. He neither smokes nor drinks alcohol and has no history of illicit drug use.  Past Medical History:   The patient has a documented history of surgically repaired bicuspid aortic valve in his early 30s. He has a controlled hypertensive regimen for the past ten years and has a congenital heart murmur. His father passed away from cardiovascular disease at age 64  and his mother has a history of hypertension and diabetes.  Key Complaints:   The patient presented himself to the ER with a chief complaint of a high-grade fever for the past 4 days  associated with chills  severe fatigue  and rapid unexplained weight loss over the last two weeks. He also reported an increasing difficulty in breathing and intermittent chest pain during the same duration.   Analysis:  The collected information depicts a high-risk scenario for native-valve infective endocarditis (NVE)  particularly due to his history of heart valve repair  an inherent heart murmur. The manifestation of symptoms such as persisting fever  fatigue  weight loss  and signs of heart problems like breathlessness and chest pain further heightens clinical suspicion. The case  therefore  is of significant educational value for medical students  primarily to enhance their clinical suspicions and decision-making skills.   It correlates to major epidemiological demographics; according to the literature  NVE is more prevalent among males and the middle-aged population. Prior cardiac history such as valve diseases/repairs significantly increases the risk. The case does not involve either substance abuse or healthcare-associated factors  indicating the necessity for students to understand that NVE can occur in the absence of these factors  especially in patients with underlying cardiovascular disease.

Case Report:  Patient Information:  Mr. Aguilar is a 52-year-old Hispanic male laborer from a rural setting  who presented to the emergency department with a 2-week history of persistent and progressive malaise  fever  and unexplained weight loss. He is married with three children and his family history does not suggest any congenital heart diseases.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Aguilar was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus ten years ago  and occasionally experiences poor glucometer control. Furthermore  he has a history of periodontal disease that was previously treated but has worsened within the past few years due to inconsistent dental care. He is a former alcoholic  quit drinking 8 years back  and has been a tobacco user for the past 30 years. There is no history of IV drug use  recent dental procedures  or noteworthy travel. He has no known drug allergies.  Presenting Complaints:  The patient complained of a high-grade fever that was not alleviated by over-the-counter antipyretics. Additionally  he was feeling increasingly fatigued  weak  and had unintentionally lost about 5kg over the last month. He was also experiencing night sweats and joint pain.  These demographics are representative of many patients diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis - male  with pre-existing conditions such as diabetes and poor dental healthcare  indicating a potential source of infection. Contrary to popular belief  injectable drug users make up only a small subset of those diagnosed  providing a good teaching point about stereotype bias in the clinical setting. Hispanic and aged populations  as well as individuals exposed to occupational risk factors and lifestyle choices such as smoking  also have increased prevalence. This case  thus  accurately encompasses these demographic findings.  The case will be continued with investigations  subsequent diagnosis confirming native-valve infective endocarditis  followed by an explanation of the decision-making regarding treatment options  encouraging students to fully comprehend the relevance of the patient's clinical history  symptoms  and socio-demographic factors in managing this life-threatening condition.

Case Report:  Patient Profile:  Ms. Jackson is a 65-year-old African American female  retired school teacher  and lifelong resident of an urban area in the Midwest. She is status post hysterectomy 20 years ago for benign reasons and has a 10-year history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus. She is also a diagnosed hypertensive since age 60  and was under oral medication. She is a non-smoker and rarely consumes alcohol.   Recent Health Concerns:  Ms. Jackson was brought to the emergency department (ED) by her daughter due to progressive weakness and extreme fatigue over the past 2 weeks  accompanied by an intermittent fever spiking to a maximum of 102°F at home. She reports lack of appetite and unintentional weight loss of approximately 10 pounds over the last month. She stated that she feels short of breath and have developing painful red sores on her fingertips and toes that are tender and interferes with her ability to walk and perform her daily activities without pain.   Background:  Navajo American Indians and Alaskan Native populations have a higher incidence of infective endocarditis  but this pattern isn’t reflected in African Americans. African American female of middle-age have relatively lower incidence of native valve infective endocarditis  but risks can be elevated due to certain conditions such as poorly controlled diabetes and hypertension which are quite prevalent in this population. This case is representative of an ethnic group that is often underrepresented in medical curricula.   Literature Reference:   Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report (2019). Racial/Ethnic Disparities in Hospitalizations for Native-valve Infective Endocarditis  National Inpatient Sample  2000–2014. https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/68/wr/pdfs/mm6825a4-H.pdf   Heidenreich  P. A.  Masoudi  F. A.  Maini  B.  Chou  T. M.  Foster  E.  Schiller  N. B.  & Smith  S. C. (2002). Echocardiography in patients with suspected endocarditis: a cost-effectiveness analysis. The American journal of medicine  113(8)  634-639.

Patient Profile: Patient Name: Mr. B Age: 55 years Ethnicity: African American Gender: Male Occupation: Office Clerk  Residence: Urban dwelling  middle-income neighborhood  Past Medical History: - Type II diabetes mellitus – 15 years - Past IV drug abuse - clean for 10 years  Chief Complaint:  - History of fever and chills for the past 3 weeks. - Recently developed shortness of breath and generalized fatigue.  Additional information: Mr. B reported no recent dental procedures or indwelling devices. He has been non-compliant with his diabetic medications  with an inconsistent diet and lack of regular exercise being contributing factors. Social history reveals two packs per day smoking for 30 years and past intravenous drug use  now clean for 10 years.  Medical literature suggests the median age group for native valve infective endocarditis is typically between 50-70 years old. Males are more frequently affected than females  and there is a high prevalence in persons with a history of drug use. African Americans  particularly those within urban areas  are disproportionately affected  likely due to a combination of epidemiologic and socioeconomic factors. Concurrent conditions like diabetes enhance susceptibility  providing a set-up for healthcare-related procedures and likewise infective endocarditis. Compliance with medications and follow-up appointments is a common issue in such patients  linked to lack of education  socioeconomic stressors  or inherent factors associated with chronic diseases.

Case Report   Patient Profile:  - Name: Mr. David Moreno - Age: 56 years old - Sex: Male - Ethnicity: Non-Hispanic Caucasian  - Occupation: Carpenter  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Moreno presents with a 2-week history of fever and fatigue. He also reports feeling more fatigued after physical activity and notes experiencing a decrease in appetite with an unintended loss of 5 pounds in the last 3 weeks. He further describes nights sweats  shortness of breath on exertion  and minimal discomfort around his chest.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Moreno was diagnosed with moderate aortic stenosis 4 years ago  but he has not been following up for his condition. He had a dental procedure carried out one month ago. Due to his occupation  he has a history of occasional minor injuries  for which he self-treated. His other past medical history includes Hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  both of which are well-controlled with medications. He does not smoke or consume alcohol excessively.   Epidemiology:  The choice of this case was influenced by the epidemiology of infective endocarditis. The condition has a high occurrence rate in males  especially those between the ages of 30 to 60 years. Non-Hispanic whites have been shown to have the highest incidence of endocarditis. Conditions such as aortic stenosis  history of invasive procedures (like dental procedures)  diabetes  and hypertension are known risk factors for developing infective endocarditis.  The symptoms presented  such as fever  fatigue  appetite and weight loss  night sweats  shortness of breath  and chest discomfort  are common symptoms of infective endocarditis. This case  therefore  is a good representation of how native-valve infective endocarditis can present in a fairly typical patient with several risk factors for the disease.  References:  - Murdoch  D. R.  et al. (2009). Clinical presentation  etiology  and outcome of infective endocarditis in the 21st century: the International Collaboration on Endocarditis-Prospective Cohort Study. Archives of internal medicine  169(5)  463-473. - Slipczuk  L.  et al. (2013). Infective endocarditis epidemiology over five decades: a systematic review. PLoS One  8(12)  e82665.

Case Vignette:  Patient Information:   This case features a 53-year-old male of Hispanic ethnicity. He is a full-time construction worker  married  living with his wife and two sons in urban North Carolina. No reported international travels. He is a smoker (smoking one pack daily for 20 years) and admits to moderate alcohol consumption (2-3 beers daily). No drug use.  Past Medical History:  The patient had a diagnosis of non-insulin-dependent Diabetes Mellitus type II (NIDDM)  diagnosed seven years ago. He also has a history of Rheumatic Heart disease diagnosed during childhood. He adheres to a strict medication regimen of Metformin 500mg BID and Lisinopril 10mg daily  yet his blood pressure and glucose levels are moderately controlled. The patient denies any known drug allergies. There is no history of relevant surgeries. His family history is significant for Hypertension (father)  Myocardial Infarction (elder brother)  and NIDDM (mother).  Presenting Complaints:  The patient presents to the Emergency Department complaining of progressive fatigue and weakness over the last three weeks  accompanied by intermittent fever and night sweats. He also reports a significant unintentional weight loss over the past month. He states he's been having new onset mild  dull  and constant retrosternal chest discomfort over the past week  which gets slightly better with rest. After a week  he noted increasing shortness of breath on mild exertion  which was not present before. There is no history of palpitations  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  or orthopnea. He also notes a rash that started on his legs and has been spreading upwards over the past week. He denies cough  hemoptysis  abdominal pain  hematuria  or recent sexual exposure.  The representation of a patient with a high-risk background (construction worker)  pre-existing underlying chronic medical conditions like poorly controlled diabetes mellitus  and Rheumatic Heart disease comprises a complex condition  commonly associated with the native-valve infective endocarditis  reflecting a clinically relevant scenario for medical students' teaching and training. Also  the demographic representation of Hispanic ethnicity conveys the need to address cardiovascular diseases and related risks in minority ethnicities.   The case presentation encapsulates both constitutional and systemic symptoms and caters to the medical literature's typical presentation of native valve infective endocarditis. This case will facilitate teaching students to consider endocarditis as a differential diagnosis for sepsis or undifferentiated symptoms in patients with cardiovascular risk or disease.

Patient Information:  A 65-year-old Hispanic male.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of diabetes mellitus type II and a 30-year history of illicit intravenous drug use for which he attended rehab and has been clean for the last two years. There's no prior history of heart diseases.  Key Complaints:  The patient presents to the emergency department with a two-week history of fatigue  low-grade fever  and unusual sweating  especially at night. He has also been experiencing unexplained weight loss and mild joint pain over the same period. The patient indicated that he had a dental procedure about a month ago.   This case aligns with literature indicating that native-valve infective endocarditis is often seen in older adults  and has been associated with Hispanic ethnicity. Other risk factors include poor dental hygiene leading to dental procedures  and history of intravenous drug use  although this typically affects the right side of the heart  particularly the tricuspid valve.    Encourage students to think critically and consider other differential diagnoses as well  such as malignancy and autoimmune diseases  which can present with similar constitutional symptoms. However  the recent dental work provides a clue  as minor dental or surgical procedures can serve as gateways for bacterial invasion of the bloodstream  potentially causing endocarditis in vulnerable patients. Furthermore  the patient's ethnic background should guide students to consider certain cultural and socioeconomic factors that can contribute to disease risk and health-care access.

Case Report:  Patient Profile:  - Name: Mr. Johnson - Age: 65 years old - Gender: Male - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired repairman - Social history: Ex-smoker  moderate alcohol use  Past Medical History: -Mitral valve prolapse -Heart murmur -Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus -Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease  Presenting Complaints:  - Persistent fever lasting for the past two weeks - Shortness of breath  notably worsening on exertion - Swelling in the legs - Transient  stabbing chest pain  - Unexplained weight loss  - Night sweats - Two episodes of syncope in the past week  While infective endocarditis can affect anyone  it is more prevalent in men aged 50 and above. Conditions that increase the prevalence include past history of valve disease  structural cardiac defects  and intravenous drug use. Other risk factors include diabetes mellitus  rheumatic heart disease  and a history of invasive procedures. The above case represents these demographics and risk factors.  Key points of focus in this case should include:  1. Differential diagnosis of the fever: Given the patient's cardiac history  the persistent fever and other systemic signs would prompt consideration for infective endocarditis.  2. Examination of the cardiovascular system: The medical students should specifically look for signs of infective endocarditis  such as a new or changed heart murmur  Janeway lesions  Osler's nodes  or Roth spots in the eyes.  3. Necessary investigations: Discuss the importance and frequency of blood cultures  the role of an ECG  chest X-ray  and echocardiogram in diagnosis.  4. Antibiotic therapy and need for surgical intervention: Discern when to apply antibiotics and the indications to refer the case to a cardiothoracic surgeon for valve replacement surgery.  5. Prognosis: Discuss the potential complications of infective endocarditis such as congestive heart failure  systemic embolism  and highlight the relevance of early detection and management.  5. Educate about the importance of dental hygiene and avoidance of specific triggers to prevent recurrent episodes.   This case will serve as a comprehensive guide 0 ensuring medical students cover all aspects of diagnosis  management  and prevention of native-valve infective endocarditis. The discussions surrounding the case will provide students valuable insight into the complexities encountered in diagnosing and managing infective endocarditis.

Case Report:  Demographics: Mr. Rodriguez  a 53-year-old Hispanic male working as a manual laborer  presents to the clinic. He is a tobacco smoker but denies any use of illicit drugs. He's not on any regular medications and his immunization status is up-to-date.   Past Medical History: He had rheumatic fever at the age of 10  and was diagnosed with mitral valve stenosis in his adulthood. There are no known allergies. There's no history of substance abuse. His family history includes hypertension in his father and stroke in his mother.  Chief Complaints: Over the past three weeks  Mr. Rodriguez has been feeling fatigued with associated low-grade fever and night sweats. He also mentions a 5 kg unintentional weight loss over the same period. Recently  he has complained of dyspnea on exertion which has been progressively worsening.   In reviewing this case  it is important to note that native-valve endocarditis predominantly affects males  with higher prevalence in middle-aged and older adults. The burden of infective endocarditis is also found to be higher in some racial and ethnic groups  like the Hispanic population  due to various socioeconomic influences  cultural beliefs  healthcare accessibility and genetic predispositions. Rheumatic heart disease  tobacco smoking and previous valve diseases are known risk factors. Common symptoms such as fever  fatigue  night sweats  weight loss and dyspnea should always lead to further investigation for possible infective endocarditis in the appropriate clinical context.

Case Study:  Patient Profile: Demographics: Caucasian male  62 years old  retired manual laborer  lives in the rural Midwest   Past Medical History: Diagnosed with mild hypertension 6 years ago  managed with lifestyle modifications. No history of heart disease  illicit drug use  dental procedures  or recent infections. Physical examination 2 years prior indicated no valvular heart disease.  Presenting Complaints: The patient was admitted to the outpatient department presenting with high-grade fever persisting for more than two weeks. The fever was associated with chills and rigors but not accompanied by any rash or night sweats. Over this period  the patient also reported progressive fatigue and unexplained weight loss. He noted occasional discomfort in the left upper quadrant of his abdomen but reported no recent changes in bowel habits or urine output. He also mentioned a new onset of fleeting  migrating joint pain  predominantly in the knees and elbows  which seemed unrelated to exertion.  On further enquiry  the patient reported no recent travel  animal contact  food poisoning  or any other specific event that might trigger his symptoms. His family history revealed that his father had passed away due to a stroke at 68  and mother had lived till 87 with hypertension and type 2 diabetes.  The brief case report outlines key features of the patient's complaints  demographic  and medical history relevant to native-valve infective endocarditis. The inclusion of a relatively less common presentation would assist in broadening the differential diagnoses considered by medical students and prompt the need for comprehensive investigative work-up in febrile patients.

Patient Information:  A 56-year-old Caucasian male  with a past medical history of intravenous drug use (IVDU) in his early adulthood and long-term smoker suffering from chronic bronchitis. He is currently under methadone maintenance therapy and living in a suburban area with his family.  Chief Complaint:  Patient presents to the emergency department complaining of unexplained fever  generalized fatigue  loss of appetite with occasional night sweats for the last two weeks. He also mentions a new onset of shortness of breath that has been progressively worsening over the last few days. He denies any recent IVDU.  Physical Examination:  Upon examination  the patient appears in moderate distress with clammy  pale skin. Vital signs show fever (38.7°C/101.6°F)  tachycardia at 112 bpm  and mild tachypnea at 22 breaths/min. Cardiovascular examination reveals a diastolic murmur on auscultation. Small erythematous lesions on his palms and soles  consistent with Janeway lesions  and several painless  small erythematous nodules on his fingers and toes  suspected to be Osler nodes.  Investigations: Blood cultures  chest X-ray  and echocardiography are advised to identify the presence of infective endocarditis and any potential complications. Also  some laboratory tests such as complete blood count (CBC)  erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)  C-reactive protein (CRP)  and tests for hepatitis B  C  and HIV considering his history of IVDU.  Differential diagnosis: Native-valve infective endocarditis  Rheumatic fever  Systemic lupus erythematosus.  This case mostly represents the most common demographics for native-valve infective endocarditis as seen in medical literature. It is more common in males than females  and people over 50 years old are at a higher risk. Furthermore  people with a history of IVDU are at significant risk  and endocarditis often affects the native valves in this group. It is also important to note the role of chronic conditions like bronchitis that can predispose to bacterial infections. As per literature  Staphylococcus aureus  including MRSA  is one of the most common organisms causing native valve endocarditis  particularly in patients with a history of drug use.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis: A Training Case for Medical Students  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. Johnson Age: 55 years Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Profession: Gardener  Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a history of intravenous (IV) drug use but is sober for the past 5 years. He also has Type II Diabetes  Hypertension  and occasional dental issues. He has a paternal family history of heart disease.  Chief Complaint: Mr. Johnson presents to the ER complaining of fatigue and shortness of breath  especially on exertion  that has been worsening over the past two weeks. He reports experiencing episodic low-grade fever with occasional night sweats and has lost around 10 pounds unintentionally. He also recalls having a dental cleaning one month prior to this episode  after which he suffered a mild periodontal infection for which he completed a course of oral antibiotics.  Examiner's notes: The focus of the case should orient the students towards the significant history of IV drug use  chronic dental issues and the recent dental procedure in combination with nonspecific but chronic symptoms. This history should guide them towards suspecting an infection of the heart valves  namely native-valve infective endocarditis  which might be confirmed by the presence of symptoms of heart failure  sepsis  or embolization and further investigation with imaging and blood cultures. Emphasize the importance of being vigilant about possible complications and considering endocarditis in cases with chronic symptoms and seemingly unrelated history of presenting illness.

Case Report:      Patient Profile:      The patient is a 56-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the Emergency Department with a chief complaint of lethargy  loss of appetite  increasing shortness of breath  fever  and weight loss over the past four weeks.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of intravenous drug use (heroin) but has been abstinent for several years. His past medical history is noteworthy for Hepatitis C infection contracted during his drug use months  untreated hypertension  and a dental procedure approximately two months prior with limited antibiotic prophylaxis due to the patient's reported penicillin allergy. He has no record of previous surgery  no known allergies except for penicillin  and no established care with a primary care physician due to lack of health insurance.  Presenting Complaints:     The patient's main symptoms include newly developed lethargy  loss of appetite  and shortness of breath. He also reports experiencing nocturnal diaphoresis and a weight loss of approximately 15 pounds in the last month. Worth noting are intermittent fevers  infrequent chills  and a low-grade persisting occasional cough.   Background Context:  This case presents a common clinical scenario for native valve infective endocarditis in the developed world  particularly among populations with a history of intravenous drug use. The patient's symptoms have been ongoing for an extended period  and he is at risk of developing more severe complications caused by the condition. With high-risk factors such as untreated hypertension  Hepatitis C infection  history of drug use  poor dental hygiene  and recent dental work  this patient is at a higher likelihood of developing infective endocarditis.  According to literature  Infective Endocarditis (IE) affects mostly men (2:1 ratio) and tends to peak in the 5th to 7th decade of life  making our patient demographic appropriate. The described social background and medical history  such as intravenous drug use  and predisposing heart condition also align with the most frequently reported risk factors.

Patient Case:  Patient Demographics: Patient is a 62-year-old African-American male  who lives in an urban area and is a former IV drug user.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of chronic hepatitis C and hypertension. He has been sober for 15 years but used injectable heroin for 20 years prior. He has no history of heart disease  diabetes  or other significant medical conditions.  Presenting Complaints: The patient presents to the clinic with a three-week history of fever  chills  and fatigue. The fever spikes in the late afternoon and is often accompanied by night sweats. He also complains of recent onset of shortness of breath on exertion and a painful  swollen  red lump on his right elbow  which he assumes is a spider bite. His appetite has decreased lately and he reports unintentional weight loss. He denies chest pain  cough  or other localizing symptoms. He has not noticed any changes in his urine or stool color.  This case is designed to represent a typical case of a patient who might present with native-valve infective endocarditis. The risk factors for this patient include his history of IV drug use. The features of possible septic arthritis or immune complex deposition (represented by the lump on the elbow)  the evidence of systemic illness (weight loss  fatigue)  and the presentation with a persistent fever are all consistent with this diagnosis. This case should provoke thought about the need for further investigation with blood cultures and possibly imaging of the heart.   African-American males have been found to have a higher incidence of native-valve infective endocarditis  with IV drug users making up a significant proportion of these patients. Public health interventions have reduced the incidence of endocarditis among IV drug users  but it remains a significant risk factor  particularly in those with a long history of use. The incidence of native-valve endocarditis is also somewhat higher in urban areas. The age of the patient reflects the fact that endocarditis typically affects adults  but can occur at any age.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Profile: The patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian male  a smoker with a history of Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus (DM) and mild Hypertension.  Demographic Considerations: Given that infective endocarditis most often occurs in males aged 30 to 60 and that Caucasians are at an elevated risk  this patient presentation reflects a demographic group that is disproportionately affected. Furthermore  a history of smoking  DM  and hypertension are common comorbidities associated with endocarditis  encompassing a broad range of pathophysiology and clinical situations that a student might encounter.  Past Medical History: The patient was diagnosed with Type-2 DM a decade ago and has kept it under control with regular medication. He has been a smoker for the past 40 years and has a history of mild hypertension. There isn't any history of any congenital heart defects  rheumatic heart disease  or intravenous drug use. The patient has undergone no prior surgeries. Family history is unremarkable.  Chief Complaint: Patient presents with a 2-week history of intermittent low-grade fever  fatigue  loss of appetite  and night sweats. Over the past few days  he has also noticed that small  reddish spots have appeared on his skin and the whites of his eyes appear slightly yellow.   This case should lead the student to consider infective endocarditis early on  given the constellation of vague constitutional symptoms (fever  fatigue  loss of appetite) as well as the more specific findings of petechiae and subtle jaundice. The patient's past medical history of DM and smoking provides cardiovascular risk factors and avenues for deeper studies into the pathogenesis. While this patient does not feature any direct risks for endocarditis such as intravenous drug use or a history of valvular disease  his presentation can help educate students on the fact that endocarditis can still occur outside of these direct risks  particularly in the presence of other  more indirect cardiovascular risks.   Here  students can discuss common pathogens leading to endocarditis and relevant diagnostic workups  including the importance of blood cultures and echocardiography. The therapeutic interventions such as the choice of antimicrobial therapy and surgical intervention criteria can also be discussed.

Case Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Male   Patient Information: Mr. Patrick Alone  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department with persistent  unexplained fever  malaise  and an unintentional weight loss of 15 pounds over the past 2 months.  Past Medical History: He has a past medical history of untreated type 2 diabetes  hypertension and a lifelong smoking habit. Ten years prior  he was treated for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He underwent dental extraction 2 months ago. He has no history of drug abuse or intravenous drug use. His medications include metformin and amlodipine.  Key Complaints: 1. Febrile episodes for the past 2 months  described as high-grade  intermittent fever with chills. 2. Generalized weakness and malaise that progressively worsened over the past few weeks. 3. Significant weight loss (approximately 15 pounds) over the past 2 months. 4. Shortness of breath  especially on exertion  which he initially associated with his COPD  but it seems to have increased recently. 5. Occasional night sweats.  Note: The presentation of infective endocarditis can be atypical in elderly patients with multiple comorbid conditions. While intravenous drug use is a well-recognized risk factor for infective endocarditis  non-IV drug users may also develop this condition  particularly those with poor dental hygiene  a condition which our patient fits given his history of dental extraction. It is essential for trainees to bear in mind that a high degree of suspicion is often required to diagnose infective endocarditis timely  given its insidious presentation.   Objective: This case is intended to help trainees recognize and appreciate the complexity and variability of clinical presentations in infective endocarditis  particularly among older patients with comorbidities. Moreover  this case is also designed to reinforce the importance of detailed history taking and conducting a thorough physical examination in diagnosing this condition.

Case Report: Native Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Demographics: Mr. Antonio Martinez is a 68-year-old Hispanic male who resides in a suburban setting. He is a retired electrician who lives with his 65-year-old wife. He enjoys fishing  gardening  and spending time with his grandchildren. He is an ex-smoker (quit 23 years ago) and drinks alcohol moderately. He is not known to use recreational drugs.  Past Medical History: Mr. Martinez has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  of which he's been managing with metformin for the past 10 years. He also has Hypertension controlled with lisinopril. He has no known allergies. He had an appendectomy in his 30s and has been relatively healthy until now. No noted history of valve disease  rheumatic heart disease  or intravenous drug use. He does  however  have poor dental hygiene.  Chief Complaints: Mr. Martinez presents to the emergency room with a three-week history of generalized body weakness  fatigue  and unexplained weight loss (around 12 lbs in a month). He complains of persistent low-grade fever which does not seem to reduce in any significant way by taking over-the-counter paracetamol. He also mentions night sweats and occasional chills. He has been experiencing increased shortness of breath  especially during trivial activities. There has been reduced appetite and intermittent nausea. He has noted leg swelling for the past two days. He denies any chest pain or discomfort  cough  or urinary symptoms.  Upon further inquiry  he reveals that he had recently (about a month ago) undergone a dental extraction which was done at a local community health fair. He noticed that it took longer for the bleeding to stop  and the site was painful and uncomfortable for a few days. However  he relates these issues to his old age and did not seek follow up.  This comprehensive case looks into native-valve infective endocarditis  relevant to both racial/ethnic and age demographics  and the prevalence of occurrence in patients without a known history of valve disease  but who may be exposed to risk factors such as invasive dental procedures without appropriate prophylaxis. The case is designed to guide students to investigate beyond the common to a more serious condition that might initially present with rather generalized and non-specific symptoms.

Case Scenario:  Patient Profile:  Mr. Garcia  a 58-year-old Hispanic male construction worker  walks into the clinic.   Past Medical History: He has a history of poorly controlled type two diabetes mellitus and a recent dental procedure performed three weeks ago. He has been non-compliant with his diabetes medication due to his lack of health literacy. His parents both suffered from cardiovascular diseases  but no history of congenital heart diseases in the family. No history of IV drug use.   Key Complaints: He presents with a two-week history of persistent fever  night sweats  and weight loss. He also complains of increasing fatigue  muscle aches  and intermittent episodes of shortness of breath. Over the past few days  he also noticed a new rash on his legs and blood in his urine.  Discussion:  This case is fitting for teaching about native valve infective endocarditis. The patient’s presentation is typical of subacute endocarditis with the persistent unexplained fever  symptoms of systemic illness like night sweats  weight loss  fatigue  and the new vascular phenomena like rash and hematuria.  One important hint towards infective endocarditis in the history is the recent dental procedure. Instrumentation during dental procedures can lead to transient bacteremia  especially in patients who didn't take prophylactic antibiotics. Also noteworthy is the patient's poorly controlled diabetes  which can compromise his immunity and increase susceptibility to infections.  This case emphasizes the importance of comprehensive history taking and considering infective endocarditis in patients with unexplained fever  especially when there are other suggestive features or risk factors like poor dental hygiene  recent invasive procedures  or inadequate glycemic control.  The next steps in assessment would involve physical examination looking for classic signs of endocarditis like Janeway lesions  Osler nodes  or Roth spots  etc. Investigations would include blood cultures and echocardiography. Proper management will then follow depending on the results.   Finally  this case involves a Hispanic male  representative of a demographic that is less represented in medical literature but does not show a lower incidence of infective endocarditis. This points towards the need for inclusivity and awareness about health issues across all racial and ethnic groups.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male from an urban location. He is a retired elementary school teacher who lives with his wife. He has a history of occasional alcohol consumption and smokes 10 cigarettes a day.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of rheumatic fever as a child. He was diagnosed with mild mitral stenosis in his 40s but the condition remained stable with no significant issues. He was also diagnosed with type 2 diabetes at the age of 55 and is managed on Metformin. There is no history of intravenous drug use or recent dental procedures. His father passed due to cardiovascular complications in his early 60s.  Key Complaints:  The patient presented at the hospital with a 2-week history of fatigue  shortness of breath  low-grade fever  and night sweats. He mentioned recent unintentional weight loss along with loss of appetite. He also reported having noticeable discomfort in his joints and a persistent  new heart murmur that was non-existent before.  This case was designed with current demographic representation of infective endocarditis in mind. The literature suggests that infective endocarditis is most common in men in their late 50s or early 60s  with a history of valvular heart disease or other structural heart disease  and a risk factor of smoking or occasional alcohol use. The presence of diabetes increases the susceptibility due to impaired immune system. The key complaints including fatigue  low grade fever  night sweats  and a new cardiac murmur are indicative of a subacute course of infective endocarditis.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Demographics and Past Medical History: Patient Name: Patient X (anonymized for privacy) Age: 62 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Construction Worker Insurance: Medicare Residence: Urban suburb in the Pacific Northwest  Past medical history: - Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) related to history of smoking (20 pack-years)  quit five years ago - Hypertension (HTN) controlled with medication - Excessive alcohol intake in the past but stopped 2 years ago - History of intravenous drug use (IVDU) 30 years ago with long-term recovery  - No known drug allergies  Presenting Complaints: Mr. X presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of persistent  low-grade fever (T max 100.4°F)  recent episodes of night sweats  and weight loss of about 7 lbs over the last 6 weeks. He also complains of intermittent shortness of breath  worse on exertion and a progredient issue of fatigue. He noticed the presence of blood in his urine this morning  which prompted his visit.   NOTE: This case description aligns with available published data that demonstrates a higher prevalence of infective endocarditis among older males  often related to a history of IVDU or alcoholism  as well as common comorbidities of chronic illnesses such as COPD and hypertension. While the geographical location may not play a significant role in the development of infectious endocarditis  stating it contributes to a holistic approach to patient care.   The main symptoms characteristic for infective endocarditis - fevor  weight loss  night sweat  and possible hematuria - have been included.

Case Report  Patient Information:   A 58-year-old African American male who is currently a shift worker in a chemical factory. He is unmarried and lives alone.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of intravenous drug abuse  primarily heroin  up until about 10 years ago. He was involved in a substance abuse treatment program and since then manages to stay clean. He has a history of intermittent dental abscesses  poor dental hygiene  and has not seen a dentist in five years. He also has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) from prolonged tobacco use (40 pack-years).   Presenting Complaints:  Over the past two weeks  the patient has been feeling malaise  fatigue  and has seen a low-grade fever (38-38.5°C). He also reports discomfort in his chest  specifically a dull aching pain  along with shortness of breath exacerbation during his normal COPD symptoms. He also notes he's had night sweats and experienced unintended weight loss  lacks appetite but does not report any nausea or vomiting.  The case of a 58-year-old African American male with a history of intravenous drug use  poor dental hygiene  and COPD presenting with malaise  low-grade fever  night sweats  unintentional weight loss  and increased dyspnea represents a typical case of native-valve infective endocarditis. This case is designed with an appropriate demographic in mind and incorporates several risk factors associated with endocarditis such as intravenous drug use  poor dental hygiene  and a history of respiratory disorders.  This case prompts students to think about the relation between the patient's past medical history  the presenting complaints  and the possible diagnosis of infective endocarditis. It can facilitate the discussion about the underlying pathophysiological mechanisms  clinical features  diagnostic work-ups  management  and prevention strategies of native valve infective endocarditis. Additionally  the case helps emphasize the comprehensive approach needed in managing patients with multiple comorbid conditions.

Case Study: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Demographics:  Name: Mrs. Susan Rodriguez  Age: 55 years old Sex: Female Ethnicity: Hispanic/Latino Occupation: Teacher Location: Urban area  Past Medical History:  Mrs. Rodriguez has a 15-year history of rheumatic heart disease which resulted in moderate aortic stenosis. She never had any surgical intervention or replacement procedures due to her controlled condition. She is on a regular course of metoprolol and aspirin.   Key Complaints:  Mrs. Rodriguez visited her family doctor complaining of low-grade fever lasting for about three weeks accompanied by chills and night sweats. She also reported persistent fatigue and lethargy  weight loss without changes in her eating habits  and a new onset of a heart murmur detected by her primary care physician. On more detailed questioning  she admitted to experiencing an intermittent  dull chest pain  close to her heart  for about a week. She had also noted reddish-pink spots (petechiae) on her skin  predominantly on her palms and soles. Of note  she had a dental procedure about five weeks ago.  Rational for case design:  Infective endocarditis predominantly affects individuals with pre-existing heart conditions  including rheumatic heart disease. The typical age of presentation is between 30 and 60 years  and there have been numerous studies indicating a slight propensity towards males - however  female cases are still significant. A 2017 study in the Journal of American College of Cardiology indicates Hispanics bear a high burden of cardiovascular diseases  including infective endocarditis  and hence the demographic representation.  The case emphasizes the importance of recognizing non-specific symptoms and signs of endocarditis  such as fever  fatigue  weight loss  and heart murmurs. The risk associated with dental procedures and onset of infective endocarditis is also highlighted by this case. The timing and description of symptoms are typical for native-valve infective endocarditis  which is usually subacute in nature.   This case should enable students to learn how to recognize and approach suspected cases of infective endocarditis  appreciate its risk factors  understand the importance of in-depth history taking  and also provide a platform to discuss the underlying pathophysiology.

Patient Profile:  Name: Maria Gonzalez Gender: Age: 60 Race/Ethnicity: Hispanic Occupation: Retired school teacher Setting: Urban  Past Medical History:  - Diagnosis of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 15 years ago  managed with metformin. - Hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago  on Lisinopril. - She had a dental procedure (tooth extraction) a month ago.  Chief Complaint:  - Presented with intermittent fever for 2 weeks  - Fatigue  - Weight loss  - Moderate to severe joint aches  Effects on Daily Life:  - Maria reports extreme fatigue and weakness  leaving her unable to perform her daily activities. - She also reports loss of appetite  leading to unintentional weight loss.  Clinical Examination:  - Temperature: 100.8°F (38.2°C) - Heart Rate: 110 bpm  - Blood pressure: 140/85 mmHg - On auscultation: a new heart murmur heard  This case presentation avails a rich training opportunity geared towards the diagnosis  investigation  differential diagnosis  and management of native valve infective endocarditis. It also incorporates important elements such as the consideration of oral-dental procedures as potential sources of infection  risk factors in the elderly  and clinical manifestation of infective endocarditis in the background of other comorbid conditions like diabetes and hypertension.

Patient Profile  Name: Mr. Sandoval Age: 65 Race/Ethnicity: Hispanic Gender: Male Occupation: Retired  previously worked in construction  Past Medical History 1. Diabetes Mellitus Type 2 2. Previous diagnosis of Rheumatic Fever in late adulthood.  Chief Complaints 1. Persistent high-grade fever for the past 10 days. 2. Experiencing fatigue and weakness. 3. Onset of shortness of breath even on minor exertion. 4. Unexplained weight loss. 5. Observing blood in urine.  This case reflects a patient who belongs to one of the high-risk populations for native-valve infective endocarditis - those with a history of rheumatic heart disease. The patient’s complaints are indicative of possible infective endocarditis  in combination with potential complicating factors (e.g. chronic disease state like diabetes). Studies indicate the disease is more common in older adults  with the average age of diagnosis around 60 years. It is also reported that men are more likely than women to develop this condition. Lastly  it also emphasizes the increased susceptibility of infective endocarditis in the Hispanic population  as referenced in the literature. This case is intended to stimulate discussion around risk factors  signs and symptoms  diagnosis  and the treatment of native-valve infective endocarditis.

Patient Profile:   Name: Mr. Johnson (hypothetical patient to maintain confidentiality)   Age: 60 years old  Gender: Male  Ethnicity: Caucasian  Living Status: Lives alone in a rural setup   Occupation: Retired farmer   Case Information:  Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson has a documented history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for 15 years  adequately controlled on metformin. He also has mild hypertension  controlled with ACE inhibitors. He had a dental procedure a month ago due to a tooth abscess.  Key Complaints: He's experiencing moderate to high fevers irregularly for the past three weeks. He also complains of fatigue  headache  weight loss  chills  and skin petechiae. There's a shortness of breath and occasional chest pain during exertion. A critical complaint is a new onset mild regurgitation heard during the chest auscultation.  Infective endocarditis is more common in males and older adults  with a median age of diagnosis around 58 years  according to the European Heart Journal. The disease has been associated with certain heart conditions and risk factors such as diabetes and invasive dental procedures. In this case  we've included the dental procedure as a precipitating event and other common symptoms of native-valve infective endocarditis like fevers  fatigue  and new onset murmur. It's also important to highlight the morbidity factor of residing in rural settings due to a potential delay in diagnosis and treatment.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. Rodriguez  a 55-year-old Hispanic male  owner of a gardening company  presented to the emergency department with a 10-day history of progressive fatigue  low-grade fever  night sweats  loss of appetite  and unintentional weight loss. He noted a change in skin color to be slightly more yellow and also observed occasional drops of blood in his urine. He is married with two kids and lives in a suburban area. He does not smoke  occasionally drinks alcohol  and denies any drug usage.  Past Medical History: His past medical history revealed that Mr. Rodriguez was diagnosed with rheumatic fever during his childhood. As a consequence  he has been dealing with mild mitral valve regurgitation for the last 20 years. However  he had been asymptomatic and was not taking any regular medications. His immunizations  including pneumococcal and influenza vaccinations  were up to date. His other routine screenings  such as diabetes  cholesterol  and colonoscopy were generally within normal range. His mother had hypertension and his father had type 2 diabetes mellitus.  Key Complaints:  The primary complaints include fever  malaise  anorexia  night sweats  mild jaundice  and hematuria. He is particularly disturbed by the persistent low-grade fever that refuses to abate  and the systemic fatigue and weakness that are making it difficult for him to function. He also noted a decreased appetite and increasing night sweats that are affecting his quality of life.  This case can pave the way to discuss the manifestations of infective endocarditis and how it may present with non-specific symptoms like fever  night sweats  and fatigue  which can often be confused with other conditions. The history of rheumatic fever and resultant heart disease could be an important point to introduce the concept of predisposing risk factors for endocarditis.   It may also open a discussion about demographic and socio-economic factors involved in developing infective endocarditis  such as the higher rate of incidence among males  and the role of age  ethnicity  and access to healthcare. This patient's case promotes understanding of how to approach investigations and management of a case of suspected native-valve infective endocarditis.

Case Report  Demographics: Patient Name: Mr. Samuel Montgomery Age: 53 Gender: Male Race: African American Occupation: Teacher Location: Urban Area of Detroit  Michigan  Past Medical History: Mr. Montgomery has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  for which he has been on metformin for the past 10 years. He has been fairly controlled and has no late diabetes complications. His other medical history includes two dental procedures in the past year for gum disease and a root canal. He is known hypertensive  controlled with lisinopril. Mr. Montgomery does not lead an active lifestyle and his daily food consumption often exceeds the recommended portions for his condition. He does not smoke  but admits to moderate alcohol consumption.  Presenting Complaints: For about 3 weeks now  Mr. Montgomery has been experiencing on-and-off fever  getting as high as 102°F. He has also been complaining of chills  fatigue  weight loss  night sweats  and joint/muscle aches. He has noticed a few red tender spots on his palms and soles and small painful red bumps on his fingers and toes. For the past one week  he complains of increasing shortness of breath and chest pain  particularly when lying flat.  Upon reading literature  a similar range of demographics was found where individuals over the age of 50  especially those with a history of diabetes  hypertension  dental procedures  and indulging in unhealthy lifestyles  were found to be more prone to native-valve infective endocarditis. Therefore  it is important for medical students treating such patients to include it in their differential diagnosis when encountering similar presenting complaints and histories.

Patient Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Demographics: Patient: Mrs. Patricia Sanchez Gender: Female Age: 62 years old Race: Hispanic Occupation: Retired school teacher Marital Status: Widowed  Past Medical History: Mrs. Sanchez has a history of Type II diabetes and is currently on metformin. She also has well-controlled hypertension with losartan. Patricia underwent dental surgery for periodontitis two months ago. She does not have a history of IV drug abuse  recent travel  or autoimmune disorders. She is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol.  Presenting Complaints: Over the past three weeks  she began feeling fatigued and experienced a weight loss of 8 pounds not related to any dietary changes. Patricia also noted that she had been running a low-grade fever and experiencing night sweats intermittently. She also complained of a new onset weakness in her left leg. For her last three days  she recognized petechial hemorrhages under the nails of her right hand.  Clinical Examination: On examination  slight pallor was apparent  and a new systolic murmur was detected at the left lower sternal border. Moreover  she experienced mild tenderness on palpation of the left calf muscle.  Note: This case of a 62-year-old Hispanic woman  Mrs. Sanchez  having potential for native-valve infective endocarditis has been prepared considering the actual literature-based demographics. According to data  infective endocarditis tends to be more common in men; however  it also affects post-menopausal women  particularly those with a history of valvular heart disease. However  the presentation can also be seen in those without a prior history of heart conditions  especially when there has been a recent invasive procedure  similar characteristic to our case. Remember  a complete history  careful physical examination alongside pertinent investigation  is vital for diagnosing endocarditis which had a myriad of systemic manifestations.    Reference: Moreillon P  Que YA. Infective Endocarditis. Lancet. 2004;363:139-49.

Case Report for Training:  Patient's Demographics: The patient is a 57-year-old African-American male who is a smoker and heavy drinker. He works as a janitor  and his income is below the poverty level.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of rheumatic fever during his childhood but never had any surgery or heart anomaly identified. He has been diagnosed with uncontrolled type II diabetes mellitus for the past ten years and converted hepatitis C of unknown duration. Furthermore  the patient has a 25-year history of tobacco smoking equivalent to 50 pack-years and chronic alcohol use.  Key Complaints:  He presents with a 3 weeks history of persistent fever with daily temperature peaking at 39 degrees Celsius. He also reports progressive fatigue  unintended weight loss of about 20 pounds over the past month  and occasional night sweats. A new  isolateral headache has started recently. Moreover  he also complains of night blindness and increasing difficulty in picking up objects with his right hand for the past week.  Upon further questioning  he mentions that he's been having a deep  sharp  intermittent  lower retrosternal chest pain for the past week. The patient denies having any cough  dyspnea  abdominal pain  diarrhea  or urinary symptoms.   This case scenario represents a typical patient at risk for endocarditis  taking into account the demographic data available in medical literature pointing towards a higher prevalence among middle-aged men  smokers  alcoholics  immunocompromised individuals (Hep C)  and lower economic strata. This choice of patient demographic aims to allow medical students to establish the correlation between these risk factors and the presented case and develop their capability of making accurate diagnoses based on thorough assessments.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Information:  - Age: 65 years old - Sex: Male - Ethnicity: Caucasian  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of intravenous drug abuse up until about fifteen years ago but has been clean since enrolling in a rehabilitation program. He has also been documented with chronic hepatitis C contracted during his years of drug usage. Additionally  the patient has been diagnosed with hypertension and mild hyperlipidemia  both of which are being managed by lifestyle modifications and medication.  Key Presenting Complaints:  The patient has come in complaining of persistent  low-grade fever for two weeks  which has not subsided with over-the-counter medication. He has also expressed feeling unusually fatigued throughout this period  with loss of appetite and weight. Recently  he has also noticed mild swelling in his feet and ankles. He reports experiencing shortness of breath  in particular after climbing stairs or walking a long distance  which he earlier used to do so without difficulty.  There is no history of chest pain  cough  or other respiratory symptoms. He denies any newer changes in his bowel or urinary habits. The patient has been adherent to his hypertensive and hyperlipidemic treatment  and there have been no recent changes in his medications.  Note: The patient's age  sex  and ethnicity have been chosen as they are representative of demographics where valvular heart disease and subsequent infective endocarditis occurrence are more commonly found in literature. The history of IV drug abuse is included as this is a known risk factor for infective endocarditis. Chronic hepatitis C  while potentially related to IV drug use history  is also included as it can pose additional challenges in patient management. Other comorbidities like hypertension and hyperlipidemia have been added to add complexity to the case.

Case Study: Title: ""An Unexpected Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis""  Patient Demographics:  Mr. Thompson is a 62-year-old Caucasian male who is a retired truck driver. He is a resident of a suburban area  married with three children. He occasionally consumes alcohol  in the form of a glass of wine with dinner a few times a week  and he quit smoking cigarettes 10 years ago after a pack-a-day habit for 35 years. He has a history of non-compliance to medications and infrequent medical check-ups due to his previous traveling work lifestyle.   Past Medical History: Mr. Thompson has a significant medical history of poorly controlled Type 2 diabetes mellitus since the age of 53. He also suffers from hypertension and hyperlipidemia - conditions that he was diagnosed with five years back. His family history is positive for ischemic heart disease. Despite these medical conditions  he has been free from chronic or recurrent infections in the past.  Key Complaints: Mr. Thompson presents with six days of malaise  low-grade fever  night sweats  and a recent loss of appetite causing abrupt weight loss. He also complains of a constant dull-ache in the middle of his chest. A new symptom he has noticed is shortness of breath while performing daily activities  something which he did not experience earlier. He also casually mentions that he has been noticing more bleeding while brushing his teeth lately.  Objective: The objective of this case study is to make young learners aware of the cardinal symptoms and history which raise suspicion towards infective endocarditis in at-risk population  their identification  and clinical relevance.  Takeaway: This case is an example of how infective endocarditis can present in an individual with pre-existing conditions that predispose him to develop such infections. Early recognition and prompt management are crucial to reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with native-valve infective endocarditis. This case also provides information regarding the symptoms of infective endocarditis which will help in the early identification of the disease.   Note: Though this case study represents a commonly encountered clinical scenario  please bear in mind that infective endocarditis can occur even in people without significant past medical history or epidemiological risk factors. Also  though men are generally more affected as per the literature  it must be noted that women are also susceptible to this condition.

Patient Information: Mr. Philip Hudson  a 50-year-old Caucasian male is currently employed as a farmer in a rural community. He lives on his farm with his wife and two children.   Past Medical History: Mr. Hudson has a past medical history of moderate dental decay requiring multiple extractions and fillings but has not sought dental care for the past 4 years due to financial constraints. He reports a 20-pack year smoking history  but quit 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol socially and was recently diagnosed with high blood pressure  for which he is taking medication. He has no known drug allergies. His immunizations are up to date and he has no history of illicit drug use or hospitalization.  Chief Complaint: Mr. Hudson came to the hospital  complaining of severe fatigue  fever of 38.5°C that has persisted for almost three weeks  and unintended weight loss of about 10 pounds over the same period. He reports noticing fingernail changes (splinter hemorrhages) and an unusual red  painless rash on his legs. He also mentions experiencing intermittent night sweats and mild shortness of breath.  Physical examination findings suggest potential Janeway lesions. On cardiovascular examination  the provider notes a harsh murmur  best heard at the left lower sternal border. His dental examination reveals severe dental caries and periodontal disease with visible inflammation.  In this scenario  Mr. Hudson's prolonged fever  weight loss  cardiac murmur  and cutaneous manifestations along with a pertinent history of poor dental health suggest the possibility of native-valve infective endocarditis  warranting further diagnostic tests  including blood cultures and echocardiography.   Reflecting the epidemiological data  the patient represents the demographic who are at a higher risk of native-valve endocarditis  specifically middle-aged males with poor dental health  even without a history of intravenous drug use. This case outlines the importance of considering endocarditis in patients demonstrating non-specific symptoms along with evidence of end organ damage  even in the absence of traditional risk factors.

Patient Profile: Name: James Martinez Age: 54 Sex: Male Race: Hispanic Occupation: Factory worker Location: Urban city setting  Past Medical History: Diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes 7 years ago  Diagnosed with Hypertension 5 years ago Recent dental surgery 2 weeks ago Illicit drug abuse (heroin): 15 years (in recovery - last use approx. 5 years ago)  Presenting Complaints: Over the last one week  Mr. Martinez has been complaining of 1. General malaise 2. High-grade intermittent fever with chills and night sweats 3. Fatigue 4. Mild shortness of breath  particularly on exertion 5. Subtle weight loss 6. Vague chest discomfort  described as a dull ache  Background:  Infective endocarditis  despite being rare  largely affects individuals with pre-existing cardiac conditions  or those exposed to certain risk factors. Diabetes and illicit drug use are known risk factors  as well as recent dental procedures. This case represents a patient at high risk due to his pre-existing conditions and history of illicit drug use. The demographics show this is an urban Hispanic male which not only represents a significant portion of US population but also addresses health disparities occurring among racial and ethnic minorities. According to the CDC  Hispanic people are at a higher risk for Type 2 Diabetes and hypertension  risk factors for infective endocarditis. Furthermore  the use of intravenous drugs  another risk factor  is prevalent across metropolitan areas.   The students should be educated on recognizing these risk factors early on to suspect infective endocarditis and initiate timely investigations. Similarly  the case ideally highlights the importance of patient counseling regarding oral hygiene  especially in those having undergone dental procedures. It is indicative of the multiple opportunities available for introducing preventive measures. In this way  the case emphasizes a holistic approach that considers epidemiology  social determinants  and prevention along with the pathophysiology and treatment of the disease.

Patient Case:    Demographics: 67-year-old African-American male  Past Medical History: The patient has been diagnosed with Diabetes Mellitus Type II (managed with Metformin and lifestyle modifications) and Hypertension (managed with Lisinopril)  both medical conditions have been under control for over a decade. Patient has a 30-pack year history of smoking  but quit 15 years ago. Patient also admits to a long history of poor dental hygiene  with infrequent dental visits. He had rheumatic fever as a child.  Chief Complaints: Patient presents to the hospital with a two-week history of low-grade fever  fatigue  loss of appetite  and an unintentional weight loss of around 10 pounds over this period. More recently  the patient states he has experienced intermittent  sharp chest pain radiating to his left arm  with associated shortness of breath.  Such demographic representation aligns with literature suggesting  infective endocarditis  a deadly infection of the heart valves  tends to be diagnosed more frequently among elderly male patients with a history of chronic diseases like diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Moreover  smoking and poor dental hygiene serve as significant risk factors. Symptoms often start subtly  and may include nonspecific complaints like low-grade fever  fatigue  loss of appetite  and weight loss.                                         -The case also underlines the connection between cardiopulmonary symptoms and infective endocarditis  which serious students must learn to potentially diagnose this condition earlier in similar at-risk patient groups.

Case Study: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient demographics:  The patient is a 56-year-old White male from a rural  low socio-economic background. He is a smoker with a 30 pack-year history and an occasional heavy alcohol drinker. His occupation requires long hours of manual labour  which hasn't changed since he immigrated to the United States 25 years ago.   Past medical history:  The patient has a history of moderate persistent asthma  controlled with the use of low-dose inhaled corticosteroids and a short-acting beta-2 agonist as needed. He was diagnosed with hypertension two years ago  which has been managed with amlodipine 10mg daily. The patient was recently diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes but has been noncompliant with metformin therapy and dietary modifications. There are no known drug allergies. He does not have any known history of heart disease in the family.  Presenting complaints:  The patient presents with symptoms that have gradually worsened over the past four weeks. He initially noticed a few days of nonspecific malaise and low-grade fever. Over the following week  he experienced increased fatigue  night sweats  small joint arthralgias  and unexplained weight loss.   Over the previous week  he also reported a new onset of a heart murmur described as a new harsh midsystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border  shortness of breath on exertion  and weakness.
