Physical examination revealed several conjunctival hemorrhages  tender nodules on the pads of his fingers and toes (Osler's nodes)  and small  painless red or purplish skin lesions on his palms and soles (Janeway's lesions).  These symptoms  alongside the patient's history and socio-economic background  should lead to initial investigations to confirm suspicions of native-valve infective endocarditis. It will be essential to use this case to educate students on recognizing the signs and symptoms of this disease and understanding the importance of early detection and treatment. This case will help students learn and apply appropriate diagnostic tests and treatment guidelines.

Patient Profile: Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 65 years Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Engineer  Complaints: Mr. Doe presented to the emergency department with a 3-week history of fever  fatigue  night sweats  and weight loss. He also reported a new onset of mild chest discomfort and a shortness of breath that has been progressively getting worse.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe is diabetic and hypertensive for the last 12 years. These conditions were well-managed with Metformin (500mg BD) and Lisinopril (10mg daily). He had a dental procedure around 5 weeks ago. He quit alcohol 10 years back and has never smoked. He showed good adherence to his medication schedule.  Justification for Patient Selection: Infective endocarditis (IE) is most likely to arise in persons over 60 years old  with men being affected 1.5 times more frequently than women  according to literature. Diabetes mellitus and hypertension are also risk factors associated with IE.  Main Focus of the Case:  This case centers on Mr. Doe's subsequent diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis  focusing on his risk factors (age  sex  comorbidities such as diabetes and hypertension  recent dental procedure)  symptoms  effective diagnosis  and the complexities of treatment strategies in patients with preexisting conditions like his. It provides an opportunity to understand the mechanisms  susceptibility factors  and presentation of infective endocarditis  along with its implications on the heart valves. It also placing strong emphasis on the importance of early recognition and timely intervention.   Relevance of the Case to Medical Education: Infective endocarditis is a serious condition that  if untreated  can lead to severe complications and has a high rate of mortality. For medical students  this case teaches the importance of gaining comprehensive patient history and recognizing the symptoms that  although may appear non-specific (fever  fatigue  weight loss)  combined with certain risk factors can point towards a life-threatening condition such as infective endocarditis.

Case Report:  Patient Information:   Mr. J is a 58-year-old African American male employed as a janitorial worker. He is from a middle-class socio-economic background and lives with his wife in the urban settings of Atlanta  GA. He has a history of tobacco and alcohol use.   Past Medical History:  Mr. J has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes for the past 15 years  for which he takes Metformin. His other significant medical history includes hypertension  for which he is on Lisinopril  and stage IIIb chronic kidney disease. He lacks any familial history of heart diseases. He has no known allergies and underwent an appendectomy 30 years ago.   Key Complaints:   Mr. J presented to the emergency department complaining of a high-grade fever of 102°F  sweating  malaise  fatigue  and unintentional weight loss over the past 15 days. He also reports experiencing a reduced appetite  general body aches  and a new heart murmur detected by his primary health care provider during a routine follow-up. He also mentioned an episode of hemoptysis a few days ago.  Justification:   The demographic information and background are in line with literature findings that noted endocarditis more frequently in males  middle-aged adults  African Americans  people with lower-income occupations  and urban populations (Slipczuk L. et al.  2013). High prevalence is also found in patients with underlying diseases like diabetes  hypertension  or kidney disease  making Mr. J a typical patient (Bor DH. Et al.  1992). The complaints listed are common in patients with native-valve infective endocarditis  including fever  fatigue  weight loss  heart murmur  and hemoptysis associated with pulmonary embolism (Baddour LM. Et al.  2005).   References:  - Slipczuk L  Codolosa JN  Davila CD. Infective endocarditis epidemiology over five decades: a systematic review. PLoS ONE. 2013;8(12):e82665. - Bor DH  Woolhandler S  Nardin R  Brusch J  Himmelstein DU. Infective endocarditis in the U.S.  1998–2009: a nationwide study. PLoS ONE. 2013;8(3):e60033. - Baddour LM  Wilson WR  Bayer AS  et al. Infective endocarditis: diagnosis  antimicrobial therapy  and management of complications: a statement for healthcare professionals from the Committee on Rheumatic Fever  Endocarditis  and Kawasaki Disease  Council on Cardiovascular Disease in the Young  and the Councils on Clinical Cardiology  Stroke  and Cardiovascular Surgery and Anesthesia  American Heart Association: endorsed by the Infectious Diseases Society of America. Circulation. 2005;111(23):e394–e434.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  Name: Mr. Hernandez Age: 59 years old Sex: Male Ethnicity: Hispanic  Past Medical History:  Mr. Hernandez  a 59-year-old Hispanic male  presents with a known history of intravenous drug use (IVDU). He also has a long-standing history of type 2 diabetes that is moderately controlled on gliclazide and metformin. His background history also highlights chronic hepatitis C infection which remains untreated. He has no known allergies.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Hernandez arrived at the emergency department complaining of a one week history of increasing shortness of breath  malaise  and unintentional weight loss. Additionally  he reported a low-grade fever lasting for the same duration. On closer inquiry  he also admitted to experiencing night sweats and a recent loss of appetite.  Recently  Mr. Hernandez noticed a few red  painful spots on his fingers and toes. He also states that his urine appeared darker than usual. He denied having cough  chest pain  nausea  vomiting  hemoptysis  joint pains  or any recent injury. He has no travel history in the past six months.  Given his past medical history and current complaints  the medical team is keeping a strong clinical suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis  especially as IVDU puts him at a significantly higher risk. Further diagnostic work-up including blood cultures  complete blood counts  a chest x-ray  and an echocardiogram will be needed to confirm the diagnosis.  This training case would serve to help students understand the early signs and symptoms of native-valve infective endocarditis  the importance of taking a thorough history and the role that social and behavioral factors (such as IVDU) can play in contributing to illness. Additionally  it highlights the need for rapid diagnostic work-up in patients with similar presentations.  Reference: Baddour  et al. (2015). Infective Endocarditis in Adults: Diagnosis  Antimicrobial Therapy  and Management of Complications: A Scientific Statement for Healthcare Professionals From the American Heart Association. Circulation  132(15)  1435–1486. doi: 10.1161/CIR.0000000000000296.

Patient Information: 56-year-old Hispanic male  married  construction worker  residing in Brooklyn  New York  non-smoker with a history of moderate alcohol consumption.   Past Medical History: Known hypertensive for the last 10 years  well controlled on medication. No known allergies to drugs. He has no history of illicit drug use  no surgical history  and no known familial diseases.   Chief Complaints: Presented in the emergency room with a 10-day history of fever  fatigue  decreased appetite  weight loss  night sweats  and a new onset of progressive exertional dyspnea. He also complained of intermittent right-sided joint pain in his knee and ankle. He reported having dental cleaning done approximately 4 weeks ago without prophylactic antibiotics.   It should be noted that Infective Endocarditis (IE) is a serious and potentially life-threatening disease with a predilection towards the male gender (62-65%). Although it can affect people of all age groups  persons aged 50-70 years old are particularly vulnerable  with a median age of approximately 58 years old. Additionally  infective endocarditis shows a particular racial/ethnic predisposition  with non-Hispanic whites and Hispanics being overrepresented compared to other racial/ethnic groups. Risk factors such as poor oral health  invasive dental procedures without antibiotic prophylaxis  and alcoholism  particularly in the lower socioeconomic classes like construction workers  should be considered in this context. Although intravenous drug use (IVDU) is a strong risk factor for IE  our patient reports no such history.

Case Report:  Demographics:  Patient is a 67-year-old Hispanic-American male  employed as a construction worker.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of type II diabetes mellitus and has been non-compliant with his antidiabetic medications. He also has high blood pressure under control with medication and has had periodontal disease. The patient does not smoke or consume alcohol and has no known drug allergies. His family history reveals cardiovascular disease and type II diabetes mellitus.  Chief Complaints: The patient presented to the emergency department with a chief complaint of intermittent fevers peaking at 38.5°C for the past two weeks  accompanied by unintentional weight loss (around 7 pounds in two weeks) and increasing fatigue. He also reported a recent onset of a new heart murmur and experiencing night sweats  although no cough  shortness of breath or chest pain. He also divulged that he occasionally had trouble maintaining balance while walking  suggesting possible central nervous system involvement.  It's important to mention that the incidence of infective endocarditis is particularly representative in the male population and is most frequently encountered among individuals aged 60 years and older. The case study represents the typical demographic while taking into account potential risk factors such as employment status and related exposure and chronic systemic diseases. The chronic uncontrolled diabetes and periodontal disease serve as potential sources of bacteremia seeding valvular vegetation. The early recognition of systemic features are key in such presentations as prompt management can drastically alter the prognostic and outcome trajectory among patients.

Patient Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. Johnson Age: 60 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired  Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has been living with Type 2 diabetes for the past 15 years. He is a former smoker  having quit smoking around 10 years ago  and has a history of battling with drug addiction  particularly heroin  that was successfully brought under control through rehabilitation and remains clean for 6 years. He also underwent a dental procedure about 2 months ago.  Presenting Complaints:  The patient presents with complaints of persistent and high-grade fever for the past 2 weeks. Accompanying the fever  he also reports experiencing fatigue  shortness of breath  unexplained weight loss  a decline in appetite  night sweats and occasional episodes of chills. He also mentions seeing blood in his urine recently.  (Note: The age of the patient and his history of drug use are according to the articles suggesting infective endocarditis is more commonly found in older patients and ones with intravenous drug use. The preceding dental procedures mentioned can be an important clue due to the possible dissemination of oral bacteria into the bloodstream during such procedures.)  Key Learning Objectives from the Case:    - Understand the clinical presentation of a patient with native-valve infective endocarditis and learn to correlate it with the patient's presenting symptoms. - Highlight the importance of comprehensive history-taking in diagnosing conditions like infective endocarditis. - Emphasize on the need for considering predisposing factors such as intravenous drug use  pre-existing heart valve disorders  and recent invasive procedures (like dental procedures) while making a clinical diagnosis. - Understand the potential complications of infective endocarditis and ways to identify them early. - Develop a comprehensive treatment plan including the choice of appropriate antibiotics and other supportive therapies.

Case Report   Patient Demographics:   The patient is a 48-year-old African American male  residing in an urban setting. He is unemployed and lives alone. The patient has a history of intravenous drug use  particularly  heroin  which he has been using for the last 20 years.  Past Medical History:   The patient has a history of chronic hepatitis C infection due to intravenous drug use  and hypertension for which he has been prescribed antihypertensive medication. He has an intermittent history of treatment for various infections  most recently a skin abscess three months prior. He has not completed full courses of prescribed antibiotics before. He does not have any known allergies to drugs or medications.  Key Complaints:  He has been feeling consistently unwell over the past two weeks  presenting with symptoms such as intermittent fever  fatigue  chills  and night sweats leading to substantial weight loss. He also reports a new onset of shortness of breath  along with a persistent cough. He is additionally complaining about severe joint and muscle aches  particularly in the lower extremities.  He has noticed that his symptoms notably deteriorate at night  causing him considerable distress. He attributes the onset of these symptoms to a “bad batch” of drugs but decided to seek medical help as the symptoms persist and have started interfering with his day-to-day activities.  Given the patient's history of intravenous drug use and the symptomatology presented  suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis (IE) should be high  mandating an immediate diagnostic work-up. The blood cultures and echocardiography would be key to confirm this diagnosis.   Teaching Notes:  This case is significant due to the patient's socio-economic history and risky behaviors leading to a notorious predisposition to conditions such as IE. It showcases the critical need for empathetic patient interaction  a thorough understanding of risk factors  and a comprehensive and vigilant approach to non-specific signs and symptoms leading to early diagnosis of less common yet significant conditions. Furthermore  it prompts discussions on prevention strategies  importance of adherence to medication  especially to antibiotic prophylaxis for patients at high risk of IE.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Information: The patient is a 61-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use. He is a retired construction worker living in an urban environment. His family history reveals his mother died of breast cancer at 65  and his father passed away from heart failure at 73. He used to smoke  but quit about 15 years ago  and still maintains a moderate alcohol intake.  Past Medical History: The patient has a medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and recurrent cellulitis from injecting drugs. His only surgery was an appendectomy at the age of 25. He is not on any routine medications but takes over-the-counter pain killers when required. He has been hospitalized once before  two years ago  for cellulitis of his right forearm.  Presenting Complaints: The patient presents with a three-week history of nocturnal fevers  chills  night sweats  weakness  and a 10-pound unintended weight loss over the same period. He also reports new onset of dyspnea on exertion and chest discomfort over the past week.   This fictive scenario depicts a patient in a high-risk group subject to infective endocarditis - samples such as this can be utilized for medical education purposes.  References: Baddour  L. M.  Wilson  W. R.  Bayer  A. S.  Fowler  V. G.  Bolger  A. F.  Levison  M. E.  ... & Gerber  M. A. (2005). Infective endocarditis: diagnosis  antimicrobial therapy  and management of complications: a statement for healthcare professionals from the Committee on Rheumatic Fever  Endocarditis  and Kawasaki Disease  Council on Cardiovascular Disease in the Young  and the Councils on Clinical Cardiology  Stroke  and Cardiovascular Surgery and Anesthesia  American Heart Association: endorsed by the Infectious Diseases Society of America. Circulation  111(23)  e394-e434.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Information: Name: Mr. Patel Age: 63 years old Gender: Male Ethnicity: South Asian Occupation: Retired engineer  Medical History: 1. Past history of IV drug use during the patient's college years  but has been clean for 30 years. 2. Non-compliant with his dental hygiene practices. 3. Personal history of smoking cigarettes for 20 years. 4. No known family history of heart diseases or stroke.  Key Complaints: 1. Persistent and unexplained fever for the past three weeks  which is not responding to over-the-counter medications. 2. Experiencing shortness of breath  especially with exertion. 3. Night sweats and chills without identifiable cause. 4. Recent incident of aching muscle pain and joint pain. 5. Noticed unexplained weight loss over the past month. 6. Fatigue and lethargy that is getting worse. 7. One episode of syncope last week  recovered spontaneously.  *This hypothetical training case aims to represent the typical demographics for native-valve infective endocarditis  as mentioned in the literature. According to studies  males are more likely to develop infective endocarditis  with the median age of diagnosis being 58 years old. Comorbid history of IV drug use and poor oral hygiene are some contributors to this condition. This case scenario should prompt students to further investigate symptoms indicative of infective endocarditis and aim to incorporate other important conditions into the differential diagnosis  such as pneumonia  tuberculosis  etc.  given the presenting symptoms.

Patient Case:   Demographics: Mr. Tang  a 60-year-old Chinese male who works as a truck driver residing in a suburban environment.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Tang has a history of tobacco use (10-pack year history  quit 20 years ago)  moderate alcohol use  no illicit drug use  no history of intravenous drug use  and no known allergies. Past surgical history is significant for a hernia repair 10 years ago. He has hypertension that is controlled by hydrochlorothiazide. He was recently diagnosed with stage 3 chronic kidney disease  likely secondary to his long-standing hypertension. He has no known contacts with tuberculosis or hepatitides. Mr. Tang has never been vaccinated for pneumonia or influenza.  Primary Complaint:  Mr. Tang has reported experiencing malaise  fatigue  fever  chills  night sweats  and unexplained weight loss for the past 3 months. Recently  he's started to notice blood in his urine and newly developed breathlessness  particularly with exertion.   Notice:  The chosen demographic simulates one of many people at risk for infective endocarditis. Hypertension  age  and reduced kidney function all contribute to his risk. Furthermore  his profession as a truck driver may also suggest poor access to regular hygiene and increases risk of infection. His ethnicity was specified to highlight that infective endocarditis can affect people of all backgrounds  and that the most significant risk factors are related to health history and habits  rather than ethnicity.   Note: This patient case is designed to introduce students to the typical presentation of native-valve infective endocarditis and encourages them to explore potential causes  symptoms  physical examination findings  relevant diagnostic/lab tests  treatment options  and preventative methods. It is important to address the specifics of the patient's lifestyle and habits (e.g.  nicotine and alcohol use) and ask about history suggestive of exposure to risk factors of endocarditis.   References:   - Osler  W. (2009). The Gulstonian Lectures  on Malignant Endocarditis. Clinical Infectious Diseases  49(7)  991-997. - Habib  G.  Lancellotti  P.  Antunes  M. J.  Bongiorni  M. G.  Casalta  J. P.  Del Zotti  F.  ... & Napoli  C. (2015). 2015 ESC guidelines for the management of infective endocarditis: the task force for the management of infective endocarditis of the European Society of Cardiology (ESC) endorsed by: European Association for Cardio-Thoracic Surgery (EACTS)  the European Association of Nuclear Medicine (EANM). European heart journal  36(44)  3075-3128.

Case Report  Patient's Profile: Name: Patient X (Maintaining confidentiality as per HIPAA rules) Gender: Male Age: 65 years Residence: Urban Neighborhood Occupation: Retired Mechanic  Presenting Complaints:  1. Fever and chills which has been on and off for the past three weeks. 2. Fatigue and unintentional weight loss. 3. New-onset  systolic murmur detected on routine check-up. 4. Several small and painless reddish spots seen on skin.  History of Presenting Illness:  Patient has been feeling ill for approximately the last three weeks and initially attributed this to a common cold. However  the fever did not abate and now is accompanied by night sweats and unexplained weight loss. There's a recently observed systolic heart murmur mentioned in his health records from last week's GP visit.   Past Medical and Social History:  He is a lifelong smoker but quit drinking alcohol 10 years ago. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he has been prescribed medication. He had a dental extraction performed 1 month prior. His father passed away from heart disease in his 70s. He does not have any allergies.  Physical Examination:  A new systolic murmur was detected on cardiac auscultation. Reddish spots (Janeway lesions) were noticed on his palms and soles. No Osler nodes were found on his fingers or toes. His oral examination showed no signs of any current infection.  Diagnosis:  With these symptoms and findings  the case suggests a scenario that fits the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis  likely from the dental extraction a month ago. The patient's advanced age  smoking history  and male gender  make this a highly possible diagnosis as per the demographic prevalence found in literature. The Janeway lesions and new systolic murmur further support this diagnosis.   Lesson:  This case serves as a reminder for students to always consider the risk of endocarditis in their differential diagnosis when seeing patients with constant or recurrent fevers  especially those with a prior history of invasive dental or other procedures. This is even more important in patients with a history of heart conditions  as they have an increased risk for developing infective endocarditis.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Patient Demographics: 60-year-old Hispanic male  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of Intravenous (IV) drug abuse but stopped around ten years ago. He's also known to be hypertensive and diabetic (Type II) under oral medication. Additionally  the patient is a heavy smoker with a pack/day habit for more than 30 years.  Presenting Complaints: The main complaints were intermittent fever for the past one month  associated with chills  night sweats and a weight loss of about 10 pounds during this period. Over the past week  he started experiencing dyspnea on exertion and occasional orthopnea which is unusual for him. He denied any recent history of IV drug use  dental procedures  or travel.  Note: Infective endocarditis is most common among men  aged between 30-60 years  especially among those with a history of IV drug use  even remote. Other important risk factors include underlying heart conditions  and poor oral hygiene. The choice of a Hispanic male in this case recognizes the need for more ethnic diverse case presentations in medical education. The manifestation of key symptoms like fever  malaise  and weight loss are typical of subacute bacterial endocarditis.

Case Summary:  Patient Demographics: 55-year-old Hispanic Male  non-smoking but has a history of intravenous drug use.  Past Medical History: History of Hepatitis C  varices  myalgia  previous Gram-negative sepsis  and recurrent urinary tract infections. He has been out of medical care for several years.  Key Complaints: Presents with a four-week history of malaise  fever  chills  night sweats  unexplained weight loss  intermittent chest pain  palpitations  and shortness of breath.   [Rationale: Infective Endocarditis often presents over several weeks with nonspecific symptoms such as malaise  fever  and weight loss. In our scenario  the patient's history of intravenous drug use and negligence of regular medical care serve as potential risk factors indicating possible infective endocarditis. Additionally  the choice of a Hispanic patient adheres to accurate demographic representation and highlights the disease's span across various ethnicities.]  This case design should be followed by key questions to help medical students identify important risk factors  associated symptoms  and potential complications for a patient presenting with infective endocarditis. It will also guide them through creating a differential diagnosis  selecting appropriate investigational tools and managing the condition.   References:  1. Selton-Suty C et al.  (2006). Clinical and bacteriological characteristics of infective endocarditis in the elderly. Heart  92(5)  687–693. https://doi.org/10.1136/hrt.2005.065878 2. Murdoch DR et al.  (2009). Clinical presentation  etiology  and outcome of infective endocarditis in the 21st century: the International Collaboration on Endocarditis–Prospective Cohort Study. Archives of internal medicine  169(5)  463–473. 3. Hoen B et al.  (2002). Changing profile of infective endocarditis: Results of a 1-year survey in France. The Journal of the American Medical Association  288(1)  75–81. 4. Fowler VG et al.  (2005). Staphylococcus aureus endocarditis: a consequence of medical progress. The Journal of the American Medical Association  293(24)  3012–3021.

Patient Demographics: The patient is a 63-year-old Caucasian male  retired  and currently residing in a suburban neighborhood. He is a non-smoker  drinks alcohol occasionally  and does not have a history of drug use. He has no known allergies. He is overweight with a BMI of 28.  Past Medical History: The patient has a significant past medical history. He suffered from a mild stroke 3 years ago and has also been managing atrial fibrillation (AF) for the last 5 years. The patient's AF is managed with regular anticoagulation therapy. Additionally  he has moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  managed with bronchodilators and occasional steroid therapy. The patient also has a history of dental infections having had two root canals in the last 10 years.  Key Complaints: The patient reports to the clinic with a two-week history of flu-like symptoms  the onset of which was gradual  and includes moderate to high-grade intermittent fevers  fatigue  and malaise. Recently  he has also been experiencing shortness of breath on slight exertion  unintentional weight loss  night sweats  and occasional chills. His family also noticed that his complexion seems slightly pallor. His primary care provider referred him to the hospital after noticing a new  low-grade murmur on his recent visit.  This case represents a demographic population prone to native-valve infective endocarditis: older adults with a history of previous heart problems. Endocarditis  in general  occurs more often in men than in women  with Caucasians more likely to be affected than other racial groups. While there are risk factors for endocarditis such as intravenous drug use  they won't be represented in this case so as to concentrate on the more common risk factors such as age  sex  previously damaged heart valves  and diseases causing a weakened immune system such as COPD.

Case Report  Patient Demographics  Patient Jonathan K  is a 60-year-old African American male residing in the suburban area of Washington  D.C. He has been working as a construction engineer for the past 35 years.   Past Medical History  Jonathan had been previously diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus; controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents. There is also a history of hypertension managed with ACE inhibitors. He has a 30-pack/year smoking history and binge drinks alcohol on weekends. No documented history of intravenous drug use. His family history is significant for coronary artery disease and hypertension.  Presenting Complaints  Jonathan visited his primary care provider after persistently running a low-grade fever for the past three weeks (100-101F)  with a sudden escalation to 103F in the last 48 hours. He describes the initial fever as unremarkable despite progressing to severe fatigue  unintentional weight loss  night sweats  and joint pain. After the recent high-grade fever episode  he experienced increasing shortness of breath at rest and chest discomfort resembling tightness.  Notes for Medical Educators  This case is structured to reflect characteristics found in literature for patients with native-valve infective endocarditis. The African American male representation is a departure from the historically Caucasian-centric representation  reflecting the increasing rates of this condition in African American populations in recent years. Risk factors such as intermediate age  occupation – suggesting potential exposure to infectious agents  and a history of diabetes  hypertension  smoking  and alcoholism have been integrated to enable teaching on the significance of comorbidities and health behaviors. Furthermore  a lack of intravenous drug use history keeps discussion focused on native-valve involvement. The case's unique set of symptoms ensure that trainees learn to suspect endocarditis even in patients who don't present classically.

Case Report: Native-valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Patient  Patient Details: Name: Mr. X Age: 70 years Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer  Past Medical History: 1. History of mild hypertension  for which he takes a daily low-dose of thiazide diuretic. 2. Past smoker  had quit smoking 15 years ago. 3. No history of diabetes  chronic kidney disease  or any other systemic disease. 4. No past surgeries or hospitalizations. 5. No known drug allergies. 6. Mild periodontal disease  poor oral hygiene.  Presenting Complaints: 1. Fever of 38.5 C present for the last two weeks. 2. Malaise and fatigue. 3. Weight loss of about 5 kgs in the past month. 4. Shortness of breath  particularly on exertion. 5. A new heart murmur noted.  Additional information: Mr. X lives alone and is fairly self-reliant. He reports difficulty in maintaining his dental hygiene due to poor manual dexterity. He has no known close contacts with infectious diseases and has not traveled recently.  Note: This patient represents a high-risk group (elderly  male  Caucasian) for native valve endocarditis  and has some common risk factors such as poor dental hygiene. Older age is a significant risk factor for infective endocarditis with the median age for presentation being around 60 years. Males are reported to be more affected than females. Native valve endocarditis most commonly affects the mitral valve  followed by the aortic valve. Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococci are the most common pathogens. This case has multiple opportunities for students to learn about the importance of detailed history taking  physical exams  and a comprehensive approach to diagnosis and management of endocarditis.

Patient Information: Mr. M  a 64-year-old retired African American male.  Past Medical History: Diabetes mellitus type 2 controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents  and a history of chronic untreated dental infections.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. M presents with a high-grade fever for the past week  accompanied by night sweats  and unexplained weight loss. He reports that he has been feeling fatigued  with diminished appetite. He also mentions experiencing shortness of breath with moderate exertion. No recent travel  drug misuse  or recent surgeries. Not a smoker but history of mild alcohol use.  Medical Examination: On examination  he is febrile with a temperature of 101.9°F (38.8°C)  blood pressure of 135/90 mmHg  pulse of 95 beats/min  respiratory rate of 18 breaths/min  and oxygen saturation of 93% on room air. Upon inspection  there is noticeable conjunctival pallor. He has Janeway lesions on his palms and soles  and Osler's nodes seen on his fingers. Cardiovascular examination reveals a new pansystolic murmur best heard at the cardiac apex. Dental examination reveals poor dental hygiene with multiple untreated carious teeth.  This case presents a common demographic victim of native-valve infective endocarditis as literature often connects this condition with males over 60  of African American descent  featuring pre-existing conditions of diabetes and poor oral health.

Case Report:  Demographics: Patient ""X"" is a 67-year-old African American male from a suburban neighborhood. He is a retired mechanic living with his wife. He is also a long-term tobacco smoker with a history of alcohol intake but quit both five years back.   Past Medical History: Patient ""X"" has a medical history of type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension  both managed with oral medications for the past 15 years. The patient was also diagnosed with a mild form of chronic kidney disease 3 years ago. He has no known allergies  no previous surgeries  and his family history is notable for coronary artery disease in his father.  Key complaints: Patient ""X"" presented at the emergency department complaining of a two-week history of general malaise  intermittent fever with night sweats  and an unintentional weight loss of approximately 10 pounds over the past month. He reports recent onset of shortness of breath and occasional discomfort in his chest with exertion.   Accurate Demographic Representation as per Literature: This case reasonably represents a common demographic for native-valve infective endocarditis  which is most frequently seen in males over the age of 60. The patient’s African American ethnicity correlates with the disproportionate prevalence of hypertension  diabetes  and chronic kidney disease in this population  which also puts patient ""X"" at an increased risk of endocarditis. The patient's past history of tobacco smoking and alcohol usage further increases his susceptibility to this condition. Irrespective of ethnicity  adults with underlying chronic conditions  such as the ones stated  comprise a significant proportion of the patient population. Patient ""X's"" presentation aligns well with typical findings in infective endocarditis—fever  malaise  and weight loss  as well as the less common symptoms of night sweats and exertional chest discomfort.   This theoretical case representation helps medical students identify infective endocarditis's clinical symptoms  highlight risk factors  and understand the disease's demographics.

Title: Case Study on Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Information: Mr. M  a 59-year-old African American male  presented to the emergency department (ED).  Medical History: The patient has a significant medical history of illicit intravenous drug use (IVDU)  controlled Type II diabetes  and hypertension for which he is under medication. He does not have any history of cardiovascular disease  surgery  or dental procedures.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. M came to the ED with complaints of consistent  severe headache associated with high-grade fever for the past three weeks. Alongside this  he reported experiencing night sweats  loss of appetite leading to significant weight loss  and malaise. He also mentioned experiencing occasional shortness of breath  especially when lying flat  and a mild  intermittent dull aching chest pain.  Case Report: Research identifies men  specifically African American men between ages 50-70  as higher at risk for infective endocarditis  coupled with a history of IVDU and poor dental hygiene. Mr. M fits into these characteristic risk factors  making this case an illustrative model for the typical demographic affected by this disease.  This case can be used to train students to recognize the serious and subtle signs of native-valve infective endocarditis and understand the importance of obtaining detailed medical history in every patient to evaluate their risk factors.  [From here  educators can guide students through specific investigations such as blood cultures  echocardiogram  and treatment regimens like antibiotics  thus exploring the diagnostic and therapeutic aspects of managing infective endocarditis.]

Case Report:  Patient Information:  Mr. E  a 65-year-old Caucasian male of intermediate socioeconomic status  presents to the hospital. He lives in a rural area and has limited access to health care facilities.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension. He has been managed outpatient with metformin 500mg twice daily  and losartan 50mg once daily. Despite his regular treatments  his control of both hypertension and diabetes is sub-optimal. He denies any history of intravenous drug use  alcohol abuse  or previous heart surgery. His family history reveals that his father had coronary artery disease and his younger sister suffers from type 1 diabetes.  Present Complaints:  Mr. E has been experiencing persistent low-grade fever and chills for the past two weeks. He also complains of generalized weakness  loss of appetite  night sweats  and unintentional weight loss. He reports a recent decline in exercise tolerance due to episodes of shortness of breath and noticed that his ankles are swelling. Lastly  he states intermittent bouts of dizziness and heart palpitations.  The goal is to train students to arrive at a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis  based on presenting complaints and risk factors belied by history. It's important to emphasize the role of diabetes in enabling infections due to its impact on immune function. Make students aware of common signs and symptoms of infective endocarditis while keeping in mind that this disorder can present differently in every patient.  Demographic data is representative regarding more common occurrence of native-valve infective endocarditis in aging male patients. This case takes into account the data on patients with preceding conditions like diabetes  hypertension  which are found more often in endocarditis patients  providing an accurate context for the training case.

Patient Information:  Name: ""Mr. Richard"" Age: 65 years old Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Engineer  Medical History: Mr. Richard has a history of mild hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he takes medication regularly. He does not smoke or consume alcohol. Fourteen months ago he was treated for a mild dental infection.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Richard presents to the emergency department with three weeks of intermittent fevers  night sweats  fatigue  and recent onset confusion. He has also noticed a decreased appetite and unintentional weight loss over the last month. His family members have noted that he has had been increasingly short of breath over the past week.  These complaints  along with his previous dental infection  could point towards a potential diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. Being a Caucasian male above 60 years  with comorbid cardiovascular risks (hypertension and hyperlipidemia)  he fits within the typical demographic profile for infective endocarditis as per recent medical literature.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  A 62-year-old African-American male.  Past Medical History:  The patient has an established history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and heroin misuse.  Presenting Complaints:  The patient presents with a two-week history of persistent fever  chills  excessive fatigue  weight loss  and occasional shortness of breath. The patient additionally mentions experiencing a constant dull backache and occasional night sweats.  Background Information: Infective endocarditis is an infection of the inner lining of the heart and its structures  commonly the heart valves. Previously  rheumatic heart disease was a common predisposing condition; however  in developed countries  its prevalence has decreased. Nowadays  patients with pre-existing structural heart disease and intravenous drug users are more likely to acquire this condition. It is slightly more prevalent among African-American  male  and patients aged 60 and above. The patient's demographic information and history of drug misuse make him susceptible to this condition.

Case Report  Patient Demographics:  A 60-year-old African American male  works as a truck driver  overweight (BMI: 30)  smoker (15 cigarettes/day)  married  living in an urban neighborhood.  Past Medical History: This patient has a history of intravenous drug use during his early adulthood but has been clean for over 25 years. He has a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 10 years which is poorly controlled (HbA1C: 8.5) due to poor medication adherence. Moreover  he was also diagnosed with hypertension and stage 3 chronic kidney disease two years ago. He has no known allergies.  Key Complaints: The patient presents to the emergency department complaining of a 4-week history of fatigue  low-grade fevers (usually above 100.4°F)  weight loss (approximately 10 pounds)  and night sweats. Over the past two weeks  he has noticed swelling in his legs and shortness of breath  particularly when climbing stairs. In the last 3 days  he has developed a new onset of a persistent and migratory joint pain that started in the knees and moved to the wrists. He has also noticed dark red spots on the palms of his hands and soles of his feet which are painless.  The presenting complaints are in keeping with the classical triad of infective endocarditis; fever  heart murmur (due to valvular insufficiency) and peripheral phenomena ( e.g.  cutaneous findings such as Janeway lesions).  Note: The choice of a 60 year-old African American male patient  with the given comorbidities and socioeconomic background  provides an accurate representation as per literature on the most frequent demographic affected by infective endocarditis.

Patient Case:   Demographics:  Patient’s age: 65 years old  Gender: Male  Race: Caucasian  Residence: Urban  Occupation: Retired   Medical History:  Diabetes Mellitus type 2  hypertension  moderate alcohol use  history of intravenous drug use  Presentation:  The patient presents to the emergency department with a two-month history of intermittent fever and chills  loss of weight and generalized fatigue. Over the past week  he has noticed shortness of breath on exertion. He also reports night sweats  decreased appetite and a rash on his legs which his wife noticed.  The choice of a 65-year-old male patient with a history of intravenous drug use takes into account epidemiological studies which suggest that infective endocarditis (IE) is increasing in incidence among older adults. Additionally  intravenous drug use is a recognized risk factor for IE  particularly among males.  In this case  the patient’s complaints align with the classical symptoms of native-valve infective endocarditis  including fever  the presence of a rash (potentially Osler's nodes or Janeway lesions) and symptoms related to cardiac decompensation (shortness of breath).  NB: IE is associated with significant morbidity and mortality  particularly without early diagnosis and treatment. Thus  this case is designed to highlight the importance of recognizing critical but often subtle signs of this condition. Further discussion of this case should focus on key investigations that can confirm IE (like blood cultures and echocardiography)  different etiologies (including different causative organisms) and appropriate management strategies  potentially including surgical intervention.   Recognizing the risk factors  presentation and management of IE is important for reducing complications associated with the infection. This case should enable students to focus on history taking  differential diagnoses  investigations  and management of infective endocarditis.

Patient Information:  - Name: Mr. John Doe - Age: 55 years old - Ethnicity: Caucasian  - Occupation: Farmer  Past Medical History: - Recurrent Dental Infections - Regular Intravenous Drug Use - Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus - History of Heavy Alcohol Consumption  Presenting Complaints: - Reported 3-4 weeks of ongoing fatigue - New onset shortness of breath  particularly on exertion  - Fever  - Night sweats - Rapid weight loss - Muscular pain and joint pain  Physical Examination Findings - Low-grade fever  - Paleness  - Possible signs of peripheral embolization including Osler nodes (painful nodes on the fingers and toes) and Janeway lesions (red or purple spots on the palms or soles) - Murmurs detected on cardiac auscultation  This training case is fictional but is representative and intended for educational purposes. While infective endocarditis can occur at any age and in any demographic  this case uses a commonly represented patient: middle-aged  male  with significant risk factors including dental infections and intravenous drug use. Heavy alcohol use and diabetes are not unusual in this demographic  and they contribute to overall health vulnerability. Regular updates and consults with prevalent literature may be needed for the most accurate demographic representation.

Patient Information: Mr. Miguel Rodriguez  60-year-old Hispanic male  born and raised in Texas  a retired construction worker living with his wife.  Past Medical History: Mr. Rodriguez was diagnosed with type II diabetes 5 years ago and has been managing it with diet and oral medication. He has a known history of illicit drug use (heroine)  which he quit 15 years ago but has ongoing impairment of the heart valve from that period. Although he quit  he has had numerous courses of treatment for skin abscesses due to complications from when he was using drugs. The patient is also hypertensive and occasionally experiences angina symptoms  but has no other systemic illnesses. Family history reveals a father deceased from myocardial infarction  and a mother with type II diabetes.  Presenting Complaints:  1. Mr. Rodriguez presents with a three-week history of intermittent fever  extreme fatigue and noticeable weight loss.  2. He also complains of heart palpitations and occasional chest pain. 3. His wife has noticed that his complexion has become pale and faintly bluish  especially around the mouth. 4. She also reports that he's been experiencing night sweats frequently. 5. He admits to the shortness of breath even during resting and especially with activities he could previously perform without trouble  such as climbing few stairs and household chores.  This case focuses on a common demographic who is at high risk for native valve endocarditis. A history of intravenous drug use  combined with the presence of type II diabetes and hypertension  increases Mr. Rodriguez's risk. It is  therefore  highly important for medical students to understand the role of these risk factors in the presentation and progression of infective endocarditis.   In the case report  the students need to identify the indicative symptoms of endocarditis such as intermittent fever and fatigue  night sweats  weight loss  shortness of breath  heart palpitations  chest pain and symptoms of heart failure  which may result from damage to the heart valves.  Taking this case forward  students should formulate a relevant plan  including further investigations and management in accordance with the current guidelines for endocarditis. The importance of considering valve replacement surgery for patients with severe and continuous symptoms  despite antibiotic therapy  should also be stressed.

Patient Case Report: Native Valve Infective Endocarditis   Patient Information:  A 48-year-old Caucasian male  Occupation: Works as a janitor in a local school  Past Medical History:  The patient is a known case of moderate-severity Rheumatic Heart Disease  diagnosed about six years ago  with a recurrent history of Strep throat infections during his childhood. He occasionally takes over-the-counter NSAIDs for joint pain that he attributes to his working conditions. He is a non-smoker and refrains from alcohol consumption. No known drug allergies or history of recreational drug use are reported.   Presenting Complaints: The patient presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of high-grade  intermittent fever for the past three weeks that is unresponsive to common antipyretics. He also reports experiencing night sweats and unintentional weight loss during the same period.   In addition  he mentions experiencing difficulty in breathing  especially on exertion  accompanied by palpitations. Upon further questioning  he also admits to noticing small  painless  red-blue spots (petechiae) on his palms and soles  not associated with itching or any other discomfort.  Review of Systems (ROS) discloses loss of appetite  light-headedness  and extreme fatigue. No other systemic complaints have been reported.  The patient's demographic representation with a common predisposing condition (Rheumatic Heart Disease)  occupations that expose to infection  and significant key complaints suggest the possibility of Native Valve Infective Endocarditis. However  further evaluations  including physical examination and necessary diagnostic tests  should be carried out to confirm the diagnosis and decide on the subsequent course of treatment.

Case Report:  Patient Information:  Mr. Alvarez  a 57-year-old Hispanic male.  Demographics:  Mr. Alvarez lives in Colorado  USA  and works as a long-haul truck driver.   Past Medical History: In terms of medical history  Mr. Alvarez is a known Type 2 Diabetic. He has been smoking two packs of cigarettes per day for the last 25 years but no history of alcohol or illicit drug use. The patient also has a dental history of chronic periodontitis and has lost several teeth  opting for partial dentures. He had his last dental treatment 8 months ago.  Chief Complaints: Mr. Alvarez presented to the outpatient department with a fever of 102°F that started 3 weeks ago. He reports intermittent low-grade fever thereafter  and associated chills  malaise  and weight loss. He also mentions being more short of breath than usual in the past month  experienced fatigue  and palpitations. He reports seeing some reddish spots on his skin. He also reveals noticing a vaguely described discomfort in his upper abdomen and complains of loss of appetite.  The case focuses on these symptoms  which are indicative of infective endocarditis in context with his background of poor dental hygiene and diabetes  predisposing Mr. Alvarez to a higher risk. It is important to remind medical students of the connection between oral health and conditions such as infective endocarditis. Remembering that presentation may differ widely  symptoms such as persistent fever unresponsive to regular antibiotics  embolic phenomenon  and immunological phenomena should lead students to consider endocarditis in their differential diagnosis.   Case reports like these are essential tools for teaching and reinforcing the understanding of disease presentation  clinical reasoning  and management strategies.

Case Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Patient History:   Mr. Jeff Bowman is a 62-year-old African American male who presents to the emergency department with complaints consistent with a three-week history of low-grade fever  loss of appetite  weight loss of 5% over the last month  fatigue  and a new heart murmur.  Mr. Bowman is a retired chemical engineer from Birmingham  Alabama. He is a former smoker  quitting some 15 years earlier. He has a past medical history of hypertension  managed with Lisinopril 10 mg  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  controlled with Metformin 1000 mg twice daily. There is no known history of intravenous drug use  recent dental procedures  or any invasive procedure. He does not have any known allergies and is up-to-date with his vaccinations.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Bowman has been feeling unwell for the past three weeks. He has mentioned intermittent low-grade fever  unexplained fatigue  a loss of appetite  and unintentional weight loss. His wife also noticed that his breathing has been faster than usual  especially at night. Recently  he has been complaining of discomfort in his chest. In the last few days  the discomfort has turned into chest pain that does not radiate and is more noticeable when he is lying down.   Physical Examination:   On physical examination  his vital signs are: blood pressure 135/85 mmHg  heart rate 98 beats per minute  respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute  temperature 100.2°F (37.9°C)  and oxygen saturation 94% on room air. His BMI is 29. He appears chronically ill. The cardiac exam reveals a new early diastolic murmur best heard at the left upper sternal border  and some peripheral stigmata of endocarditis are present. He looks pale and in visible pain due to the chest discomfort.   This case of endocarditis has been developed considering the epidemiologic data. Native valve infective endocarditis mainly occurs in men (male to female ratio approximately 2:1)  people more than 60 years old  and those with prior cardiac conditions. African-Americans have a slightly higher risk for endocarditis  particularly men aged over 60. The gradual onset of symptoms  like fever and weight loss  and examination findings  like a new murmur and signs of vasculitis  align with the insidious nature of this disease. The case focuses on native-valve infective endocarditis as this is more common and presents a characteristic clinical scenario that would assist in teaching undergraduates.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Profile: Name: Mr. Garcia Age: 60 years old Sex: Male Ethnicity: Hispanic  Occupation: Janitor  Past Medical History: Mr. Garcia has a history of intravenous drug use  an important risk factor for native-valve infective endocarditis. He is in recovery and has been sober for the last ten years with no history of relapse. He is diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and hypertension. The patient had an episode of Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia 4 years back  treated with antibiotics not leading to any significant complications. He was not on any sanitary prophylaxis and has no known allergies. He has a history of smoking but quit 2 years ago.  Presenting Complaints: Over the last three weeks  Mr. Garcia presented with intermittent fever with chills  night sweats  and an unintended weight loss of nearly 6kgs. Recently  he noticed petechial rashes on his torso and legs. He has also been experiencing shortness of breath on exertion which was previously not there. A mild and continuous headache has been concerning him over a week.  Note: This case presents a patient in the key demographic for native-valve infective endocarditis. Risk factors include his history of drug use  age  male sex  and pre-existing conditions like diabetes and hypertension. The case also highlights classical systemic  pulmonary  and neurological symptoms along with characteristic skin signs.

Case Report:  Patient Information:  Mr. Thomas is a 60-year-old Caucasian male  working as a construction supervisor  living in a suburban setting. He is not a smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. He has no known drug allergies.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Thomas has a past medical history of rheumatic fever in his early teens  with no recurrences. He has mild hypertension  managed with lifestyle modifications and is diet-controlled type-2 diabetes mellitus. He has no family history of cardiovascular disease. He does not partake in any recreational drug use.   Presenting Complaint:  The patient has presented with a 3-week history of malaise  intermittent fever  loss of appetite  and unexplained weight loss. More recently  he has been experiencing dyspnea on exertion and a new onset of a heart murmur that is not previously documented in his medical records.  Given the patient's previous history of rheumatic fever with no evidence of current pharyngeal infection  and new findings such as unexplained fevers  malaise  weight loss  this situation raises a high clinical suspicion for infective endocarditis. Furthermore  signs like new-onset heart murmur and dyspnea on exertion represent possible valvular involvement signifying a native-valve infective endocarditis. Antibiotic misuse or poor antibiotic adherence could be a potential risk factor  which needs to be explored.   This case will provide the students an opportunity to discuss history taking  examination findings  differential diagnosis  investigations  complications  and management regarding native-valve infective endocarditis.   Patients like Mr. Thomas are appropriate for a case on native-valve infective endocarditis considering the fact that men  especially those over 50  and Caucasians are at a heightened risk for this condition.

Patient Case:  Mr. Alfredo Cruz  a 56-year-old Hispanic male  presents to the emergency department accompanied by his wife  who reports that he has been lethargic and had worsening shortness of breath for the past two weeks. He has also been experiencing unexplained weight loss and night sweats. Mr. Cruz works as a laborer and primarily speaks Spanish.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Cruz is known to have a history of intravenous drug use (heroin) in his 30s. There is a past history of Hepatitis C infection  for which he received treatment with the completion of therapy 6 years ago. He denies any medical intervention since then. He does not have any known heart disease  diabetes  hypertension  or hyperlipidemia.   Family History:  His family history is significant for his father who passed away because of congestive heart failure at the age of 65.  Key Complaints:  1. Lethargy  2. Shortness of breath 3. Unexplained weight loss 4. Night sweats  This case for medical students weaves in facts about native valve infective endocarditis  such as the association with IV drug use history in Hispanic males disproportionately affected. The key complaints listed may indicate endocarditis  bearing further investigation. The case allows students to explore the diagnosis pathway via physical exam  blood cultures  echocardiography and ultimately the management of such patient.  Teaching note: Native valve infective endocarditis often affects patients with regular heart valves but with predisposing conditions like IV drug use. The diagnosis can be complex due to the wide variety of clinical presentations. Early diagnosis and intervention are critical for improving the outcome. This clinical scenario will help students understand the significance of comprehensive history taking  thorough physical examination  and corralling these findings into a relevant differential diagnosis  leading to appropriate diagnostic tests and management. This case encourages discussions on health disparities and cultural sensitivities in healthcare.

Case Report - Native Valve Infective Endocarditis (NVE)  Demographics: Mr. Rodriguez  a 65-year-old Hispanic male retiree  presented himself at the emergency department. He resides in an urban environment with his wife  is a former construction worker  and is a non-smoker with a history of moderate alcohol consumption.  Past Medical History (PMH): The patient has a documented history of Type-II Diabetes Mellitus  under good control with diet and metformin. He also has been treated for hypertension for the past ten years. Mr. Rodriguez underwent a dental extraction 2 months back. He has no prior history of illicit drug use  congestive heart failure  or valvular heart disease. His family history is significant for coronary artery disease.  Chief Complaint (CC): Over the past 3 weeks  Mr. Rodriguez has been experiencing persistent fatigue  intermittent fever with night sweats  and unintended weight loss. He also mentioned a new onset of lower back pain for the past one week.  Please note: This case has been designed to reflect common demographic representation for native-valve infective endocarditis  given that this condition frequently impacts elderly males with some form of pre-existing heart condition or exposure to conditions that could potentially lead to bacteremia  such as dental procedures. Additionally  the prevalence of NVE in the Hispanic population is significant.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Information: John is a 43-year-old Caucasian male  a known intravenous drug user without consistent access to healthcare.  Past Medical History: John carries a diagnosis of chronic Hepatitis C from his drug abuse. He has experienced recurrent skin abscesses  but has no known allergies. John has never been hospitalized. He has intermittent access to substance abuse counseling and management for Hepatitis C but frequently misses appointments.  Chief Complaint:  Recently  John began experiencing constant fatigue  intermittent fever  chills  night sweats  and an unintentional weight loss. He reports worsening shortness of breath and tiring easily after minor activity.  Clinical Relevance: Intravenous drug use is a risk factor for infective endocarditis due to repeated introduction of bacteria into the bloodstream. Furthermore  these individuals often present with delayed or missed diagnoses due to inconsistent access to healthcare and the nonspecific symptoms of infective endocarditis. This scenario offers an opportunity to teach medical students about the epidemiology and varying presentations of infective endocarditis  and the need for a high degree of clinical suspicion in at-risk populations. It further underscores the notion of patient-centered care and the association between social determinants of health and patient outcomes.   Note: This case is representative of native-valve infective endocarditis  which is more common in intravenous drug users and may include symptoms such as fever  chills  fatigue  and weight loss. The patient's chronic Hepatitis C is representative of comorbid conditions that pose an additional risk toward endocarditis. The demographic used in this case accounts for the over-representation of Caucasian males among intravenous drug users  as identified in several research studies. The development of the case presents an opportunity to discuss the clinical presentation  management and complications of native valve infective endocarditis.

Patient Information:   Patient is a 63-year-old male of Hispanic ethnicity. He works in the construction industry and lives in urban conditions with his wife and two children.  Past Medical History:   The patient has a known history of bi-valvular heart disease with moderate stenosis in both mitral and aortic valves. He was diagnosed 5 years ago. He takes medication for hypertension and is in Phase II of congestive heart failure. He is a former smoker  having quit about 10 years ago  due to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He is not an IV drug user. He has no known allergies to medications.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient has come in complaining of fever associated with a cough and shortness of breath for the past two weeks. The fever is accompanied by night sweats and intermittent chills. His chronic cough has also worsened  with increased sputum production. The patient's family reports he seems more fatigued than usual and has experienced an unexplained weight loss of approximately 10 pounds over the past month. His wife also mentioned an change in his mental status recently  involving occasional periods of confusion. He has also reported some joint pain  and yesterday began to notice some small red spots on the palms of his hands.   Explanation:  The demographic information and presentation align with the literature's depiction of the usual population affected by native-valve infective endocarditis. It is often associated with underlying valvular heart disease and men have a higher incidence than women. Hispanic and non-Hispanic white populations have a similar incidence of infective endocarditis. Symptoms such as prolonged fever  cough  and weight loss  coupled with the patient's known history of valvular heart disease  should prompt concern for endocarditis as a differential diagnosis. The presence of Janeway lesions (small red spots on palms)  worsening of COPD symptoms  confusion  and fever are indicative of possible septic emboli.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Demographics:  Patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male  locally born and raised. He is a retired construction worker who resides with his wife in a suburban neighborhood. He is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago  with a 40 pack-year history  and reports occasional alcohol consumption. He denies any drug misuse.  Past Medical History:  Patient has a known history of diabetes mellitus type 2 and is on Metformin. He was diagnosed with moderate aortic stenosis 5 years ago  but he declined surgical intervention. He had an admission for pneumonia 1 year ago. His latest echocardiogram report (6 months ago) showed moderate aortic stenosis remained stable.   Presenting Complaints: The patient presented to the emergency department with a four-day history of fatigue  generalized weakness  and fevers up to 39.5°C. He reports intermittent  mild  dull  and non-radiating chest pain for the last week  without exertional symptoms. Further  he mentions unintentional weight loss (~5 Kg) within the past 2 months. His wife has also noticed that he is more confused recently.  This hypothetical case represents an older patient with known valvular disease and other comorbidities (as frequently seen in cases of infective endocarditis). His symptoms are consistent with potential infective endocarditis – fevers  malaise  chest discomfort  and possible new cognitive changes indicating potential septic emboli. This example takes into account the average demographic of these patients as per relevant literature - individuals who are older  male  and have pre-existing valvular disease or other risk factors relating to an infection.   The case encourages medical students to consider a holistic approach to patient's symptoms  correlates these to pathophysiology of potential diseases  and accentuates the significance of integrated care  right from the emergency department to tertiary cardio-care  for the management of complex conditions like infective endiocarditis.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: A 35-year-old Caucasian male  working as a construction worker  presenting to the emergency department. He is in a steady relationship  has two preschool-aged children  and is a non-smoker. He also has a history of sporadic intravenous drug use  in remission from his heavy use in his teens and early twenties.   Past Medical History: His prior health history significantly includes hepatitis C and a previous dental abscess that required extraction two years ago. There are no known allergies; however  the risks associated with drug use and poor dental hygiene are noted.  Key Complaints: For the past few weeks  the patient has been feeling generally unwell with intermittent fevers  significant weight loss  and a new-onset shortness of breath. He had presumed this was due to overworking and stress  but the symptoms progressively worsened. He also noticed an unusual lump in his left armpit. On the day of reporting  he experienced excruciating chest pain and hence  presented to the ER.  The character  severity  duration  variation  and radiation of the chest pain and associated symptoms should be explored. The construction industry has a well-documented high incidence of drug misuse  leading to potential infections from unsanitized needles. This patient's background allows the consideration of native-valve infective endocarditis  which has been empirically correlated with intravenous drug use. Additionally  dental procedures are known to release bacteria in the bloodstream  which could potentially reach the heart leading to infective endocarditis.  This realistic case blend ensures ample representation of significant stressors and demographic factors associated with this clinical pathology. The late presentation of the condition also mirrors real-world doctor-patient scenarios where non-medical factors may delay patient's care. Consequently  this highlights the importance of holistic patient management and considering patients' diverse backgrounds when crafting differential diagnoses  particularly when symptoms are inconsistent or non-specific.

Patient Report:  Patient Information:  A 52-year-old white male patient  known as Mr. Woods  working as a construction worker.  Past Medical History: Mr. Woods has a significant history of intravenous drug use  with sporadic periods of abstinence. He has been diagnosed with Hepatitis C five years prior due to his high-risk behavior and has been monitored ever since without the need for antiviral treatment. He has a past instance of a right leg abscess from needle use  though no previous history of endocarditis or other heart disease. He has no known allergies.   Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Woods presents with a two-week history of increasing fatigue  malaise  and excessive night sweats. Over the past few days  he also reports experiencing shortness of breath  particularly on exertion. He mentions intermittent fevers at home. He has noticed occasional 'spots' on his skin  which are reddish-purple and have a slightly raised appearance. He denied any discomfort in the chest  pallor  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  or lower leg edema. He has not experienced any changes in weight  appetite  or bowel habits.   The chosen demographics reflect literature data  indicating Caucasian males  especially those with a history of intravenous drug use  are commonly affected by native-valve infective endocarditis (Lalani et al.  2018). The primary symptoms  including fatigue  malaise  night sweats  intermittent fever  dyspnea on exertion  and skin spots  are typical presentations of this disease (Sladden et al.  2019). Furthermore  the simultaneous presence of Hepatitis C provides an interesting background of co-morbidity  common in patients with high-risk behaviors  such as IV drug use. The lack of resistance to antibiotics adds another layer of complexity to the case that can fairly challenge medical students to think critically.   References: Lalani  T.  Chu  V. H.  Park  L. P.  Cecchi  E.  Corey  G. R.  Durante-Mangoni  E.  Fowler  V. G.  Jr.  Gordon  D.  Grossi  P.  Hannan  M.  Hoen  B.  Muñoz  P.  Rizk  H.  Kanj  S. S.  Selton-Suty  C.  Sexton  D. J.  Spelman  D.  Ravasio  V.  Tripodi  M. F.  Wang  A.; International Collaboration on Endocarditis–Prospective Cohort Study (ICE-PCS) Investigators. (2018). In-hospital and 1-year mortality in patients undergoing early surgery for prosthetic valve endocarditis. JAMA internal medicine  178(11)  1493–1500. https://doi.org/10.1001/jamainternmed.2018.4349  Sladden  R.  Thomson  S. J.  & Pollard  C. M. (2019). Palliative Management in End-Stage Infective Endocarditis: Case Report and Review of the Literature. Journal of Palliative Medicine  22(5)  565–569. https://doi.org/10.1089/jpm.2018.0468

Patient Information:  Patient's Name: Patient X (to maintain confidentiality) Gender: Male Age: 45 Race: Caucasian Occupation: Factory Worker Living environment: Urban  Past Medical History:  Patient X has a documented history of intravenous drug use spanning over two decades and sporadic / inadequate treatment for this addiction. Patient also has a history of smoking and untreated Hepatitis C infection.  Chief Complaint:  Patient X presents with a 2-week history of severe and worsening malaise  intermittent fevers  chills and night sweats. He has also experienced weight loss of approximately 5 kilograms over the last month  which was unintentional. Patient denies any trauma  recent travel  or known sick contacts. He has no history of heart disease or any other chronic illnesses apart from Hepatitis C.  The scenario assumes a relatively common demographic for native-valve infective endocarditis; an adult male with a history of intravenous drug use. Infective endocarditis is indeed often associated with these factors in the developed world  and it is quite important to educate medical students about the diverse social determinants of health  and to challenge any potential biases they may have.   In this case  although Hepatitis C does not directly result in endocarditis  it helps paint a realistic picture of a patient with multiple ongoing health and social issues  and encourages a holistic approach to healthcare provision. Additionally  emphasis should be placed on the patient's occupational setting as a factory worker  as this socio-economic context could potentially impact the availability and access to healthcare services.   Moreover  the symptoms described are classic for endocarditis  and should lead practitioners to look out for potential signs on examination such as Osler's nodes  Janeway Lesions  and Roth spots in the eyes. It would also prompt important follow-up investigations such as blood cultures  echocardiogram and potentially treatment with intravenous antibiotics.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Information:   Mr. Jones  a 62-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic  Past Medical History:  Mr. Jones has a medical history of type II diabetes mellitus  which is managed through diet and oral hypoglycemic medication  and mild hypertension controlled through lifestyle interventions. No previous surgeries have been reported. He is a former smoker  having quit around 10 years ago  and denies any history of illicit drug use.  Chief Complaint:  The patient presents with a three-week history of intermittent fever  excessive fatigue  and weight loss. He also reports experiencing diaphoresis (excessive sweating) during sleep. Furthermore  he complains of a new  mild heart murmur that he felt over the last week. His wife  who accompanied him  expressed concern over his recent onset of nocturnal delirium  which never occurred in the past.  These symptoms have prompted the need for further investigation to rule out the possibility of native-valve infective endocarditis. As infective endocarditis incidence is higher in males and typically presents in their sixth decade  Mr. Jones' demographics and symptoms are consistent with a real-world case example.  NB: The design of this case was focused on representing a typical patient who might develop native-valve infective endocarditis  according to literature. Variations may certainly occur in real-world clinical situations depending on multifarious factors such as patient's unique medical history  environmental exposure  and genetic background.

Patient Information: The patient is a 56-year-old Irish male named Mr. Murphy who works on a dairy farm.   Past Medical History: Mr. Murphy has a history of rheumatic heart disease from childhood for which he has been on long-term antibiotics prophylaxis. He also has moderate hypertension  for which he takes Lisinopril  and is a smoker with about a 20-pack year history. He is not a drinker and does not use any illicit drugs. He has not undergone any recent dental procedures. His family history includes cardiac disease and diabetes.   Presenting Complaints: For the past 2 weeks  Mr. Murphy has been experiencing intermittent fevers that usually occur at night. He has also been feeling generally unwell and fatigued  which he initially attributed to overwork. In the last few days  he's noticed that his breathlessness has significantly increased  especially while tending to his farm. He has lost his appetite and has lost about 2 kilograms of weight in the past two weeks. He has noticed small red spots on his skin. He denies any chest pain  palpitations  cough  or changes in bowel or bladder habits.  Relevance: According to literature  patients with a history of rheumatic heart disease and chronic antibiotic use  and who are involved in animal farming  are at a high risk of developing native valve infective endocarditis. In Europe  infective endocarditis is most commonly seen in males  and its incidence increases with age  especially in patients who have underlying heart diseases like rheumatic heart disease. Given this  it’s important for medical students to fully understand this demographic patient representation in order to manage and treat accordingly. The above-narrated case thus very well integrates such a real-life scenario.   Students must be trained to approach the diagnosis and management of endocarditis in patients with past rheumatic heart disease  considering that their pre-existing valvular damage increases their susceptibility to infections. Symptoms like fevers  fatigue  weight loss  breathlessness  little red spots on the skin (petechiae) and being generally unwell are some of the key signs that should raise clinician suspicion for infective endocarditis in such patients. Timely recognition and initiation of appropriate management are crucial as infective endocarditis can rapidly progress to a critical condition if left untreated.

Patient Profile: Age: 55 years Gender: Male Race: African American  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. X has visited the emergency department with complaints of persistent high-grade fever  accompanied by chills and night sweats. He is also experiencing weight loss  fatigue and intermittent shortness of breath on exertion. He has noticed some small  painless  red spots on his palms and soles.  Past Medical History: Mr. X has had a history of Intravenous (IV) drug use in the past  but he claims to have been clean for the past five years. His past medical history also includes Hepatitis C and intermittent periods of homelessness. He is a smoker and has a pack-a-day habit for the past 30 years.  Clinical consideration: Given his history of IV drug use and his current symptoms  one of the considerations would be infective endocarditis. His age  ethnicity and male gender  all are key demographic factors. African-Americans and men have been demonstrated to have higher prevalence  with increasing incidence noted in the fifth and sixth decade of life. IV drug use remains one of the major risk factors.  This short report provides a broad starting point for more detailed case development with a targeted depicter of native-valve infective endocarditis  particularly in connection with elevated risk due to the past IV drug use. The case challenges the learners to consider societal and lifestyle factors  time to recovery from previous substance issues  systemic symptoms and common complications of this important condition.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  Mr. R.B  a 60-year-old Caucasian male smoker from a rural setting who works as a farmer.  Past Medical History: The patient has a previous medical history of rheumatic heart disease from his adolescent years.
