He never adhered to a regular follow-up routine due to non-availability of medical facilities in his vicinity.  Clinical Presentation: The patient has been feeling generally unwell for the past few weeks. His primary complaints include an unrelenting fever for 3 weeks  a 10 lbs weight loss over a period of 1 month  fatigue  night sweats  and a decrease in appetite. Recently  he developed dyspnea on exertion and has noticed his shoes have become tight due to ankle swelling. He has no prior history of illicit IV drug use.  Physical exam: Physical exam findings include pallor  poor dentition  a heart murmur best heard at the cardiac apex  signs of congestive heart failure  and small hemorrhages under his fingernails.  These basics can set up a case study to discuss native-valve infective endocarditis  specifically focusing on causative agents (probably Streptococcus viridans due to poor dentition)  related diagnostic procedures (including blood cultures  echocardiograms  Duke’s criteria)  potential complications  and therapeutic approaches.   This case profile represents a common demographic for the incidence of this condition. Often it occurs among elderly patients who have a history of valvular heart disease. Non-compliance with medical follow-up due to difficulty accessing care is a more common problem among rural populations  increasing the risk of not identifying health problems in a timely manner. Although rheumatic heart disease is less common in developed countries  it remains problematic in certain high-risk groups  making this case relevant.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: A 63-year-old African American male.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of intravenous drug abuse (IVDA) which ended five years ago  Diabetes mellitus type 2 managed with metformin  and is frequently admitted to the hospital for recurrent pneumonia.   Chief Complaints:  The patient presents to the emergency department with a one-week history of intermittent fever of unknown origin  chills  and malaise. More acute symptoms developed over the last two days  including confusion  night sweats  shortness of breath  and a new-onset rash resulting in scar-like erosions on his hands and feet.   Background:  In the context of the past medical history and high-risk behavior  the symptoms presented by the subject in our case simulate a possible case of infective endocarditis (IE). Native-valve IE is more common among older adults  men  and is often complicated by drug abuse  poor dental hygiene  and uncontrolled diabetes mellitus. African Americans  partly due to disparities in healthcare  exhibit higher rates of IE. Hence  the demographic representation in this case scenario is based on accurate epidemiologic data.  This brief case introduces students to the clauses of infectious diseases  namely infective endocarditis. The goal of this training is to help them understand the risk factors  clinical presentation  and underlying pathophysiology of IE  with an emphasis on the importance of comprehensive communication and clinical expertise in patient care.   Note: This case report is open-ended  providing room for students to deduce the relevant investigations necessary  possible findings  management  and prevention methods. Through understanding this case  students should be able to recognize infective endocarditis  understand its pathophysiology  and propose appropriate management strategies.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Profile: Gender: Male Age: 60 years Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Unemployed Location: Urban area  Chief Complaints: 1. Recurrent intermittent fever for last two weeks. 2. Fatigue and overall weakness. 3. 2-3 episodes of nocturnal shortness of breath. 4. Noticed reddish spots in skin - mainly on his hands and feet.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of intravenous drug use in his 40s  but no recent history of drug use. He was diagnosed with Hepatitis C 15 years ago and received treatment. However  a recent health check showed elevated liver enzymes indicating possible chronic liver disease. He also has been diagnosed with hypertension and type-2 diabetes mellitus  for which he takes medication regularly.  Family History: Father died of heart attack at the age of 70. Mother is hypertensive and diabetic.  Physical Examination: On examination  patient has a fever of 101°F. He appears pale. Cardiac auscultation reveals a new regurgitant murmur. Skin examination shows scattered petechiae predominately in his extremities and the presence of Osler's nodes on his hands and feet.   Smoking/Alcohol history: Patient is a former smoker and quit 10 years ago. He consumes alcohol occasionally.  Summary: This case represents a 60-year-old male with a past history of intravenous drug use  Hepatitis C  hypertension  and type-II diabetes  now presenting with indicative signs and symptoms of infective endocarditis. The combination of fever  cardiac murmur  petechiae  and Osler's nodes in conjunction with the patient's medical past is strongly suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis. This case would necessitate critical thinking from medical students about how to approach diagnosis and management considering comorbid conditions.

Case Scenario: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Demographics: Gender: Male Age: 60 years old Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired manual laborer Address: Lives in a suburban community Smoking Status: Current smoker Alcohol Consumption: Light drinker Illicit Drug Use: None  Past Medical History:  1) Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus - under treatment with Metformin 2) Rheumatic Fever in his teens 3) Surgery for appendicitis 20 years ago 4) Multiple dental procedures in the past year  Key complaints: The patient presents with a 3-week history of a persistent  low-grade fever  sweating  and generalized body weakness. He also mentioned unintentional weight loss and reduced appetite. He stated that he has been feeling fatigued  which has ultimately led to a decrease in physical activity. He complains of occasional night sweats and a newfound disdain for cold weather as he feels it more intensely. In the recent week  he has also noticed a change in urine color  turning dark yellow.  All these symptoms have led him to seek medical attention. Despite no history of illicit drug use or recent invasive procedures  his history of recent multiple dental procedures  rheumatic fever in his past medical history  the presence of a chronic disease (Diabetes mellitus)  and his current complaints warrants a strong suspicion towards infective endocarditis on native valves.  The course of the case will then be designed to make medical students consider  diagnose  and manage patients with potential native-valve infective endocarditis. Key learning objectives will encompass understanding the epidemiology of this infection  interpreting present clinical signs and symptoms alongside appropriate diagnostic approach  and formulating an efficient treatment plan based on the infecting pathogen and individual health factors.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Information:  Mr. J. Martinez  a 63-year-old Hispanic male with a moderate-level socioeconomic status  presented to the emergency department of a large urban hospital.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Martinez has a past medical history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease stage III. He also has a 35-year history of smoking but quit eight years ago. There is no prior history of illicit drug use. His father had an early myocardial infarction  and his mother suffers from hypertension.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Martinez reported experiencing a high-grade intermittent fever associated with chills for the past two weeks  which was not alleviated by over-the-counter medications. The fever was occasionally accompanied by night sweats. Mr. Martinez also mentioned a loss of appetite and subsequent weight loss during this period. For the past two days  he had been feeling general weakness and shortness of breath upon minimal exertion. He did not report any chest pain  cough  hemoptysis  or orthopnea.   Reason for Inclusion:  Given the demographic representation and the patient's clinical presentation  this case provides clinical relevance for the teaching and understanding of native-valve infective endocarditis (IE). According to literature  IE occurs most frequently among males  with a male-to-female ratio of 1.6:1  and peaks in older patients who have pre-existing cardiac conditions. It is seen in ethnic minorities disproportionately due to barriers in accessing healthcare. Complications may arise in patients with coexisting diabetes mellitus and renal dysfunction. The persistence of symptoms despite symptomatic management  paired with the patient's medical history  raises the suspicion of a systemic infection like IE. The case  thus  emphasizes the importance of considering IE in differential diagnoses when treating elderly patients who present with persistent fevers and have previously known comorbid conditions.

Case Report:  Patient Information:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male  Chief Complaint: The patient has been experiencing persistent fever  fatigue  and unexplained weight loss over the course of a few weeks. Recently  he has developed mild shortness of breath.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of intravenous drug use in his late 20s to early 30s  but has been clean for almost three decades. Documented medical history includes hypertension  for which he takes medication  and he quit smoking 10 years ago. He does not have a history of heart disease  diabetes  or significant infections. He has no known allergies.  Family History: His father died of a sudden myocardial infarction in his 70s  and his mother is living and healthy in her late 80s. His younger sister is a breast cancer survivor. No history of heart disease is known in the immediate family members.  Present Illness: The patient has noticed a decline in his general health over the past few weeks. He has a fever that has not subsided and has also lost a considerable amount of weight without intending to do so. These symptoms have led to extreme fatigue. His symptoms have escalated recently with the onset of shortness of breath  especially upon exertion.  Summary: The case is an ideal representation of an elderly patient with a past history of drug use who presents with symptoms of infective endocarditis. The symptoms are nonspecific  except for the persistent fever  which is often a common clinical presentation of infective endocarditis. The patient's condition will provide an excellent learning opportunity for students to grasp the intricate disease process  its relationship with the patient's past drug history  the insidious and polymorphic nature of infective endocarditis  as well as the importance of early diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

Case Report:   Patient Information: Ms. C  a 52-year-old African-American female with a notable smoking habit.  Past Medical History: Hypertension and hyperlipidemia. No past surgical or relevant family history. Non-compliant with her prescribed hypertensive and lipid-lowering medication regimen.  Presenting Complaints: Presenting with a 2-week history of periodic fevers  chills  and unintentional weight loss of approximately 10 pounds. She has been feeling generally unwell  and also complains of night sweats and new onset of shortness of breath on exertion along with occasional palpitations.  Notably  she has not had recent dental work or procedures. She does not use illicit drugs. She has never been diagnosed with any heart conditions in the past.  Relevant Information: According to an overview by Selton-Suty et al.  2012  infective endocarditis most often presents in patients with predisposing cardiac conditions or those who engage in intravenous drug use. However  it is also seen in patients without these risk factors. Additionally  the presentation of infective endocarditis can be variable  but often includes nonspecific symptoms such as fatigue  weight loss  fevers  night sweats  and sometimes heart murmurs or embolic phenomena.  Reminder: Healthcare providers should remain vigilant for possible cases of infective endocarditis  especially among patients presenting with atypical symptoms and no identifiable risk factors.  This case could be used to highlight the importance of maintaining a broad differential  considering the possible diagnosis in many forms of presentation  and recognizing the life-threatening potential of this condition if left untreated.  References:  Selton-Suty  C.  Célard  M.  Le Moing  V.  Doco-Lecompte  T.  Chirouze  C.  Iung  B.  ... & Alla  F. (2012). Preeminence of Staphylococcus aureus in infective endocarditis: a 1-year population-based survey. Clinical Infectious Diseases  54(9)  1230-1239.

Patient Information:   Mr. Giovanni Ortiz  50-year-old Latino male  employed as a construction worker  residing in urban settlement.   Past Medical History:   Patient has a 10-year history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension  both well-controlled with Metformin and Lisinopril  respectively. He admits to being a previous intravenous drug user but has been clean for 15 years. Has no prior surgical history and no known drug allergies.  Chief Complaints:  The patient has presented with a two-week history of intermittent fever  fatigue  weight loss; a recent onset of discomfort in the chest  and dyspnea on exertion. He also complains of night sweats and a loss of appetite that has progressively worsened.  Note:  This case is designed to focus on native-valve infective endocarditis. It's important to note that Infective Endocarditis (IE) is a rare condition but can be lethal if not diagnosed or treated properly. It can occur in any age group but is more common in males than females. Risk factors include prior heart valve disease  intravenous drug use  poor oral hygiene  central venous catheters. The disease often presents non-specifically and involves multiple systems  requiring a high degree of clinical suspicion for diagnosis.   This case is built with a patient demographic typical and representative of the patients that the students are likely to encounter in clinical practice. The patient's history of heart disease makes him a high-risk candidate for Infective Endocarditis (IE). The chosen symptoms are indicative of typical IE presentation as per research  with the intention of guiding the learner to consider IE among differential diagnoses.   This case would prompt considerations such as:   1. The importance of thorough history taking  particularly regarding past medical history that may predispose the patient to endocarditis. 2. Prompt recognition of IE symptoms leading to timely diagnosis and management. 3. The appreciation of complex decision-making in the treatment of patients with IE. 4. The understanding of consequences of delayed or incorrect treatment.   This case  therefore  represents a real-world scenario for students to develop their clinical and decision-making skills. It provides a concrete starting point for discussion and evaluation of a common but challenging clinical problem.

Case Study: Native-valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Information: A 63-year-old African-American male  presenting to the emergency department (ED).  Past Medical History: Patient has a known history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension. He has been on oral hypoglycemics and anti-hypertensive medicines for past five years.  Chief Complaints: He came to the ED with the chief complaints of:  1) High-grade fever with chills for past 10 days.  2) Shortness of breath  getting progressively worse during the same period.  3) Mild  intermittent chest pain for past week.  Given the prominent prevalence of infective endocarditis among males aged 60 and above (according to literature)  along with their heightened risk due to comorbid conditions such as hypertension and diabetes  this case paints an accurate picture for a medical student learning about real world presentations of native-valve infective endocarditis. Utilizing this case  medical students can be taught to diagnose the disease based on symptoms  risk factors and later on  clinical tests and examination. Informing them about the greater prevalence among African American and male demographics further roots their understanding in real-world data and prepares them for practical scenarios.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Details: Name: Mr. Torres Age: 53 years old Sex: Male Race: Hispanic Occupation: Factory worker  Past Medical History:  Mr. Torres is a previous smoker  having quit 8 years ago. He has a known history of moderate rheumatic heart disease from childhood  with no surgical interventions. The patient has been managing type II diabetes mellitus for the last 5 years  largely through a combination of Metformin and lifestyle modifications. There is no known history of illicit drug use.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Torres presents to the clinic with a three-week history of generalized weakness  recent anorexia and unintended weight loss  and fevers with night sweats. He also mentions a new heart murmur noted by his primary care physician  associated with occasional shortness of breath on exertion  which is unusual for him. Mr. Torres also noticed petechiae on his lower limbs over the past week.   Significant findings:  On examination  he is febrile with a temperature of 38.4 degrees Celsius. He shows Osler’s nodes in his hands and Janeway lesions are spotted on his palms and soles. Cardiac exam reveals a new-onset grade III/VI diastolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border.   Diagnosis:  Mr. Torres's presentation  along with his history  strongly suggest a case of infective endocarditis on a native valve  likely a sequela of his rheumatic heart disease. His condition could be complicated due to his immunocompromised status as a result of diabetes mellitus.   Note: This case illustrates infective endocarditis in an adult male patient with multiple risk factors like rheumatic heart disease and diabetes. The patient belongs to an underrepresented Hispanic community and has a history of smoking. The combination of generalized systemic and specific clinical features contributes to the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis here. This case can be used to train medical students about early recognition and management of infective endocarditis. Instruction on the crucial role of dental hygiene  as well as consultation with dentistry  could be included as part of preventative measures  especially in those with pre-existing valvular disease.

Case Report  Patient Demographics:   Mr. Reynolds is a 60-year-old African American male  a retired construction worker  who hails from the urban area of Detroit  Michigan. He lives alone and is a widower with two adult children who stay separately.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Reynolds has a past medical history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  both diagnosed 5 years ago and is on a regimen of Metformin and Lisinopril. He quit smoking 2 years ago but admits to occasional alcohol consumption. He also reports a history of an untreated dental abscess 1 month ago.  Presenting Complaints:  He presents to the emergency department with a complaint of fever  fatigue  and shortness of breath for the past three weeks  which he initially presumed to be flu symptoms. Mr. Reynolds also reports an intermittent  low intensity  non-radiating chest pain for the past week. He denies any history of intravenous drug use.  Rationale for the demographics:  According to literature  infective endocarditis commonly affects males over age 50 with prevalence rates highest among African Americans  typically those with a history of cardiovascular disease risk factors such as diabetes  hypertension (JAMA Cardiology  2017). It is also associated with poor dental health due to a higher chance of Streptococcus viridans  one of the most common pathogens causing native-valve endocarditis  entering the bloodstream and colonizing the heart valves (Medscape  2019). Choosing Detroit as a location for this case takes into account the contribution of socioeconomic factors to health outcomes  given it is one of the poorest major cities in the United States with a large African American population.

Patient Introduction: Mr. Gomez  a 65-year-old Hispanic male.  Presenting Complaint: A 10-day history of malaise  intermittent fever  and unintended weight loss.  Past Medical History: Diagnosed with rheumatic heart disease in his thirties  history of intravenous drug use (sober for approximately 15 years)  and untreated dental caries. He is also known to have diabetes mellitus type 2 controlled via lifestyle modification over the past 8 years.  Demographical note: Infectious endocarditis (IE) is commonly seen in males  especially in the age group of 30-60 years old. However  in native valve IE  it is also seen in an elderly patient with a prior history of rheumatic heart disease and/or degenerative valve disease. Additionally  the incidence of IE is higher in the Hispanic population compared to others  making Mr. Gomez a real representation of the population suffering from this disease.  Case Progression: A physical examination reveals conjunctival pallor  splinter hemorrhages under the nails  Janeway lesions on palms and soles  and Osler's nodes on his fingers. Cardiac auscultation identifies a new murmur suggestive of mitral valve regurgitation.   Preliminary Diagnosis: The patient's history and examination are consistent with a suspected diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.   Further Tests: He is sent for blood culture  full blood count  erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)  chest x-ray  and an urgent Transthoracic Echocardiogram (TTE) to confirm the diagnosis and establish the severity.  This case scenario will guide the students to understand the common complaints  history  physical findings  demographics  and further management of patients suspected of having native-valve infective endocarditis. The student's goal is to synthesize a holistic approach to diagnose and manage the patient based on the information provided.

Patient Information:  The patient is a 54-year-old male of African American descent who is working as a construction worker. He is unmarried and lives alone in an urban neighborhood. He is a smoker and has a 15-year history of intravenous drug use with multiple previous rehabilitation attempts.  Chief Complaint:  The patient came to the emergency department (ED) complaining of shortness of breath and a high-grade intermittent fever for the last two weeks.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a medical history of untreated Hepatitis C infection and a remote history of Staphylococcus aureus skin infection. He also has a history of hypertension which is not regularly treated due to his sporadic commitment to regular clinic visits. He denies any history of diabetes  cardiac conditions  surgery or allergies.  Review of Systems:  The patient reports unintentional weight loss (approximately 10 pounds in the last month)  night sweats  chills  and a new-onset  non-pruritic reddish rash on his trunk and extremities. He also reports fatigue and persistent cough but no hemoptysis  chest pain  orthopnea  or any gastrointestinal or urinary symptoms. He denies recent contact with sick individuals or travel outside the country.  This case report covers an important and representative patient who might present with native-valve infective endocarditis  tying in statistical predisposition for high-risk groups such as intravenous drug users and certain ethnicities. References: (BMJ Quality and Safety  2021; American Heart Association  2020; Journal of the American College of Cardiology  2007)

Case Report:  Patient Information:  A 66-year-old Caucasian male  retired school teacher  residential address: Midwest  USA  Medical History:  The patient has a medical history of moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis  for which he is currently under chronic low-dose corticosteroids and methotrexate therapy for the last five years.  He has a 20-pack year history of smoking but quit ten years ago. He is also known to have an occasional alcohol intake.  Key Complaints:  The patient presented to the Emergency Department with complaints of mild intermittent fever for the past three weeks  progressive fatigue  and loss of appetite. Over the past one week  the patient also noticed the appearance of purplish spots on his skin and some pain in the soles of his feet. In addition  he noted an unexplained weight loss of around 6 Kg over the last month. There is no history of recent travel or sick contacts. He also denies any illicit drug use. His family mentioned that there is a change in his mood and a decrease in social activities.   This case represents a typical scenario of native-valve infective endocarditis  a condition generally occurring in males and commonly seen in older adults with a pre-existing heart condition or immune disorders. The patient characteristics and symptoms align with the demographic data found in medical literature  and the patient's history of corticosteroid and methotrexate use due to rheumatoid arthritis significantly increases his risk of developing an infection  such as endocarditis. Furthermore  his history of tobacco use and occasional alcohol intake can further weaken his immunity and cardiovascular health. The symptoms  including prolonged low-grade fever  fatigue  anorexia  weight loss  skin manifestations  and mood changes  are commonly observed in subacute infective endocarditis.

Case Report: Patient Demographics:  The patient is a 65-year-old caucasian male  employed as an engineer  who resides in an urban setting. He is a non-smoker  occasionally consumes alcohol  and has no known recreational drug history. He does not engage in regular physical activity  has a high-fat diet but is not obese (BMI=24).  Past Medical History:  Patient has a history of moderate Rheumatic Heart Disease (RHD) with mitral valve insufficiency. This has been managed with prophylactic antibiotics prior to dental procedures and regular follow-up with his primary care physician. Additionally  he has been diagnosed with hyperlipidemia which is kept under control by statin therapy. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 70.  Vital signs: Blood pressure 152/96mmHg  Pulse rate 98 bpm  Respiratory rate 16/min  Temperature 38.2 degrees Celsius (feverish)  Key Complaints:  The patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of a high-grade fever of 102.5 degrees Fahrenheit over the past week  which is associated with chills. He also reports weakness and shortness of breath upon mild exertion  along with an unexplained weight loss of 15 pounds over the last month. He also exhibits signs of night sweats and malaise. He noticed small red spots on his palms and soles that have made him concerned.  This case represents infective endocarditis in a patient with a history of rheumatic heart disease  which is one of the most common risk factors for this condition according to studies. The demographic details align with the literature suggesting that males over 60 are most commonly affected.  For didactic purposes  it is worth noting that this case can enlighten learners about the high suspicion of infective endocarditis in any patient with pre-existing valvular disease who arrives with prolonged fever  systemic symptoms and vasculitic appearance. This case emphasizes the urgency of early diagnosis and treatment to prevent devastating sequalae of this serious condition.

Patient Case: Native-valve Infective Endocarditis   Introduction: This case highlights the diagnostic process for identifying native-valve infective endocarditis  the implementation of the modified Duke criteria in diagnosis  the importance of early treatment  and long-term management.  Patient Information: A 60-year-old African American female presenting to the emergency room.  Past Medical History: 1. Diabetes Mellitus type II  diagnosed ten years ago  well controlled with Metformin. 2. Mild hypertension  controlled with medication.  Key Complaints: 1. Persistent  intermittent low-grade fever for the past two weeks. 2. Fatigue and unexplained weight loss over one month. 3. Recently developed a red  painless skin rash on her left hand.  Epidemiology Context: While infective endocarditis can affect individuals of any age and race  the prevalence increases with age  and it is slightly more common in males. Among races  the incidence is highest in African Americans. The patient's demographic data (age  gender  race) and medical history of diabetes and hypertension align with the literature.  Next Steps for Educators: Further discussion should focus on clinical examination  diagnostic findings (including laboratory and imaging tests)  the application of the modified Duke criteria for diagnosis  heart valve culture results  selection of antibiotic therapy  surgical intervention if required  and long-term patient management. This case should be utilized to emphasize the importance of suspecting infective endocarditis in patients with persistent fevers and vasculitis signs even in the absence of heart murmurs  especially those with predisposing conditions such as diabetes.

Case Study: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Information: Name: Mr. Peters Age: 63 years Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Engineer  Presenting Complaint: The patient presents with a 3-week history of fatigue  weight loss  night sweats  intermittent fever  and a new onset persistent cough.  Past Medical History: Mr. Peters has a history of mild hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both controlled with medication. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history but quit 10 years ago. He does not have any history of illicit drug use  and he has no known allergies. He had one dental extraction two months ago.  Demographic Representation:  In the literature  it is mentioned that native-valve infective endocarditis is most commonly seen in males above 60 years of age with some form of cardiac damage or lesion. However  it is important to note that the disease can affect individuals from any demographic  but considering the typical patients  the chosen demographic here represents a relatively common scenario.  Teaching Focus:  This case provides medical students an opportunity to understand how to diagnose and manage a patient suspected of having native-valve infective endocarditis  with an emphasis on clinical history  physical examination  and appropriate investigations like blood cultures and echocardiography. As dental procedures can often lead to transient bacteremia  causing endocarditis in people with risk factors  this case emphasizes the importance of preventative strategies  and conveys the critical relationship between oral health and systemic disease. Further  they learn to identify risk factors for endocarditis  such as the patient's past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  as well as long-term smoking history which might have contributed to cardiovascular disease  creating an environment for potential infection.

Patient Information:  55-year-old African American male who is a smoker with a 20 pack-year history.  Past Medical History:  - Diabetes Mellitus Type II - Hypertension  well-controlled with medication - History of intravenous drug use - No known drug allergies  Presenting Complaints:  - Four-day history of fever  night sweats - Shortness of breath on exertion - Generalized malaise and fatigue - Pain and swelling in right elbow - Recently noted a few small red spots on the skin (expected to be Janeway lesions)  The patient reports recent poor dental hygiene with a visit to the dentist six weeks ago which required intervention for an abscessed tooth. He denies any recent travel or exposure to sick contacts but admits to continued intravenous drug use.  Rationale:  This case was designed to mirror demographic trends identified in the literature  focusing specifically on native-valve infective endocarditis (IE)  a frequent and severe complication of bloodstream infections  which is often associated with poor dental hygiene  smoking  and more commonly observed in African American males.  In fact  published materials by Reller et al. (“Infective Endocarditis”) and Murdoch et al. (Clin Microbiol Rev. 2009) identified that IE disproportionately affects males and is associated with increasing age  making our 55-year-old male representative of a typical patient cohort. An additional significant risk factor is intravenous drug use  reflected in our patient's history.  The common symptoms of IE  such as fevers  night sweats  malaise  and shortness of breath on exertion  are included in the patient's complaints. The patient's right elbow pain and swelling could be pointing towards septic arthritis  a known complication of systemic infections such as IE.  The fever coinciding with the recent dental procedure points towards a possible entry point for the bacteria leading to IE  as poor dental hygiene is a common risk factor for this disease. Also  the small red spots may represent Janeway lesions  which are non-tender  small erythematous lesions found on the palms and soles  indicative of IE.   This patient's history and presentation amalgamate key risk factors and symptoms for native-valve infective endocarditis  presenting a comprehensive  evidence-based case for educational purposes.
